￼
18 Highlights from 2018
Dear friend,   I hope you had a wonderful holiday season with loved ones. While the current government shutdown does not demonstrate it, there were many successes - several bipartisan - in 2018. I disagree with the government shutdown because no one wins. I believe border security is very important and should have been handled months ago, which is why I urged a vote on a bill that provided immediate border funding for the wall and included a permanent solution for DACA recipients. Democrats and Republicans are going to need to work together to fix our broken immigration system. I hope our new Democratic leadership in the House will work quickly to find a compromise with the Senate and White House to reopen the government.   As 2018 comes to a close, I wanted to share a few highlights from the year. Although it may seem that Republicans and Democrats don't work together, much of what we accomplished this year was done on a bipartisan basis.   The 115th Congress was one of the most productive congresses in history and nearly 80% of all the bills passed were bipartisan. As we move into the 116th Congress next week, I hope the Democratic leadership will continue working across the aisle to deliver results to the American people.   2018 by the numbers -Nearly 7,000 letters sent -645 cases helping constituents get answers from the federal government -Over 3,000 meetings held  -391 tours arranged for constituents -34 open office hour sessions  Here are 18 of the top moments from 2018:    1. Fighting the Opioid Epidemic  
 
￼
Davis and USDA Assistant to the Secretary for Rural Development Anne Hazlett host an opioid roundtable with local elected officials, law enforcement, and other stakeholders. 
The opioid crisis is wreaking havoc on communities in my district and across the country and Congress took action. Earlier this year, President Trump signed comprehensive legislation to combat the epidemic from all angles.   This is the most significant congressional effort against a single drug crisis in history.  H.R. 6, the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act will help in our efforts to advance treatment and recovery initiatives, improve prevention, protect our communities, and fight illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl.   I’ve held numerous roundtables in the district asking first responders, law enforcement, and health care experts what they need from the federal government to help address this issue locally and this package contains many provisions that will address those issues.  Some of the highlights include:  -Expand access to treatment and recovery services, including establishing comprehensive opioid recovery centers -Improve data to identify and help at-risk patients and families -Give law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of our communities -Improve access to federal resources for local communities -Crack down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs  There is still much work to be done, but this legislation will go a long way in fighting against this epidemic.   2. Bigger paychecks, benefits, & job growth thanks to  tax reform 
 
The new tax code meant bigger paychecks, job growth, and more benefits for Americans. And this year was the last time you'll ever have to file on the old, complicated tax code. Next year, you'll get to file on a simpler tax code that allows you to keep more of your hard-earned paycheck.   In the 13th District, a family of four making the median income of $78,509 will see a tax cut of $1,691 and a median income household making $49,758 for a single filer will see a tax cut of $1,224. Here is how tax reform directly benefits middle-income Americans:   - Lower rates ensure individuals at every income level will see a tax cut.  - Doubles the standard deduction to $12,000/$24,000, which 75% of people in the 13th District currently take. - Doubles the Child Tax Credit to $2,000 with up to $1,400 refundable. - Retains popular deductions like mortgage interest (capped at $750,000 for new homes), state and local taxes (SALT) (capped at $10,000), medical expenses (expands to 10%), and charitable deductions.  Since the bill has been signed, more than 4 million workers have seen higher wages, bonuses, paid sick and family leave, and other investments. For a list of companies who have announced benefits to employees because of tax reform, click here.    3. The Logan S. Palmer Post Office in Harristown & a   stronger military 
 
￼
Davis with Petty Officer Logan Palmer's parents, Sid and Theresa Palmer. 
Legislation honoring the life and service of Petty Officer Logan Palmer was signed into law. It designates the post office in Harristown, Illinois, as the “Logan S. Palmer Post Office." Petty Officer Logan Palmer, of Harristown, Illinois, was among the sailors killed when the USS John S McCain collided with a tanker off the coast of Singapore last August.  Logan's parents, Sid and Theresa, joined me in DC to introduce this bill six months ago and I’m so glad we were able to get this bill honoring their son signed into law this year.  This building will serve as a grave reminder of risks our servicemembers take on each day.   Department of Defense policy had previously been that transportation to Dover Air Force Base would only be arranged and covered by the government if the servicemember died in a combat operation. Families of servicemembers who died in non-combat operations could have their costs covered, but only if a waiver was obtained first.   I worked with the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness to get this policy changed after the family of Petty Officer Logan Palmer, who was killed in the USS John S. McCain accident in Singapore, received outside funding to attend his arrival at Dover. The Department of Defense (DoD) announced it has changed its policy to automatically arrange and cover the travel costs for families of servicemembers killed in non-combat operations to meet the casket at Dover Air Force Base.  This Congress ended the nearly decade-long cuts to our military which led to increased accidents, like the one that cost Logan Palmer his life. By ending these cuts, we've started to rebuild our military and provided our troops with the largest pay increase in seven years.    4. Helping rural communities when  disaster strikes 
 
￼
Davis speaks on the House floor in support of his FEMA reform legislation. 
My legislation to reform the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) funding formula was signed into law. This change is long overdue and it is one I have fought tirelessly for since my first term in Congress. It requires FEMA to consider the localized impact of a disaster. This will help level the playing field for rural communities in largely populated states like Illinois. People in the 13th District pay into the Disaster Relief Fund and deserve help when needed just as it's been provided to communities in other states over the years.  The Disaster Declaration Improvement Act, requires FEMA to place greater consideration on the severe localized impact of damage following a disaster. In the past, FEMA has placed more focus a standard formula based on population and less on the amount of damage done to a community and its size.  Click here to watch my remarks on the bill.    5. Promoting civility and bipartisanship
 
￼
Davis and Panetta talk to high school students about bipartisanship and civility in politics. 
Bipartisanship and civility in politics are what make our government great. We can have differences in policy and ideas, but we can put our disagreements aside and come up with a good solution that moves us forward. Rep. Jimmy Panetta and I come from different states and different political parties, but we are friends and work together to do our jobs. I am glad he was able to visit three high schools in my district and help show our next generation there is more bipartisanship in Washington than people might think. 
 
￼
Davis, Mullin, Kennedy, and Blunt Rochester participate in bipartisan panel at Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the U.S. Senate. 
I joined U.S. Reps. Joe Kennedy III (D-Mass.), Markwayne Mullin (R-Okla.), and Lisa Blunt Rochester (D-Del.) on a panel at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the U.S. Senate about fostering civic dialogue, civility in politics, and opportunities for finding common ground in the 116th Congress. The panel was moderated by Paul Kane, Senior Congressional Correspondent and Columnist for The Washington Post.  This was part of a two-day program hosted by the Congressional Study Group on American Democracy and Civics through the U.S. Association of Former Members of Congress. Kennedy and I serve as co-chairs of the group created to strengthen our democratic process by showcasing bipartisanship, civility, and emphasizing the importance of civic knowledge.  Click here to watch the full event.  6. Largest increase for medical research in more than   a decade 
 
Earlier this year, I voted for the largest increase in funding for the National Institute of Health for critical medical research and development, including fighting cancer, in more than a decade.  The Childhood Cancer STAR Act, which focuses on improving efforts to identify and track the incidences of pediatric cancer, was signed into law earlier this year. It will also work to improve the quality of life for children with cancer, expand opportunities for pediatric cancer research, and ensure there is pediatric cancer expertise on the National Cancer Advisory Board.  My wife is a 19-year colon cancer survivor and in Congress, I am promoting policies that encourage early detection through screening and tests, along with supporting critical research, so that one day no families will have to go through what my family, and so many other families, have gone through.    7. Springfield Rail Improvements Project and   Preserving Springfield Race Riot Artifacts 
 
￼
The Springfield Rail Improvements project is incredibly important to Springfield and I was excited to bring Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) Administrator Ronald Batory to meet with local stakeholders and show him firsthand it’s value to our local economy. This project will improve pedestrian safety in downtown Springfield as well as improve passenger rail service throughout central Illinois. The support this project has received so far is enormous and I want to make sure the federal government is doing its part to ensure this project is completed and we have reliable passenger trains running through Illinois. I’ve always believed that once it’s completed, Springfield will be a great example of where high-speed rail can work and I will continue to fight for federal support for this project.   
 
￼
Davis and Librarian of Congress, Dr. Carla Hayden, view the Springfield Race Riot artifacts. 
I have been working with the Illinois NAACP, the Central Illinois African American Museum, and the Library of Congress to preserve artifacts from the 1908 Springfield race riots unearthed during construction of the Carpenter Street segment of the Rail Improvement Project. Additionally, I hosted the Librarian of Congress, Dr. Carla Hayden, in Springfield to view the artifacts.  Recently, the National Park Service (NPS) has agreed to conduct a preliminary survey of the site of the 1908 Springfield Race Riots. The survey is necessary to begin the process of getting a national designation by the park service. This is something I will work diligently towards in 2019.   8. Investing in infrastructure 
 
￼
This Congress passed one of the largest investments in transportation and infrastructure in years. This funding allows localities to fix roads and bridges and invest in their communities.  This includes investments in our smaller, public transit systems, which means investing in jobs and economic growth, while also ensuring access to safe and affordable transportation for riders. I joined U.S. Rep. Darin LaHood, Acting Administrator of the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) K. Jane Williams and General Manager of Connect Transit Isaac Thorne today to recognize grant funding awarded to Connect Transit by the FTA. I was proud to have the Acting Administrator in central Illinois to see firsthand the difference the bus grant will make in the community. As a member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I will continue to be an advocate for our smaller transit systems that are critical to the communities they serve.   9. Building a stronger workforce 
 
￼
I was honored to host Ivanka Trump, Advisor to the President, at Lewis and Clark Community College (LCCC) in August. We toured the college's welding facility and held a workforce development roundtable with manufacturers, labor, and LCCC students.   We saw the advancement in technical training and heard from people who are proof that you don't have to have a four-year degree to succeed in this country. It was great to have Ivanka Trump, who continues to be a leader on workforce training and child care issues in the White House, visit the 13th District. As we heard from the panel, this is about growing the middle class and creating jobs that allow people to succeed. In Washington, we passed an overhaul of our career and technical education programs to ensure they are providing training for jobs that are actually open within a community. I continue to work with the administration to expand apprenticeship opportunities and reduce college debt.   10. Granite City is back to work 
 
￼
I attended President Trump’s visit to Granite City with hundreds of steelworkers, who are now back to work. In 2015, Granite City Works laid off nearly 2,000 workers, but has since brought back many of these jobs citing market demand and efforts to stop illegal trade practices.  You can hear stories from people across my district and throughout the country who have been put back to work because of policies in Washington that are helping this economy grow. Since coming to Congress, I have been working to get stronger trade enforcement so American companies, like Granite City Works, can fight back against China who for years have violated our trade laws in order to decimate our manufacturing industry.   11. Preserving Route 66 
 
￼
Route 66 is a symbol of American independence and prosperity, a critical part of our economy, and it's important to preserve it for future generations. In April of last year, I went on an extended tour of Illinois’ stretch of the highway with my colleague Rep. Darin LaHood and many state and local leaders. I had the opportunity to see the economic impact the Mother Road brings to Illinois, supporting many jobs and key economic activity in small towns, helping generate important revenue to support our communities.  My legislation to create a 19-member Commission to honor the 100th anniversary of Route 66 in 2026 and to develop a plan to ensure the first-all-paved U.S. highway connecting the Midwest to California will be preserved for many years to come, passed the House unanimously.   Although this bill was not taken up in the Senate this year, I will continue to work to ensure Route 66 is ready for its 100th anniversary and for years to come.   12. Supporting our country's veterans  
 
￼
Davis greets a veteran on the Land of Lincoln Honor Flight in Springfield. 
Our veterans sacrificed for our country and we must be there for them in their time of need. The VA MISSION Act, which is landmark legislation to reform the VA, was signed into law on June 6, 2018. It strengthens and improves the VA healthcare system for approximately 9 million veterans by consolidating multiple existing community care programs into one cohesive program. Community care programs are authorized when the VA cannot fulfill the services the veteran needs and among other circumstances.  Additionally, it establishes process to review VA's assets and to recommend actions to modernize and realign medical infrastructure to ensure veterans have access to quality care and expands the Department of Veterans Affairs' Post-9/11 Caregiver program so that caregivers from all eras can take advantage of the benefits it provides to those who care for those who served. The legislation also funds the VA Choice Program until the new program is implemented so that veteran care is not disrupted.   I honored David Freyling on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives. David, who passed away earlier this year served our country in the U.S. Army and most recently served his fellow veterans as the Chairman of the Veterans Assistance Commission of Macon County for 13 years. He always went above and beyond for veterans and I strive to follow his example each day in Congress. Click here to watch my remarks.    13. Fighting Human Trafficking  
 
￼
Democrats and Republicans came together and took additional steps to stop human trafficking. Bad internet actors have helped facilitate this horrendous crime with little retribution. Dozens of bills to fight human trafficking have been signed into law, including the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act, which gives states and victims the power to sue websites that support and facilitate human trafficking. As a result, online advertising for commercial sex trafficking has gone down by 60-80%.  The No Human Trafficking on Our Roads Act, and the Combating Human Trafficking in Commercial Vehicles Act have helped cracked down on the transportation human traffickers use and helped law enforcement better combat it.   14. Securing our schools 
 
￼
Davis meets with school administrators about school safety.  
Helping our teachers and administrators make their schools safer is a priority. Not only is school safety about making the buildings more secure, but we also have to be able to identify potential issues and take steps to prevent violence before it happens. What schools need vary by district and Congress took action by authorizing the Secure Our Schools grant program to give schools the resources which can be used based on the needs of their school.  15. Championing organic agriculture 
 
￼
This year, I invited Jayson Werth to be my guest to President Trump's first State of the Union address to highlight the importance of agriculture. Jayson, who was a former professional baseball player who played for the Washington Nationals, owns an organic farm in Macoupin County, IL and has become an advocate for the industry and farmers.   Consumer demand for organic products continues to increase and this years farm bill makes positive changes to support organic products by placing higher scrutiny on organic imports, helping farmers who seek organic certification, and increasing funding for organic research.  16. No one should feel unsafe at work 

The House and Senate unanimously approved bipartisan legislation to reform sexual harassment rules within the Legislative Branch. The House led on strengthening protections against sexual harassment in the workplace and I’m glad both chambers were able to work together to get this done before the start of the new Congress. The compromise bill increases transparency, provides greater reporting requirements, and for the first time ever, ensures taxpayers are not footing the bill for any misconduct by members of Congress. Whether you work in government, in the media, in Hollywood, or elsewhere, no one should have to worry about sexual harassment when they come to work. I believe members of Congress should lead our nation by example and this legislation is a huge step in that direction.
  17. Passing a Farm Bill   
 
￼
Last week, President Trump signed the farm bill into law. The farm bill is one of the single most important pieces of legislation to ensure farmers in the 13th District can continue their family business, support a major component of our state’s economy, and help feed the world. I’ve been honored to serve on the House Agriculture Committee since I came to Congress and I’m proud to say I’ve been able to deliver two long-term farm bills, one in 2014 and now 2018, to provide certainty and help farmers in my district succeed.  Getting a farm bill across the finish line this year for our farmers was always my goal. This bill maintains programs critical for Central Illinois farmers, strengthens agricultural research, and improves protections for organic products.    18. Historic criminal justice reform  

For years, lawmakers, including myself, have advocated for reforming our criminal justice system and it’s finally a reality. The First Step Act fixes some of the biggest injustices within the system that have led to increased recidivism rates and left a bigger bill for taxpayers. We would not have gotten this bill across the finish line without leadership from within the White House, Democrat and Republican members of Congress, and a variety of outside groups coming together to unite around re-focusing the system on rehabilitation and giving millions a second chance. It’s a great example of what our government can accomplish when we set politics aside and commit to governing.  The First Step Act provides individualized assessments to federal offenders in order to tailor programming that best meets their needs, and offers programs to inmates that include: vocational training, education support, substance abuse treatment, mental health care, anger-management courses, faith-based initiatives, and other resources proven to lower the chance of recidivism.   Additionally, it contains sentencing reform provisions, including reducing the enhanced penalties for certain non-violent repeat drug offenders and eliminates the three-strike mandatory life provision, but it is not retroactive. Also, certain nonviolent offenders will be able to petition courts for a review of their sentence, which can be reduced only after the judge reviews all circumstances, including public safety, criminal history, and the nature of the offense.

Subject: Newsletter from Congresswoman Carol Shea-Porter
Message:
Open this e-mail in its own browser window  
News from Congresswoman Shea-Porter
￼
NEWS FROM THE FIRST DISTRICT
Dear Friends, 
Happy New Year! I hope you and your family and friends enjoyed the holidays, and I wish you all peace and good health in 2019. Since I decided to retire this year, I have received many kind notes, and I thank you all for that and for the great privilege of serving you in Congress for eight years. Every day in this job, I was reminded in so many ways that Americans are good people who work hard, care about issues, and deserve to be heard. That has kept me optimistic and hopeful throughout my time in Congress. 
The 115th Congress has adjourned. In the last few days of the session, we passed a bipartisan Farm Bill. The Farm Bill supports our farmers and rural communities, and it rejects attempts to strip nutrition benefits from people who need them. 
We are, of course, in a partial government shutdown because the president rejected a carefully developed compromise to keep the government funded, which had passed the Senate unanimously. This senseless shutdown is hurting federal employees and halting critical work that protects all Americans, but President Trump said he was proud to shut down the government. I hope he changes his mind and decides to support any one of the bipartisan paths forward to end this shutdown.
Secretary Mattis’s departure this month is extremely concerning. His resignation letter makes it clear that the president does not believe that we must stand with our allies and be clear-eyed in countering our enemies and competitors on the world stage. I worry that the President will make more dangerous decisions in the future because Secretary Mattis will not be in the administration.
Opposing seismic testing in the Atlantic 
The Trump Administration announced that it would allow drilling in the Atlantic Ocean last year. The administration continued down this path last week, issuing five Incidental Harassment Authorizations (IHAs) for Atlantic seismic airgun blasting permits.
I sent a letter with 93 other Members of Congress from both parties to Interior Secretary Zinke and Commerce Secretary Ross, urging them not to approve seismic testing in the Atlantic Ocean. Seismic testing is an immediate risk to communities up and down the Atlantic. According to the Washington Post, “In addition to harming sea life, acoustic tests — in which acoustic waves are sent through water 10 to 12 seconds apart to image the sea floor — can disrupt thriving commercial fisheries.” 
In our letter, we wrote that, “Opening the Atlantic to seismic testing and drilling jeopardizes our coastal businesses, fishing communities, tourism, and our national security. It harms our coastal economies in the near term and opens the door to even greater risks from offshore oil and gas production down the road. Given the significant environmental and economic risks, we strongly oppose the issuance of IHA permits for companies seeking to conduct seismic testing in the Atlantic.”
Passing a bipartisan Farm Bill 
I am pleased that the House and Senate have agreed to a bipartisan farm bill that includes critical New Hampshire priorities. For over a year, House Republicans have held up this bill because they have wanted to reduce nutrition support for millions of Americans who rely on these benefits to feed their families. Most people who receive nutrition benefits are children, seniors, and people with disabilities. I am pleased that these harmful provisions were not included in the final bill. The Farm Bill reauthorizes the Northern Border Regional Commission, which generates important economic activity in our state and which grows our workforce. Furthermore, this bill supports our farmers and makes critical investments that will benefit our rural communities, such as expanded access to broadband.
Breaking ground at the new Somersworth VA outpatient clinic  
I joined Senator Hassan, Manchester VA Director Al Montoya, and other civic leaders to officially break ground on the new VA outpatient clinic in Somersworth. We promised and we owe our veterans high quality health care, and this new, much larger facility will help the VA better serve Seacoast veterans. I am so pleased that many veterans will be able to receive additional services closer to home soon, and I look forward to seeing the VA continue to expand services and improve care in New Hampshire. 
￼ 
Announcing new funding to repair Market Street Wharf in Portsmouth 
The congressional delegation has announced that the U.S. Department of Transportation will award $7.5 million to the Pease Development Authority, Division of Ports and Harbors (PDA-DPH) for the Main Wharf Rehabilitation and Modification Project. Our economy depends on the maritime infrastructure along the Piscataqua River. This funding will allow PDA-DPH to rehabilitate approximately 17,500 square feet of the Main Wharf at the Market Street Marine Terminal. 
Bringing this facility back up to full capacity can’t happen soon enough, and I applaud the approval of this federal funding. Without these repairs, large parts of the wharf will have to be closed. Funding for infrastructure projects needs to be a federal priority, and I hope to see a bipartisan infrastructure package move forward that creates jobs and addresses critical infrastructure needs.  
Addressing the SVAC 
I enjoyed speaking at the monthly State Veterans Advisory Committee meeting. Thank you to the SVAC for all you do to help New Hampshire veterans! The Granite State is grateful for your dedication to those who served and their families. 
￼ 
Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans 
Blue Water Navy Vietnam veterans have earned and deserve benefits for health conditions developed as a result of Agent Orange exposure. I am beyond disappointed that H.R. 299, which passed the House 382-0, was blocked by a few Republican Senators. This legislation would restore VA benefits for these veterans, who lost them in 2002 when the VA unilaterally re-wrote the rules on who was covered by the Agent Orange Act of 1991. Congress has been trying to fix this problem for many years, and we got very close this time. Failure to enact this bill is a grave injustice and a betrayal to those who served. I hope the next Congress will act swiftly to enact this bill. 
Best Wishes, ￼  Carol Shea-Porter Member of Congress ￼￼

ICYMI! 
Shea-Porter: ‘We made NH bluer’ 
Portsmouth Herald // Paul Steinhauser 
ROCHESTER — As she leaves Congress after four terms in the U.S. House of Representatives, retiring Democratic Rep. Carol Shea-Porter says she’s proud she’s been “part of that big change that’s come over New Hampshire.”
  
Departing Rep. Shea-Porter reflects on 12 years of wins, losses in 1st District 
WMUR // Adam Sexton 
MANCHESTER, N.H. — She started by making history, smashing the glass ceiling in New Hampshire's congressional delegation as the first woman to represent the Granite State on Capitol Hill. 
  
NH port gets $7.5M grant to fix wharf 
Portsmouth Herald // Jeff McMenemy 
PORTSMOUTH -- The Port of New Hampshire has received a $7.5 million federal grant to rehabilitate the main wharf at the Market Street Marine Terminal, U.S. Sens. Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan, along with U.S. Rep. Carol Shea-Porter, announced Thursday.
  
Grants to help fight violence against women 
Conway Daily Sun // Staff 
WASHINGTON D.C. — U.S. Sens. Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan and U.S. Reps. Carol Shea-Porter and Annie Kuster have announced an additional $2,441,735 in grants from the U.S. Department of Justice Office on Violence Against Women.
  
Federal drug report shows mixed results 
Nashua Telegraph // Adam Urquhart 
NASHUA – A new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found the drug overdose death rate in New Hampshire in 2017 remained roughly the same as the previous year, but problems with fentanyl seem to be spreading throughout the nation. 
  
Report: Repair backlog leaves subs pierside 
Fosters // Hadley Barndollar 
KITTERY, Maine — A new report issued by the Government Accountability Office depicts hugely consequential maintenance delays for the nuclear submarine fleet, and more than $1.5 billion spent over the last 10 years to support submarines sitting idle with no operational capabilities. 
“Congress and the Navy are working hard to address maintenance delays by investing significant resources into upgrading public shipyards, including nearly $150 million for the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard,” Shea-Porter said. “The shipyard is working at full capacity and meeting its goals, and I do not expect that any maintenance availabilities will be transferred from Portsmouth. It’s clear from this report that our public shipyards are needed now than ever...”

Subject: The Year in Review | 2018 Edition
Message:
￼ 
  


Dear Friends,

As we look forward to 2019, it's important to reflect on what we've accomplished together this year. This newsletter highlights some of our successes throughout the second session of the 115th Congress, as we continued to work together to build "One Meck." I'm grateful for the opportunity to represent you, and I will continue to fight for you and your family throughout 2019. Take a look to see the year in review.

Please join us on January 24th for my annual State of the District Town Hall. 

I look forward to seeing you there. 

Best,
￼
Congresswoman Alma S. Adams, Ph.D.

￼ 

￼

On January 25th, I held my annual State of the District Address at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, where I had the opportunity to speak directly to my constituents about my agenda for our district. I continued to emphasize "One Meck," because Mecklenburg County is stronger when we are united.

￼

On January 20th, Americans across the country participated in the 2nd Annual Women’s March to protest the gross misogyny of the Trump Administration. I was proud that over five thousand people in Charlotte joined in this effort by marching through the streets to send a direct message to the President that women will not be silenced. Your voices are heard loud and clear: we will keep marching until women earn equal wages, have equal access to comprehensive healthcare, and do not have to fear sexual violence and harassment.

￼

On March 20th, the Bipartisan Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Caucus, which I founded and serve as the Caucus Co-Chair, and the Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics (STEAM) Caucus hosted the first HBCU STEAM Day of Action on Capitol Hill. This unique event brought HBCU presidents and administrators from forty schools and industry leaders to Capitol Hill to meet with key members of Congress and senior staff from both parties and in both chambers. The meetings allowed the coalition to advocate for bipartisan priorities impacting HBCUs and increased efforts to diversify our workforce. These priorities included increased resources for 1890 land-grant universities through the Farm Bill, reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, STEAM initiatives, and appropriations.

￼

I hosted the Third Annual Women's Symposium and Resource Fair on March 29th. This year's theme was "Women Who Lead: Encourage, Inspire, Empower." 

Thank you to our panelists, host and everyone who attended or watched the live-stream. This year's event demonstrated why we often find strength in the stories of others. I hope you came away from the event with tools to realize your dreams. If you'd like to re-watch the program or see what you missed click here.

￼

It was a pleasure meeting with Mecklenburg County Commissioners George Dunlap, Trevor Fuller, Dumont Clarke, County Manager Dena Diorio and the Deputy County Manager Derrick Ramos in my D.C. office on March 6th. We discussed issues important to the more than 830,000 citizens of the 12th Congressional District of North Carolina.

￼

This March, I was honored to receive the North Carolina Association of Educators (NCAE) President's  award at the annual NCAE  State Convention. During my opening remarks, I reaffirmed my commitment to quality education and public schools. As your champion in Congress, I won’t stop fighting for public education.

￼

One of the most important aspects of my job is listening to my constituents. In April, I hosted a listening session on affordable housing so I could hear, firsthand, from constituents and local organizations concerned with the affordable housing crisis in the district. During the meeting, members of our community gathered to share how this crisis impacts Mecklenburg County and to brainstorm solutions. I remain committed to bringing attention to this issue, and will continue to work on behalf of those impacted.

￼

I’m thankful for our first responders everyday -- but it’s not every day that I have chance to thank them personally alongside an NBA star! On April 7th, Kemba Walker, star point guard of the Charlotte Hornets, and I participated in Coca-Cola’s “Message in a Bottle” initiative. This program collects messages of thanks from community members to deliver to those who serve them. To those who keep us safe -- thank you for all you do!

￼

On April 10th, I met with officials from the NC Electric Cooperatives to talk about what policies would expand utilities to rural communities in North Carolina. As a member of Congress, I am determined to find funding for valuable initiatives such as electric cooperatives, clean energy in rural communities, and lowering utility costs for low-income households. I'm grateful to hear what these experts had to say.

￼

One of my favorite things about being a Congresswoman is hosting the annual 12th District Congressional Art Competition. After all, I was an Art Professor for over 40 years. Each Spring, I invite submissions from all high school students in Mecklenburg County to submit their work and have it judged by a professional panel. The first place winner’s work is featured in the halls of U.S. Capitol along with winners from House districts across the country. In addition, the second place winners work is displayed in my D.C. office, while the third place winners work is displayed in my District Office for one year.  Congratulations to this year’s award recipients:   1. "Peony" by Beryl Shoemaker (Senior, William Hough High School)  2. "Sky Scraper" by Kevin Garcia (Senior, Olympic High School)  3. "My Neighbor" Dave by Vuk Petrovic (Junior, Northwest School of the Arts)


￼

Each year, I nominate high school students from our district for an appointment to a military service academy. This May, I met with six of the twelve students who received appointment offers and full scholarships to attend one of our nation's prestigious military institutions of higher learning. 
￼

On May 22nd, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos testified before the House Committee on Education and the Workforce. I had the opportunity to question Secretary DeVos about consumer protections for students that attend for-proft college, the HBCU Capital Financing Program, andprotections for student loan borrowers.Click here to watch.
￼

Students from Charlotte's Trinity Episcopal Middle School joined me in D.C. on May 16th to discuss the ways that children can serve as educational advocates. As a former educator and a member of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, I recognize that education offers opportunities to achieve economic prosperity and social mobility. I will continue to use my position to advocate for a strong education system. 
￼

Many people in our community are unemployed or underemployed, even though there are plenty of employers eager to hire. On May 3rd, I hosted the Bridging the Gap Career Fair, which provided an opportunity for those seeking employment to connect with over 40 employers who have jobs to fill. 
￼

I met with Charlotte's Mayor Vi Lyles and members of the Charlotte City Council during their May visit to Washington D.C. 
￼

On June 4th, I was joined by Mayor Woody Washam to announce the launch of the 12th District’s Cornelius Satellite Office hours. We’re pleased to expand office hours across the district in order to serve our constituents. 
￼

On July 17th, I stood with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA), and fellow Democratic women in Congress, to stop the confirmation of United States Supreme Court Justice nominee Brett Kavanaugh due to major concerns about his potential impact on women’s rights and other vital rights and liberties.  
￼

Also on July 17th, the Small Business Subcommittee on Investigations, Oversight, and Regulations and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations met for a hearing titled, “Achieving Government-Wide Verification of Service-Disabled Veteran-Owned Small Businesses.” During this hearing, we heard from experts and leaders on how to expand opportunities for disabled veterans to be successful small business owners. 
￼

In July, I met with the interim Chief Executive Officer of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Fern Fernandez, to discuss how to expand small business and labor opportunities for Hispanic business owners and workers.
￼

On July 19th, I hosted “HBCUs: The Key to Diversifying Tech” with the National Urban League, the Bipartisan HBCU Caucus, and the Congressional Black Caucus. This roundtable brought together leaders from the HBCU community, tech sector, and Congress to discuss how government and industry can work together to build a more diverse and inclusive workforce. During the roundtable, we evaluated best practices in creating a diverse pipeline through partnerships between businesses and HBCUs.     
￼

On July 24th, I had the opportunity to give a guest lecture at the Davidson College Washington Program. I shared my story of political activism and what it means to live the “American Dream” with this brilliant class of Davidson students.  
￼

At the end of the summer, I hosted my Merge Mobility Community Conversation. This was a community discussion on the factors that contribute to economic mobility and how they impact the residents of the 12th District. 
￼
On October 17th, I hosted a Suicide Prevention and Mental Health Panel and Resource Fair. I spoke to attendees about the importance of mental health and ending the stigma that goes along with seeking mental health assistance. 
￼
On November 28th, I met with Governor Cooper and other members of the North Carolina delegation to discuss continued efforts to secure greater funding for Hurricane Florence Recovery. 
￼
On December 3rd, I received the SCORE 2018 House Small Business Champion Award for legislation my colleagues and I passed in the House this year. 
￼

One of my greatest achievements of 2018 was the passing of the 2018 Farm Bill. This legislation will help combat hunger in Mecklenburg County, provide greater resources to HBCUs, and support our local food system - from our farmers markets to our farmers.

￼
To end this wonderful year, I hosted my annual Day of Service at Loaves and Fishes Food Pantry on December 14th. During the day of service, we packed boxes of food to send to food pantries and fight hunger in the 12th District.
￼ 
Hurricane Corner 
During the week of September 9th, our district and state prepared for Hurricane Florence's impact. My staff and I closely monitored the storm throughout the week as it traveled toward our coast, made landfall and impacted our district the weekend of September 14th. During the week I participated in calls with FEMA calls as they briefed all NC leaders on the impact of the storm and their recovery efforts. We worked hard to make sure our constituents were informed and safe. 
￼

Top Photo:  Between monitoring the storms and daily updates to constituents, I visited emergency shelters in our district. I visited North and East Mecklenburg High School and talked with some of the families and individuals who came to Charlotte to escape the brunt of Hurricane Florence. 

Bottom Photo: High school music instructors visited the shelters to provide a bit of musical relief.  
￼ 
Legislative Update 
Introduced Bills
H.R. 6698, The Maternal CARE Act: This bill would support States in their efforts to reduce persistent, racial health disparities in maternal mortality and morbidity by utilizing evidence-based quality improvement programs. To do so, the Maternal CARE Act would create two new grant programs focused on maternal mortality and morbidity with an emphasis on reducing existing racial health disparities.
Learn More
H.R. 6876, the Strengthening Minority-Serving Institutions Act of 2018: This bill would permanently reauthorize mandatory funding for minority-serving institutions under Title III of the Higher Education Act. It would also increase the line-items by $20-30 million. In Fiscal Year 2019, this funding is scheduled to expire, removing $485 million from the budgets of HBCUs, in particular.
Learn More 
H.R. 7066, Army Security Agency Monument Act: This bill would direct the Department of the Army to place a monument honoring the United States Army Security Agency in Arlington National Cemetery. The Agency, which existed between 1945 and 1976, operated as the Army’s signals intelligence branch which monitored and interpreted the military communications of the Soviet Union, China, and their allies.  H.R. 7136, LIVE Well Act: This bill would include eating disorders prevention within the nutrition education and obesity prevention grant program and the local wellness program. The Nutrition Education and Obesity Prevention Grant Program supports nutrition education for SNAP beneficiaries, while the Local Wellness Program helps school districts promote student health within their respective school lunch programs. 
Key Letters 
Letter to Congressional Leadership Opposing Federal Pay Raise Freeze by POTUS: This letter, sent September 7th, expressed opposition to President Trump’s decision to rescind modest statutory pay increases and locality pay increases for federal government employees. Pay increases were included and passed in the Senate-approved Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Bill for FY19.
Letter to OIG regarding ICE subpoenas of voting records in NC: This letter, sent September 7th, expressed concerns about the scope of recent Department of Justice, DOJ, and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) subpoenas used for voting records and private information in the Eastern District of North Carolina and requested an investigation to examine the circumstances thereof. Subpoenas requested over 15 million sensitive documents concerning North Carolina voters and appeared to target voters of color. After the letter, the DOJ extended the deadline after North Carolina board of elections’ unanimous objections but requested that election officials send the records by January 2019.
Letter to Appropriators asking for additional deferment money for the HBCU Capital Finance Program: This letter, sent September 5th, asked for the House and Senate Appropriations Committees to provide an additional $10 million in deferment funding for the HBCU Capital Finance Program.  In the Fiscal Year 2018 Omnibus, Rep. Adams and Rep. Ted Budd were able to secure $10 million for 8 schools to defer payments on their HBCU Capital Finance Loan. On September 27th, Congress passed the Labor-HHS-Ed Appropriations bill which included the ask for an additional $10 million, which will assist 7 more schools in deferring loan payments.
Letter to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin at the CBC meeting this week on reforming the Community Reinvestment Act: This letter, sent September 7th, was in continuation of a discussion from the July 12, 2018 House Financial Services Committee Hearing. The letter addressed the persistence of discrimination in lending practices against minorities in spite of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. The letter concluded with three follow up questions regarding the Office of the Comptroller of Currency’s plans to revisit policies and narrow the impact occurrences of discrimination have on a bank’s CRA rating. 
Letter to Sen. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and President Trump asking for an apology for Christine Blasey Ford Comments: This letter was led by Rep. Adams and sent on September 27th to highlight the disrespectful comments made by Senator McConnell and President Trump regarding Christine Blasey Ford’s allegation against now-Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh. It was written from the perspective of victims of domestic and sexual assault, as all signatories to the letter were.
Letter to Sec. Pompeo expressing concern for the total cut of US funding to the UN Relief and Works Agency: This letter, sent on September 28, was written to urge the administration to reverse its decisions to cut funding to the United Nations Relief Works Agency to reprogram aid away from the West Bank and Gaza. Steps to cut funding would threaten stability in the West Bank/ Gaza regions and undercut the ability of the U.S. to facilitate negotiations. 
Letter to Secretary of State Pompeo opposing the State Department’s decision to strip reproductive rights from its human rights report: This letter, sent on October 1, was written to express opposition to the omission of reproductive rights in the State Department’s Human Rights Practices reports. Congress relies on these reports when considering appropriations for requests of foreign assistance and to inform legislation. The private sector also relies on these reports to inform resource allocations. After this letter, Ranking Member Nita Lowey, Democratic Caucus Vice Chair Rep. Katherine Clark, Ranking Member Eliot Engel, Rep. Barbara Lee, and Rep. Lois Frankel introduced the Reproductive Rights are Human Rights Act. 
Letter to President Trump opposing the EPA proposal to weaken methane leak inspection measure from oil and gas operations: This letter, sent on October 3, expressed concerns with the impact of weakening methane emission controls by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Bureau of Land Management (BLM). Weakening federal regulations would compromise air quality and adversely affect health. 
Letter to Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS) Administrator Verma requesting improvement to how the Prior Authorization works under Medicare Advantage: This letter, sent on October 9, expressed concerns with the barriers imposed by prior authorization requirements on patients. Prior authorization is a requirement that physicians obtain approval from health care providers before prescribing a specific medication or performing an operation. 
Letter to HHS Secretary Azar urging resumption of collective bargaining with HHS employees’ union: This letter, sent on October 21, addressed concerns with HHS’ hasty and rushed collective bargaining with employees and its impact on the Department’s ability to serve citizens. In July, the Department carried out two days of negotiations with employee unions before declaring an impasse. After this letter, employees picketed the Department and the Federal Services Impasses Panel subsequently coordinated an additional 30-day period in which the Department could carry out additional bargaining.
Letter to Secretary Pompeo about the Brazilian election and reinforcing the need for protection of basic human rights and democratic values: This letter, sent on October 26, expressed concerns regarding Brazilian presidential candidate Bolsonaro and the threat his election would pose to human rights and democracy.  Bolsonaro’s campaign was marked by political violence and his support for military governance. After this letter, Bolsonaro was elected on October 28, 2018. 
Letter to Chairman Pai regarding expanding the availability of 1.4 GHz spectrum band for wireless medical telemetry service (WMTS), including remote healthcare monitoring devices: This letter, sent on October 18, asked that Chairman Pai act quickly when expanding access to 1.4 GHz band for WMTS. This expansion will allow more hospitals and patients in rural areas to use remote healthcare devices.   Amicus Brief opposing the President’s illegal national monuments rollbacks last year: This brief, sent on November 19, was submitted to the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to challenge the Trump Administration’s decision to diminish the Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments. The brief argued that under the Antiquities Act, Congress has only permitted the President to designate monuments, not to abolish or reduce them. After this letter, several Native American tribes and government entities also entered into litigation against the Administration. 
Letter to Secretary DeVos raising concerns about the new Title IX guidance: This letter, sent on November 29, was written expressing concerns about DeVos’ new Title IX rule which would diminish essential protections for victims of sexual harassment and assault in K-12 and collegiate education. The deadline to submit public comments on the guidance papers will stay open until January 2019. Advocacy groups, universities, and individuals are flocking to leave their comments of opposition. 
Letter to Speaker Ryan and Leader Pelosi supporting Agriculture Disaster funding for Hurricane Florence and Michael: This letter, sent on November 28, was written to request disaster assistance appropriations for agriculture producers. Disaster Assistance helps many vulnerable farmers avoid bankruptcy and continue food production. 
Letter to Senate Majority Leader McConnell and Minority Leader Schumer on Thomas Farr Nomination: This letter, sent on November 27, was written by Rep. Adams and joined by her colleagues in the North Carolina congressional delegation to express disapproval of Thomas Farr, the nominee for the U.S. Eastern District Court of North Carolina. Thomas Farr has supported several initiatives which threaten the civil rights of American people, and especially those of African Americans. After this letter, Farr’s nomination was defeated by the U.S. Senate and will expire on January 2nd.
Letter to DHS requesting an investigation into the Trump Administration’s decision to terminate TPS: This letter, sent on November 29, was written to investigate the abrupt termination of TPS status in several Central American countries. TPS is a humanitarian program which grants temporary protection to nationals of countries that have been destabilized by war or catastrophe. As crises have persisted throughout El Salvador, Honduras, and Nicaragua, Trump’s decision to curtail TPS protection threatens the safety and health of hundreds of thousands of individuals and families.  
Letter to Express Opposition to the Trump Administration’s Issuance of Permits for Surveys to Assess Offshore Drilling: This letter, sent on December 6 to the Secretaries of Commerce and the Interior, expresses concern regarding the Trump Administration’s recent decision to issue five Incidental Harassment Authorization permits for companies planning to conduct seismic geological and geophysical surveys along the Atlantic coast – a major step toward offshore oil and gas drilling. Studies have shown that offshore drilling activities have led to the disruption of a wide range of marine habitats that support economies along the coast.
Congressional Black Caucus Letter to Express Opposition to Proposed Change to Public Charge Determinations: This letter, sent on December 10, expressed concern regarding the Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) proposed rule that would make it more difficult for immigrants of color to be admitted into the United States. Public Charge determinations are made based on a variety of factors that assess an immigrant’s likelihood to be dependent on public benefits, however, the interpretation of what constitutes a benefit was left for courts to decide. DHS’s proposed rule creates a list of programs for the first time and would force previously excluded populations such as refugees to undergo the analysis.

Subject: My Final E-Newsletter: Thank You for Everything!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼


 
Labrador Letter -   December 31, 2018
 
￼
Website | About Raúl | Serving You | News | Issues | Resources | Contact Me | District
￼

Dear friends,
This is my final e-newsletter as a member of Congress. I’ve enjoyed communicating with you and thousands of other subscribers and appreciate your kind attention and thoughtful feedback.  Let me begin by thanking you, from the bottom of my heart, for giving me the opportunity to represent you in Congress for the past eight years. When I first ran for Congress in 2010, very few people knew who I was and even fewer people gave me a chance to win.  But you listened to me in the same way I listened to you.  You stood by me in the same way I stood by you. You sent me to Washington to fight for you; to stand strong for conservative values; to help preserve this wonderful country.  I have worked every day to be worthy of your trust, and I am grateful for the trust you have repeatedly placed in me.  
￼
 I leave Congress more humbled than anything else. Over 800,000 people live in Idaho’s First Congressional District. And we are a very opinionated group of people (which is great). Tapping into your advice and counsel was a constant priority of mine, because I knew I couldn’t do it alone. That’s why I hosted scores of town halls over the past eight years, covering all 19 counties and towns from Meridian to Weiser, Cottonwood to Lewiston and Coeur d’Alene to Bonners Ferry. In these eight years, I received over 500,000 contacts from Idahoans who called, wrote, emailed, or faxed my office about issues ranging from the border wall to gun control, from wildfires to the President’s tweets. You cared enough about our country to contact me directly, and because of that, you made me a better congressman.  My favorite part of the job was being able to help Idahoans directly when you had a problem with a federal agency. Every day, Idahoans contacted my office seeking help with agencies such as the IRS, the VA, the SSA, and the BLM. When dealing with these agencies, I instructed my staff to be persistent, yet professional, and to “never take the first ‘no’ for an answer.” It’s one of the main reasons Newsmax named me one of the “25 hardest working members of Congress.”  Since 2011, my office has handled over 1,000 constituent service cases per year, with more than half of those cases involving veterans. We recovered over $10 million in benefits, including retroactive pay, reimbursement for medical expenses, new benefit awards, disability claims, pensions and more.  One of my proudest accomplishments originated in a casework request. In 2013, Navy Capt. Edward Hill and his wife Heidi contacted my office because of an issue they were having with the VA. Their daughter, Shauna, tragically died at age 16 in a car accident. The Hills tried to transfer their veterans’ education benefits to their surviving daughter, but they were told it was impossible. I sought an administrative fix, but soon discovered the law prohibited a transfer. So I set out to change the law.  In February 2017, I introduced the Shauna Hill Post 9/11 Education Benefits Transferability Act, which would permit the reassignment of benefits for veterans’ families. Six month later, President Trump signed my bill into law as part of a larger veterans’ education bill.
￼
 (Capt. Edward Hill, who served 28 years in the Navy, lives in Eagle with his wife, Heidi)
I also am proud of having passed legislation to help ranchers graze their livestock on federal lands and a bill providing for a gun range in Idaho County. I have been a strong voice for modernizing our immigration laws, tough but fair reforms to our criminal justice system (which passed Congress this month), and slowing the dangerous rise in our federal debt.  Looking ahead, I plan on remaining involved in the political process and fighting for Idaho values – it just won’t be from Congress.  I feel that eight years was the right amount of time for me in the House.  Some members, in my opinion, stay too long, blocking the way for new members who can confront issues with a new approach.  I don’t believe in career politicians, but I do believe our country is stronger when every citizen is involved in the political process.  An engaged citizenry is critical to our country’s future.  We know that in Idaho, and I hope it stays that way.  To conclude, we are blessed to live in the greatest country on Earth and the greatest country in history. Growing up as the son of a single mom from Puerto Rico, I would never have imagined I would have the opportunity to serve in Congress.  Thank you for making that dream possible. Thank you for your support and friendship, and I look forward to strengthening that friendship in the days and years to come. 
￼
 May God bless you, and may God continue to bless America.  Happy New Year!
Thank you,
￼

Subject: Washington Watch: Wrapping Up 2018 And Welcoming The 116th Congress
Message:
News from Representative Woodall
￼

PRESERVING OUR NATION’S FOOD STAMP PROGRAM FOR THOSE IN NEED 
Under the direction of President Trump, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is working on regulations that would increase the solvency of one of our nation’s most important social safety net programs, the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), also commonly referred to as food stamps...READ MORE. 
TRUMP ADMINISTRATION MOVES TO PROTECT 340B HOSPITALS AND HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS  
In addition to the many steps the Trump Administration has taken to advance America’s agricultural backbone, President Trump, with the help of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services’ Administrator Seema Verma and Department of Health and Human Services’ Secretary Alex Azar, has had tremendous success on the regulatory front when it comes to delivering common-sense and long overdue solutions to better our nation’s health care system...READ MORE. 
HOUSE PASSES MORE BIPARTISAN BILLS DURING SPENDING NEGOTIATIONS 
Amid the speculation and concern over the partial government shutdown, we in the House of Representatives rolled up our sleeves and continued working to deliver good public policy as the President and congressional leaders continued negotiating over the handful of remaining spending bills...READ MORE. 
SECOND ROUND OF RELIEF FOR AMERICAN FARMERS 
Earlier this month, President Trump announced additional relief for farmers negatively affected by retaliatory tariffs as the Administration continues to iron out the details on new trade agreements with our neighbors abroad...READ MORE. 
LOCAL PARENT STARTS NON-PROFIT ADDRESSING FOOD INSECURITY IN GWINNETT SCHOOLS 
We are doers here in the Seventh District of Georgia. It’s easy to talk about making a difference, but it takes a special kind of person to take the action needed to make the difference. Here at home we have example after example of folks doing just that: identifying a need and going about creating a way to address that need...READ MORE. 
CHAPTER 1030 VIETNAM VETERANS OF AMERICA IN CUMMING SELECTS VETERAN(S) OF THE YEAR 
Settling on the most exemplary of our veterans in any given category is a very difficult task, so I can’t say I fault the folks over at Chapter 1030 Vietnam Veterans of America for selecting two Veterans of the Year!...READ MORE. 
HAPPY NEW YEAR; WELCOME TO THE 116TH CONGRESS 
With 2018 coming to a close and the new year beginning soon, we all naturally take time to pause and reflect. This is a time to be thankful for friends and family, to reflect on our lives and all that transpired in 2018, and to set new goals for 2019...READ MORE. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Rob Woodall  Member of Congress

Subject: Thanks for the opportunity to serve you in Congress
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
Thanks for the opportunity to serve you in Congress
Dear Friend:
It has been a great honor for me to serve the constituents of the 6th Congressional District for the last ten years.  As you may well recall, when I was first elected in 2008, the sixth was redrawn following the 2012 redistricting process. The district that I represented, starting in January of 2013, was dramatically different by its diversity.  This newly redrawn district covered all of Aurora. This meant the district now included large Hispanic, African, and Asian immigrant communities. I worked hard to understand these communities, particularly their challenges, their values, and their religious faiths. Reaching out to them not only made me a better Congressman, as I gained an understanding of the issues that were important to them, but it made me a better, more understanding, and compassionate human being.  Having a combined 21 years in the military between the U.S. Army, the Marine Corps, and their reserve components, I was honored to serve on both the House Armed Services Committee and on the Veterans’ Affairs Committee. On Armed Services, I worked hard to make sure that we had the best led, best equipped, and best trained military in the world. On Veterans Affairs, I worked to see that our nation met its obligations to the men and women who have worn the uniform and who have made extraordinary sacrifices in defense of our freedom.  Few Americans have the privilege of serving in Congress, and to think that the son of a career enlisted soldier who grew up in Aurora and dropped out of high school to join the U.S. Army, would be one of them, speaks to all that is possible in this country through hard work and determination.  Again, thanks for the opportunity to serve you in Congress.
Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative 
￼

Subject: Looking Toward the New Year and New Congress
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Looking Toward the New Year and New Congress
With the New Year and new Congress on the horizon, it is my hope that 2019 will usher in a sense of urgency and renewed commitment to civility. 
Still today, too many hardworking Ohioans and middle-class families are struggling to make ends meet and want Congress to do something about it. They want better wages, better jobs, and a better future. 
They want affordable, high-quality healthcare, education, and childcare. They want to be able to pay their bills, afford a mortgage, save a few extra dollars at the end of the month, and equal opportunity at the American Dream. Finally, and equally as important, they want a government that is accountable to the people. 
In that spirit, I will work in Congress with Democrats and Republicans to deliver real progress on these issues and the many economic, social, and global challenges facing our country.
Unfortunately, civility and bipartisanship are sorely missing right now. It is time we move beyond the divisive and hurtful rhetoric poisoning our political landscape and realize we are ALL Americans first and foremost. Violence cannot be the answer. That is why I will continue to fight in D.C. and Central Ohio to be a bridge builder and spearhead efforts in Congress to ratchet down the rhetoric. 
I look forward to talking, listening and working with you in the weeks and months ahead to make these goals a reality.
Best wishes in the New Year! 
Sincerely, 
￼

Washington, DC Office
133 Cannon House Building
Washington, DC 20515
Phone: (202) 225-4324
Fax: (202) 225-1984
Hours: Mon-Fri 9AM - 5PM 
Columbus Office
471 East Broad Street, Suite 1100

￼
Friends,  As I reflect on the last 12 months, I'm reminded that 2018 was filled with many productive events and meetings, countless conversations and discussions with new friends and old, and plenty of wonderful memories. I'm truly blessed to work for you and represent Northwest Georgia in Washington!   Here are some of the highlights from the last year: 
￼
It was fun visiting the Boys & Girls Club in Paulding County in January.


￼
I enjoyed meeting a group of bright young students from Berry Middle School after their Capitol tour in February.


￼
In March, it was great to host the Rome Floyd Chamber in my D.C. office during their annual trip to Washington.


￼
My office hosted a Local Government Services Day in Paulding County in April. The high caliber and deep commitment of our local leadership in Northwest Georgia is truly impressive.


￼
In April, I also held a reception at the Murray Arts Council for the winners of the annual 14th District Congressional Art Competition. These young artists are extremely gifted.


￼
I was honored to speak at the Chatsworth-Murray County Chamber of Commerce Annual Luncheon in May.


￼
In June, I held a send-off dinner in Calhoun to honor the students from the 14th Congressional District who were appointed this year to attend a U.S. military academy. Each of these students demonstrated through an extremely rigorous process that they have the leadership skills, integrity and drive to earn success in our nation’s academies.


￼
In July, the House passed my bill to fund our nation's financial infrastructure - such as the Treasury Department and Securities and Exchange Commission - as well as create the Fund for America's Kids and Grandkids, which functions like a savings account for future generations.  


￼
I appreciate the team at Metro Boiler Tube Company, Inc. in Ringgold for inviting me out to the plant in August. These hard-working men and women keep Northwest Georgia thriving!


￼
I was also grateful to join Governor Nathan Deal, Georgia Ports Authority and community officials at the ribbon cutting for the Appalachian Regional Port in Crandall in August. This investment between government and the private sector will pay major dividends in the form of jobs and economic development in Northwest Georgia for years to come.


￼
In September, I spoke at the Boost Your Business event in Dalton, which was hosted by Facebook and the Greater Dalton Chamber of Commerce. As we transition to a more digitally-based economy, we must ensure small businesses aren’t left behind.


￼
I hosted my fifth annual Youth Leadership Summit in October. More than 500 high school students from across Northwest Georgia attended!


￼
In November, I was honored to host a breakfast for Northwest Georgia veterans at the Filling Station in Dalton on Veterans Day. America remains the land of the free because of these brave men and women.


￼
This month, it was great to meet with Mick Mulvaney who was recently appointed as President Trump's chief of staff. 

Thank you for giving me the honor to represent you in Congress. I'm wishing you and your family a happy and healthy New Year! 
 Freedom First,
￼
Congressman Tom Graves

Subject: Notes From The Capital: December 2018
Message:
￼

 Hello,  On the last day of 2018, I'm thinking about the past year, and all that's happened.  People tend to use two phrases to describe what this year has been like for me: "whirlwind" and "hit the ground running."  The whirlwind was showing up in Washington almost exactly a year ago to meet with my new colleagues and staff, have dinner with Al and Franni, and, amazingly, find a place to live in an hour and a half. The whirlwind was the hundreds of meetings with Minnesotans—there were times when I fit 17 different meetings into one day. The whirlwind was going to dozens and dozens of committee hearings, helping pass the strong, bipartisan Farm Bill and bipartisan legislation to address the opioid epidemic into law, and hosting my first Minnesota Congressional Hotdish Competition. I only wish I could have slowed the whirlwind down and remember every single minute.  Sometimes when people say, "you really hit the ground running," I remember the time when I was a Senate intern in Washington, and I literally fell down the Capitol steps in my hurry, papers flying, grateful that I was wearing pants that day. That's what it has felt like sometimes as a new Senator. There was the time I went off to find lunch and ended up in a corner of the basement in the Russell office building, completely confused about where I was. Or the time one of my colleagues from a southern state, as we were riding up in the "Senators Only" elevator, smiled at me and said, "you must be a big Packers fan!" I smiled back and said, "well, I'm actually partial to the Vikings!" He looked befuddled—another case of mistaken identity.  I'm most proud of the thousands of constituent questions we answered and problems we helped solve. And if hitting the ground running means that I ran my heart out to accomplish good things for Minnesota, even in a year when most people said nothing could get done in Washington, then yes, I did hit the ground running.  I wish you all a joyful New Year. I've been gathering my strength and purpose for the year ahead, and hope you have too. We are all going to need it!  —Tina 
￼

Subject: Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 12.31.18
Message:
December 31, 2018
Share this email:
￼
￼
￼

￼
Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 12.31.18
Monday, December 31, 2018 –                                 
1619 and Today
The year 1619 does not loom as large in American memory as some others from our colonial experience. When thinking of those early times of English settlement in North America, 1607, the year Jamestown was founded, and 1620, when the Pilgrims landed in what is now Massachusetts, are more likely to come to mind. 
Yet the events of 1619 had a profound impact. They are worth remembering as we enter 2019 and mark the passage of 400 years.
One of them was a great stain: the beginning of slavery in English North America, with the first record of enslaved Africans arriving in Jamestown. While slavery ended with the Thirteenth Amendment passed by a Republican Congress in 1865 and subsequently ratified by the states, its effects still linger.
Another event marked a major shift in the culture of Jamestown: the first large-scale recruitment of women to the colony. While some women had arrived earlier, the settlement retained the overall character of the soldiers and adventurers who had first established it. The Virginia Company’s recruitment of about 90 women introduced families into the social fabric of the colony and gave it longer-term prospects.
A third event was one of our Commonwealth’s signal contributions to the American story.
In a church in Jamestown on July 30, the Governor, four councilors, and 22 burgesses representing the colony’s jurisdictions gathered. They reviewed the laws imposed by the Virginia Company and its charter, regulated commerce and settler conduct, and heard grievances from the colonists.
That first session lasted less than a week, adjourning on August 4 due to the summer heat, but it was the beginning of what is today the House of Delegates, the oldest elected legislative body to have continuously met in the world.
I say “continuously met” as, although the Parliament of the United Kingdom has older roots than our House of Delegates (the rules of that first Assembly were modeled on English parliamentary procedure), during the rule of Oliver Cromwell in the 1650s Parliament was dissolved and substituted with the appointed “Barebones Parliament” and the “Protectorate Parliaments.”
Other legislative bodies had appointed members, but from the start, the House of Delegates was elected by at least a portion of its constituents. In the case of the first session, the male freeholders and tenants of the jurisdictions chose the burgesses.
Even if you take out continuously-serving and elected, Virginia’s House of Delegates, which was subsequently confirmed in a charter by King James I a couple of years later, is without dispute the oldest legislative body in the New World.
The establishment of representative government in Virginia charted a path for what would become the thirteen British colonies. It was followed by the Mayflower Compact of 1620, in which the Pilgrims organized themselves as a self-governing body. Colonies that followed set up their own institutions for representative government. Instead of the mother country, the colonists exercised control over their own affairs to a large extent.
Because Virginia had a lot of practice with representative government, our Commonwealth was ready to lead when the colonies sought independence. Virginia’s governing documents and laws, including the Declaration of Rights and the Statute for Religious Freedom, would shape foundations of the new republic such as the Bill of Rights.
Among the Founders who served in the House of Burgesses or, as it became known after declaring independence from Britain, the House of Delegates were George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, Patrick Henry, George Mason, and James Monroe.
As we begin the new year, think about what was happening in Virginia 400 years ago. That span of time may be hard to fathom, but what happened that year still shapes us.
Slavery’s introduction reminds us that human beings are capable of great cruelty to each other. The birth of representative government in the New World was a great accomplishment of humanity. It started the process toward our current republic based on democratic principles. The legislative process ultimately abolished slavery through the Thirteenth Amendment and guaranteed the right to vote for women through the Nineteenth Amendment, showing that our nation is always capable of improving.
The events of 1619 resonate down to our own time.
While 2019 is not as likely to have the historical significance of 1619, I hope it will be a happy and prosperous year for us all.
If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office.  You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405 or my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671. To reach my office via email, please visit my website at www.morgangriffith.house.gov. Also on my website is the latest material from my office, including information on votes recently taken on the floor of the House of Representatives.
###
