Subject: A look back at 2018
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Sunday, December 30, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
A look back at 2018
 

Over the last two years, Republicans have moved our country forward by eliminating burdensome regulations, reforming our tax code, and as a result, fueling economic growth. I have worked alongside my colleagues to put more money back into the pockets of hard working Americans! We have also taken strong measures to better the care of our veterans, strengthen our military and put an end to illegal immigration. We are restoring American confidence by returning our country back to its core values and putting American citizens first. Below is a look at the hard work and achievements of 2018.  
Border Security & Immigration   This year we saw members of the migrant caravan rush our border and assault our Border Patrol agents. We all watched in despair as officials announced that Mollie Tibbetts a 20-year-old young woman from Iowa, was murdered by an illegal immigrant. Still, Democrats continue to put the lives of people who have entered this country illegally before our own citizens at the cost of American lives. It’s time to build the wall and secure our borders.
This Congress I supported $5 billion in funding for the border wall. Additionally, I have supported legislation that eliminates the visa lottery, revises our annual immigration levels, mandates e-verify, ends catch and release, and closes the loopholes hurting our immigration system.  I opposed H.R. 6136, a bill that granted amnesty to illegal immigrants.
I also introduced the Border Bonds for America Act of 2018, which allows American citizens the opportunity to purchase revenue bonds to help finance the construction of a southern border wall.  During World War II, 85 million Americans purchased $185 billion in war bonds and financially supported our troops while they were defending our country. This legislation would allow for the patriots of today’s era to help support American security in the same way as previous generations.
Border security is national security, and the safety of the American people must come first. Then and only then, can we begin to focus on comprehensive immigration reform. My priorities remain; building the wall, surging the National Guard to the border, ending chain migration, and shutting down sanctuary cities. 
Supporting our Military
As a member of Congress my top priority is to provide for the common defense of our nation. That means ensuring the safety of all Americans against enemies both foreign and domestic. This starts with investing in our military and making sure our men and women in uniform have the tools and resources they need to do their job.  There are over 20,000 military and DoD personnel right here in south Mississippi that depend on our support for their mission.
The National Defense Authorization Act for the 2019 fiscal year was passed by Congress and signed into law by President Trump in August.  This is the earliest passed NDAA in 41 years and will invest in a much stronger military. It included the largest pay raise for troops in nine years. Additionally, it expanded the size and strength of our troops by increasing the number of uniformed personnel for the Army, Navy, Navy Reserves, Air Force Reserves and the Air National Guard.  It also increases funding for training operations while working to repair vital military equipment. Our men and women in uniform are the best in the world at what they do,  and we owe it to them to ensure they have the tools and resources they need to get the job done.
As Co-Chair of the National Guard and Reserve Component Caucus this year, I was proud to introduce The Reserve Component Benefits Parity Act of 2018 to help bridge the gap of equal benefits for members of our military's reserve components. This bill will ensure that all service members, regardless of deployment authority, are given the same benefits for their service. That legislation laid the groundwork to provide fairness to certain mobilized National Guard and Reserve Component service members, by extending their eligibility for pre-mobilization and transitional health care, eligibility for post-9/11 educational assistance, and access to rehabilitation for veterans with service-connected disabilities.
Within the last year, the "Forever G.I. Bill" and the FY2018 NDAA were signed into law, and included portions from our legislation, the Reserve Component Benefits Parity Act.
I am looking forward to working with my colleagues in the House to ensure that we get this legislation signed into law. Our Reservists and Guardsmen deserve better. I came to Washington to support our military's mission before, during, and after their service.
Veterans
I am fully committed to ensuring our veterans  receive the care they need and have earned. For far too long our veterans have suffered under the bureaucracy of the VA.  Some have literally died while waiting in line for care, and no one was held accountable.
As a Marine veteran of the Persian Gulf War and a member of the Mississippi National Guard, I do not take lightly my responsibility to ensure our veterans receive the best service and appreciation. During the 115th Congress, we have passed significant legislation that works to improve the care of our veterans.
In September, I supported the Department of Veterans Affairs funding bill that specifically benefits Mississippi's veterans by funding rural health initiatives and allocating $64.3 million for the Armed Forces Retirement Home in Gulfport. That legislation also funded the VA MISSION Act which implements major reforms and improvements to the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Below are several other pro-veteran bills that I have co-sponsored this congress, 3 of which have been signed by the President.
H.R. 3218: Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act of 2017 signed into law H.R. 2519: The American Legion 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act signed into law H.R. 873: Global War on Terrorism War Memorial Act signed into law H.R. 299: Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2017 H.R. 512: WINGMAN Act H.R. 2327: PAWS Act of 2017 H.R. 846: Military Surviving Spouses Equity Act 

Jobs/Economy
Last year, Republicans in Congress worked with President Trump to pass the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that implemented pro-growth and pro-family tax cuts for Mississippi families.
Since we've reformed our tax code we've seen millions of Americans receive bonuses, companies investing back in the United States, small businesses expanding, and unemployment decreasing. Since late 2017, the number of jobs in Mississippi has increased by the thousands and we've achieved our lowest unemployment rate in history!
As a result of this success, House Republicans passed a bill to lock-in the recently passed tax cuts, Tax Reform 2.0. This bill is estimated to create millions of jobs, boost wages, and increase GDP for the long haul by locking in the individual and small business tax cuts that were included in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
Two years ago, House Republicans revealed our Better Way agenda. A promise to the American people that we will enact policies that meet America's biggest problems with bold solutions.  Passing tax reform was a great victory for hard working American people. Since Republicans have taken control of the House, Senate, and the White House, we've seen our economy boom, our wages rise, and American confidence soar. While there is still much work to be done, I believe we are all better off now.
Do you agree? Tell me now how you’re better off now and what I can do to best serve you in 2019.
Legislative Victories
As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I am charged with the responsibility of allocating every dollar of discretionary spending for the federal government. In addition to my work on the Appropriations committee, I introduced and supported a number of bills this year that will positively impact south Mississippi.   I joined several of my House and Senate colleagues in introducing the Commercial Engagement through Ocean Technology Act (CENOTE) which advances and expands the use of unmanned maritime systems. This bill establishes the framework for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and provides a guide map for public and private defense and non-defense industries to come together, and grow the usage of unmanned maritime systems. This bill was passed by Congress and signed into law by the President.
This year, President Trump also signed my bill the Gulf Islands National Seashore Land Exchange Act into law. This was a constituent-driven proposal that would make permanent a 30-year easement that has provided an access road and driveway for The Mark Seymour Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 5699, which is located within the National Park Service’s (NPS) Gulf Islands National Seashore in Ocean Springs. In exchange for the easement, the VFW will transfer a portion of its acreage to the park, which includes valuable wetlands. The National Seashore is a staple of the Mississippi Gulf Coast that holds historic sites, wildlife sanctuaries, and natural beaches. 
Mississippi has a long history of harvesting and consuming seafood and is currently the nation’s sixth largest producer of seafood. As the representative of the former seafood capital of the world, I believe we have the opportunity to move our ranking up by expanding our aquaculture industry. That’s why this year, I introduced the Advancing the Quality of Understanding of American Aquaculture Act, also known as the AQUAA Act, to increase the United States’ involvement and production of healthy, sustainable, and affordable seafood. This bill helps develop an industry that will create jobs, support our coastal communities, and put us on the right track to reducing our seafood trade deficit in a safe and sustainable way.
Constituent Services/Community involvement
My team and I work every day to better the daily lives of south Mississippians in many ways. Creating, reforming and voting on legislation in DC is simply one of the ways we are working to accomplish this. My office also serves constituents through casework and help with federal agencies.   This year my office has been able to help 2,799 individuals through casework, and of that number 1,592 of those were veterans cases. If you or someone you know is ever in need of assistance with a federal agency, please don’t hesitate to reach out to my office. We are here to serve you.
Spending time developing our south Mississippi students into the leaders they aspire to be is another priority of mine as your Congressman. Every year, I host several events for our youth that provide immeasurable opportunities for them to learn and grow as individuals.
This year I hosted the 7th Annual Palazzo Youth Leadership Summit.  This event consists of high school juniors and seniors spending the day getting to hear from some of Mississippi’s most successful people. This year students heard from Dr. Kelly Lucas, Director of the Thad Cochran Marine Aquaculture Center, Asya Branch, Miss Mississippi 2018, and Dr. Christopher Frigo, Owner of Frigo Orthodontics. Over 360 students participated in this year's summit.  
￼
This year approximately 65 students from across south Mississippi attended my annual Academy Day. This is an informational event for those who are considering applying for one of our Service Academies. They were able to hear from and speak with leaders from the academies and as well as from south Mississippians who currently attend or have graduated from an academy. 
￼

In October, I  had the pleasure of attending the 40th Annual Salute to the Military. The annual event honoring our Armed Forces has become a staple and tradition on the Mississippi Gulf Coast.  This year it was a privilege to welcome the Vice Commandant of the United States Coast Guard, Admiral Charles Ray as the keynote speaker. I was also honored to have Purple Heart recipient Ken Duncan and his grandson join me for the evening as my special guest. 
￼
This year, my office hosted a VA Claims Clinic and Information Day, which allowed south Mississippi veterans immediate access to Jackson VA Regional Office representatives and over 32 veteran resource vendors. Upholding the promises we’ve made to our veterans is something I take very serious. They have made great sacrifices to protect and defend this nation and we must ensure they are getting the care they need and deserve.  We are scheduled to host another VA Claims Clinic February 21st & 22nd of next year at the Pascagoula Elks Lodge #1120. If you are interested in attending click this link to sign up for updates and receive the opportunity to schedule a meeting with a caseworker during the event. 
￼

I had the opportunity to experience a top-notch training operation with the Special Boat Team 22 at Stennis. The SBT-22 opened in 2010 and is the only command in the Department of Defense designated to conduct special operations in riverine environments.

￼
It was my pleasure to welcome NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine to Stennis Space Center for the RS-25 rocket engine test this week. We watched the 5th series of the test for the RS-25 that supports NASA's Space Launch System Program. With the Trump Administration's renewed focus on space exploration, Stennis plays a vital role in the future of our country's space capabilities.
￼
I was happy to join the groundbreaking ceremony for construction of a new main gate at Keesler Air Force Base. The new gate will enhance the base and provide new added security that will better protect our military assets.
￼

As a former CFO for a small public housing authority, and a member of the Congressional Public Housing Caucus, I thoroughly enjoyed my tour of the Laurel Public Housing Authority. 

￼

I joined several military officials in recognizing the 1108th Aviation Group for their outstanding performance and for serving our country so well. From September 2011 to August 2012 they displayed their expertise and extraordinary skills, contributing to the success of multiple highly visible military operations.

￼
Thank you for putting your trust in me to serve as your representative in Congress.  I look forward to continuing my hard work in the new year. 
In your service, 
￼

Steven M. Palazzo

Subject: Wishing you a wonderful New Year!
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
December 30, 2018
Dear Friend, 
I hope that each of you were able to spend a joyous Christmas with those you hold most dear.  As is typical during Christmas season, last week was very quiet on the legislative front.  I was fortunate to spend extra time with my wife, sons and parents.  However, I did partake in many behind the scenes discussions in an attempt to broker an agreement to fully reopen the government.  The position of the Administration and my party is unified.  We absolutely must secure sufficient funding for border security to prevent the flow of illegal drugs, human trafficking and terrorism into our country.  Our national security is at stake, and we cannot compromise on that paramount priority.  This is a priority that both parties have historically supported.  It is a shame that it has been politicized and used as leverage to score cheap political points.   
The urgency of this priority was highlighted by last week’s tragic death of a California law enforcement officer, New Police Cpl. Ronil Singh, who was brutally murdered by someone who illegally gained entry into our country.  While any loss of life, especially of someone working to protect his community, is devastating, the fact that his killer would not have been in our country if we had stronger border security measures in place is reprehensible.  Additionally, as noted by law enforcement, this case emphasizes the need to address irresponsible sanctuary city policies that exist in certain places around the country.  I will continue to fight for the security of all Americans until we have the appropriate level of funding and systems in place which are necessary.     
I would like to wish you a safe New Year’s celebration this week.  May 2019 bring each of you many blessings, good health and prosperity. 
￼ 
Due to the holiday closure and my work on budget negotiations, this week’s newsletter is abbreviated.  I have provided a few clips of news articles below from last week which highlight some of my recent efforts on your behalf.   
Advocating for our Heroes 
Holding the VA Accountable 
Protecting our Four Legged Friends 
Working Together to Help Children in Need 
Having my 26th bill since 2015 Signed into Law, Giving Hope to Millions  
Sincerely,
￼ 
Gus Bilirakis

Subject: Federal Funding Update
Message:
￼ 
  

FEDERAL FUNDING UPDATE

Unfortunately, Senate Democrats are continuing to put party politics ahead of our national security, disaster assistance and federal workers and are still preventing passage of federal funding legislation. 

Last week I told you I was proud to support legislation to keep the federal government running and support President Trump's border wall. 

As I mentioned, I have been to the Southwest border and I have seen the threats we face firsthand. There are illegal drugs, human trafficking, gang members and terrorists coming across our border and the legislation passed by the House included funding necessary to secure the border. 
The legislation also included critical disaster assistance for our own agricultural community in the First District and for agriculture across our state. For months I have been working to secure assistance for Georgia's blueberry growers to help in their recovery from devastating winter weather. This bill authorizes and directs the United States Department of Agriculture to provide disaster assistance to these farmers. Blueberries are a billion dollar industry in Georgia and the commodity is the backbone of some of our communities. These growers and communities need and deserve this support.   We sent this important legislation to the Senate more than a week ago, but they have yet to act causing the continuation of a partial shutdown of 25% of the federal government. As a reminder, in the Senate, this legislation requires 60 votes to pass so there needs to be bipartisan cooperation. Senate Democrats have not been willing to come to the table.   Enough is enough. It is absolutely unacceptable that Senate Democrats continue to block support for our national security, America's farmers and others who need this disaster assistance and hardworking federal employees.

REFLECTING ON 2018

In case you missed it, I recently reflected on a productive year in the Savannah Morning News. Click here to read more. I look forward to seeing you in 2019. 

Happy New Year!

Rep. Buddy Carter column: Reflecting on 2018
Savannah Morning News

With the new year approaching, I am preparing to step into my third term as your representative of Georgia’s 1st Congressional District. I’m thankful you have given me the honor and privilege to serve another term. Before we enter 2019, I want to take a moment to reflect on a strong 2018.

Over the past year, I again had the incredible opportunity to travel across the 1st District to meet with residents at local meetings, community events, schools, military installations and more. I not only enjoy this time with our neighbors across the 1st District, it’s also an important time for me to hear about the issues important to you so I can bring them 1st hand back to Washington.

I also had the opportunity to visit countless small businesses to hear from our job creators directly about how tax reform is positively impacting their business. Across the 1st District throughout the year, I heard great news about businesses growing, hiring more employees, purchasing new equipment and investing in their communities. 1st District families also got to keep more of their hard-earned money this year thanks to our new tax law.

This year I had the honor of joining President Trump as he signed my proposal to end “gag clause” provisions. Before this legislation became law, many times pharmacists were contractually prohibited from telling patients when there was a less expensive, out-of-pocket option rather than using their insurance for prescriptions. As the only pharmacist in Congress I experienced this gag clause 1st hand and it’s why I made this an important part of my ongoing mission to lower prescription drug prices. Now, pharmacists are able to ensure patients are receiving the best possible prices on medications.

With my background in pharmacy and as a member of the Energy and Commerce Committee, I also worked this year to combat the opioid crisis. I am proud that legislation I wrote this year was signed into law as part of our ongoing efforts to end this epidemic.

My bills that are now law give pharmacists the tools they need to help fight fraud and abuse, explore the use of abuse deterrent formulas as opposed to pills that can be crushed or misused in other ways and help to promote the treatment of opioid addiction through telemedicine. In part due to this crisis, life expectancy in the United States has dropped for the second time in three years. We must end this once and for all.

Also this year, we were able to make great improvements in our infrastructure here in the 1st District and across the nation. Working together with Georgia Senators Johnny Isakson and David Perdue, we were able to secure the critical funding necessary to keep the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project on track. With this commitment, we are one step closer to realizing the full economic impact expanding our harbor will have on the nation and the world. We will continue fighting for this federal support to keep the project moving forward and on time until it becomes a reality.

As the proud representative of every branch of the military, I had the privilege of visiting our troops and installations throughout the year to not only hear what needs to be done and how I can help, but to also say thank you.

Our service members sacrifice so much to defend our freedoms. One of my top priorities this year, and every year, is to provide the resources necessary to strengthen the 1st District’s military presence. I am also very glad that we were able to provide military members with an extremely well deserved pay raise – the largest raise in 9 years.

While 2018 was an extremely productive year, I look forward to serving you for another two years. Together I believe we will accomplish great things.

I am committed to continuing the hard work on these priorities as we enter a new Congress next year. I am prepared to work with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to continue to deliver results.

I am always mindful that while my voting card may have my picture on it, it belongs to the residents of the 1st District of Georgia. I look forward to seeing you in the new year.

ISSUES & LEGISLATION 
|  
NEWSROOM 


December 29, 2018 
TRAFALGAR ROAD FIRE UPDATE
I toured the Trafalgar Road Fire site with Governor Asa Hutchinson and representatives from EnSafe, the environmental engineering company that is charged with evaluating the situation and remediation efforts. This was my second visit to the site, and I can confirm that local, state, and federal officials continue to work together to ensure the safety and security of residents. 
Following the visit, I joined Governor Hutchinson and members of the community for a press conference. He announced that the situation will be declared an emergency in the coming days. This will help cut through bureaucratic red tape and move remediation efforts forward. Additionally, the state will provide funds to extinguish the fire and eliminate hazards. 
The Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency will continue to monitor the air quality as an action plan is developed. This is about the quality of life and safety of our Bella Vista community. My office will remain involved in safety efforts and keep the public updated on the situation. Additional resources for residents can be found here. 
￼ 

GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN
The government shutdown continues, and it seems unlikely that a deal will be reached anytime soon. House Republicans voted to keep the government open and fund the wall, but the Democrats in the Senate have refused to act. 
Senate Democrats are determined to block the funding bill and refuse to support securing our border. This is peculiar, given that Democrats previously supported border security. This isn’t just rhetoric – in a 2009 speech, Senator Chuck Schumer said that “any immigration solution must recognize that we must do as much as we can to gain operational control of our borders as soon as possible.” 
He continued: “Between 2005 and 2009, a vast amount of progress has been made on our borders and ports of entry. This progress includes…construction of 630 miles of border fence that create a significant barrier to illegal immigration on our southern land border.” 
Securing our border is a national security issue. Senator Schumer previously recognized that. It’s time for Democrats to come to the table and end this shutdown. I want an open government, not open borders. 
Watch my recent Fox News interview with David Asman where I discussed border funding and the partial government shutdown here. 
￼ 
HAPPY NEW YEAR
It is an honor and great privilege to represent Arkansas’s Third Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives. As we look toward the New Year, I would like to say 'thank you' for the opportunity to serve you and the people of AR-3. I look forward to continuing to work on your behalf in the coming Congress and fighting for a stronger and more prosperous nation. Be sure to look for a roundup of 2018 highlights in your inbox in the coming days. 
Wishing you and your family a happy and healthy New Year! 
￼ 
Remember to keep an eye on my website or check out my Twitter and Instagram pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington. 

From the front...
￼  Congressman Steve Womack Arkansas Third District

Subject: Looking Back at 2018
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: December 29, 2018   ￼  
Looking Back at 2018
2018 has been a productive year. The economic benefits of tax reform are on display throughout the country with businesses expanding and jobs being created all around us. While there is much left to be done, I’d like to discuss a few of our proudest accomplishments from the past year.    During the week before Christmas, the Senate passed my bill to help our agricultural producers in the Northport Irrigation District. Once signed into law, this bill will allow individual land owners to repay their portion of federal irrigation infrastructure loans instead of paying only the interest as they have for decades. I was pleased to see the House pass it earlier this year and I thank Senator Fischer for her diligent efforts to shepherd it through the Senate.    Earlier in December, President Trump issued a new rule to supplant President Obama’s vastly overreaching WOTUS rule which threatened the productivity of our farmers and ranchers. When President Obama’s EPA first issued the rule, I introduced a joint resolution to repeal it under the Congressional Review Act (CRA) which easily passed both the House and Senate and forced a veto by President Obama. I appreciate President Trump’s efforts to shield our agricultural producers from overregulation and I look forward to putting this problem behind us for good.     President Trump also recently notified Congress of his intent to negotiate a trade agreement to reduce tariffs and other trade barriers between the United States and Japan. I have long called for such negotiations, including through a House resolution I introduced last year, and I look forward to the 116th Congress when I will take over as co-Chair of the U.S. Japan Congressional Caucus. Through this position, I hope to strengthen our ties with Japanese leaders and build support a mutually beneficial agreement between our two nations.    Among our other accomplishments was an amendment to the FAA’s reauthorization bill which will allow several of Nebraska’s airports to continue receiving safety improvement funding. Many of our airports were hurt by pilot shortages likely brought on by increased pilot regulations which caused them to fall below the traffic threshold required for federal safety funding. Enplanements have already begun to increase under new carriers, and my initiative will help to bridge the gap as Nebraska airports rebounds from this setback.  Last year’s tax reform package was a great accomplishment and I was able to address a number of Nebraska concerns in it, such as maintaining full property tax deductions for agricultural land. This year we were able to ensure the equitable treatment of cooperatives and private grain elevators and buyers under the new tax code by eliminating the “Grain Glitch.” Nebraska’s farmers and ranchers deserve to see the same benefits as other businesses under tax reform.  Overall, it was a very productive year, but there is still much to be done to resolve our current trade disputes and level the playing field for our agricultural producers as well as the Nebraska business sector as a whole. I appreciate President Trump’s leadership on many of these issues and look forward to the many things we can accomplish moving forward.                                              Sincerely, ￼  ADRIAN SMITH Member of Congress

Dear Friend,
A new year and a new Congress are just around the corner. Nancy Pelosi will become Speaker next week, and its uncertain if she’ll want to work with President Trump on common ground for the American people, or if she will use her power to obstruct the president and fight him on behalf of her friends running for president. Despite the uncertainty in Congress, I closed 2018 how I have spent much of the year – meeting with folks in southern Missouri and holding public forums so I can hear thoughts and ideas directly from the people I represent...KEEP READING HERE 


WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH

￼
I hope you and your family had a Merry Christmas! May this wonderful season bring peace and goodwill to you and your family.
￼

Thanks to all the folks who turned out to Dottie's Family Restaurant in Cuba for a public forum on the government shutdown and border security debate. I held two public forums this week and had the opportunity to talk about all kinds of issues important to Missourians including ending the poverty trap, repealing burdensome regulations, and creating jobs.

￼ 
We had a great showing at our public forum at Jen's Diner in Poplar Bluff. I appreciate everyone coming out to share their thoughts and ideas on ending the government shutdown and securing the border so I can share them with the White House.  
￼ I caught up with the press after our public forum in Poplar Bluff and explained why I will be giving up pay until a deal is reached to reopen the government.
￼
Tell Congress: What are YOUR priorities in the new year?

Subject: Jackie's Reads for December 29, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

December 29, 2018 
Dear Friends, 
As 2018 draws to a close, I hope you will join me in taking some time to reflect on the past year and consider the opportunities and challenges ahead of us. There is much to be thankful for and celebrate -- including the passage of landmark legislation to finally hold Members of Congress personally liable for sexual harassment and retaliation. And there is much more work to be done to ensure everyone in our great country has a chance at achieving their American Dream.
That is why I am sharing with you the following articles and editorials that have captured my interest this past week. By remaining abreast of current events and educating ourselves through verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and seize opportunities for positive change.    
I wish you all a happy, healthy, and prosperous New Year. 
Happy reading and all the best,   ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
'What if someone was shooting?'
More than 4 million children endured lockdowns last school year, a groundbreaking Washington Post analysis found. The experience left many traumatized.
By Steven Rich and John Woodrow Cox, The Washington Post
￼
Locked behind their green classroom door, MaKenzie Woody and 25 other first-graders huddled in the darkness. She sat on the vinyl tile floor against a far wall, beneath a taped-up list of phrases the kids were encouraged to say to each other: “I like you,” “You’re a rainbow,” “Are you ok?”
In that moment, though, the 6-year-old didn’t say anything at all, because she believed that a man with a gun was stalking the hallways of her school in the nation’s capital, and MaKenzie feared what he might do to her.
To read the complete Washington Post article, please click here. 
Two children have died in US border custody this month. Before that, none in a decade. Why now?
￼
By Doug Stanglin, USA TODAY
On Christmas Eve, an 8-year-old Guatemalan boy who suffered a cough, vomiting and fever died in U.S. custody at a New Mexico hospital. The boy, identified by Guatemalan officials as Felipe Gomez Alonzo, was the second child in three weeks to die while being detained near the U.S.-Mexico border by U.S. authorities. 
Jakelin Caal, 7, also Guatemalan, died Dec. 8. at an El Paso children's hospital after being detained with her father and while preparing to travel by bus to a Border Patrol station in New Mexico. 
The back-to-back deaths prompted an outcry from immigration activists, politicians and human rights groups and raised questions about the Trump administration policies that have separated children and parents and filled detention centers. 
To read the complete USA TODAY article, please click here. 
Trump’s presidency has changed Washington, defied convention
By Jonathan Lemire, AP
Mr. Trump went to Washington. And he changed it. 
In his first two years in office, President Donald Trump has rewritten the rules of the presidency and the norms of the nation’s capital, casting aside codes of conduct and traditions that have held for generations. 
In Trump’s Washington, facts are less relevant. Insults and highly personal attacks are increasingly employed by members of both parties. The White House press briefing is all but gone, international summits are optional, the arts are an afterthought and everything — including inherently nonpartisan institutions and investigations — is suddenly political. 
To read the complete AP article, please click here. 
Trump’s Syria decision was essentially correct. Here’s how he can make the most of it
By Robert S. Ford, The Washington Post
President Trump’s Dec. 23 tweet promising a “slow and highly coordinated” withdrawal of U.S. forces from Syria may ease the gnashing of teeth among officials and analysts in Washington, but it won’t end the criticism of his decision. That is precisely why the president should view the hullabaloo that erupted after he announced the Syrian pullout as an opportunity to take a number of steps to make the most of his essentially correct, but widely unpopular, move. 
To read the complete Washington Post op-ed, please click here.

Subject: Louis Farrakhan Thanks You
Message:
December 29, 2018

￼
The Nation of Islam preaches that “Hitler was a very great man” and white people are “blue-eyed devils.” 
  
So why did Louis Farrakhan’s notorious hate group receive taxpayer money to provide federal inmates with “spiritual guide services?” 
  
Read below and let me know if you think this is how your taxpayer dollars should be spent. I certainly don't - which is why I'm writing to the Justice Department demanding an immediate end to this funding.
  
Vern 
  
￼ 
  
Nation of Islam receiving federal cash to teach prisoners 
Alana Goodman 
  
The Nation of Islam and its leaders have received hundreds of thousands of dollars from the U.S. government since 2008 to teach religious study programs for federal prison inmates, according to records reviewed by the Washington Examiner. 
  
A black nationalist group led by Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam preaches that white people are “blue-eyed devils” and Jews are “the synagogue of Satan." Its leaders have received at least $364,500 in contracts and awards from the U.S. Bureau of Prisons and the Department of Justice between fiscal 2008 and fiscal 2019.
  
The funding was designed to provide "Nation of Islam religious services," "Nation of Islam spiritual guide services," "Nation of Islam study services," and other related programming led by the organization’s leaders, according to Bureau of Prison records. The Nation of Islam has been labeled a hate group by the Anti-Defamation League and the Southern Poverty Law Center.
  
New York Republican Peter King, chairman of the House Homeland Security Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence, told the Washington Examiner the funding was "beyond the pale."
  
He said: "Categorically, no group or entity or individual associated any way with Farrakhan or the Nation of Islam should receive any federal funding.
  
What Farrakhan preaches is hatred and anti-Semitism and racism, and to use any federal money for any group that’s he’s involved with that do any type of teaching or proselytizing is just wrong."

Saturday, December 29, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼

Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 

This week I had the priviledge of swearing-in my sister, Rosie Cuellar, as Webb County’s new Tax Assessor Collector. Rosie is the former City of Laredo Municipal Court Judge.

In the district, my staff attended numerous meetings and events, including the Doctor’s Hospital at Renaissance (DHR) State of the Hospital Address, the swearing-in ceremonies of several Laredo political officials, and guided tours around the Capitol, amongst others. 

In honor of the upcoming new year, I have also included a video from the Federal Emergency Management Agency that details ways you can resolve to better prepare yourselves in the event of an emergency in 2019.
As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency.

Lastly, I hope you join my staff and I for a Swearing-In Ceremony and New Office Open House on Thursday, January 3, 2019. 

￼

Congressman Swears in Rosie Cuellar
￼
On Thursday, December 27, I had the opportunity to swear-in my sister Rosie Cuellar as Webb County’s new Tax Assessor Collector. Rosie is also the former City of Laredo Municipal Court Judge.
 
Congressman Cuellar with Webb County Sheriff and Tax Assessor Collector 
￼
On Thursday, December 27, I met up with my brother Webb County Sheriff Martin Cuellar during the swearing-in of our sister Rosie Cuellar as Webb County’s Tax Assessor Collector. From left are Webb County Sheriff Martin Cuellar, Webb County Tax Assessor Collector Rosie Cuellar, and Congressman Henry Cuellar.
 
DHR State of the Hospital Address
￼
On Thursday, December 21, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr County, Nichole Hernandez, attended the Doctor’s Hospital at Renaissance (DHR) State of the Hospital Address in the Rio Grande Valley, Texas. This event included educated stakeholders and employees about the latest advancements at DHR Health and what’s to come in 2019.

Swearing-In Ceremony for Re-Elected Mayor Pete Saenz
￼
On Friday, December 22, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties, Francis Atwell, attended the swearing-in ceremony for the newly-reelected mayor of Laredo, Texas, Pete Saenz. The ceremony took place at Laredo City Hall and was officiated by Federal Magistrate John Kazen. Pictured from left are: Mayor Pete Saenz and Francis Atwell. 

Swearing-In Ceremony for Councilman Elect District 3 Mercurio ‘Merc’ Martinez
￼
On Friday, December 22, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties, Francis Atwell, attended the swearing-in ceremony for the newly-elected councilman of Distric 3 in Laredo, Texas, Mercurio ‘Merc’ Martinez. The ceremony took place at Laredo City Hall. Pictured from left are: Francis Atwell and Councilman Martinez. 

Swearing in Ceremony for Councilman District 2 Vidal Rodriguez
￼
On Friday, December 22, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties, Francis Atwell, attended the swearing-in ceremony for the newly-elected councilman of District 2 in Laredo, Texas, Vidal Rodriguez. The ceremony took place at Laredo City Hall. Pictured from left are: Councilman Rodriguez and Francis Atwell. 

Guided Tour of the Capitol in Washington, DC
￼
On Thursday, December 27, my Legislative Correspondent in Washington, DC, Patrick O’Connor, guided a tour of the Capitol for Laredo Constituents Lorena Rodriguez and Glenn Ruiz, Jr. To schedule a tour of your own, visit my website: www.cuellar.house.gov. Picture from left are: Patrick O’Conner, Lorena Rodriguez, and Glenn Ruiz, Jr. 

New Year, New Plan: Be Prepared in 2019
￼ 
With the year drawing to a close, many people begin considering New Year’s resolutions. This video from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) demonstrates ways you can resolve to be more prepared for emergencies in the coming new year.  

 
Happy New Year!

￼ 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

December 29, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review




December 24

A Little Wisdom on Christmas Eve: I promise a very brief Christmas post tomorrow, but here on Christmas Eve, I wanted to at least send you a copy of my Christmas Card. I’ve always loved this verse from Micah, and it’s my prayer that in these crazy political times all of us as participants would have the wisdom to grab a bit more Micah in what we do and the way we do it.
The construct, I think, is fascinating.
We are to do justice…it’s simply a requirement. But we are to actually love mercy and kindness. This goes well beyond the notion of being a requirement to being a duty of the heart in the way that we conduct ourselves and relate one to the other. Equally fascinating is the second duty of the heart in the way that we are to walk with our God above and those around us…humbly.
If there were just a bit more of those three things in Washington, I suspect our national enterprise would be on much firmer footing.
So I wish you the best in last-minute Christmas shopping and all that you may have to do in preparation for tomorrow, but for now, know how much I wish for you a joyous Holiday season and a happy Christmas Eve.  

￼

￼

December 25

Merry Christmas: Merry Christmas!

I hope your day is a great one and that you’re in the company of those you love.

I also hope the Christmas spirit gets you. In the Christian faith, much of that is about love and the way in which each one of us can be a reflection of God’s love to the other. It’s also to be remembered in the midst of gift-giving of how it is better to give than to receive and how above all things we, in the form of time and presence, can be the greatest of all gifts to those that we love.

Indeed, it’s an important day, and I hope a joyous one for you, family, and friends.

Merry Christmas!



￼


￼
December 26
Thank You and Farewell: I hope that Christmas Day was great for you, family, and friends. Happy Post-Christmas, and before long, it will be Happy New Year!
I’ve embedded below text from the genesis of what would have been my farewell address on the House floor. As it turned out, last week was chaotic and the time that I have reserved on the floor got washed out with all the upheaval that Thursday delivered in Washington.
Take a look below, and know that it has but two main messages:
One, thank you for your part in allowing my time in the arena of politics. It’s been an honor, and I am most appreciative.
Two, we are headed for a shipwreck if we don’t change course. I walk through some of the ingredients of what we need to be careful about in the pages below, but the main point here is what we all know in the way in which Washington cannot continue to do business as it now does and have our republic survive. Click here to read more.                                        
￼
December 27  Tax Cuts 3.0: Last Thursday, the House voted on a package of revisions to the tax code that some called “Tax Cuts 3.0.” It included delays of certain Obamacare taxes, reforms to rules governing retirement savings, changes to the IRS, and technical corrections to the larger tax bill Congress passed last year. It was viewed to be a messaging bill, given that the Senate has made clear that there’s absolutely no chance of its passage.
Think about this. There are several days left in this Congress, and legislation that doesn’t pass in this Congress has to be started from ground zero in the new Congress. So although there was no chance of passage on the Senate side, they advanced this bill knowing it would go back to the drawing board on January 3rd as a way of somehow scoring political points.
I have voted for essentially every component part of the bill over this Congress. But amalgamating these different bills and passing them in the 11th hour as a messaging bill to me made no sense.
If we’re going to message, can we ever message on cuts to spending? Click here to read more. 
￼
                                

￼
Click above to read the Legislative Review.

￼
December 28  Debate over Government Funding: It’s sad the degree to which politics is at times theater.
I think at the end of the day this well describes what took place last Thursday with our vote on a continuing resolution to fund government through February 8th.
Its mechanics were fairly straight forward: to fund that which had not been funded permanently on a short-term basis through February. Short-term pending measures are by no means the way in which to fund government, and they’re certainly not a mechanism that I have been supportive of in the way we fund our federal government.
But this is where the theater comes in….
It would fund a number of agencies that had not received appropriation. These were smaller agencies that had been saved for last because the issues surrounding them, in this case the wall, were contentious. Click here to read more.

Subject: My Year In Review
Message:
￼ 

About Grassley
Constituent Services
News Center
Contact Grassley


Photos: My Year in Review
An online version of these photos can be found here.  
￼ 
I met with-then Iowa Secretary of Agriculture Bill Northey in January before he was confirmed to be the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Under Secretary for Farm and Foreign Agricultural Service.  
￼ 
In honor of the reauthorization of the Maternal, Infant and Early Childhood Home Visiting program that I introduced with Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey, I met with actress Jennifer Garner and other advocates to discuss the program's benefits for families across America.
￼ 
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which I chair, and the Senate Commerce Committee to answer hours of questions about data privacy.
￼ 
￼ 
I paid tribute to 93 veterans from Eastern Iowa who were visiting the memorials dedicated to their service and sacrifice, including the World War II, Vietnam and Korean War memorials, as well as the Arlington National Cemetery, as part of the Honor Flight program.
￼ 
I greeted witnesses Amanda Nguyen and actor Terry Crews ahead of the Judiciary Committee hearing I chaired on the Survivors’ Bill of Rights, a 2016 law I led that secured new rights for survivors of sexual assault.
￼ 
I visited the Iowa State Fair this year where I celebrated 4-H day by thanking volunteers.
 ￼ 
I greeted over 65 Habitat for Humanity volunteers working to restore Marshalltown after it was devastated by a tornado. They helped Iowans rebuild after losing everything.
￼ 
￼ 
As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I led the confirmation process for Justice Brett Kavanaugh, who was confirmed by the Senate on October 6, 2018. 
￼ 
I had a great meeting with leaders of the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association. This year, I led efforts to put pressure on the EPA to stop issuing “hardship waivers” to obligated refiners as well as make the waiver process more transparent and highlight the importance of the RFS to President Trump. 
￼ 
I gave my Instagram and Twitter followers an insider look at farming operations and tracked the progression of the corn crop grown on the Grassley family farm in New Hartford, Iowa from planting through harvest. #CornWatch
￼ 
I completed my 38th annual #99CountyMeetings, with at least one Q&A in every county, every year. I began my 2018 meetings in Harrison County in January and finished in Clarke County in September.
￼ 
The USS Sioux City was commissioned on November 17, 2018 in Annapolis, Maryland. This is the first warship commissioned at the Naval Academy. I am proud to have the USS Sioux City protecting our nation at sea.
￼ 
It was an honor to attend President George H. W. Bush's funeral service at the National Cathedral. President Bush will be missed, but his life and service to our nation will be celebrated.
￼ 
Senator Joni Ernst, my friend and colleague, was elected to serve as Vice Chair of the Senate Republican Conference. She will serve Senate Republicans superbly, just as she serves Iowans.
￼ 
The Senate passed the First Step Act, which I cosponsored with Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois. This bill will reduce crime, strengthen faith in our justice system, support law enforcement and give thousands of people a better shot at living a good life.

Subject: One Week And Counting
Message:
Can't see the pictures? Select "Always display images" or Click here to open in browser.
 
￼
One Week And Counting


￼
#TrumpShutdown 
Regrettably, America has now entered a Trump Shutdown.  Republicans control the House, the Senate, and the White House.  But instead of honoring his responsibility to the American people, President Trump threw a temper tantrum and convinced his party to push our nation into a destructive Trump Shutdown in the middle of the holiday season.  President Trump has said more than 25 times that he wanted a shutdown and now he has gotten what he wanted. 
We have offered Republicans multiple proposals to keep the government open, including one that already passed the Senate unanimously, and all of which include funding for strong, sensible, and effective border security – not the president’s ineffective and expensive wall.  If President Trump chooses to continue this Trump Shutdown, the new House Democratic majority will swiftly pass legislation to re-open government in January. 
￼ 
Death of Felipe Alonzo-Gomez at the Border
On Christmas, an eight-year-old boy died in the custody of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, which followed the death of seven-year-old Jakelin Amei Rosmery Caal Maquin earlier this month. The tragic death of an innocent child on Christmas Day breaks the hearts of all. 
We all have a moral responsibility to ensure all children of God are treated with compassion and decency.  The death now of two children in U.S. custody is unconscionable. 
I have called on Homeland Security’s Inspector General to immediately open an investigation into Felipe Alzono-Gomez’s death.  The Congress will also investigate this tragedy and the heartbreaking death of Jakelin Amei Rosmery Caal Maquin, to seek justice and ensure that no other child is left to such a fate. 
￼ 

Frequently Asked Questions on the Trump Government Shutdown 
Will my mail still arrive during the shutdown? Yes.  The U.S. Postal Service is not affected by a government shutdown.  The U.S. Postal Service is an independent entity that is funded through the sale of its products and services, and not by tax dollars.   Will I continue to receive my Social Security checks? Yes.  During a government shutdown, recipients continue to receive their Social Security checks.    Will Medicare and Medicaid be interrupted? No.  The operations of Medicare and Medicaid will operate normally during the shutdown.    Can I get taxpayer assistance from IRS personnel during the shutdown? It will likely be difficult.  If the Trump Shutdown goes into January, it will have a significant impact on the IRS.  While the shutdown continues, 90 percent of the IRS staff is furloughed.  IRS’s “tax filing season” is January-April.  Beginning in January, some Americans will start thinking about filing their 2018 taxes, due April 15, 2019.  This will be the first year when Americans are filing their taxes under the new GOP tax law, and many will have numerous questions.  If the Trump Shutdown continues, the limited IRS staff will be unable to keep up with the questions coming in from taxpayers using the IRS customer service hotline.    Can I get a passport during the shutdown? Perhaps, with it depending on where you live.  The U.S. Passport Agency remains open during the shutdown and continues to issue passports.  However, depending on where you live, the State Department could curtail issuing passports where those passport services are offered in buildings run by another agency that is shut down.      Will I be able to continue visiting the national parks during the shutdown?  The Trump Administration claims that the vast majority of national parks are “open” during the shutdown (on the grounds that barriers have not been put up at the parks to prevent entry.)  However, the fact is that there are no services for visitors to National Park Service sites during the shutdown.  Services such as restrooms, visitors’ centers, campgrounds, information kiosks, trash removal, and interpretative programs are all closed during the shutdown.  The vast majority of National Park Service employees are furloughed.  Also, law enforcement staffing is sharply curtailed, so visitors’ safety will be put at risk.  Which federal departments are affected by the Trump Shutdown? There are nine federal departments affected by the Trump Shutdown:  Homeland Security, Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, HUD, Justice, Commerce, Transportation, and State.  In addition, numerous critical smaller independent agencies, including EPA, the Small Business Administration, and NASA, are affected.  (The six federal departments that are already fully funded for FY 2019 and are not affected by the Trump Shutdown are:  Defense, Veterans Affairs, HHS, Education, Labor, and Energy.)        How many federal employees have to work without pay during the Trump Shutdown?  There are approximately 420,000 federal employees, deemed “essential,” including FBI agents, DEA agents, Secret Service agents, and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents, who are being required to work without pay during the Trump Shutdown.  None of them will receive a paycheck until the shutdown is over and the government re-opens.  The longer the Trump Shutdown lasts, the longer they are working without a paycheck, increasing their families’ financial difficulties.  How many federal employees have been put on unpaid furlough during the Trump Shutdown? There are also approximately 380,000 federal employees who have been placed on unpaid furlough during the Trump Shutdown. They are also not receiving any pay during the Trump Shutdown.   Will the 420,000 federal employees forced to work without pay during the shutdown receive the pay for their work when the shutdown is over? Yes.  Under federal law, those federal employees forced to work without pay in the shutdown are guaranteed the pay they have earned when the government re-opens.  Will the 380,000 federal employees who were placed on unpaid furlough during the shutdown receive back pay when the shutdown is over? That will be up to the Congress and the White House. Legislation would have to be enacted.  The precedent has been that furloughed employees are later paid, through legislation.  Indeed, after every previous shutdown, Congress has passed legislation mandating that furloughed workers get paid.  What is the impact of the Trump Shutdown on small businesses? A shutdown halts federal loans to small businesses.  During a shutdown, the Small Business Administration stops approving applications for small businesses to obtain loans and guarantees, typically $1 billion per month.  Indeed, on Dec. 22, SBA put a notice on Facebook simply stating, “Due to the lapse in government funding, SBA will remain inactive until further notice.”    What is the impact on home mortgage applications? During the shutdown, the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) will see significant delays in loan processing and approvals, due to the furloughing of most employees.  Thousands of people trying to buy a new home or refinance a FHA-insured mortgage will likely be put on standby.   What is the impact on FDA’s food safety activities? During the Trump Shutdown, the FDA will be unable to support a number of its food safety activities.  FDA has furloughed 40 percent of its employees.  As a result, it will have to reduce its routine inspections of domestic food facilities.  For example, in the 16-day GOP shutdown in 2013, the FDA had to delay nearly 360 food safety inspections.
 
￼ 
My office assisted with preventing the potential revocation of the non-profit (501c3) status for a local community nonprofit. Due to erroneous filings by the organization, they feared their status had already been revoked. With the assistance of my office, the organization was advised to quickly file the correct paperwork to retain their status.
Caseworkers in my San Francisco office work to address any problems or concerns you may have with a federal government agency. To submit a Casework Authorization Form, please visit my website. 


Please feel free to forward this information to your family and friends. To learn more about these efforts, express your views, or sign up for email updates, please visit my website. 
best regards,  ￼

• Legislative Highlights
 
 
 

180-day transition for IR parole

Humanitarian parole policies, under which about 1,500 people currently live in the Marianas, will end on December 31. But those affected will have a 180-day transition period to look for some other immigration status or arrange to leave the islands, USCIS Director L. Francis Cissna told me in a call and letter on Thursday. I worked with the Obama administration to put the parole policy in place in 2011. But President Trump declared his intention to limit use of parole in his executive order of January 25, 2017. The groups losing parole include spouses and parents of U.S. citizens in the Marianas, immediate relatives of citizens of the Freely Associated States, certain stateless individuals and persons with permanent resident status, and in-home caregivers. They were covered by my language in S. 744, passed by the Senate in 113th Congress. But House Republicans would not take up the bill. My legislation, H.R. 1466 in the 112th Congress, also tried to fix the problem. But Governor Fitial got Republicans in Congress to block it. Now that Democrats will control the House, I will re-introduce legislation to help protect those losing parole and keep families together.
 
 
 

January
 

CW bill introduced. Senator Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) and I introduced the Northern Mariana Islands U.S. Workforce Act. The bill was the product of many hours of discussion within a bipartisan, bicameral working group that was formed to craft a long-term labor policy for the Northern Marianas. The bill sought to give the Marianas access to foreign labor for another 10 years, allow for 13,000 CW workers, and create a new visa category to give long-time foreign workers more certainty.
 

February
 

Confronting the opioid crisis. As Ranking Member of the Health, Employment, Labor, and Pensions Subcommittee, I spoke on behalf of Democrats on how the opioid epidemic is affecting America’s workplaces. The human toll is incalculable and billions of dollars are lost from the injuries, absenteeism, and lost productivity stemming from opioid abuse. We need safer workplaces, stronger consumer protections in health law, and greater access to treatment to combat this problem.
 

March
 

Students lead to stop gun violence. I joined Washington, D.C.-area students on the grounds of the U.S. Capitol on National Walkout Day. These smart, articulate, and politically engaged young adults seek sensible gun control policy. I could not agree more.
 

$1.3 trillion spending bill passes. Congress enacted a $1.3 trillion omnibus appropriations law that funded the federal government through September 30, 2018. Funding remained steady or even went up for many federal programs President Trump wanted to cut back or eliminate. Many are important to the Marianas and on my priorities list submitted to the Appropriations Committee, including the preserved 1.5 percent set-aside in water and sewer grants for insular areas that we began in 2010.
 
 

CODEL Murkowski. Senator Lisa Murkowski, who chairs the Senate Energy and Natural Resources, led a congressional delegation, including Rep. Amata Aumua Coleman Radewagen (R-American Samoa) and myself, through the Pacific. This time spent building relationship has made it possible to keep the Northern Marianas Islands U.S. Workforce Act moving forward since the Senator and I introduced the bill in January.
 

April
 

Veterans Resource Fair a success. More than 300 veterans, service members, military family members, providers, and members of the public turned out for the 2018 Northern Marianas Veterans Resource Fairs, held on Rota, Tinian, and Saipan — nearly double last year’s turnout. Improving access to services for Marianas veterans and their families is one of my top priorities as a member of House Veterans Affairs Committee. And better access begins with raising awareness about the services that exist.
 
 

App Challenge winners impress in DC. Daniel Villarmero and Chenoa Bunts-Anderson, Marianas winners of the Congressional App Challenge, showcased their “Student Companion” app in Washington, DC.  
 

May
 

New funds bring iPads to PSS. The CNMI Public School System put 3,000 new iPads in students’ hands thanks to the funding formula I added to the Every Student Succeeds Act in 2015, which brought in $4.1 million this year. Students now use the iPads to learn about coding, math, and problem-solving.
 
 

Renovated troop store. The newly-renovated Saipan Army Reserve Center was unveiled and dedicated to the memory of Army SSG Wilgene Lieto and SPC Derence Jack, who gave their lives during service in Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Army and Air Force Exchange Service troop store had its grand opening. A study I included in the 2011 National Defense Authorization Act led to the 5,000-foot expansion of the store, which serves 4,000 active and reserve service members, retirees, and their families.
 

June

Veterans clinic signed into law. President Trump signed the VA MISSION Act, which requires a feasibility study for a veterans’ health clinic in the Marianas. I put Section 213 into the legislation to advance the goal of getting our own Community-Based Outpatient Clinic. Getting a favorable feasibility study is the same strategy we used successfully to expand the AAFES troop store on Saipan.
 

July

U.S. Workforce Act becomes law. President Trump signed the Northern Mariana Islands U.S. Workforce Act. U.S. Public Law 115-218 gave the Marianas economy access to foreign labor for 10 more years and more protections for U.S. workers and local businesses. The legislation also provided 13,000 Marianas-only CW visas beginning in fiscal year 2019, averting the economic disaster that would have resulted from the Trump administration’s earlier move to cut CW slots down to 4,999.
 
 

CODIFY CNMI is up and running. Codify CNMI organizers Blane Wilson and Darren Demapan asked me to introduce them to the CNMI Public School System’s leadership to collaborate on a summer program to teach coding to middle and high school students. I put them in touch and got to see the results: a workshop in full swing at Dandan Middle School, with over a dozen students learning how to code.
 

August

NDAA is law, $51 million to Tinian divert. President Trump signed the John S. McCain National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2019 authorizing $50.7 million for Air Force divert airfield projects on Tinian. $46 million will go towards construction of a cargo pad with taxiway extension and $4.7 million for a maintenance support facility north of the Tinian airport. Section 2863 bars the Defense Department from spending anything on public infrastructure in the Marianas until an Economic Adjustment Committee reports to Congress on what civilian projects are needed to support proposed military activities. The report is due in May 2019.
 

September
 

Making sure Rota is cared for. Rota bore the brunt of Typhoon Mangkhut, so I was there the next day visiting families and making sure that federal agencies were doing everything to help Rota and the Commonwealth government respond. 
 

October
 

Yutu relief takes top priority. Super Typhoon Yutu ravaged Tinian and Saipan on October 24-25, killing at least one, injuring over 130, and causing massive destruction to homes, businesses, and public infrastructure. Within days of Yutu’s landfall, I got pledges from incoming Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi and the House Appropriations Committee that the Marianas will be included in any supplemental funding bill for U.S. areas hit by natural disasters this year. The congressional office also served as a temporary registration center for disaster aid applications and an online hub for relief and recovery information following the typhoon.
 

More CIP funds for water. President Trump signed the America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018, doubling the authorization for the Safe Drinking Water Act from $1 billion to $1.95 billion in 2021. Because I got the insular set-aside increased beginning in 2010, the Marianas got a larger share of this money. 
 

November
 

Hearing probes disaster response. As a guest of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, I questioned FEMA Administrator Brock Long on his agency’s delivery of services in the Marianas after Typhoon Mangkhut and Super Typhoon Yutu. For instance, power and water were slow to be restored. Disaster Recovery Centers took weeks to open. And wait times for inspections took much longer than FEMA promised. The hearing was focused on recurring problems with disaster response nationwide, many of which we have seen in the Marianas. 
 

December

$100M+ for Marianas recovery. The House passed a disaster assistance bill that includes at least $100 million for the Marianas. This is the first time the Marianas has ever been included in a disaster appropriation that provides money above and beyond what FEMA brings to a recovery effort. The bill’s fate in the Senate is undecided because it includes a controversial $5 billion President Trump has demanded for a border wall.
 
 
 


OPPORTUNITIES

	•	Do you want to work on Capitol Hill for a House Democratic Member of Congress? Enter your information into the official resume bank for House Democrats: www.democraticwhip.gov/resumes. Your submission will be visible to current House Democratic staff only.

	•	APS Practice Survey

THIS WEEK
No votes were scheduled.

NEXT WEEK

Subject: Latest News from Congressman Steve Cohen
Message:

News from Congressman Steve Cohen 
￼ ￼ 
Website
|
Serving You
|
Legislative Work
|
Our District
|
Resources
￼
December 28, 2018 
 
Dear Friend, 

This week, the federal government remained partially shutdown by an unnecessary demand by the President for funding for a border wall. In addition to pushing back against the Trump shutdown, I met with constituents and went on CNN to emphasize the need for overdue oversight of the Trump administration, announced a grant for Early Head Start programs at Porter-Leath, expressed concern at the death of a second child migrant in U.S. custody this month, and offered a holiday health tip about getting enough sleep. Keep reading to learn more about my week and follow me on Twitter and Facebookto see more updates as they happen. 
Criticizing Trump’s Government Shutdown  Talking Future Oversight of Trump Administration on CNN  Announcing $2.3 million Early Head Start Grant to Porter-Leath  Expressing Concern at a Second Death of a Child Migrant in U.S. Custody  Appearing on MSNBC on Sunday  Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars  Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter   Weekly Health Tip  Quote of the Week 


Criticizing Trump’s Government Shutdown 
This week, for the third time in Trump’s presidency, portions of the federal government shut down.  This time it was because of Trump’s 11th hour demand for a border wall that the President said Mexico would pay for, not taxpayers. As he boasted how “proud” he was to shut down the government, I spoke out against it. The public deserves and expects the programs and services it pays for to stay open and work. I will continue to work to reopen the government, and get federal employees back to work for the American people. 
Talking Future Oversight of Trump Administration on CNN 
On Wednesday, I went on CNN with Dana Bash who asked me about oversight of the Trump administration after Democrats take the Majority in the House on January 3. I told her oversight is a basic duty of Congress that has been neglected during the past two years and that that will change in the year ahead. See the interview here.  
Announcing $2.3 million Early Head Start Grant to Porter-Leath 
￼  
On Thursday, I announced that Porter-Leath will be receiving a $2,330,982 Early Head Start grant from the Department of Health and Human Services Head Start Office. Early Head Start helps at-risk children under three years old develop the skills they need to give them and their families a shot at the American Dream. I was pleased to announce this important grant funding is heading to Memphis. I appreciate the outstanding work Mike Warr and his staff do at Porter-Leath. 
Expressing Concern at a Second in-Custody Death of a Child Migrant 
￼ 
On Christmas Eve, an 8-year-old Guatemalan boy, Felipe Gomez Alonzo, died while in U.S. custody.  This follows the death of a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl, Jakelin Caal Maquin, earlier this month.  While I understand the necessity of border patrol stations, I am concerned that these overcrowded stations are unhealthy to the point of death. After Jakelin’s death, I wrote to Secretary of Homeland Security Kirstjen Nielsen urging her to take immediate steps to end the policy of deterring migrants from applying for asylum at ports of entry which has led these desperate asylum seekers to attempt crossings at dangerous areas. Asylum is a human right and people seeking it must be protected.  I will continue to support oversight of the Department of Homeland Security and seek answers about how these unfortunate deaths occurred.

Appearing on MSNBC on Sunday 
On Sunday, I’ll join MSNBC’s Frances Rivera in the noon hour in Memphis to talk about the ongoing government shutdown, the border wall and the new Congress that convenes January 3.  
Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars   
￼ 
My office has a limited number of 2019 U.S. Capitol Historical Society calendars available. If you would like to receive a calendar, please complete this form on my website. Due to the rules of the House, I can mail calendars only to residents of Tennessee’s 9th Congressional District. Please feel free to share this email with other residents of the 9th District who may be interested in receiving one but who do not receive my e-Newsletter.   
Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter   

￼  
I enjoy meeting regularly with constituents in the district and helping get answers for them to questions about dealing with federal agencies. If you are interested in attending one of my “Congress on Your Corner” events, you can sign up hereto receive notification as soon as the next event is scheduled.   
For those who haven’t participated in a telephone town hall, it’s easy to sign up for them by using this form.     
If you would like to receive this weekly e-Newsletter, or share it with others, you can do that with this form.   
Weekly Health Tip 
￼ 
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), getting enough sleep is not a luxury; it’s a necessity for maintaining good health and avoiding mistakes and injuries. See the CDC’s sleep guidelines and recommendations here.  
Quote of the Week 
￼ 
“I’ve been in politics over 50 years in a number of positions and working under nine presidents. I’ve never seen a situation like this, in which almost every important area that is key to this country is confronting crisis.” – Former Defense Secretary, CIA Director, Budget Director and Member of Congress Leon Panetta on “Fox News Sunday.” 
As 2018 draws to an end, I wish all my constituents and friends a very happy 2019. The new year looks to be full of promise.
As always, I remain Most sincerely, 
￼ 
Steve Cohen Member of Congress

Subject: Rep. Peterson's Newsletter 12/28/2018
Message:
￼
NEWSLETTER-MN07: Updates

￼
U.S. Capitol and the Capitol Christmas Tree
 
Dear Friends,
 
Last week, the House and Senate negotiated a reasonable agreement that extended funding for nine agencies until February 8th, 2019. However, at the last minute, House Republican Leadership decided to add controversial funding priorities backed by the Freedom Caucus to our budget knowing it did not have bipartisan support and would not pass the Senate.
 
This is all too familiar given the similar mess the Freedom Caucus caused on the farm bill rule vote. In the late hours of the Rules Committee hearing for the farm bill, Freedom Caucus members inserted the Yemen provision, risking the whole bill.
 
The dysfunction that resulted in this shutdown is a good example of what was at stake had I allowed the horrible Yemen provision to derail the farm bill and push it in to this week. Had we taken the farm bill up a week later, it’s clear now that it would have gotten caught up in the shutdown and we would have no farm bill at all. 
 
As it is, the shutdown leaves producers in a really tough spot, at a time when they’re already hurting. Farmers and ranchers count on USDA to deliver a range of services, many of which are now suspended during the shutdown. For those producers hurt by the Administration’s trade war, they may not be able to access payments under the Market Facilitation Program. FSA borrowers can’t cash checks to pay bills and those hoping to build on-farm grain storage are also in limbo. Finally, the shutdown threatens implementation of the 2018 Farm Bill and its improvements for dairy farmers, and the others counting on the funding and program updates it makes.
 
If you are experiencing any hardships or delays in critical services as a result of this shut down, I encourage you to contact my office. My staff remain ready to advocate on your behalf wherever possible as we work to get our government open again.
 
Sincerely,
￼ Congressman Collin C. Peterson
Minnesota 7th District
 
Christmas Greeting
￼
 
Please click on the image above to play my electronic Christmas card.
 
Heavy Snow Hits the Seventh
￼
 
On December 26 and 27, a storm system brought wind, snow, and blizzard conditions to much of western Minnesota, causing poor travel conditions and more than a foot of snow in some areas. For more information and winter weather safety tips, visit the National Weather Service website. 
 
This Week in American History
￼
The Good Samaritan Episcopal Church today
 
On December 24th, 1869, Sauk Centre’s Church of the Good Samaritan held its first service. This service was the marriage of Nellie A. Barrows to Captain Edward Oakford. This church still stands today, nearly 150 years after that very first service.
 
What’s the Story?
￼
 
In 1991, the Minnesota Twins won the World Series, beating the Atlanta Braves 4-3. In recognition for their sportsmanship and skills, Wheaties cereal recognized two Twins players. Photos of both Kirby Puckett and Kent Hrbek were printed on Wheaties’ cereal boxes. Kirby Puckett was a center fielder and was inducted into the Major League Baseball Hall of Fame in 2001. Kent Hrbek was a first baseman and played for the Twins for fourteen years. Both players helped to secure the World Series win in 1991. I have one of these cereal boxes displayed in my Washington office.
 
￼
Canadian Pacific Holiday Train
Plummer, 2017
