Subject: A look back at 2018
Message:
News from Representative Courtney  Having trouble viewing this email? Click here!     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
 Dear  , 
As we prepare to welcome the new year, I wanted to take a moment to provide you a quick snapshot of the work we have done this year. While it has been an often challenging year for our region and our nation, I’m proud of the work that I’ve done in Connecticut and in Washington for the people of eastern Connecticut. With new opportunities ahead in 2019, I look forward to keeping in touch with you about my work and hearing from you about the priorities you have for the year ahead. 
One of the areas I am most proud of this year is the work my staff does every day to help constituents who have run into issues with their federal benefits or red tape in dealing with federal agencies. Over the course of the year, my dedicated staff has worked on over 1,000 cases from every corner of eastern Connecticut, helping with agencies like the VA or Social Security.  
Thanks to these efforts, we’ve helped return $1,965,729 to constituents who have worked with my office to resolve their cases. This includes nearly $850,000 in back pay and benefit adjustments through the Social Security Administration, over $626,000 in veteran's benefits and pay, and $427,000 in housing assistance such as mortgage rate adjustments and other help. 
As you can see in the examples below, however, not every case is about money or benefits – sometimes it’s about helping someone get their security clearance so they don’t lose their job or helping a veteran receive his or her long overdue military honors. If you think we can help you or someone you know with an issue they are having with federal agencies or benefits, please make sure to call my Norwich office at (860) 886-0139. 

Helping with Federal Student Loans 
Meredith Clermont-Ferrand is a professor at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic and contacted my office seeking assistance with the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) program. A representative from her loan servicer, FedLoan Servicing, claimed that because she had rounded up her past 51 monthly payments-- they would not qualify for the loan forgiveness program. Upon receiving this information, our office sent an inquiry to the U.S. Department of Education requesting clarification and discovered that making an “overpayment” would not disqualify payments. Eventually, we received welcome news that all of Meredith’s payments would count towards her loan forgiveness.  
￼
Meredith Clermont-Ferrand, professor at ECSU

Resolving Mortgage Challenges 
“A.H.”, a homeowner from Canterbury, contacted my office in August regarding her mortgage.  Previously, she was approved for a home modification, but the mortgage servicer had rescinded the new payment plan erroneously. Through ongoing communication and negotiation, my office successfully reinstated the modified plan, which saved the family hundreds of dollars each month and kept their local small business thriving. 
￼
A.H. of Canterbury 
Another homeowner, Ms. Maria Davila of Norwich, contacted my office regarding insurance monies approved by USAA Insurance Co.  Although the claim was approved, her mortgage servicer held the funds for an extended period in a restricted escrow account.  Due to health concerns, it was imperative that the funds be released for a clean air test and mold remediation. My office contacted the mortgage servicer and the first release of funds became available shortly thereafter.  
￼
 Maria Davila of Norwich

Securing overdue honors for our veterans 
Thomas Southiere, a local veteran from Hebron, contacted our office seeking help with an issue he was having with military medals. Mr. Southiere served in Vietnam and upon his return home, was awarded several military decorations but never physically received the medals. Decades later he inquired to our office on how he could acquire his medals. Our office went ahead and contacted the national archives and after a bit of paperwork--our office received the medals and was able to give them to a very happy Mr. Southiere and family in an honorary ceremony. He received 10 medals including the Purple Heart.  
￼
Thomas Southiere of Hebron and his family

Speeding up a slow federal bureaucracy  
Mr. Garbo of Stonington, a private airplane pilot, contacted our office seeking help with an issue he was having with the Federal Aviation Administration. Mr. Garbo had filed to have his license renewed before the looming expiration date but had yet to receive a reply. With the concern that this would jeopardize prescheduled flights made by his clients, our office contacted the FAA for a status update on the renewal and was quickly able to secure a digital copy of the renewed license so there were no flight delays!  
￼
Mr. Bargo of Stonington

Resolving the security clearance backlog 
With the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) clocking in a backlog of 600,000 for background investigations for security clearances--many individuals applying for jobs with security clearances have found the processing time to receive the clearance to take months and sometimes even years. For our region, that means delays in starting jobs at places like Electric Boat or many other jobs across eastern Connecticut. Although I have to withhold names and examples for security reasons, I can tell you that we have assisted dozens of individuals who were waiting months – or even years – for action on their clearance request. In most cases, we were able to positively resolve the issue and get people back to work or onto their new career path.  
￼

Helping connect families with Social Security 
Danielle, a constituent from Plainfield, contacted our office seeking assistance with an issue she was having with the Social Security Administration. Danielle was attempting to acquire survivor benefits for her daughter, Charlie, whose father had recently passed away. The process for SSA to verify the evidence of paternity that Danielle had submitted was taking an elongated period of time, so she reached out to our office for assistance. Our caseworker intervened and helped Danielle get the correct information to SSA to expedite the claim. Shortly thereafter, Danielle and Charlie were able to receive their survivor benefits and were also able to move into their own home.  
￼
Danielle of Plainfield

Let us know how we can help   
These areas are just some of the many areas that my office is available to help with.  Although I cannot override the decisions made by a federal agency, I can often intervene on a person's behalf to answer questions, find solutions, or just cut through the red tape. The first step is to reach out and seek help, which you can do by calling my Norwich District office at (860) 886-0139 or visiting my website at https://courtney.house.gov/services/help-with-a-federal-agency.  
Thank you, again, for taking the time to read this update and others I have sent this year. My best to you and your family for a safe and happy new year.   
Sincerely,                               
￼  Joe Courtney Member of Congress

Subject: The first step in the right direction
Message:

￼￼￼


￼



Biography | How May I Help You? | Policy Issues | News | Our District | Contact




Long’s Short Report – The first step in the right direction
By: Rep. Billy Long
The media likes to portray Congress as Republican vs. Democrat, and although that’s sometimes the case, there are still areas where we can come together and work to advance important legislation. Prison reform is one of those areas. In December, both the House of Representatives and Senate passed the First Step Act with overwhelming bipartisan support. This bill will overhaul the federal criminal justice system, which is long overdue.
There are nearly 200,000 inmates in our federal prison system. Ninety-five percent of these individuals will leave prison, but unfortunately, due to how the system is currently set up, around 38 percent of these inmates will be arrested again within five years of release. Our failure to provide adequate resources for prisoners has led to challenges reintegrating into society. That’s why prison reform is so important. This bill will not only help provides opportunities for inmates to gain valuable skills to become productive, law-abiding members of society, it will also create safer communities.
The First Step Act’s goal is to ensure inmates don’t return to prison by better preparing them for reentry into society. This bill will provide opportunities for inmates to gain valuable skills through vocational training, educational coursework and faith-based programs. This targeted approach will help keep our streets safe and give inmates the ability to make the most of their second chance.
The First Step Act will also create a fairer justice system. This bill will improve mandatory minimums, which over the years have caused overcrowding and excessive costs that hardworking taxpayers end up paying for. Specifically, this bill will reduce harsh sentences for nonviolent drug offenders and reform the three-strike mandatory life provision. It will also expand the safety valve, which will allow judges to avoid handing down mandatory minimums for certain offenses if the individual meets certain criteria.
Like President Trump said, it’s our job to fight for all citizens, even those who have made mistakes. The First Step Act does just that while also creating a safer America.
For more information on my activities in our district and in Washington I encourage you to follow my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/Rep.Billy.Longand my Twitter page at https://twitter.com/USRepLong. You can also subscribe to my weekly newsletter, "Long's Short Report,” at https://longforms.house.gov/newsletter-and-email-updates-form.

Message:
News from Representative Carson

￼
Forward to a Friend 
Upcoming Events: 
Office Hours in Your Neighborhood
  
Where:  Indianapolis Public Library Southport Branch 2630 E. Stop 11 Road Indianapolis, IN 46227                                       When:        Thursday, Jan 10, 2019 4:00-6:00PM 
  
December 28, 2018  
Dear Friend, 
As your representative, it is a privilege to serve you. Everyday I’m working to bring your voice to our nation’s capital and make government work for you. 
This year, my focus has continued to be on supporting and protecting my fellow Hoosiers.
	•	I fought to promote access to good paying jobs through my 9th annual Central Indiana Job Fair. The fair featured more than 145 employers and over 4,400 full and part-time positions. 
	•	I worked to draw attention to our city’s role in our nation's civil rights history by getting the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Park designated as a National Commemorative Site and added to the National Civil Rights Network.
	•	I also continued to proudly serve on the House Intelligence Committee, responding to threats around the world and investigating Russian meddling in our democracy. 
￼ 
This year, Congressman Carson's Kennedy-King Establishment Act was signed into law making the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Park a National Historic Site. 
  
My work in the Congress is about more than legislating – it’s about helping individual Hoosier families. This year, I responded to over 28,000 of your letters, calls, and emails, and helped over 700 Hoosiers navigate our federal bureaucracy by helping them get Veterans, Social Security, or other benefits they’ve rightfully earned.
I am looking forward to starting the 116th Congress and the opportunity it brings to fight for Hoosier values and Midwestern common sense. I will continue to push to protect Medicare and Social Security, support local workers and small business owners, and tackle gun violence, including funding a Centers for Disease Control (CDC) study of gun violence, all while advocating for universal background checks and an assault weapons ban. With the Democrats in the majority, I am also slated to become Chairman of a subcommittee on the House Intelligence Committee, where I will work to strengthen our intelligence agencies to prevent terrorism and fight threats to our security around the world. I also look forward to continuing my work on the House Transportation Committee, where I will prioritize investing in our nation's crumbling infrastructure. 
It is an honor and a privilege to serve you. Best wishes for a happy and healthy 2019!  

Your friend,
￼  André

Subject: How Could the Government Shutdown Affect Me? Here are Some Answers.
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼

HOME
ABOUT G.K.B.
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
 
Frequently Asked Questions from North Carolinians on the December 2018 Government Shutdown 
Will my mail still arrive during the shutdown? 
Yes.  The U.S. Postal Service is not affected by a government shutdown.  The U.S. Postal Service is an independent entity that is funded through the sale of its products and services, and not by tax dollars.  
Will I continue to receive my Social Security checks?  Yes.  During a government shutdown, recipients continue to receive their Social Security checks.  
Will Medicare and Medicaid be interrupted?  No.  The operations of Medicare and Medicaid will operate normally during the shutdown.   
Will veterans' health care and other veterans' programs continue as usual? Yes.  The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs is funded through separate legislation which has already been approved. 
Which federal departments are affected by the partial federal government shutdown? There are nine federal departments affected by the government shutdown:  Homeland Security, Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, HUD, Justice, Commerce, Transportation, and State.  In addition, numerous critical smaller independent agencies, including EPA, the Small Business Administration, and NASA, are affected.  (The six federal departments that are already fully funded for FY 2019 and are not affected by the shutdown are:  Defense, Veterans Affairs, HHS, Education, Labor, and Energy.)  Read Congressman Butterfield's statement on the partial federal government shutdown.  
Can I get taxpayer assistance from IRS personnel during the shutdown?  It will likely be difficult.  If the government shutdown goes into January, it will have a significant impact on the IRS.  While the shutdown continues, 90 percent of the IRS staff is furloughed.  IRS’s “tax filing season” is January-April.  Beginning in January, some Americans will start thinking about filing their 2018 taxes, due April 15, 2019.  This will be the first year when Americans are filing their taxes under the new GOP tax law, and many will have numerous questions.  If the shutdown continues, the limited IRS staff will be unable to keep up with the questions coming in from taxpayers using the IRS customer service hotline.   
Can I get a passport during the shutdown?  Perhaps, with it depending on where you live.  The U.S. Passport Agency remains open during the shutdown and continues to issue passports.  However, depending on where you live, the State Department could curtail issuing passports where those passport services are offered in buildings run by another agency that is shut down.     
Will I be able to continue visiting the national parks during the shutdown?   The Trump Administration claims that the vast majority of national parks are “open” during the shutdown (on the grounds that barriers have not been put up at the parks to prevent entry.)  However, the fact is that there are no services for visitors to National Park Service sites during the shutdown.  Services such as restrooms, visitors’ centers, campgrounds, information kiosks, trash removal, and interpretative programs are all closed during the shutdown.  The vast majority of National Park Service employees are furloughed.  Also, law enforcement staffing is sharply curtailed, so visitors’ safety will be put at risk. 
Will I be able to obtain a new flood insurance policy or renew my existing flood insurance policy during the shutdown? No.  Just yesterday, December 27, the Trump Administration’s FEMA ruled to not renew the National Flood Insurance Program during the shutdown.  The National Association of Realtors (NAR) has stated that this decision by FEMA “jeopardizes tens of thousands of home sales across America, as NAR estimates up to 40,000 closings are disrupted each month that the NFIP cannot issue flood insurance policies.”  
How many federal employees have to work without pay during the government shutdown?   There are approximately 420,000 federal employees, deemed “essential,” including FBI agents, DEA agents, Secret Service agents, and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents, who are being required to work without pay during the shutdown.  None of them will receive a paycheck until the shutdown is over and the government re-opens. The longer President Trump and the Republican-led Congress allow the shutdown to last, the longer these federal employees are working without a paycheck, increasing their families’ financial difficulties. 
How many federal employees have been put on unpaid furlough during the shutdown?  There are also approximately 380,000 federal employees who have been placed on unpaid furlough during the partial government shutdown. They are also not receiving any pay during the shutdown. 
Will the 420,000 federal employees forced to work without pay during the shutdown receive the pay for their work when the shutdown is over?  Yes.  Under federal law, those federal employees forced to work without pay in the shutdown are guaranteed the pay they have earned when the government re-opens.  
 Will the 380,000 federal employees who were placed on unpaid furlough during the shutdown receive back pay when the shutdown is over? That will be up to the Congress and the White House. Legislation would have to be enacted.  The precedent has been that furloughed employees are later paid, through legislation.  Indeed, after every previous shutdown, Congress has passed legislation mandating that furloughed workers get paid. 
What is the impact of the partial government shutdown on small businesses? A shutdown halts federal loans to small businesses.  During a shutdown, the Small Business Administration stops approving applications for small businesses to obtain loans and guarantees, typically $1 billion per month.  Indeed, on Dec. 22, SBA put a notice on Facebook simply stating, “Due to the lapse in government funding, SBA will remain inactive until further notice.”   
What is the impact on home mortgage applications? During the shutdown, the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) will see significant delays in loan processing and approvals, due to the furloughing of most employees.  Thousands of people trying to buy a new home or refinance a FHA-insured mortgage will likely be put on standby.  
What is the impact on FDA’s food safety activities?  During the shutdown, the FDA will be unable to support a number of its food safety activities.  FDA has furloughed 40 percent of its employees.   As a result, it will have to reduce its routine inspections of domestic food facilities.  For example, in the 16-day GOP shutdown in 2013, the FDA had to delay nearly 360 food safety inspections. 
  
Need Assistance? 
Congressman Butterfield’s Wilson, Durham, and Washington, DC offices will remain open for normal business hours and will be on hand to help constituents as best we can with the consequences of the partial government shutdown. 
Wilson, North Carolina | 252-237-9816 
Durham, North Carolina | 919-908-0164 
Washington, D.C. | 202-225-3101

Subject: Congressman Dan Lipinski Honors Veterans
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
Website 
News Center 
Constituent Services 
Issues 
About the District 
About Me 
Contact Us 
December 28, 2018 
 
Lipinski Honors Area Veterans
￼ Lipinski honors area veterans at a ceremony in Oak Lawn.
“I am committed to ensuring that America’s heroic women and men in uniform and their families continue to be supported once they return home.  From education to healthcare to housing assistance and other benefits, I have always made it a priority of my office to fight for those brave individuals that have sacrificed so much for our nation.  
“I am proud to have a staff member whose primary focus is to address the questions and concerns of veterans in the district.  Whether it is an issue with your benefits as a veteran, a problem with obtaining your service records, or if you have earned medals for your service but never received them, I can help.”
 
Lipinski Bill Commemorating WWII Clears House and Senate
￼
Congressman Lipinski is pleased to announce that S 3661, a bill he co-sponsored that establishes a Depart of Defense program to commemorate the 75th anniversary of World War II, has passed both the House and Senate. The bill will educate the public about the war’s history and pay tribute to the contributions made on the home front.
 “The victory of the Allies in the War and the contributions of America’s Armed Forces must never be forgotten,” Lipinski said. “That is why commemorating this anniversary should be done in extraordinary ways. Commemorating this critical event in history will also allow us to recognize our World War II veterans who are still living. We must listen to and learn from their stories while we’re still able.”
 
Lipinski Helps Dedicate the New Legion Park and Veterans Memorial in Summit
￼
In October, Congressman Lipinski spoke at the dedication ceremony for the new Legion Park in Summit, which features a veterans memorial.
"It's great to have another beautiful location in the area for us to reflect on the brave service and sacrifice of members of our armed forces. And the park provides a nice place for children to play and this close-knit community to come together. Thanks to the Summit Park District, members of the Argo-Summit American Legion Post 735, and Mayor Sergio Rodriguez for their hard work."
 
Lipinski Encourages Veterans to Share Their Stories for the Library of Congress' Veterans History Project
￼ The congressman discusses the needs of veterans in Washington and  thanks a WWII vet for his service and sacrifice. 
Congressman Lipinski is asking veterans in the Third District to share their stories so they can be preserved in the Library of Congress’ Veterans History Project (VHP).  For any veteran that is interested, the Congressman’s office will set up a recorded interview at a local site.  The VHP collects, preserves, and makes accessible the personal accounts of veterans so that current and future generations can better understand the contributions and sacrifices they made.  All veterans are invited to call Lipinski’s Chicago office at 773-948-6223 for more information or to schedule an interview.  At the conclusion of the recorded interview, participants will receive a copy and one will be sent to the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. 
“I encourage all veterans to take advantage of this unique opportunity,” Rep. Lipinski said.  “Our history is the story of every person who has contributed in some way to our great nation, and that means every veteran, including those that served during the Cold War.  Our heroes are not just those we read about in the history books, but every man and woman who has served our nation in uniform.”  All recorded interviews will be housed in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress.  They will be available to researchers, scholars, students, authors, filmmakers, and anyone else visiting the library.  For more information, go online to lipinski.house.gov.
 
Scam Alert
￼
The Palos Park police are warning residents of a telephone scam in which a caller claims to represent the Veterans Administration and then requests money or personal information. Remember that the VA will never call you and request money, even if you see “Veterans Affairs” on your caller ID. Never give out any sensitive data such as financial and banking information. If you need any help with your benefits, please contact my office at (773) 948-6223.
 
Time for a New Flag?
￼
Remember that if your flag or flags have seen better days, the Congressman’s offices in Chicago, Oak Lawn, Orland Park, and Lockport will accept worn American flags for proper disposal. 
If you’re looking for a replacement flag for special occasions, please contact the office in Washington toll free at 866-822-5701 for more information on how to purchase an American flag that's been flown over the U.S. Capitol.  Please be advised that requests cannot be processed more than one month prior to date the flag would need to be flown.  Congressman Lipinski is also happy to provide veterans their first flag free of charge.

Subject: 2018 Year in Review
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
Contact
Helping You
Issues
News
28th District
About
￼
Dear Friend,
As the year draws to a close, I wanted to update you on some of what I worked on this year, share a few thoughts on what was accomplished, and talk about what we will face next year.
This has been a challenging time for the nation and in Congress. And as we approach the new year with the government still shut down, next year looks to be equally difficult. But I’m proud to say that despite the partisan differences at the Capitol, we have had some success this year advancing local proposals that I have focused on for much of my career — like the expansion of open space, mass transit, earthquake early warning, and quality of life measures for our community — as well as many new ideas.
At a national level, one of my top priorities continues to be my duties as the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee. While overseeing the nation’s intelligence professionals and shoring up our cyber defenses, the Committee had the added responsibility this year of conducting the investigation into Russia’s attack on our democracy. In the coming year, we have a lot of work remaining not only on the investigation, but most important, on how to protect our nation from attacks like that in the future.
This year was also spent pushing back against Administration attacks on the freedom of the press, the independence of the Justice Department, and the mission of the EPA and State Department.
January will bring a change to the Congress in the form of divided government when Democrats become the Majority in the House. I believe the first priority must be to put forward a positive legislative agenda — one that helps Americans provide for their families, put bread on the table, and access affordable health care when they get sick. Caring for the needs of the American people goes hand in hand with our oversight responsibilities.
I look forward to the new year with the hope that we can be effective agents for change and with a profound sense of duty at a time when I believe our democracy is at risk. We are a strong and resilient nation and I know we will get through this by doing our part to advance and cherish the values and ideals of America.
Happy Holidays and a very Happy New Year,
￼
Adam Schiff
Member of Congress
2018 Legislative and Oversight Initiatives
Leading the Effort on Funding an Early Earthquake Warning System
￼
Rep. Schiff continues to lead the effort to get an Earthquake Early Warning System up and running along the entire West Coast, including California. The system – called ShakeAlert – has the potential to save lives, prevent injuries and protect infrastructure and property. 
Despite the Trump Administration’s initial lack of support for this crucial lifesaving initiative, Schiff helped secure $22.9 million for the system in the FY18 funding bill passed in March and is working to ensure that funding is sustained. In October, he joined ShakeAlert partners in announcing the next, public phase of the system. Now, businesses, organizations, and local governments can work with ShakeAlert to send alerts to their members. Within the next couple years, individuals all along the West Coast should be able to receive alerts on their phones.
Read more:
LA Times - Earthquake early warning system gets big funding boost in new budget
Introducing Legislation to Bring Vision Services to Underserved Students and Communities
￼
In November, Rep. Schiff introduced the See the Board Act. The bill would authorize the Department of Health and Human Services to make grants available to support the work of organizations that are bringing vision services to schools in underserved communities across the country. While these programs would still rely on the generosity and volunteerism of eyecare professionals, the See the Board Act would help nonprofits with some of the substantial equipment and infrastructure costs.
“Thousands of kids across the nation need glasses, but because they have never received an eye exam, they struggle through school and life, for lack of a pair of glasses that would often be free for them and their families,” said Schiff. “Grants to allow these organizations to expand their work to reach more underserved urban and rural schools would be a cost-effective intervention, helping potentially millions of students whose performance and self-confidence suffers for lack of a pair of affordable glasses.”
Read more:
Beverly Press - Rep. Adam Schiff introduces See the Board Act
Bipartisan Congenital Heart Disease Bill Passes the House
In February, the House passed the bipartisan Congenital Heart Futures Reauthorization Act, introduced by Reps. Schiff and Gus Bilirakis (R-FL). The bill supports critical research, education and awareness for congenital heart disease (CHD) — the most common birth defect and the leading cause of infant mortality. Children and adults with CHD require ongoing, costly, specialized cardiac care and face a lifelong risk of permanent disability and premature death. The President signed the bill into law on December 21, 2018.   “Children born with congenital heart defects face lingering health risks and increased medical costs throughout their entire lives,” said Rep. Schiff. “This bipartisan bill will enable the Center for Disease Control and National Institutes of Health to continue vital research studies into early childhood congenital heart defects to assess the lifelong needs of those born with CHD.”
Taking Next Step to Protect the Rim of the Valley Corridor
￼
One of Rep. Schiff’s top legislative priorities for the last decade has been to preserve the Rim of the Valley Corridor. Schiff has introduced legislation to expand the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area by 191,000 acres. This would help protect open space while preserving private property rights.
This year, Schiff worked to grow support across the aisle – including securing the cosponsorship of every representative whose districts include any portion of the Rim of the Valley. With Democrats retaking the Majority in the House next year, Schiff is hopeful that the bill will finally receive a hearing and vote and be passed into law.
Read more:
Los Angeles Daily News - ‘Rim of Valley’ land preservation measure gets bipartisan support; House members ask for stalled bill to move forward
Bipartisan Child Protection Improvements Act Becomes Law
When he was first out of law school, Rep. Schiff volunteered with Big Brothers Big Sisters. Through this experience, Schiff grew to understand the tremendous amount of trust put into volunteers at child-serving organizations across the country. In the vast majority of cases, that trust is well placed. Unfortunately, there are exceptions.
For this reason, Schiff championed and introduced the Child Protection Improvements Act (CPIA), a bipartisan bill which would ensure that organizations in every state that serve children, seniors and individuals with disabilities, can access FBI background checks for prospective volunteers and staff. FBI fingerprint background checks are considered to be the gold standard of background checks, and this bill will allow parents to trust that their children and loved ones are in good hands.
Rep. Schiff worked with his Republican colleagues to pass the Child Protection Improvements Act, and it was signed into law by the President in March. The Department of Justice is now required by law to implement the provisions of CPIA by March 2019, and Schiff is keeping pressure on the DOJ to ensure that the deadline is met.
Read more:
Schiff, Bishop Applaud Signing of Bipartisan Child Protection Improvements Act
Fighting Against the Trump Administration’s Separation of Immigrant Families
￼
Rep. Schiff has consistently fought against the Trump Administration’s decision to separate immigrant children from their families when they try to come across the southern border. That is why Schiff led an effort in the House to prevent any funds from being used by the Administration to separate children from their families entering the U.S. In a letter with 94 other House Members led by Schiff, he also demanded that no funds could be used to construct so-called “tent cities” on military bases.
Schiff visited a shelter facility in July to witness first hand the confinement and treatment of immigrant children who were separated from their parents. He has also cosponsored legislation that would outlaw the separation of families permanently. Schiff will continue to fight the efforts by the Trump Administration to separate families and militarize the southern border of the United States.
Watch Rep. Schiff discuss visiting the shelter facility here.
Decreasing Helicopter Noise Above Homes, and Making the Skies Safer
This year, Rep. Schiff continued his efforts to pressure the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to regulate helicopter noise above Los Angeles County. After learning that the FAA planned to end the helicopter noise complaint system, which was started as a result of Schiff’s actions, he led a letter with Senators Feinstein and Harris and other members of the Los Angeles delegation urging the FAA to reconsider termination.
In addition, Schiff offered an amendment to the FAA Reauthorization bill to require the FAA to regulate helicopters above Los Angeles County. While this amendment did not succeed, Schiff was able to include an amendment into the FAA bill giving the agency the authority to detect and monitor drones entering restricted airspace. This is in response to the increase in drones entering space above airports as well as areas where firefighters are battling fires across California.
Read more:
House Passes Schiff Drone Amendment to FAA Reauthorization - Amendment gives FAA the Ability to Detect and Monitor Drones Entering Restricted Airspace
Rep. Schiff’s op-ed in Crescenta Valley Weekly - The FAA Must Improve LA’s Helicopter Noise Complaint System, Not End it
Increasing Funding to Restore the Los Angeles River
￼
For years, Rep. Schiff has been working with the Los Angeles delegation to restore the Los Angeles River to its natural prominence and beauty. This year, he successfully lobbied Congress to provide significant funding for the Army Corps of Engineers so that it could continue its early work on the Los Angeles Ecosystem Restoration Project.
Los Feliz Ledger - Schiff and Others Ask Trump to Increase 2019 Funding for Projects, Like the Los Angeles River
Introducing Legislation to Support our Veterans with a New Opportunity to Serve the Nation During Times of Crisis
In May, Rep. Schiff introduced legislation to provide training, employment opportunities and a new way to serve for millions who served their nation in uniform. The Veterans Crisis Response Corps Act would leverage the unique skills of veterans, augmented by training, and bring them to bear on a variety of disaster response, both at home and abroad.
Schiff’s legislation would establish a new independent agency – the VetCorps – with the mission of matching veterans with a desire and ability to serve with crisis response, hazard mitigation, development, infrastructure, and other projects that can utilize their skill sets. In keeping with our commitment to veterans, it would provide training, employment, and a new way to serve for millions of Americans who served their nation.
Read more:
Rep. Schiff's op-ed in Crescenta Valley Weekly - Creating New Service Opportunities for Veterans
Schiff Introduces Legislation to Establish New VetCorps Agency to Match Veterans with Service Opportunities
Working to Pass the U.S.S. Frank E. Evans Vietnam War Memorial Bill
￼
Rep. Schiff successfully passed a bipartisan amendment to require the names of 74 sailors who died aboard the USS Frank E. Evans in 1969 to be added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, DC. For years, Schiff has been urging the Department of Defense to include the Evans sailors on the Memorial Wall. 
The amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act offered by Schiff and Rep. Kevin Cramer (R-ND) passed by voice vote, but was unfortunately stripped out of the final bill by the Senate. Schiff will continue to fight for the inclusion of the names and pursue new legislation in 2019 so that the families and loved ones of those who lost their lives can see their sacrifice properly recognized.
Read more:
ABC News - Heartbreak, Hope in Quest to Add 74 Names to Vietnam Memorial
2018 Highlights Around the Community
Schiff Participates in Town Hall to Discuss Gun Violence
￼
Last month, Rep. Schiff held a town hall with State Senator Anthony Portantino, Andrea Welsing of the LA County Public Health Department, and Dr. Karen Rogers of Children’s Hospital Los Angeles to discuss the need to deal with gun violence, from mass shootings, daily homicides and people taking their own lives. During the town hall, Schiff called for commonsense solutions that help prevent gun violence as well as treat those who are impacted by this grave threat to the public health and welfare.
Read more:
Burbank Leader - Schiff, Portantino lead gun-violence talk at Woodbury University
Schiff Honors Women of the Year
￼
In April, Rep. Schiff held a luncheon in Echo Park to honor a group of inspiring women from communities in the 28th Congressional District. The honorees included Claudette Nicole Saba Monestime (Atwater Village), Vicky Marachelian (Burbank), Isa-Kae Meksin (Echo Park), Emily Gleicher (Elysian Valley), Lori Hartwell (Glendale), Anastasia Mann (Hollywood Hills), Donna Ford (La Canada Flintridge), Kiljoo Lee Kurumada (La Crescenta), Brenda Levin (Los Feliz), Patricia Anne Kinaga (Pasadena), Nina Sorkin (Silver Lake), Kelly Erin Decker (Kagel Canyon), Medea Kalognomos (Sunland) and Ivy Bottini (West Hollywood).
Read about each of the incredible women of the year here.
Schiff Recognizes Student Artists in the Community at the Congressional Art Competition
￼
Each year, Rep. Adam Schiff and Members of Congress from all over the nation host a congressional competition for high school students. In May, Schiff held this year’s art competition at Descanso Gardens in La Cañada Flintridge.
Schiff announced that Jennifer Bae’s acrylic painting “Have a Slice” won first place and will be displayed in the United States Capitol for one year, alongside winners from other Congressional Districts across the nation. Additionally, Schiff announced that Abrielle Marsden’s acrylic painting “Perception” and Alejandra Santana’s photograph “Sunny Light Up” won second and third place, respectively. The “People’s Choice” award went to Vilen Manukyan for his graphite and acrylic artwork, “Path Behind the Glory.” Their artwork will be displayed in Congressman Schiff’s Washington, DC Office, his Burbank District Office, and his Hollywood District Office.
Schiff Joins Seismologists and Officials at Caltech to Announce Roll-Out and Next Phase of ShakeAlert
￼
Rep. Schiff joined seismologists and officials from Caltech, U.S. Geological Service and the California Office of Emergency Services at Caltech to announce the roll-out of the next phase of ShakeAlert, the West Coast earthquake early warning system, marking a major milestone in their efforts to prepare for the next major earthquake.
Even with just a few seconds of warning, trains can be slowed or stopped, surgery can be paused, or a person can quickly take shelter before shaking begins. Schiff will continue to work to secure the funding to build out this critical lifesaving tool, and expand pilot projects across the state like those already up and running in public transportation systems, schools, hospitals, and utilities.
Read more:
ABC 7 - USGS, Caltech officials announce rollout of West Coast's earthquake early warning system
Schiff Speaks with Students at Burbank High School
￼
Young people are leading the way on climate change, gun violence prevention and so much more. In February, Rep. Schiff met with students at Burbank High School to discuss important issues like these.
As President Obama liked to remind his audiences, the new generation can truly say, “we are the ones we’ve been waiting for” and will be the change agents our country needs. Schiff enjoyed talking with such enthusiastic students who are so impressively informed and engaged.
Schiff Marches with Members of the Community to Commemorate the Armenian Genocide
￼
Every year, Rep. Schiff marches to commemorate the 1.5 million men, women, and children killed in the Armenian Genocide more than one hundred years ago. He marches to fight against genocide and hatred all over the world, to call for justice and restitution, and to pledge we will never forget.
Schiff has introduced bipartisan legislation to commemorate the Armenian Genocide each of the nine terms he has served. In the new Congress, Schiff will reintroduce legislation to formally recognize the Armenian Genocide in the new year.
Read more:
Rep. Schiff Speaks on House Floor: United States Must Recognize the Armenian Genocide  
Schiff Joins Los Angeles Alumni of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School to Push for Legislation to Address Gun Violence
￼
In February, seventeen students and staff members were murdered in a mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The next month, in March, Rep. Schiff met with the Southern California alumni of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School to discuss what Congress can and must do to prevent gun violence.
Read more:
KTLA 5: Rep. Schiff Joins Marjory Stoneman Douglas Alumni in Pushing for Gun Votes
2018 by the Numbers
Over 1,000: Constituents Helped During This Calendar Year by the Office of Congressman Schiff
Every year, Rep. Schiff’s staff members work hard to help constituents access the federal benefits they deserve and ensure that everyone is treated fairly. While not successful in every case, Schiff’s office is committed to helping constituents with the IRS or Social Security, navigate the complicated immigration and visa system, and get back benefits or medals they earned while serving.
For help, please call Congressman Schiff’s district office in Burbank at (818) 450-2900 or (323) 315-5555. In most cases, you will be required to fill out a form to give permission for members of staff help you and contact federal agencies on your behalf.

Subject: 2018 Report:  Federal Dollars for Tampa Bay
Message:
￼ 
Dear friends,   As 2018 winds down and we look ahead to 2019, I want to thank you for the opportunity to represent you and the wonderful Tampa Bay community.
Everyday, my Tampa constituent services team, Tery Sanchez, Dee Gonzalez and Tania Fernandez (with help from all of Team Castor) work hard to cut through red tape to advocate for the benefits and services our neighbors have earned, including for veterans, Social Security and Medicare for seniors, people with disabilities and more. In 2018, we returned $2.6 million to veterans, seniors, small businesses and families across Tampa Bay and assisted with more than 2,900 cases. 
More than half of the $2.6 million in federal benefits went to veterans/military and their families. With more than 98,000 veterans in Hillsborough County, the highest veteran population in Florida according to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, every day we are focused on benefit adjustments, disability claims and appeals, debt waivers, as well as expedited benefits decisions and record requests.  My team tackles complex cases and works persistently with federal agencies to get results. My neighbors often turn to us as a last resort or when they are on the brink. The dollars and benefits returned to them can be a critical lifeline.   Grants – $340 million  My office also worked this year to secure more than $340 million in federal grants for this district to create jobs, invest in education and infrastructure, and support the important work of local partners.  Grants bolster vital education and job training resources for students and families who need it the most.  They can grow our region’s startup hub, lead to expanding small businesses and boosting jobs.   Among the federal grants that I championed this year, most recently was $300,000 to Tampa Bay Wave to help launch a regional investor collaborative.    Bay Area Legal Services, the Spring of Tampa Bay and Sunrise of Pasco County also received a $600,000 federal grant to provide ”seamless” assistance – legal aid for our neighbors experiencing domestic violence, sexual assault, and other issues. The University of South Florida (USF) received a $2.7 million grant to conduct trials on Alzheimer’s disease prevention. Small and large grants make a meaningful impact – from a $5,365 grant awarded to the Agency for Community Treatment Services (ACTS) by the Department of Veterans Affairs to a $2.7 million grant to H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center & Research Institute.  Earlier in 2018, researchers and scientists from USF and Moffitt Cancer Center shared how grants advance their research and create jobs. USF, Moffitt, nonprofits and the many growing businesses make our region a hotbed for economic growth and I am proud to team up with them to bring our tax dollars back to Tampa to create higher paying  jobs.  We look forward to an active 2019! You can count on us to be your advocates. 


￼

￼

For more information, please visit my webpage at www.castor.house.gov. 

Happy Holidays!


Sincerely, 

Kathy Castor 

P.S. Remember to join me on Facebook for more pictures and information about issues important to our community.

To unsubscribe, please visit my web site .

Subject: Thank you
Message:
News from Congressman Sessions  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
Dear friend, 
I want to express my sincere gratitude for the opportunity to represent you in the U.S. House of Representatives. Since 2003, I have had the privilege of providing the residents of the 32nd Congressional District of Texas with a voice in Washington. And before that, I was honored to serve the constituents of Texas' 5th District from 1997 to 2003. 
However, I look at each of you as so much more than constituents. You are my neighbors, fellow church-goers, mentors to my sons, volunteer partners, and friends. 
We share the same love of community and country, we want what is best for our children and families, and we work hard for the good of North Texas.  
While we are in a season of change, I trust that these fundamental similarities and shared values will withstand the test of time. I look forward to continuing to call you my neighbors, friends, and fellow patriots for many years to come. 
In my 15 years as your Congressman, my staff and I have been privileged to: 
Welcome more than 6,000 North Texans to my Washington office and provide them with a personal U.S. Capitol tour.
￼ 
Host nearly 1,500 high school students in Washington, D.C. for my annual Leadership and Growth Program to see firsthand how government works and learn invaluable leadership skills.
￼
Nominate more than 200 North Texas students to our distinguished U.S. Service Academies.
￼
Continue my support for the Boy Scouts of America, for example, by passing the Boy Scouts of America Centennial Commemorative Coin Act.
￼
Serve as Chairman of the prestigious House Rules Committee, ultimately shepherding many critical bills, like the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, into law.
￼
It has been the honor of a lifetime and I will continue to be a voice for those who feel their thoughts, concerns, and ideas have fallen on deaf ears.  
From one friend to another, I wish you and your family a Happy New Year.  
Respectfully yours, 
  
￼  Pete Sessions U.S. Congressman 
￼

Subject: Christmas with the troops
Message:
News from Congressman
￼ 

Home
About
About District
Conact
Media 


Christmas in the Middle East
 ￼ 
One of the greatest honors in serving our community in Congress is spending Christmas Day with our U.S. Troops deployed to war zones overseas, so that I can personally express the love and gratitude that our community has for their brave service and sacrifice. On behalf of our community, I served Christmas dinner to our courageous heroes whose missions include operations in Iraq and Syria. And I ran into Bucks County’s own Andrew Alexander of Doylestown and Mike Mignogna of Warrington, two courageous hometown heroes and public servants! 
  
Senate Passes Fitzpatrick Cyberstalking Bill
 ￼ 
We have no higher responsibility than to protect our kids. I’m pleased that the Senate has advanced the Combat Online Predators Act. We must do everything we can to forcefully respond to egregious instances of stalking and cyberstalking. This legislation, inspired by Erin and Madison Zezzo, ensures that, not only are we increasing penalties for cyberstalking crimes against minors, but we are also requiring federal law enforcement officials to evaluate and update practices to combat this dangerous harassment. I urge House leadership to immediately bring the Senate-passed bill up for a vote before the end of the Congress. 
Read more HERE. 
  
House Send Historic Criminal Justice Reform to President
￼  
The U.S. House overwhelmingly passed the FIRST STEP Act [S. 756], prison reform that would lower recidivism and prison populations through rehabilitative programming. I’m proud to cast my vote in support of the FIRST STEP Act with my fellow Problem Solvers Caucus members. As a former FBI agent, I understand criminal justice reform is critically important to reducing crime and recidivism. This bipartisan measure demonstrates our investment and confidence in our fellow Americans. While there is still more work to accomplish, this vote marks a generational shift towards a criminal justice system that establishes a more practical, efficient rehabilitative framework to keep communities safe. 
Learn more HERE. 
Statement on Government Shutdown
Government shutdowns are not an effective way to govern. They’re costly, unnecessary, and demonstrate a failure to lead from both parties. I have not, and will not, vote to shut down the government. It’s the basic duty of Congress to fund the federal government. Shutdowns disrupt government services, compromise national security, and cause uncertainty for federal employees. Critical funding for programs like the Violence Against Women Act lapse. Congress should follow the way the American people run their businesses and manage their families: lead by example to build consensus and solve problems in a dignified, honorable manner. 
Read my full statement, including my intention to abide by my ‘No Budget, No Pay’ proposal HERE.

Subject: Update on the ACA
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
BIOGRAPHY 
CONTACT 
SERVICES
OUR DISTRICT 
NEWSROOM
ON THE ISSUES
LEGISLATIVE
December 27, 2018
 
Dear Friend,
 
There has been a lot of news about the Affordable Care Act (ACA) recently and I want to ensure you have the latest details.
 
Please know that the ACA remains in effect, and there is still time for New Yorkers to sign up for affordable health care coverage. Visit nystateofhealth.ny.gov or call 1 (855) 355-5777 by January 15th for coverage beginning February 1st. The final deadline is January 31st.
 
There has been confusion due to a December 14th court ruling, wherein a U.S. District Court judge struck down the entire ACA. I believe the ruling, which jeopardizes millions of Americans’ health care, is deeply flawed. If this decision is allowed to stand, the critical consumer protections that families rely on will disappear. That means no protections for Americans with pre-existing conditions, no ban on annual and lifetime limits, and no limit on out-of-pocket costs. On top of that, 17 million Americans would lose their health insurance in the first year alone, and premiums would increase for millions more.
 
But this case is not over. This ruling will be challenged immediately, and I will work tirelessly to ensure that it never goes into effect. My colleagues and I will fight to make sure this lawsuit doesn't take away millions of Americans’ health coverage.
 
The American people have made it clear time and time again that they want to maintain the vital protections within the ACA. That’s why this backdoor attempt to repeal the law cannot stand.
Sincerely, ￼ Eliot L. Engel MEMBER OF CONGRESS

December 27, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | Meet Rodney | 11th District
￼
Services | Newsroom | Contact Rodney
Partial Government Shutdown
Honor to Serve the People of New Jersey’s 11th Congressional District in Congress
Salute: My Excellent Staff
 
Partial Government Shutdown  
It is deeply disappointing that Congress was unable to reach a compromise that would have prevented this destabilizing, unnecessary, partial government shutdown during the holidays. I urge House and Senate leadership—Democrat and Republican—and the White House to come together and find a deal that will reopen the government, provide much-needed border security funding, and help Americans recover from recent natural disasters—as quickly as possible.
 
The Appropriations Committee did its work on all twelve bills and gave our House and Senate leaderships every opportunity to include our bipartisan efforts in the final ‘deal’ to keep the government open.
 
I am proud of the efforts of all twelve Chairs, Ranking Members and all committee members, but most especially the professional committee staff for all their hard work and dedication in recent weeks, but especially during the August ‘break’ or recess, which most missed because they were still in Washington working on their bills to anticipate every ‘exit strategy’!
 
Honor to Serve New Jersey’s 11th Congressional District in Congress
It has been the honor of my life to serve and represent the people of New Jersey’s 11th Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives for twenty four years.
 
During my time serving here there have been times of great tragedy including the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and the ravages of Hurricane Sandy on my home state.  In my role on the House Appropriations Committee, I made sure that New Jersey’s needs were met in both the immediate aftermath as well as over time in the wake of these events. I have proudly been able to secure key federal investments for New Jersey to strengthen our economy, our institutions of higher education, our hospitals and public transportation systems, to preserve open space and protect the environment and to better serve our veterans and our fellow citizens with mental illness and developmental disabilities.
 
As Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, over the past two years, I had a singular focus on “getting our work done”. In Fiscal Year 2019 we approved 75 percent of all annual discretionary funding prior to the start of the fiscal year – a critical step in returning to the regular federal funding process, and an achievement that has not occurred in twenty-two years. In Fiscal Year 2018, we passed all twelve bills in record time through regular order, and three Disaster Supplemental Appropriations bills, historic in scope, and the expediency with which we acted to help our fellow citizens in times of despair and destruction.
 
Throughout my service in this House, my deepest devotion has been supporting our Armed Forces, all volunteers, wonderful men and women, and their families, here and abroad, and those warfighters who have returned home with injuries and who depend on a functioning veterans’ health care system.  To those of you I have met while you served us overseas and to those of you that I have sat by your bedside, I hope and trust I have served you well.
 
A key component of my focus to ensure our nation’s military remains second to none included supporting New Jersey’s critical military installations. Chief among these was my efforts to expand the mission of Picatinny Arsenal and support the thousands of engineers, scientists and dedicated professionals who work to provide our warfighters with the resources that allow our Armed Forces to succeed on the battlefield.
 
I am also extremely proud of my efforts to provide substantial increases in funding to the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency to hasten their critical work of recovering the remains of military personnel lost in Southeast Asia during the Vietnam War. As a Vietnam veteran, I will never forget those who died, were wounded, or were lost or missing in Vietnam, Laos, or Cambodia.
 
I have worked in a bipartisan manner, not just in times of crisis but always, because I believe it best serves our District, our state and our country. My father reminded me often that we are temporary stewards of the public trust.  I have sincerely endeavored to earn that trust every day and I thank my constituents and my home state of New Jersey for the honor to serve.
 
Salute: My Excellent Staff
The unsung heroes of my time in Congress are my staff who served in Morristown and Washington, my Chief of Staff, Kathleen Hazlett, Austin Bone, Kacy Hobbis, Nora Burns, Aura Dunn, Judith Lemus, Ryan Gallagher, Anthony Pryer, Nick D’Alessio, and many other men and women who dedicated their time and talents to serve my constituents. And, the professional staff of the House Appropriations Committee, led by Nancy Fox, my former Chief of Staff.

Subject: Congressman Lamb End of Year Message
Message:
Open this e-mail in its own browser window Open a plain text version of this email 
News from Congressman Lamb 
￼
Dear Friends,  
Since I was sworn into Congress in April, our office has received thousands of letters and calls from constituents sharing their questions, opinions and suggestions, and I greatly appreciate the time and effort you have taken to communicate with me.

I came to Congress to represent the people of Pennsylvania’s 18th District, to reach across the aisle, find common ground, and get things done.  That's what I've tried to do during my time.  I’ve worked on legislation with members of both parties.  I’ve supported Republican bills and Democratic bills that would help people in our region, and I’ve voted against Republican and Democratic bills that I didn't think were in our District's best interests. 

As a veteran and a member of the Veterans' Affairs Committee, one of my first priorities has been working on issues that affect veterans and military families in Pennsylvania and all over the country.  I’m glad that we've been able to work together in a bipartisan way to get things done for veterans who have sacrificed so much to protect our country.  I have worked to introduce and help pass meaningful bills through the Committee, including H.R. 5805 to protect the VA from arbitrary budget cuts and H.R. 6815, the Military Learning for Credit Act, to help veterans who are working towards their degrees receive college credit for prior military training. 

Combating the heroin epidemic will also continue to be a top priority in Congress.  Pennsylvania had one of the greatest overdose death rate increases from 2015 to 2017, and in 2017 more than 5,000 Pennsylvanians died from overdoses.  This is a crisis that demands comprehensive action, and I’m going to continue to push for the major investments we need to save lives from the disease of addiction.  We also know that fentanyl is a major factor in the increase in overdose deaths.  That's why I introduced H.R. 5871, the bipartisan POWER Act, which gives first responders the tools to test and identify fentanyl in real time, to protect themselves from exposure and to assist with investigations that get these drugs off the street.  I also voted for the SUPPORT for Patients and Community Act (H.R. 6), a bipartisan package that included dozens of proposals to address the devastating opioid crisis in America.  This important legislation passed in the U.S. House of Representatives in June 2018 by a vote of 396-14 and was signed into law by the President in October.

I believe Congress must also work to strengthen and protect Social Security and keep our commitments to seniors and hardworking Americans.  I am proud to be an original cosponsor of H.R. 1902, the Social Security 2100 Act, which would expand benefits and keep the system fully funded through the year 2100.  I will continue to fight against any efforts to cut or privatize Social Security and make sure seniors get the benefits they have earned. 

As our economy grows, I think it's critical for Congress to support and encourage that growth while also fighting for strong labor protections to make sure our workers get their fair share of the benefits of a strong American economy.  I will continue to push for a major bipartisan infrastructure bill to help repair our crumbling roads and bridges and create good jobs, and I cosponsored H.R. 5137, the Buy America 2.0 Act, to require that federally-funded transportation and infrastructure projects only use American-made raw materials and manufactured goods.  I also supported efforts to protect workers' rights to organize and bargain collectively, and I cosponsored legislation to protect mine workers' pensions and health care benefits, so we keep the promises we made to people who sacrificed so much to help build this country.

I believe that every American has a right to go see a doctor when they're sick, and that means all Americans deserve high-quality, affordable health insurance -- including for people with cancer, diabetes, asthma, or any other preexisting condition.  No senior citizen should ever have to choose between buying medicine and buying food, and no family should have to choose between keeping their kids healthy and keeping the lights on.  That is why I’ve cosponsored several bills to expand critical Medicare coverage, and I’ll continue to push for real, bipartisan solutions to protect people with preexisting conditions, keep and improve the Affordable Care Act, and make health insurance and prescription drugs more affordable for all Americans.

I believe that when Congress works together and stays focused on getting things done for the people we serve, we can find common ground and make a real difference in people's lives.  That’s what I have worked to do in my first term in Congress, and what will continue to guide me in the future.

It has been an honor representing the people of Pennsylvania’s 18th district.  If you would like to stay updated on my activities in both Washington and southwestern Pennsylvania representing the people of Pennsylvania’s new 17th district, please visit my website at: lamb.house.gov.


                                                                      Sincerely,
                                                            ￼ 
                                                                      Conor Lamb
                                                                      Member of Congress

Subject: Christmas greetings with the troops in the Middle East!
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
News from Representative Lee Zeldin
￼
Dear Lindsey,
￼
￼
￼
 ￼ 
 ￼
 ￼
 ￼
It’s been an honor to visit our troops deployed to the Middle East every Christmas since coming to Congress; a tradition continuing again this week. I’m so grateful of these men and women who defend our freedoms and sacrifice so much.
Spending Christmas away from their families isn’t easy, and for many of our servicemen and women this isn’t the first holiday season away from home. It was an honor to be able to again spend Christmas and the holiday season with them in the Middle East to personally thank them for their service, serve them lunches and dinner and break bread, let them know how much they are appreciated and how many Americans are thinking of them, praying for them and immensely grateful for their service. It was also great to be able to bring a little bit of home to them by delivering chocolate chip cookies from Tate’s Bake Shop; based in New York’s First Congressional District, to deployed constituents from Orient, Riverhead and elsewhere. 
From my family to yours, have a blessed and safe remainder of your Christmas week.  With Best Regards,   ￼  Lee Zeldin  Member of Congress

Subject: Season's Greetings
Message:
￼
Season's Greetings
Dear Friends,

Dee Dee and I hope you and your family had a very merry Christmas. We offer prayers of gratitude for the many blessings in our lives and prayers of hope for those who are less fortunate. Thank you for everything that each and every one of you does to make the 10th District such a wonderful place to call home. This year, I want to share a brief video to celebrate the Christmas season and to ask you to join me in praying for all those who have sacrificed their time at home with their loved ones so we can be with ours. Click here or on the image below to watch.
￼

A Funding Lapse
As you may know, last Thursday, the House passed legislation that would have kept the government running, taken steps toward securing the southern border by funding the wall, and provided additional disaster aid for those states, including Georgia, affected by Hurricane Michael. Unfortunately, the Senate failed to take further action and the second Schumer Shutdown of the year is now underway.

It’s important to keep it mind that this is a partial shutdown because Congress funded nearly three-fourths of the discretionary budget earlier this year through the passage of several appropriations packages, fully funding the Department of Defense, the Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Education, and others. One major item still remaining is the funding for the Department of Homeland Security. 

Democrats have shown their hand – they prefer open borders over an open government. As Members of Congress, we took an oath of allegiance to the citizens of the United States, not those trying to enter it illegally. While we can’t avoid a partial shutdown at this point, Congress can control how long it lasts. I call on my colleagues in both chambers to come to the table and do what is right for our Nation by putting the safety and security of Americans ahead of pandering to their open-border base. 

Border security is national security, and the reality is the Democrats’ platform previously supported a border barrier, border security funding, and additional border patrol agents. Now, they’ve done a complete about-face on these critical priorities and placed political expediency in front of delivering results for the American people. Our constituents did not send us to Washington to shut down the government, and it’s time for Senate Democrats to stop blocking efforts to secure our southern border and protect our communities. 

I appeared on Fox News last week to discuss our efforts to secure the border and deliver on the promises we’ve made to the American people.
￼

 
Hice in the House
Last week marked an important win for criminal justice reform. With the passage of S. 756, the FIRST Step Act, in the Senate on Tuesday followed by the House approval of the measure on Thursday with my support, President Trump signed this landmark legislation into law on Friday.

The FIRST Step Act will not only help make our criminal justice system more efficient and fair, but it will also continue to ensure Americans are protected from violent criminals. This bill makes improvements to our justice system that correct current issues by allowing judges more discretion in sentencing, limiting the harsh potency of mandatory minimums, and adding critical funding to prevent recidivism. To be clear, this new law does not let criminals “off the hook.” For serious offenses, stiff penalties remain enshrined in law. America is the land of promise and opportunity, and the FIRST Step Act paves the way for nonviolent, low-risk offenders with that very opportunity – the opportunity for a fresh start and the chance to become productive members of society.

While no bill is perfect, I am heartened by the potential of this measure. I applaud Governor Nathan Deal and Congressman Doug Collins for their hard work throughout this process, and I’m proud that Congress and President Trump have taken the lessons we’ve learned in Georgia to heart and passed a milestone criminal justice reform law that will apply those lessons throughout our federal criminal justice system. You can read a summary of this bill, which drew broad bipartisan support from faith leaders, law enforcement, governors, and attorneys general, by clicking here.

Hice on the Homefront
Last Tuesday, I enjoyed joining community leaders and officials from Greene, Hancock, Oglethorpe, and Oconee counties for a roundtable to discuss local infrastructure investment, rural broadband, and efforts to combat the opioid crisis. While there, I also highlighted the work being done by Congress and President Trump to reduce barriers to broadband services while ensuring faster and widespread access to high-speed internet for all Americans.

A big thank you to Becky Taylor, the Georgia Municipal Association Federal Relations Director, and Kathleen Bowen, the Association of County Commissioners of GA Associate Legislative Director, for hosting this important discussion. I look forward to seeing many of you next year!
￼
Congressman Hice provides a legislative update to local community leaders in Greensboro
￼
L-R: Billy Pittard (Oglethorpe County Board of Commissioners Chairman), Becky Taylor (Georgia Municipal Association Federal Relations Director), John Daniel (Oconee County Board of Commissioners Chairman), Representative Jody Hice, Sistie Hudson (Hancock County Board of Commissioners Chair), Glenn Wright (Greensboro Mayor), Kathleen Bowen (Association of County Commissioners of GA Associate Legislative Director), and Ronald McWhorter (Greensboro Mayor Pro-Tem)
 
The Week Ahead
Leaders in the House and Senate will continue negotiating with the president on a path forward to fund the rest of the federal government. As we wrap up this year, I wish you and your family a joyous and Happy New Year. I look forward to serving you in 2019 as we continue to work toward a better and brighter future for our children and grandchildren. 

As always, I encourage you to contact my office with any questions, comments, or concerns. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to keep track of upcoming legislation and events!

Sincerely, 
￼

Subject: Jeffries Historic Criminal Justice Reform Bill Signed Into Law
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼



WEBSITE | FORWARD TO A FRIEND

 
Wednesday, December 26, 2018

Jeffries Historic Criminal Justice Reform Bill Signed Into Law
 
 
Last week, historic, bipartisan criminal justice reform legislation, S.756, was signed into law. The First Step Act of 2018 is based on the Formerly Incarcerated Reenter Society Transformed, Safely Transitioning Every Person Act (FIRST STEP) co-authored by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (NY-08) and Republican Congressman Doug Collins (GA-09), that overwhelmingly passed the House in May.
The legislation will propel formerly-incarcerated individuals toward success when they return home, while enacting targeted reforms that would improve public safety and reduce recidivism. It authorizes $375 million over five years to develop new programs, including education, vocational training and mental health counseling. Consequently, newly-released individuals will be positioned to successfully re-enter society.
With respect to sentencing reform, the FIRST STEP Act will increase public safety and engineer much-needed changes to draconian sentencing laws connected to the failed war on drugs. It modifies the three strikes law to make it more humane, increases judicial discretion to reduce sentences for low-level nonviolent drug offenders and provides retroactive relief for thousands unjustly sentenced during the crack-cocaine era.
The FIRST STEP Act passed the House of Representatives 358-36 and the Senate 87-12 this week.
Rep. Jeffries said: “The FIRST STEP Act is a victory for all Americans who believe in justice and the power of redemption. This bill will transform lives by providing access to the mental health counseling, education, job training and substance abuse treatment needed to help incarcerated individuals get back on their feet and become productive members of society. It also provides retroactive relief for the shameful crack cocaine sentencing disparity that unfairly destroyed lives, families and communities. The FIRST STEP Act is not the end. It’s not even the beginning of the end. It's simply the end of the beginning of a bipartisan journey to eradicate the mass incarceration epidemic in America.”
￼


Highlights of the bill include:
Address Crack Cocaine Sentencing Disparity: Before 2010, those convicted for crack cocaine-related issues received a sentence 100 times harsher than that of those convicted of cocaine-related offenses. The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 reduced that disparity to 18-1. FIRST STEP makes that change retroactive, thereby reducing the sentences of thousands of individuals serving unduly heavy sentences.
Curtails Juvenile Solitary Confinement:  No young person should be kept in solitary confinement, which can cause substantial psychological damage. This provision severely limits the use of juvenile solitary confinement.
Focus on Dignity for Women: Being pregnant while incarcerated can be a harrowing experience. There are far too few guarantees for the health and safety of both mother and baby. Egregiously, there is no federal ban on shackling pregnant and post-partum women. This bill implements such a ban starting from the moment that a woman is confirmed to be pregnant and extending three months beyond her pregnancy. In addition, the bill requires that BOP provide sanitary napkins and tampons to incarcerated women for free.
Requirement to Move People Closer to Home: The journey to visit loved ones in prison can be extremely burdensome and cost-prohibitive for families. However, contact with family reduces recidivism. That’s why the bill mandates that prisoners shall be placed within 500 driving miles of their families.
Reduce Mandatory Minimums: The bill reduces second strike mandatory minimums of 20 years to 15 years, and reduces the third strike mandatory minimum of life in prison to 25 years. It also solves the 924(c) “stacking” problem by prohibiting the application of recidivist mandatory minimum enhancements for repeat offenders who commit certain firearms offenses to conduct within the same indictment.
Good Time Credit Fix: A provision which will ensure that incarcerated individuals can earn the 54 days of good time credit per year that Congress intended, and not just the 47 days that the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) currently allows. This retroactively applies to all prisoners who have earned credit for good behavior. It has been estimated by BOP and GAO that fixing this will lead to the release of roughly 4,000 prisoners and save $40 million in the first fiscal year.
Compassionate Release: The current prison population is aging, causing significant challenges. This bill expands the compassionate release program from the Second Chance Act. It expedites BOP consideration of petitions, providing family members the opportunity to visit terminally ill offenders and ensures assistance with submissions of petitions for compassionate release.
The Establishment of a Risk-Reduction System: This system, which is already used at the state level to best match inmates to programs fitting their needs, must be based on dynamic factors to best lower someone’s risk of recidivating over time. The bill mandates that the system must be statistically validated and must be evaluated to ensure that it does not result in unwanted racial disparities in order to address concerns about prisoners of color being disproportionately impacted.
Focused Resources on High and Medium Risk Prisoners: Evidence shows that this kind of programming has the greatest impact on those prisoners who are at the greatest risk of recidivating. To make the bill as effective as possible, it gives priority to high and medium risk inmates. People will be able to participate in such programming throughout their sentence.
Add Safety Valve: Low-level drug offenders who cooperate with the government should not have to face the certainty of decades in prison. Under the bill, judges will have more discretion to sentence below the mandatory minimum for qualified nonviolent offenders.
Requirement for Provisions of IDs: When transitioning back into society, many formerly incarcerated individuals find themselves without proper identification necessary to access essential services like housing, or to apply for employment. Assisting formerly incarcerated individuals with obtaining ID prior to release will reduce the collateral consequences of incarceration by allowing a quicker integration back into society, as well as create significant cost savings for BOP of approximately $19 million.
The FIRST STEP Act enjoys the support of more than 70 organizations, including the Equal Justice Initiative, National Urban League, Families Against Mandatory Minimums, Gathering for Justice/Justice League NYC, the Charles Koch Foundation, #cut50, Public Defender Association and the CAN-DO Foundation.
