Subject: From the Front...
Message:
News from Representative Steve Womack
￼

HOME 
| 
ABOUT STEVE 
|  
SERVICES 
|  
3RD DISTRICT 
|  
ISSUES & LEGISLATION 
|  
NEWSROOM 


December 21, 2018 
GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN
As you may know, Congress failed to pass either continued funding or fiscal year 2019 appropriations for the seven remaining annual bills, which resulted in a partial government shutdown that started at midnight. The House did pass a Continuing Resolution on Thursday, which would have kept our government running, funded the wall, and provided disaster aid – but the Senate did not take further action. 
Democrats have shown their hand—they prefer open borders over an open government. As Members of Congress, we took an oath of allegiance to the United States, not those trying to enter it illegally. It is unacceptable to hold the government hostage to play political games. While we can’t avoid a partial shutdown at this point, Congress can control how long it lasts.  I call on my Democratic colleagues in both chambers to come to the table and do what is right for our nation. 
The reality is the Democrats’ platform previously supported a border barrier, border security funding, and an increase of border patrol agents. Now, they’ve done a complete about face on these critical priorities and placed political expediency in front of delivering results for the American people. Our constituents did not send us to Washington to shut down the government. Congress needs to end this chaos and do our job. Border security is national security. It’s time for Democrats to stop blocking efforts to secure our Southern Border and protect our communities.  
I joined Fox News this morning to discuss the partial shutdown and what next steps are needed to get the government funded and running. 
￼ 
Watch the segment here.  
Negotiations will likely continue throughout the week. You can follow updates on my Twitter. 
WEEK IN REVIEW
￼
To start off this week's From the Front... I would like to thank all of the Arkansans who stopped by my Washington office during their visits to our nation’s capital, including Eric, Amber, Ashley and Austin Lunnen of Mountain Home, Tyler and Peggy Young of Western Grove, Phillip Bowen of Western Grove, Jennifer and Brandon Klingaman of Western Grove, Michael, Kelli, Kason, Carter, and Maci Adkins of Mountain Home, Robert and Tina Steiner of Bentonville, Ray Mary and Emma Taylor of Bentonville, and Isabella Arkin and Sophie Quandt of Bentonville. Safe travels back to the Natural State! 
Last weekend, thousands of Americans gathered across the U.S. to participate in Wreaths Across America and honor those who sacrificed for our freedom. My grandson Kaden and I laid wreaths at Fayetteville National Cemetery to thank our fallen heroes. It was very humbling to lay a wreath at the grave of one of my former UA Cadets, Todd Williams. I’m forever grateful for his service. Teaching Kaden about those lost and seeing so many Arkansans come together to remember those who gave their all was a truly moving experience. 
￼
It was a busy week. I started off in Arkansas and met with Bella Vista Mayor Peter Christie, Bella Vista Fire Chief Steve Sims, and Bella Vista Communications Manager Cassi Lapp to discuss the latest information about the Trafalgar Road stump dump fire. We then visited the site, so I could see and assess the situation firsthand. My office continues to monitor updates and support state and federal officials as an action plan is put together. On Wednesday, I had a follow-up call with the EPA, Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality, Arkansas Department of Health, Senator Boozman, and the Governor’s office to discuss additional updates related to the situation. Local and federal officials are working together to find a way to safely extinguish the fire. Resources for impacted residents can be found here: bit.ly/2QC0kZ8 
￼
There was big legislative news throughout the week. The House passed another tax reform package to further support hardworking U.S. families. The legislation improves access to retirement savings accounts, implements reforms to the IRS to increase efficiency, and frees Americans from several burdensome Obamacare taxes. Last year, Congress passed monumental tax reform that has led to a booming economy and opportunity. This bill builds on that work, and I was proud to support it.  
Historic criminal justice reform was also passed by the House and Senate, and then signed into law by President Trump. The First Step Act is an important bill that makes substantive reforms to our criminal justice system. America is the land of promise and opportunity.
￼
The First Step Act gives nonviolent, low-risk offenders that very opportunity—the opportunity for a fresh start and the chance to become productive members of society. This bipartisan legislation does so while also ensuring that dangerous and violent prisoners stay behind bars and making our communities safer. I was proud to vote in support of these important criminal justice reforms.
Additionally, President Trump signed the Farm Bill into law. This legislation will provide Arkansas farmers, ranchers, and dairy producers five years of policy certainty and stability, which will also support consumers, families, and rural communities across the U.S. 
SUSPENSIONS
This week, the House considered and passed on suspension the Congenital Heart Futures Reauthorization Act of 2017 (H.R. 1222), BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer’s Act (S. 2076), Concurring in the Senate Amendment to (H.R. 6615) Traumatic Brain Injury Program Reauthorization Act of 2018, State Offices of Rural Health Reauthorization Act of 2018 (S. 2278), Water Infrastructure Improvement Act (H.R. 7279), SECURE Technology Act (H.R. 7327), Concurring in the Senate Amendment to (H.R. 6227) - A Christmas Message from Rep. Loudermilk 
 

￼
 
 
Rep. Loudermilk on WSB Discussing the Border Wall and Possible Government Shutdown
 
￼
Video of the Week [1 Of 2]: Loudermilk: It Looks More Promising That There May Not Be a Partial Shutdown, Lots of Activity with Pence and Mulvaney



 
￼
Video of the Week [2 of 2]: Border Funding Battle Continues as Government Shutdown Approaches
 
 
 
Press Release of the Week [1 of 2]: Rep. Loudermilk Meets with President Trump to Discuss Funding for Government and Border Security Amid Talk of Government Shutdown
 
 
Rep. Barry Loudermilk (R-GA) issued the following statement after he met with President Trump at the White House about funding for the federal government, disaster relief for Georgia, and security at our southern border:

“Today, I met with President Trump and House leadership to discuss the urgency of securing our southern border. The President agrees it is of paramount importance to end the flow of drugs, illegal weapons, human trafficking, and terrorists entering our country. I believe Congress should not leave Washington, D.C. without completing our job, and many of my Republican colleagues in the House agree we should stay in town and continue to fight for the American people. 

Read More ▸ 

 

 
Press Release of the Week [2 of 2]: House Passes Retirement Savings Tax Incentives, Obamacare Reforms, and Tax Relief for Disaster Victims
 
 
Rep. Barry Loudermilk (R-GA) issued the following statement after the House passed the Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act, H.R. 88: 

“This vote reaffirms House Republicans’ continued commitment to alleviate the tax burdens placed on the American taxpayer. This package of bills will provide some retirement savings tax incentives, as well as tax relief for victims of disasters, specifically hurricanes Florence and Michael, in addition to the California wildfires. Among other provisions, Republicans voted to permanently repeal the Obamacare tanning tax and delay the Obamacare medical device tax, the health insurance tax, and the Cadillac tax. This legislation also makes several technical corrections to the 2017 tax reform law, which businesses in Georgia’s 11th Congressional District desperately need, and requires the IRS to develop a customer service strategy - something I have long advocated for. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly consider its importance, and how it will improve the lives of America’s hardworking taxpayers.” 

Read More ▸

Subject: Fighting for Border Security
Message:
￼ 
Website  |   About  |   Contact Me  |   Serving You  |   Media Center  |   Legislative Work  |   Our District  |   Resources 
  

December 22, 2018
THE SCALISE CAPITOL REPORT
Fighting for Border Security This Thursday, House Republicans overwhelmingly voted to support President Trump's request for border security funding to keep our country safe. We are a nation of immigrants and we are also a nation of laws. There is a legal way to come to our country, and more than 1 million people come to our country legally every year. Unfortunately, we know there are people that illegally cross our southern border and do harm to our neighbors and our country. We cannot let this continue. We need to secure the border.   I spoke on the House floor to urge support for this funding. You can watch the clip here.   While the House showed our commitment to keeping this country safe, the Senate needs to act. I am urging the Senate to quickly reach an agreement with President Trump that secures our border.   Ensuring Certainty of NFIP Millions of families across the country, and hundreds of thousands in Louisiana, depend on the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP), and we must ensure that there isn’t a lapse in the program. Earlier this week, I led the effort in Congress to pass legislation ensuring there wouldn’t be a lapse in the program as it faced a December 21 deadline for renewal.   I spoke on the House floor about my dedication to keeping this program running and to promoting commonsense reforms. You can watch the clip here. 
Awarding Steve Gleason the Congressional Gold Medal In Louisiana, Steve Gleason inspired all of us as a New Orleans Saint and has continued to inspire us with his bravery and service to others battling ALS. More than 5,000 people each year are diagnosed with ALS, and Steve Gleason serves as a leading voice in championing the fight against ALS. I am pleased to announce that to honor this service, Congress is awarding Steve Gleason a 2019 Congressional Gold Medal. More than 350 Members of Congress signed on to support this legislation, a sign of how powerful a mark Steve Gleason has made on this country. 
 It is an honor to represent you in Congress. For more information please visit my website, Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook pages.   God Bless,
￼

Steve Scalise
House Majority Whip

Subject: Funding the government
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
I, like many Americans, am frustrated that the Senate could not come to an agreement on a spending measure late Friday night, causing a partial government shutdown. 
For years, we have promised the American people that we would fix security and manpower issues along the southern border that have allowed not only illegal immigration, but also drug, weapon and human trafficking to occur. Thankfully, the House successfully amended the Senate continuing resolution (CR) earlier in the week to include $5 billion the President has continuously requested to protect our country from criminal activity along the southern border.
I am also thankful that after a long fight we were able to amend the CR to include $7.8 billion in federal assistance to help farmers and families recover from catastrophic weather events in Georgia, Alabama, Florida, the Carolinas and California. 
Chuck Schumer seems to have two goals: First, embarrass the President no matter the cost to America, and second, protect Nancy Pelosi no matter the cost to America. 
As we continue to work through negotiations, I will press my colleagues and the White House for additional resources for disaster assistance and border security. 
  
2018 FARM BILL SIGNED INTO LAW 
After nearly five years of countless meetings, round tables, hearings and farm visits, our farmers and rural communities have an updated agriculture policy to meet the needs of today. 
The 2018 Farm Bill contains provisions to strengthen the farm safety net, prioritize research and development, improve credit programs for farmers, and develop additional risk management policies for specialty crops like peaches and pecans, among others.  
I was very honored to be at the White House for the signing of this legislation, and I thank President Trump for his support of rural Georgians and commitment to advancing policies that benefit all Americans.  
￼ 
President Trump signs the Farm Bill into law. 
  
CHRISTMAS MESSAGE TO OUR TROOPS 
In advance of Christmas, I wanted to share a special Christmas message with our troops overseas and their families. Thank you for your service and sacrifice to our county. Our thoughts are with you during the holiday season.
Click here to watch a special message to our troops. 
￼ 
Merry Christmas to our troops and military families.
  
VALDOSTA STATE WINS DII FOOTBALL NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP 
On December 15th, the Valdosta State University Blazers football team won their 4th NCAA Division II Football National Championship. I want to congratulate the Blazers, Coach Kerwin Bell, Valdosta State President Richard Carvajal, and the entire football and athletics staff at Valdosta State on this accomplishment. Georgia is very proud of you, and I hope you will take time to celebrate another title in "Titletown."



￼
￼
Rep. Austin Scott

Subject: Merry Christmas!
Message:
For unto us a Child is born, Unto us a Son is given (Isaiah 9:6-7) 
Having trouble viewing this email? View it as a Web page.
￼ 
Website                          Media Center                        Contact Me
Merry Christmas!
This is a season of hope and renewal – a reminder that even in the darkest days, the greatest hope can emerge.  As Christians, we celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ, our Lord and Savior.
￼
This beautiful Constitution Christmas ornament was a gift from the Indy Defenders of Liberty. It makes a great addition to the Rokita family Christmas tree.
Celebrating Christmas has long been a part of American history and celebrated by generations of Americans.  In 1783, General George Washington resigned his commission as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army on December 23, so that he could be home in Mount Vernon by Christmas.  When Congress first established the first four federal holidays in 1870, Christmas was one of them.  For Hoosiers, since 1962 Monument Circle has been transformed into the "world's largest Christmas tree."  Christmas is a part of our fabric.
￼
My greatest blessing in life is my family - my wife Kathy and our two boys, Teddy and Ryan.
I believe strongly in the need to preserve the true purpose of Christmas as a holiday in America.  I have cosponsored legislation to protect the symbols of Christmas.  I do so because Christmas is a deep part of our Nation's culture and the traditions which are rooted in the Christian faith of our founding fathers.  Our Nation has always cherished our faith.  The Founding Fathers took Christmas seriously, as did successive generations of Americans, and so must we.
￼
Ryan was excited to meet Santa at the Indy Defenders of Liberty-West's annual Christmas party.
As you join with loved ones for Christmas, I hope you too will reflect on the season of giving and remember what Christmas is really about, the greatest gift that we could ever be given - the birth of our Savior in Christ.
And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” (Luke 2:8-12)
From all of us in the Rokita Family, as our President says, Merry Christmas!


Sincerely,
￼

Dear Friend,  No matter how you spend the holidays, I hope this Christmas season brings peace and goodwill into your life. Inspired by the perfect savior given to imperfect people, many will find the ‘Christmas Spirit’ in their hearts and take care of the needy, volunteer at food shelters, sing Christmas carols to their neighbors, attend religious services, and find ways to spread cheer into the world. All of the acts of kindness and generosity around the world remind me that the child born in Bethlehem has touched more lives than any one person or even nation could ever dream of...KEEP READING HERE


WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH

￼
￼
I was thrilled to help Kingston and Lake Road Elementary Schools celebrate being named National Blue Ribbon Schools! It's a tremendous honor that was earned by only 349 schools in the nation. I presented both schools with my remarks in the U.S. House of Representatives celebrating their achievements, which will be preserved forever in the Congressional Record. 
￼  I caught up with Faune Riggin in Cape Girardeau to discuss the ongoing debate over funding border security and why I believe it's time to properly protect our country - listen here.
￼
I donated books of every variety from the Library of Congress to the Bonne Terre Regional Library this week. One of the books was about the Chicago Cubs... I have a feeling somebody was pretty eager to get rid of that one. 


THIS WEEK IN DC
￼

People visiting the White House were treated to wonderful piano music from the talented southern Missouri native Stephen Limbaugh III. Check out this story, I love the part where the Secret Service gives him the thumbs up for playing Charlie Brown!

￼

The Student Empowerment Act, my bill with Senator Ted Cruz that allows families to save for everyday education expenses, passed the U.S. House this week! It would allow families to save for tuition, books, tutoring expenses, and more K-12 expenses in tax-free accounts while expanding this benefit to homeschool families for the first time.

￼
The New Year and new Congress are right around the corner - what are YOUR priorities for 2019? 


LEGISLATIVE WRAP-UP
H.R. 695 - Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act, Fulfills the Trump Administration's request for border security and would keep the government open. PASSED – REP. SMITH VOTED YES  H.R. 88 - Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act, Includes Congressman Smith and Senator Cruz's bill to help families pay for education, allows families to withdraw money penalty-free from retirement accounts when they have a child, and requires the IRS to submit a plan to improve its customer service. PASSED – REP. SMITH VOTED YES   S. 2076 - BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act, Applies a public health approach to fight Alzheimer's disease and support early detection and diagnosis, enhance support to caregivers, and reduce the risk of cognitive decline. PASSED – REP. SMITH VOTED YES

Subject: Tax Reform Anniversary
Message:
News from Representative Olson

Clicks open in browser window     Clicks open plain text version
￼
 
Website
Contact Us
How Can I Help?
Issues
Legislation
News Center
Our District
About Pete
 
December 22, 2018
￼

￼


CONNECT WITH ME
￼
￼
￼
  
Dear Friend,  Today is the one year anniversary of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act becoming law! Since its enactment, America has benefited from the strongest labor market in nearly 20 years. Over 2 million jobs have been created and our 3.7 % unemployment rate is at a 17 year low. That’s historic economic growth!  While we all filed our taxes under the old tax code this past spring, Texans have already reaped the benefits of the new tax law. Many folks received bonuses at local companies and others received higher wages or stock options. Folks have more money in the bank and more peace of mind knowing they can set some extra money aside for future emergencies. In addition, when you file your taxes this upcoming spring, most Americans will see lower rates and a simplified process – saving you both time and money! Here are a few ways the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will do just that:  Lowered Rates for All Americans - With lower rates across the board, American workers will keep more of their hard-earned income. A typical family of four earning $75,000 will see a tax cut of more than $2,000. Folks will have more money to pay bills, purchase groceries or send their kids to college.  Nearly Doubled the Standard Deduction – We increased the income tax standard deduction to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for married couples. That’s almost double the amount folks received under the old tax code!  Doubled the Child Tax Credit - We doubled the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $2,000 and preserved both the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit and the Adoption Tax Credit. Families will be able to use 529 accounts to save for elementary, secondary and higher education. This provides real relief for parents coping with the high costs of raising a family.   A Simpler Tax Filing Process – 2018 was the last year of filing your taxes under the old, complicated tax code. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is designed to help Americans file taxes in a simpler way, saving time and money. The IRS also released a withholding calculator to help you determine the correct withholding amount for you and your family.    Repealed the Obamacare Individual Mandate - The new tax law repealed the unpopular Obamacare individual mandate, which forced folks to purchase  health coverage they didn’t want, didn’t need or couldn’t afford. Folks are no longer fined if they don’t purchase these government mandated plans. Now they have the freedom to buy the health care plan they want and that is right for them and their families.  I'm honored to represent you in Congress. For more information or to sign up for my E-newsletter, please visit my website, www.olson.house.gov.     Very respectfully, Pete Olson

Subject: A Chaotic Finale...
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
A Chaotic Finale...
Dear Friend:
I appreciate you taking the time to read this brief update. It remains an honor for me to serve as your United States Representative in Washington, D.C.  I returned to Washington this past Wednesday, along with my Congressional colleagues, to conclude the work of the 115th Congress. While we also passed other important legislation this week – more on that below – our primary reason to return was to complete our work on the Federal Government’s 2019 fiscal year appropriations.  As you probably have heard from news reports, a handful of federal agencies were funded on a Continuing Resolution scheduled to expire on December 21st. These agencies represent about 25% of annual federal discretionary funding. Congress did provide on-time, full-year funding for the departments of Defense, Education, Energy, Health and Human Services, Labor, Veterans Affairs, and Congressional operations. So far so good, but then events took some surprising twists.   On Wednesday, December 19th, just prior to the expiration of the Continuing Resolution, the Senate decided to “punt” by extending the Continuing Resolution to February 8, 2019. While this would have avoided a partial government shutdown, my view is that we should focus on passing final appropriation bills – not continuing resolutions. The job of the 115th Congress is to complete the 2019 appropriation process. Pushing this into next year means that the 116th Congress will be delayed in getting started on 2020 appropriations and will instead have to spend time and effort dealing with matters that this Congress should have resolved.  The primary reason for this failure was a dispute between the President and my Democratic colleagues over how much to appropriate to the Department of Homeland Security to construct additional fencing and other security measures on our southern border. The President wanted $5 billion in funding for this program, while my Democratic colleagues were only willing to provide $1.6 billion. When the Senate bill arrived in the House, we amended it to add the $5 billion for border security, plus another $8 billion for disaster relief to assist the victims of the California fires and the hurricane in Florida.    I voted for the amended version of the Continuing Resolution presented to the House even though it was not, as I noted above, my first choice. I voted for it because when presented with an “either-or” choice of pass the resolution or shut down the government, my priority is to keep the government open so that it can continue to serve the American people.  I do not know what the right dollar amount is for the U.S. to spend right now on improving the security of its southern border. What I do know is that it is our job in Congress (and for the President) to work out reasonable compromises of our differences and focus on taking care of our country and its citizens. The unwillingness of either my Democratic colleagues or the President to bend even a bit is deeply troubling to me. If this is the state of affairs today, I worry about how partisan positioning will impact the ability of the 116th Congress to function in 2019 and 2020. So at the time of this writing, I remain in Washington waiting for House and Senate leadership to come to some sort of an agreement with the President so we can vote on a final bill to fund the government for 2019. This is not the way I had planned to spend the Christmas holiday or to end my time as your representative in Congress.  On a more positive note, while we were back here in Washington this week we passed, on a bipartisan basis, the First Step Act. This bill takes some significant steps toward altering the federal criminal justice system by easing overly punitive federal prison sentences. This legislation only affects the federal system that currently incarcerates about 180,000 out the total U.S. jail and prison population of 2.1 million. However, if these reforms do successfully decrease recidivism, I would expect the states to adopt similar policies. If we can reduce the number of people we imprison without an increase in rates of criminal activity that will represent a major accomplishment. I look forward to seeing how these reforms work. This bill is on its way to the President for his signature.  The House also passed this week the Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act and the Taxpayer First Act. This 253-page bill includes tax-related disaster relief, technical tax corrections, Internal Revenue Service (IRS) reform, retirement savings measures, and a delay of certain healthcare related taxes. Many of the reforms in this bill are designed to make it easier and simpler for you to deal with the IRS.  Finally, I invite you to stay in contact with me via my website, Facebook or Twitter. See you around the district! 
Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative

Subject: Merry Christmas
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: December 22, 2018  
￼  I was honored to fill out holiday cards for our men and women in uniform as part of the American Red Cross's Holidays for Heroes program.    
Merry Christmas   As we prepare to join our families for Christmas, I am reminded of so many things we should be thankful for. This year will be our second Christmas with our young son, Zeke. Much of what I do in Washington is motivated by a desire to leave a healthy country for coming generations to inherit.   When I listen to former President Ronald Reagan’s speeches, it is clear he was motivated by the same feelings. He always appealed for unity with a positive disposition, but he never shied away from directly addressing the American people.  President Reagan understood the importance of fiscal discipline, family values, and the American embrace of freedom. As is my tradition, I would like to share with you one of his speeches which holds the same truths as it did in 1981 when he gave it.   I wish your family a Merry Christmas and a very Happy New Year.    President Ronald Reagan Radio Address to the Nation  December 23, 1981   Tonight, in millions of American homes, the glow of the Christmas tree is a reflection of the love Jesus taught us.  Like the shepherds and wise men of that first Christmas, we Americans have always tried to follow a higher light, a star, if you will.  At lonely campfire vigils along the frontier, in the darkest days of the Great Depression, through war and peace, the twin beacons of faith and freedom have brightened the American sky.  At times our footsteps may have faltered, but trusting in God's help, we've never lost our way. ... Like the National Christmas Tree, our country is a living, growing thing planted in rich American soil.  Only our devoted care can bring it to full flower.  So, let this holiday season be for us a time of rededication.  Even as we rejoice, however, let us remember that for some Americans, this will not be as happy a Christmas as it should be.  I know a little of what they feel.  I remember one Christmas Eve during the Great Depression, my father opening what he thought was a Christmas greeting.  It was a notice that he no longer had a job.  Over the past year, we've begun the long, hard work of economic recovery.  Our goal is an America in which every citizen who needs and wants a job can get a job. ... A few months before he took up residence in this house, one of my predecessors, John Kennedy, tried to sum up the temper of the times with a quote from an author closely tied to Christmas, Charles Dickens.  We were living, he said, in the best of times and the worst of times.  Well, in some ways that's even more true today.  The world is full of peril, as well as promise.  Too many of its people, even now, live in the shadow of want and tyranny. ... Once, earlier in this century, an evil influence threatened that the lights were going out all over the world.  Let the light of millions of candles in American homes give notice that the light of freedom is not going to be extinguished.  We are blessed with a freedom and abundance denied to so many.  Let those candles remind us that these blessings bring with them a solid obligation, an obligation to the God who guides us, an obligation to the heritage of liberty and dignity handed down to us by our forefathers and an obligation to the children of the world, whose future will be shaped by the way we live our lives today. ... Christmas means so much because of one special child.  But Christmas also reminds us that all children are special, that they are gifts from God, gifts beyond price that mean more than any presents money can buy.  In their love and laughter, in our hopes for their future lies the true meaning of Christmas. 
Sincerely,
￼ 
ADRIAN SMITH
Member of Congress

Subject: We Must Secure Our Border
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email 
￼ 
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
December 22, 2018


WE MUST SECURE OUR BORDER The crisis we face at our southern border is a national security issue. Nancy Pelosi Democrats have decided that keeping our borders open is more important than keeping the American people safe and our government open. I supported the funding bill because it fully funds President Trump’s $5 billion request for border security. The national security of our country can’t wait any longer.
The House has done its job to make America safer. Now it’s up to the Senate. 
KEEPING IHS DOORS OPEN DURING A GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN This week, I introduced the Pay Our Doctors Bill to keep IHS' doors open despite the potential for a government shutdown. Congress needs to stop putting Native Americans’ health care in the crossfire of political spending fights. The Pay Our Doctors Act is a good start. Learn more about the bill on my website.  
REAUTHORIZING THE STATE OFFICES OF RURAL HEALTH Rural hospitals are closing their doors at an alarming rate. Eighty-five rural hospitals have closed since 2010, and 673 are vulnerable to closure. More closures are coming and Congress needs to start making changes to ensure that rural Americans have the healthcare they need. My bill, the State Offices of Rural Health Reauthorization Act, will help Oklahoma rural hospitals keep their doors open and continue to improve and build on the quality care they provide their patients. The bill is now on its way to be signed by the president. I spoke on my bill before it passed the House floor. Watch on my YouTube page.  
￼
STIGLER ACT AMENDMENTS HEADS TO PRESIDENT'S DESK The Stigler Act Amendments passed the House this week. Land that is handed down from generation to generation in Native American families is a part of our culture. It is what allows families like mine to continually pass their family’s history on to the next generation. The members of the Five Tribes deserve the right to hand down their history without blood quantum requirements—just like members of every other tribe can. I was proud to work with Congressman Tom Cole to get this bill across the finish line. On to the president's desk! 
OK IN DC It was great to have Kim Teehee of the Cherokee Nation visit the office this week for the passage of the Stigler Act Amendments.  
￼
 
￼
Enjoyed having the Shaddix Family of Verdigris in town!
WEEKLY WRAP-UP Since Congress has not completed its work to fund the remaining 25 percent of the government, our work this week is not done. I will continue to update you about Congress's efforts to fund the government on my Facebook and Twitter pages.   
THE RETURN OF THE CHRISTMAS SPIRIT It’s hard to remember a time when the real meaning of Christmas was the same as what the world was celebrating.  By and large, Christmas as we know it is about giving and receiving presents, Santa coming to town, and the commercialization that comes along with it.
Somewhere along the way, we lost the true spirit of Christmas.  Between giving the perfect gift and getting everything on our list, we forgot the real meaning of Christmas.  Christmas—as it should be—got lost in the noise.
Matthew 1:21 tells us: “And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus: for he shall save his people from their sins.”  The true meaning of Christmas is the celebration of the Lord Jesus Christ who was born to this earth to save sinners like us. 
For the last two years, I have been wished Merry Christmas, rather than Happy Holidays, by the President of the United States.  The war on Christmas is over.  And in turn, Americans are free to say Merry Christmas again, without political correctness getting in the way.  We are free to celebrate our faith in God, just as are others are free to practice their religion. 
The miraculous birth of Jesus Christ calls us to rejoice.  This Christmas, my family will partake in the celebration of the real spirit of Christmas.  “For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life (John 3:16).” 
On behalf of the entire Mullin family, I want to wish you and your family a very, Merry Christmas.

￼
See more from this week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way.
Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin
Member of Congress

Subject: Congressional Report

Saturday, December 22, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 

This week, I met with various individuals and organizations, including a meeting with the President of the Texas Farm Bureau. I was also named Chief Deputy Whip for the 116th Congress, a great leadership opportunity that I am looking forward to. 

In the district, my staff attended several events including the Atascosa County Justice Center ribbon cutting ceremony, the Baptist Health Foundation grant presentation, and more. My Outreach Coordinators also presented several Congressional Certificates of Recognition to different outstanding constituents throughout the area.  

I have also included a video from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that details ways you can ensure your pets' safety this holiday season. 

As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 

Lastly, I hope you join my staff and I for a Swearing-In Ceremony and New Office Open House on Thursday, January 3, 2019. 

Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays!

￼



Rep. Cuellar Named Chief Deputy Whip in the 116th Congress


I would like to thank House Majority Whip-Elect Clyburn for providing me with this great leadership opportunity. It is a great honor to be named Chief Deputy Whip for this upcoming Congress, where I promise to work in a bipartisan manner and serve the American people. 


Rep. Cuellar Meets with Texas Farm Bureau President
￼

On Wednesday, December 12, I met with Texas Farm Bureau (TFB) President Russell Boening to celebrate the successful passage of the Farm Bill and to discuss upcoming legislative priorities for the 116th Congress. Pictured from left to right are Rep. Henry Cuellar and TFB President Russell Boening. 


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Attends Atascosa County Justice Ribbon Cutting Ceremony 
￼

On Monday, December 17, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen, and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente attended the Atascosa County Justice ribbon cutting ceremony in Jourdanton. The plaque in the center recognizes officials who made this facility possible. Pictured from left to right are Commissioners Bill Carroll, Mark Gillespie, Bill Torans, Eliseo Perez, and Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente. 


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Presents Congressional Certificate of Recognition to McMullen County Treasurer
￼
 
 
On Tuesday, December 18, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen, and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente presented retiring McMullen County Treasurer, Judy Wyatt, with a Congressional Certificate of Recognition on behalf of the Congressman. A lifelong resident of McMullen County, she proudly served the last eight years as County Treasurer as well as a retiring teacher in the McMullen County Independent School District (ISD). Pictured from left to right are Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente and retiring McMullen County Treasurer Judy Wyatt. 


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Attends Baptist Health Foundation Grant Presentation
￼

On Monday, December 17, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen, and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente attended an event announcing Baptist Health Foundation's $300,000 grant presentation towards the construction of the Atascosa Health Center facility in Floresville. From left to right are Wilson County Judge Richard Jackson, Director of Atascosa Health Center, Inc. Monty Small, Executive Director of Children's Alliance of South Texas Meriden M. Erickson, and Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente.  


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Holds Rio Grande Valley Community Engagement Meetings
￼

On Tuesday, December 18, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo County and Starr counties Nichole Hernandez met with Rio Grande Valley (RGV) community members and Senators John Cornyn and Ted Cruz's staff to discuss upcoming events and legislative days in 2019. Pictured from left to right are RGV Partnership President/CEO Sergio Contreras, Office of Sen. Cruz Deputy State Director Casandra Meade, Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez, Office of Sen. Cornyn South Texas Staff Assistant Clarissa Sanchez, Office of Sen. Cornyn South Texas Regional Director and Community Outreach Advisor Ana Maria Garcia, Small Business Adminstration District Director for the Lower RGV Angela Burton, RGV Partnership Engagement and Events Director Melissa Sanchez, and RGV Partnership Financial Director Dulce Martinez. 


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Meets with RGV Hispanic Chamber of Commerce
￼

On Tuesday, December 18, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr counties Nichole Hernandez met with the President and CEO of the Rio Grande Valley (RGV) Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Cynthia Sakulenzki, to discuss future community engagement events, such as the 2019 Senior Summit and Legislative Luncheon. These events will provide the community with detailed information about federal resources available to resolve issues related to Social Security Benefits, Identity Theft, Healthcare, Citizenship and Immigration Services. Pictured from left to right are President and CEO of the RGV Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Cynthia Sakulenzki and Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez.


Rep. Cuellar's Outreach Coordinator Presents Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Starr County Justice of the Peace, Precinct 5
￼

On Thursday, December 20, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr counties Nichole Hernandez presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Starr County Justice of the Peace for Precinct 5, Judge Antonia "Toni" Trevino, on behalf of the Congressman. She will be retiring after 34 years of public service. Pictured from left to right are Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez and Starr County Justice of the Peace for Precinct 5, Judge Antonia "Toni" Trevino.


Staff Spotlight: Patrick O'Connor
￼
Meet my Legislative Correspondent Patrick O'Connor. Patrick works in my Washington, D.C. office where he supervises interns, coordinates tours, and manages constituent mail. In his free time, he enjoys reading and cooking. 

 




Keep Your Pets Safe from Holiday Hazards 
￼
With all the excitement that the holiday season brings, it is often easy to forget some of the health hazards that are posed to our dogs and cats. This video from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) gives an informational overview about steps to take in order to ensure that pets are safe over the holidays. 


Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays! 

￼

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: The Trump Shutdown is Bad for Our Country
Message:
￼ 




 
 December 22, 2018
The Trump Shutdown is  Bad for Our Country
A MESSAGE FROM CONGRESSMAN STENY H. HOYER   
I am extremely disappointed that President Trump and Congressional Republicans forced a partial government shutdown. Not only is the chaos and uncertainty of a government shutdown bad for our country, it jeopardizes thousands of federal employees, many of whom live in the Fifth District.  
For the second time in a calendar year, Republicans have shut down the government of the United States. This cynical ploy, just days before Christmas, is extremely irresponsible. Republicans still control all levers of government. If they are serious about ending the shutdown, they will work with Democrats to find consensus. I urge my Republican colleagues to end this irresponsible shutdown and work with Democrats to reopen the government as soon as possible.  
My office will be open to help residents of Maryland's Fifth Congressional District to the best of our ability during the Trump shutdown. Please do not hesitate to reach out should you need assistance.  
As always, I encourage all Fifth District residents to continue to share their concerns and insights with me by contacting my office or connecting with me on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram.    
Sincerely Yours,   ￼  Steny H. Hoyer

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

December 22, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review




December 17

Exit Interview with C-SPAN: I hope your weekend went well….

Last week, I did an exit interview with C-SPAN, and I have taken the liberty of including it here.

I’d love to get your thoughts….

￼
Click above to watch the video. 

￼

December 18

Thank You and a Look Back: Tomorrow, I head back to Washington, and it remains to be seen if a deal will emerge with regards to passing the remaining spending bills before funding expires this Friday. I’ll have more on that later, but I wanted to take minute to say the obvious…it’s been an honor to represent you in Congress and to attempt to advance the ideals of limited government and personal freedom while there. I’ve tried my very best to do these things, and my team put together what follows as a synopsis of our collective endeavors on your behalf. Indeed, the operative questions of leadership at any inflection point lie in what does it mean and where do we go from here and this piece at some levels represents our office's attempt to answer those questions.

What they put together is, in essence, a footprint of the thousands of hours invested over the last five years in trying to represent the people of the Lowcountry and the principles of limited government. The legislative review is broken down into the five sections that represent the focal points of our efforts. Click here to read more.


￼
Click above to read the Legislative Review.


￼


￼
Click above to read the article. 

￼

December 19
                               
Suspension Votes are Supposed to be Noncontroversial: Tonight, we had a series of ten suspension votes whose topics ranged from fisheries management to educational programs on heart disease. At the bottom of this vote description, I have included each of the bill numbers, names, and sponsors - and how I voted.
So as to avoid a twelve-page post in describing these votes, let me give you a little overview of at least my thinking on suspension votes like these. Suspension votes are non-controversial votes that have an expedited path to the floor. As a consequence, they require a two-thirds vote rather than the simple majority usually required on votes.
Because they are non-controversial, many of the T’s that normally get crossed are looked over - and this phenomenon goes on steroids as you get to the closing days of a session. And that’s obviously where we are.
Structurally, my concerns over these votes fell into four categories.... Click here to read more.                                                              
￼
December 20  Government Funding Debate: Just a quick update to let you know what I know as I know it….
Last night’s votes went late, and it looks like that was just a precursor to the way that votes will go today.
There are three things at play that I think will very much impact the day and today’s voting schedule.
First, it’s the end of session, and given that whatever time we have remaining represents the last train leaving the station in carrying legislative ideas forward, a lot gets added here at the end. This creates its own time drag.
Two, we’re now in for a fight. I wouldn’t have said this yesterday, but after stepping out of an hour and a half long conference meeting a bit ago, it certainly seems to reflect the mood of the majority of Republican Conference members. Click here to read more. 
￼
December 21  Getting Philosophical After a Successful Surgery: How about a strange and rather philosophic post here at the end of a long Friday?
I say this because we are now in hurry-up-and-wait-mode here at the capitol. There is a tug of war on funding for the wall in the continuing resolution versus no funding for the wall. I’m here with about 400 other members waiting to see what negotiations bare over the hours ahead. We’re in complete limbo for the evening. And so while I wish I could give you an update on what’s going to come next, that will certainly not come until tomorrow…if it comes then.
So let me go back to the strange and philosophical.
I say that because it has been a long week at many different levels. Over the last few days, we have actually set records with regard to the number of recorded votes outside of amendments to appropriation bills. It’s been a grind trying to keep up with all of the different topics covered in each of these bills, but that seems to be the season that we’re in right now.
It’s also becoming a long week given all the explosions on the Hill that have ranged from the Gen. Mattis resignation to the looming government shutdown that will likely come at midnight.
But, in my case, it’s also been a long week, given I spent last Friday at MUSC undergoing a heart procedure. Click here to read more.

Subject: saturday snapshot
Message:
￼ 
 

December 22, 2018
 
Dear Friends, 
There has been a lot going on in our neck of the woods of Wisconsin, and I wanted to take a moment to share some of the latest news with you!
 Top Five In The Nation...Number One In Our Hearts 
There are a lot of reasons to be proud to be from Wisconsin; it's hands down the best place to work, raise a family, or vacation in the country.  But we're also leaders when it comes to Christmas tree production! That means that Wisconsin continues to bring joy to families across the country this season. 
Click HERE or the image below to celebrate Wisconsin's proud Christmas tree production! 
￼ 
 Our Nation Deserves Border Security 
At my recent townhall meeting at Northcentral Technical College in Antigo, I discussed the need for our nation to have a secure border. 
There are too many families across our nation who have lost loved ones because of the meth and heroin that pours over our southern border.  In fact, at a recent Law Enforcement Roundtable, Wisconsin law enforcement leaders told me that even though our state is more than 1,000 miles away from Mexico, more than 90% of the meth and heroin in our community can be traced back to Mexico.  This is unacceptable. Click HERE to watch a short interview with Eau Claire's Channel 18 about the need for border security. 
￼ 
 More Town Halls! 
Not only did we have a productive townhall meeting in Antigo, but it was great to chat with folks in Eagle River and Medford as well. It's important that we routinely get the opportunity to discuss the issues face to face.
Click HERE or the image below to "like" and SHARE our recent town hall pics!
￼ 
 Spring Isn't THAT Far Off! Great Opportunity For College Students Or Recent Grads      Attention college students or recent grads: my Washington DC office is now accepting applications for Spring internships. It's a great way to serve your community and get involved in the political process.   For more information on the internship, click HERE or the photo below. Also be sure to share these opportunities with any interested students!
￼ 
 Stay Connected On Social Media         
Snapchat is a fun way to stay connected with what’s going on in Wisconsin and Washington (and of course, find me on Facebook and Twitter- @RepSeanDuffy). Find my snapchat profile either by searching @RepSeanDuffy or use the Snapcode below!  
￼   
 
Until next week!   God bless, 
￼ 
Sean Duffy

Subject: A secure border is part of the fight against the opioid crisis
Message:
￼ 
A secure border is part of the 
fight against the opioid crisis 


Our government was founded for one purpose: to fulfill the charges set forth in the Constitution, “. . .establish Justice, insure domestic Tranquility, provide for the common defence, promote the general Welfare, and secure the Blessings of Liberty.” 

Lawmakers take an oath to the Constitution. We fail in our sworn duty if we refuse to ensure the sovereignty, security, and well-being of this nation through secure borders.
 
     
￼

On an otherwise calm August morning I sat in the Clermont County Courthouse listening to the devastating story of a local couple who had struggled to save both their lives and the lives of their children as they wrestled with the throes of addiction. Their stories started as so many do, from childhood exposure to drug abuse, or a workplace injury that led to a deadly addiction, and then the desperate lengths they would go to, putting themselves and their children in danger for the next fix. Fortunately, for the couple I spoke to, they found treatment and successfully broke from the intense grip of addiction.
Many Ohio families are not so lucky. The Cincinnati Enquirer won a Pulitzer Prize for their piece documenting a week tracking the opioid crisis in southern Ohio. They found there at least 180 overdoses, 18 overdose deaths, and 15 babies born with heroin-related medical problems were reported in our Southern Ohio counties in just one week. Our backyard has been ground zero for the opioid epidemic. The book Dreamland: The True Tale of America’s Opiate Epidemic, by Sam Quinones, tells the story of how opioids devastated the city of Portsmouth, located in Ohio’s 2nd Congressional District.
The very detailed book tracks the flow of drugs from Xalisco, Mexico, to Ohio — a route that had surprisingly no obstacles for drug traffickers and dealers. It talks about cartels using customer service to “ deliver just like pizza delivery.” Drug dealers would prey on the most vulnerable, waiting outside of treatment centers to tempt people on shaky ground early in their recovery back into addiction.
The claims in the book about the origins of the drugs are supported by the Council on Foreign Relations, which estimates that “most of the heroin coming into the United States is cultivated on poppy farms in Mexico, with eight cartels controlling production and operating distribution hubs in major U.S. cities.” They also estimate that “most fentanyl coming into the United States is produced in China, and commonly transited through Mexico.”
U.S. Customs and Border Protection reported just three years ago that 99.8 percent of methamphetamine seized in the U.S. came through the southern border. Burying our heads in the sand will not solve this urgent problem.
To truly curb the flow of illicit drugs into our community, we must secure our border. Some have said that a wall would not stop drug traffic. But the wall is just one component used to describe an all-of-the-above approach to border security, from physical barriers, to surveillance technology, to increased personnel patrolling the border and ports of entry.
I have always believed that there is not a single solution to complex problems, but rather multi-faceted solutions needed to combat problems on multiple fronts. Increased border security will not be a magic bullet. It will not stop every drug lord from trafficking drugs and people over the border, but it will help curb the flow. It is not the single solution, but rather one of many important solutions. Earlier this year Congress passed the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6), a comprehensive package of bills targeted toward advancing treatment and recovery initiatives, improving addiction prevention, protecting our communities, and bolstering efforts to fight deadly synthetic drugs like fentanyl. This was an important effort to help fight the opioid crisis. However, securing the border is a step we cannot skip.
Sadly, gridlock in Washington has stopped any possible progress toward securing the border. To date, the solutions proposed by Democrats have been to leave the status quo, which is effectively no solution at all, or to fully advocate for open borders. Open borders would make the situation worse and would welcome even more drugs and violence across the border.
Funding for border security shouldn’t be about a political point. This should be about keeping Americans safe, keeping illicit drugs out of our country, protecting families, and our precious lives. 
This is the first installment of a four part series on border security.
Part 2: Immigration Reform is Not Possible Without A Secure Border 
Part 3: Border Security Is National Security
Part 4: The Health Implications of an Unsecure Border 


￼  ￼  ￼  ￼

Subject: Approaching Health Care in the Upcoming Congress
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Approaching Health Care in the Upcoming Congress
Just last week a federal court declared all of Obamacare unconstitutional. I know many read about the ruling and wondered what it means for them. The short answer is that nothing changes for next year. Obamacare is still in effect, except the individual mandate has been repealed so there’s no fine if you choose not to buy a government-approved plan. If you are currently covered by an Obamacare policy, this ruling won’t affect you. Long-term – if the ruling is upheld on appeal – this could be the catalyst that brings the two parties together to get a workable, bipartisan health care solution that provides affordable access to quality, patient-centered health coverage. 
Why did the federal court overturn the law? When the Supreme Court upheld Obamacare in 2012, the majority argued that Obamacare’s enforcement mechanism to require people to purchase insurance – the individual mandate – was a tax. While I disagreed with that ruling at the time, the judge in this case said that because this fine was repealed, the rest of Obamacare – which for the first time compels U.S. citizens to purchase a product – was unconstitutional. Americans will no longer be forced to buy a product they can’t afford – or don’t want – or face a tax penalty if they go without. Obamacare has resulted in taxpayers, at state and federal levels, paying more to fund government health care programs, and it needs to be replaced. 
If you have a pre-existing condition, I think it’s important you know something else: both parties agree that protections are needed to ensure these folks can access affordable health coverage. I think a better alternative to Obamacare would be extending the same protections that exist for employer-sponsored health plans to the individual and small group markets, where many small businesses purchase their health insurance. Before the enactment of Obamacare, if you had a pre-existing condition and a plan through your employer, you were able to get affordable health insurance. Folks in the individual and small group markets should have that same sense of security.  
Another approach we can take to make health care coverage affordable is to allow people to purchase their plans across state lines, which will spur competition, thereby lowering cost. These are just a few suggestions, and I hope the incoming Democrat majority will seriously consider these ideas to come up with alternatives that do a better job of keeping health insurance affordable. 
In the upcoming Congress, we need to start with a clean slate where both parties come together to craft a bipartisan plan that works for all Americans. I hope Democrats will recognize that many Tennesseans see Obamacare as a failure because average premiums have risen by 176 percent since the law went into effect. For the past three Congresses I’ve introduced the American Health Care Reform Act, a comprehensive bill that would have replaced Obamacare with free-market competition in our health care system. I think many of the ideas included in this legislation – which included protections for people with pre-existing conditions – deserve bipartisan support. But I’ve said it before and will say it again: health care isn’t a Republican or Democrat issue, it’s a people issue. If the court ruling stands, I hope we can put partisan politics aside and fix the very real problems that exist in the health care market.  
As a physician, there is nothing that I want more than for every individual to have access to affordable health care. I believe if Congress can work together we can find a path forward that works for both sides of the aisle, and every American. I will continue reaching out to Tennesseans, listening to their concerns and working across the aisle to find better health care solutions.  

Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

Subject: Latest from Lamar: Thanking Tennessee for giving me the privilege to serve our state
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
The people of Tennessee have been very generous in electing me to serve more combined years as Governor and Senator than anyone else from our state. I am deeply grateful, but as Ecclesiastes teaches us, there is a time for everything. And now after three terms as our state’s Senator and two terms as governor, it is time for someone else to have that privilege.
I have gotten up every day thinking that I could help make our state and country a little better and have gone to bed most nights thinking that I have. I will continue to serve with that same spirit during the remaining two years of my term. When I was governor, 80 percent of my best work for Tennesseans was done in my second term, when everybody knew I was leaving. So I have two more years as chairman of two Senate committees that are important to Tennessee, and in that time, I intend to get results.
On Sunday night, I called President Trump at the White House. He called me right back and the first thing he said was, "Let's talk about you running for the Senate for another 20 years." I said, "Mr. President, I'm actually calling to tell you that I'm not going to run for reelection in 2020." The president congratulated me and said we'll find some things to work together on. I look forward to working with him over the next two years to continue get results for Tennessee.
 
￼
 
 
For the last eight years, Governor Bill Haslam’s example, actions, and leadership have made all of us look and feel a little better about being from Tennessee. I enjoyed being at his portrait unveiling this week.
 
 
 
President Trump signs legislation I sponsored to prevent preterm births  
This week, President Trump signed into law the PREEMIE Reauthorization Act -- legislation I sponsored that will reduce infant deaths and improve infant health by continuing research and education programs aimed at preventing preterm births. In Tennessee, about 11 percent of babies are born preterm. Since it was first signed into law in 2006, this legislation has helped improve our understanding of premature births and support health care professionals caring for these infants. This new law will give more babies the chance at long and healthy lives.
 
President Trump signs farm bill that will help 340,000 Tennessee farmers
President Trump signed an important law on Thursday that will provide much-needed certainty to Tennessee’s 340,000 farmers. Agriculture is one of Tennessee’s most important industries, with more than 66,000 farms contributing approximately $74 billion each year to our state’s economy. This bill supports agriculture, rural development, and conservation programs that benefit farmers across Tennessee, as well as agricultural research at Tennessee’s universities to help find ways for farmers to grow better crops. This new law will also help provide much-needed certainty to farmers in Tennessee and across the country, which is one of the reasons it is supported by the Tennessee agriculture community -- including the Tennessee Farm Bureau, Tennessee Soybean Association, Tennessee Cattlemen’s Association, Tennessee Farmer’s Cooperative, and other agriculture and conservation groups.
Included in the Farm bill that was signed into law this week was the Tennessee Wilderness Act -- legislation that will protect 20,000 acres of federal land in the Cherokee National Forest as “wilderness,” where Tennesseans can roam and enjoy nature. This is land in East Tennessee that's already managed as wilderness, but not made a part of the wilderness law. Designation as wilderness will not only better protect ecosystems and watersheds, but also benefit the diverse recreational value of these areas, which is a crucial part of East Tennessee’s economy.
 
￼
 
 It was good to have U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary, Sonny Perdue, and Acting Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Andrew Wheeler, in Lebanon this week to highlight the importance of the Trump administration’s new proposed Waters of the U.S. rule that would end the Obama administration’s excessive regulation on waters, streams, and wetlands.
 
Making it easier for students and families to apply for federal student aid
The former president of Southwest Community College in Memphis once told me he believes that he loses 1,500 students each semester because of the complexity of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Over and over families have asked me, “I’ve already given most of this information to the federal government when I paid my taxes, why do I have to do it again? Once is enough.” I agree. This week, the U.S. Senate passed legislation I sponsored that will make completing the complicated FAFSA much easier for students and families -- allowing them to answer up to 22 questions on the form with one simple click, while securing the applicant’s data. It is my hope that the House of Representatives swiftly passes this legislation.
 
￼
Last month, I visited Sevier County High School with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to show students and local guidance counselors how to use the new phone application that makes it easier for students to apply for federal and state financial aid.
Improving the federal criminal justice system and reforming federal prisons
The Senate and House passed and President Trump signed bipartisan legislation this week that will help improve the federal criminal justice system and reform federal prisons. This legislation will take some important first steps to help non-violent offenders re-enter their communities and reduce the likelihood that they would commit another crime. I commend President Trump, Chairman Chuck Grassley, and Jared Kushner for their leadership in passing this legislation.
￼
Congratulations to Grace and Stash on their marriage! Grace works as the health policy director on the Senate HELP Committee that I chair. Honey and I wish you both a lifetime of happiness!
 
Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:
Tennessean: U.S. Sen. Lamar Alexander will not seek re-election in 2020
Tennessean: What US Sen. Lamar Alexander hopes to tackle in his final two years in office
The Columbia Daily Herald: James Bennett: Lamar and me, 40 years later
Chattanooga Times Free Press: Clint Cooper: Sen. Alexander's workhorse service
Johnson City Press: Column by Senator Lamar Alexander: Protecting our mountain wilderness, heritage
 
When you’re really stuck for an answer, ask your mother or grandmother for advice.
#195 in Lamar Alexander’s Little Plaid Book

Subject: A Year In Review
Message:
￼
￼

As the 115th Congressional Session draws to a close, it's exciting to look back on all that we have accomplished. 
￼
A Year In Review 
In my office, we’re dedicated to serving our constituents any way we can. This year, we’ve hosted 2,823 constituents in our DC office, flown 96 flags over the capitol building, and have given 694 capitol tours. Be it by phone call, email or letter, we’ve responded over 60,200 times to constituent comments and inquires this Congress, including over 24,000 in 2018 alone. On top of that, my tireless caseworkers have helped 1,268 constituents with casework. What a year! 
￼
115th Congress By The Numbers 
Under Republican leadership, the 115th Congress had an extremely productive session. Collectively, we’ve passed 1,135 bills out of committee, which is 343 more bills than the congressional average. On the floor, we’ve passed 1,011 bills out of the House, which is 279 more bills than average. Of these 1,011 bills, 245 have been signed into law; and I’m proud to have sponsored four and co-sponsored ten. 

￼
Rep. Brady speaks at a joint press conference with Speaker Ryan.
ONE-YEAR ANNIVERSARY OF THE TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT 
On December 22, 2017, President Trump signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act into law. When I first introduced this bill, my goals were simple: cut taxes for the middle-class, simplify our unfair and broken tax code and make America the most competitive place in the world to do business.  
One year later, it is clear these goals have been accomplished. Our new tax code is simple and allows hardworking Americans— not Washington— to keep more of their hard-earned paychecks. Small businesses are thriving, consumer optimism is at record-highs and the economy is booming in a way we haven’t seen in decades. Workers are seeing higher wages and decreased unemployment, and families are taking advantage of increased deductions and the ability to save for retirement earlier. There can be no question the Republican led tax reform altered the trajectory of the American economy for the better. Simply put, our nation is winning again.
￼
REBUILDING AFTER HURRICANE HARVEY
Hurricane Harvey was one of the most devastating storms in history, and the damage was felt by the residents of the Eighth Congressional District and our neighbors. The storm left thousands of Texans homeless and without resources, and 88 Texans lost their lives. In the aftermath, Texans came together to rebuild and recover. In Washington, the Texas Delegation worked to deliver the quickest disaster relief in history, and in just six months we were able to provide $146 billion in relief funding. My team and I were on the ground and witnessed first-hand the incredible outpouring of love and support, not only from fellow Texans, but from folks all across the country. Looking back, what I remember most is the resilient and unbreakable spirit of all Texans and a state that truly showed what it means to be #TexasStrong.
CUTTING RED-TAPE
Throughout the 115th congress, I’ve been dedicated to protecting America’s businesses and hardworking people. As part of our fight to reduce Washington’s regulatory burdens, Republicans have repealed 17 burdensome regulations from the previous administration, which have saved the U.S. economy over $4 billion (Leader McCarthy, American Action Forum). Just this month, the Administration also announced that regulatory reform efforts have saved American families and business $23 billion in fiscal year 2018—even more good news. 
SUPPORT FOR MILITARY AND VETERANS
For the first time since 2008, Congress and the Administration worked together to fully fund our military – on time. This appropriations bill increased funding to every branch, boosted troop levels, provided dedicated funding for equipment maintenance and gave our service men and women the largest pay raise in nine years. In addition, President Trump made it clear that supporting our Veterans is a top priority, and I agree. I am proud to report that the 115th Congress has prioritized legislation impacting our Veterans. In fact, the House passed more than seventy Veterans bills—over twenty of which have been signed into law by President Trump—to improve the care and services provided to our Veterans. This included legislation to improve accountability and whistleblower protections at the VA, improve veterans’ Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA), and expand veterans’ access to community care. Measures like these are crucial for national defense and ensure the brave men and women serving our nation have our full support.
COMBATTING THE OPIOID CRISIS
In response to the opioid crisis, Congress put aside party politics and came together to provide necessary support to communities who are struggling. The Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act was a bipartisan bill signed into law by the President that took an important first step in defeating the opioid crisis once and for all. By expanding treatment resources, educating folks on the dangers of opioids and stopping the flow of synthetic opioids into our country, the SUPPORT act will save lives and make towns across the country safer.
LOOKING FORWARD…
We’ve accomplished a lot in the 115th Congress—but there is still more work to be done. As we head into the new year and new Congress, I look forward to working with my colleagues to address the critical issues facing our nation, and as the Ranking Member on the House Committee on Ways and Means, I remain committed to fighting for the hardworking folks of the Eighth Congressional District of Texas and for American workers all across the nation.

I'm always interested in hearing about which issues matter to you most, so please consider filling out this survey.

From my family to yours, I wish you a Merry Christmas and a happy and healthy New Year. 

Thank you and God Bless, 
￼

Subject: Somebody Needs to be Fired!
Message:
December 22, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
The suicide rate among veterans is twice that of the general population – 20 vets a day take their own lives. 
The Department of Veterans Affairs was allocated $6 million to address the problem through outreach and prevention. How much did it spend? Less than 1 percent, $57,000. 
Why? “bureaucratic confusion” according to a new report by the General Accounting Office.  
Somebody needs to be fired! Let me know your thoughts.  
Vern
￼ 
Vern Buchanan furious at Veterans Affairs inattention to stopping suicides  Jacob Ogles 
U.S. Rep. Vern Buchanan demanded answers why the Department of Veterans Affairs spent less than 1 percent of its suicide prevention funding this year. 
Buchanan wrote a letter to Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie, calling it “unacceptable and disgraceful” for the agency to ignore a crisis. 
“Of the 20 veterans who commit suicide on a daily basis, it is estimated that 14 of those individuals have had little or no contact with the VA in the months preceding their death,” Buchanan wrote.
“This demonstrates that the VA must dramatically improve its outreach to those veterans who are not taking advantage of the department’s mental health services and exactly why Congress allocated funds for this purpose.” 
The Government Accountability Office yesterday released a report showing the VA spent just $57,000 out of $6.2 million set aside for suicide prevention in 2018. 
There’s been a sharp decline over the past two years in spending on the effort, something officials at the VA attributed on the GAO report to “not having leadership available for a period of time to make decisions about the suicide prevention media outreach campaign.”
There’s been sharp declines in spending over the past two years, in particular in the first 10 months of 2018. 
Most of the spending has gone to publicize a suicide prevention hotline. Wilkie did release a message across media platforms in August, Suicide Prevention Month, encouraging veterans to take advantage of mental health services.
“Ultimately, whether Veterans choose VA, or get care or support from a peer, or a community agency, there is no wrong door when it comes to saving lives,” Wilkie wrote then. “Preventing Veterans suicide is a top priority for VA, the Department of Defense and this administration. Our goal is to prevent suicide among all Veterans, including those who may not receive care from us.”
But Buchanan said the failure to devote more resources to preventing suicides proved disturbing, especially considering Wilkie had proclaimed suicide prevention to be such a priority. 
“As you are undoubtedly aware, an astonishing 20 veterans a day commit suicide, accounting for 18 percent of all suicides nationwide,” Buchanan wrote in his letter to Wilkie.
“Among veterans younger than 35, the number of suicides has increased dramatically in recent years. These statistics are not only heartbreaking; they are downright inexcusable.” 
Florida’s 16th Congressional District, which Buchanan represents, includes a high percentage of veterans, so programs to help veterans have been a priority for the Sarasota Republican.
Buchanan said stopping veteran suicides remains a top priority of his, and he expects the department tasked with caring for veterans’ health to focus on the issue as well. 
The congressman requested Wilkie provide a report before Congress reconvenes on Jan. 3 offering a written explanation “as to how these failures were allowed to take place and what you will be doing going forward to ensure that they do not occur again on your watch.”
