Subject: Tax Reform: One Year Later
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Open a plain text version
News from Representative Barr
￼
 
Home
About
Services
Media Center
Contact
 
 
￼
Tax Reform: One Year Later
Dear Friend, 
One year ago today, Congress passed and the President signed into law the first comprehensive tax reform legislation in nearly 31 years.  This much-needed relief has given hard-working Kentuckians the ability to keep more of their paychecks, simplified the code by eliminating special interest loopholes, and made our businesses more competitive.  
￼ 
More Opportunities through Economic Growth:  
	•	The average increase in take home pay per family of four in the Sixth District thanks to the tax reform is $2,052 and $17,386 over the next 10 years (Heritage Foundation).
	•	Over the next 7 years, American can expect more than 1.44 million jobs to be created, including 18,748 in Kentucky. (Tax Foundation).
	•	1.7 million jobs have been created as a result of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (JEC).
	•	More than 700 businesses have passed on its savings to employees through bonuses, expanded benefits, and increased 401K contributions (ATR).
	•	The unemployment rate hit 3.7%, the lowest level since 1969, and youth unemployment hit a 52-year low (Department of Labor).
	•	Small business optimism hit its highest level ever recorded (NFIB).
	•	Jobless claims fell to a near 49-year low (Reuters).
	•	120 utility companies have lowered prices for their customers because of tax reform, including Kentucky Utilities (KU) and LG&E (LGE-KU).
	•	90% of Americans are receiving bigger paychecks under the new withholding tables (U.S. Treasury).
Throughout consideration of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, I diligently worked to advocate for the interests important to the Commonwealth, which includes: 
	•	My legislation, the Aged Distilled Spirits Competitiveness Act, which levels the playing field in the tax code for Kentucky bourbon producers by allowing the deduction of interest expense incurred during the aging process.
	•	Immediate expensing for business assets, including investments in Kentucky's signature bourbon and equine industries.
	•	Exemption of federally recognized work study colleges, including Berea College, from an excise tax that would have hindered their ability to serve low-income and first generation college students.
Key Provisions:
	•	Lowers individual tax rates for low- and middle-income Americans
	•	Significantly increases the Standard Deduction and expands the Child Tax Credit
	•	Delivers significant tax relief to Main Street job creators
	•	Provides relief for Americans with expensive medical bills and eliminates Obamacare's individual mandate penalty tax.
	•	Lowers the corporate tax rate to 21% and prevents American jobs, headquarters, and research from moving overseas.
To learn more about how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act impacts you and your family, go to fairandsimple.gop.  I look forward to continue working on pro-growth initiatives to ensure individuals, families, and small businesses throughout the Sixth District are afforded greater opportunities through additional economic growth.  
Please continue to let me know your thoughts and concerns about issues facing our community, and I hope you will forward my newsletter to your friends, family and neighbors. 
You may also visit my website, Facebook and Twitter, where you can find regular updates about my work at home in the Sixth District and in Washington. 
Thank you, and I'm wishing you and your family the happiest of holidays!  
Sincerely, Andy Barr

Subject: this is BIG
Message:
News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼ 
PROGRESS FOR OUR WATERWAYS!
￼ 
Lindsey - 
The federal government, through the Army Corps of Engineers, has played a huge role in perpetuating the human health crisis caused by Lake Okeechobee discharges and they need to take responsibility for the damage by helping to pay for the cleanup. 
This week we made big progress to do exactly that: 
Congress passed my bill to make federal funding available to communities impacted by harmful algal blooms and ensure the continuation of a federal program aimed at combating harmful algal blooms. In total, the bill authorizes more than $100 million to be spent to combat harmful algal blooms. Now, states and local governments will be able to access federal resources when Harmful Algal Blooms have a detrimental impact on a state's environment, economy or public health! 
Our coalition fighting for clean water also grew substantially this week as I helped lead a group of more than 60 Members of Congress in lobbying the Administration for full funding of programs designed to combat toxic algal blooms. Securing these resources is essential, especially as we move toward construction of the EAA Southern Storage Reservoir and other projects! 
Finally, after increasing the size of the Hobe Sound National Wildlife Refuge to increase the land and habitats that are protected, we also voted to rename the area after environmentalist Nathaniel Reed, who passed away in July. He led conservation fights throughout the United States and was one of our state's most influential environmental leaders.
The government needs to stop prioritizing special interests over human health and put an end to the crisis once and for all! Our bipartisan progress this week will help deliver the federal resources needed to end this environmental disaster. To hear more, watch this week's Week In Review video: 
WATCH NOW 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media: 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman 
P.S. Click here to learn more about my work to protect our waterways.

Subject: Merry Christmas
Message:
News from Representative Crawford 
￼ 
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   
￼
 Merry Christmas
Normally at Christmas, I take time to reflect upon the previous year. However, this year Congress will adjourn, rather than recess for Christmas, marking the end of the 115th Congress. I’d like to take a look at the past two years, my 4th term on Capitol Hill.
It’s no secret that the past two years in Washington have been some of the most tumultuous in history, certainly since I’ve been here. Following a bitter election, there has been gridlock, vitriol, and setbacks, but all things considered, it’s been a remarkably productive two years. The 115thCongress rolled back disastrous and burdensome regulations, implemented financial reforms that increase market liquidity, and passed the most sweeping reforms to our tax code in a generation. 
On a personal level, I finished my first term on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. While I cannot discuss my work on the committee in depth, I have thoroughly enjoyed the challenge of overseeing the Intelligence Community. This Congress, I also became the Chair of the Congressional Steel Caucus, which develops and implements policies to protect the American steel industry from our adversaries who are intent on destroying it. Cooperating with the Administration, we have given the steel industry the policy support it needs to compete in its own domestic market against price dumpers and trade abusers. While I have enjoyed becoming involved in new issues in Congress, I got my start with Agriculture, and it will always hold a special place in my heart. As a member of the Agriculture Committee, and a member of the Farm Bill conference committee, I helped draft, refine, and pass the Farm Bill recently signed into law by President Trump. In a time of foreign hostility, uncertain markets, and bad weather, farmers can rest assured that the support programs that have existed for generations have been strengthened and will continue. American farmers feed the world, and the Farm Bill just signed by President Trump will enable them to continue to do so.
My next Congress will be my first in the minority. While I wish my party had fared better in the midterms, I am optimistic about the future and am honored to continue to represent the First District of Arkansas. The place we call home truly is a cross section of America. We have great industry, great agriculture, and great people. This Christmas, I am content knowing that steel workers don’t have to fear low-quality foreign steel being sold below market price on our shores, that farmers can finish this season and prepare for the next knowing that a farm bill is in place, and that hardworking parents across Eastern Arkansas have more money in their take home pay each month, making this Christmas easier financially.
I’d like to thank you once again for allowing me to represent you in Washington. From my family to yours, I wish you a Merry Christmas, and a Happy New Year.
￼ 
The Hill
Farm bill’s expansion of trade opportunities between the US and Cuba historic and mutually beneficial
A natural next step for Congress is to remove financing restrictions on U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba, and we have introduced legislation in the House and Senate to do just that. Although Arkansas rice, poultry and soybeans are only a few hundred miles away, Cuba has little choice but to purchase more expensive and lower quality goods from countries like Vietnam and New Zealand. Estimates show the U.S. could capture at least half of Cuba’s total agriculture market if the cash-in-advance requirement were removed. Our farmers deserve access to nearby markets, just as the Cuban people deserve the ability to stock their shelves with high-quality U.S. food.

Western Farm Press
Officials laud passage of Farm Bill
The Congressional Western Caucus offered the following comments from some of its members:
Rep. Rick Crawford (AR): "For too long, rural America has been left behind as the rest of the nation moves forward. The farm bill is important for those engaged in production agriculture but also includes key provisions that address issues facing our rural communities, such as the opioid crisis, food deserts, and broadband access. This legislation is a resounding commitment from this Congress to rural constituencies that we recognize their needs and delivers on our promises to farmers and ranchers across America. The Farm Bill ensures our farmers and ranchers can continue to produce a reliable food and fiber supply, even amid uncertain economic times.”

TB&P
USDA launches second round of trade mitigation payments to farmers

U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford, R-Jonesboro, has supported Trump’s bailout since it was announced. He was pleased that the second round of relief has been doled, and he hopes it will compel the Chinese to strike a fairer trade deal.
“I am pleased to see the President not only deliver such a quick response to the concerns I voiced last week, but to see him continue to stand with rural America. Like any other industry, farmers are harmed by unfair foreign trade practices, but are also challenged by risks inherent to agriculture and a struggling farm economy,” Crawford said.
￼

KAIT 8 - Mexico World Trade Center visits NEA businesses

TB&P - Baptist Memorial Health and Jonesboro DO school reach partnership deal

Subject: McKinley Talks Bipartisan Healthcare Reform
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online. 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT  |   SERVICES  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   OUR DISTRICT  |   CONTACT 
December 22, 2018 
McKinley Calls For Bipartisan Healthcare Reform 
Last Saturday, a federal judge in Texas ruled that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional. This decision should spur Congress into action to reform health care on a bipartisan basis. With divided government we have a chance to improve affordability, ensure access to care, address the cost of prescription drugs, and protect coverage for people with pre-existing conditions. 
This ruling will not have any immediate impact on premiums or coverage for the coming year and will likely be appealed. In the meantime, Republicans and Democrats alike should take this opportunity to put aside the partisan squabbling and enact reforms that will help people get affordable and quality health care.   Click here to read more 

McKinley Nominates 17 Students To Military Academies 
This month we nominated 17 West Virginia Students to United Sates service academies. These young men and women will be the next generation of leaders in West Virginia. They have earned their nomination through hard work, achievement and good character, demonstrated in the classroom, the athletic field and their community. 
Nominating deserving young people for the opportunity of a lifetime is one of the best parts of my job representing the First District. I am proud to endorse these students in the first step towards appointment at America’s service academies.   Click here to learn more 
￼

Criminal Justice Reform Includes McKinley Bill To Protect Correctional Officers
This week Congress passed a major criminal justice bill called the First Step Act, aimed at reducing recidivism and pushing a second chance for individuals who have committed non-violent crimes. This includes our Lt. Osvaldo Albarati Correctional Self-Protection Act which provides for safe storage of personal firearms for corrections officers to protect them during transit to and from work. We look forward to the implementation of this policy as it heads to the President’s desk for signature. This bill is in honor Lt. Albarati’s life as we work towards ensuring the safety of our correctional officers. 
￼

House Passes Bill To Provide Funding For Border Wall
As of Thursday night, the House voted 217-185 on legislation to avoid the government shutdown. This bill included an allotment of $5.7 billion for the President’s proposed border wall and border security, as well as, several other government agencies. The bill awaits approval from the Senate.
 

Congress Passes Museum and Library Services Act With Bipartisan Support
This week, Congress passed S.3530, legislation to reauthorize the federal Institute of Museum and Library Services, with bipartisan support. With a 331-28 vote in the House, many of West Virginia’s libraries will continue to benefit as a result of this legislation. This past year, West Virginia was allotted $1.3 million in grants. As the lead co-sponsor and firm advocate towards the betterment of our nations museums, libraries, and other related organizations, this is a step forward in ensuring that our constituents will continue to have access to furthering their education.  Click here to learn more

Subject: Government Shutdown Update
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Brooks
￼
 
RESOURCES
ISSUES
LEGISLATION
CONTACT
 
￼ 
￼ 
 
 
Dear Friend, 
At midnight on December 21, 2018, funding for the federal government expired. We are currently operating under what is called “a lapse in appropriations” – that is, a partial government shutdown, because we still need to fund for Fiscal Year 2019 the federal Departments of Homeland Security, Agriculture, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, State, Interior, Commerce, and Justice.
The Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Energy, as well as the Legislative Branch and United States Postal Service have already been funded and will continue to operate without disruption. 
I voted to keep the government open, which included voting to strengthen border security and provide relief to communities struggling to rebuild after devastation caused by natural disasters. It is government’s job to work together to fund the government and I am disappointed my colleagues in the Senate have not yet voted.
￼ 
Because the government has not been fully funded, this morning, I submitted a letter requesting that my pay be withheld for the duration of the shutdown. My offices will remain accessible for constituents who need services during the shutdown. 
Please know that during this time, government programs involving the safety of human life or the protection of property continue to fully operate.
What this means for you according to the Office of Management and Budget: 
	•	HOLIDAY TRAVEL: 
	◦	PLANES: Air travel will not be affected, meaning Transportation Security Administration’s (TSA) airport functions will continue to operate. Air traffic controllers, critical airline safety inspections and the registration of aircraft would also continue to work if a government shutdown occurs. 
	◦	TRAINS: Amtrak will continue its normal operations during a short-term shutdown. Railroad inspectors and accident investigators at the Federal Railroad Administration will remain at work.
	◦	CARS & TRUCKS: The Federal Highway Administration and Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, which regulates trucking, will continue their operations. Highway tollbooths are typically staffed by state authorities.
	◦	PASSPORTS: Consular operations domestically and abroad will remain fully operational as long as there are sufficient fees to support operations. However, if a passport agency is located in a government building affected by a lapse in appropriations, the facility may become unsupported. The continuance of consular operations in such instances will be treated on a case-by-case basis by the Office of the Under Secretary for Management.    
	•	MEDICARE & SOCIAL SECURITY: 
	◦	Medicare services for current beneficiaries will continue without interruption. 
	◦	Social Security and Supplemental Security Income payments to beneficiaries will continue with no change in payment dates.    
	•	BORDER SECURITY: 
	◦	The vast majority of Customs and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement workers will stay on the job if there's a shutdown.    
	•	EMERGENCY RESPONSE: 
	◦	At the Federal Emergency Management Agency, almost 90 percent of the agency's more than 20,000 employees are exempt from furlough, according to a contingency plan released in March of this year. Nor will the shutdown halt FEMA's disaster payments, which go to victims of recent hurricanes, wildfires and other emergencies.  
	•	  
	•	HEALTH, SAFETY & NEEDED SERVICES: 
	◦	The U.S. Department of Agriculture will continue inspecting agricultural products.
	◦	The Department of Housing and Urban Development’s homeless assistance grants, including support for veterans, will continue to operate.
	◦	The Department of Justice activities that involve the safety of human life and protection of life and property will continue.  
	•	  
	•	NATIONAL PARK SERVICE: 
	◦	National Park Service roads, lookouts, trails and open-air memorials will generally remain open. 
	◦	The park service won't provide visitor services, including restrooms, collecting trash and plowing roads. 
	◦	Campgrounds, boat ramps and other recreational sites overseen by the Bureau of Land Management will stay open, but restrooms will be locked and water systems will be shut down. Campgrounds, picnic areas and boat launches operated by the Forest Service funded by user fees will remain open.
Thank you for taking the time to read this newsletter. I continue to stand ready to negotiate a solution that will re-open the federal government.  
Sincerely, ￼  Congresswoman Susan W. Brooks 
￼  ￼

Subject: Government Shutdown: What It Means for You
Message:
December 22, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
The partial federal government shutdown is yet another sad example of Washington dysfunction. While I hope leaders from both parties will come to the table and reach a compromise as quickly as possible, I wanted to share an article by the AARP detailing which federal offices and services will be affected as well as those that will not be affected.
Vern 
Social Security, Mail, Air Travel Would Continue in Government Shutdown 
A potential preholiday shutdown of the federal government would not affect mail delivery, air travel, Social Security benefits or Medicare reimbursements to doctors and hospitals.
The partial shutdown may occur starting Saturday because nine departments wouldn’t have money to continue to operate. The agencies affected are the departments of Agriculture, Commerce, Homeland Security, Interior, Justice, State, Transportation, Treasury, and Housing and Urban Development. Although those departments technically would not be funded, more than 400,000 workers will continue on the job — without being paid. (In previous shutdowns they have been paid for their time once normal operations resume.) They will provide law enforcement, air traffic control and other services the government deems essential. Veterans’ health care, vital food inspections and National Weather Service forecasting also will continue. 
Here’s a look at some key government responsibilities and what would happen during a shutdown: 
Social Security and Medicare: These agencies are funded and would not be affected by the shutdown, so Social Security payments to retirees, individuals with disabilities and other beneficiaries will continue, and Medicare beneficiaries will still be able to get health care services.
Mail service: Mail will be delivered. The U.S. Postal Service, which is an independent organization, will remain open, and mail service will not be affected. 
National parks and U.S. monuments: According to the National Park Service, while some parks might still be accessible to visitors, no visitor services would be provided. That includes snow removal from roads and keeping restrooms, shops and other amenities open. Contact individual parks or check online for more information. To reschedule camping reservations, call 800-365-2267. In Washington, D.C., the shutdown would close most of the museums on the National Mall. The National Gallery, which is not part of the Smithsonian Institution, says it has enough funds to stay open at least through Dec. 31. 
Veterans benefits and services: The Veterans Administration is funded, so VA hospitals, medical centers and clinics will stay fully operational.  
Taxes: The Internal Revenue Service would be affected by the shutdown, which would slow the processing of any tax documents, including audits and tax returns. 
Travel: Flights will not be affected. Air traffic controllers will remain on the job. So will the Transportation Security Administration's airport security screeners. 
Passports: The State Department will continue to issue passports. 
Food safety: The Food and Drug Administration will continue to handle high-risk food recalls. Routine meat, poultry and egg inspections will also continue because the U.S. Department of Agriculture considers them essential to safeguarding human life. 
Federal home loans: There could be a delay processing some FHA loans because furloughs at the IRS would reduce its capacity to verify information about borrowers. 
￼

Subject: The Scoop: Criminal Justice Reform, Christmas, Oversight
Message:
￼ 

About Grassley
Constituent Services
News Center
Contact Grassley


Grassley Direct
On my weekly "Capitol Hill Report," I spoke with Brian Fancher of KLMJ Radio in Hampton and Terri Queck-Matzie of Successful Farming about criminal justice reform, the Farm Bill and the Senate Finance Committee chairmanship.  
Q&A: First Step Act
Q. What is the First Step Act? Q. How does the First Step Act change sentencing laws? 
Quick Links
My bill, the First Step Act, overwhelmingly passed the Senate and the House and has now been signed into law by President Trump. There haven't been significant reforms made to our nation’s criminal justice and prison policies in a generation. The First Step Act takes lessons from history and from states – our laboratories of democracy – to reduce crime, save taxpayer dollars and strengthen faith and fairness in our criminal justice system. This bill is the product of careful deliberation and input from a wide range of stakeholders and law enforcement organizations. I’m grateful for the engagement from those who joined us to pass the bill and for President Trump’s leadership. 
  
The Christmas season is a busy time of the year. Like you, I’m preparing to celebrate the holiday with my family and friends on my farm in New Hartford. But as we look forward to celebrating the birth of our Lord and Savior, I want to take a moment to wish you all a safe and joyful season. Thank you for the honor of serving you in the United States Senate. Have a blessed Christmas. You can watch my message here or below.  
￼
I’ve spent more than three decades reviewing egregious spending at the Defense Department. But it seems like the Pentagon has done very little to change its ways. Over the past few months alone, the Defense Department has had to explain why it’s been paying $14,000 for individual 3-D printed toilet seat lids and purchasing cups for $1,280 each. Americans routinely balance their checkbooks, scrutinize their credit card statements and review their banking phone apps to manage their household budgets. There’s no reason the Defense Department can’t effectively do the same thing. Read more about my oversight of the Defense Department in my op-ed here.  
  
Each year, I have the opportunity as a U.S. senator to nominate either current or future Iowa high school graduates for a select few service academy placements. This year, I nominated 33 Iowa students to be considered for appointments to the U.S. service academies. These young Iowans who want to enter the academies and serve our country are a remarkable reflection on our state. Their accomplishments, leadership and desire to serve are exceptional, and signal continued excellence in the U.S. armed forces. 
  
As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I’ve made it a top priority to champion bipartisan initiatives to enhance victims' rights and protect our nation’s at-risk children. In the 115th Congress, I introduced and led the Senate in approving multiple bills to prevent crime, identify missing children, enhance services to crime victims, and reform our juvenile justice system. These include the Elder Abuse Prevention and Prosecution Act, Kevin and Avonte’s Law, the Trafficking Victims Protection Act, the Missing Children’s Assistance Act and the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act. I’m proud of what we’ve achieved on the Judiciary Committee in this period, as we sent half a dozen of these measures to the President’s desk after both chambers passed them unanimously.
Post of the Week
￼ 
Senate passed criminal justice reform/First Step Act 87-12. House of Representatives passed it 358-36. Overwhelmingly bipartisan in both chambers! Thx to Pres Trump for working w me on this legislation & for your support

Subject: $100M+ for Marianas recovery
Message:
Email not displaying correctly? Click here.
  ‌   ‌ 
 

This Week in Congress
December 21, 2018

• $100M+ for Marianas recovery
• $17.9M for Yutu recovery
• Disaster tax relief passes House
• Typhoon Yutu updates
• We must address climate change
• Farewell, Speaker Ryan
• Farm bill signed
• Keeping tabs on VA MISSION Act
• Urging action on Agent Orange
• Congratulations, educators 
• Returning intern
• Opportunities
• Legislative Highlights
 
 
 

$100M+ for Marianas recovery

There is at least $100 million for the Marianas in legislation passed by the House on Thursday night—the first time ever for our islands to be included in special disaster relief above and beyond what FEMA provides. The bill’s fate in the Senate is undecided, as we go to press, because it includes a controversial $5 billion President Trump has demanded for a border wall. Incoming Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi gave me her pledge of support for Marianas recovery a few days after Yutu struck, as did the incoming Chairman of the Appropriations Committee Nita Lowey, when she called on November 10. Since then, I have worked with appropriators on both sides of the aisle to ensure that any help for U.S. areas hit by natural disasters this year includes the Marianas. 

What’s in the bill

Much of what I asked for in my formal request on November 26 is in the bill:
	•	$1.1 billion for community development block grants is available to the Marianas as one of the areas most impacted by a disaster in 2018. The money can be used for long-term recovery efforts, restoration of infrastructure and housing, economic revitalization, or as a local match for other federal grants.
	•	$56 million for solid waste for the Marianas, enough for new sanitary landfills on Rota and Tinian and to open a new cell at the existing Marpi landfill on Saipan.
	•	A $20 million territorial set-aside for highway repairs.
	•	$2 million to the Marianas for additional technical assistance from the Office of Insular Affairs.
	•	$8.5 million for the Marianas Nutrition Assistance Program, or food stamps.
	•	$300 million for grants from the Economic Development Administration for relief, recovery, and restoration from typhoons Mangkhut and Yutu, hurricanes Florence, Michael, and Lane, and other natural disasters.

Other funding I requested and the bill makes the Marianas eligible for includes:
	•	School and college restart: $50 million
	•	Public transportation: $10.5 million
	•	Head Start: $25 million
	•	Community health centers: $7.5 million 
	•	National Parks: $128 million
	•	Watershed and flood protection: $125 million 
	•	Crop loss and reforestation: $1.3 billion 
	•	Legal Services Corporation: $5 million for local branches, like Micronesian Legal Services, that aided typhoon survivors.

What comes next?

Whether this bill is enacted now or dies because of the controversial wall funding, there will certainly be disaster assistance taken up in the new Congress. And what the House approved on Thursday will be the basis for any future legislation. The task now is to increase funding—particularly for food stamps—and make even more programs available to us. We already have a very good start. My thanks to Appropriations Chairman Rodney Frelinghuysen, Ranking Member Nita Lowey, and all the Members who are helping me with typhoon recovery.
 
 
 

$17.9 million for Yutu recovery

The Federal Emergency Management Agency announced Public Assistance Grants for the Northern Marianas for Super Typhoon Yutu recovery. A total of $6,929,271 was awarded for temporary classrooms and $13,447,432 for power restoration. FEMA obligates funding for these projects directly to the Commonwealth, which is then responsible for reimbursing agencies for costs associated with those activities. To date, FEMA has approved more than $7.8 million under the Individual and Households Program and more than $20.5 million for Public Assistance projects. The funds are authorized under Section 403 of the Robert T. Stafford Act.
 

Disaster tax relief passes House

The House passed a year-end tax package with tax relief for the Marianas and other communities hit by natural disasters this year. Under the bill, qualified disaster relief distributions will be exempt from the 10-percent penalty levied on retirement money withdrawn before age 59 and a half. The bill also allows homebuyers to re-contribute retirement plan withdrawals for home purchases that were cancelled due to eligible disasters, and provides flexibility for loans from retirement plans for qualified hurricane relief. To help disaster-affected employers retain employees, the bill provides a tax credit for 40 percent of wages (up to $6,000 per employee). There is also a temporary suspension of limitations on charitable contributions associated with qualified disaster relief made before December 31, 2018. And families that lost income in 2018 may use their 2017 income to determine their Child Tax Credit for this year. Any loss of revenue for the Commonwealth resulting from these tax changes will be covered by the U.S. Treasury. The bill must still pass the Senate and be signed by the President to be effective.
 
 
 

Typhoon Yutu relief updates

Water
Saipan has 95 percent of its water restored. Tinian has all its water service restored.  

Power
63 percent of power has been restored on Saipan with Tinian still operating at 20 percent power restored.

Transitional shelters
There are about 40 families – about 150 people – still at the Kagman transitional shelter.

Tents
1,593 tents have been installed on Saipan. 203 tents have been installed on Tinian.

SBA Loans
The U.S. Small Business Administration has approved a total of 737 loans to home and business owners totaling to over $46.8 million.
 

We must address climate change

With two typhoons this year, the Marianas understands the impact of climate change. That is why I joined 100 of my colleagues this week urging President Trump to pay attention to his administration’s own National Climate Assessment. The report is a comprehensive, science-based evaluation of the consequences of climate change, the risks of inaction, and strategies we can adopt. President Trump has dismissed the findings. I believe our nation should follow the scientific evidence—and what we have seen with our own eyes—and, in collaboration with nations across the globe, act to address climate change.
 
 

Farewell, Mr. Speaker. Retiring Speaker of the House Paul Ryan invited Members for a commemorative photo this week. The Wisconsin representative and once-vice presidential candidate is leaving after 20 years in Congress. We did not always agree, but thank you for your public service, Mr. Speaker. 
 

Farm bill signed

President Trump signed the farm bill into law on Thursday. See our write-up from last week’s e-news on the new micro-grants program for the Marianas in the Agriculture Act of 2018, Public Law 115-334.
 
 

Implementation of the VA MISSION Act, which authorizes the study needed for a Veterans Community-Based Outpatient Clinic in the Marianas, was the purpose of a joint hearing of the House and Senate Veterans Affairs Committees on Wednesday. I was there along with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) and Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-TX). Your congressional office has held veteran registration drives throughout the year to increase the numbers of Marianas vets and help justify having our own C-BOC.
 

Urging action on Agent Orange

More than a year later, no decision has been made on the recommendation of former VA Secretary David Shulkin to add bladder cancer, hypothyroidism, Parkinson-like tremors, and hypertension to the list of diseases that are presumed the result of exposure to Agent Orange and other herbicides. This week I wrote the Office of Management and Budget urging immediate action. The letter from 29 Members of Congress also asks that Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS) be included on the list. The National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine has found sufficient evidence of association between MGUS and the chemicals in Agent Orange. Veterans exposed to toxic substances during their service and who now suffer from these diseases should receive benefits without question.
 
 

Congratulations to the Public School System’s exemplary educators of 2019: Teacher of the Year Roselle Carreon of Oleai Elementary School, Instructor of the Year Michael Berbes of Hopwood Middle School, and Teacher Aides of the Year Salote Kesol of Hopwood Middle School and Grace Belyea of Garapan Elementary School. Two students were also recognized during Education Day festivities this week: 4th grader Daniel Job of San Vicente Elementary School, who won the Education Day Theme Contest, and 8th grader Adrian Manalang of Dandan Middle School, who won the Education Day Logo Contest. Kudos to all! 
 
 

Returning intern. Michael Ortizo returned to the congressional office this week to intern with us over the winter break. Ortizo is majoring in Political Science and Criminal Justice at the University at Delaware and will be until February. Welcome back, Michael!

Subject: Shutting down the government is a bad idea.
Message:
News from Representative Kilmer  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
WEBSITE
BIOGRAPHY
SERVICES
MEDIA CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT
 
December 21, 2018
Friends,   I’m sorry to bother you on a Friday night. But, I wanted to check in from Washington, DC.   As I wrote this, our nation is once again on the brink of yet another government shutdown.      This has happened so many times this year that it’s starting to feel like the norm.    That should never be the case.   Shutting down the government is a bad idea.   It’s bad for federal workers, it’s bad for taxpayers, it’s bad for the economy and it’s bad for the American people who depend on important government services.    This time is different, too.   This isn’t happening because of a disagreement between factions in Congress--there’s a bipartisan path to keeping government open. In fact, there’s a bipartisan path for dealing with immigration issues, too.  I’m for border security, but I’m not for holding the government hostage in hopes of spending $25 billion on a 14th century solution to a 21st century challenge.      The president said he would be ‘proud’ to shut down the government.    I couldn’t disagree more. I hope the president comes to his senses and embraces a bipartisan path to keeping the government open.  And I hope that you know I’m doing what I can on an individual level to try to fix this.   Because I know what is at stake for Washingtonians when the government shuts down:   All Visitor Services in the National Parks Will Be Suspended.  While there will not be barriers put up to prevent entry, there will be no services for visitors to National Park Service sites – with restrooms, visitors’ centers, and interpretative programs all closed during a shutdown.    More than 420,000 federal employees nationwide will be working over the holidays without pay, including federal law enforcement and correctional officers from the FBI, ATF, DEA and US Marshal Service.   Almost 90% of Homeland Security employees nationwide will also be working without pay in agencies like Custom and Border Protection, the Secret Service and TSA (so those of you traveling—throw out your liquids, remove your shoes and maybe have a little mercy on the people patting you down—it’s a tough time of year to wonder when you’ll be paid)   An additional 400,000 federal employees nationwide will be furloughed, sent home without pay with no guarantee of when their next pay check is coming. 
The federal agencies that protect you from identity theft will have most of their staff furloughed, leaving us all more vulnerable.   Crime victim services and law enforcement training programs will stop, and other Justice Department activities will halt.   Mortgage applications will slow as most of the staff who process them will be sent home.   During A Difficult Time for Farmers, Critical Services Will Be Stopped.  As farmers begin to make their plans for next year’s planting season, the Department of Agriculture will be forced to close Farm Service county offices throughout the nation and stop providing aid to farmers already hard hit by the trade war. With the dramatic drop in commodity prices brought on by the trade war, many farmers have had to rely on USDA as their lender of last resort to help pay the bills and stay afloat.    Small business loans will stop. During the 2013 shutdown, nearly 700 businesses were unable to have $140 million in loans processed by the SBA.   Even if the president backs down before midnight, all this posturing has real consequences.   I met with a hotel owner near Olympic National Park after a shutdown a few years ago.  He laid it out pretty well. 
He said: “Derek, when the government shut down, I lost a ton of business because people weren’t sure how long the park would be closed. They just went somewhere else. I’m still recovering a year later, and every time this seems like it is going to happen, people decide to go someplace else.”   The president’s decision has a direct effect on our economy. It risks the $26.2 billion that outdoor recreation generates in our state, and 201,000 jobs that are directly dependent on the outdoor economy. And, it cuts into the bottom line at restaurants and other small businesses around our parks.   Worst of all, this kind of behavior in Washington, DC undermines citizens’ faith in their government.  The American people expect and deserve better.   If you’re watching this from our neck of the woods, you’re likely frustrated by all this.  I share that --I’m also highly motivated to get this back on track.  
  
We’ll keep pushing!   ￼   Derek 
￼

Subject: Providing Opportunities for Low-Risk Inmates to Rejoin Society & Helping Women in the System
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
  
￼ 

 Home | Newsroom | Helping Iowans | Contact 

Providing Opportunities for Low-Risk Inmates to Rejoin Society & Helping Women in the System 
This week, a sentencing reform bill became law. The First Step Act will not only reduce recidivism and improve fairness in sentencing of federal crimes – but it will also help women, especially mothers, in our justice system by addressing their unique needs.

The comprehensive and bipartisan legislation provides opportunities for low-risk inmates to rejoin society, while ensuring that dangerous criminals stay behind bars. 
The First Step Act uses data-driven tools to evaluate each person in the prison system to see if they are eligible for earned time credits.  Anyone convicted for a number of serious offenses disqualifies them, but those who are found to be low risk will be given an opportunity to participate in workforce development programs that could lead to a portion of their federal sentence being served in pre-release custody –like a halfway house. 
As a conservative, I supported this legislation because I believe in providing opportunity. 
And, I also believe that we need to address the disturbing trend of women, especially mothers, who are going to prison at higher and higher rates.  Women are the fastest growing population segment of the prison population, and about two-thirds of incarcerated women are mothers to children under the age of 18. 
In a time of intense partisanship, the First Step Act brought the House, Senate and the president together around a common goal of helping people in the system get another chance. 

For more updates on what's happening in Washington, D.C. and Iowa, be sure to 'Like' my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter @SenJoniErnst, and subscribe to my YouTube channel. 
Thank you! 
 ￼

Subject: Year in Review
Message:
District Update | December 21, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 Year In Review 
Dear Friends,  

As this year comes to an end, I wanted to take the time to reflect on the 115th Congress (2nd year). This past year, our economy saw record numbers, Congress passed significant legislation to combat the Opioid Crisis, and we continued to improve the new tax law. This is only to name a few of our accomplishments. In this newsletter, you will find a month-to-month highlight of major accomplishments made. 

In the 116th Congress I look forward to working to surpass the numbers outlined in the graphic below and supporting the interests of Arizonans. 

Sincerely, 

￼
David Schweikert
Member of Congress

￼
January
                                                                   
Ways and Means Hearing on "The Opioid Crisis: The Current   Landscape and CMS Actions to Prevent Opioid Misuse." 
￼
Myself at the Ways and Means Health Subcommittee hearing. 
During this hearing, Ways and Means members spoke about the multiple pieces of legislation that we could put together to help combat the Opioid Crisis. This package we all discussed during the hearing later became H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act.   Included in the package, I proposed legislation that supports a prior authorization standard in Medicare. H.R. 4841. This legislation was later included in the H.R. 6 package to help move pharmacies and doctors away from faxing the prior authorization forms and encourage them to communicate in real time through electronic means.   The bill consists of two main ideas: to prevent the delays caused by the current system of non-electronic/real time prior authorization requests so that Medicare patients receive prescriptions as soon as possible, and by making the process electronic, there will be an improved oversight in the system to ensure patients are only receiving approved medications. 
February
 ASU Law Blockchain Event 
￼
Speaking to students of ASU Law at the Blockchain Summit

This February I joined ASU Law students for a conference on "Blockchain and the Law" to discuss how government can better support emerging technologies. 

As a co-chair of the Congressional Blockchain Caucus, this issue has become a fixation of mine. There are so many technologies being developed that I believe can create a disruption in government processes. Arizona is a state that has become very accepting of new businesses in the technology industry. I look forward to working with stakeholders in the technology field that have the same fixation on creating a revolution. 
March
 This March, our DC team wanted to create a time during the week were all staff and I were in one spot, at the same time. With unknown vote schedules, and staff meetings all throughout the day, we set aside an hour for Arizona groups to join our team for an Open House.   We have come to really appreciate the time allotted to connect with Arizonans on their legislative priorities. Below are a few photos from my meetings with these groups.   If you are in Washington, D.C. and your group would like to discuss legislative priorities, email Schweikert.Scheduling@Mail.House.Gov for more information.   
￼
￼
Two Constituent groups above that came to one of our Washington, D.C. open houses!
April
 Joint Select Committee on Multi-Employer Pensions
￼
At the Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Pensions

This year, I was selected to serve on the Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Pension Plans. It was an honor to serve on this committee and to take a deep dive into this complex issue. 

In April, the committee held a hearing titled "The History and Structure of the Multiemployer Pension System" with two witnesses Mr. Barthold from the Joint Committee on Taxation and Mr. Goldman from the American Academy of Actuaries. 

To watch the full committee hearings, click here. 


￼

H.R. Subcommittee Hearing on Jobs and Opportunity: Local Perspectives on the Jobs Gap

This April, the Ways and Means H.R. Subcommittee welcomed two Arizonans to testify. Mrs. Connie Wilhelm and Mr. Brian Potaczek came to speak about Arizona's labor shortage. Mr. Potaczek was a part of the criminal justice system and towards the end of his time serving he joined a program that provides training for skilled labor jobs to prior offenders. 

It was a pleasure to have some Arizonans join me in the hearing room. I look forward to seeing programs like this bring success to our community. 


￼
Visiting with Mr. Potaczek after the hearing. To watch the full hearing click here. 
 
May
 CODEL trip to South Korea
￼
Representative Tom O'Halleran and I meeting troops in South Korea. 

This May, a handful of my colleagues and I had the opportunity to visit South Korea to see the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea and discuss with troops on the ground the day to day operations and concerns at the border. 
During the trip we visited US forces Korea (USFK) troops, the leadership team at Osan Air Base, and the 25th Fighter Squadron. 

As the Holidays near, my team and I would like to thank all of the men and women protecting our country during this season. 


Trip to the U.S.-Mexican Border

This May I took a trip down to the U.S. Mexico border with Representative McSally and Secretary Nielsen. During our visit we met with border patrol agents and Arizona stakeholders to discuss how to keep America's borders secure and safe. 

I thank all of the men and women border patrol agents working to keep our country safe. 
￼

Picture at the Nogales Border with Secretary Nielson and Representative Martha McSally. 
June
 Congressional Baseball Game
￼
A picture of myself at the Congressional Baseball team practice. 

This year, I joined my colleagues in the annual Congressional Baseball game at Nationals Park. During the spring and early summer, we all arose before sunrise and work hours to get practice in. Although we suffered a loss, I thoroughly enjoyed spending some time outside of the Capitol with my colleagues. 

Summer Internships
￼
A photo with my Fall 2018 Washington, D.C. interns

My Scottsdale and Washington, D.C. offices offer internships throughout the school year and summer. 
We are now accepting applications for Summer 2019! Applicants should be motivated, detail oriented, display a strong work ethic, and interact well with constituents. In addition, applicants should have a interest in the legislative process and the function of Congress. 
Strong ties to the sixth district of Arizona or the state of Arizona are preferred, but not required. Priority is given to current college students, but recent high school graduates with exceptional credentials may be considered. 
July
The FORWARD Act

This July, I joined Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, as co-chairs of the Valley Fever Task Force, to introduce H.R. 6562, the Finding Orphan-disease Remedies With Antifungal Research and Development (FORWARD) Act. The FORWARD Act is designed to strength endemic fungal disease research and help bring new fungal diagnostics, antifungal treatments, and eventually a fungal vaccine to patients. 

This legislation also represents a breakthrough for medical research; Section 9 of the FORWARD Act establishes a blockchain pilot to ensure Valley Fever researchers have access to robust clinical data without compromising patient privacy. 

The graphic below provides a concise description of how the pilot will operate, ensuring data accessibility and security. I am proud to sponsor this legislation, which will support Arizona and other states in their continued efforts to fight endemic fungal diseases, including Valley Fever!

￼
Blockchain/FORWARD Act graphic to visual the process. 
August
Remembering Senator John McCain

￼
The Arizona delegation pictured above in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda. 

On August 25, 2018, we lost a great man, a great leader and a great voice for our home state of Arizona. Throughout his long and distinguished life, Senator McCain personified honorable service to one’s nation. There is no question that with his passing, Senator McCain will serve as a shining example to all who endeavor to a life of service to America. 
September
Meeting with Chairman Jerome Powell

￼
Chairman Jerome Powell and I in my office. 

This September I had the pleasure of welcoming Chairman of the Federal Reserve Jerome Powell into my office for a meeting. We had a fascinating conversation including the importance of the United States long term growth and the stability of our labor force.

￼ 
￼
  Click the photo above for a link to watch me speak during the Ways and Means Mark-Up on Tax 2.0
 This September, the House passed Tax Reform 2.0 which included three bills:   - H.R. 6760 Protecting Families and Small Business Tax Cuts Act of 2018: This legislation would make the individual and small business tax cuts permanent, as they are now set to dissolve in 2025.  - H.R. 6757 Family Savings Act of 2018: Helping to expand access to savings vehicles and helps local businesses expand their ability to provide retirement plans for their employees as well as have better access for employees to use those retirement plans.   - H.R. 6756 American Innovation Act of 2018: This legislation will support new ventures by supporting their start-up costs and capital that is incurred when opening to create innovation.   These three pieces of legislation locked in tax cuts for middle-class families and show continued support for small businesses. By continuing to work on tax reform, we will ensure our tax code will never fall behind global competitors again.  
October
 H.R. 6 SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act

￼
 I am very proud of this bi-partisan, bi-cameral package Congress passed for the President to sign into law. My contribution to the package, which is mentioned above in the January subheading, is H.R. 4841, the Standardizing Electronic Prior Authorization for Safe Prescribing Act of 2018. 

As we enter 2019, I look forward to seeing how this package has helped the Opioid crisis in America. 
November
Arizona Delegation Meeting
￼
From left, Rep. Andy Biggs, Rep. Ruben Gallego, Rep. Debbie Lesko, Rep.-elect Greg Stanton, Senator Kyl, Rep. Ann Kirkpatrick, and Rep. Paul Gosar. 

This November, Congresswoman Lesko invited the Arizona delegation to her office for a breakfast to discuss how we can all work together for Arizonans next Congress. 


 "Championing American Businesses" Bill

In November, my colleague Congressman Michael McCaul and I introduced the 'Championing American Businesses Through Diplomacy Act.' This bill prioritizes economic and commercial diplomacy at the Department of State and U.S. missions throughout the world, allowing U.S. businesses better access to markets abroad. 

Here are a few key points the bill seeks to address: 
· Authorizes in statute the Assistant Secretary for Economic and Business Affairs, setting in statute their responsibilities to promote and support U.S. economic and commercial diplomacy;
· Streamlines and combines two commercial diplomacy guides – the Investment Climate Statement and the Country Commercial Guide, respectfully produced by the Department of State and Department of Commerce –  into one annual guide for each country focused on critical information that businesses rely upon when assessing whether to do business in a particular country;
· Requires Ambassadors and their Embassies to submit a report to the Department of State of the specific actions they took in the year prior of how they are aided businesses achieve market access, while assessing levels of private-sector commercial competition from other strategic competitor nation-states;
· Requires the Secretary to report to Congress general commercial diplomacy trends, as well as assessments of commercial activity in strategic areas from competing nation-states that threatens U.S. national security; and
· Places further emphasis on training our diplomats on matters of commercial diplomacy.
December
 As we wrap up this year, my team and I wish you and your family a joyous holiday season, a Merry Christmas, and a Happy New Year. I look forward to working with you all in 2019 to best support Arizona.  
￼

Subject: Senate Update: Fighting Against the Shutdown Clock
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼

 
December 21, 2018 


Today, we are on the brink of an unnecessary and reckless partial government shutdown. Earlier this week, the Senate passed a bipartisan agreement to prevent such a shutdown. While far from perfect, it would have avoided the havoc a shutdown wreaks on our country and hardworking federal employees. Then, yesterday, we watched as President Trump pulled the rug out from under the agreement after he was criticized by conservative talk show hosts. I was then deeply frustrated to see Speaker Paul Ryan and House Republicans do the President’s bidding instead of letting democracy work its will and allowing the House to vote on the Senate compromise to fund the government.  This argument is not about border security. There is strong bipartisan support for securing our borders. This is about wasting $5 billion on an ineffective, 2,000-mile-long border wall that President Trump said Mexico -- not American taxpayers -- would pay for. The short-term budget agreement the Senate passed earlier this week maintains the significant funding for border security that the Congress passed last year -- much of which the President has yet to put to use. But it’s clear that this common-sense approach is not sufficient for the President, who said he would be “proud” to shut down the government if he didn’t get everything his way.    I will continue fighting to keep the government open. A shutdown will have dire consequences on our state and country -- shuttering large portions of agencies ranging from the Department of Justice to the Department of Agriculture to Homeland Security. The closings negatively impact small businesses, farmers, homeowners, and more. Over 26,000 jobs in Maryland could be directly impacted.  If the government does shut down, hardworking federal employees should not be punished for political dysfunction they had nothing to do with -- they should at the very least be provided the comfort of knowing that they will receive full retroactive pay once the government reopens. Senator Cardin and I have introduced legislation to do just that, and I'm very pleased to report that we passed it out of the Senate today. Now the House should pass it immediately.   As we move forward, I will keep urging my colleagues to put party politics aside to fund our government. 
￼ 
Chris Van Hollen 

Protecting Americans’ Health Care
Since day one, President Trump and Congressional Republicans have worked to repeal, sabotage, and dismantle the Affordable Care Act. Each time, we stood together and refused to stay silent because we knew what was at stake. Without this landmark law, tens of millions of Americans, including many of our friends, neighbors, and family members, would be left without the lifesaving care they need. Healthcare costs would become unaffordable for millions more, and people would be left without important protections.  Unfortunately, we must unite once again to defend our healthcare system. Last week, a federal judge in Texas -- after pressure from Congressional Republicans, the Trump Administration, and Republican Attorneys General -- ruled that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional. If upheld, this ruling will have a devastating impact on our entire healthcare system. It will threaten access to coverage and protections -- including for those with pre-existing conditions -- for millions of people, potentially leaving them with astronomically high costs or no healthcare coverage at all.  As this ruling makes its way through the courts, the President and the GOP are trying to accomplish in court what they couldn’t do in Congress. I will continue to use every tool at my disposal to fight against this effort -- and I urge you to do the same. This week I introduced a bill with some of my Senate colleagues authorizing the Senate Legal Counsel to represent the Senate in court to defend all provisions of the ACA. I’m confident the new House will authorize their legal counsel to do the same come January. 

Supporting Farmers, the Chesapeake Bay, and Our Environment 
Last week, Congress passed a bipartisan five-year Farm Bill that authorizes and updates programs that help our farmers and protect our environment. It includes important wins for our state, and we defeated attempts to undermine conservation efforts.  I’m pleased to announce that the legislation includes three major initiatives that I’ve championed in the Senate. First, the Farm Bill includes my plan to significantly increase funding for the Regional Conservation Partnership Program -- a program that helps farmers and conservation groups work together to reduce runoff and prevent pollution. It also makes improvements to the program so that increased funding goes to sensitive environmental areas like the Chesapeake Bay watershed.  The bill also contains provisions I introduced to reauthorize and improve access to assistance for veteran and socially disadvantaged farmers, as well as language I introduced to correct an inequity and give 1890s Land-Grant Universities (which are all Historically Black Colleges and Universities) the same flexibility to use their funding as other Land Grant universities. Both of these programs will help the University of Maryland Eastern Shore and the great work it’s doing in our state. 
Improving Justice for All
For all the understandable cynicism about Congress being unable to accomplish anything significant, there was a little ray of light here as we head into the New Year: the Congress took an important first step to reform our broken criminal justice system. The First Step Act is backed by a diverse group of supporters -- from the American Civil Liberties Union to the Fraternal Order of Police. It includes crucial reforms to reduce mandatory minimum sentences for non-violent crimes, end juvenile solitary confinement, and provide more people with a second chance.  As the bill makes clear, this is just the beginning of the work we need to do to ensure that all Americans have equal rights and equal justice under the law. For example, I’ve partnered with my friend Senator Cory Booker to push to end private prisons, which have seen countless abuses and create perverse profit incentives to lock up more people for longer periods of time. I also believe Maryland has taken several important steps, including on bail reform, that the federal government should examine on a national basis. And through my role on the Appropriations Committee, I’ll keep fighting to secure critical resources for programs that improve our justice system, such as the Justice Reinvestment Initiative and the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion program.  America’s history has always been tied to the struggle for equal rights and opportunity for all. Working together, we will keep fighting to build an ever more perfect union. 

￼￼￼￼￼

Subject: Merry Christmas!
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼


 ￼
￼ 
￼



The Webster Wire
Listening to Floridians
Dear Friends: 
"For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given..." Isaiah 9:6 Christmas is one of my favorite times of year because we get to celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ with our beloved family and friends. Sandy and I pray that you and your family have a wonderful Christmas and Happy New Year! 
￼  
______________ 
Yesterday, I voted to provide $5 billion to begin construction of a border wall.  I dislike funding the government through Continuing Resolutions. They act as a slush fund allowing agencies to follow their own path independent of proper congressional oversight. Because of this lack of oversight and high spending, I typically oppose these bills.  However, I supported it this time because we must secure our borders and I believe wall funding is an important component of that.  
I remain concerned about our nation’s debt and spending trajectory. This concern will continue to guide my decision making as I evaluate budget/spending plans in the 116th Congress. I pledge to continue to work hard on behalf of Florida’s hardworking taxpayers and families to advance common-sense reforms and principled policy and budgets that get our fiscal house in order. 
￼
______________ 
I was disappointed to hear that General Jim Mattis is retiring from serving as Secretary of the Department of Defense at the end of February.  General Mattis has spent his entire life in service to his country.  We owe him a debt we can never repay.
￼  
_______________ 
On Wednesday, President Trump announced that American troops would begin to withdraw from Syria where they have been supporting the Kurds in their fight against ISIS. ISIS has sustained significant defeats in Syria and removing troops from Syria fulfills a campaign promise President Trump made in 2016. However, I share the concern of some of our military leaders and allies that an early withdrawal empowers Iran, Hezbollah, ISIS and Russia.  These individuals assault that which is at the heart of America—freedom.  The images of war and the news of terrorist attacks remind us of the differences between the United States and many other countries.  
I look forward to learning more details from the White House and Pentagon to better understand their plan in Syria. We must not forget the horrific human rights abuses and ethnic cleansing that was perpetrated on Syrians by their government.  We must remain vigilant in the ongoing fight against ISIS and global terrorism.
￼ 
_______________ 
Tuesday, a disturbing report was issued by the Government Accountability Office, asserting that the Department of Veterans Affairs spent less than $57,000 out of $6.2 million appropriated by Congress for veteran suicide prevention outreach. 20 veterans commit suicide daily, many of them their contact with the VA is little to none. Outreach to veterans could change this and give these men and women the opportunity to receive vital mental health services.   
Serving our veterans is one of my priorities, from improving access to and the quality of services that our veterans receive to holding government leaders accountable for providing our veterans the care they have earned and need. I have contacted VA Secretary Robert Wilkie asking him to inform me how the VA will remedy this inaction and hold individuals accountable, so this failure is not repeated.   
_______________ 
This week the House also passed H.R. 88, the Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act, with my support.  This bill builds on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act we passed a year ago and provides additional relief, streamlining corrections and changes that further assist everyday Americans as they file and pay taxes. Change include: 
	•	 Repealing the onerous Johnson Amendment, which the IRS has used to threaten to remove churches and faith-based non-profit charitable groups tax-exempt status for exercising their First Amendment free speech rights on public policy and political issues.
	•	Allowing individuals to access their retirement funds, if needed for disaster relief.
	•	Expanding the use of 529 accounts to allow families to start saving earlier and more. 
	•	Modernizing more elements of the IRS to improve the efficiency of filing taxes, retrieving information, resolving issues and making payments.
	•	It also repeals or delays taxes that were imbedded in Obamacare, including medical device tax, health insurance tax and tanning tax.
￼ 
_______________ 
Thursday, I supported the House passage of S.3777, the Forever GI Bill Housing Payment Fulfillment Act. This bill holds the Veterans Affairs Department responsible for inaccurate housing stipends for thousands of Post-9/11 GI Bill students. The VA will be required to retroactively pay these veteran students the housing money they are owed. It requires the VA to create a “Tiger Team” within 15 days, whose purpose will be to correct the technology that caused this error and ensure veteran students receive their proper stipends. Retroactive payments are set to begin in January. We owe our veterans a debt we can never repay. It is essential that the federal government hold the VA accountable, fulfill its promises to our nation’s heroes, and provide our veterans with the assistance they deserve and need. 
_______________ 
The United States Air Force (USAF) recently announced its Inaugural Air Force Pitch Day. This is a new initiative that will connect small businesses, startups and entrepreneurs across the nation with opportunities to work with the USAF. The Air Force Pitch Day is modeled after commercial investment pitch competitions, and their goal is to award up to $40 million in startups using one-day, one-page contracts. They are looking for startups that can help the USAF in command, control, communications, intelligence and network, battlefield air operations, and digital technology. Startup solutions can be pitched from January 9th through February 6th. The Air Force will then contact those selected to do an in-person pitch. I encourage all interested constituents to visit this page, familiarize themselves with the process and details, and apply for this exciting opportunity. 
￼  photo source: defensenews.com 
_______________ 
The Webster Wire will be on hiatus for the next couple weeks for Christmas and New Years Holiday.  For breaking news updates, follow me on Facebook. Merry Christmas! 
  
Daniel Webster Member of Congress   Your servant, 
￼ 
￼  Daniel Webster Member of Congress  
Constituent Corner
A constituent from Weeki Wachee contacted our office because she was having an issue obtaining a new passport card for her upcoming trip. We sent an inquiry to the passport center and learned that original documents were needed, instead of the photocopies that were provided with the application. We relayed the information to the constituent who then mailed the originals overnight. The constituent called our office to say she received her passport and was thankful for our assistance.
Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you.  
District Update
On Friday December 14th, Cindy Brown from my district office attended the "Home for the Holidays" adoption event at the Ocala courtroom.  
￼
Legislative Update 
Last week, Congress passed the FIRST STEP Act with my support. This legislation requires the Department of Justice to develop and apply a risk and needs assessment system to identify a prisoner’s risk level and assign them to participate in an appropriate evidence-based program. These programs could include vocational training, educational support, substance abuse treatment, mental health care, anger management courses, faith-based initiatives or other resources. Prisoners could then earn incentives such as extra commissary items, extra yard time, or even halfway home placement towards the end of their sentences (only those with the lowest risk) for participating in these programs. 
For individuals who make mistakes and subject themselves to the justice system, we should provide pathways that afford them the opportunity to regain their footing in life and transition into the classroom or workforce. Such opportunities will improve communities by reducing recidivism and empowering formerly incarcerated or committed inmates to contribute in a meaningful way in the workforce and become productive citizens.
The FIRST STEP Act also gets rid of harmful prison practices, such as shackling pregnant inmates. Additionally, inmates will be placed in prisons within 500 miles of their homes, making family-visits possible. Finally, it gives judges more discernment on a case-by-case basis in deciding the length of prison sentences. These initiatives have proven to reduce recidivism in state prisons.
Survey

	•	Yes
	•	No
	•	Unsure

Subject: Putting politics aside to get results for families
Message:
News from Representative Bustos 
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
During a hectic and far too partisan week in Washington, I’m pleased to share some good news for the hardworking people of Illinois. 
Infrastructure Improvements  
￼
Congresswoman Bustos announced funding this week to help keep homes safe and lead-free 
It started on Tuesday, when I announced federal dollars for lead abatement available to folks in Galesburg and across Illinois who want nothing more than a safe and lead-free home to raise their family. Whether it’s toxic lead-based paint or unsafe drinking water, we can and must work tirelessly to keep our children safe and to make our region a great place to live, work and raise a family. These dollars will help us do just that. Click here to learn how to apply for funding. 
Additionally, the House passed my bipartisan Water Infrastructure Improvement Act. This bill would formalize the process for communities to create integrated plans for water infrastructure improvements. My legislation encourages green infrastructure development, paving the way for cities like Peoria to address combined sewer overflow through investments in modern, environmentally-sound infrastructure. Learn more by clicking here.  
Support for Gold Star Spouses  
￼
Congresswoman Bustos with Gold Star spouse, Kylie Riney
Wednesday evening, the Senate unanimously passed my legislation, the Gold Star Spouses Leasing Relief Act, sending it to the president’s desk to be signed into law. This bill extends residential leasing protections of surviving spouses of servicemembers killed in the line of duty. I was inspired by the experience of Kylie Riney, whose husband – Sergeant Douglas J. Riney – tragically died defending our country in Afghanistan. Kylie chose to move back to their home state of Illinois as they mourned his passing, but was confronted with costly lease cancellation fees. Once this bill is signed into law, Gold Star spouses will no longer have to go through this experience – and I want to thank Kylie for sharing her story and helping us change the law for the better. To hear from Kylie, click here. 
To keep up on the work that I am doing to fight for the hardworking families of Illinois, make sure to stay connected with me @RepCheri!           
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
Have a happy holiday season, Cheri

December 21, 2018

Services | Newsroom | Contact Rodney
Salute: Secretary James Mattis
Worth a Read:“Stay in Syria”
Pleased to Receive National Park Service Award
Historic Criminal Justice Reform Legislation Approved by House
Happy Birthday New Jersey!
 
Salute: Secretary James Mattis who has served our nation with honor and distinction for 44 years, most recently as the 26th Secretary of Defense. Yesterday, Secretary Mattis announced his resignation in a letter to the President. I would encourage you to read that letter here.
 
I had the honor of working with former Generals Mattis and John Kelly as chair of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense. Both of these men were and are excellent public servants and Marines.
 
Further, I was extremely honored to receive a personal note from the Secretary today, which reads:
 
DEAR CHAIRMAN FRELINGHUYSEN,
 
On behalf of the men and women of the U.S. Department of Defense, thank you for your 24 years of committed service in Congress and especially for your leadership the House Committee on Appropriations: first as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Defense, then as Chairman of the full Committee.
 
In an era of renewed Great Power Competition, you ensured our Armed Forces received essential funding required to protect our Nation. It was a comfort to know that, in you, we had an effective advocate- an Army veteran who carried the motto “This We’ll Defend” with him in Washington’s halls of power.
 
From America’s founding to the antebellum years to the present day, public service runs in your family. As you prepare to bid farewell to “the People’s House,” know that you leave a lasting legacy, written in terms of increasing military readiness and greater security for the American people.
 
Thank you for your leadership. We wish you fair winds and following seas.
 
WITH GREAT RESPECT,  
Jim Mattis     
 
Worth a Read: “Stay in Syria”, National Review’s opinion, which I strongly share, highlighting the many reasons why the U.S. should maintain our strategic presence in the war torn country.  
 
Pleased to Receive National Park Service Award
On Wednesday, I was very pleased to receive, the rarely presented, National Park Service (NPS) Ranger Hat for my longstanding support of our nation’s parks, including Morristown and Thomas Edison National Historic Parks. 
 
In a letter from, NPS Deputy Director, Daniel Smith stated, “I want to personally express my sincere gratitude for your dedication to America’s national parks and public lands.  For over 23 years you have served as the U.S. Representatives for New Jersey’s 11th Congressional District: a district that encompasses Thomas Edison National Historic Park (NHP) and Morristown National Historic Park (NHP). You have been a true champion for these parks in addition to the 415 other units in the National Park System.”
 
You can view Deputy Director Smith’s entire letter here.
 
You can read Eric Kiefer’s article in the West Orange Patch on the award here. 
 
Historic Criminal Justice Reform Legislation Approved by House
On Thursday, I was pleased to support the passage of the First Step Act on the floor of the House of Representatives, which was approved by a vote of 358 to 36. This bipartisan legislation will bring historic reforms to our criminal justice system that will keep New Jersey communities safer and give nonviolent offenders a real chance after serving their sentence, reducing the chance of recidivism.
 
Specifically, the legislation revises federal sentencing laws, reducing the "three strikes" penalty for drug felonies from life behind bars to 25 years and retroactively limiting the disparity in sentencing guidelines between crack and powder cocaine offenses.
 
Further, the bill establishes an evidence-based risk and needs assessment tool to tailor expanded rehabilitative programs to individual prisoners and affords low-risk, well-behaved inmates the opportunity to access alternative confinement near the end of their sentences in order to ease their transitions to society.
 
The First Step Act will now go to the president’s desk where it is expected to signed into law. The bill has wide support, especially from the law enforcement community.
 
You can read the entire text of the legislation here. 
 
Happy Birthday New Jersey!
This week we marked the 231st Anniversary of New Jersey joining the Union. On December 18, 1787, New Jersey was the third state to ratify the Constitution.
 
With a past rich in patriotism, New Jersey has played a significant role in the history of United States, and maybe most importantly, during our founding. 
 
Known as the “Crossroads of the Revolution”, there are nearly 300 sites in New Jersey with direct ties to the American Revolution. Among the landmarks are Washington’s Headquarters in Morristown, Jockey Hollow, the Old Trenton Barracks, the Dey Mansion in Wayne, the Princeton, Monmouth, and Red Bank battlefields, and the Great Falls of the Passaic.
 
I was extremely proud to introduce legislation to recognize the critical role our state played in the American Revolution. This legislation was included in the National Heritage Areas Act of 2005, which was signed into law on October 12, 2006. The Crossroads of the American Revolution National Heritage Area Act has raised the profile of New Jersey's historical importance.
 
For more information regarding the Crossroads of the American Revolution National Heritage Area, please visit here.

ABOUT ANNA
NEWSROOM
