The federal government could shut down. Here's what it would mean for Middle Tennessee.  Tennessean When the clock strikes midnight Friday, a portion of the federal government will shut down without Congress and the White House agreeing on a budget, a development could leave some in Middle Tennessee feeling the effect. 
Jim Mattis, Defense Secretary, Resigns in Rebuke of Trump’s Worldview  New York Times Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, whose experience and stability were widely seen as a balance to an unpredictable president, resigned Thursday in protest of President Trump’s decision to withdraw American forces from Syria and his rejection of international alliances.  Gov. Bill Haslam granted 11 people clemency, but he has yet to address Cyntoia Brown case  Tennessean Gov. Bill Haslam on Thursday granted clemency to 11 current or former Tennesseans. Cyntoia Brown, whose high-profile request for mercy has received national attention, was not mentioned in the announcement.  A Decade After Kingston Spill, TVA Is Still Figuring Out What To Do With Tennessee's Coal Ash  WPLN Exactly 10 years ago, one of the worst environmental disasters in U.S. history happened near Kingston, Tennessee. Over a billion tons of coal ash spilled from a pit at a Tennessee Valley Authority plant into the Emory and Clinch rivers and surrounding land on Dec. 22, 2008.   Tennessee Foster System Shows ‘Sustained Progress’ Caring For Vulnerable Children  WPLN In the past two years, Tennessee’s foster care system showed “sustained major improvements” caring for vulnerable children, according to a study out this week. The findings mean that intense outside reviews of the Department of Children’s Services will likely end next year.  Demanding Wall Funding, Trump Balks at Bill to Avert Shutdown  New York Times WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday torpedoed a spending deal and sent the government careening toward a Christmastime shutdown over his demand of $5 billion for a wall on the southwestern border, refusing to sign a stopgap measure to keep funds flowing past midnight Friday.  U.S. to Withdraw About 7,000 Troops From Afghanistan, Officials Say  The New York Times The Trump administration has ordered the military to start withdrawing roughly 7,000 troops from Afghanistan in the coming months, two defense officials said Thursday, an abrupt shift in the 17-year-old war there and a decision that stunned Afghan officials, who said they had not been briefed on the plans.  U.S. Accuses Chinese Nationals of Infiltrating Corporate and Government Technology  New York Times The Trump administration ramped up its pressure campaign on Beijing on Thursday, as the Justice Department accused two Chinese nationals with ties to the country’s Ministry of State Security of infiltrating the biggest providers of internet services and boring into government computer systems, including a major Department of Energy laboratory.  Trump Administration Moves to Restrict Food Stamp Access the Farm Bill Protected  New York Times The Trump administration announced on Thursday that it would seek to put in place more stringent work requirements for adults who rely on food stamps, even as the president signed a sweeping farm bill in which lawmakers had rejected stricter rules. 
House Passes Criminal-Justice Reform Bill  Wall Street Journal The House on Thursday passed legislation that will change sentencing guidelines for federal prisoners and allow for early release for thousands of inmates convicted of nonviolent crimes. It cleared the Senate earlier this week and will now head to President Trump, who has already endorsed it.

Subject: UPDATE: New Farm Bill is law
Message:
News from Congressman Greg Gianforte  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
   
￼
￼
Greg's Treasure State Update
Stronger, booming economy heading into 2019 

President Trump and congressional Republicans have enacted pro-growth policies, from cutting taxes for hardworking Montanans to cutting red tape for Montana farmers, ranchers, and businesses. As a result, our economy is booming and opportunities are growing.
	•	Our economy is expected to grow 3.1 percent for 2018, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The U.S. economy hasn’t grown at or above 3 percent in 13 years.
	•	America’s unemployment rate is near a 50-year low.
	•	Montana’s unemployment rate has been at or below the national average for the last several months.
	•	Americans’ wages are growing at their fastest rate in nine years.
	•	Optimism is at record levels heading into the new year.
I’ve heard about that confidence and growing optimism as I’ve met with Montanans throughout the state, whether at Big Sky Wholesale Seeds in Shelby, Billings Flying Service, or with female entrepreneurs in Bozeman. 

I’ll continue to support pro-growth, pro-family policies in 2019. 

￼
Greg talks with entrepreneurs in Bozeman about pro-growth ideas before Congress

Pro-Montana Farm Bill now law 

President Trump recently signed the 2018 Farm Bill which gives Montana farmers and ranchers much needed certainty. It provides a strong safety net that guards against the impact of natural disasters and unpredictable, unfair trade practices of other countries. 

The Farm Bill takes care of Montana priorities, including protecting our state’s sugar beet growers and producers, supporting the Agricultural Research Service, assisting rural EMS providers, and improving rural broadband delivery. 

It also improves how we manage our forests by empowering county governments to improve management of neighboring National Forest System lands. Though there is more work to do, the measure provides tools to help improve the health of our forests and reduce the severity of wildfires. 

Nearly 500 ag groups supported the measure, including the Montana Grain Growers Association and the Montana Farm Bureau Federation. 

Since taking office in June 2017, I’ve worked closely with Montana farmers, ranchers, and ag leaders. Together, we put Montana’s fingerprints on the new Farm Bill. 

Learn more about the 2018 Farm Bill HERE. 

￼
Greg tours a Columbia Grain facility in Plentywood and gathers input for the Farm Bill


Supporting EMS in rural Montana 

President Trump also signed into law my bill to help rural EMS providers who are the first line of care for Montanans in more remote areas who face a medical emergency. 

The Supporting and Improving Rural EMS Needs Act, or SIREN Act, which I introduced in April, provides access to resources so that EMS providers in our rural areas have the training and equipment they need to get the job done. The SIREN Act was included in the 2018 Farm Bill. 

I urged Farm Bill negotiators to include the measure, along with other Montana priorities, in the new Farm Bill. 


Learning and coding with Montana’s youngest students 

Montana’s classrooms were full of budding computer engineers recently, as more than 200 classrooms across the state took part in Hour of Code, an educational outreach to demystify computer coding and broaden participation in the field of computer science. 

I visited with students from first through fourth grade at Emily Dickinson School in Bozeman to see what they were working on and to encourage their efforts. Their imagination and creativity were inspiring, and they shared a lot of great ideas. 

￼
An elementary school student in Bozeman shares her creative ideas with Greg at an event in which he addressed the importance of STEM education


Spirit of Montana 

I had the honor of recognizing Devin Rich and Kiersten Bare, siblings from Kalispell, who helped in the recovery efforts from the disastrous Woolsey and Camp fires in California. 

Rich helped victims of the Woolsey Fire search through the ash and rubble where their homes stood to salvage items dear to them, and Bare worked to reunite lost pets with their owners 

Anyone may nominate Montanans for the Spirit of Montana award by contacting my office at 202-225-3211 or by email at https://gianforte.house.gov/contact/email. 


MT in DC 

 ￼
Greg and Nicole Rolf of the Montana Farm Bureau Federation discuss the 2018 Farm Bill 


Stay in touch 

As your voice in the U.S. House of Representatives, I look forward to hearing your thoughts and concerns, so please don't hesitate to reach out to me. Contact any of my offices if I can be of service to you, and keep up to date by liking my Facebook page. 

I am honored to serve you. 
￼ 
Greg

Subject: Congressman Hank Johnson's Holiday E-Newsletter
Tantrums
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
FriendNews from Representative David Cicilline 
￼
SERVING YOU  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATIVE WORK  |  OUR DISTRICT
 
December 21, 2018
 
 

Dear Friend, 

As I write to you this morning, the federal government inches closer towards a partial shutdown at midnight tonight. The American people want a federal government that does its job and gets things done. Instead, this will be the third time in less than a year that President Trump and the Republicans who control Congress allow funding for the federal government to expire. 

The President says he will keep the government shut down unless Congress gives him the money he wants for his costly, ineffective border wall – a complete waste of money that will do nothing to make our border more secure. Let me be clear, I strongly support smart investments in border security using advancements in technology, drones, satellites, and additional personnel. But no matter how many tantrums he throws on Twitter, the President isn’t going to persuade Congress to waste taxpayer money on a border wall. The reality is that there aren’t even enough Republicans who support it to make that happen.

The good news is that help is on the way. When Democrats take control of the U.S. House in January, we will restore honest, effective government that knows how to get things done for the people it serves. The President needs to work with us, not against us, even if it doesn’t mean he will always get what he wants.

$2 Million for Newport 

On Tuesday, I announced that the Newport County Community Mental Health Center will receive $2,000,000 to meet the needs of 24,500 Rhode Islanders over the next two years. This federal funding will help ensure that even more Rhode Islanders who need care will be able to get it. I was proud to advocate for this funding directly with the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), and I am pleased that these resources will be put to use here in Rhode Island. Click here to learn more about this announcement.

Secretary Mattis 

We owe Secretary of Defense James Mattis an enormous debt of gratitude for his service to our country. He is a patriot who has always conducted himself with dignity and honor. His resignation yesterday, which came as a direct result of the President abruptly withdrawing from Syria, is bad news for the security of our country and the strength of our alliances. 

Over the past two years, President Trump has made America less safe at home and less respected around the world. It is long past time for Republicans to work with Democrats to conduct real oversight of this administration and the bizarre decisions it is making by the day.

I am very grateful for Secretary Mattis’s devotion to our country, and I am very disappointed that our country will no longer benefit from his wise and experienced service.

Serving You Over the Holidays 

As we prepare to enter the holiday season, my office will remain ready to serve you. Send me an email at David.Cicilline@mail.house.gov, or call my Pawtucket office at 729-5600. 

Warm Regards,
￼ 
David N. Cicilline
Member of Congress

Subject: Update on Agriculture
Message:
￼
Home 
| 
Serving You
| 
Issues 
|
Newsroom 
| 
Contact Adrian 
 
About the District
| 
About Adrian 



 

December 21, 2018 
  
Mrs. Lindsey P.   
235 W 102nd Street #11m 
Scottsblue, NE 69361
  
Dear Mrs.  : 
  
Knowing of your interest in issues affecting agriculture, I am writing to update you on recent developments. 
As you may know, every five years the House of Representatives reauthorizes agriculture programs through legislation commonly referred to as the Farm Bill. The Farm Bill covers the federal crop insurance program, provides disaster assistance to livestock producers impacted by severe weather, invests in agriculture research, funds the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), and builds upon conversation efforts already undertaken by landowners across the country.
As the Farm Bill represents one of the most important pieces of legislation for Nebraska, I started this process in 2017 with my Farm Bill Listening Tour: five listening sessions held across the state to hear directly from ag producers about their needs and concerns. Throughout 2017, the House Committee on Agriculture also held hearings both in Washington, DC and across the country to gain the information and farmer feedback needed to draft the Farm Bill. Additionally, on January 24, 2018, Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue released the Department of Agriculture’s legislative principles for the 2018 Farm Bill. With my support, the House of Representatives passed its version of the Farm Bill by a vote of 213-211 on June 21, 2018, which was followed by Senate passage of its version one week later.
Due to significant differences between the House and Senate Farm Bills, the House voted unanimously on July 18, 2018, to form a conference committee to resolve these differences. Composed of 47 House Representatives and 9 Senators, this committee negotiated for months to produce a final product which can provide the certainty our producers need for the next five years. In particular, this legislation included the continuation of a strong crop insurance program, and the establishment of a new disease prevention program and vaccine bank for our livestock producers.
With my support, the Farm Bill conference report was adopted by the House of Representatives on December 12, 2018, by a vote of 369-47. I was then proud to join President Trump at White House to witness him sign the legislation in a ceremony on December 20, 2018. While the 2018 Farm Bill will remain in effect through the 2023 crop year, as co-chair of both the Congressional Rural Caucus and the Modern Agriculture Caucus, I remain committed to ensuring opportunity for producers across Nebraska as future legislation is considered in the House. 
For more information on this issue or to receive additional legislative updates, please visit http://adriansmith.house.gov. 



Sincerely, 

 ￼  ADRIAN SMITH Member of Congress

Subject: Catastrophic Climate Report Demands Congressional Response
Message:
DECEMBER 21, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Catastrophic Climate Report Demands Congressional Response
￼
 
The National Climate Assessment (NCA) released last month reaffirms what 97% of climate scientists have made abundantly clear: climate change poses a real danger to American’s health and economic well-being. The report also explains that the catastrophic damage done by climate change will continue to intensify, and that inaction will be far costlier than confronting the problem now.  
In my view, the President has double-downed on his anti-climate policies by publicly disputing the findings in the NCA. This is disappointing, but not surprising. This year alone, our nation witnessed deadly wildfires, disastrous hurricanes, and debilitating droughts and heat waves that have displaced thousands across the country. Instead of prioritizing solutions that could reverse the effects of climate change, I believe the Administration has pursued policies that expand offshore drilling, weaken clean air and water protections, and dismantle renewable energy programs, all of which I vehemently oppose. The effects of climate change are undeniable, and the American people deserve a Congress that will stand up to the oil industry and fight for real solutions that will preserve our planet for future generations. 
Combating Hate Crimes & Anti-Semitism in Our Communities
According to the New York Police Department, anti-Semitic hate crimes are up 22% compared to last year, and anti-Semitic incidents have constituted half of all hate crimes in New York this year. A recent report by the Anti-Defamation League found a 57% rise in anti-Semitic incidents nationwide since 2016. I am deeply concerned and heartbroken by these crimes, which have cast an unsettling shadow on our community and our country as whole. As a Member of Congress, it is my duty to ensure that this disgusting, hate-fueled behavior does not go unaddressed. Earlier this month, I joined my fellow NYC Members of Congress in pressing the NYPD for answers on how they are combating what appears to be a recent wave of anti-Semitic acts, and I have made this a priority for the House Judiciary Committee next year in the new Congress. Hate crimes and anti-Semitism should have no place in our city or country.
To read our full letter to the NYPD, please click here. 
￼
 
Rep. Nadler standing with Democratic lawmakers discussing the importance of protecting the rights of victims of harassment and assault.
Improving Protections for Victims of Workplace Harassment 
Across workplaces, schools, and communities, our nation is beginning to come to terms with how our laws have failed victims of harassment. This month, Congress passed bipartisan MeToo legislation which helps foster a climate of respect and dignity by fundamentally changing the flawed process Congress had previously used to address sexual harassment claims. While this is an important first step, Congress must not stop it’s work there.  
I am proud to be a lead sponsor of H.R. 6406, the EMPOWER Act, which would lift the veil of secrecy surrounding workplace harassment, and bolster transparency and accountability. Every man and woman deserves a safe, transparent, and fair work environment, and if the women and men who have been victimized, shamed, and abandoned by our laws and society can find the courage to stand up and tell their stories, then Congress must step-up and act in their names and the names of the millions who don’t have the platform to speak out. Time is up for this misconduct to go unpunished.
To read more about the EMPOWER Act, please click here. 
Ending the Unconstitutional War in Yemen 
For over three years, military forces led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates -with direct U.S. military participation-have been fighting the Houthis, a Yemeni rebel group that are not covered under any Authorization for Use of Military Force. As a Member of Congress, I have always opposed intervening in international conflicts with military force without congressional approval. That is why I am a cosponsor H.Con.Res. 138, which would stop the unauthorized U.S. military participation in Yemen and help bring an end to this humanitarian crisis. Unfortunately, the Majority prevented this resolution from being voted on, and instead passed legislation that would prevent any vote to limit our military involvement in Yemen for the rest of the year. 

It is essential that the power to decide whether or not to commit the country to war rest with the people, through their representatives in Congress, and I will continue to work to ensure the Administration does not overstep their power. 
Honoring Shirley Chisholm in Prospect Park 
 
￼
Rep. Shirley Chisholm's portrait honoring her life and career inside of the U.S. Capitol Building.

Last month, I joined She Built NYC to announce that a monument to Representative Shirley Chisholm, a political trailblazer from Brooklyn who was the first black Congresswoman in the U.S. House of Representatives, will be erected in Prospect Park. Rep. Shirley Chisholm was a model of courage and conviction who worked tirelessly on behalf of women and minorities at a critical time in our nation’s history. For too long, we have not done enough to honor the significant contributions of women in our city and our nation, and this monument is an important step in correcting that omission. 


Get Updates in Real Time
Want to check out more of my work for New York's tenth congressional district? Make sure to follow me on Twitter as well as on Facebook, and YouTube, where you can see more of my work on these and other issues.

Sincerely,

Subject: Congressman Harper's Final Year In Review
Message:
￼ 
PROUD TO SERVE MISSISSIPPI’S THIRD DISTRICT 
Dear Friend,
As this year and the 115th Congress ends, it is a bitter sweet moment knowing that this will be my final newsletter serving as your Congressman. I cannot begin to express my deep and sincere appreciation to you for affording me this great honor. 
Serving as a Member of the United States House of Representatives has been the greatest privilege of my life. The opportunity to serve the people of the Third District, our state, and our country is something that my wife, Sidney, and I will never forget. Last Christmas, my family and I made the very difficult decision to say that 10 years would be long enough. I never intended for this to be a career, and it is now time for Member-elect Michael Guest to represent us. 
I have worked tirelessly over the past 12 months of my term this year, and I want to give you a few highlights.   Thanks to Speaker Paul Ryan, I have been allowed to serve as Chairman of the Committee on House Administration and work to make the institution of the House of Representatives more transparent, accountable, and stronger for America’s future. I have worked hard in a bipartisan manner over the remainder of my term to be a problem solver, including my work on establishing accountability on Capitol Hill for sexual harassment issues in the House and Senate.   I will also miss being Chairman of the Energy & Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, where we have continued to work on important issues such as the opioid epidemic and sexual abuse in the U.S. Olympic community. 
 Policy Update  
Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
We promised the American people more jobs, fairer taxes, and bigger paychecks. With the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act, we delivered on those promises. Last year, the House passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, giving the American tax payer the relief you deserve. Since this historic legislation was signed into law, our nation's unemployment is at a historic low, job numbers are at record highs, paychecks are growing, and wages are rising with economic optimism. 
This year, the House voted to make them permanent. Tax Reform 2.0 is a package of three bills that locked in the historic reforms of the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act to protect middle-class and small business tax cuts, promote family savings, and advance the next generation of entrepreneurs. 
Combatting the Opioid Crisis
We have also made significant investments to combat the opioid crisis, an effort that I have been honored to lead as Chairman of the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.
In June, the House of Representatives passed the most significant congressional action against a single drug crisis in history. 
H.R. 6, the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act, is a bipartisan bill that will help in our overall efforts to combat the opioid crisis. This bill advances treatment and recovery initiatives, improves prevention, protects our communities, and bolsters our efforts to fight deadly illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl. 
In October, H.R. 6 was passed by the House and the Senate and sent to President Trump’s desk for signature. This landmark opioid legislation is now law. 
I am proud that members from both chambers and both sides of the aisle were able to come together along President Trump to find tangible solutions to stop this destructive epidemic from continuing to wreck our nation's communities.    Historic Military Funding
Congress understands the significance and importance of our duty to provide for the common defense. For 57 years, the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) has been the primary way Congress executes this constitutional obligation. 
The Trump Administration has prioritized the military, and this year, we worked together to strengthen and rebuild – something that has been neglected for far too long. 
After key discussions between both chambers of Congress, and hearing from many of the top military officials across all branches, the House passed the National Defense Authorization Act with a vote of 359-54 on July 26. This vote count shows a strong bipartisan effort to strengthen our forces and provides a start to building them to the levels of strength this country hasn’t seen in decades. 
Additionally, we fully funded the largest pay raise for our troops in 9 years and reformed the VA to provide better care to our nation's veterans.   Self-Drive Act 
On September 6, 2017, the Energy & Commerce Committee passed the bipartisan SELF DRIVE Act by voice vote, the first-of-its-kind federal framework for the safe and innovative development and deployment of self-driving cars.  Self-driving car technology has the potential to provide new, more reliable modes of transportation which will lead to additional opportunities for the disability community and others who are unable to drive.
After a year of delays, forcing automakers and innovators to develop in a state-by-state patchwork of rules, House leaders on this issue continue to urge the Senate to act to support this critical safety innovation and secure America’s place as a global leader in technology.
America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018
In September, the House unanimously passed the House Amendment to S. 3021, the America's Water Infrastructure Act of 2018.  The bill represents a bipartisan agreement between the House and the Senate on comprehensive water resources infrastructure legislation.  In this bill, the House supported language from my bill, the Drinking Water System Improvement Act, that was included in the America’s Water Infrastructure Act. I am grateful for the hard work of the Energy and Commerce committee staff and everyone who had a hand in passing this legislation. Americans and their drinking water infrastructure will benefit greatly.
Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 Reforms
As Chairman of the Committee on House Administration, Speaker Paul Ryan asked me to lead the House effort in handling sexual harassment, a job I did not take lightly. 
Over the past year, the House has taken a number of steps to ensure a safer and more productive work environment. Those steps include implementing mandatory training for all Members and staff, creating the Office of Employee Advocacy, setting minimum requirements for each office with respect to anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policies, and amending House rules. 
Earlier this month, the House and the Senate came to an agreement which reflects the first set of comprehensive reforms that have been made to the Congressional Accountability Act since 1995. I believe this is a strong step towards creating a new standard in Congress that will set a positive example in our nation, but there is still more work to be done. 
As we celebrate the season and look forward to the New Year, let's remember God's promise in Jeremiah 29:11—“For I know the plans I have for you, declares the LORD, plans to prosper you and not to harm you; plans to give you a future and a hope.”  Sidney and I want to wish you all the best in this upcoming year and a very Merry Christmas as we remember the Christ child who came to give us peace and forgiveness.  Thank you for the honor of allowing me to serve you in Congress.  
God Bless,

￼

Gregg Harper
Member of Congress

December 21, 2018
Dear Lindsey,   
  
Since coming to Congress, I have been focused on supporting policies that will create jobs, revitalize America's tax code, strengthen our defense, and reduce the size of the federal government. It has always been my goal to work on the issues that matter most to Michigan families. I still firmly believe America is the greatest country in the world, and it is our duty as citizens to continue to fight for the principles that make our country great. 

Even though we may not agree on every issue, it has been the honor of my life to serve as your representative from Michigan's Eleventh District in the United States House of Representatives. 

From my family to yours, I wish you a safe, healthy, and happy holiday season. May God bless the United States of America.  

Sincerely,

Subject: Farm Bill signed into law!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼

                     President Trump Signs Farm Bill Into Law  Watch this video from Smieja Farm in Belgrade and Trapper Creek Ranch in Melrose on the importance of the Farm Bill:
 ￼
Today President Trump signed the Farm Bill into law. As Montana’s lone voice on the Senate Ag Committee, I fought hard to ensure that critical priorities for Montana’s farmers and ranchers were included. This Farm Bill will go a long way in helping provide more certainty for Montana agriculture and you can find the text of the new Farm Bill here.  A few highlights of the Farm Bill include:  • Protected crop insurance, a critical part of the safety net for Montana farmers to mitigate risks inherent to agriculture.  • Secured funding for land grant universities, including MSU, specialty crops, and agriculture research stations across Montana.  • Secured provisions to expand broadband access in rural Montana, promote precision agriculture, and prioritize funds to areas that are unserved with no access.  • Included an amendment to help the ARC-County program, an important commodity support program, better reflect actual growing conditions in many of Montana’s large counties.  I will closely monitor implementation of the 2018 Farm Bill to ensure it is working for Montana. As always, please feel to visit my website at www.daines.senate.gov to share feedback you might have on this new law or any other federal policy matter. 
Best Wishes, 
￼
Steve Daines United States Senate

Subject: Congressman Adam Smith's December Newsletter
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A message from Congressman Adam Smith
￼

Home
Issues
Legislation
Services

Congressman Adam Smith’s December Newsletter 
With the year coming to an end, I wanted to take a moment to update you on my recent work both in Washington, D.C and here at home in the 9th District. 
Remembering Councilmember Amina Ahmed
Earlier this month, our community was shocked by the tragic news of SeaTac City Councilmember Amina Ahmed’s death. I join our community in mourning the sudden passing of Councilmember Ahmed. She was an incredible advocate for immigrants and refugees and worked hard to make our community better for everyone. My thoughts and prayers are with her family during this difficult time. 
￼  
Celebrating Veterans’ Service to Our Country 
U.S. Army Veteran 1st Lieutenant Frances Harman was recently inducted to the VA Puget Sound's Wall of Heroes, the first woman to receive this honor. My office had the honor of joining in celebrating this momentous occasion. Lt. Harman’s legacy of service in the Nurse Corps will continue to be an inspiration to our entire community and generations to come! 
￼  
My office attended the VA Puget Sound Wall of Heroes Induction to honor 1st Lt. Frances Harman 
After immigrating to America in 1949, Brendan Moriarty served in the US Air Force. Over Veterans Day weekend, my office had the incredible honor of participating in Mr. Moriarty's “We Honor Veterans” Pinning Ceremony. This ceremony is an opportunity for veterans to be publicly acknowledged for their sacrifices and their willingness to serve our country. Thank you to Mr. Moriarty for sharing your story. Your service is an exemplary model of American values and ideals. 
￼  
Brendan Moriarty’s “We Honor Veterans” Pinning Ceremony 
Congressman Smith in Our Community 
I had the deep honor of joining the Islamic Center of the Eastside Mosque before their Friday prayer. I am proud to work with CAIR-Washington State and our local Muslim community to defend American Muslims’ civil liberties and ensure everyone has the freedom to practice their religion. 
 ￼ 
Adam speaks with members of the Islamic Center of the Eastside Mosque 
It was a privilege to present Diane Narasaki with a speech submitted to the Congressional Record recognizing her legacy. As she retires from Asian Counseling and Referral Service (ACRS), I join in celebrating Diane's commitment to helping others and her incredible service to our community. 
 ￼ 
Adam presents Diane Narasaki with a speech submitted to the Congressional Record  
Legislative Update 
Boosting Therapy and Treatment for Veterans 
I have joined Representative Chris Smith (R-NJ) in the introduction of the Outdoor Recreation Therapy for Veterans Act to help expand opportunities for veterans to access the outdoors for medical care and therapy. 
Access to the outdoors is proven to have a positive impact on mental health and physical wellbeing. For our veterans, the healing effects of nature can be especially powerful. In Washington state, we know the incredible benefits that come from spending time in nature, and we owe it to our servicemen and women to open the door to all avenues of recovery when they return home. I look forward to working with Rep. Chris Smith in building support for this bipartisan legislation to help connect our nation’s veterans with the great outdoors. By bringing together stakeholders from the VA and Land Management, we are building a foundation that will ensure that our veterans and their families can experience the restorative power of the public lands their service to our country has protected. 
A 2013 report by the Sierra Club said that of a sample study of veterans who took part in month-long group wilderness recreation programs, participants exhibited “significant improvements in psychological well-being, social functioning, and life outlook.” The Outdoor Recreation Therapy for Veterans Act, would direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish, within 180 days of enactment, an inter-agency task force to be co-chaired by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of the Interior and including the Secretary of HHS, Secretary of Agriculture, Secretary of Defense as members. The task force would seek to increase the availability of federal lands for use for medical therapy for veterans. 
The task force would also help increase coordination between the Department of Veterans Affairs and public land agencies on using public lands for therapy and medical treatment. 
Global Fragility and Violence Reduction Act Passes House 
On November 28th, the House passed my bipartisan bill, the Global Fragility and Violence Reduction Act. This legislation would improve U.S. engagement in fragile and unstable countries to reduce violence and address the conditions that create safe havens for terrorists, criminal networks, and war lords. Instability across the world continues to lead to the displacement of millions of people. In response to the unprecedented refugee crisis caused by the rise in conflict, famine and disease, the U.S. must be a leader in addressing the root causes of violence and fragility. The Global Fragility and Violence Reduction Act is a significant step in bringing together defense, diplomatic, and development stakeholders to better tackle these complex challenges. 
Learn more about the bill here. 
Fighting Climate Change 
The recently released Fourth National Climate Assessment and the Intergovernmental Panel On Climate Change (IPCC) Report have both laid out the devastating effects of our changing climate on the environment, our health and the economy. The United States should be a global leader in the fight against climate change. Trump continues to put the U.S. on the sidelines instead of working with international partners to address this growing crisis. Climate change is a danger to the health and future of the American people, and we are already seeing its detrimental impact on Washington state. The new Democratic House majority will act on climate. 
I’ve joined in sponsoring a resolution that recognizes and reaffirms the IPCC report findings, and together with my colleagues I have also sent a letter to President Trump calling for him to reverse his administration’s attacks on the environment and take climate change seriously. 
Charting a New Course on Nuclear Policy 
Congress must conduct vigorous oversight of the Trump Administration and the Department of Defense. This oversight needs to include taking substantial steps to reduce America’s overreliance on nuclear weapons and greater transparency in national security matters. You can read more about the importance of this oversight in Politico here. 
￼Fixing Our Broken Immigration Detention System 
Our immigration detention system is unacceptable. For years, we've seen this first-hand at the Northwest Detention Center (NWDC). With the tragic death of Mergansana Amar, a Russian asylum seeker detained in the custody of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at the NWDC, I've demanded an investigation into his death and conditions at NWDC with Senator Patty Murray, Senator Maria Cantwell, and Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal. 
This week, the Department of Homeland Security Office of the Inspector General opened an independent investigation into Mr. Amar’s death. This is critical to better understanding why this tragedy took place and prevent future similar incidents. 
I'll continue working to reform our immigration detention system. A Democratic majority will conduct oversight and bring desperately needed fairness and integrity to our broken system. 
Honoring Jimi Hendrix 
My bill designating the post office at 4301 NE 4th Street in Renton as the James Marshall “Jimi” Hendrix Post Office passed the Senate by Unanimous Consent following its previous passage in the House of Representatives. The legislation was supported by both Senators Patty Murray and Maria Cantwell, as well as each member of the Washington State Delegation in the House. 
I am honored to join in paying tribute to rock and roll icon and Seattle native Jimi Hendrix with the renaming of the Renton Highlands Post Office in honor of Jimi Hendrix. This designation will further celebrate Hendrix’s deep connection to the Puget Sound region and help ensure that his creative legacy will be remembered by our community and inspire future generations. 
Both the Urban League of Metropolitan Seattle and the Urban League of Metropolitan Seattle joined in support of the renaming. 
“Jimi Hendrix is one of the most influential American artists of all time. This Seattle native son, is truly one of the most celebrated musicians of the 20th century. In honor of his memory and service to our country, it is truly fitting that we move forward in naming the United States Postal Service located at 4301 Northeast 4th Street in Renton, Washington, as the James Marshall ‘Jimi’ Hendrix Post Office Building. The Urban League of Metropolitan Seattle strongly supports this effort and applauds Congress for reminding those that patron this facility that his legacy lives on and his memory is etched in the fabric of our country and community,” said Michelle Merriweather, the President and CEO of the Urban League of Metropolitan Seattle. 
“The Northwest African American Museum fully supports the renaming of a local post office to bear the name of Seattle's most recognizable native son, Jimi Hendrix.  His legendary artistic genius chartered new territory within world music.  While his reach was international in scope, his roots trace back to Seattle and we are proud to richly celebrate his legacy as part of his hometown community. This bill, led by U.S. Congressman Adam Smith, will provide a fitting tribute to a Seattle-born global icon whose humility, generosity, musical giftedness, and timeless brilliance will inspire for generations to come,” said LaNesha DeBardelaben, the Director of Northwest African American Museum. 
  
I am incredibly thankful for the opportunity to serve our community. My family and I send our best wishes to you for a happy and healthy 2019. 
Best, 
Adam

Subject: Sea lion bill becomes law!
Message:
District Update | December 20, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼


My bipartisan bill to control sea lions, save salmon on the Columbia River becomes law
￼
This bipartisan legislation authorizes 
states and tribal members to lethally 
remove sea lions that are predating on
endangered salmon, steelhead and other
native fish species.
￼
California sea lions have killed the most 
spring Chinook salmon and steelhead
this year than any year since 
2011. Fish and wildlife experts estimate
that at the current rate, the Willamette
Winter Steelhead run faces a 90% chance
of extinction if nothing changes 
(fortunately, we now have a powerful tool
to prevent extinction!).

The bipartisan bill I authored with Rep. Kurt Schrader (D-OR) giving tribal members and government fish managers the authority to lethally remove sea lions that are decimating endangered salmon and steelhead runs was signed into law yesterday.

After 12 years of hard work by so many on this legislation, seeing it finally become law today represents a momentous step in the effort to protect our endangered salmon and steelhead runs. Today, we have reason to be optimistic that our fight to prevent the extinction of entire Northwest salmon runs, and the species that depend on them, can succeed. 

￼
I learned a lot by joining members of the 
Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish 
Commission as they operated a sea lion 
hazing boat at the Bonneville Dam 
this spring.
￼
A sea lion tears into a sturgeon near the
dam. Local fishing guides told me 
70-100% of the fish they land show 
visible signs of a struggle with a sea lion.

Subject: Update from Rep. Collins: Victory on prison reform & lower drug pricing
Message:
￼ 



December 20, 2018 

Dear Friends,
I hope you and your loved ones are enjoying this season of celebration. The end of the year is a great time to reflect on what we've accomplished and of the work the new year and new Congress will bring us. Here's an update on some issues that Northeast Georgians talk to me about regularly.  
￼
￼
  
Making Communities Safer through Prison Reform
On November 14, I stood with President Donald Trump as he endorsed the First Step Act. I introduced this bill in the House last May, and it passed in our chamber by a vote of 360-59. This week, the Senate passed an updated version of the bill, and I then voted with my colleagues in the House to send the bill straight to the president's desk. 
Working with the White House to increase public safety by lowering recidivism has been an incredible opportunity. The First Step Act represents a rare chance to fulfill the demands of justice today while reducing future burdens on the criminal justice system. By putting in place initiatives focused on rehabilitating individual men and women, we are promoting public safety and basic fairness. 
With President Trump's signature, this bill will reunite families, provide meaningful job skills, make our streets safer, and promote the wellbeing of communities. I'm proud to have worked with our president to apply reforms that have been implemented in Georgia at the federal level. This success shows us the president's ability to find common agreement for the common good on key issues. 
￼
￼

Fighting Overreach in a New Role

With Democrats in control of the House beginning in January, it's the responsibility of Republicans to ensure that investigations don't go rogue at a time when we have real governing to do. I'm prepared to help move the conservative agenda forward in the face of opposition across the aisle, and House Republicans recently elected me to lead fellow Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee as Ranking Member. 
Democrats aren't hiding their plans to oppose President Trump through the Judiciary Committee, but America remains a nation of ideas, principles, and laws. Right now, it seems like some Members of Congress want to weaponize taxpayer resources against a president instead of focusing on building the economy and creating more jobs. Conservatives, though, are here to ensure that liberals don't use their majority in the House to chase political vendettas at deep cost—and no benefit—to hardworking Americans. 
I also plan to continue fighting for our Second Amendment rights and to work to strengthen our immigration system in a way that protects America's sovereignty and upholds the rule of law, as these are key issues that fall under the scope of the Judiciary Committee. 
Moving to Lower Prescription Drug Costs
Earlier this year, I introduced the Phair Pricing Act to lower the cost of prescription medications for patients in the Medicare Part D program. Recently, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) released a proposed rule to lower prescription drug costs and increase transparency surrounding Medicare Parts C and D. I'm excited to report that this proposal includes the bulk of the Phair Pricing Act. 
The Phair Pricing Act is necessary because prescription drug middlemen too often use abusive reimbursement schemes to inflate patient prices and unfairly cripple local health care providers. I’ve seen how much this ultimately leaves communities with higher costs and less access to quality care. 
President Trump’s administration is taking a concrete step to ensure that patients at the counter feel the savings that middlemen claim to negotiate on their behalves but have often kept in their own coffers. I look forward to continuing to work with the administration on this front. 
Representing the priorities of Georgia's 9th District remains a humbling responsibility. If you'd like to keep up with the latest news about the policy improvements I support and why they matter to Northeast Georgia, I invite you to sign up for my regular newsletters. You can also follow me on Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube. 
  
Yours in service, 
 ￼ 
Doug Collins 
Member of Congress 
  
 ￼

Subject: Would You Support a Government Shutdown Over Border Wall Funding? [E-Survey]
Message:
Open in its own browser window   Open a plain text version

￼
 
HOME
ABOUT
CONTACT
MEDIA
SERVICES
 
Congress has until Friday to pass spending legislation and avoid a partial government shutdown, but there have been disagreements over certain aspects of the budget, notably funding for a border wall. President Trump has threatened to shut the government down until the border wall is fully funded. Democrat leaders in Congress refuse to support a measure that provides border wall funding, causing a stalemate. 

Would you support a partial federal government shutdown over border wall funding?


A border wall is critically important to our security and so I would support a partial government shutdown to get funding for it. 

A border wall is important but not enough to shut down portions of the federal government. 

I oppose shutting down the federal government for any reason - it's just irresponsible. 

I oppose a border wall and efforts to fund it completely.

Dear  ,   Thank you for signing up to receive my email newsletter. These newsletters will cover a variety of topics, including events happening in northeast Indiana, legislation being considered in Congress, and my perspective on current issues. My hope is to keep you updated and informed on how issues in Washington may impact our region. I welcome your feedback.  
Thanks for reading, ￼  Jim Banks Member of Congress Indiana's Third District 
	•	
Discussing Maj. Mathew Golsteyn on Fox News
￼ 
On Monday, I appeared on Fox News to discuss a former Green Beret who is charged with killing a suspected Taliban bombmaker in 2010. To watch my interview, click here or on the image above.
 

Update on Border Wall Debate
I pledged to my constituents that I would fight for increased border security and wall funding. I can’t support a funding bill that doesn’t take meaningful steps to fulfill these commitments. Now is the time for Republicans to fight for promises we made.
Fighting to Protect the Sanctity of Life
￼ 
I joined 74 of my House colleagues in a letter encouraging U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to end federally funded fetal tissue research. All life is sacred and taxpayer dollars should never be used to exploit the unborn for research.
Defending Democracy in Bangladesh 
￼ 
I appreciate the Hudson Institute allowing me to speak about democracy in Bangladesh and my resolution that expresses concern about the threat posed by radical groups operating in Bangladesh.To watch my remarks, click here or on the image above.
Highlights from the Hill
￼
 
 
 
National Guard Industry Day
It was an honor to speak at the National Guard Association’s Industry Day today at the National Guard Memorial. Thank you to our Guard members and industry partners for your commitment to our national defense. 
￼
 
 
 
Bangladesh Ambassador to the U.S. Ziauddin
I enjoyed meeting with Bangladesh Ambassador to the United States Mohammad Ziauddin. I strongly support Bangladesh’s efforts to combat radical Islamist groups and affirm the rights of religious minorities. 
￼
 
 
 Iranian Material Display
I toured the Iranian Material Display this week with Congressman Rick Larsen (D-WA). The evidence is literally on the table and clearly demonstrates Iran’s destabilization efforts. The IRGC’s proliferation fingerprints are in Yemen, Afghanistan and Bahrain. 
￼
 
 
Trine University Men's Wrestling Team
It was great to host Trine University's men’s wrestling team for a Capitol tour on Tuesday. Go Thunder!

Subject: Rep. Raskin's Year In Review
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT
ISSUES
NEWS
SERVING YOU
 ￼￼￼￼￼
Dear Friend,   We have made it through 2018, a year I perceived that – when many of our cherished values were tested – our people and government proved supple and resilient.   Despite the odds, we saw some notable legislative successes and a tremendous number of small victories for our constituents by our District office. Thanks for all your remarkable letters, emails, and phone calls in 2018. I greatly appreciate your feedback and ideas, and hope you will continue connecting with my office in my next Term in office. Meantime, check out this quick recap of some of what we have accomplished this year in Congress.    Legislative Successes   When the President proposed a 20 percent cut in funding for the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in his FY 2018 Budget Request, a bipartisan group of lawmakers – myself included – came together to urge the Appropriations Committees to not only preserve NIH’s funding but increase it. We turned a proposed cut of $5.7 billion to NIH into a $3 billion increase, so that researchers at the NIH can continue working to fight killer diseases like Alzheimer’s, breast cancer, colon cancer, multiple sclerosis and cystic fibrosis. We were able to replicate that bipartisan success for this Fiscal Year as well.   As a cancer survivor and a member of the bipartisan Cancer Survivors Caucus, I was pleased to work with my Republican colleague Rep. Pete Sessions to secure report language in a recent appropriations bill that will encourage the National Cancer Institute (NCI), which is within NIH, to improve patient access to clinical trials. For many cancer patients, ancillary costs associated with participation in clinical trials, such as long-distance travel and lodging expenses, are a significant obstacle to participation.  Not only does this prevent patients from obtaining potentially life-saving clinical trials, a lack of diversity in the patient pool in a study can undermine the safety, efficacy and value of new drugs. We should ensure that every cancer patient, regardless of his or her economic situation, is able to participate in clinical trials of his or her choosing.   Earlier this year, I worked closely with two of my Oversight Committee colleagues - Republican Congressman Trey Gowdy and Democratic Congresswoman Eleanor Holmes Norton - to fight for an increase in pay for people serving on federal juries, from $40 to $50 per day. This modest raise would be the first increase to federal juror pay in 28 years, something significant especially for working people who are self-employed.    Recently, President Trump signed into law the Federal Aviation Administration Reauthorization Act of 2018 (FAA Reauthorization Act), which included several airplane noise mitigation provisions that I championed. For example, I coauthored an amendment included in the final bill that requires the FAA to conclude its evaluation of enhanced, alternative airplane noise measurement metrics within the next year, so that progress can be made toward implementing a new and more accurate airplane noise metric that reflects the reality of the level of airplane noise experienced by Montgomery County residents. The bill also contained several other noise mitigation measures advanced by our effective and vigilant community organizations like the Montgomery County Quiet Skies Coalition.   The opioid crisis is taking a heavy toll on our people and requires immediate solutions.  Everyone – Congress, the President,  state and local governments, and our people – must continue to work together to turn the tide. Earlier this year the House considered a bill aimed at curbing the illegal importation and trafficking of synthetic drugs, but some researchers and scientists studying the science and treatment of addiction at the NIH and the National Institute on Drug Addiction (NIDA) had expressed concern that important research could be abruptly halted mid-study until they could clear new and bureaucratic licensing hurdles. Working with NIH and NIDA, my Republican colleague Congressman Morgan Griffith and I offered a successful amendment on the House Floor to ensure that this critical research can continue. Another bipartisan measure that I cosponsored, the INTERDICT Act, recently became law. The bill will help stop the flow of the illicit opioid fentanyl across the U.S. border. CDC data shows that nearly half of opioid overdose deaths in 2016 were linked to synthetic opioids like fentanyl.    Additionally, I teamed up with a Virginia Republican Colleague in the House to introduce and work for passage of legislation to create a nationwide public alert system for missing and endangered adults, similar to the Amber Alert. The Ashanti Alert Act is named after Ashanti Billie, a 19-year-old who grew up in Prince George’s County and was kidnapped and murdered last fall. Although there was evidence that Billie had been kidnapped, no system like an AMBER Alert or Silver Alert for adults over 60 years old existed to notify the public about missing and endangered adults. The Ashanti Alert, like other alert systems, will establish an alert network to help local and regional law enforcement efforts to search for missing adults between the ages of 18-65.    District Office Update   As the Representative for Maryland's 8th District, nothing is more important to me than helping you navigate the twists and turns of federal agencies to receive all the right government benefits and services that are available to you. In the 115th Congress, my hard-working District Office staff resolved more than 3,438 constituent cases and saved or returned more than $1,460,000.00 to constituents.    My District Office, located in Rockville, is open Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. We have also launched mobile office hours across the 8th District, including in Thurmont, Westminster, and Silver Spring. Click here to see times and locations. No appointment is necessary for mobile office hours, but you are encouraged to contact my District Office at 301-354-1000 ahead of your visit to ensure you bring along proper documentation that may expedite service requests.    I was delighted to speak with many of you at events that we hosted around the 8th District this year: the Town Hall Meeting on Medicare and Social Security; first annual ConsumerFest;  Coffee or Cafecito with Your Congressman; second annual Federal Employee Health Benefits Forum; Teach-In Town Hall Meeting; the Election Security Forum; Vietnam War Commemoration Pinning Ceremony; and many of the other terrific community events taking place in our district.    Committee Work   As the Vice Ranking Member of the House Judiciary Committee, I’ve spent much of this year working to defeat efforts to wipe out the 50 states’ concealed carry laws that I believe would allow millions of people to carry loaded concealed weapons nationwide; to work for an end to family separation in the immigration process; and to defend civil rights, civil liberties, public justice and Constitutional values.   As a member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, I am defending federal employees against baseless partisan attacks, constant threats of salary and benefit cuts, and scandalous political interference with their work. In September, I led more than 158 House Democrats in urging congressional leadership to oppose President Trump’s effort to rescind a modest 1.9 percent planned pay increase for federal workers. Learn more about that effort by clicking here. The under-funding of important government agencies and continuing efforts to decimate the federal workforce are undermining essential public missions. That’s why I’ve worked to defeat drastic budget cuts and defend the full funding of crucial environmental, water, public health, Chesapeake Bay, and medical and scientific research programs (read more here).    Additionally, I serve on the Committee on House Administration, which oversees the Election Assistance Commission (EAC), the only federal agency charged with making elections more secure, accessible, accurate, and transparent. The EAC is headquartered in the 8th Congressional District, and earlier this year I worked with my colleagues on the Committee to secure $380 million in funding in the omnibus spending deal to help states secure their election systems and replace their most vulnerable voting machines (read more on that here). I also introduced H.R. 6435, the Election Vendor Security Act, after the Federal Bureau of Investigation informed Maryland officials that a Russian oligarch had invested in one of the state’s voting software vendors in 2015 without the state’s knowledge. To learn more about H.R. 6435 click here.   Please note: my committee assignments will likely remain the same in the 116th Congress.     Looking Ahead to 2019   Last month, I was proudly elected to serve as Caucus Leadership Representative for the House Democratic Caucus in the 116th Congress. The Caucus Leadership Representative is the member of the House leadership who represents the five most junior classes of the Democratic Caucus.  I am gratified to have won the support of my 140+ fellow junior colleagues, including the 65 Members of the extraordinary Class of 2018, in this quest. I will be a faithful servant for the policy values, interests and ideas of Junior Members and, as a Member who proudly represents Maryland’s 8th District, I will be working to keep us focused on advancing our positive agenda—quality health care for all, prescription drug price reform, dramatic reduction of greenhouse gas emissions to address climate change, investment in infrastructure, gun violence reduction, immigration reform, and more —even as we defend the Constitution and Bill of Rights against attack.    That’s all for now. Stay tuned and stay close!      All Best,   ￼

Subject: “Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act”
Message:
eNewsletter | Facebook | Twitter | Mac's Blog | YouTube | Video Mailbox 
￼
Dear Friend,
The U.S. House of Representatives passed H.R. 88, the “Retirement, Savings, and Other Tax Relief Act.”
It is important that we continue to work on legislation that brings relief to hardworking Americans.  Last year, we took a step in reforming our tax code by passing tax reform.  Earlier this year, we passed tax reform 2.0.  Now we are taking a third step to continue to help our economy thrive.  With our progress on tax reform we have seen a lot of growth in our economy, Americans keeping more of the money they earn, and jobs being created.
Some of the highlights of the Amendment include:
	•	Includes special tax relief benefits for individuals and businesses affected by recent natural disasters;
	•	Helps businesses provide retirement plans for their workers and helps families to start saving earlier;
	•	Makes key technical corrections to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act;
	•	Further delays several Obamacare taxes, including the medical device tax and health insurer tax;
	•	Makes the railroad track maintenance credit permanent; and
	•	Updates the IRS and makes taxpayer service the focus of the agency.

I invite you to learn more about this issue and others by visiting my website here. Have a question you would like answered? Please contact me by phone, letter, e-mail, on Facebook, or on Twitter.

As always, I appreciate hearing from you.

Sincerely,
￼

Subject: Have You Herd? 2018 Farm Bill SIGNED INTO LAW
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Brooks
￼
 
RESOURCES
ISSUES
LEGISLATION
CONTACT
 
￼ 
￼ 
 
 
￼ 
Dear Friend, 
Today, the President signed the 2018 Farm Bill into law. I am proud this law strongly supports Hoosier farmers by providing them the relief and resources they deserve as they work hard to produce our food supply and ensure that it is safe, abundant and affordable.
97% of farms in our state are family owned and Indiana’s agriculture economy supports more than 107,000 Hoosier jobs. There are 14.7 million acres of farmland cultivated by Indiana’s nearly 57,000 farming operations. Unfortunately, due to weather and shifts in commodity markets, the agriculture economy nationwide, including in Indiana, has trended downwards over the past several years.
Every five years, Congress must pass the federal government’s primary tool for agriculture and food policy – the Farm Bill – in order to support our farmers and ensure critical agricultural and food programs are updated and reauthorized. 
I want to thank the many farmers from the Fifth District who have shared with me the importance of crop insurance, conservation programs, strong trade deals, and ensuring rural communities have the support they need. I am proud the 2018 Farm Bill has been signed into law because it champions the needs of rural America and provides certainty to Hoosier families and farmers.
The 2018 Farm Bill: 
	•	renews and protects crop insurance, a critically important safety net for Hoosier farmers;
	•	supports and enables significant investment in emerging conservation practices;
	•	reauthorizes crucial commodity programs including corn, soybean and other top commodities produced in Indiana;
	•	repeals the harmful and burdensome Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule, providing regulatory certainty and relief;
	•	addresses the predatory trading practices of foreign countries, including retaliatory tariffs leveled by foreign governments like China, and strengthens promotion of U.S. agricultural exports through the Market Access Program (MAP);
	•	provides funding for animal disease prevention and management efforts, including the stockpiling of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) vaccine;
	•	helps rural communities to combat the opioid crisis;
	•	improves the efficiency and execution of federal efforts to expand broadband connectivity;
	•	is part of a comprehensive response to natural disasters, including provisions to support communities still recovering from the devastating impacts of the recent hurricanes and wildfires; and
	•	lays the groundwork for improved Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Policy (SNAP) policy by focusing on improving program integrity;
During this holiday season, I’d like to send a special thank you to every Hoosier farmer who works to feed and fuel Americans across the country. Without their tireless efforts, we would not have the reliable and safe food supply so many of us take for granted. So as you gather for your holiday meal, give thanks to the farmers who provide the food we are blessed to have. 
Again, thank you to all who contacted my office or met with me or my staff about this critical bill – now law – as we worked to get it passed through the House of Representatives and Senate. 
As always, feel free to be in touch with any questions or comments you may have.  
Sincerely, ￼  Congresswoman Susan W. Brooks

Subject: 2018 Farm Bill — including provisions to legalize hemp — becomes law
Message:
￼
Dear friend,
 It's official - the 2018 Farm Bill, which included key provisions to legalize hemp, was signed into law today. This comprehensive bipartisan legislation ends the outdated ban on hemp production and allows Virginia farmers to finally grow and sell the plant, creating new business opportunities and jobs in our Commonwealth. 
Read more about the bill here >>
The 2018 Farm Bill also included significant investments to expand Chesapeake Bay clean-up efforts, protect Virginia commodities like dairy and cotton, and maintain funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) that Virginia families depend on for food security.
I'm proud we came together and delivered these big wins for Virginia families, farmers, and businesses.
Sincerely,   
￼ 
 
Visit my website: kaine.senate.gov

Subject: Great news for farmers!
Message:
District Update | December 20, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
2018 Farm Bill: ✅
￼

Today, President Trump signed the farm bill into law. The farm bill is one of the single most important pieces of legislation to ensure farmers in the 13th District can continue their family business, support a major component of our state’s economy, and help feed the world. I’ve been honored to serve on the House Agriculture Committee since I came to Congress and I’m proud to say I’ve been able to deliver two long-term farm bills, one in 2014 and now 2018, to provide certainty and help farmers in my district succeed.  Getting a farm bill across the finish line this year for our farmers was always my goal. This bill maintains programs critical for Central Illinois farmers, strengthens agricultural research, and improves protections for organic products.  
 
￼
Agriculture is one of the largest indistries in the 13th district and the state of Illinois and ensuring there is strong agriculture policy in place is vital to our economy.  But the farm bill benefits more than just agriculture. It provides continued funding for rural development grants, like one the hospital in Jerseyville received to help fight the opioid epidemic. Research at universities, like the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, also depend on the farm bill for funding. Additionally, the bill includes reforms that ensure rural communities have access to broadband that meets minimum requirements for today’s technological age.  While this is a strong bill for our farmers, 80 percent of the farm bill is SNAP, or more commonly referred to as food stamps. When I visit employers throughout the district, they’re biggest worry right now is filling their workforce. While there is a slight increase in employment and training in the bill, not every able-bodied adult enrolled in SNAP will have access to this job training program like they would have under the House bill. The House-passed bill strengthened work requirements for the program while investing historic amounts in workforce training. Unfortunately, this issue became much more partisan than it needed to be and we were forced to remove it in order to get a bill that would help our farmers in this difficult farm economy. I believe this is a missed opportunity because if our economy is going to continue grow, we’re going to need to fill the jobs that are open.  I will work with anyone to help end the cycle of poverty and provide more workforce opportunities for millions of Americans. I hope Democrats in the House will set the next election aside and work with Republicans to make this a priority next year.   Click here to learn more about the 2018 farm bill.  


Passing the 2018 Farm Bill in Pictures
The 2018 Farm Bill is the product of years of listening to priorities and concerns from both farmers and agriculture stakeholders and working in a bipartisan way to deliver strong agriculture policy.  
 
￼
I hosted several Tool Shed Talks throughout my district last year to hear directly from farmers what their priorities were for the farm bill. I was able to ensure many of their top concerns were addressed in the final bill, including protecting crop insurance.  
 
￼
In the summer of 2017, I was honored to host a House Agriculture Committee Field Hearing at Richland Community College with Chairman Mike Conaway (R-TX), Ranking Member Colin Peterson (D-MN), and other bipartisan members of the committee. Central Illinois farmers and agriculture stakeholders had the opportunity to ask questions and hear from various committee members on the progress we were making on crafting the 2018 farm bill.
 
￼
After the House and Senate passed their own versions of the bill, I was named to the conference committee to help work out the differences between the two bills.   Click here to watch my remarks at Farm Bill Conference Committee Public Meeting.  
 
￼
This week, I signed the conference report for the 2018 farm bill before it was voted on in both the House and Senate.  
 
￼
I was proud to speak on the House floor in support of the final bill this week. It passed both the House and Senate with overwhelming bipartisan support. Click here to watch my remarks.  
 
￼
It was an honor to attend the farm bill signing today at the White House.

Subject: Trump Republicans Keep Trying to Kill Obamacare
Message:
￼ 
￼
  
Dear Professor  ,
As you may know, on December 14, a U.S. District Court judge in Texas ruled that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional.  However, this fight is far from over.  Legal proceedings in the case are ongoing, the ACA is still the law of the land, and Americans are still able to access the health care benefits they rely on.
This ruling is the latest example in a years-long effort by national Republicans to sabotage the ACA by any possible means.  From their unsuccessful attempts to repeal the law here in Congress, to promoting junk insurance plans that do not cover essential health benefits or pre-existing conditions, Republicans continue to try to gut the key consumer protections that the ACA provides.  In fact, the Trump Administration played a major role in this court ruling by instructing the Department of Justice not to defend the ACA in this case.
Should this ruling stand, 20 million Americans and over 100,000 Rhode Islanders who receive health insurance through the ACA would be without health coverage, and a further 133 million Americans and over 450,000 Rhode Islanders with pre-existing conditions could lose access to affordable health care plans.  I joined all of my Democratic colleagues in the Senate to urge the President to defend the law and condemn the court's decision.  I also joined as an original cosponsor of a resolution that would authorize the Senate Legal Counsel to represent the Senate in this case and defend all provisions of the ACA. 
Know that I will continue fighting to preserve the ACA and ensure that all Americans have access to affordable, meaningful health care coverage.
Sincerely,
 
Jack Reed
United States Senator

Subject: Capitol Hill Update from Congressman Castro
Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
Congratulations to the University of Texas at San Antonio and Our Lady of the Lake University for receiving $160,000 in federal grants for the humanities. We know the more we invest in our next generation's education, the bigger promise we have for tomorrow. 
Congratulations also to the Daughters of Charity Services for the $1,170,081 they received from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to expanding access to education . We know education is the surest path to success, and this grant will inevitably help build a stronger Infrastructure of Opportunity for a more prosperous tomorrow.  
Justice for Jakelin 
Like all Americans, I was devastated to hear about the death of seven-year-old Jakelin Caal who died in Border Patrol Custody earlier this month. I spoke to Joy Reid on MSNBC's Rachel Maddow show last Friday to discuss this tragedy and how we can and must do better as a nation.  
￼ 
I led a Hispanic Caucus congressional delegation this week to retrace Jakelin’s journey, and investigate the circumstances of her tragic death. You can watch the full readout of our findings here. 
￼ 
You can watch the press conference we held outside Lordsburg Border Patrol Station here.  
You can also read about in the Washington Post, NBC News, Buzzfeed News, and Dallas Morning News. 
I joined Ranking Member of the House Judiciary Committee Jerrold Nadler, Ranking Member of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security Zoe Lofgren, Rep. Pramila Jayapal, and Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security Lucille Roybal-Allard in urging the Department of Homeland Security Inspector General to open an investigation into Jakelin’s death. 
￼￼￼ 
I also joined colleagues from New Mexico and Texas, Senators Tom Udall and Martin Heinrich, and Congressmen Ben Ray Luján, Michelle Lujan Grisham, and Marc Veasey in a letter to the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Customs and Border Protection demanding an immediate investigation into Jakelin’s death. 
  
￼￼￼ 
New DHS Asylum Policy 
The U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s decision to make migrants wait in Mexico while processing asylum claims is the single biggest assault to date by this Administration on the world’s most vulnerable populations that come to America, legally, and in search of a better life. You can read my full statement here. 
District Updates 
Team Castro joined the 2018 Project QUEST VIP Ceremony graduates and their families in celebrating this great achievement and attended South San Antonio Chamber’s 2nd annual #ThrivingTogether Symposium on economic sustainability, workforce development, and education.
￼ ￼ 
￼ 
Team Castro also joined the Interfaith Welcome Coalition to hear about their work on helping migrants navigate airports and bus stations after being released by ICE, and recently joined Texas HD 123 Diego Bernal for a preview of his 86th Texas Legislative agenda.
￼ ￼
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress 
  
  
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
  
Join Me....

Dear Friend, 
As we turn our calendars, the new year delivers the youngest, most diverse Congress in our nation’s history.  I am honored to once again have the opportunity to represent you in Washington, DC.  In the 116th Congress, we will go big, be bold, and do good to ensure every American has the freedom to dream.
If you will be in the Washington, DC area, I hope you will join me for an open house at my new office as we mark the start of the 116th Congress.  Please RSVP here if you plan to attend.

Sincerely,
