￼￼

Subject: News from the 10th
Message:
News from Congressman Brad Schneider 
￼

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Dear Friends, 
While the year is winding down, much remains on the agenda in Congress, including passing critical funding before current funding lapses on Friday, December 21. This is among the most basic responsibilities of Congress. President Trump last week expressed he was willing to shut down the government over a border wall. This would be extremely irresponsible, putting undue burdens on countless working families right before Christmas, and would likely hurt our economy and the work of our federal agencies. I’ll be actively working this week in the hope that cooler heads will prevail. 
In addition to keeping the government open, Congress needs to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act and has the opportunity to pass major Criminal Justice Reform.  I will keep you posted. Please continue reading for an update on new climate legislation I introduced last week. I’ll also be in Mt. Prospect tomorrow morning (Tuesday) during our Neighborhood Office Hours. Drop by and say hello if you can!
  
FIGHTING FOR AMERICAN LEADERSHIP ON CLIMATE 
Last week, world leaders gathered in Poland for the UN Climate Change Summit (COP24). Due to the Trump Administration's reckless decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement, American leadership at the summit was notably lacking. 
I introduced legislation with my colleague Rep. Don McEachin to highlight this disconnect. Our bill makes clear Congress is concerned about consequences of climate inaction outlined in the National Climate Assessment, and also requires the Secretary of State to regularly publish a public assessment that highlights the consequences of the Trump Administration’s decision to unilaterally withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
Tackling climate change is a global problem, urgently requiring the countries of the world to work together in big, bold ways.  Significantly lowering carbon emissions and other major actions will require American leadership. It’s therefore imperative for the United States to re-engage with the international community on this pressing threat. This issue will be one of my key priorities in the new 116th Congress. 
Learn more about our legislation. 
  
NEIGHBORHOOD OFFICE HOURS – JOIN ME IN MT. PROSPECT 
￼ 
  
This week, I’ll be joining our constituent service representatives at the Mt. Prospect RecPlex (420 Dempster St.) on Tuesday, December 18 from 9:00-11:00am. Stop by to say hello or share what’s on your mind! 
In addition, my staff will be in Libertyville and Glenview this week. If you need assistance with a federal issue, from Medicare and Social Security to Immigration and the VA, please come see us! 
View the full schedule on our website. 
  
NEED ASSISTANCE WITH STUDENT LOANS? 
The Department of Education was recently ordered by a federal court to cancel more than $150 million in student debt to individuals who attended schools that closed while students were enrolled. If you received a notice from the Department of Education or believe you are affected, our office may be able to help. Give us a call at (847) 383-4870 
  
WEEKLY WRAP-UP 
￼ 
  
Thank you to everyone who turned in cards for military servicemembers at our district office as part of our Holiday Cards for Heroes program. We collected nearly 400, which we’ll be distributing with help from USO to Americans serving our country far from home this holiday season.
  
￼ 
  
While we were collecting cards in the district, the American Red Cross was collecting cards on Capitol Hill. I was glad to participate to express my thanks to the men and women in uniform and let them know we are all thinking of them this time of year.
  
￼
￼
I spoke on the House floor to share the priorities of our district from our recent constituent survey. In the coming Congress, we have a new opportunity for progress. We need to listen and prioritize the issues that matter to the communities we represent.
  
￼ 
  
I joined other elected leaders at a press event in Chicago to urge everyone to sign-up for health insurance on heathcare.gov before Open Enrollment ended on Saturday, December 15.
Thanks for reading!         
 Sincerely, ￼  Bradley S. Schneider Member of Congress

Subject: News from Nita: 💵$4.1M Grant for Westchester — Leadership on Reproductive Rights - Securing Social Security Benefits for a Constituent
Message:
￼
ABOUT NITA           CONSTITUENT SERVICES           NEWSROOM           LEGISLATIVE ISSUES           17th DISTRICT           CONTACT ME 
Dear Friend:
Here are some of the ways in which I'm fighting hard to keep Lower Hudson Valley communities safe, healthy, and secure:  
	•	Announcing $4.1 Million Federal Grant to Address Lead Hazards in Westchester Housing  
	•	Introducing Legislation to Maintain U.S. Leadership on Reproductive Rights  
	•	Announcing $30K Federal Grant for Historic Hudson Valley  
	•	Securing Social Security Benefits for a Rockland Constituent
Announcing $4.1 Million Federal Grant to Address Lead Hazards in Westchester Housing  
￼ 
A federal  grant of $4.1 million will go to the County of Westchester to address lead hazards in 240 housing units for low- and very low-income families with children, and to perform healthy homes assessments. 
	•	Every person, regardless of their economic circumstance, deserves to live in a safe and healthy environment.  
	•	With this federal funding, Westchester can improve the quality of life for families with children by tackling dangerous, potentially life-threatening lead hazards and conducting healthy homes assessments in hundreds of local housing units.  
	•	As Ranking Member on the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue working in Congress to secure vital resources for Westchester and the larger Lower Hudson Valley.
Introducing Legislation to Maintain U.S. Leadership on Reproductive Rights 
￼ 
The Reproductive Rights are Human Rights Act-legislation I introduced this week with Reps. Katherine Clark, Eliot Engel, Barbara Lee, and Lois Frankel-would require the U.S. State Department to include reproductive rights in its annual human rights report after the State Department deleted all subsections without warning or justification in 2017.
	•	The U.S. cannot turn its back on the countless women around the world who are deprived of basic reproductive rights.  
	•	I'm proud to support legislation that would restore reproductive rights to the State Department's annual human rights report, maintaining U.S. leadership on behalf of the world's women across administrations.  
	•	Reproductive health care is a fundamental right for women-one I will continue to defend in Congress. 
Announcing $30K Federal Grant for Historic Hudson Valley 
￼ 
I'm pleased to announce that the non-profit cultural organization Historic Hudson Valley (HHV) in Sleepy Hollow has been awarded a $30,000 National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) grant to share the history of slavery in the north through digital storytelling.
	•	The legacy of slavery is still felt today, and accurately teaching its history is critically important to improving understanding of issues of race and racism in hopes of creating a more civil and equitable society.  
	•	As the highest-ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, I secured nearly $153 million for the NEH in the Fiscal Year 2018 omnibus spending bill, an increase of $3 million over the previous year's funding level, despite President Trump's efforts to end the Endowment. I will continue to defend funding for this important agency.
Securing Social Security Benefits for a Rockland Constituent  
An Airmont resident contacted me regarding his disability benefits from the Social Security Administration (SSA). He started receiving monthly payments but had yet to receive his retroactive payment. I contacted SSA asking the agency to expedite the processing of the check. Soon after, the resident confirmed receiving the $12,253 he was owed. 
Need help navigating the Social Security Administration or another federal agency? My office is here to help. Contact us at the numbers below. 
Staying in Touch  It is an honor to represent the Lower Hudson Valley in the United States Congress. To stay in touch and get the latest updates, please connect with me on Facebook and on Twitter.  If you have questions or need assistance, please contact my office in Westchester County at (914) 428-1707, Rockland County at (845) 639-3485, or Washington, D.C., at (202) 225-6506, and we will do all we can to help.  
    Sincerely,  ￼      Nita M. Lowey     Member of Congress 
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: A Message From Ann
Message:
A message from Congresswoman Ann Wagner 
￼ 

About
Contact
Services
Media Center
Issues


Dear Lindsey, 
St. Louis has been home to the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) for over 70 years, and our city’s wonderful talent has kept America safe again and again. A huge moment that was years in the making, the land transfer for the NGA West campus officially took place last week. I’ve been working with my colleagues in Congress to keep and grow NGA’s new campus in St. Louis and provide funding for its acquisition and construction. This project secures thousands of jobs for our region. St. Louis has tremendous assets, resources, and knowledge, and I’m excited for this opportunity to enhance our contributions to America’s critical national security and intelligence missions. My friends in St. Louis City, NGA, and the Air Force have been working just as hard to realize this groundbreaking property transfer. Thank you to everyone involved in this truly regional effort—I look forward to construction getting underway!
 
￼
￼
￼

Congresswoman Elise Stefanik and I joined The Story on FOX News to discuss our efforts to support GOP women and build a winning suburban agenda. To watch our interview, click here. 
 
Throughout the past year, we have seen immense progress in relations between the United States and our African partners. The Foreign Affairs Committee met this week to hear testimony regarding China’s increasing control over the global cobalt market and the unspeakable acts of violence that terrorist organization Boko Haram is committing to gain international notoriety. I was appalled to learn last February that Boko Haram had abducted 112 schoolgirls from a town in Nigeria. While most were released a month later, one brave girl, 15-year-old Leah Sharibu, remains in captivity because she refused to abandon her Christian faith. The U.S. must continue to fight for her release and stand against these senseless acts of violence.
 
￼
￼

It was a pleasure to have the National Association of Chemical Distributors stop by my office on Capitol Hill last week. Joining them was Kurt Hettinga, President of Superior Solvents and Chemicals located right in Arnold. We discussed the importance of reauthorizing the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS) to keep our communities safe. These standards ensure that Missouri facilities that use, manufacture, store, and handle certain high-risk chemicals are protected and secure. We need to keep these chemicals out of the wrong hands, and the reauthorization reduces the risk of terrorists using chemicals in attacks against our nation.

￼

On Tuesday, Congress overwhelmingly passed legislation to combat the maternal mortality crisis in our nation, as well as renew our efforts to prevent premature births. According to the CDC, 60% of maternal deaths are preventable, and the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act supports state-level research to stop these tragedies from ever taking place. The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act provides crucial funding to continue research and support community initiatives that protect our unborn children. These bills are very near and dear to me, and I’m proud to support our families.
 
Sincerely,
￼  Ann Wagner Member of Congress

As 2018 quickly comes to a close, everyone's attention turns towards 2019 and what the new year can mean for them.  It is a chance for a fresh start; to set new goals, new priorities, and tackle new challenges.  The same is true as we begin the 116th Congress. 

Despite a politically divided Congress, I am confident that all 535 of my colleagues share the most important goal: improving the lives of our constituents.  It is the spirit of collaboration that will allow us to move forward on a number of topics, including the opioid epidemic and infrastructure. 

As we look forward to January, one thing is for certain: I am honored to serve the 15th District and I will work to bring people together to deliver real solutions to the problems facing our country.  And I want to hear from you: what issue is most important to you as the new Congress begins?  Take my survey by clicking here. 

Throughout the 116th Congress, I welcome you to share your thoughts with me by calling my Washington, D.C. office at (202) 225-2015, my Hilliard office at (614) 771-4968, my Lancaster office at (740) 654-2654, or my Wilmington office at (937) 283-7049.

Subject: Washington Watch: Farm Bill Approved By Congress
Message:
News from Representative Woodall
￼

FARM BILL APPROVED BY CONGRESS; WILL SOON BECOME LAW  
After months of negotiations, Congress has sent the 2018 Farm Bill to President Trump’s desk for his signature; the last step needed to provide stability and predictability to Georgia’s number one industry, agriculture, for the next five years. The measure garnered overwhelming bipartisan support...READ MORE. 
HOUSE SUPPORTS DEMOCRACY AND HUMANITARIAN AID AROUND THE WORLD 
As the leader of the free world, the United States of America has both a self-interest and a moral obligation to promote universal values abroad, especially the values of a free and open press and religious freedom. And last week, I had the opportunity to vote for a number of bills that move the needle further in the direction of freedom...READ MORE. 
CONGRESS PASSES SEXUAL HARRASSMENT REFORM MEASURE  
As 2018 comes to a close, we’re starting to see year-end recaps and reviews in magazines and on television that highlight the trends, movements, and big events that will forever denote 2018 in the history books...READ MORE. 
CONSTITUENT SPOTLIGHT: THE SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM 
With the Farm Bill’s passage last week, I heard from many constituents who were concerned about nearly every portion of the massive bill, from prioritizing conservation to protecting local markets to preventing animal cruelty. The most popular concern came from folks who cared about the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), popularly known as food stamps...READ MORE. 
SHARING HOLIDAY CELEBRATIONS, BUILDING UNITY 
Hanukkah came to a close one week ago, but in case you missed this wonderful story from right here at home, I wanted to share it with you – and encourage you to take part in this great community celebration next year!...READ MORE. 
REMEMBERING OUR REMARKABLE NON-PROFITS THIS HOLIDAY SEASON 
Generosity is embedded into who we are in the Seventh District. There’s no doubt about that. At the individual level, community level, throughout remarkable non-profit organizations and beyond, we take care of each other. While we have an abundance of generosity, the reality is there is also a great deal of need that the holidays can accentuate...READ MORE. 
THE WEEK AHEAD 
This week, as the House is expected to finish its work for the 115th Congress, I hope that we will be acting on an end of the year funding package to allow those federal agencies currently operating under a Continuing Resolution to receive the rest of their FY19 money...READ MORE.   
Sincerely,  ￼  Rob Woodall  Member of Congress

Subject: Bergman Announces FEMA Grant for Grand Traverse Shelters
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Dec 17, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158


Bergman Announces FEMA Grant for Grand Traverse Shelters

Traverse City - Today, Congressman Jack Bergman announced a $1.1 Million FEMA grant for three tornado safe rooms in Grand Traverse County.

This grant will cover 75% of construction costs at Interlochen State Park, Ludington State Park, and Traverse City State Park, and provide shelter for nearly 850 visitors in the case of a severe weather event. These safe rooms will double as bathroom/showers at each location.

Subject: Wicker Glad to See Farm Bill Pass Final Hurdle
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
December 17, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | About Roger | How Can I Help You? | Newsroom | Issues | Mississippi | Visiting DC | Contact
Wicker Glad to See Farm Bill Pass Final Hurdle
Positive Senate Outcome Followed Months of Negotiations
The Senate has passed the “Agriculture Improvement Act,” sending to President Trump a bill that empowers our farmers to continue feeding and clothing our nation and the world.  This comprehensive legislation, commonly known as the Farm Bill, reauthorizes $867 billion over the next five years to support critical programs for our farmers, low-income Americans, and rural communities. 
Although the bill’s negotiations were tough, the outcome was the right one for Mississippi farmers.  It was imperative for lawmakers to pass this bill before the end of the year and the start of a new Congress.  In the end, the bill earned overwhelming support in the Senate and the House of Representatives.
U.S. Farmers & Food Security
The value of the American farmer cannot be overstated.  According to the American Farm Bureau Federation, one farm can feed 165 people every year.  Multiply this number by more than two million – the number of farms in America – and our farmers’ impact on the well-being of humanity becomes clear.  Our state alone has more than 36,000 farms contributing to the production of the healthy food and fiber that sustain our families and our communities.  
With so many lives relying on our agricultural growers and producers, Congress has a responsibility to enact policies encouraging their success.  This Farm Bill does that by recognizing the risks our farmers face, such as hazardous weather and the volatility of global markets, both of which we have seen this year.  It mitigates those challenges by strengthening the programs that give our farmers peace of mind when times get tough.  This certainty is as important to the daily operations of a farm as it is to the overall food security of our nation.  The Farm Bill also champions the long-term safety and vitality of our agricultural resources through responsible conservation practices.
Wins for Rural Broadband, Timber Innovation
Tying together the goals of predictability and stewardship is a provision I authored to promote rural broadband development.  Included in the Farm Bill was my “Precision Agriculture Connectivity Act,” which aims to equip our farmers and ranchers with the connectivity they need.  This technology can enable our farmers to be more competitive by producing more crops on less land for fewer dollars. 
I was also pleased to see provisions from the “Timber Innovation Act” in the final version of the bill.  These provisions are designed to advance cutting-edge research on timber and timber products.  Our local universities are already finding new ways to use local timber – one of Mississippi’s most abundant natural resources – and expand market opportunities for our state’s foresters.
This multiyear reauthorization of the Farm Bill is a win for America’s heartland, giving the Department of Agriculture and the President the resources necessary to safeguard our farmers’ livelihoods amid often extreme and difficult circumstances.

Subject: Rep. Paul Gosar: The GOP's last chance to keep our border wall promise
Message:
￼ 
  


 
￼

Rep. Paul Gosar: The GOP's last chance to keep our border wall promise
 
Published by: Washington Examiner 
By: Representative Paul Gosar, D.D.S.
 Thousands of economic migrants are currently sitting on the U.S. border after traveling as a political group together through Mexico. The “caravan” is just the most visible example of Hondurans, Guatemalans, and El Salvadorans trying in record numbers to illegally enter the U.S., waving Honduran and Guatemalan flags, while they claim a “right” to invade our country. Our failure to secure our southern border has very real, concerning implications for our nation’s security.
To begin, we know MS-13 gang members are there. Regardless of whether this particular caravan of economic migrants contains a terrorist contingent, it still highlights to those who are interested in hurting the U.S. that our laws can be flaunted and that illegal entry into the U.S. is easy. It’s clear this message is spreading: As rumors of possible amnesty spread this past fall, Border Patrol reported a surge in illegal crossings. It’s clear that our border policies are encouraging lawbreaking. From 2009-2016, the number of aliens claiming credible fear skyrocketed from 5,000 to 94,000 in 2016, according to the Department of Homeland Security.
This highlights another important fact: Every illegal immigrant who aspires to become an American is making lawbreaking their first act on U.S. soil. This disqualifies them. This also undermines our Constitution and insults the Americans and immigrants who have waited in line and worked hard to immigrate the right way.  
Sadly, the supposed immigration champions, the Democrats, are exacerbating the problem instead of working with Republicans to solve it. Their solution is open borders — a “borderless hemisphere” as Hillary Clinton put it. Potential House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., calls border security “immoral,” and she advocates for illegal immigrants. But blind acceptance of any and all migrants who show up at the U.S.-Mexican border ignores the very real problems occurring in South and Central American countries and fails to deal with our own.
Instead, we need to work together to address the issues that we face: anywhere between 11 and 22 million illegal immigrants in the U.S. already (more than 3 percent of our population), and a porous border that encourages more lawbreaking instead of encouraging law-abiding immigrants to go through a proper orderly process.
Before the end of the 115th Congress, we must send a bill to President Trump’s desk that finally secures our border with a wall and by ending “catch and release” and chain migration policies that encourage illegal immigration. We must attach this legislation to a must-pass funding bill, to ensure that it gets through both the House and Senate and to President Trump so he can sign it into law.
Republicans have been trying to do this all year, and have been far from intransigent on this issue. Open-border Democrats are putting illegal immigrants’ priorities ahead of law-abiding citizens. Instead of acknowledging that Republicans are putting American priorities first, they are allowing humanitarian crises like caravans and smuggling rings to operate with impunity. Too many in the press, rather than acknowledging the good faith efforts of Republicans and the entrenchment of Democrats, have continued to blame Trump’s rhetoric for the immigration issues we face. This must change.
President Trump has tried to force that change, and I applaud his efforts. He has warned Central American countries that he might withhold humanitarian aid from countries that won’t block the caravan. This refocuses the issue where it belongs: On our foreign policy and the countries who are aiding U.S. lawbreakers and failing to address their own economic problems.
We need first to secure our border, and then we can address the millions of illegal immigrants already here in a realistic way. But while our border problem exacerbates the issue and encourages thousands to migrate illegally, we can’t have that conversation. That’s why Congress must act now to finally secure our southern border, before we gavel out of session and hand the House of Representatives to open-borders Democrats.

Subject: Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 12.17.18
Message:
December 17, 2018
Share this email:
￼
￼
￼

￼
Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 12.17.18
Monday, December 17, 2018 –                                 
Big Stone Wall
C. Bascom Slemp
President Trump recently named Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney as his acting Chief of Staff. Having worked with Mick when he represented South Carolina in the House of Representatives, I think the President has made a good choice.
Earlier in the search process, attention focused on a current colleague of mine and another Freedom Caucus member, Congressman Mark Meadows (R-NC). At a Freedom Caucus meeting, Senator Mike Lee (R-UT) observed that if Meadows was selected, he would be the most conservative White House Chief of Staff since the Coolidge Administration of 1923-29.
This remark drew my interest, for as I noted to Senator Lee, the Chief of Staff’s equivalent under President Calvin Coolidge was an earlier representative of Virginia’s Fighting Ninth, C. Bascom Slemp.
Slemp was born in Turkey Cove in Lee County in 1870. His father was active in politics, and at the age of eleven Slemp served as a page in the House of Delegates. He later attended the Virginia Military Institute and studied law at the University of Virginia, eventually practicing in Big Stone Gap.
In 1907, Slemp’s father, by then representing the Ninth District in Congress, died, and he won the race for the vacant seat. He served several terms in Congress before retiring in 1923. As it happened, that year Calvin Coolidge ascended to the presidency upon the death of Warren Harding, and he needed a private secretary to assist in his dealings with Congress and the 1924 presidential election.
President Coolidge recalled in his autobiography, “I was especially fortunate in securing C. Bascom Slemp as my Secretary, who had . . . a wide acquaintance with public men and the workings of legislative machinery. His advice was most helpful.”
Slemp aided Coolidge as he finished Harding’s term and won a resounding victory to the Presidency in his own right. Slemp resigned in 1925 and returned to practicing law in Big Stone Gap (where the federal building is named after him) and Washington. When he died in 1943, Slemp was buried in the family plot in Turkey Cove.
The Need for Border Security
It is often noted that America has a government of laws, not of men.
The current immigration system seems to be an exception. Illegal immigration to our country occurs frequently without consequence, while aspiring legal immigrants are left to navigate for years through a maze of red tape.
The process for those who want to come here the right way, legally, should be simpler and easier. You shouldn’t have to wait a lifetime to get citizenship if you came here legally in the first place. We want people to share in the American dream. Congress must act, which is why I supported several reform measures this year.
The focus right now, however, is on illegal immigration and border security, and this situation will not get better on its own. According to U.S. Customs and Border Protection, an astounding 3,029 people were apprehended attempting to cross the southern border illegally in a single day, December 3.
Lack of border security also facilitates trafficking in people and illegal substances. For example, methamphetamine use has surged as Mexican cartels move the product across the border, contributing to a surge in nationwide overdose deaths involving meth from 1,887 in 2011 to 6,762 in 2016.
More border security is necessary to deter illegal immigration and to crack down on trafficking.
President Trump wants a “wall” to guard the southern border. I support the President on this issue. Building a “wall,” in some places a physical wall, but in others smart fences and other technology, will help reduce human trafficking and the flow of illegal aliens and illicit drugs that now cross the border with relative ease.
I have previously voted for wall funding, including almost $25 billion twice in separate bills in June. President Trump has asked for $5 billion in “wall” funding to be included in legislation funding the government for the 2019 fiscal year, and I support him in this request.
I have also signed on as an original cosponsor of a bill by Congressman Andy Harris (R-MD) to allow the Treasury to sell bonds raising money for wall construction. If private citizens want their money to support border security, they ought to have that right.
I believe it is important to protect our borders, making it more difficult for illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings and illicit drugs.
I am committed to working with my colleagues and President Trump to get this done.
If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office.  You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405 or my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671. To reach my office via email, please visit my website at www.morgangriffith.house.gov.
###

Subject: Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Message:
News from Representative Davidson
￼

Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you. 
Sincerely, ￼  Warren Davidson Member of Congress 
Opportunity Zones and Ohio 
Congressman Warren Davidson was in Washington, D.C. last week as Congress was in Session.  
On Wednesday, Congressman Davidson applauded President Trump’s executive order creating the White House Opportunity and Revitalization Council. In April, Congressman Davidson submitted a list of census tracts in Ohio to the IRS in which he recommended for designation as Opportunity Zones. You can read the release here.  
On Friday, in Ohio, Congressman Davidson toured the Garst Museum in Greenville. You can read more about his visit to the museum here. Later in the day he spoke with students at Versailles High School. 
While in Greenville, Congressman Davidson stopped by the Early Bird newspaper to share his thoughts on current issues. Read the article here. 
￼ 
￼
Davidson Pens Op-Ed Pushing Reforms to Food-Stamp Policy
In an op-ed for the National Review, Congressman Warren Davidson writes that the farm bill Congress passed last Thursday should have included more reforms to benefit farmers and welfare recipients. He explains that approximately 80 percent of the farm bill will be spent on food stamps, with only 20 percent directed to the farm economy.
Congressman Davidson introduced a bill last year to consolidate more than 90 welfare programs which cost taxpayers almost $1 trillion a year.
Every year Congressman Davidson hosts Farm Forum in Piqua, Ohio. The event, which was started by former Congressman John Boehner, gives those involved in farming the opportunity to hear industry experts share updates in agriculture from across the state as well as nationally.
Click here to read Congressman Davidson’s op-ed. 
 
It’s Time to Reform Food-Stamp Policy 
With no work requirements, the farm bill offers more of the same 
A strong farming industry is vital to America’s economy and national security. With the ongoing tariff battle, there is no question that some federal assistance can help protect America’s farm economy. However, the farm bill passed yesterday by Congress undermines the interests of America’s taxpayers. 
During the Great Depression, farm subsidies were created to keep family farms afloat and ensure a stable national food supply. Today, the farm bill has less to do with helping family farms than with maintaining the status quo and administering a plethora of food-assistance poverty programs as if the economy were still in crisis. 
According to the Congressional Budget Office, total farm-bill spending from 2018 to 2028 is estimated to be $867 billion. Approximately 80 percent of that will be spent on food stamps, with only 20 percent directed to the farm economy... 
  
￼

Subject: Gosar Review: wall funding, land grabs and MORE
Message:
Click here to view this email in your browser 
￼
￼
  
 
For the past two years, I haven’t been afraid of joining the fray and standing up to leadership demanding accountability. I’m here to tell you that this won’t change under Democratic leadership. I plan on doing the same thing in the 116th Congress as I have done since I was first elected to the House, fight for the people of Arizona’s 4th Congressional district. 

￼
Build the Wall
Walls have proven to be a successful tool at decreasing illegal immigration. After a wall was built in 2005 in Yuma, Arizona illegal traffic dropped 90 percent over 15 years. This week, I joined my House Freedom Caucus colleagues in taking a strong stance on the upcoming spending bill. I will not support any end of year spending bill unless it properly funds a wall on our southern border. It’s time for Congress to keep its promise and build the wall to secure our border.


Click here to read more 
￼
Telephone Town Hall
I enjoyed hearing from many of you this week during my Telephone Town Hall. When I’m in Washington I want to make sure the people of Arizona’s 4th Congressional district are able to talk directly to me about their concerns. I’m always encouraged by the number of great ideas and questions that come from these events. It was no surprise that our border wall was one of the leading topics of the night. As I mentioned on the phone call, I will continue to fight to ensure we secure our southern border. I look forward to continuing the conversation whether it’s on the phone, in person or even via email.  Please keep the ideas coming!


Click here to read more 
￼

Unwinding Land Grabs
Environmental stewardship is not stewardship without the input of state and local communities. The BLM’s Environmental Impact Statement and related plan amendments recently released are another step towards unwinding one of the largest land grabs in our nation’s history. Thanks to the strong leadership of President Trump and Secretary Zinke, we are more closely aligning with the vision of our Founding Fathers and preventing further encroachment on private lands by the federal government. Hopefully, the Forest Service will catch up and follow DOI and BLM’s efforts.


Click here to read more 
￼
Reversing WOTUS
Like a villain in Scooby Doo, the past Administration almost got away with an unparalleled expansion of Federal power. The WOTUS land and water-grab rule proposed by the Obama Administration was one of the greatest regulatory threats to the West and rural communities. Fortunately, this legally-dubious effort was unmasked for what it was by the Supreme Court and this Administration. I’m happy to see some sanity restored to Clean Water Act implementation. Thanks to Acting Administrator Wheeler and President Trump for taking the lead and crafting a definition that adheres to the original law, promotes extremely clean and safe waterways, and remains Federalist in its nature.


Read my op-ed in The Hill HERE 
As always, you can follow everything I am working on in Arizona and Washington, D.C. through my website (https://gosar.house.gov) on Twitter @RepGosar, Facebook and through Instagram.

Subject: Schweikert Review December 16th
Message:
District Update |December 16, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼

Week in Review
Wreaths Across America 
￼

This Saturday, I joined the Wreaths Across America ceremony in Scottsdale. This event invites individuals to lay a wreath upon a Veteran's grave site honoring their sacrifice and heroism while protecting these United States. It was a very beautiful ceremony to honor our veterans, may God bless each of them and their families this holiday season. 
Health IT Now
￼ 
Thank you to Health IT Now for selecting me as a recipient of the 2018 Health IT Pioneer Award. I look forward to continuing to advocate for innovation and interoperability in healthcare in the 116th congress!
Social Security Administration Advisory
This week, our office received awareness of telephone impersonation schemes that are exploiting the Social Security Administration's (SSA) reputation and authority. 

The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) has received reports from across the country in relation to these fraudulent phone calls from people who are claiming to work for the SSA. This is a scam and it is advised that you should not engage with these calls or provide any personal information. 

See the full advisory at the OIG website. 
Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce Conference
￼

Thank you to the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce for inviting me to speak at your annual conference. The Chamber has done a great job working to keep the Taiwanese and United States relationship strong. It was an honor to be invited to speak at such a great event. 
 Meeting Ambassador Abraham Chu
￼

Prior to the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce Conference, I had the pleasure of sitting down for a meeting with Ambassador Abraham Chu, Director General of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office. We had great conversation and I look forward to continuing a friendship with him. 
Chart of the Week
The Joint Economic Committee prepared a chart detailing the creation of jobs and the unemployment rate in November 2018. These numbers show the economy is on the right path to stay strong and jobs are continuing to be created.   
￼

New Addition to Team Schweikert
We are very excited to introduce Victoria Okula as a new addition to the Schweikert Team! While studying at ASU, Victoria interned with our office and this December after graduation she will be joining us full time as a Staff Assistant.   Congratulations Victoria, we are so excited for you to continue working with Team Schweikert!  
￼

Subject: This Week in Washington
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
More Jobs and a Booming Economy
We are quickly approaching the one year anniversary of historic tax reform being signed into law. In that time, we've seen numerous examples of positive change directly attributable to reforming our outdated tax code. From a lower tax burden for millions of families, to rising wages for workers and companies reinvesting in their businesses and employees, the effects of tax reform are being felt by everyone.
One recent example is General Carbide, a tooling manufacturer in Westmoreland County. While I was visiting their facility this week, General Carbide announced it is adding 100 jobs, financing a $14 million expansion, and awarding $250,000 in employee bonuses.
General Carbide's CEO credited tax reform and our booming economy as the reason the company is experiencing its best year ever!
Across Pennsylvania, employers like General Carbide are investing more in their workers and operations. This is just the beginning, and I look forward to seeing how tax reform will continue to create positive change in the lives of Pennsylvanians.  
You can read about my visit to General Carbide in the Tribune-Review here.
￼
￼
Hearing from You
This week, I held my 57th telephone town hall to hear more about the issues that matter to Pennsylvanians. Over 7,500 constituents joined me on the call to discuss border security, tax reform, criminal justice reform, bipartisanship, and many other topics.
I've now completed 80 constituent forums across the state since being elected to the Senate - in person, on social media, and over the phone. Telephone town halls are an especially helpful way to keep in touch with constituents when I am in Washington.
I appreciate every opportunity I get to hear directly from you, answer questions, and share my perspective on some of the most important issues of the day. I look forward to hosting more forums like this in the future. You can also follow me on Facebook and Twitter where I provide advanced notice of upcoming opportunities to participate in town halls.
￼
￼
Fighting for Victims of Child Pornography
Sexual exploitation of a child is amongst the most abhorrent of crimes. For too long, victims of child pornography have not had access to full and fair restitution for the crimes committed against them. But this week, the Amy, Vicky, and Andy Child Pornography Victim Assistance Act was signed into law. While nothing can erase the pain victims and their families have endured, this legislation guarantees victims access to the restitution they deserve.
I have been fighting for victims of child pornography since 2014, when I introduced the Justice for Amy Act. Since then, a bipartisan group of senators came together to tackle this problem and stand up for victims. You can read more and see what Amy said about this legislation here.
￼
￼
Farm Bill: A Wasted Opportunity
The Farm Bill, which passed Congress this week, was a wasted opportunity to rein in excessive spending and end corporate welfare. I opposed this legislation because it made no attempt to curb taxpayer-funded handouts or reform the broken sugar program that forces American consumers to pay twice as much for sugar as the rest of the world. Further, efforts to establish a reasonable work requirement for adult, able-bodied food stamp recipients with no dependents, were abandoned. American farmers, consumers, and taxpayers deserved better.

Subject: Updated Farm Bill, Rockhill Quarry, and more
Message:
News from Congressman
￼ 

Home
About
About District
Conact
Media 


Updated Farm Bill Protects SNAP Benefits
I was proud to support the updated Farm Bill, which passed the House with overwhelming bipartisan support. The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program serves as our nation’s most effective anti-hunger program. The updated measure ensures that the thousands of families, including our community’s children, seniors, and veterans, maintain the support they need to raise themselves out of poverty. In addition, this bill reauthorizes much-needed assistance programs for our local farmers and producers. 
The approved a 5-year Farm Bill agreement protects thousands of families in our community and charts a better path for America’s farmers and ranchers, rural communities, small businesses, and consumers across the country. 
Learn more HERE. 
  
Suspend Redevelopment of Rockhill Quarry
￼  
While I appreciate the immediate moratorium of all mining, rock crushing and sizing, and all other activities related to the Rockhill Quarry after asbestos was found, the seriousness of this test result cannot be overstated. As such, I've requested that Governor Tom Wolf suspend redevelopment of Rockhill Quarry until a more thorough environmental review of the site can be conducted, and the concerns of the community are addressed. 
Learn more HERE. 
  
Croydon gets mobile postal office
￼  
After complaints from area residents and business owners in Croydon, I contacted U.S. Postmaster General Megan Brennan demanding answers as to the future of the post office. I'm pleased that the USPS has announced it will open a temporary mobile unit outside the Croydon mailing center the retail mobile unit will offer full postal services, stamps, mailing packages and money orders. 
While the closure of the Croydon Post Office has temporarily disrupted service for local residents and small businesses, I am hopeful that this temporary facility will mitigate further interruption, especially with the holiday season upon us. 
Read more HERE. 
Holiday Mail for Heroes 
￼  
I joined the American Red Cross Holiday Mail for Heroes event. During the season of hope and giving, we are so thankful for our service members, veterans, and their families in the U.S. and abroad. Since 2007, the Holiday Mail for Heroes program has provided Americans the opportunity to extend holiday greetings and well wishes to service members and their families.

Subject: Amodei Report: Year in Review
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
WEBSITE | MEET MARK | 2ND DISTRICT | SERVICES | ISSUES | NEWS | CONTACT





December 16, 2018
Dear Friend,
 The spirit of the holiday season unites us in several ways. Like many Nevadans, my family has an annual tradition of coming together to reflect on everything we’re thankful for. This year, I’d like to carry that same tradition over to the work my office and I do each day. So as 2018 comes to a close, let’s take a look at some positives.  
The 115th Congress made significant investments to: combat the opioid crisis, end human trafficking, target dangerous criminals, and make schools safer. We continued to honor and support our brave men and women in uniform by increasing funding for military training and readiness programs, equipment, and quality-of-life programs for our troops and their families. We’ve also continued to show gratitude to our nation’s heroes by making significant reforms to the Department of Veterans’ Affairs (VA), authorizing the largest amount of funding in the history of the VA to improve quality of care for vets.  
Finally, we promised you a better economy. After years of struggling to get ahead, I’m pleased to report Americans are finally seeing jobs, opportunities, and consumer confidence come roaring back as a direct result of Congress passing tax reform. Here in CD-2, unemployment is at historic lows and residents have seen a median increase in income of 5.2%.  
In addition to being thankful for these accomplishments, I’m equally thankful for the opportunity to serve you – the people of Nevada’s Second Congressional District. When it comes to constituent services, Team Amodei’s priorities will always be accessibility and responsiveness.  
If you’re ever unable to get the answers you need, or if you have been treated unfairly, our job is to intervene on your behalf. From resolving issues with federal agencies, to coordinating visits to our nation’s capital, my office helped Nevadans with several matters in 2018, and I’d like to take a moment to reflect on some of those highlights below.  
This year, I traveled more than 157,000 miles meeting with nearly 600 groups and organizations throughout our district and in Washington, D.C. In addition to answering 84,755 constituent letters, my office helped 361 Nevadans with cases involving a federal agency, returning $136,921 to constituents in unpaid benefits withheld by the federal government.  
￼
 I’m grateful for the continued opportunity to serve you folks. We have achieved a lot together over these last seven years, and I look forward to working with you in the 116th Congress as we continue making a difference for Nevada.  
Washington, D.C. Wrap-up  
With only a few working days left in the 115th Congress, the House took critical action last week to pass a five-year Farm Bill. This legislation will ensure our farmers, ranchers, and foresters have the tools, resources, and certainty they need to remain competitive in the 21st century. I commend my colleagues for coming together to pass legislation before the new year that will strengthen our rural communities and look forward to seeing the President sign this bill into law. 
 
Click here to learn more about the priorities included in the bill.
 
Looking Ahead  
As you may know, to avoid a partial government shutdown, Congress must pass a spending bill by December 21. One of the issues on which Congress must agree with President Trump is his requested amount of funding for border security.  
In case you missed it, in April, Congress passed an omnibus appropriations bill which allocated $47.7 billion in discretionary funding for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). When discussing border security, it’s important to realize the current state and scale of our southern border and how the omnibus bill responsibly addresses its needs. Our current border has a concentrated combination of various types of infrastructure such as wall, fence, all-weather roads, lighting, enforcement cameras, ground sensors, and other related technology. Additionally, about 1,300 miles of the Southwest border have no barriers established by the government.  
The omnibus greatly strengthened our borders by providing billions of dollars in funding for Customs and Border Protections, personnel, physical barrier assets, and infrastructure, in addition to more than 90 miles of border wall systems – going beyond the Administration’s original request for 74 miles.  
In the coming weeks, my staff and I will be sure to keep you informed of any updates surrounding funding for border security and a short-term spending bill.    
As you and your family begin making plans to gather with loved ones, please travel safe, share what you can with others, and stay warm. I extend my best wishes for a happy and healthy holiday season and a happy new year.   
As always, thank you for subscribing to the Amodei Report. I look forward to keeping you updated on the issues you care about most. For additional information, please visit my website at amodei.house.gov or call my Washington office: (202) 225-6155, Reno office: (775) 686-5760 or Elko office: (775) 777-7705. To receive updates on what I am doing in Washington and in Nevada’s 2nd District follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Youtube.

NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend,

We had a busy week, with the passing of the 2018 Farm Bill and the reopening of Tyndall Air Force Base. Please read about my week below: 

Farm Bill
This week, we sent the 2018 Farm Bill to President Trump's desk. While not perfect, the 2018 Farm Bill gives certainty to our farmers, foresters, and ranchers at a time when many producers are struggling. Under the compromise legislation, we were able to strengthen the farm safety net, improve conservation programs, and make changes to the SNAP program. Our farmers need to know we have their backs and I look forward to this important legislation being signed into law.
Click here to learn more. 

Reopening of Tyndall
￼ 
[Click the photo to view Dr. Dunn's remarks]
This week, Tyndall Air Force Base reopened - a crucial step in the rebuilding process after Hurricane Michael devastated the base. I salute the tremendous efforts of the Tyndall community and the surrounding civilian communities, which have supported recovery efforts from Hurricane Michael.

￼ 
I was also able to join my friend Congressman Joe Wilson in learning about the new planes that will be based out of Tyndall in the future. Lockheed Martin brought F-35 simulators to Washington to showcase the top-of-the-line technology our war planes at Tyndall will have in a few short years.

Military Service Academy Appointments 
Year after year, our district has managed to garner a disproportionate share of appointments to the military academies and the Merchant Marine Academy. This is a tribute to the quality of student citizens that we nominate and the preparation they receive from our Academy Prep Board. I was privileged and moved  that we had 23 excellent candidates that earned nominations this year and it was a special experience for me to speak to all of these students and share the good news of their nominations with them and their families this week. They represent the best of America and the future for all of us.
Mobile Office Hours My district staff will be hosting Mobile Office Hours in Jackson, Bay, and Gulf Counties this week. I encourage you to stop by to see how my office might be able to help you.  Jackson County  Date: Tuesday, December 18th  Time: 10:00AM-12:00PM CT Location: Jackson County Public Library, 2929 Green St, Marianna, FL 32446  Bay County   Date: Tuesday, December 18th  Time: 9:00AM-12:00PM CT Location: Mexico Beach Public Works Building at City Hall, 201 Paradise Path, Mexico Beach, FL 32410  Gulf County   Date: Wednesday, December 19th Time: 10:00AM-12:00PM ET Location: Port St Joe City Hall, 305 Cecil G. Costin Sr. Blvd, Port St Joe, FL 32456   Thank you for your continued energy and enthusiasm, as reflected in your letters and Facebook posts. If you haven’t already, LIKE my Facebook page. You can also follow me on Twitter @DrNealDunnFL2. 
Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in Congress! 
 Sincerely,  ￼  Dr. Neal Dunn Member of Congress

Subject: Walker Weekly Report: December 16, 2018
Message:
￼
Walker Weekly Report
In this season of giving, we must also remember and honor the work of our local churches and charities. That’s why it has been my goal to make sure our policies are empowering these organizations in their work, rather than hindering their service with burdensome regulations. We have introduced the LIFT for Charities Act to remove strenuous compliance measures and other legislation to establish a universal charitable deduction for individuals and married couples who do not itemize, in addition to the standard deduction.
Without the passage of this legislation, these organizations will spend millions collectively on IRS compliance, further diminishing the resources they are able to spend on serving communities. I am proud of our churches and charitable organizations in the Sixth District, and the services they bring to our neighbors of all walks of life. I will continue to fight for effective policies that protect their important work and those they serve.
We are hopeful that the LIFT for Charities Act will come up for a vote next week. There is also important legislation headed to the floor to reform our criminal justice system.
This week, we honored Guilford County Sheriff BJ Barnes on the House floor and named our Community Hero of the Month. 
Keep reading for the full update. Have a blessed week.
Sincerely, ￼ Mark Walker
￼
HIGHLIGHTS
￼
Honoring the Service of Guilford County Sheriff BJ Barnes on the House Floor
This week, I had the privilege of honoring the decades of service to Guilford County by Sheriff BJ Barnes on the U.S. House floor.
His service forever changed our community, and we along with his peers throughout the state and the country will always remember his relentless dedication, his integrity and his compassion. Heroes like Sheriff Barnes are the fabric of our community and I am blessed to call him a friend and mentor.  Sheriff Barnes leaves his position as the longest-serving sheriff in Guilford County history.
Watch the full video of the House floor speech below.
Learn More
￼
UPDATE: Senate Will Move My Co-Sponsored Criminal Justice Reform Bill Before the End of the Year
This week, we received encouraging news as the Senate struck a deal with House to move the FIRST STEP Act – my co-sponsored criminal justice reform bill – before the end of the year. On Thursday, I joined Reps. Doug Collins (R-Ga.) and Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.), as well as Senate Judiciary Chairman Grassley (R-Iowa) and Senate Democratic Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) in introducing the updated FIRST STEP Act in both the House and Senate as support for the reform effort continues to expand. The package has been pledged to be taken up before the end of the year.
Communities and families across the country and from every background will benefit from the reforms included in the FIRST STEP Act. As this Congress comes to a close, passing this bill would leave a legacy of hope and redemption.
Last week, I joined MSNBC's Morning Joe to talk about the importance of this legislation. See the video below.
Learn More
￼
Our Community Hero of the Month: Dori Goebel of Greensboro
Every month, I am moved by the selfless devotion seen in our community as we honor our local heroes. Most recently, we had the privilege of recognizing Dori Goebel as our Sixth District Community Hero of the Month for December 2018. In an extraordinary act of service, Dori volunteered to be a living organ donor for Cindy Mondello, the founder and Executive Director of Restoration Place Counseling. Dori’s act of heroism gave Cindy an opportunity to continue helping those in need.
Both Dori and Cindy had successful surgeries on December 4. I am honored to represent people like Dori and Cindy and feel very blessed to have them as a part of our community. Living organ donation is an important lifesaving measure for so many and this story is an inspiration to us all.
Learn More
 
￼
FEATURED VIDEOS
￼
Honoring Guilford County Sheriff BJ Barnes on the House Floor
￼

￼
LEGISLATION PASSED
S. 2248 | Veterans Benefit and Transition Act
What It Means for North Carolina: This legislation is a bipartisan package that includes provisions related to the improvement of transition assistance for veterans, changes to the GI Bill, healthcare improvements, amendments to the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act, improvements to veterans’ burial benefits, and other improvements to veterans’ benefits. This will help North Carolina keep leading as America's most military friendly state.
Read the Bill
H.R. 1318 | Preventing Maternal Deaths Act
What It Means for North Carolina: This legislation would reauthorize programs for safe motherhood, including support for States and tribes in establishing or operating maternal mortality review committees. This will help North Carolina mothers and prevent deaths during pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum.
Read the Bill

Subject: An Inside Look
Message:
District Update | December 16, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friends,

This week, I met with future Arkansas leaders, honored President George H.W. Bush on the House floor, supported the farm bill that brings much needed security and support to hardworking Arkansas farm families, and more. Thank you for taking the time to follow my work in central Arkansas and Washington. Here are the highlights from this week.

Supporting Arkansas Farmers
￼
Rep. Hill visited the Bearskin and Isbell farms in September 2018. 

Agriculture is Arkansas’s number one economic industry, and this year’s comprehensive farm bill brings much needed security and support to hardworking Arkansas farm families. Farmers benefit from programs funded through this bill including commodity, conservation, and research programs. We take pride in what we produce in our state, and I will continue supporting our farmers and ranchers who produce agricultural products that are second to none. Read more here.

Taking the First Step
￼
This past spring, I was pleased to support the passage of the House’s criminal justice reform package, the FIRST STEP Act, which helps to reduce recidivism rates and adds needed workers to the workforce. I was grateful for the chance to discuss the impacts of this important bill with Sheriff-Elect Eric Higgins from Pulaski County, Paul Chapman with Restore Hope, and Ruby Welch with #Cut50. There is more work to be done, but we are working hard to reform and improve our criminal justice system in Arkansas and across the nation.

Giving Our Sickest Children a Fighting Chance
￼
Rep. Hill visited the NICU at Arkansas Children's Hospital in August 2018.

Our nation’s children with severe, chronic medical challenges deserve quality, comprehensive approaches to health care. This week, we passed a bill in the House that helps America’s children with complex medical conditions receive the care they need. As a father and former board member of Arkansas Children's Hospital, I’m pleased to support this piece of legislation that gives our most vulnerable children the attention and care they deserve. Read more here. 

Meeting with Future Leaders
￼
I had a wonderful time with my Future Leaders Council, and we had a special guest speaker join us from North Little Rock, Arkansas State Rep. Doug House. We discussed federalism, voting, and elections. Afterwards, everyone made their own campaign poster. Each one of these young people is ready to help shape our country, and I couldn’t be more proud.

Honoring President George H.W. Bush
￼
I had the privilege of honoring the life and legacy of my friend and former boss, President George H.W. Bush, on the House floor this week. He was an excellent sportsman, a man of warm and goofy humor, and a man who, in every instance, put himself in the position of serving others. Martha and I will miss him dearly. Watch my tribute on the House floor as I recount a life well lived, and a man of exceptional distinction here. 

Securing Our Borders
￼
Rep. Hill talking with border patrol during his visit to the Southern Border in March of 2018.

The American and Arkansan people want adequate border security. House Republicans have proposed concrete security initiatives and voted on them. I've visited the southern border four times, and I brought back these key takeaways: we need more manpower, proper technology, judges, and an effective set of barriers (depending on the terrain/topography) including a wall, fencing, sophisticated technology, and other means to protect the citizens of our country. I am committed to ensuring that our borders remain secure.

Relocating Offices
￼
We moved our D.C. office to 1533 Longworth House Office Building. Please stop by when you visit our nation’s capital. We are always happy to see fellow Arkansans in D.C. We would also love the chance to show you our nation's historic U.S. Capitol building when you do come. Schedule a tour here: hill.house.gov/forms/tourrequest.
 
Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I'm doing on your behalf. If I can be of any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at (501) 324-5941 or Hill.House.Gov. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Representative French Hill

Subject: Rep. Lynn Jenkins Weekly Update: Passing the 2018 Farm Bill!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
HOME 
CONTACT US 
CONSTITUENT SERVICES 
ISSUES AND LEGISLATION 
December 16, 2018 
Passage of the Farm Bill:
On Wednesday, I was proud to have joined my colleagues in the House of Representatives and the Senate in passing the 2018 Farm Bill. As the legislation is sent to President Trump’s desk for his signature, I was relieved to see Congress come together to reach such an important win for America’s farmers and ranchers, for our rural communities, for small businesses, and for consumers across the country at the grocery store. 
 
The Farm Bill conference report strengthens critical farm safety net policies, including Price Loss Coverage, Agriculture Risk Coverage, Livestock Disaster Programs, and Crop Insurance, providing our farmers with flexibility and peace of mind as they fight so many unpredictable variables. The bill also invests in critical cost-share programs to help farm families improve natural resources, permanently funds the Foreign Market Development program and other trade initiatives to promote America’s agricultural exports. In keeping with our country’s global stewardship, the 2018 Farm Bill maintains U.S. food aid to provide emergency feeding and development assistance around the world. It will also make improvements to the SNAP program by increasing program integrity and incentivizing work in order to fill the employment opportunities that have increased with our thriving economy. 
 
If there is one thing I have learned during my time representing Kansas in Congress, it is that the Farm Bill is essential to the success of our farmers and agriculture industry. I am very pleased this bill passed before the conclusion of the 115th session of Congress and I look forward to watching our innovative Kansans flourish in the coming years.

Subject: The Swamp is Draining
Message:
News from Representative Bradley Byrne
  
￼
ABOUT BRADLEY | HOW CAN I HELP | CONTACT BRADLEY | WANT TO RECEIVE MY UPDATES?
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
That sound you are hearing is the D.C. swamp draining. 
Last week, Congress passed landmark, bipartisan legislation to reform our sexual harassment policies in Washington, and I was proud to write the reform bill and help push it through Congress. 
The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 Reform Act holds Members of Congress personally accountable to the people for their actions, rather than using taxpayer funds to pay for their misdeeds. It will bring transparency and accountability to the halls of Congress.  
No longer will taxpayers be asked to foot the bill for anonymous sexual harassment settlements committed by Members of Congress. Thanks to our bill, the Congressional "hush fund" that you may have heard about is no more. Also, no longer will Members of Congress being able to keep these sexual harassment settlements private.
It was important for the Congress to make this statement for several reasons.  
First, we did the right thing. By doing the right thing, we not only do right by the people who work around us and for us, but we do right by the American people.  
We should always keep that first and foremost in our mind.  
We also did right because we are setting an example. It is important for the leaders of the country to set an example, and this legislation does just that. 
It shows that we cannot tolerate such actions by our elected officials, and most importantly, it should not come at the expense of the American taxpayer. Washington will be a little less swampy thanks to these long overdue reforms.
Passed: 2018 Farm Bill 
￼
On Wednesday, Congress passed the Conference Report to accompany H.R. 2, the Agriculture and Nutrition Act, also known as the 2018 Farm Bill. The bill represents the final product negotiated by members of the House and the Senate after both chambers passed separate versions of the bill earlier this year. The bill will now be signed into law by President Trump.
Our farmers and foresters are our future. I was proud support this bipartisan legislation to better support our farmers in Alabama and throughout the country. 
The 2018 Farm Bill will allow for improved crop protections and loan options for farmers, incentivize rural development, support animal disease prevention and management, and will continue our nation’s commitment to agriculture and farmers.
I was especially pleased to see the substantial resources provided to improve rural broadband access to communities. Providing Internet access to people in rural Alabama is absolutely critical to economic development and the success of these communities in the 21st Century. 
The 2018 Farm Bill is supported by various groups including the Alabama Farmers Federation (ALFA), American Farm Bureau Federation, National Cotton Council, National Association of Conservation Districts, National Pork Producers Council, National Cattlemen’s Beef Association, National Alliance of Forest Owners, and Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue. 
Click here to learn more about the bill’s many important provisions.  
Protecting Local Businesses 
Our local businesses must be unburdened from unclear and unnecessary government regulations in order to succeed.  
Just this week I sent a letter on this very issue to the National Labor Relations Board signed by 83 of my colleagues in the House encouraging action.  
In a move to restore a commonsense understanding of the joint employer standard, in November of last year, the House passed my bill, the Save Local Business Act, meant to update both the National Labor Relations Act and Fair Labor Standards Act to provide clarity for local businesses on what it means to be a joint employer.  
The legislation remains stalled in the U.S. Senate, reinforcing the need for the NLRB to engage in joint employer rulemaking.
We must act to save our Main Street businesses, and I hope that both the NLRB and my colleagues in the Senate will make the right decision for the American people. 
Birthday Celebrations
￼ 
On Thursday, the National Guard celebrated their 382nd birthday! 
Right here in Alabama and all around the country, the service provided by the fine men and women of the National Guard is immeasurable. Thank you for all you do for our state and nation.
*        *        * 
￼ 
On Friday, the State of Alabama celebrated our 199th birthday and kicked off the countdown to our bicentennial celebration!
From Huntsville to Mobile, Florence to Dothan, the people of Alabama are unlike any others in the United States.  
Our great state holds the heart of the country. Nowhere else are the neighbors as nice, the food as good, or the community as uplifting as here in Alabama. 
We not only celebrated 199 years as a state, but we are celebrating the people of Alabama. I am proud to call Alabama my home, but most importantly, I am proud to call all Alabamians my neighbor. 
USS Mobile 
￼ 
You may remember that last year we learned the 26th Littoral Combat Ship, which will be built by Austal USA, will be named the USS Mobile. Well, on Friday we held the keel laying ceremony for the USS Mobile. The keel laying serves as the formal recognition of the start of a ship's construction.
The USS Mobile is especially notable for our family because my wife, Rebecca, was selected to serve as the ship's sponsor. Rebecca embodies the spirit of Mobile, and I know she is truly honored to have this special role. 
I look forward to more celebrations in the months to come as we mark the construction of the USS Mobile! 
Congressional App Challenge Winners 
￼ 
On Friday, I visited Fairhope Middle School to announce the winners of the 2018 Congressional App Challenge.  
Kaleigh Chambers, Alex Etheridge, and Logan Lanicek of Fairhope Middle School won the Congressional App Challenge for their application entitled “Student Shuffle.” The students’ app will be displayed in the United States Capitol and will be featured on the House of Representatives’ website. 
Congratulations to Kaleigh, Alex, and Logan on winning the Congressional App Challenge. Understanding and being proficient in technology is critically important in the 21st Century economy, so I applaud all students who take an interest in coding. I also want to thank the teachers and administration at Fairhope Middle School for encouraging students to take part in the Congressional App Challenge and for expanding interest in coding and technology.
Click here to learn more about the Congressional App Challenge. 
In Case You Missed It!   
Here are a few articles from the past weeks that are worth a read:      
“Bradley Byrne: The light and life of President George H.W. Bush.” - Alabama Today 
“Byrne applauds NOAA’s increased Red Snapper catch limit under new rule.” - AL Reporter  
“Alabama ranks 10th nationally in board certified teachers.” – al.com  
“Proposed Waters of the United States guidelines praised as good for Alabama farmers, landowners.” - Yellowhammer 
“Congress reaches deal to curb sexual harassment on Capitol Hill.” – Politico 
“Alabama House delegation backs $867B Farm Bill.” - Alabama Today   
“House, Senate agree on bill to establish new sexual harassment policy for Congress.” – Washington Post 
“Byrne remembers his cousin Sheriff Scotty Byrne.” - AL Reporter  
“How Congress can jump-start local business growth.” –  Washington Examiner   
Photo of the Week   
 ￼
Thanks to Ms. Sigler's 1st grade class at St. Paul's Episcopal School for these fantastic ornaments to hang on my Christmas tree in Washington! Always excited to see the creativity of our local students.  
What's Ahead  
Congress will be back in Washington this upcoming week to finish out a few more year-end tasks. This is expected to be the last week of legislative business in the House this year, but that could change depending how things go.
The big priority is to secure funding for the rest of the federal government. The deadline to pass a new funding bill is December 21st. Thankfully, we have passed funding for almost 75% of the federal government already, including critical funding for our military, farmers, and infrastructure projects. 
The focus now is on ensuring our borders are protected, and that means including money in the funding bill for President Trump's border wall. That is a priority for me, so I will be working hard to see our border secured. We cannot allow Democrats to block our efforts to keep the American people safe and secure our borders.
As always, if you need help with a federal agency or have questions about anything under debate in Washington, please contact my office. You can call my Mobile office at 251-690-2811 or you can click here to send me an email directly. I also invite you to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to get up-to-the-minute updates from Washington. At the end of the day, my staff and I are here to serve you!   
Stay in touch, 
￼
Congressman Bradley Byrne
PS: Do you enjoy my email updates? If so, please forward these updates to your friends and family. They can also sign up to get my updates by clicking here.

Subject: Cruz News: December 16, 2018
Message:
￼
 
 
December 16, 2018
Greetings,
This week, the House of Representatives passed two of my bipartisan bills addressing the national security interests of the United States. The NICA Act imposes targeted sanctions and establishes conditions for U.S. approval of international loans to the Government of Nicaragua, ensuring the Ortega regime will be held accountable for its systemic corruption, human rights violations, and assault on democratic order. I had the pleasure of participating in a Facebook Live discussion with Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) where we urged President Trump to sign our bill into law, and talked about our shared hope for a free Nicaragua.
I am also pleased the House passed my bipartisan bill to impose sanctions on Iran-backed groups such as Hezbollah, Hamas, and the Houthis for their use of civilians as human shields. For years, the international community has failed to hold these groups accountable. By passing this bill, the United States is sending a message that it will not turn a blind eye to terrorist war crimes, that those who use civilians as human shields are the ones responsible for endangering civilians, and that they will be held accountable.
In the weeks after Hurricane Harvey made landfall, Congress passed the Cruz-Cornyn-Rubio bill, which among other items, eliminated the tax penalty for hurricane survivors who wanted to withdraw from retirement accounts to pay for the costs of repairs from storm damages. Retirement account withdrawals must be made by December 31, 2018 – a deadline that is quickly approaching. If you are still in the process of rebuilding and recovering from the ravages of Harvey, I strongly urge you to contact your tax advisor or for more information go to the IRS website at irs.gov. I am encouraged by the progress we have seen in the Texas communities affected by Hurricane Harvey, and will continue working each day to ensure Texas rebuilds stronger than before.
Please read below for an update from this last week.
Keep Texas Strong,
￼ Ted Cruz
￼
Sen. Cruz and Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) introduced the SuperPAC Elimination Act, which expands and protects free speech in elections by allowing unlimited individual contributions to candidates with immediate disclosure, effectively eliminating SuperPACs. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz and Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) were joined by Sens. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.), and Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), as well as Reps. Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) and Albio Sires (D-N.J.) in applauding the final passage of H.R. 1918, the Nicaraguan Investment and Conditionality Act (NICA), which will soon be signed into law by President Trump. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz, member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, participated in a hearing entitled, ‘Oversight of U.S. Customs and Border Protection.’ Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement in response to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers’ proposal to rein in federal overreach by replacing the Obama administration’s 2015 definition of “waters of the United States” with a clear definition and by creating a cost-effective approach to distinguishing federally protected waterways from state protected waterways. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement upon casting a vote in support of the final 2018 Farm Bill. Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz, Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) and Reps. Mike Gallagher (R-Wisc.), Thomas Suozzi (D-N.Y.), Joe Wilson (R-S.C.), and Seth Moulton (D-Mass.) applauded the House’s passage of the Sanctioning the Use of Civilians as Defenseless Shields Act (H.R. 3342) to impose sanctions on Hezbollah and Hamas for their use of civilians as human shields. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz, member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, questioned administration officials on the threats of China’s non-traditional espionage against the United States. Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz and Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) on Thursday sat down in a Facebook Live discussion to talk about the ongoing crisis in Nicaragua and their efforts to shine a light on the human rights abuses by the Ortega regime. Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz, member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Rep. Mike Gallagher (R-Wisc.), member of the House Armed Services Committee, on Thursday introduced the Blocking Iranian Illicit Finance Act. Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) issued statements praising the bipartisan deal to combat sexual harassment in Congress. Read more...

Subject: Big Win For Georgia Ag
Message:
￼ 








Here are a few highlights from this week: 
  
1. Big Win For Georgia Ag 
  
￼ 
  
The U.S. Senate and House got a good Farm Bill across the finish line. This Farm Bill is an important investment in our rural communities, and it will provide much-needed certainty to farmers in Georgia and across the country. Ultimately, it ensures America's agriculture industry will continue to be a strategic industry for years to come. 
  
Read more in Albany Herald. 
 
2. Honoring The Triple Nickles 
  
￼ 
  
The Triple Nickles was America's first all-black parachute group. They trained at Fort Benning and went on to serve in more airborne units than any other parachute group in history. They are a key part of Georgia's proud military tradition, and a post office in Columbus is being renamed in their honor. 
  
Read more in Columbus CEO. 
  
3. Keeping Georgia The Best State For Business 
  
￼ 
  
It was great to talk with Marty Kemp about her ambitious agenda as Georgia's next First Lady. I'm excited to work with Governor-elect Brian Kemp and Marty to keep Georgia the best state in the country in which to do business.  
  
Read more at 11 Alive.
