Subject: Good news for GA farmers
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
After nearly five years of meetings, hearings, roundtables and site visits, and I am very glad to share that Congress has passed and sent to President Trump a new Farm Bill.
I was very honored to once again serve on the Conference Committee for the 2018 Farm Bill which was charged with handling final negotiations between the different House and Senate versions of the bill. On Monday this past week, we reached an agreement and discharged the Conference Report back to the House and the Senate for one final vote.  
￼ 
Signing and discharging the Conference Committee's final negotiations and sending them back to the House and Senate for one final vote of approval. 
  
I believe the 2018 Farm Bill delivers on our promise to support America’s farmers and rural communities, and I am confident that this bill delivers the necessary policy our farmers desperately need to keep our producers and communities growing and innovating for the 21st century.
Included in the final negations were provisions concerning crop insurance, rural development, rural heath care, specialty crops, and research, extension and education programs, among many other things. 
The 2018 Farm Bill also contains a handful of provisions to further protect our natural resources. As a life-long avid sportsman and a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I was very happy to see a fully-funded conservation title included in the final version of the 2018 Farm Bill. Farmers, ranchers, and sportsmen are dedicated to the conservation of our wildlife and natural resources, and as a Co-Chair of the Sportsmen’s Caucus in the upcoming Congress, I look forward to continuing to find areas where we can advance bipartisan conservation policy. 
Additionally, I was very pleased that two amendments I authored to bring more highspeed internet investment to rural America were included in the final legislation. Bridging the digital divide is something I have been fighting for for years now, and I look forward to seeing growth in network service and infrastructure development through the provisions in this bill. You can click here to read more on the 2018 Farm Bill and our rural broadband initiatives. 
￼ 
The 2018 Farm Bill delivers on many of our key promises to rural America. 
  
In this Conference Report, we also found common ground to make revisions to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) to improve program integrity and incentivize work, while also laying the groundwork for better policy by this Administration and future Farm Bill negotiations. There was certainly more we could do in my opinion to regain the public’s trust in the integrity of SNAP, but I am proud of the reforms we were able to accomplish. I will continue to push for further reforms to the SNAP program to ensure we are providing our fellow Americans will tools and training to lead themselves to financial independence. 
Shortly before the final vote, I spoke on the House Floor stressing the importance of our nation's agriculture industry and urging my colleagues to support our farmers and rural communities by passing the 2018 Farm Bill. You can click here to watch my short remarks. 
￼ 
Speaking on the House Floor urging my colleagues to support our nation’s farmers and rural communities by voting YES on the 2018 Farm Bill. 
  
NATIONAL GUARD CELEBRATES 382nd BIRTHDAY 
On Thursday, December 13, the National Guard celebrated their 382nd birthday. The Guard is a critical component of our national defense, and we are thankful for their commitment of service in our communities and abroad.
￼ 
Image courtesy of the Georgia National Guard. 
  
HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Bipartisanship at work
Message:
￼
  
Bipartisan Farm Bill Passes The House
 
This year, Republicans and Democrats on the Agriculture Committee have been hard at work writing the Farm Bill, an important bipartisan effort to direct and manage our nation’s federal agriculture, crop insurance, nutrition assistance, and conservation programs.
￼ 
American farmers have faced several years of a difficult agriculture economy with depressed crop prices. This bill helps America continue to grow and raise the world’s safest, most abundant food supply. It also maintains the agricultural safety net without adding any new spending. Additionally, some improvements were made to the SNAP program, including initiatives to assist beneficiaries find work. I also worked to ensure provisions to prevent abuse of SNAP were included. These measures include shortening the length of time SNAP benefits are frozen for lack of use and reducing from twelve to nine months the amount of time before unused SNAP benefits are removed from an account.
I was also able to include a provision to promote responsible fertilizer application modeled after Ohio’s successful 4R program, protecting water quality. This Farm Bill was not perfect, but included key reforms while preserving nutrition assistance and insurance support. I am glad to see this strong bipartisan effort pass the House 369 to 47. It now goes to the President's desk for signing.
New WOTUS Rule Proposed
 
Last week, I was able to attend the announcement by EPA’s Acting Administrator Andrew Wheeler of the new Waters of the United States Rule, which replaces the Obama-era rule that treated state agencies and our agriculture community as adversaries. It is clear that enforcement of the Clean Water Act must be a collaborative effort between the federal and state governments. This is an issue I’ve been fighting for several years, working to make sure our agriculture community, homebuilders, private property advocates, and local governments are given a clear set of jurisdictional rules. We can protect the environment, encourage economic growth, and safeguard private property rights without unnecessarily expanding federal jurisdiction. This proposed WOTUS rule does that while providing the certainty our nation’s farmers and ranchers need.
￼ 
Remembering George HW Bush
 
￼ 
Earlier this month, I was honored to attend the funeral of former President George HW Bush to mourn his passing and celebrate his life. It was a touching ceremony highlighting not just his public service, but his faith, his kindness, and his love for his family. May he rest in peace.
 
￼
￼
￼

Subject: Secure Our Border
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends, 
 
We all have our different nighttime routines. Mine looks a little like this: eat dinner. Watch the evening news. Give my three year old son, Lane, a bath, read him a bedtime story, say our prayers and put him to bed. Put Lane back to bed when he gets up for the third time. Make sure the doors are locked and the house is secure. And finally, brush my teeth, tell my wife goodnight and go to sleep. I’d bet your routine looks similar and we have at least one thing in common: locking our doors.
 
As someone once put it, we lock our doors “because we love the people inside, not because we hate the people outside.” 
 
Why should we operate our sovereign nation’s borders any other way?
 
Right now, a caravan of immigrants is attempting to illegally cross our southern border. While many illegal immigrants are innocent people seeking safety and a better life, the truth is criminals and terrorists are exploiting serious vulnerabilities along our border. As a reporter on MSNBC said on live TV from the U.S.-Mexican border recently, “the majority are actually men and some of these men have not articulated that need for asylum.” In fact, more than 90% of the individuals who are part of the caravan are not qualified to enter under the asylum program and there are over 600 known felons traveling with the group. 
 
The previous administration’s policies and Washington’s inability to secure our border make these immigrants believe that once they reach our soil, they will be able to stay here. This has only encouraged other families in Central America to make the dangerous journey and put their children at risk. 
 
￼
I have visited our southern border to assess secuirty and meet with Border Patrol Agents.
 
The southern border also serves as an entryway for illegal drugs to enter our country. In his book, Dreamland: The True Tale of America’s Opiate Epidemic, investigative journalist Sam Quinones lays out how black tar heroin is smuggled from Southwestern Mexico across our border into the United States. Fentanyl, which was just named the deadliest drug in America with over 18,000 deaths in 2016, is also pouring across our border.
 
On a typical day in 2017, Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) officials intercepted 1,607 individuals with national security concerns, seized 5,863 pounds of narcotics, and apprehended 851 wanted criminals. This was just one day. So far in 2018, CBP has apprehended 728 gang members on the southern border, and according to Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, we block 10 known or suspected terrorists a day from traveling or attempting to enter the United States.
 
The House of Representatives has been on the forefront of efforts to secure our borders, crack down on drug trafficking and stop illegal immigration. President Donald Trump signed into law H.R. 6, legislation I led to combat the opioid epidemic and to stop the flow of foreign shipments of fentanyl. In addition, the House has passed numerous bills to secure our border and fix our broken immigration system; however Senate Democrats have blocked these bills from being considered and getting to President Trump’s desk.
 
As your representative, I’ve made a promise to each of you to fight for common sense border security. 
 
Rest assured, I will not give up on that promise. 
 
We have a crisis at our southern border, and I will stand with President Trump to secure the funds he needs to deal with this crisis.  
 
 
Until next week,
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
December 16, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


A Win For American Farmers



On Wednesday, the House fulfilled its promise to American farmers by sending the farm bill to President Trump’s desk. This bill is an important win for U.S. farmers and all Americans who rely on the goods farmers deliver to our tables every day. This bill also helps our rural communities combat the devastating opioid crisis and helps ensure broadband services for the most unserved in our country. It will also help many of our nation’s most vulnerable with reforms to nutrition assistance programs like SNAP so they are administered in the most efficient and effective way possible. Click here or on the image below to learn more about the Agriculture and Nutrition Act.

￼





Celebrating the Bill of Rights


On December 15, 1971 the Bill of Rights was ratified by Congress. The Bill of Rights established some of the important freedoms that define us as Americans to this day. I’m thankful for the wisdom and vision of our founding fathers to establish the first ten amendments to our Constitution to ensure we continue to enjoy these unalienable rights. 
￼





Celebrating Christmas with the US Capitol Police



While the official United States Capitol tree gets most of the attention, the unofficial United States Capitol Police tree at the House barricade is just as important. Thanks to the men and women of the US Capitol Police for inviting me to the ceremonial lighting of this year’s tree and for all the work they do each day keeping members, staff, and the public safe. 

￼





What I Have Been Reading



The National Guard just turned 382- check out these impressive photos of the Guard battling fires, hurricanes, and more

Business Insider 

On December 13th in 1636, the first militia regiments in North America were organized in Massachusetts and became the foundation for the National Guard that continues to protect and serve us today. Thank you to the brave men and women who have served and everything you do to keep North Carolina and our nation safe! 


It's Shelby, again, in the NCHSAA state championship seat

Charlotte Observer 

Congratulations to the Tenth District’s very own Shelby High Golden Lions on their impressive 2AA state championship win over North Davidson. This game was the Golden Lions 12th straight win this season and the 17th state championship in the school's history.

Subject: Fighting for Farmers
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
Next Stop for the Farm Bill: President Trump's Desk
 
 
Good news for South Carolina’s farmers: the 2018 Farm Bill is on the way to President Trump’s desk! This legislation strengthens the farm safety net by expanding crop insurance, providing certainty for producers in the face of dropping farm income and natural disasters. 
South Carolina farmers have dealt with more than their fair share of devastation, having to overcome three natural disasters in the last four years. After Hurricane Florence, I joined farmers across our district to survey crop damage and saw first-hand the challenges they face after such a catastrophic event. The Farm Bill is a critical component of disaster recovery and will provide peace of mind as our farmers continue to work, grow, and produce despite tough circumstances and unforeseen challenges.
 

￼
 
 
Disaster Relief Update
 
 
In the Seventh District, we are still facing a long recovery from Hurricane Florence and my team will be here for you every step of the way. If you applied for federal assistance, you can get updates about your registration, learn about the appeals process, and check the status of your appeal online at DisasterAssistance.gov.     This week, I received a letter from Governor McMaster requesting additional CDBG-DR funding. These additional funds will allow us to help as many people as possible rebuild their homes and lives. He also requested that the South Carolina delegation find a way to fund I-73 as an adequate evacuation route. Improving outdated infrastructure is a critical component of disaster mitigation and preparedness. I will continue to work at the federal, state, and local level to ensure a complete and strong recovery!  Read More »
 

 
Putting Taxpayers First
 
 
I had the opportunity to meet with IRS Commissioner Rettig this week. As a member of the Ways and Means Committee, it is an important part of my job to hold the IRS accountable and ensure they are effectively serving taxpayers. Unfortunately, the agency has fallen short of this goal largely because of their antiquated IT infrastructure. We had a productive meeting and discussed ways to return the agency to their taxpayer first mission. I look forward to working with Commissioner Rettig to achieve this goal!
 

￼
 
 
Reversing A Regulatory Regime: Waters of the United States
 
 
President Obama’s regulatory-happy EPA expanded the federal government’s regulatory authority from “main waterways” to all bodies of water including streams, ditches, ponds, and private property. Farmers and landowners were rightly outraged at this unconstitutional land grab. At the time, I heard from many concerned Seventh District landowners whose fears unfortunately turned into reality across the country. Farmers were no longer able to plow their own land or became tied up in jurisdictional disputes that took years and hundreds of thousands of dollars to resolve. 
I’m happy to report that the Trump Administration has tackled this issue head on. The EPA and Army Corps of Engineers proposed a new WOTUS definition this week. Their straightforward approach will provide much needed certainty, return authority to state and local entities, and promote responsible management of our nation’s land and water in accordance with the Clean Water Act. This will empower hardworking people in the Seventh District to grow, build, and invest in our community. 
Read More »
 

 
Always Ready, Always There
 
 
The United States National Guard turned 382 this week! That’s 382 years of The Guard being always ready and always there to serve our country when we need them most. After Hurricane Florence, more than 3,400 South Carolina National Guard Soldiers and Airmen were activated in response to the storm. This is just one of many times they have answered the call of duty and I am so grateful for their service! 
Read More » 
 

￼
Have a great week, 
￼

Tom Rice

Subject: Five-Year Farm Bill Passes Congress
Message:
Babin Bulletin | December 16, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Babin Comments on Passage of Five-Year Farm Bill
I’m glad the House and Senate were able to come together to pass a compromise farm bill. The certainty this bill provides our farmers will enable them to plan for multiple crop cycles in the coming years. That certainty is necessary both for the livelihood of our farmers and to secure a dependable supply of food, fiber, and feed for our nation. I am particularly pleased this bill has improvements which will benefit Texas rice and soybean farmers and timber growers.

While I am pleased with the commodity, crop insurance, and conservation titles in the farm bill, which will be welcomed by farmers in Southeast Texas, Congress must show a renewed commitment towards ensuring that taxpayer dollars go to those who truly need them and our country’s safety net is not abused at the expense of our agricultural programs. I am disappointed that Congress missed the best opportunity in decades to make significant reforms to a bill that allocates more than 80 percent of its funding to food stamps. Without the commonsense reforms included in the original version of the House-passed farm bill, funds that could go towards securing our agricultural safety net will continue to go to the SNAP program, which has ballooned in recent years even as our economy has markedly improved. Fortunately, the Administration and USDA will have authority to enact some limited safeguards to strengthen the integrity of our SNAP program.
New WOTUS Rule
I applaud the EPA’s decision to repeal the Obama-era Waters of the US (WOTUS) rule. The Obama WOTUS rule was a pure power grab that placed overburdensome regulations on our farmers, ranchers, and land owners. This rule vastly expanded federal regulatory authority by qualifying almost every puddle of water in the country, even seasonal ponds and ditches, as “navigable waters”. By following the law as intended, the Trump-proposed replacement rule will lift bureaucratic red tape, return power to the American people, and clarify the government’s role in managing our nation’s waters.
￼
To read article, please click here.
 ACA Ruled Unconstitutional
 The ruling that the so-called Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional is a major blow to this disastrous law. I will work with my colleagues to replace Obamacare with a free market approach that keep premiums low while protecting preexisting conditions. And as a health care provider, I will prioritize reforms which strengthen doctor-patient relationships.
￼
To read the article, please click here.

￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Meeting with Former ICE Director
I had the opportunity to meet with former Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Director Thomas Homan on Wednesday to discuss the very serious situation our country is in with border security. We are in agreement that something has to be done to secure America's borders immediately. 
￼
Photos of the Week
It was great visiting with fellow East Texan and U.S. Marine Corps Major Russell Fluker (pictured below) in Washington this week. Major Fluker is originally from Kirbyvillle, but is currently stationed in the area with his wife and three children. I am thankful for his service, and glad we were able to catch up!
￼
 Roxanne, my wife, and Will Carter, Regional Community Manager on my staff, were able to present Hull-Daisetta Superintendent Mary Huckabee (pictured below in middle) with a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol in recognition of her lifelong dedication to education. Mary and Roxanne earned their teaching certificates together at Lamar University and have remained great friends ever since. Thank you for your service to Hull-Daisetta ISD!
￼

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
Friends,
It is important that during this holiday season we emphasize the spirit of giving. Whether it's spending quality time with family and friends or volunteering for a local charity, every act of kindness is always worthwhile. 
I was honored to send a Christmas card to a very special young lady from Ashtabula, Oliviah Hall, whose compassion and strength continues to inspire us all. Oliviah's wish this Christmas is to receive as many cards as her home can hold. If you'd like to help Oliviah's wish come true you can send a card to the following address:
Team Oliviah P.O. Box 2655 Ashtabula, OH 44005
￼
This week, I also joined the American Red Cross for their annual Holiday Mail for Heroes event to send holiday cards to our service members overseas. I am especially thankful for our men and women in uniform for their sacrifice and service during this holiday season. 
￼
Great Lakes Advisory Board
On Thursday, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced the re-establishment of the Great Lakes Advisory Board (Board). The Board was created to ensure transparent, credible and diverse views in guiding the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative's (GLRI) investments. 
The Board's charter expired in June of 2018. Given the importance of the Board, I led a bipartisan letter to former EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt earlier this year in support of the continuation of the Board. I also conveyed the importance of the Board to former EPA Administrator Pruitt during a House Appropriations Committee hearing in the Spring. 
I applaud the EPA's decision to re-establish the Board. I am proud that after working with my colleagues and local stakeholders, the Board will continue to guide Great Lakes Restoration Initiative protection and restoration efforts in the region. The Great Lakes are a national treasure and the Board plays an important role in our ability to protect them for future generations. 
￼
Andover Post Office
As you may know, many members of the Andover community have been without mail delivery service. Residents of certain streets have to go to the Andover Post Office to retrieve their mail and packages. After working with Councilman Matt DiBell, Mayor Raymond French and the United States Postal Service, we are closer to establishing rural delivery service for these residents. 
I am thankful to Councilman DiBell for bringing this important issue to my attention and pleased with the progress we are making. I will continue to work with him, Mayor French and the rest of the Village of Andover to provide better mail service for its residents. 
IMPROVE Act 
This week, my colleagues and I passed the Improving Medicaid Programs and Opportunities for Eligible Beneficiaries (IMPROVE) Act to penalize drugmakers that knowingly misclassify outpatient drugs to avoid paying higher Medicaid rebates. This is about transparency and affordability and it is the right thing to do for the American people. This bill also improves access to medical assistance for children with medically complex conditions, such as HIV/AIDS and cerebral palsy; it would also include life-limiting illnesses or rare pediatric diseases. I'm proud to support this progress in addressing the challenges children with these conditions are facing.
Congressional App Challenge
Congratulations to our 2018 Congressional App Challenge winners! All of the contestants should be very proud of their hard work and I'm certain that they have promising futures ahead of them. Help me in congratulating our winners: 
Olivija Tatarunas and Summer Mastandrea App: Jungle Adventure Mentor High School 
￼
Thank you for taking the time to read my Weekly Wrap. I hope you all are enjoying this holiday season. 
Dave

December 16, 2018   Dear  @gmail.com,  In the coming weeks, Congress must pass a year-end spending bill to fund certain departments and agencies. This must-pass bill will include priorities of both Republicans and Democrats, so it's no surprise that President Trump is insisting that the bill address one of his top priorities: the border wall.  
I've voted in support of increased border security — including the construction of a physical wall — on several occasions. While we do have to reform our immigration system and address the DACA issue, I believe that first and foremost we must secure our borders.  
What do you think? 
Should Congress appropriate funds in the year-end spending bill to construct a wall along our southern border?

Subject: The Bost Bulletin 📰
Message:
News From Congressman Bost 
￼

Website 
About Mike
Contact 
Issues 
Media Center
Services


￼
￼ 
￼ 
 
THE BOST BULLETIN
Friend:  
We were back at it this week in Washington. Right now, I am focused on getting the Farm Bill over the finish line and signed into law. We also received an update in the House Veterans Affairs Committee from the VA on how my legislation to reform the VA appeals process is going. Additionally, the House passed legislation that I support which will reduce maternal deaths and save lives. 
Farm Bill Update 
￼ 
On Wednesday, I voted for the House-Senate compromise Agriculture Improvement Act (H.R.2), commonly known as the Farm Bill. The legislation, which authorizes agricultural and nutrition policy for the next five years, includes provisions I introduced to aid beginning farmers in growing their operations and help existing farmers enhance their nutrient management practices. The bill now moves to President Trump’s desk to be signed into law.
Protecting our agricultural economy is essential to the sustainability of our rural areas. Illinois’ 12th Congressional District is the most diverse in terms of agriculture in the entire state. I made it a priority to listen to the over 10,000 producers in my district, so I knew what they needed most. I’m proud of the provisions I fought to have included in this Farm Bill.
More information about the Farm Bill and the provisions I fought for is available HERE. 

House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs Hearing 
￼ 
Too many veterans faced intolerable delays during VA’s benefits claims appeal process. That’s why I introduced bipartisan legislation that was signed into law to modernize the system and ensure our veterans get the help they need in a more efficient and effective manner. But our work isn’t done. We need to make certain that VA properly implements the law. That's what this week’s hearing was about. America’s heroes and their families deserve nothing less.

Preventing Maternal Deaths Act 
The U.S. has the highest rate of maternal mortality in the developed world. That’s simply unacceptable and why I'm a cosponsor of H.R.1318, the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act, which would establish and support Maternal Mortality Review Committees (MMRCs). These committees identify trends and risk factors, and develop recommendations to reduce maternal deaths. This bipartisan legislation can prevent future families from suffering the profound loss of a mother. It passed the House and Senate this week and now awaits President Trump’s signature. 
Local news coverage of H.R. 1318 HERE. 
That’s a quick update on what I’ve been up to. I hope you have a great week ahead! 
 
- Mike

Subject: Supporting Mississippi in Congress
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


December 16, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
Supporting Mississippi in Congress
 
 
This week, the House passed the Commercial Engagement through Ocean Technology Act (CENOTE) which will benefit many of south Mississippi's industries related to marine research and development. 

The CENOTE bill, that I introduced with Senator Roger Wicker in March, establishes a framework for NOAA and allows public and private defense and non-defense industries to come together. With this collaboration, we will expand the usage of unmanned maritime systems and provide more support for Mississippi's Blue Economy. 

The legislation is bicameral, bipartisan, and bicoastal and directs that the data collected by NOAA on unmanned missions be made accessible to the public, benefiting our commercial, academic, and national security interests. 

I believe that uniting these industries to expand unmanned maritime systems will have a long-lasting positive impact on our Mississippi Gulf Coast. This is a great victory for south Mississippi and I was glad to see Congress advance our legislation. 

If you're interested in a summary of the legislation, that can be found here. 

￼
Congressman Palazzo views an unmanned maritime system at the new Southern Miss Marine Research Education Center in Gulfport.

2018 Farm Bill
As a member of the Subcommittee on Agriculture for House Appropriations, I was pleased to provide my support for the 2018 Farm Bill which provides certainty and stability to our farmers and ranchers. 

The Farm Bill passed through Congress this week and will now head to the President to be signed into law. This bill promotes smart and sustainable land conservation efforts and works to protect crucial safety net programs such as affordable crop insurance and disaster recovery programs. 

Specifically, South Mississippi is a leading producer of timber, peanuts  and a variety of specialty crops such as watermelons and blueberries. I was glad to see that our south Mississippi timber producers, specialty crop farmers, cattlemen and ranchers are supported through this legislation.

Week in Review
￼
Had a productive meeting this week with Dennis Alvord, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Regional Affairs for the Economic Development Administration, whose goal is to assist economically distressed areas and rural areas.
As a member of the Commerce, Justice, and Science Subcommittee, I was glad we had the opportunity to discuss how EDA grants have positively impacted south Mississippi and ways we will continue working together.
￼

It was my pleasure to meet with Suzette Kent, the Chief Information Officer for the Office of Management and Budget in my Washington, D.C. office.  

￼
It was a beautiful evening to welcome the Ole Miss students of the Mississippi Excellence in Teaching Program to the steps of the Capitol. Terrific group of students with bright futures ahead!

As always, I'd like to remind you to connect with me on social media so you can receive frequent updates on the work I am doing in Congress through Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

In your service,
￼
Steven
 ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

ABOUT  |  CONTACT  |  SERVICES  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATION  |  RESOURCES
￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
December 16, 2018
Around the District
TOMORROW: Farewell Open House
Join us on Monday, December 17th from 3:00 to 5:00 PM for a Farewell Constituent Open House with Congressman Kevin Yoder. 
 
OVERLAND PARK CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
9001 West 110th Street
Second Floor
Overland Park, Kansas 66210
Farewell Address
Final Speech on the House Floor
￼ Click here to watch Kevin's remarks on the House floor.
I never imagined that as a farm kid from Yoder, Kansas I would ever have the privilege of serving in the United States Congress. I have many people to thank for helping me along the way, including my family, friends, and most of all you - the constituents of the Third District. Thank you for giving me the opportunity of a lifetime to be your voice in Washington, DC. 
￼
Last Week in Congress
Kansas Sen. Pat Roberts Ushers 5-Year Farm Bill Reauthorization to President's Desk
￼ Click here to read more about the Farm Bill in the Kansas City Star.
As farm kid who was blessed with the opportunity to serve six years on the House Agriculture Appropriations Committee, I was proud to cast one of my final votes in the House for the 2018 Farm Bill. The bill provides long-term stability and certainty for farmers and ranchers in Kansas and across the US and makes important reforms to safety net programs aiming to pull people out of poverty and into the workforce. I’m also thankful to Senator Pat Roberts for leading the negotiations to prioritize the needs of Kansas farmers - many of whom have been left behind in our economy and seen their income slashed in half over the last half decade - so they can continue to feed America and the world.
￼
Yoder Helps Secure $13.8M DOT Grant for Turner Diagonal Interchange
￼ ￼ Click here to read more coverage from the Wyandotte Daily.
I’m thrilled the Department of Transportation has recognized the need for this project in Wyandotte County. The new interchange will open the door for major economic development in the area for years to come. I’ve been pushing for this grant for years, and personally discussed the need for the new interchange with Secretary Chao in the Third District this year. I want to applaud Mayor David Alvey for his steadfast leadership at the UG and thank the DOT for recognizing this critical need. This is a massive win for KCK, and will continue to build on the already amazing economic development we have seen over the last decade. 
￼
Funeral Ceremony for President George HW Bush
￼
It was an honor to be on hand in Washington, DC to celebrate the extraordinary life and legacy of our 41st President George H.W. Bush along with Senators Bob and Elizabeth Dole, and many other leaders as we paid tribute to President Bush and his life of service to the American people.
￼

Fact of the Week
￼
 
The fewest Americans since 2005 have been unemployed this year. 
Legislative Look Ahead
There may be votes in the House of Representatives next week. The House Majority Leader has yet to release the weekly schedule.
Legislative Wrap Up
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10TH
 
H.R. 5513 - Big Bear Land Exchange Act  – PASSED BY VOICE
 
H.R. 6108 - Preserving America’s Battlefields Act  – PASSED BY VOICE
 
H.R. 3008 - George W. Bush Childhood Home Study Act – PASSED 382 – 4 – 2 (YES)
 
H.R. 6118 - American World War II Heritage City – PASSED BY VOICE

Subject: 2018 Farm Bill is Headed to the President's Desk
Message:
￼ 
Website  |   About  |   Contact Me  |   Serving You  |   Media Center  |   Legislative Work  |   Our District  |   Resources 
  

December 16, 2018
THE SCALISE CAPITOL REPORT
Reforming SNAP, Protecting Farmers and Ranchers
This week, the House and Senate overwhelmingly voted to pass the 2018 Farm Bill. This Farm Bill is a win for hard-working taxpayers, as well as America’s farmers and ranchers, and will provide the certainty and economic stability our farmers need to continue leading the world in food production. Our farmers and ranchers not only put food on the tables of American families, but also serve as the bread basket of the world. 

This bill also includes key reforms to the food stamp program that will help millions of Americans move from government dependence to work and self-sufficiency. With a strong economy, and more job openings than there are Americans looking for work, there has never been a better time to help unemployed Americans get back into the workforce so they can support their families and achieve the American dream.

Lastly, the conference agreement includes the House bill’s provision that I fought hard to include that creates additional research opportunities for Roseau cane. This research is vital to Louisiana’s First Congressional District and our efforts to combat coastal erosion. I look forward to President Trump signing this reform bill into law.

Working to Fund Border Security
This week we continued negotiations trying to get a bill to the President’s desk giving him the tools he needs to safely secure our border. Right now, there are about 8,000 people in the migrant caravan trying to enter our country illegally, and the Department of Homeland Security has confirmed that more than 600 convicted criminals are part of this caravan. The reason for strong border security has never been more clear.

President Trump has requested $5 billion over the next year for border security, including funding to continue building a wall, as well as technology and equipment to help our border patrol officers do their jobs more safely and effectively. 

Negotiations are still ongoing, but if Democrats in Congress, led by Minority Leaders Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer, refuse to support this, then they need to come up with an alternative that addresses this crisis at the border while keeping America safe and secure. They can’t come and say they want to shut the government down because they don’t want to secure America’s border. 

I discussed our plan to strengthen border security on Fox News Channel's America's Newsroom this week. Click here to watch the interview. 

Meeting with Louisiana Restaurant Association
This week, I enjoyed meeting with representatives from Louisiana’s restaurant industry. Louisiana restaurants and cuisine are second to none, and across our state, Louisiana restaurants employ over 200,000 people. It was great to catch up on issues that impact Louisiana’s restaurants and the thousands of hard-working Louisianans they employ.

￼
Congressman Scalise sits down with members of the Louisiana Restaurant Association.
 It is an honor to represent you in Congress. For more information please visit my website, Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook pages.   God Bless,
￼

Steve Scalise
House Majority Whip

ABOUT
CONTACT
ISSUES

SERVICES
￼
December 16, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
This week in Congress,I joined 368 of my colleagues in supporting the passage of the 2018 Farm Bill.
Setting America’s Farmers, Ranchers, and Consumers up for Success 
I am proud to support a Farm Bill that will prioritize the needs of Pennsylvania’s farmers, ranchers, consumers, and rural communities.The conference report to H.R. 2, the Agriculture and Nutrition Act extends major federal farm, nutrition assistance, rural development, and other USDA programs.
￼
This bill gives agricultural producers, especially those in the dairy industry, the safety net to mitigate risks associated with a changing market and inclement weather, highlights the careful conservation of America’s natural resources, solidifies key animal protections, and expands agricultural research and rural development to keep up with 21st century technology. Additionally, this bill makes many changes to the nation’s nutrition programs that ensure the neediest have food on the table while also preparing participants with the skills, certifications, and education to build better futures for themselves and their families. I believe this bill will provide the certainty and flexibility our farmers and ranchers need to produce food and fiber for Americans and the world.
Disaster Assistance Available for Pennsylvanians
The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) approved Governor Tom Wolf's request to declare a disaster in Bradford, Columbia, Delaware, Northumberland, Schuylkill and Susquehanna counties after significant flood damage to homes and businesses was sustained from severe storms between Aug. 10 – 15, 2018.
Homeowners, renters and businesses impacted by the storms in Bradford, Columbia, Delaware, Northumberland, Schuylkill and Susquehanna, as well as neighboring counties Berks, Carbon, Chester, Dauphin, Juniata, Lackawanna, Lebanon, Lehigh, Luzerne, Lycoming, Montgomery, Montour, Perry, Philadelphia, Snyder, Sullivan, Tioga, Union, Wayne and Wyoming may be eligible for low-interest disaster loans through the SBA Disaster Loan Programs.
Low-interest loans of up to $200,000 are available to homeowners to repair or replace damaged or destroyed real estate. SBA regulations permit loans up to $40,000 to repair or replace personal property. Businesses and nonprofits can borrow up to $2 million to restore damaged or destroyed buildings, inventory, equipment and assets. Loan amounts and terms are set by the SBA and are based on each applicant’s financial qualifications.
The SBA will establish a Disaster Loan Outreach Centers (DLOC) to assist anyone who wishes to apply for a loan. Applicants from any eligible county may report to any DLOC location in order to get help. The DLOCs will be open at the following locations and times:
Bradford County: Fairfield Inn By Marriott 1248 Gold Mile Road Towanda, PA 18848
Columbia County: Benton Borough Building 590 Everett Street Benton, PA 17814
Delaware County: Delaware County Emergency Services Building 360 North Middletown Road Media, PA 19063
Northumberland County: Warrior Run Area Fire Department Headquarters 1125 Main Street Watsontown, PA 17777
Schuylkill County: Port Carbon Borough Municipal Building 301 First Street P.O. Box 71 Port Carbon, PA 17965
Susquehanna County: Susquehanna County Department of Public Safety County Office Building 81 Public Avenue Montrose, PA 18801
Opening: Thursday, December 13: 11 a.m. Days: Friday, Monday – Wednesday: 9 a.m. – 6 p.m. Saturday, December 15: 10 a.m. – 2 p.m. Closed: Sunday, December 16 Closing: Thursday, December 20: 4 p.m.
SBA customer service representatives will be on hand at the disaster loan outreach center to issue loan applications, answer questions about the disaster loan program, explain the application process and help individuals to complete their applications.
Loan applications can also be downloaded at www.sba.gov/disaster. Applicants may apply online using the Electronic Loan Application (ELA) via the SBA’s secure website at https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela. Completed applications should be returned to the local DLOC or mailed to: U.S. Small Business Administration, Processing and Disbursement Center, 14925 Kingsport Road, Fort Worth, TX 76155.
The filing deadline to return applications for physical property damage is Feb. 11, 2019. The deadline to return economic injury disaster loan applications is Sept. 11, 2019.
Google CEO Testifies Before House Judiciary Committee
Google chief executive Sundar Pichai testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday. The hearing revolved around Google’s business practices and behavior, focusing heavily on the company's data collection practices on its users and claims of political bias in search results. Mr. Pichai answered a series of questions regarding Google’s algorithms and technical features.
￼
While I appreciated the testimony of Mr. Pichai, I remain concerned about the company’s long-term plans in China, specifically regarding the protection of user data. Tech companies like Google have an enormous responsibility to ensure that the user information that is entrusted to them is not abused.
Ensuring Competition and a Healthy Marketplace 
As the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Regulatory Reform, Commercial, and Antitrust Law, I had the opportunity to hear from the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice about current competition enforcement activities and policy priorities. It is important to ensure our agencies are promoting policies that enforce a competitive marketplace and are in the best interest of American businesses and consumers.
Combat Injured Veterans May be Due a Refund
From 1991 through 2016, approximately 130,000 combat injured veterans received disability severance payments that were inadvertently treated as taxable.
In response to the Combat Injured Veterans Tax Fairness Act, in July of 2018 the Department of Defense issued a letter to eligible veterans advising that they may be due a refund. On July 11, 2018, IRS issued a news release advising that eligible veterans owed refunds attributable to disability severance payments should file amended returns for the year in which they received the payment to claim tax refunds.
Veterans have one year from the date of the DoD letter (until July 2019), or three years from the due date of the return, whichever is later, to claim the refund.
Some, not all, VITA sites will be able to help eligible veterans claim a refund based on the actual amount of their disability severance payment. Claims based on actual amounts paid may be larger or smaller than the standard refund amounts. To find a VITA site, click here.
Lake Ariel Office Closing
Due to the recent redistricting of Pennsylvania, I will represent PA-12 beginning in the 116th Congress. It is important to note that PA-12 no longer covers much of its northeastern tier, including Wayne, Lackawanna, Pike, and Monroe Counties. Potter, Clinton, and parts of Centre and Tioga will be added. Because of these changes, my Lake Ariel office will be closing on December 21, 2018.
The official start of PA-12 is January 3, 2019. At that time, you can click here If you have any questions about who represents you in the 116th Congress.
As always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA

As always, my staff and I are ready and willing to assist you.  If you would like to schedule a meeting, request a tour or flag, voice an opinion, or make a suggestion please contact my Washington, D.C. office.
If you need assistance working with a federal agency or applying for a grant please contact one of my Constituent Service Centers, located throughout the district.
I am here to serve you and represent your views, as a resident of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District.

Subject: Still negotiating...making progress on healthcare improvement and Veterans' benefits
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
December 16, 2018
Dear Friend,  
Last week was quite active in Washington, D.C. There was a great deal of discussion around the remaining seven appropriations bills that must be passed by this Friday, with much of the debate focused on the amount of money that will be allocated to the Department of Homeland Security for various public safety initiatives, including how much will be spent to build a wall along our southern border.  National security is too important to be used as a political football.  Border security is essential to national security and we need to fund the Department of Homeland Security at a level necessary to protect all Americans. Negotiations are ongoing and I will continue to advocate for protecting our national security throughout the process.
 Continue reading for a brief summary of my work on your behalf last week! 
Improving the Quality and Delivery of Healthcare 
I am proud that the IMPROVE ACT passed the House last week.  This bill included the Advancing Care for Exceptional Kids Act (ACE Kids Act) which I’ve been advocating for with my colleague, Congresswoman Kathy Castor, because it is very important to families who are served in local children’s hospitals, such as All Children’s Hospital and St. Joseph’s Children’s Hospital.  The bill improves care coordination within Medicaid for children with complex medical conditions.   Click here to watch me discuss this bill on the House Floor. 
 Also, in last week’s Health Subcommittee we received an update on the adoption and use of electronic health records facilitated through 21st Century Cures legislation. Electronic health information is facilitating better patient care coordination, and will ultimately help reduce costs by making care faster and less duplicative.  
 ￼ 
Supporting Common Sense Regulation and Infrastructure Needed to Improve Public Safety 
ICYMI- A recent story highlighted my quest for answers and improvement in safety procedures that could have prevented a fire on a local casino boat that claimed the life of a young mother in Pasco County. Last week’s report issued by the National Transportation Safety Board identified several mistakes that contributed to the fire and contained recommendations for strengthening public safety. Nothing can bring back my constituent, Carrie Dempsey, who died in this tragedy—but we can, and must, work together to address gaps in safety precautions and prevent future loss of life.  I will not rest until we do.   
Also, during last week’s Communications and Technology Subcommittee hearing, we discussed the already emerging benefits from the recently enacted RAY BAUM’S Act, which improves public safety and spurs deployment of 5G Internet networks. I highlighted how Florida was just deemed the best state for broadband deployment and examined how this law is improving communications for those in a natural disaster area. 
￼ 
Fighting for our Nation’s Heroes 
I am proud that my bill, the SIT-REP Act, passed the House as part of S. 2248 last week.  This legislation, which ensures our Veterans are not adversely impacted when bureaucratic red tape causes GI Bill payments to be delayed, is very timely given the recent delays by the VA in processing payments.  I am continuing to closely monitor that situation, and have been assured that all Veterans will receive the full amount they are due.  However, my bill will guarantee, moving forward, that Veterans will not lose access to education or be charged with additional fees from the schools.  Click here  to watch me discuss this bill on the House Floor. 
 ￼ 
ICYMI-There was a local article discussing the possibility of the Cohen Network opening a facility in Tampa Bay.  To be clear, I do not support privatizing or replacing the VA in any way. I was heavily involved with enacting the VA MISSION Act so that local VA entities can partner alongside community providers to best meet the needs of Veterans.  Veterans should have the choice to access private care if the VA cannot meet their needs in a timely manner.  I want Veterans to have the option to choose their care in a patient-centered manner, and MISSION helps do that. Any entity serving the Veteran community (whether private or within the VA) should be held accountable for meeting the highest standard of care.  If the Cohen Network helps meet an unmet need by providing mental health services in the Tampa area, that could potentially be a good option for some Veterans. However, my hope is that it (like any other community provider) would be working in unison with the VA via the Community Care Program and held to an unwavering standard of excellence. Our Veterans deserve no less!
Additionally, in last week’s VA Committee hearing we discussed progress that is being made on modernizing the benefit appeal process.  Veterans are still waiting too long to receive the benefits they’ve earned and that has to change! 
Serving as a Good Steward of Your Tax Dollars and Ensuring a Level Playing Field for American Businesses 
It is always wonderful to have constituents up in D.C.  Last week, I was privileged to host members of the Pasco County Sheriff’s office.  They were in town to meet with me and several federal agencies about the possibility of utilizing Pasco’s new state-of-the-art training facility that will be located in Land O’ Lakes (pictured below).  Partnerships between federal and local governments are in the best interests of tax payers, and I was happy to facilitate the dialogue.  
￼ 
I was pleased by President Trump’s directive to federal agencies last week that will result in greater spending in economically distressed areas, known as opportunity zones, throughout the country.  This is part of an overall strategy to build upon the economic relief provided to middle class Americans and small businesses through tax reform, by focusing on a broader effort to combat poverty and geographic inequality.  There are Opportunity Zones designated in parts of Pasco, Pinellas and Hillsborough counties.  For a complete listing, click here. 
Also, I applaud the recent action by Canada to arrest Meng Wanzhou, CFO of Huawei, a company that is well known for violating international law and stealing intellectual property.  In order for American businesses to have a level playing field, bad actors must be held accountable for breaking the law.  
 And, a special congratulations to my constituent, Catherine Tomasello, creator of an award winning video designed to raise awareness about the need to protect intellectual property through the patent process.  Her video is both engaging and educational.  While in D.C. to accept her award, she stopped by to discuss ways we can help to secure intellectual property (pictured below).
 ￼ 
Recognizing Contributions Made to our Nation  
Normally, I do not comment publicly on the naming of buildings. However, last week the President signed into law a bill (S. 3389) we recently passed which designates a facility at NASA as the Katherine Johnson Independent Verification and Validation Facility. You may recognize Katherine (pictured below) from the popular movie, “Hidden Figures.” The invaluable contributions made through her work and the work of many of her female contemporaries went unrecognized for far too long.
 ￼ 
Defending Basic Human Rights  
As co-Chairman of the International Freedom Caucus and an original co-sponsor of this bill, I was glad to see President Trump sign the Iraq and Syria Genocide Emergency Relief and Accountability Act into law last week.  Protecting religious minorities in those countries from persecution, which this bill will help to do, is a matter of ensuring basic human rights around the globe.    
Constituent Corner 
My staff has been working with a homeless Veteran who resides in Pasco County since earlier this year when he first contacted my office.  He has severe physical and mental health issues which have prevented him from being able to work. Though he applied for Social Security Disability benefits many years ago, he had been previously denied and his appeal was tied up in the system.  We were able to advocate on his behalf and have appeal review expedited.  His disability was approved last week.  Even one homeless Veteran is too many, in mind.  I was happy to help get this Veteran the help he needs. 
This is just one example of the work we do each and every day.  Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you.  
Highlights from Around the District 
I have a great team, both locally and in Washington, D.C.  When I am in Washington, members of my team are working each and every day to provide excellent constituent service and to be my eyes and ears on the ground as they attend community events.  Here are just a few highlights of their efforts this week.
My Deputy Chief of Staff, Summer, attended the Alliance for Substance Abuse Prevention’s annual brunch which was attended by over 200 people in Pasco County.  Patients in recovery from substance abuse shared their inspirational stories about the work that is being done in our community utilizing the recent influx of federal dollars to assist those who are addicted on their journey to sobriety. 
￼ 
Dan, my District Aide, attended the North Tampa Bay Chamber of Commerce’s Economic Briefing in which county officials discussed the progress being made on the Ridge Road Extension Project.  I have been working closely with county staff and the leadership of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to expedite approval of the permit, as this project is vital to public safety.  
￼ 
Rob, my Outreach Director and Veterans' Liaison, attended the Community Service Council's annual event in New Port Richey to honor students who have demonstrated a strong commitment to the community while achieving academic excellence.  
￼ 
Bob, a member of my outreach team, attended the Sunrise Domestic Violence and Pasco County Housing Authority’s annual luncheon to discuss efforts to ensure federal dollars are used to ensure housing opportunities for victims of domestic violence.     
￼ 
   
Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Gus Bilirakis

Subject: Good Samaritans are Part of Solution to Abandoned Mine Cleanup
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A message from Congressman Scott Tipton
￼

Contact Me
#CUTtheCODE
￼
￼
￼

About Me
Media Center
Serving You
Legislation
Contact Me

  Hi, 
In August of 2015, Coloradans across the southwest part of our state experienced both shock and anger as the Animas River turned yellow, the result of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) accidentally releasing millions of gallons of toxic mining waste from the abandoned Gold King Mine. The impact of this spill was widespread downstream. The EPA promised to make the individuals, businesses and communities impacted by the spill whole, and I have continued to work to ensure the agency fulfills this promise. 
The Gold King Mine spill was a catastrophic reminder of the risks that abandoned mines pose across the entire western United States. Across the West, there are more than 50,000 mines that were abandoned before the era of modern regulations, 23,000 of which are located in Colorado. Much like the Gold King Mine, many of these abandoned mines were never sufficiently cleaned-up, have no current responsible party, and release pollution into surrounding watersheds.
Since these abandoned sites were opened long before the enactment of the nation’s environmental and land management laws and have no existing responsible party, it has fallen to the federal government to perform remediation. In 1997, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and Forest Service (FS) started to remediate the abandoned mines located on federal lands, often in conjunction with state and local municipalities. While progress has been made, a tremendous amount of work remains and the price tag to remediate every abandoned mine in the U.S. is estimated to be a whopping $50 billion. Federal agencies estimate that $80-85 million is already spent annually on mine remediation, so if this process continues as is, it will not just be slow, it will also be an extraordinary burden at the federal, state and local levels for years to come. 
If we have learned anything from the Gold King Mine spill, it is that the status quo is unacceptable when it comes to cleaning-up abandoned mine sites. There are many Good Samaritan Groups – sportsmen’s and environment groups, as well as mining organizations – that have the technical expertise, financial ability, and desire to conduct successful remediation at abandoned mines. Unfortunately, Good Samaritan groups are often discouraged from taking on these important projects because of federal clean water and liability regulations.
Abandoned mines threaten water quality and the environment in Colorado, so Senator Cory Gardner and I have been working for several years to develop legislation that would create a Good Samaritan pilot project to remove hurdles that have prevented Good Samaritan groups from taking on abandoned mine remediation projects. We introduced the latest version of the bill, the Good Samaritan Remediation of Orphan Hardrock Mines Act of 2018 (H.R. 7226), on December 6, 2018. This bill would authorize the EPA to establish a 7-year Good Samaritan pilot program, under which the EPA will administer up to 15 Good Samaritan permits to carry out projects to remediate historic mine residue at orphan mine sites. 
H.R. 7226 includes strong permitting requirements to ensure potential Good Samaritan groups have the expertise and financial ability needed to responsibly take on remediation projects. Additionally, before any application can be granted, the Good Samaritan group must make earnest efforts to identify if there are existing responsible parties for the mine, and if one is identified, the permit would be denied. The Good Samaritan group must also provide detailed plans for the project, including a work schedule, a health and safety plan and a specific contingency plan if downstream waters are impacted by an unplanned discharge of hazardous substances. Should the Good Samaritan group break any of the terms of its permit, it will face all liability under current law.
I am confident in the progress that has been made towards finding a solution to help cleanup abandoned mines across the West and look forward to continued work on this bill in the 116th Congress. 
Sincerely, 
￼ 
  


Washington, DC 218 Cannon HOB Washington, DC 20515 (202) 225-4761 

Grand Junction 225 N 5th St. #702 Grand Junction, CO 81501 (970) 241-2499

SERVICES
 
Thank you for subscribing to my E-Newsletter! This week I want to update you on attending the funeral for former President George H.W. Bush, share some highlights from the Shop with a Cop Christmas event, and let you know about the latest happenings in Congress like this week's vote on the Farm Bill to help Pennsylvania farmers.  
I enjoy hearing from you and responding to your questions via email, phone calls, and letters. If you'd like to share your concerns or opinions with me, or if you have questions about legislation or specific votes, you can send me an email here.  
Since taking office almost two years ago, I've responded to more than 145,000 contacts from you. To stay up-to-date on my work in the district and Washington, be sure to follow me on Facebook and Twitter. You can also check out my YouTube page here where there are 100+ videos, many of which are direct responses to your questions.  
I'm very proud of the casework my office has been able to provide for constituents. More than 3,200 cases have been completed, and more than $650,000 has been returned to individuals. If you need help with a federal agency, my office can help cut through Washington's red tape and bureaucracy. I encourage you to contact my district office at (717) 393-0667 if you need assistance. 
   
 

Remembering George H.W. Bush  
Cindy and I had the honor of attending the state funeral to celebrate the life and legacy of former President George H.W. Bush at the Washington National Cathedral earlier this month.   
President Bush was an example of servant leadership that we can all learn from. He was a veteran, a diplomat, an Intelligence Chief, a Vice President and a President. In all of these roles, he served with honor and virtue. 
The service for our former president was very touching. I particularly enjoyed George W. Bush's recollection of his father and his wonderful life. I am so grateful for George H.W. Bush's commitment to our American values. He will certainly be missed. 
 

Celebrating the Christmas Spirit at 'Shop With a Cop'  
￼ 
It’s always great to see the wonderful things happening in our community. Christmas is a time of giving -- and this month, I was glad to have been invited to join an event celebrating the the spirit of generosity in Pennsylvania's 16th District.  
Year after year, our local police officers have found a way to give back to needy children in our community through the "Shop with a Cop" event. Our police officers shop with these kids as their "personal assistants" to help them buy presents for their families, friends and sometimes even themselves.   
Thank you to Trinity Lutheran Church for organizing this event and thank you to the Lancaster County police officers for reminding us the reason for the season.  
And a thank you to all our law enforcement officers for working so hard to keep us safe.   
 

Prioritizing Pennsylvania Farmers  
Our district is the largest agricultural district in the state -- and that means one of my biggest duties in Congress is to fight for our farmers. On Wednesday, the House passed the 2018 Farm Bill, which will help support our farmers who feed America. 
Agriculture is our state's No. 1 industry and it's especially vital for our district. The agriculture industry supports more than 93,000 jobs in our district and contributes more than $16 billion to Pennsylvania's economy.  
Our farmers have fallen on hard times though -- and their incomes are currently at a 12-year low. This year's Farm Bill will help these struggling farmers get through tough times.  
Our district came away with some wins in the Farm Bill. We were able to reduce premiums on our dairy farmers' milk and my request of $75 million to combat the spotted lanternfly -- an invasive species threatening our local crops -- was also included in the final bill. 
Unfortunately, the bill which came back from the Senate eliminated key reforms to our SNAP programs. I hope we will reconsider these ideas. Those are reforms to improve people’s lives and help connect them to good-paying jobs – and those are reforms which will still be needed in the future. 
 

Thank you for subscribing to my newsletter! You can stay up-to-date on what I'm doing in Washington and Pennsylvania by following me on Twitter and Facebook. 
  Sincerely,  


Sincerely, 
￼ 
Lloyd Smucker

Subject: Heading to President Trump's Desk
Message:
￼ 
  

HEADING TO PRESIDENT TRUMP'S DESK

This week, the United States Senate unanimously passed my legislation to protect American veterans from military service deposit errors. It is now on the way to President Trump to be signed into law.  

My legislation, the Correcting Miscalculations in Veterans' Pensions Act, authorizes federal agencies that make a mistake in calculating military service deposits and pensions to pay the incorrectly accrued interest on behalf of veteran employees.

Currently, veterans working at a federal agency are required to pay a military service deposit in order to receive their military service pension while working for the federal agency. Due to a misclassification in the type of the employee’s status, the federal agency will therefore charge different interest rates on those military service deposits, often leading to miscalculations. 

Once the federal agency becomes aware of the miscalculation, they will contact the veteran and notify them of the need to pay back the balance with accrued interest. In some cases, I heard from veterans that the interest can be tens of thousands of dollars that the veteran would be required to pay. 

Without this legislation, there is no recourse for veterans to mediate that payment and there is no authority for the federal agency to wipe away the incorrectly accrued interest.

My legislation authorizes agencies that make a mistake in calculating military service deposits and pensions to pay the incorrectly accrued interest on behalf of the veterans.

Our veterans deserve better and I am thrilled this legislation is heading to President Trump to be signed into law. 

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CXC

Monday, December 10, 2018:  After unexpectedly being out of session last week due to the death of our 41st President, George H. W. Bush, I arrived back in Washington last night and this morning my first meeting is our weekly staff briefing.  As I reported a few weeks ago, we are in the process of moving offices which is no easy task.  Boxes are everywhere, pictures still need to be hung and, plain and simple, the place is a mess.  However, we are happy with our new location as we are in a bigger office that is closer to the House Chamber as well as our committee meeting rooms, and, most importantly to me, closer to the member’s gym.  We also welcome a new staff member to our team today as Jay Gulshen takes over the important role of our Legislative Health Care Assistant.  Jay brings a wealth of experience as he previously served on the Energy and Commerce (E&C) Health Subcommittee that I am a member of.  After our staff meeting, I head to the House Chamber where I deliver a series of tributes including one to Mr. Bill Brown of Brunswick who recently celebrated his 100th birthday.  I also recognized one of my former pharmacy professors who recently passed, Dr. Henry Cobb, Officer John White, one of the first African American police officers in the City of Savannah and crew members of the Brunswick bar pilots who recently helped rescue a drowning man near the St. Simons Pier.  A link to these tributes can be found here, here and here.  Later in the afternoon, I head to our weekly Whip Team meeting where we hear from the Chairman of the Agriculture Committee, Rep. Mike Conaway (R-TX), about the conference report on the Farm Bill that we will be voting on later this week.  For the past six months, I have been lobbying Chairman Conaway as well as Appropriations Committee members and leadership for disaster funds for our blueberry farmers who have suffered two straight years of devastating losses due to late freezes.  Afterwards, I head to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the week. 
Tuesday, December 11, 2018:  This morning we have a Doctor’s Caucus meeting where we hear from representatives from the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) to gain their perspective on proposals to lower prescription drug prices.  Next, I head to our weekly GOP Conference before heading to an E&C Environment Subcommittee hearing on “21st Century Transportation Fuels.”  A link to my questions can be found here.  Afterwards, I head to the Red Cross Holiday Mail for Heroes Card Signing where I have the opportunity to sign and send out holiday cards to our troops serving overseas. 
￼
Rep. Carter writing letters with American Red Cross Holiday Mail for Heroes
Next, I head to an E&C Health Subcommittee hearing on “Implementing the 21st Century Cures Act” as we hear from the office of the National Coordinator.  A link to my questions can be found here.  Afterwards, I head to a meeting with representatives from Microsoft to learn how artificial intelligence can be used to solve global challenges and then head to the House Chamber where I speak on legislation from the E&C Committee that is being considered today.  Next, I head back to my office where I have an on camera interview with Gray TV to discuss the Farm Bill before having a phone interview with WTOC TV in Savannah to discuss offshore energy exploration followed by another phone interview with Southeast AgNet to discuss the Farm bill.  After a meeting with my good friend, John McCallum, who is up visiting from St. Simons Island, I head to the House Chamber for our first and only vote series of the day and then head back to my office to record a video.  
Wednesday, December 12, 2018:  After an early morning meeting with Jay Greissing with BioMarin Pharmaceuticals, I head to an E&C Oversight and Investigations (O&I) hearing on “Examining the Availability of SAFE kits at Hospitals in the United States.”  A link to my questions can be found here.  Afterwards, I have an on camera interview with WSB TV in Atlanta to discuss the hearing before heading to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the day.  Later, I head back to my office where I have a meeting with John O’Brien with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to discuss priorities for Medicare Parts B and D.  John is one of the many fine staff members at HHS who, under the leadership of HHS Secretary Alex Azar, is working hard to bring about positive changes to our health care system particularly in the area of prescription drug pricing.
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with John O'Brien, Senior Advisor to Secretary Azar for Drug Pricing Reform
Afterwards, I head back to the House Chamber for our second vote series of the day and then return to my office for a meeting with Endeavors, a company that provides disaster case management and emergency services.
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with Endeavors
My final event of the day is a tele town hall meeting where we hear from constituents throughout the district.
Thursday, December 13, 2018:  I begin this morning with a classified member’s only briefing where we hear from Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo about the ongoing situation in Yemen.  Afterwards, I head to an E&C Health Subcommittee member-CDC roundtable on Acute Flaccid Myelitis (AFM), a rare, but serious condition affecting the nervous system, especially in children.  Next, I head to the House Chamber for our first and only vote series of the day before returning to my office for a meeting with my good friend, Becky Ryles with the National Association of Community Health Centers, a group that plays a vital role in providing care for underserved populations across the country.
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with the National Association of Community Health Centers
Next, I head to the airport for my return trip home and, once I’ve landed head straight to Richmond Hill for a meeting with the Development Authority of Bryan County.
Friday, December 14, 2018:  I’m on St. Simons Island this morning as I take part in the Brunswick-Golden Isles Chamber of Commerce Grits and Issues breakfast and answer questions from this great group of community leaders.
￼
Rep. Carter speaking at the Brunswick-Golden Isles Chamber of Commerce Grits & Issues Breakfast
This year’s event will be the last for long time BGI COC Executive Director Woody Woodside, who will be retiring next spring and will be dearly missed.  Afterwards, I head to Ludowici in Long County where I meet with Sherriff Craig Nobles before heading to City Hall where I present a copy of the tribute that I entered into the House journal in memory of Ludowici Police Chief Frank McClelland to his wife Cindy and other family members.  Chief McClelland, a stalwart of the community, was killed in the line of duty and is deeply missed.  Next, I head to our Savannah district office where I meet with Charlie Loomis regarding barriers for veterans to use their earned education benefits to pay for flight training.  Afterwards, I have a delightful visit with my good friend, Donna Camacho with the Alzheimer’s Association before meeting with Alicia Roberts from Hinesville to discuss women’s heart disease and the importance of cardiac rehab and heart health prevention.

Subject: Improving health care for women & children
Message:
District Update | December 15, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼

My bipartisan bill to prevent maternal deaths passes Congress, heads to president's desk
￼
I had the privilege of testifying on the U.S. House
floor this week in support of my bill to make 
pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum safer for all moms.
Click here to learn how we are combating the rise of maternal
mortality.

My bipartisan bill to prevent maternal deaths passed out of Congress and is now heading to the president's desk to be signed into law. Rep. Diana DeGette (D-CO) joined me in this effort, which marks the strongest step Congress has taken to date to reverse the growing maternal mortality rate in the U.S. H.R. 1318, the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act, would establish and support state Maternal Mortality Review Committees to review every pregnancy-related or pregnancy-associated death, and based on those findings, develop recommendations for how to prevent future mothers’ deaths. 

As a mom and a lawmaker, this is personal to me, and it was an honor to join with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to lead this life-saving measure successfully through the House. We must improve our understanding of why mothers are dying in pregnancy, during childbirth and postpartum so we can then unleash every possible resource to protect women in this critical season of life. 

The rise of maternal mortality in the U.S.:
• The U.S. has the highest rate of maternal mortality in the developed world, and the rate continues to rise. Between 700-900 women die in the U.S. every year from pregnancy-related and pregnancy-associated deaths.
• According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 60% of maternal deaths are preventable.

ACE Kids Act, my bill that improves care for low-income, medically-complex kids, passes U.S. House
￼
I spoke in support of the ACE Kids Act on the House floor
this week. This bill ensures that medically-complex kids of 
families who rely on Medicaid won't be restricted from
accessing life-saving care simply because of their
zip code. You can watch my full remarks here.
We took an important step Tuesday by passing my bill, the ACE Kids Act, which removes barriers families face when trying to get care for their medically-complex children.   I’ve been in the NICU and met families who were faced with the reality of having a sick child, and also have hit hard times economically. I can put too many faces and names to the reality that little kiddos often can’t get the care they need. With passage of this bill, we are doing right by our kids – regardless of their zip codes, they’ll be able to get specialized medical treatment that can often be life-saving.   Importance of improving care for low-income, medically-complex children:  • One in 25 children in the U.S. is “medically complex” with diagnoses like cancer, congenital heart disease, Down syndrome, or others that require consistent care and medical expertise. Of the several million medically-complex children, roughly two million rely on Medicaid. Children who have complex medical conditions represent a small percentage of kids in Medicaid, but account for a large portion of the costs.   • In order to enhance the critical care for these two million children, the ACE Kids Act creates networks anchored by children’s hospitals to help coordinate care. States would choose to opt into this network, allowing families to seamlessly pursue the best doctors and facilities — even if it takes them to another state, which Medicaid often wouldn’t allow. Passage of this bill works to remove that barrier so all kids can receive the treatment they need.
