Subject: Continuing Our Work in Washington
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
Continuing Our Work in Washington 
Dear Friend:
I appreciate you taking the time to read this brief update. It remains an honor for me to serve as your United States Representative in Washington, D.C.  We spent another busy week back in our nation’s capital and the most significant action of the week was, unfortunately, one I was unable to support. Specifically, on Wednesday, the House gave final approval to the once-every-five-year reauthorization of the “Farm Bill.” This bill includes 12 titles covering a wide array of agricultural issues, but the most important element is the section that covers the “SNAP” program, otherwise known as food stamps. This program represents about 80% of all spending within the Farm Bill.  I voted for the initial version of this bill, which passed the House of Representatives back in June, largely because it included some significant and important reforms to the food stamp program. Specifically, it required able-bodied, working-aged individuals who are not the primary caregiver for minor dependent children, either to find some work (part-time or full-time), participate in a job training program, or volunteer with an approved non-profit to remain eligible for SNAP assistance. Requiring work or job training is the best way to lift someone out of poverty and, more importantly, it provides them with the dignity and improved self-esteem that comes from work and financial independence.  When the bill returned to the House from the Senate, however, these reasonable work requirement provisions were gone and without these important reforms, I had to withdraw my support for the bill.  The other big topic of discussion right now, of course, is the status of the remaining appropriation bills we need to pass. Currently, about 25% of the federal government is operating on a Continuing Resolution, which will expire on December 21st. As most of you probably know from the news, the President and Democratic leaders of the House and Senate met to discuss finding a compromise agreement to finish the appropriations process. The primary sticking point is the amount to appropriate to the Department of Homeland Security to construct additional fencing and other security measures on our southern border. The President is asking Congress for about $5 billion and my Democratic colleagues are currently only willing to fund this program with about $1.6 billion. At present, it appears that no agreement is in sight, so I expect that we will now return to Washington next week to see if we can reach an agreement and vote on keeping these parts of the government open before the current continuing resolution expires. I am sure I will have more to say about this in next week’s message to you.  I also want to note that I participated in an important hearing held by the House Veterans' Affairs Committee on Wednesday. The hearing was to evaluate the VA’s readiness to implement the Veteran’s Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017. The hearing’s focus was on whether the Secretary was prepared to certify in January 2019 that VA’s IT systems and resources were ready to implement the act by its February 2019 effective date. The bill’s focus is on implementing an improved appeals process for veterans filing claims for benefits. VA stated that it was confident the implementation will occur on schedule and that the reformed processes would go live February 2019. The VA’s optimism was due to its success with its pilot programs, which have reduced appeals processing times from the current 3-7 years to an average of about 120 days to one year. The VA stated it is prepared to move from the pilot programs to full implementation by February of next year. Clearly, this is very good news for our veterans.  At the end of the hearing, the Veterans’ Affairs Committee Chairman, Rep. Phil Roe, and the Acting Ranking Member, Rep. Mark Takano, made a few comments on my impending departure from the Committee and the U.S. House of Representatives. I have included those clips below. 
￼

￼

Finally, I invite you to stay in contact with me via my website, Facebook or Twitter. See you around the district!

Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative

Subject: Jackie's Reads for December 15, 2018

News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

December 15, 2018 
Dear Friends,  Given the ongoing political turmoil that has gripped our country, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.    
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world.
When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change.      
Happy reading and all the best,    ￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼ 

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
Mueller Rejects Flynn’s Attempt to Portray Himself as Victim of the F.B.I.
By Adam Goldman, The New York Times
￼
WASHINGTON — The special counsel’s office rejected on Friday a suggestion from Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, that he had been tricked into lying last year to F.B.I. agents investigating Russia’s election interference and ties to Trump associates.
Prosecutors laid out a pattern of lies by Mr. Flynn to Vice President Mike Pence, senior White House aides, federal investigators and the news media in the weeks before and after the presidential inauguration as he scrambled to obscure the truth about his communications during the presidential transition with Sergey I. Kislyak, the Russian ambassador to the United States at the time.
Neither his lawyers nor Mr. Flynn, the former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, have explained why he lied to the F.B.I., a felony that he pleaded guilty to a year ago. But in a memo this week seeking leniency, his lawyers revealed details from the interview that stoked an unfounded theory that Mr. Flynn’s demeanor during questioning indicated that he did not understand that he was being formally investigated. They also blamed the F.B.I. for not informing Mr. Flynn ahead of time that lying to agents is illegal — an argument that prosecutors repudiated. 
“A sitting national security adviser, former head of an intelligence agency, retired lieutenant general and 33-year veteran of the armed forces knows he should not lie to federal agents,” prosecutors for the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, wrote in court papers. “He does not need to be warned it is a crime to lie to federal agents to know the importance of telling them the truth.” 
To read the complete New York Times, please click here. 
How WhatsApp Fuels Fake News and Violence in India
￼
By the time police arrived in the hamlet of Rainpada on July 1, 2018, the village council office was the scene of a massacre.
By Timothy McLaughlin, Wired
The bright blue shutters on the windows were splintered and the door was kicked in. Inside, files were strewn across the floor and the light green walls were splashed with blood. Five men were dead, beaten to death with fists, feet, sticks, and office furniture wielded by a raging mob. 
The dead men—four in their late forties and one whose age remains unknown—had arrived in Rainpada earlier that day, at around 9 am, on a bus from Solapur, some 300 miles south, to attend a Sunday market. According to their families and police, all of them were members of a Nath Panthi Davari Gosavi tribe, a nomadic group that roams India’s western Maharashtra state, surviving mostly on alms. The men sat under a tree not far from where they had gotten off the bus and, as they ate, handed a biscuit to a young girl. 
Six weeks later, Hemant Patil, the assistant police inspector for Dhule district, in which Rainpada is located, explains how this seemingly innocuous gesture had enormous consequences. For about a week before the men arrived, rumors circulated on the messaging system WhatsApp warning of bands of kidnappers roving the area and infiltrating villages to snatch young children. In one particularly grim version of the rumor, the children’s organs—kidneys and hearts—were harvested and sold. 
To read the complete Wired article, please click here. 
Congress sends Trump bill to make lawmakers liable for harassment settlements
By Elise Viebeck, The Washington Post
Congress backed legislation on Thursday that would make lawmakers financially liable for sexual harassment settlements and eliminate unnecessary barriers to reporting workplace misconduct on Capitol Hill. 
The swift passage of a compromise bill by the House and Senate revealed overwhelming bipartisan support for changing policies on Capitol Hill in response to the #MeToo movement after nearly seven months of negotiations. Last fall, Congress’s system for addressing lawmaker misconduct, including employee settlements funded by taxpayers, was criticized as unfairly protective of members of Congress over their aides. 
The bill — passed less than 24 hours after a deal was announced — now goes to the White House for President Trump’s signature. 
To read the complete Washington Post article, please click here. 
Wisconsin’s Scott Walker Signs Bills Stripping Powers From Incoming Governor
By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey, The New York Times
FOX CROSSING, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker made a national name for himself in the Republican Party by cutting the power of public sector unions eight years ago, only weeks after he swept into office in Wisconsin. On Friday, he signed legislation to cut the power of the Democrat who defeated him, a final act of a tumultuous tenure that moved Wisconsin firmly to the right. 
The response from Democrats was swift and furious. 
Tony Evers, the Democrat who beat Mr. Walker in a hard-fought election last month, said the departing governor “chose to ignore and override the will of the people.” Liberal groups, including one led by Eric H. Holder Jr., a former United States attorney general, pledged to sue. Senator Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin sent her Democratic supporters an email calling the move “a craven partisan attack on democracy” and soliciting donations to her “Vote ’Em Out Fund.” 
The tactic by Mr. Walker and his allies came as part of an increasingly fractious struggle over power in the states, following a model set in North Carolina, where Republicans in 2016 tried to restrict the power of the governor after a Democrat was elected. 
To read the complete New York Times article, please click here.

Subject: UPDATE – FARM BILL & ROUZER WWII CITIES BILL PASSES HOUSE
Message:
News from Representative Rouzer  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
ABOUT
CONTACT
ISSUES
MEDIA CENTER
SERVICES
 
Dear Friends, 
This week, the U.S. House of Representatives passed H.R. 6118, which I authored, directing the Department of Interior to designate one city per year as a nationally recognized “American World War II City.”  Additionally, the U.S. House passed the conference report to accompany H.R. 2 – Agriculture Improvement Act sending the five-year Farm Bill to the President’s desk for his signature. 
HOUSE PASSES ROUZER BILL TO DESIGNATE AMERICAN WWII CITY 
H.R. 6118 directs the Secretary of the Interior to designate at least one city in the United States each year with this illustrious title.  These cities will be designated based on their significant contributions to the war effort and their work preserving the history of WWII. 
Due to the hard work and dedication of Wilmington native Captain Wilbur D. Jones, Jr., USNR (Ret.), who is a distinguished author and veteran active in the community, the idea of honoring Wilmington as the Nation’s first World War II City is one step closer to being achieved.  Our state and country is fortunate to have Captain Wilbur D. Jones, Jr. advocating to recognize Wilmington and other cities for their significant contributions during World War II.  As many from the Greatest Generation know, the City of Wilmington was a major contributor to a nationwide effort during World War II to assist with the many components of war production such as defense manufacturing, the production of food and consumer items, and much more.  Passage of this bill brings Wilmington one step closer to receiving the recognition it so rightfully deserves. 
￼  Congressman Rouzer and Captain Wilbur D. Jones after a House Committee on Natural Resources hearing examining H.R. 6118. 
HOUSE PASSES FARM BILL CONFERENCE REPORT, HEADS TO POTUS FOR SIGNATURE
The agriculture industry contributes $87 billion to North Carolina’s economy making it the state's number one industry employing 17 percent of the state's workforce.  Passage of the 2018 Farm Bill is critically important to America’s farm families, especially those in eastern North Carolina where Hurricane Florence dealt a devastating blow.  The 2018 Farm Bill conference report is the result of an agreement reached between both chambers of Congress that will strengthen the farm safety net, incentivize work and make critical investments to support rural communities, farm families, and American consumers. 
I am very pleased that we were able to reach a compromise agreement with the Senate that delivers a stronger safety net for North Carolina's farm families.  In addition to enhancing crop insurance and other farm programs, the conference agreement increases the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s capacity to combat the opioid crisis, expands quality broadband access, and makes significant investments in animal disease preparedness critically important to North Carolina and the nation.  The agreement also makes more than 30 improvements to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) while enabling additional immediate improvements to be made by the Administration. 
￼ 
As our state continues to recover from Hurricane Florence, our four offices in Bolivia, Wilmington, Four Oaks and Washington, D.C. stand ready to assist you.  Please call us if you have any questions or concerns.  You can reach our Bolivia office by calling (910) 253-6111; our Wilmington office at (910) 395-0202; our Four Oaks office at (919) 938-3040 and Washington, D.C. office at (202) 225-2731. 
Sincerely,  ￼ 
￼
￼

Subject: An Update from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez to Constituents of the 15th District of Texas
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
The past couple of weeks have proven to be very busy, but I wanted to take the time to give you all an update on the recent work in Washington, D.C. and the 15th District of Texas. 
It is an honor to serve as your congressman.
Recently, I announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue approved a Secretarial disaster designation for the following counties in the 15th District of Texas: Duval, primary; Brooks, contiguous; Jim Hogg, contiguous; and Live Oak, contiguous. With this designation, those affected qualify to be considered for Farm Service Agency (FSA) loans.
The farming and agriculture industries in the 15th District of Texas are key components of our region’s economic success. I thank Secretary Purdue for making this assistance available to those who incurred losses from this summer’s flooding. I encourage all eligible applicants to apply for these funds as we continue to rebuild and strengthen Texas agriculture.
Prospective applicants can contact their respective FSA offices by clicking here. 
For more information, visit FSA’s informational website by clicking here. Watch more by clicking the picture below.
￼ 
On Saturday, December 1, 2018, I had the honor of joining an official congressional delegation (pictured below) to attend the inauguration of Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador in Mexico City, Mexico. This was a new day, and a new beginning, for Mexico and the entire Western Hemisphere. I congratulate President López Obrador and look forward to working with him to chart a new path forward in U.S. – Mexico relations. Central and South Texans can expect both governments to take concrete steps to increase border security, stabilize Central America, shorten wait times at our international bridges, raise food safety standards, reduce non-tariff trade barriers, improve supply chain security, and lower costs for consumers while ensuring trade that is equitable and just for all North Americans.
￼ 
On Monday, December 3, 2018, I had the honor of participating in the arrival ceremony of the late former President George H.W. Bush in the rotunda of the U.S. Capitol. President Bush was a true American statesman. I was graciously humbled to partake in the celebration of this patriot’s legacy and honor a life of public service. As a public servant and a decorated service member, President Bush, Sr. set a high bar for decency and civility. May he soon reunite with his friends; loved ones; and his beloved wife, Barbara. 
￼ 
On Tuesday, December 4, 2018, I announced that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services has issued a proposed rule that lowers prescription drug costs and increases transparency surrounding Medicare Parts C and D. In May 2018, I joined Congressman Doug Collins (GA-09) to introduce the bipartisan H.R. 5958, the PHAIR Pricing Act of 2018, to lower drug costs to Medicare recipients at the point of sale. The new rule includes language from this bill. Our prescription drug system is in dire need of reform - I commend the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for taking this important step.
￼ 
On Thursday, December 6, 2018, I joined Congressman Will Hurd (TX-23) and Senators John Cornyn (R-TX) and Ted Cruz (R-TX) to introduce the Missing Persons and Unidentified Remains Act of 2018, a bill to help local jurisdictions improve the recording and reporting of missing persons and unidentified remains found in South Texas. 
Our nation has a chance to put more resources into helping identify the remains of missing persons, and to bring closure to families who know not whether to grieve, or continue the search. This piece of legislation would provide much-needed resources directed at finding answers for families across the U.S. Southwest Border. Passing this bill will help our ranchers and farmers, our counties, and our local sheriffs. I thank Congressman Hurd and Senators Cornyn and Cruz for coming together to craft this bipartisan and bicameral piece of legislation. Read more by clicking here. 
My opposition to funding a physical barrier along the U.S.-Mexico Border remains firm. Recently, I joined Congressman Henry Cuellar in a letter to Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, urging the senator to not lose face in the Senate. On Friday, December 7, 2018, I joined Congressman Filemon Vela to ask the same of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. We need all hands on deck for this. No more funding than what has already been agreed to – plain and simple. Read more by clicking here. 
On Tuesday, December 11, 2018, I issued the following statement after learning of the death of deported Vietnam War Army Veteran, Carlos Torres. 
“Carlos Torres served this country, and in return, this country failed him. After serving in the U.S. Army, on the front lines in the Vietnam War, Mr. Torres was denied a path to citizenship and deported. He fought for a home that turned him away, and in the end, he never saw that home again. There is no excuse for this. No military service member should die in vain. The Repatriate Our Patriots Act must be enacted into law so that this never happens again.” 
Prior to deportation, Mr. Torres resided in the Rio Grande Valley. In 2017, Congressman Gonzalez introduced H.R. 3429, the Repatriate Our Patriots Act, that would create a pathway to citizenship for deported veterans who held a clean record prior to military service. 
It is my honor to announce Alaina Garza (pictured below) as the winner of the 2018 Congressional App Challenge with her submission – Brain Tame. Ms. Garza, inspired by her own struggle with anxiety, created the application to help users combat stress through a series of questions and visual catharsis. “I want users to live life stress free,” Ms. Garza said. The Elsa, Texas native, 17, is a student at South Texas High School for Health Professions in Mercedes, Texas. After high school, she plans on attending college and pursuing a major in English with a minor in psychology. I thank Alaina for finding ways to utilize technology to help her peers through hard times and congratulate her on winning this year’s App Challenge! Way to go, Alaina! 
￼ 
Are you, or is someone you know, a current college student or recent college graduate interested in learning more about the legislative process and constituent services? If so, please apply for our congressional internship program, located in the 15th District of Texas and Washington, D.C. Spots for Spring 2019 are still available! Visit our website for more information by clicking the picture below. 
￼ 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.   

Sincerely,
￼
Vicente Gonzalez Member of Congress

Subject: My #1 Priority
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email 
￼ 
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
December 15, 2018


HAPPENING IN THE HOUSE
This week, the House passed the 2018 Farm Bill. The bill maintains several vital provisions to provide crop insurance, manage risk, increase loan rates, and cut burdensome red tape for our farmers and ranchers. Most importantly, the Farm Bill brings reassurance in times of need to the 2.1 million American farms that feed our country and the world. For Oklahoma’s farmers and ranchers, I am glad to see provisions that will help rural areas, such as improving rural broadband delivery and increasing funding for rural health projects that aim to combat the opioid epidemic. I was proud to support the passage of the Farm Bill on the House floor.
However, I am disappointed that Congress did not do more to reform the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by implementing commonsense work requirements. At a time when the job market has 7.1 million openings, there is no better time than now for Americans to find meaningful work. Read more via the McCarville Report here.
The House also considered and passed several bills out of the committee I sit on, the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The IMPROVE Act (H.R. 7217) provides states with the option under Medicaid of providing coordinated care for children with complex medical conditions through a health home. The IMPROVE Act also funds the Money Follows the Program, which is a Medicaid program to help individuals with disabilities transition from an institutional care setting back into their community. Additionally, we passed the Sickle Cell Disease and Other Heritable Blood Disorders Research, Surveillance, Prevention, and Treatment Act of 2018 (S. 2465), the PREEMIE Reauthorization Act of 2018 (S. 3029), and the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act of 2018 (H.R. 1318).
 GOVERNMENT FUNDING A number of government agencies will run out of funding on December 21st, unless Congress can reach an agreement. The president has requested $5 billion in border security for our southern border, but it isn’t clear if that will pass both chambers of Congress. If Congress does not reach an agreement before Friday, there will be a partial government shutdown.
Congress has already passed a number of funding bills, so the entire government will not shutdown. Roughly 75% of the government has already been funded. Left unfunded are the programs within Department of Agriculture, Department of Commerce, Department of Justice, Department of the Treasury, United States Postal Service, Department of Homeland Security, Department of the Interior, EPA, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Department of Transportation. If you have questions about how a partial shutdown might impact you, please reach out to one of my offices. 
PORT OF MUSKOGEE RECEIVES GRANT It’s great to see the Port of Muskogee receive a BUILD Grant to bring modern rail access for manifest and unit train service to the Port. A part of the McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System (MKARNS), the Port of Muskogee is a major driver of industrial and economic development in Muskogee and across the state of Oklahoma. I am proud to have worked alongside Senator Jim Inhofe to ensure the Port receives the assistance it needs to continue bringing quality jobs and new industry to the area.
OK IN DC 
￼
Enjoyed visiting with the Institute 
of Building Technology and Safety.
 
￼
Great to have Edward, Luanna, Angelic, 
Kloei, and Kaylee in town!
INTERN SPOTLIGHT Sarah Ferrell from Tahlequah leaves our Washington, D.C. office this week after serving as an intern during the fall semester. She’s headed back to Northeastern State University to finish up her degree in health care administration and business administration. A big thank you to Sarah for all of her help this semester!  
￼
Are you interested in a congressional internship? My Washington, D.C. office is currently accepting applications for the spring 2019 semester. Interns will have the opportunity to see the inner workings of Congress firsthand, assist legislative staff in policy research, work alongside my team to provide constituent services to Oklahomans in the Second District, and much more. For more information, contact my D.C. office at 202-225-2701 and ask to speak with the intern coordinator. Interested applicants can apply on my website at this link. 
WOTUS REPLACEMENT RULE The Waters of the United States (WOTUS) Rule has been detrimental to our country’s farmers and ranchers since the day it was put in place by the Obama Administration. The federal government has no business regulating every creek, ditch, and stream. This proposed replacement rule from the Trump Administration gives farmers, ranchers, and small business owners the power to take care of their backyards without the unnecessary red tape they face now. I applaud the Trump Administration for the proposed rule. Read more on the Western Caucus’s website here.
 WEEKLY WRAP-UP Above all, our country’s number one priority should be the safety and security of Americans. As your representative, I do not take lightly the responsibility to ensure our national security is strong. Watch the weekly wrap-up on my Facebook or YouTube page.  
￼
See more from this week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way.

Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin
Member of Congress

Subject: Today is Your Last Chance to Enroll in 2019 Health Coverage
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼

HOME
ABOUT MEMBER
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
 
The Washington Rundown 
TODAY, December 15, is the deadline to enroll in affordable, quality health insurance for 2019 under the Affordable Care Act.  North Carolinians seeking health insurance for themselves or their families are encouraged to visit HealthCare.Gov to compare plans and benefits, find the best prices, and sign up for coverage.  Despite a looming partial government shutdown, Republican House leadership has delayed a potential vote on a funding bill until the end of next week.  Lawmakers will return to Washington on Wednesday facing an end-of-the-week deadline to avoid a partial government shutdown, while they work to wrap up remaining legislative business to close out the 115th Congress.  Should Congress fail to reach an agreement by midnight on December 21, operations for roughly 25 percent of the government will shut down.  President Trump's demand for $5 billion to fund his border wall is still the sticking point for an agreement to keep the entire government open.  At the same time President Trump is arguing for the border wall, a 7-year-old girl from Guatemala died from dehydration and shock while in U.S. Border Patrol Custody last week. The deadline for North Carolinians who suffered damage during Hurricane Florence to apply for federal help has now been extended to Wednesday, December 19.  Individuals and businesses with uninsured losses from Hurricane Florence can register with FEMA online at DisasterAssistance.gov OR by calling the disaster assistance helpline at 1-800-621-3362 from 7am to 11pm ET. 
Absentee Ballot Fraud Probe Continues in NC's 9th District 
The North Carolina General Assembly on Wednesday approved a bill requiring new primary elections if the State Board of Elections calls for a new general election.  This bill follows allegations of absentee ballot fraud in North Carolina's Ninth Congressional District that have called the results of that race into question.   
Congressman Butterfield was joined by Reps. David Price (NC-04) and Alma Adams (NC-12) to release the following statement on the NC-09 developments: 

￼
Remember: Today is the Deadline to Enroll in 2019 Health Coverage 
The deadline to enroll in health coverage is today, December 15 – if you, your family, or someone you know needs health insurance for 2019, now is the time to act. 
Visit HealthCare.gov today to create an account and enroll in 2019 coverage. 
￼ 
￼ 
In The News 
The News & Observer: Everyone is readying for new election in NC’s 9th, but parties are sparring over primary  North Carolina’s state board of elections hasn’t yet ordered a new election in the state’s disputed 9th Congressional District, but Republicans and Democrats are already fighting over the rules governing a new vote. [...]
Said Price, Rep. G.K. Butterfield of Wilson, and Rep. Alma Adams of Charlotte issued a joint statement: “The Republican super majority in the General Assembly must understand that changing the law after the election, to require a new primary, is likely unconstitutional. This newly enacted legislation discredits North Carolina once again in the eyes of the Nation.” 
Atlanta Daily World: Sickle Cell Treatment Act of 2018 Passed in Congress, Now Awaits President’s Signature  On December 10, 2018, S.2465 – The Sickle Cell Disease and Other Heritable Blood Disorders Research, Surveillance, Prevention, and Treatment Act of 2018  – was passed by the Congress and now moves forward for the President to sign into law. [...] Sickle Cell Disease Association of America, Inc. thanks Senator Tim Scott (R-SC) and Senator Cory Booker (D-NJ) for their leadership and for introducing the bill on February 28, 2018, and we thank the bill’s co-sponsors Senator Doug Jones (D-AL), Senator Bill Cassidy (R-LA), Senator Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), and Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA). SCDAA also thanks Congressman Danny Davis (D-IL), a long-time champion for the sickle cell community; Congressman Michael Burgess (R-TX); and Congressman G.K. Butterfield (D-NC) for supporting this bill in the U.S. House of Representatives. In addition, we are grateful to the members of the Sickle Cell Caucus and to our key partners such as theAmerican Society of Hematology(ASH), Sick Cells,Sickle Cell 101, theSickleCellForum,#BoldLipsforSickleCell and theEveryLife Foundation.

Subject: Calling for Bold Action to Address Climate Change
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email


￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
There is no doubt that global climate change is real and poses a growing threat to our planet, our country, our Great Lakes and Wisconsin. 
This summer, our southwestern counties faced devastating flooding, and severe rainstorms like the ones experienced this year are only predicted to happen more frequently in Wisconsin as climate change intensifies.  
Recently, an Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report concluded that unless the current path of climate change is slowed, massive impacts - such as limited fresh water availability, sea-ice free Arctic summers, mass die-offs of coral reefs, and intense and unprecedented heat waves - will become reality as soon as 2040. 
The National Climate Assessment published this year echoes this alarming report, demonstrating evidence that the U.S. is already feeling the effects of climate change - concluding that our nation will suffer thousands of deaths and over $500 billion per year in crop damage, lost labor, and extreme weather damages by 2100. 
It is clear the consequences of climate change cannot be ignored. We have a moral obligation to accept these recent findings, take immediate steps to address the challenge of climate change and reaffirm our commitment to future generations to pass on a world better than we found it. 
That is why I joined my colleagues in sponsoring a Senate Resolution calling for bold action to combat climate change. 
Here in Wisconsin, climate change is already affecting both the Great Lakes ecosystem and our economy. Climate change has expanded the range of invasive species like Asian carp and zebra mussels, which pose a major threat to the ecology and economy of the Great Lakes by devastating the food chain and causing major damage to our ports, pipes and water infrastructure. With our natural resources supporting over $5 billion of activity in Wisconsin’s economy alone, acting now to combat climate change is not only an environmental imperative - it is also an economic necessity.
I refuse to sit on the sidelines, and it’s now up to all of us to embrace the moral responsibility and proud Wisconsin tradition of conservation we all share. While the threat of climate change may be daunting, we cannot let this challenge overwhelm us into inaction. Doing nothing is simply not an option and the longer we wait, the more costly climate change will be. 
I’m not giving up, so I hope you will join me in calling for bold action to combat climate change. Let’s continue our work together to confront this challenge and keep our promise to leave the next generation a safer, healthier world. 
Sincerely, 
￼ 
U.S. Senator for Wisconsin

Subject: Continuing the Fight Against WOTUS
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: December 15, 2018   ￼  I was proud to speak in support of the 2018 Farm Bill Conference Report before the House of Representatives passed it by a vote of 369-47. 
Continuing the Fight Against WOTUS 
Our nation’s natural resources have no better friend than farmers and ranchers whose livelihood depends on them. From growing crops to raising livestock, their long term success is dependent upon sustainable practices. This is why President Obama’s oppressive Clean Water Rule, also known as Waters of the United States (WOTUS), was unwelcome and even offensive to people throughout the Midwest.   WOTUS sought to greatly increase the EPA’s authority to regulate “ephemeral streams” - those which flow only when it rains or snow melts – by expanding the definition of navigable waterways under the Clean Water Act. However, a vast array of legal scholars, state officials, and federal judges have agreed this Obama-era regulation is both outside the will of Congress and downright unconstitutional.   It’s not at all difficult to imagine the ways in which an activist administration might use these expanded powers to issue a litany of burdensome and unnecessary regulations surrounding everything from irrigation ditches to water puddles. As a result of the EPA’s actions, I introduced a joint resolution to repeal WOTUS under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), which allows Congress to overrule any new regulations. The resolution easily passed both the House and Senate, but was vetoed by President Obama.   When President Trump took office, he attempted to roll back the rule almost immediately. Unfortunately, the courts intervened saying the current rule would have to be replaced with a completely new one, rather than rolled back. Much to the relief of farmers and ranchers across the country, the EPA announced a replacement rule this week which both honors past court decisions and includes a more appropriate definition of navigable waterways.  Under the new rule, the EPA will continue to do its job while respecting the rights of farmers and ranchers to steward our natural resources as they have for generations. I appreciate President Trump for his efforts to shield our agricultural producers from burdensome regulations and I’m proud to have played a part in bringing the Obama administration’s overreach to light. I look forward to this rule being finalized for the benefit of our rural economy. 
Sincerely,
￼  ADRIAN SMITH Member of Congress

CONDEMNING SYRIA, RUSSIA AND IRAN
￼ 
Lindsey - 
After seven years of war and the deaths of more than half of a million people, the atrocities of the Assad regime are still ongoing with the help of Russia and Iran. The United States must push for an end to the violence and suffering in Syria and hold the perpetrators accountable. 
That's why the House of Representatives just passed my bill condemning the Assad regime and its backers, including Russia and Iran, for their continued support of war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria. 
The resolution also calls upon the President and Secretary of State to work towards a sustainable political transition in Syria and a strategy to prevent a permanent Iranian presence in the region, while condemning Russia for their continued support of war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria. 
Getting this bill passed is progress, and we must continue to work with our partners to condemn the Assad regime’s horrific abuses against the Syrian people and counter Iran and Russia’s malign influence in the region. 
Watch this week's Week In Review to learn more:

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Saturday, December 15, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week my I attended various meetings and events with different individuals and organizations, including a meeting with representatives from the Consejo Coordinador Empresarial and a discussion with representatives from the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD) about reauthorizing the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS) program.
In the district, my staff attended numerous meetings and events, including the Laredo Motor Carriers Association Award Ceremony and the IRS National Tax Security Awareness Week at the SBA District Office in Harlingen.
I have also included a video from Consumer.gov that details simple and effective steps you can take to manage a monthly budget, especially during this time of extra spending.
As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Rep. Cuellar Meets with Consejo Coordinador Empresarial Representatives 
￼

On Tuesday, December 11, I met with representatives from the Consejo Coordinador Empresarial, an organization promoting economic growth in Mexico. As one of America’s largest trade partners, a healthy Mexican economy is beneficial to both countries, especially to the people of my district. Pictured from left are International negotiations coordinator of the Mexican private sector Moises Kalach, Congressman Henry Cuellar, President of Consejo Mexicano de Asuntos Internacionales Jaime Zabludovsky, and Managing Director of IQOM Sergio Gomez Lora.


Rep. Cuellar Meets with NACD to Discuss Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards 
￼

On Tuesday, December 12, I met with representatives from the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD) to discuss reauthorizing the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS) program, which will help keep hazardous chemicals out of the hands of dangerous people. I will continue to work towards improving the safety of my constituents and the American people. Pictured from left are Congressman Henry Cuellar, NACD Treasurer Edward Boss, NACD Chairman Tom Corcoran, and NACD Senior Manager of Legislative Affairs Douglas A. Leigh III. 


Rep. Cuellar Meets with North American Development Bank 
￼ 
On Wednesday, December 12, I met with representatives from the North American Development Bank (NADB) to discuss their efforts in the district and provide them with an legislative update on topics such as trade and the USMCA. Pictured from left are NADB Acting Managing Director Alex Hinojosa, Congressman Henry Cuellar, NADB Acting Deputy Manager Calixto Mateos, and NADB Director of Public Affairs Jesse Hereford.


Laredo Motor Carriers Association Award Ceremony 
￼

On Thursday, December 6, my Laredo District Staff attended the Laredo Motor Carriers Association (LMCA) Christmas Dinner and Award Ceremony. At the event, I was recognized for my continued support to the trucking industry and commitment to cross border trade. Pictured from left to right are: Vice-President of LMCA Gerardo “Jerry” Maldonado, Outreach Coordinator Francis Atwell, Executive Coordinator of LMCA Melissa Huddleston, and President of LMCA Ernesto Gaytan Jr. 


IRS National Tax Security Awareness Week at the SBA 
￼

On Monday, December 10, my Outreach Coordinator for Starr and Hidalgo Counties Nichole Hernandez attended the IRS National Tax Security Awareness Week at the SBA at their Regional Office in Harlingen. Pictured from left are Department of the Treasury-Special Agent Adriana Gomez , BBB South Texas Regional Office President, V.P Dolores Salinas, IRS Spanish Spokeswoman Central Region Irma Trevino, SBA- Lower Rio Grande Valley District Director Angela Burton, and Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez.


Staff Spotlight: Defense Fellow 
￼

I want to wish my Defense Fellow David Kolcun farewell and good luck as he takes on his new position as Air Force Chief Master Sergeant. He has been an invaluable asset to my team and we wish him the best on all his future endeavors. 


Intern Spotlight: Christopher Soto 
￼

Christopher Soto is a recent graduate from the University of North Texas, where he is majoring in Journalism and Political Science. He is originally from Dallas, Texas and resided in Washington D.C. for the duration of his internship. He is planning on returning to D.C. in the summer for another internship where he hopes to gain more experience for a career in law. To learn more about Christopher and my other interns, click here. 


Consumer.gov: Making a Budget 
￼

This video from Consumer.gov gives an informational overview about what you can do to organize and manage a monthly budget. The holidays are often a time where we spend more money than usual, so creating a budget can be helpful in keeping tabs on expenses. Please refer to the website for additional tips and resources to create and maintain a budget. 

 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

December 15, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review




December 11

"Present" Votes: I did something I usually don’t do as I voted present on two votes last night.
Yet, I believe these were the right votes because they both fit into the wisdom my parents gave me in asking that I remember that there’s a time and place for all things and that there’s a value in moderation…in not putting all your eggs in one basket.
Let me explain….
The first vote was in place to urge the Secretary of the Interior to include the site of the plane crash that killed Roberto Clemente in the National Register of Historic Places. This bill passed, 385-1, with myself and Tom Rice, of Myrtle Beach, voting “present”.
For those of you who don’t know Roberto Clemente’s life and legacy, it’s none other than remarkable. It’s certainly worth celebrating, remembering, and emulating... Click here to read more.
￼

￼
Click above to read the full statement

￼

December 12

Procedural Vote for the Farm Bill: Today the House voted on the rule for H.R. 2, the 2018 Farm bill. I voted against it, and it passed narrowly 206 to 203.
The rule is the mechanism by which the majority party controls debate on the floor. As such, it’s considered a procedural vote, and one typically votes with one’s party in support of procedural measures. In short, it’s a no-no to vote against the rule, and I rarely do.
But this rule breached a larger constitutional protocol that I think required me in this instance to vote as I did.
In a vote that was to proscribe the debate process for the farm bill, leadership quietly included a provision that would prevent a vote on Yemen. Let me say that again: on a vote setting up the debate for the farm bill, they included a provision that would prevent debate on Yemen.
I love Christmas and certainly love Christmas trees, but these sort of ornaments attached to what ought to be a straightforward bill are something that I have fought against consistently as a matter of principle. Click here to read more. 

￼


December 13

￼
Click above to read the article 


 Farm Bill Vote: Yesterday, the House voted on the conference report for H.R. 2, better known as the Farm Bill. I voted against it and it passed 369-47. The bill will cost about $85 billion a year for the next five years, and as a conservative, it should be telling that save for three Democrats, Democratic House members supported the bill unanimously. I believe it was a missed opportunity for reform, but with regard to farm bills, this seems to be a consistent refrain.
In fact, in my time in politics, farm bills have been interesting for the way they have been repetitive. They seem as certain as the tides in the Lowcountry. The tides come in and they go out. The temperatures may change around them. Sun or clouds may change. Rain or even snow may blanket these tides, but they stay unchanged in the way that they come in and they go out.
So it is with the farm bills. There is always much talk of things that will change and the way that we can move to a more market-based system in agricultural subsidies, and even require work requirements for able-bodied welfare recipients. But the farm bills and the programs it protects have proven to be remarkably resilient in political terms.
The farm bills’ political construction also needs to be remembered. Click here to read more.
￼

￼
 Click above to read the article

￼
December 14  House Passes the IMPROVE Act: Earlier this week, I cast a “yes” vote that’s worth noting on H.R. 7217, the IMPROVE Act. It would extend and fund the Medicaid “money follows the patient” program, which assists both elderly and child patients in making the transition from institutional settings to home or group care more conducive to healing.
The bill did what we need to do more of in government: Help people that actually need help. We live in a civilized society and there is a value to giving care where it is most needed. This is in strong contrast to what we saw last week in the farm bill where aid is provided to people perfectly capable of working and helping themselves.
The bill contained a number of intelligent cost-saving provisions that fully offset its cost, and it passed 400-11. Click here to read more.  




￼  ￼  ￼  ￼

Subject: Health care innovation
Message:
￼ 


Saturday, December 15, 2018 


Health care innovation  



Friend,
Welcome to your weekly update. As always, you can learn more about these and other legislative issue at my website: upton.house.gov. 
Health care innovation
On Thursday, my partner in health care innovation - U.S. Rep. Diana DeGette, D-Colorado - and I marked the second anniversary of the 21st Century Cures Act being signed into law by President Obama.
21st Century Cures began with the spark of hope and continues today – pushing health care and medical research in new and innovative ways. 
We’re seeing the results in action already: The Beau Biden Cancer Moonshot is working to accelerate progress in cancer prevention and screening, the All of Us Research Program has more than 100,000 people signed up to help advance precision medicine and develop more effective ways to treat disease, the BRAIN Initiative is revolutionizing how we understand the human brain, and the Regenerative Medicine Innovation Project is supporting clinical research on adult stem cells. 
21st Century Cures is also making needed reforms to our mental health system and at the FDA. We’re now able to get drugs and devices to market more efficiently – helping to address drug prices. Finally, 21st Century Cures has played a pivotal role in addressing the opioid epidemic by funding the fight at the state level – with more than $1 billion in grants to states in need.
21st Century Cures was truly a bipartisan effort from start to finish. Today we can reflect on how far we have come, but also it is a reminder of all the work that remains. Patients and families are counting on us. 
Learn more here.
Bipartisan Farm Bill advances 
On Wednesday, the U.S. House of Representatives voted to advance the Conference Report to Accompany H.R. 2, the Agriculture Improvement Act.
As I’ve listened to our local farmers, they want support and certainty and the bipartisan 2018 Farm Bill delivers that. But the Farm Bill is not just for our farmers and ranchers, it is truly for all Americans as our agriculture industry plays a vital role in ensuring we have access to a safe and affordable food supply. It’s also good to see that provisions cutting school lunch assistance program did not make the final version. Those provisions would have hurt Southwest Michigan kids and families. 
As our farmer friends continue to face challenges, it’s imperative we give them the tools they need to survive and thrive. Learn more here.
Have a great weekend and God bless, 
-Fred
￼
Fred Upton
Member of Congress

Subject: LAST DAY! Enroll Now
Message:
￼ 
  


Dear Lindsey,

DON’T WAIT! Today is the LAST day in the open enrollment period to get covered for 2019. Whether you’re uninsured and looking to find coverage or exploring the available options, find a plan that works for you and your family today!

Health insurance is there when you need it most, offering peace of mind during unexpected medical emergencies and routine preventative care appointments. The Marketplace offers comprehensive coverage that meets the needs of many Delawareans and plans are more affordable than you may think.

Visit www.HealthCare.gov to create an account through the Marketplace and find coverage that works with your budget before it’s too late. If you currently have health insurance from the Marketplace, now is your chance to review your coverage and ensure it’s the right plan for you.

If you have any questions about signing up or want to talk to a trained Marketplace navigator, free help is just a call or click away. To apply and enroll quickly online, visit www.HealthCare.gov or www.choosehealthde.com. You can also call the Marketplace call center 24 hours a day, 7 days a week at 1-800-318-2596, and a trained representative will be able to assist you in the enrollment process as well as to answer any questions you may have.

Act before midnight on December 15th to #GetCovered!

Sincerely, 

Lisa Blunt Rochester 
Member of Congress

Subject: Good News for Hoosier Farmers
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | CONTACT
GOOD NEWS FOR HOOSIER FARMERS
￼
Family farmers are the backbone of America, and their hard work keeps safe, nutritious, and affordable food on our tables.
We took a big step this week to give farmers the protections and certainty they need: Congress sent the Farm Bill to the president’s desk.
That’s good news for Hoosier farmers and rural communities, and it’s good news for our economy.
The bipartisan, five-year Farm Bill strengthens critical protections for Hoosier farmers, promotes ag exports, and provides certainty so local farm operations can grow and thrive. 
Once signed into law, the Farm Bill will help Hoosier farmers by:
	•	Protecting crop insurance;
	•	Reducing regulatory hurdles;
	•	Promoting agriculture exports;
	•	Supporting voluntary conservation efforts;
	•	Preparing for disease outbreaks; and
	•	Investing in rural broadband.
It also takes steps to improve SNAP so those who fall on hard times can build a bridge out of poverty, and it strengthens the program by allowing the administration to rein in states that abuse the waiver process. 
This legislation will give farmers the long-term certainty they need and help give Hoosiers a better chance to live the American Dream.
HELP FOR GROWING FAMILIES
￼
Roughly 1 in 10 babies born in the U.S. are born preterm. And more American women are dying of pregnancy-related complications than in any other developed country.
I believe every life is precious, and giving every child a healthy chance from the start is key to success later in life. That’s why I supported two important bills this week as Congress took bipartisan action to ensure safer and healthier outcomes for growing families.
The Prematurity Research Expansion and Education for Mothers who deliver Infants Early (PREEMIE) Reauthorization Act (S. 3029) will increase research and education on premature births. It will also promote screenings and treatment for expectant mothers with substance use disorders.
The Preventing Maternal Deaths Act (H.R. 1318) will also help Hoosier families by collecting data, conducting research, and finding tools to improve maternal health.
These two measures now head to the president’s desk for his signature. They will help communities, health providers, and government agencies work together to save lives. 
I look forward to continuing to find commonsense solutions to promote healthy families.
As always, it is a privilege to represent 2nd District Hoosiers in Congress.
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website and join me on social media:
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Sincerely,
￼
Jackie Walorski U.S. Congresswoman

Subject: Farm Bill Passage Brings Certainty to Rural America
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Farm Bill Passage Brings Certainty to Rural America
I am very proud one of the House Republicans’ final actions this Congress will be to ensure long-term certainty for rural America with today’s passage of the conference report for H.R. 2, the Farm Bill. I support this bipartisan agreement, which passed the House today by a vote of 369 to 47, because I will never apologize for taking care of our farmers. America wouldn’t be as strong as we are today without our agriculture community. With a decline in net farming income of 52 percent over the past five years and the average age of farmers drastically rising, we need to ensure our farmers have an adequate safety net to continue producing for generations to come. This bill contains wins for America’s farmers, ranchers, rural communities and consumers, and provides farmers with five years of much needed stability.   
This legislation includes critical provisions needed to maintain a strong safety net for the agriculture community. Specifically, it reauthorizes and improves critical crop insurance programs, expands trade promotion initiatives such as the Market Access Program to sell American goods abroad; and it ensures small family farms have access to research and agriculture extension programs to increase their crop yields. These programs all give our local farmers in East Tennessee the ability to access and compete in markets around the world.  
In recent years, our farmers have faced depressed market prices, drought and other natural disasters forcing our farmers to rely on a safety net to keep their businesses operating in lean years. This bill expands insurance by providing coverage for forage producers and makes improvements to whole farm revenue coverage for specialty crop producers. This legislation also enhances protections for dairy farmers, including those in East Tennessee, by ensuring our dairy safety net is accessible to producers of all sizes. Programs like Price Loss Coverage, Agriculture Risk Coverage, Commodity Loans, Dairy Margin Coverage, Livestock Disaster Programs and Crop Insurance all have been maintained or strengthened. It also includes vital funding for animal disease prevention and management initiatives to keep livestock – and consumers – healthy. This ensures public safety is our highest priority, and includes the stockpiling of foot-and-mouth disease vaccines should they ever be needed. 
Finally, I am pleased this bill includes the Tennessee Wilderness Act, a bill that I introduced in the House and worked with Senators Alexander and Corker to protect land in East Tennessee. This legislation will include wilderness protection for Big Laurel Branch in Carter and Johnson Counties and Sampson Mountain in Washington and Unicoi Counties, among other areas. This land was already part of Cherokee National Forest, but this wilderness designation will ensure the area remains protected for future generations.  
While I believe we should have done more with respect to work requirements for Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) recipients in the final bill, I was pleased the bill made some changes to the SNAP program integrity that will ensure current work requirements are harder to waive entirely. It seems to me that we should be encouraging all Americans to work who are able instead of simply providing unconditional assistance, particularly at a time where jobs are readily available.  
Still, the 2018 Farm Bill does include provisions that I believe will help East Tennessee’s farmers for the next 5 years. Over the past four years, I’ve held numerous meetings across the district with farmers and other local agriculture stakeholders, and I am hopeful this legislation will meet the needs of our area. It will now head to President Trump’s desk for signature.   

Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

Subject: Three Things You May Have Missed This Week
Message:
￼  


Friends,  A lot happened this week in the Senate. From passing legislation supporting farmers and ranchers to securing important resources to repair damaged roadways in West Virginia and so much more, the Senate was focused on a whole range of issues. Among the top issues was border security. Securing our borders should be a no-brainer, which is why I’ve been working hard to deliver the Department of Homeland Security and law enforcement the resources they need to keep Americans safe.  Click here or the image below for more, and keep scrolling for additional updates. 
￼ 
Connecting Rural America  Connectivity is essential for individuals, families, students, businesses, and communities to succeed. Without access to reliable and affordable high-speed internet, rural communities and rural states like West Virginia are being left behind—especially when it comes to education, health care, job creation and retention, and overall economic potential. Earlier this week, I joined Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue in announcing a new rural broadband program, known as the ReConnect Program, which will help encourage high-speed internet e-connectivity in rural communities. Programs like this one and other efforts I’ve been working to promote through my Capito Connect initiative can help us close the digital divide, improve the lives of those living in our rural communities, and grow and diversify our economy. That’s exactly why I worked hard to ensure funding for the ReConnect Program was included in the FY2018 funding agreement and will continue to push for similar resources.  How it works: USDA will offer up to $600 million in loans and grants to help build broadband infrastructure in rural America.  Who can apply: Telecommunications companies, rural electric cooperatives and utilities, internet service providers and municipalities may apply to USDA’s new program for funding to connect rural areas that currently have insufficient broadband service.  Click here to learn more about the program, application requirements and deadlines, and additional USDA resources to help potential applicants.  Revitalizing West Virginia Communities  You’ve probably heard me talk about Opportunity Zones and how they can be a game changer for West Virginia. I really do believe this a way to drive economic growth in the parts of our state that need it most. Just this week, I joined Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and several of my colleagues to discuss Opportunity Zones and the positive impact they can have on our state and local economies. 
￼ 
[Graphic from The White House’s official Twitter account.] 
President Donald Trump has also been a strong proponent of this provision and has taken several steps to make sure we seize this opportunity. Just this week, the president created the White House Opportunity and Revitalization Council, which will help maximize revitalization of and coordination for needy communities in West Virginia and throughout America. I’m proud President Trump has prioritized economic development and is encouraging innovative solutions like Opportunity Zones, and I’ll continue working with the administration, as well as local and state leaders, to grow the economy and create more jobs and opportunity throughout our state. Click here to learn more.  Securing Our Borders  Protecting and securing our borders is something I have long been committed to. As head of the subcommittee that determines funding for the Department of Homeland Security, I’ve worked hard to make sure they have the resources they need to accomplish that; and the government funding bill I authored this year provides significant funding—the amount the administration had requested—to support our national security priorities. Failure to better secure our border will have consequences for all American communities, including West Virginia. I spoke about this on the Senate floor earlier this week and outlined exactly what the problem is, how it’s impacting communities in West Virginia and across America, and why a border wall system works. Click here to watch the speech and click here or the image below to hear what I had to say about the issue on FOX News. 
￼ 
How Can We Help?  Whether you need help with a casework issue or have a question about scheduling a meeting at one of my offices, my staff and I are ready to assist you. Learn more about the services we offer at www.capito.senate.gov.  You can also submit your feedback and share your stories with me by visiting my “Share Your Stories” webpage here: www.capito.senate.gov/ShareYourStories.  Social Media Recap 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Join me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for regular updates and photos.  Sincerely, 
￼ 
Shelley Moore Capito United States Senator

Dear Friend,  
Do you need health insurance or need to change your coverage? 
You have until midnight tonight to enroll or change your plan for 2019. If you have not signed up, go to www.healthcare.gov and find a plan that works for you.  
More than 9,000 uninsured Granite Staters can qualify for tax credits that would completely eliminate monthly premiums for a Bronze-level plan. Thousands more are eligible for tax credits to significantly reduce premiums for a variety of plans. For consumers who want help with enrollment over the phone, you can call 1-800-318-2596. 
Health care is critical for every Granite Stater so it’s important that we make sure our friends and family are covered.

Subject: Farm Bill 2018
Message:
News from Representative Crawford 
￼ 
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   
￼
Farm Bill 2018 
Given the importance of agriculture to Arkansas’s economy, I am pleased that both the House and Senate have passed the farm bill and that it now awaits the President’s signature. Farmers will have certainty for the next 5 years knowing they have a food security system that maintains reference prices and risk management programs for challenging economic times. While a strong safety net helps our farmers get through challenging times, the best way to improve prices is to open up new markets to sell surplus goods. I applaud the provision which allows trade promotion programs to be used towards improving our trade outlook with Cuba.  This is a step in the right direction for our nation’s relationship with Cuba, and I look forward to building on this progress in the 116th Congress. This farm bill eliminates burdensome SAM/DUNS requirements across several USDA agencies. It also reflects the realities of Arkansas farming families by ensuring cousins, nieces, and nephews actively engaged in a family farming operation are eligible for USDA programs. 
The farm bill is important for those engaged in production agriculture but also includes key provisions that address issues facing our rural communities such as the opioid crisis and food deserts. While the opioid crisis needs a multi-pronged solution, the farm bill takes an important first step by setting aside funds for rural areas that face unique addiction challenges. To address food deserts, I worked with the House Agriculture Committee Chairman to create a food access liaison at USDA. The liaison will be tasked with coordinating USDA programs aimed at improving Americans’ access to quality food and providing technical assistance to community leaders who work to improve the lives of those living in food deserts.
For too long, rural America has been left behind as the rest of the Nation moves forward. I’m proud to have voted “Yes” on this farm bill, because it signals to our farmers, ranchers, and rural constituencies that we recognize their potential to achieve economic prosperity too. 
FAQ (What folks have been calling/texting my office about this week)
Q: Where do you stand with the upcoming border wall funding vote?  A: Securing our borders provides an unparalleled return on investment in terms of national security and we cannot have true immigration reform without a border wall. If we continue to grant amnesty and even citizenship to large groups of people without first securing our borders then we will continue to have this issue every several years. It is unfortunate that this issue has reached the point where further delay could cause a partial government shutdown but now is the time for my colleagues to come to the table and get the job done. 
You can text me legislative concerns or questions at 870-292-6747
￼ 
KASU
NYIT, Rep. Rick Crawford's Office in Healthcare Fellowship

The NYIT College of Osteopathic Medicine at Arkansas State University is in a partnership with the office of Representative Rick Crawford.  The fellowship program will assess the usage of federal funds in the Delta region and ensure they are benefitting residents as intended. KASU News Director Johnathan Reaves sat down with the Dean, Dr. Shane Speights.  Before Reaves asked him about the fellowship, Speights commented on how this academic year has been. Click on the Listen button for the entire interview.

KARK
Boost for AR Agriculture with Congress Passage of Farm Bill

First District Rep. Rick Crawford issued this statement on the Farm Bill's passage:
“Given the importance of agriculture to Arkansas’ economy, I’m pleased to see the passage of the 2018 Farm Bill. This farm bill provides important updates to our food security system, delivers a robust crop insurance system, removes burdensome SAM/DUNs requirements for farm programs, invests in the vitality of our rural communities, and makes progress in our efforts to allow agriculture commodities to be exported to Cuba. Food security is a matter of national security, and a nation that cannot feed itself is a nation in trouble. This Farm bill ensures American farmers and ranchers will continue to produce a safe, affordable food and fiber supply for all Americans.”
Rep. Crawford is a member of the House Committee on Agriculture as well as the Chairman of Subcommittee General Farm Commodities and Risk Management. He also served as a Conferee for the 2018 Farm Bill.

Talk Business and Politics
Trump administration rolls back Clean Water Act rules, environmental groups condemn action

U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford, R-Jonesboro, earlier in June 2017 told Talk Business & Politics he was pleased with the decision to change the WOTUS rules, saying the Obama administration overreached with water rules to the detriment of rural communities.
“I think we have to dispel the myth that WOTUS was about clean water. We all want clean water, and characterizing opposition to WOTUS as being against clean water is an incredible oversimplification. The fact is, WOTUS was vague, poorly written, and an unprecedented expansion of federal regulation that didn’t take into consideration the livelihoods of many folks living in rural America,” Crawford said.
“WOTUS would have subjected producers and landowners to jurisdictional challenges and unprecedented levels of compliance costs. It’s a relief to all of us that the new administration is listening to affected stakeholders and will be scrapping the rule,” added the Northeast Arkansas congressman.
￼ 
TB&P - Baptist Memorial Health and Jonesboro DO school reach partnership deal

KAIT 8 - “Girls in STEM” receive grant from Ritter Family Endowment

KJNB - Black Oak Arkansas Prepares for New Museum

Subject: Latest from Lamar: Up to half of health care spending is unnecessary
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Republican Congress Working on Solutions for Tennesseans:
	•	Good news for Tennessee’s 340,000 farmers: This week, Congress passed the Farm bill, which will support the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) agriculture, rural development, and conservation programs that benefit farmers across Tennessee, as well as agricultural research at Tennessee’s universities to help farmers find better ways to grow their crops.
	•	The legislation also includes the Tennessee Wilderness Act, which will protect 20,000 acres of federal land in the Cherokee National Forest as “wilderness,” where Tennesseans can roam and enjoy nature. This designation will not only better protect ecosystems and watersheds, but also benefit the diverse recreational value of these areas, which is a crucial part of East Tennessee’s economy.
Important news from this past week:
	•	In Tennessee, about 11 percent of babies are born preterm. This week, the U.S. House of Representatives reauthorized legislation I introduced that will help reduce infant deaths and improve the health of infants by continuing research and education programs aimed at preventing preterm births.
	•	Spring Hill received a $25 million federal grant of for a new I-65 interchange to reduce heavy traffic congestion. It’s not a secret, traffic congestion in and around the Nashville area is a headache -- right now, if you take I-65 from Spring Hill to Nashville, you’re probably late to work because you’re sitting in at least an hour of traffic.This grant will help create a new avenue for Middle Tennesseans to get to work more quickly.  
Up to half of America’s health care spending is unnecessary 
This week, I asked leading health care experts, economists, doctors, nurses, patients, hospital administrators, state regulators and legislators, governors, employers, insurers, and innovators to identify specific ideas about how to reduce health care costs for taxpayers, employers, and families.
Last July, at the second in a series of five hearings I chaired on reducing health care costs, Dr. Brent James, a member of the National Academy of Medicine, testified that 30 percent, and probably as much as 50 percent of all the money spent on health care is unnecessary. That startled me. While this problem can’t be solved in Washington alone, my top focus as chairman of the Senate health committee for the next two years will be to reduce the cost of health care in the United States. I have asked these experts to send as many specific legislative, regulatory, or sub-regulatory solutions as possible, in priority order and in writing, by March 1, 2019. The federal government is not going to lower the cost of health care overnight, but I believe there are steps we can take that would make a real difference to American families. That might be two or three big steps, or a dozen smaller ones, but we shouldn’t let this opportunity to make progress pass us by.
 
￼
 
 
I sat down with Mike Allen of Axios Media to discuss health care costs and the important role Congress can play in reducing the price of care for American families. Watch our discussion here.
 
 
Celebrating the grand opening of DENSO’s new manufacturing facility in Maryville
￼
This week, I attended the grand opening ceremony of a new DENSO manufacturing facility in Maryville. In 1917, Alcoa came from Pittsburgh and built a big aluminum smelting plant in Blount County. The residents were so upset they tarred and feathered the mayor and ran him out of town. But, it wasn’t long before Blount Countians realized Alcoa was good for the community – the company brought good-paying jobs to East Tennessee and suddenly families found themselves making good wages. Just as Alcoa did in the last century, in this century DENSO has provided better jobs that mean stronger families, better schools, stronger communities and safer neighborhoods—something for which every single Blount Countian can be grateful. This week’s grand opening is just one more accomplishment to add to DENSO’s long history of success – a success story I know will last for generations to come.
 
￼
 
 
It was good to meet with Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn Wednesday ahead of her swearing-in ceremony to the U.S. Senate in January. We will be a great team for Tennessee, and I look forward to working together!
 
 
Farm bill is good news for Tennessee’s 340,000 farmers 
Agriculture is one of Tennessee’s most important industries, with more than 66,000 farms contributing approximately $74 billion each year to our state’s economy. This week, I voted for the Farm bill, which is good news for Tennessee’s 340,000 farmers. This legislation supports U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) agriculture, rural development, and conservation programs that benefit farmers across Tennessee as well as agricultural research at Tennessee’s universities to help farmers find better ways to grow their crops.This legislation will help provide much-needed certainty to farmers in Tennessee and across the country, which is one of the reasons it is supported by the Tennessee agriculture community, including the Tennessee Farm Bureau, Tennessee Soybean Association, Tennessee Cattleman’s Association, Tennessee Farmer’s Cooperative and other agriculture and conservation groups. I look forward to President Trump signing it into law. 
 
Tennessee Wilderness Act on track to become law
Included in the Farm bill that passed this week was the Tennessee Wilderness Act, and the legislation is on track to become law. The legislation will protect 20,000 acres of federal land in the Cherokee National Forest as “wilderness,” where Tennesseans can roam and enjoy nature. This is land in East Tennessee that's already managed as wilderness, but not made a part of the wilderness law. Designation as wilderness will not only better protect ecosystems and watersheds, but also benefit the diverse recreational value of these areas, which is a crucial part of East Tennessee’s economy. I thank Senator Corker, Congressman Roe and the many Tennesseans who’ve gotten in touch with us about making the Tennessee Wilderness Act law.
 
￼
 
 
 
It was great to have Governor-elect Bill Lee and his wife, Maria, come to my office while he is in town to meet with President Trump. Bill struck a chord with Tennesseans, and I look forward to working with him to continue Governor Haslam’s excellent leadership of our state.
 
 
Trump Administration taking next step to end Washington’s excessive regulation of Tennessee farmers’ mud puddles
The Trump Administration’s new proposed Waters of the U.S. rule is good news for Tennessee farmers as it would end Washington’s excessive regulation on waters, streams and wetlands. I’ve been fighting the Obama Administration regulation since it was announced in 2015 because it gave the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers the ability to regulate nearly all of the water in the country down to a farmer’s mud puddle. It also raised costs for Tennessee families, farmers and businesses. I’m glad President Trump has changed this regulation, and I know farmers in Tennessee and across the country are too.
 
Reducing infant deaths and improving infant health
The U.S. House of Representatives this week passed legislation I sponsored to reduce infant deaths and improve infant health by continuing research and education programs aimed at preventing preterm births. In Tennessee, about 11 percent of babies are born preterm. Since this legislation was first signed into law in 2006, this legislation has helped improve our understanding of premature births and support health care professionals caring for these infants. Now that the House has passed this vital legislation, I look forward to President Trump signing it into law soon so we can continue to give more babies the chance at long and healthy lives.
 
￼
 
 
For almost 10 years, Congressman Diane Black has served Tennessee’s 6th district well. She’s one of Tennessee’s bright stars, and I was honored to speak at her portrait unveiling this week.
 
 
 
Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:
CQ Roll Call: Alexander Seeks Proposals for Health Costs Legislation
Bloomberg: Trump, Senate Priorities Aligned to Lower Health-Care Costs
Bristol Herald Courier: March of Dimes Welcomes House Passage of PREEMIE Reauthorization Act & Maternal Mortality Bill
Exchange Monitor: Alexander Looks to Remain Chair of Appropriations Energy & Water Panel
Columbia Daily Herald : $25 million grant to fund Spring Hill I-65 interchange
 
Be as committed to military men and women as military men and women are committed to our country.
