Subject: Holiday greetings to our troops
Message:
Email not displaying correctly? Click here.
  ‌   ‌ 
 

This Week in Congress
December 14, 2018

• Holiday greetings to our troops
• $10.1M for water, sewer projects
• Marianas micro-grants in farm bill
• Yutu updates
• NOAA: Marianas coral reefs 'fair'
• Interparliamentary visitors
• Welcoming Ambassador Susaia
• DHS rule threatens child nutrition
• Protecting child workers from harm
• Opportunities
• Legislative Highlights
 
 

Holiday greetings to our troops. Our brave service men and women overseas are always on my mind, especially during the holidays. This week, at the American Red Cross Holiday Mail for Heroes event I wrote cards for our troops stationed in Kuwait and Iraq. I thanked these heroes for their sacrifices and wished them a safe and joyous holiday season. 
 
 
 

$10.1M for water, sewer projects

The Commonwealth Utilities Corporation got $10.1 million for water and sewer infrastructure this week. The money is especially useful now as CUC works to restore water service after Super Typhoon Yutu. As of June, CUC was supplying 96 percent of Saipan with 24-hour water, a welcome change from my first year in Congress, when only 25 percent of households had water around the clock. I was able to change the funding formula for the Clean Water and Safe Drinking Water State Revolving Funds, so that beginning in 2010 the average grant to the Marianas went from $1 million per year to over $6 million. In fact, this year's total is $7.1 million, plus another $3 million in carryover that was re-obligated back to CUC. All together, that is an increase of $3.8 million over 2017 for Marianas water infrastructure and $73 million in total since the formula change went into effect. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, which administers the water grant funds, also awarded $2.1 million to the CNMI Bureau of Environmental and Coastal Quality. Congratulations, CUC and BECQ! 
 

Marianas micro-grants in farm bill

A proposal by Senator Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) to provide micro-grants in Alaska, the Marianas, and other non-continental areas was included in the farm bill passed by the House and Senate this week. The grants are meant to increase local gardening and animal husbandry in areas that import much food. Grants can be up to $5,000 for an individual and $10,000 for a food bank, Head Start program, school, or similar entities. $250,000 will be available in the Marianas in 2019. The Agricultural Improvement Act of 2018, which President Trump has yet to sign, also prohibits the slaughter of dogs and cats for human consumption and extends the national ban on animal fighting to include the U.S. territories. The representatives from Guam, the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, and I all opposed the animal fighting ban because of its effect on cockfighting. The provision had too much bipartisan support, however. Perhaps, if the Commonwealth Legislature had acted on Rep. Ed Propst’s Animal Protection Act, H.B. 20-24, last year we could have used it to help defeat the ban. Now it is too late. 
 
 
 

Typhoon Yutu relief updates

Power
The Commonwealth Utilities Corporation estimates 63 percent of Saipan customers have grid power. On Tinian, about 20 percent of electricity has been restored.
 
Water
Saipan has 95 percent of its wells producing water. Tinian has all of its water service restored.

Tents
1,344 emergency tents have been installed on Saipan. Friday, December 14 was the last day to submit right of entry forms. The TETRIS program has closed on Tinian, with 202 tents installed.

Schools
Classes have started for all public school students, including online courses for the PSS Distance Education Program. Northern Marianas College classes have resumed at Saipan Southern High School in Koblerville.
 
 
 

NOAA: Marianas coral reefs ‘fair’ 

The coral reefs around our islands are in only “fair” condition and continue to be threatened by climate change, unsustainable fishing, pollution, and overuse, according to a new report by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The NOAA Coral Reef Conservation Program assessment of the Northern Marianas Islands coral reefs covers the period 2012-2017. Coral reefs are critical to the people of the Marianas for cultural and economic reasons. They are a source of food for both subsistence and commercial use, provide opportunities for recreational tourism, and protect our islands from storms. The report highlights improvements made by 3 Conservation Action Plans focusing on stormwater management in Garapan, erosion and sedimentation at Laolao Bay, and reforestation on Rota. Individually, we can also all do more by fishing responsibly, keeping household chemicals out of the water, avoiding physical damage to reefs, and reducing our carbon footprint. Let’s make sure our grandchildren can enjoy the coral reef.
 
 

Interparliamentary visitors. Chairman Wu Yuliang and other members of the Supervisory and Judicial Affairs Committee of China’s National People’s Congress met with me on Thursday. During its visit to the United States, the group has been particularly interested in learning how our nation manages corrections facilities. We also discussed China’s activities in the South China Sea, trade issues, and the importance of maintaining good relations between our two countries. 
 
 

His Excellency Akillino H. Susaia (center), Ambassador of the Federated States of Micronesia to the United States, met with me on Wednesday. We discussed the 2023 expiration of the U.S.-Micronesia Compact and pledged to work together on the issues confronting our Pacific region. The new ambassador was accompanied by his Deputy Chief of Mission, Jackson Soram. Thank you, Ambassador Susaia, for your visit.
 

DHS rule threatens child nutrition

Non-U.S. citizen families should not have to choose between providing healthy food for their children and protecting their immigration status. That is why I joined 16 of my fellow Democrats in the House Committee on Education and the Workforce in a letter opposing the Department of Homeland Security’s proposed changes to the definition of “public charge.” The new proposal would allow DHS to deny status to immigrants based on their use of certain public benefits such as food stamps, Medicaid, or Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) benefits. The rule threatens many children’s access to needed benefits at home and at school. And the rule makes it tougher for schools to use the community eligibility provision, which streamlines the process for allowing all children in high-poverty schools and communities to receive free meals.
 

Protecting our child workers from harm

The Trump administration wants to take away protections for teenagers working in hazardous industries, such as health care, a move I joined over 30 of my colleagues this week in opposing. The Fair Labor Standards Act prohibits 16 and 17-year-olds from certain jobs deemed dangerous by the evidence-based research of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. The Trump administration wants to ignore that evidence. See our letter to Labor Secretary Alex Acosta disagreeing with the proposal to alter child labor laws in a way that puts teenagers at risk.

In the News: A spouse’s love lives through Alzheimer’s advocacy
 
 
From Cherokee Tribune & Ledger-News: 

When Ruthellyn Kupsky suffered a stroke in 2001, her husband Fritz said she recovered fairly well. Her recovery from knee surgery in 2005 was different, Kupsky said. “Ruthellyn’s rehabilitation was difficult. She became uncommunicative. You’d have to classify it as dementia,” he said. “She loved to read and she became severely depressed. It was a struggle for me to keep her up for more than six hours.”

Ruthellyn Kupsky lost the use of one hand and used a wheelchair to get around. During that time Kupsky sought help from the Cherokee County Caregiver’s Assistance Network group (offered through Cherokee County Senior Services), and to get someone to stay with his wife while he attended caregiver meetings.

Subject: Rep. Grothman Newsletter - Backdoor Spending
Message:
￼ 
  

Backdoor Spending
This week at an Oversight and Government Reform Committee hearing, I questioned experts on “backdoor spending”, which is federal agency spending that occurs outside of the federal appropriations process. This means that federal bureaucrats are deciding how tax dollars are being spent with no Congressional oversight. Due to prior Congresses ceding power to bureaucrats, “backdoor spending” has increased by 88 percent since 1994.
I strongly believe that all spending should have Congressional oversight in order to stay accountable to you, the voter. Backdoor spending is a serious issue and must be curbed. We cannot allow federal bureaucrats to determine where and how tax dollars are being spent without approval or oversight from Congress. It is not fair to hardworking taxpayers. I will be sure to continue the dialogue on backdoor spending and urge the Committee to further investigate how we can put an end to this. For more on my line of questioning and full remarks click here. 
￼


Veterans Tax Fairness Act
This past July, over 130,000 veterans throughout the country were informed that they were eligible for a refund from a lump-sum disability severance payment that was inadvertently taxed. This refund is made possible by The Combat-Injured Veterans Tax Fairness Act. This act provides tax relief to veterans through a refund of taxes paid on disability severance payments.

Military service members eligible for the tax refund under the Combat-Injured Veterans Tax Fairness Act include any veteran who discontinued military service after January 17, 1991 and received a one-time disability severance payment, which, at the time, was included as income on their tax return. I support this tax refund for military service members as it provides well-deserved tax relief to soldiers who have served our country and its people.

The Department of Defense is in the process of administering those letters to the veterans eligible for the tax relief and the IRS has released information on how to ensure ones disability severance pay refund will be distributed to them. Click here for full information including a complete set of instructions on how to help veterans obtain their disability severance pay refund. 

Farm Bill Passage
This week, Congress passed the Farm Bill and it now heads to President Trump's desk for approval. The 2018 farm bill supports farmers, protects crop insurance and conservation programs, invests in efforts to expand foreign markets, and prioritizes agricultural research and rural development. 

This bill is critical to providing all stakeholders, including farmers, ranchers and consumers, as well as the sectors and industries that rely on them, with a consistent playing field over the next five years. Not only does it provide farmers with stability and support, but it also addresses the needs of the modern farming industry. 

One of the changes made to dairy policy in the new Farm Bill requires the USDA to establish regionally located dairy innovation centers to assist dairy farmers with diversifying their products to appeal to the modern market. Additionally, the new Farm Bill legalized and provided crop insurance for industrial hemp, a commodity that I have been fighting for, and will boost Wisconsin's agricultural outputs. Overall, the Farm Bill addresses many of the contemporary concerns of the agriculture industry and provides stability to farmers across the country. 

Weekly Roundup
Instead of walking to my next meeting indoors, I decided to get some fresh air. Its always a pleasure to walk by such a beautiful building!

￼

Worker earnings growth is at 3.2%, the highest level since 2010, and is far outpacing inflation.

￼

Merry Christmas to the brave men and women keeping our country safe overseas! And thanks to American Red Cross for getting these letters to our troops.

￼

￼

Contact Me 
As your congressman, I’m here to serve you. If you have any questions please don’t hesitate to reach out to my offices in Fond du Lac and Washington. If you enjoyed this newsletter be sure to forward it to your family and friends so they can stay informed on what I’m doing in Washington and the 6th District.

Sincerely,
￼
Member of Congress

Subject: The Justice Center Needs a DOJ Investigation
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼ 
WEBSITE  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   CONTACT ME  |   ABOUT TOM  |   
￼
 
CNN Interview-12.11.18  Hardball with Chris Matthews-12.11.18  4 US House reps seek federal probe of NY agency for disabled- MyTwinTiers.com  Congressmen call for investigation into agency for protecting people with special needs- 13WHAM-TV 
4 US House reps seek federal probe of NY agency for disabled- Finger Lakes Times 
Reed requests federal investigation of State Justice Center- Evening Observer
Four Congressional reps call for federal investigation of Justice Center- Spotlight News  NY reps ask DOJ to investigate agency for 'failure' to protect disabled- Albany Times Union
Lawmakers, FDA push for more insulin options, cheaper prices- Newsweek 
Rep. Tom Reed says new Farm Bill will help small dairy farmers- Olean Times Herald
 

Dear Neighbor,
I recently had a call with Michael Carey, whose son with autism was smothered to death by a state employee.
During the call, I was made aware how Governor Cuomo’s Justice Center swept crimes like murder and the abuse of people with disabilities by state employees under the rug.
In fact, nearly 1,400 allegations related to staff abuses, patient neglect, sexual assaults and patient deaths have been reported to the New York State Justice Center. 
Yet the Justice Center investigated less than 2.5 percent of these cases.
These victims matter and they deserve justice. Also, those who depend daily on state care need someone to stand up for them. This is why I took action and have requested the Department of Justice investigate the lack of prosecutions, referrals and due process violations that have been alleged and recommend a course of action.
What is happening now is not acceptable.
Our hope is to shine a bright light on these unreported crimes so our friends and neighbors who have suffered at the hands of the Justice Center receive closure and future crimes can be prevented.
As always, if our office can ever be of assistance, please do not hesitate to reach out. We are here to listen, take action and help. 
Until next time,
￼
Tom

Subject: Davis Announces the Gregg and Livingston Harper Congressional Internship Program for Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities
Message:
￼ 
PROUD TO SERVE MISSISSIPPI’S THIRD DISTRICT 
Dear Friend,

On Tuesday, my friend and colleague, Congressman Rodney Davis formally renamed the Congressional Internship Program for Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities (CIPIID) to the Gregg and Livingston Harper Congressional Internship Program for Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities. 

My son, Livingston Harper, has served as the inspiration for me during my time in Congress to focus on improving the lives of those with Intellectual Disabilities (ID). When I came to Congress and realized there was no internship program for individuals with ID, I worked with the Committee on House Administration to begin a program back in 2010. I and many others on Capitol Hill have been positively impacted by the influence and hard work of these interns. I am grateful to the Committee’s future Ranking Member, Rodney Davis, for seeing that the program will continue under his leadership.

I wanted to take this time to share with you some highlights in photographs: 

￼

Congressman Glenn Thompson, Livingston Harper, Congressman Rodney Davis, and Congressman Gregg Harper discuss the announcement for the Gregg and Livingston Harper Congressional Internship Program for Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities. 

￼

Congressman Thompson, Congressman Harper, and Congressman Davis hear about the experiences of the interns from Mason Life for the end of the year event. 

￼

Congressman Davis expresses his gratitude to Congressman Harper for his leadership over the past ten years. 

￼

Congressman Harper recognizes his first CIPIID intern, Ryan, for helping pave the way for all the Mason Life interns who have served on Capitol Hill.  

God Bless,

￼

Gregg Harper
Member of Congress

Subject: Protecting Our Dams & A New Farm Bill
Message:
News from Representative Newhouse
￼

Home
About
Contact 
Issues & Legislation
Media Center 
Constituent Services
For Students 

Protecting Our Dams 
￼ 
This week, Governor Inslee proposed $750,000 in the state budget to support a task force to study breaching the Lower Snake River dams. Rep. McMorris Rodgers and I released the following statement in response:  
"The people of Eastern Washington whose livelihoods depend on these dams should not be collateral damage for anyone's presidential ambitions. The Governor does not have the authority to breach our federal dams on the Lower Snake River, and allocating state taxpayers' funds to consider breaching them would be wasteful. Congress has the sole authority to authorize breaching our federal dams, and as representatives of Eastern Washington communities that depend on the many benefits they provide, breaching them is out of the question. We commit to do everything in our power to save our dams."  
The Federal Columbia River Power System provides irreplaceable benefits for our local communities and economies from clean, affordable energy to transportation of goods and irrigation. We have spent billions of dollars to ensure that dams and salmon can co-exist. Congress is taking steps to boost salmon recovery, and just this week, we sent the Endangered Salmon Predation Prevention Act to the President's desk to protect our salmon from non-native, predatory sea lions.  
A New Farm Bill 
￼ 
I am proud to announce that, this week, Congress approved the 2018 Farm Bill. I voted earlier this year to support the previous House version of a Farm Bill, but now both the House and the Senate have agreed on this bill that will give farmers certainty and relief for the next 5 years. As a third-generation Yakima Valley farmer, I know the Farm Bill plays an enormously important role in Central Washington's agriculture economy by delivering a secure safety net for farmers and providing for research that keeps us on the cutting edge of innovation. 
￼ 
Click here to watch me speak in support of the Farm Bill. 
Earlier this year, I traveled across Central Washington on a Farm Bill Tour to hear first-hand from farmers and ranchers from every county in the 4th Congressional District about their priorities for the legislation. I am pleased to be able to deliver a strengthened market access program to improve exports across the globe, improved crop insurance and coverage for specialty crop producers, an increase in funding for agricultural research, and an improved dairy safety net for dairies of all sizes. 
While I would have preferred to include stronger provisions to improve nutrition programs and forestry management, farmers needed action sooner rather than later. Click here to learn more. 
Thank You, Sheriff Turner 
￼ 
Click here to watch my speech on the House floor. 
Walla Walla County Sheriff John Turner honorably served the public in his role for eight years, and he dedicated himself to working to make his community safer. He sought to provide 24/7 patrol coverage, re-establish the K9 program, address gang activity in the county, and proactively address other public safety concerns. I am grateful for Sheriff Turner's tremendous service to the people of Walla Walla County and Washington state.  
Holiday Mail for Heroes 
￼ 
I joined the American Red Cross to write letters of thanks to troops who will spend the holidays away from home and family. The men and women of our Armed Forces sacrifice so much to defend our freedoms, and our nation is grateful.  
#FlashbackFriday to Farm Bill Friday 
￼ 
I remained optimistic that Congress would approve a Farm Bill, and in September, the House Agriculture Committee featured me in their Farm Bill Friday series. I spoke about the important impact the Farm Bill has on Central Washington's economy and the livelihood of its communities, and I am proud that Congress has delivered. Click here to watch. 
Thank you for reading this e-news update. It is an honor and privilege to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Dan Newhouse Member of Congress

Constituents are always welcome to visit my permanent offices in Yakima or the Tri-Cities. Mobile Office Hours are listed on my website for the month ahead.

Subject: Investing in Georgians
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼ 

Issues
Constituent Services
News

￼    ￼    ￼    ￼    ￼

Dear friends,  On Tuesday, I was pleased the Senate passed the bipartisan Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018, known as the Farm Bill. The legislation will help strengthen our agricultural economy in Georgia and the United States over the next five years. After being passed by both the U.S. Senate and the U.S. House of Representatives this week, it now moves to the president’s desk to be signed into law.  The 2018 Farm Bill will provide certainty and predictability to farmers and ranchers by improving crop insurance coverage and reauthorizing farm and conservation programs. It also provides assistance to rural communities through expansion of broadband, opioid addiction treatment programs, and support for agriculture programs for veterans.  As the senior senator from the state of Georgia where agriculture is our leading industry, I was proud to support the Farm Bill to help our farmers today and in the long term. Our nation’s farmers face near-constant uncertainty in their day-to-day operations as they work to feed the world. This bill anticipates future challenges and helps ensure that our policies reflect the needs of our farmers.  More Help for Georgia Farmers  On Tuesday, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Army Corps of Engineers signed a revised “Waters of the United States” rule, which would provide much-needed clarity to Georgia farmers and landowners and prevent overreaching federal regulation of private and state waters under the rule previously implemented by the Obama administration.   I have long argued that the previous administration’s overreaching rule allowed the federal government to regulate nearly all private and state waters in the United States, including thousands of streams, creeks, wetlands, ponds and ditches.  This action by the Trump administration is a relief to Georgia’s farmers and our agriculture industry. This new commonsense definition will restore state and private property rights while preserving the appropriate role of the federal government in protecting waterways that cross state lines.  In Other News
	•	Last week, the U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT) announced that Georgia’s highway system will receive a federal grant to assist with an interchange project in Barrow County, Ga. The Georgia Department of Transportation will receive an award of $24,821,050 for a project at the intersection of State Route 316 (SR 316)/U.S. Route 29 and State Route 11 (SR 11) to improve traffic flow and accommodate future widening of SR 316. I was glad to help support this project, and I appreciate the attention and leadership shown by Secretary Chao and President Trump to prioritize Americans’ needs through investments in our infrastructure that will help hardworking families and our economy.
	•	This week, we introduced and passed a Senate joint resolution holding Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman responsible for the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist and columnist for the Washington Post. The resolution condemns the killing and insists on accountability for those involved in his death.
	•	I was very proud the Senate passed a resolution on Tuesday night that I introduced with Senator David Perdue to recognize the 40th anniversary of Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay, located in Camden Co., Ga. 
	•	Both chambers of Congress have now passed a bill I introduced along with Sen. Perdue and Reps. Sanford Bishop and Drew Ferguson to rename a Columbus, Ga., post office the “Richard W. Williams, Jr., Chapter of the Triple Nickles (555th P.I.A.) Post Office” in honor of Columbus-area veterans who served in military units that originated from the Army’s first all-black parachute unit, which was activated at Fort Benning in December 1943. The measure now moves to the president’s desk to become law.
	•	Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch will be retiring at the end of the year after seven terms in the U.S. Senate. The longest-serving Republican in the Senate, Senator Hatch has been a great chairman, friend and example for our country. I thanked him for his years of service, mentorship and friendship during our committee hearing on Tuesday.
￼
	•	I am also going to miss U.S. Senators Joe Donnelly and Heidi Heitkamp in the Senate. I spoke on the Senate floor on Tuesday to wish them the very best as they conclude their terms and begin their next steps. 
￼
	•	Senator Dean Heller is one of a kind and someone I am very proud to have served with on the Senate Committee on Veterans’ Affairs. On Wednesday, I delivered remarks on the Senate floor to pay tribute to him as he departs the Senate at the end of his term. He will be greatly missed, but I wish him all the best in his next endeavor.
￼
	•	I appreciate America’s Essential Hospitals for presenting me with the Congressional Leader Award for my work on behalf of hospitals, including upholding the current level of Medicaid funding for disproportionate share hospitals. 
￼
	•	It’s an honor to have earned the 2018 Champion of Aid Reform from the Modernizing Foreign Assistance Network along with such leaders as Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Senator Bob Corker and Senator Chris Coons for our work to improve the effectiveness of U.S. foreign assistance. 
￼
What’s on Tap?
The Senate continues to work on funding for seven of 12 areas of government funding for 2019. 
Sincerely, ￼

Subject: This Week in the Office of Senator Marco Rubio
Message:
￼
This Week in the Office of Senator Marco Rubio 
On Tuesday, I urged Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Administrator Brock Long to accelerate the implementation of approved housing resources desperately needed in areas affected by Hurricane Michael. Read more here.
￼ 
On Tuesday, I urged Google CEO Sundar Pichai to abandon plans for Dragonfly, a censored version of its search engine in China. Read more here.
￼ 
Senator Menendez and I urged President Trump to once again denounce Nicolás Maduro as the illegitimate President of Venezuela and to recognize the National Assembly as the country’s only remaining democratic institution. Read more here.
￼ 
On Thursday, Congressman Brian Mast and I requested that Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, R. D. James, to directly intervene to prevent the Corps bureaucracy from unnecessarily delaying the design and construction of the vital Everglades Agricultural Area (EAA) Storage Reservoir project. Read more here.
￼ 
I joined CBS’s Face the Nation to discuss the threat posed by Chinese telecom companies like Huawei and ZTE. Watch the full interview here.
  ￼ 
I joined Martha MacCallum on Fox News to discuss the conflict in Yemen and what the United States should do in regards to Saudi Arabia going forward. Watch the full interview here.
  ￼ 
I voted against the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 (2018 Farm Bill) because it failed to protect farmers, working families, and taxpayers. Read more here.
￼ 
On Wednesday, I welcomed the final passage of the Nicaraguan Investment Conditionality Act (NICA), which now heads to the President’s desk to be signed into law. Read more here.
￼
On the Senate Floor, I addressed U.S. involvement with the Saudi-led coalition in the Yemen conflict, addressing the need to hold Saudi Arabia accountable, without creating a larger disaster. Watch my full speech here.
￼  
On Wednesday, I spoke about my long standing friendship with Senator Bill Nelson on the Senate Floor, following his farewell speech as a United States Senator. Watch my full speech here.
￼ 
I wrote an op-ed for The Atlantic on the need to restore the value of the dignity of work in America. Read more here.
￼ 
I wrote an op-ed for Fox News urging congress to hold Saudi Arabia accountable for the murder of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi, but to not ignore the threat of Iran in Yemen. Read more here.
￼ 
Earlier this week, I spoke at the American Principles Project State Lunch, honoring the late Jeff Bell, who passed earlier this year. Jeff Bell was a champion of creating an economy to benefit the American worker and families. See my full speech here.
￼ 
I joined Jake Tapper on CNN’s State of the Union to discuss the future of our relationship with Saudi Arabia following the murder of Jamal Khashoggi. Watch the full interview here.
￼ 
I joined ABC’s This Week to discuss the Mueller Investigation. Watch my full interview here.
￼

Subject: Latest News from Congressman Steve Cohen
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Congressman Steve Cohen 
￼ ￼ 
Website
|
Serving You
|
Legislative Work
|
Our District
|
Resources
￼
December 14, 2018 
 
Dear Friend,  

This week, I announced that my bill to name the post office on Autumn Avenue for Judge Russell B. Sugarmon has been signed into law. I also questioned Google’s CEO about protecting free speech; voted to pass a Farm Bill which protects important food assistance, animal protection and conservation programs; expressed my concern about developments in the Special Counsel Robert Mueller investigation; visited with students at Hamilton High School's pre-K program, welcomed new American citizens, noted that open enrollment for HealthCare.gov policies ends this Saturday, December 15; remembered Shelby County Election Commissioner O.C. Pleasant Jr., offered Capitol Historical Society 2019 calendars and made a health tip about preparing for wintry cold snaps. Keep reading to learn more about my week and follow me on Twitter and Facebook to see more updates as they happen.   
Announcing Russell B. Sugarmon Post Office Becoming Law  Questioning Google about Protecting Free Speech  Protecting Food Assistance  Expressing Concerns About Developments in the Mueller Probe  Visiting with Hamilton High School Pre-K Students  Welcoming New American Citizens in Memphis  Flagging Open Enrollment Ending Soon at HealthCare.gov   Remembering O.C. Pleasant Jr.  Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars   Weekly Health Tip  Quote of the Week   


Announcing Russell B. Sugarmon Post Office Becoming Law 

￼  
On Monday, I announced that my bill to rename the post office at 1325 Autumn Avenue for Russell B. Sugarmon, the civil rights leader, lawyer and judge, had been signed into law. No one deserves this honor more than Judge Sugarmon and I look forward to dedicating this monument to a great man’s achievements soon. 
Questioning Google about Protecting Free Speech 
On Tuesday, Google CEO Sundar Pichai testified before the House Judiciary Committee on which I serve and took questions about baseless claims of bias against conservatives in its search functionand concerns about privacy and tracking people’s physical locations. I asked Pichai to make it easier for people to understand and adjust privacy settings on their smart phones and asked him what Google is doing to limit the effectiveness of bots that use algorithms to stifle the free speech of humanitarian and democratic activists in authoritarian countries. See that exchange here.    The hearing and my questioning drew a lot of commentary on Twitter, including this post by journalist Eli Lake: 
￼ 
Protecting Food Assistance 
￼  
On Wednesday, I voted for and the House passed a five-year Farm Bill that  protects food assistance, conservation and animal welfare policies that are priorities for residents of the 9th Congressional District. We successfully blocked efforts by the Majority to impose punishing work requirements for food stamp recipients and preserved the Conservation Stewardship Program, which encourages farmers to strengthen conservation efforts on their farms.I am also pleased that two bills I cosponsored to protect animals, the Pet and Women Safety (PAWS) Act (H.R. 909) and the Dog and Cat Meat Trade Prohibition Act (H.R. 1406), were included in the final bill. The Farm Bill also provides permanent funding for programs promoting local farmers markets and organic farming.  
Expressing Concerns About Developments in the Mueller Probe 
All week, I have been concerned about mounting evidence in support of allegations that the President directed his lawyer to violate campaign finance laws with illicit hush-money payments to two women during the 2016 campaign and what impact that might have on the future of Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation of Russian interference in our elections. I talked to MSNBC’s Alex Witt about those concerns on Sunday. The day before, I talked with MSNBC’s Jonathan Capehart on “AM Joy” and with the network’s Richard Liu. And last Friday night, I spoke to Lawrence O’Donnell on the network’s “The Last Word.”In print press interviews, I’ve suggested tying legislation protecting the integrity of Mueller’s probe to spending bills whose deadlines are looming. I am a cosponsor of the Special Counsel Independence and Integrity Act (H.R. 5476) which I hope we can pass before the 115th Congress ends later this month. 
I am scheduled to talk with MSNBC’s the Reverend Al Sharpton on Saturday at about 4:30 p.m. 
Visiting with Hamilton High School Pre-K Students 
￼  
On Friday morning, I visited the Hamilton High School Pre-Kindergarten program for a holiday party and to deliver and read a book to encourage literacy. I talked to the students, staff and parents about the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance (SNAP, or food stamps) program reauthorized in the Farm Bill and about my support for early childhood education and Head Start. I told the kids to make good grades, stay in school and to enjoy being kids. 
While at Hamilton, I was pleased and surprised to meet football coach Cedrick Wilson, the former Melrose High School quarterback and University of Tennessee and NFL wide receiver. He is an iconic football player who will both teach and inspire. 
Welcoming New American Citizens in Memphis 
On Monday, members of my staff attended the naturalization ceremony for 59 new American citizens from 32 foreign countries, including Yemen, Mauritania, Congo, Mexico, India, China, South Korea, Venezuela, Syria, Ethiopia and Peru and Ukraine. Federal District Judge Sheryl Lipman administered the oath and shared a story about her family which originated in Ukraine, then part of the Russian Empire. Her family fled the anti-Jewish pogroms at the end of the 19th century and settled in Memphis. It was a struggle but there was much hope because America offered religious freedom, had separation of church and state, and had a democratic form of government that offered opportunity to all. On Sunday night, her family celebrated Chanukah as they have for a hundred years here in Memphis. I’m proud to have recommended Judge Lipman to President Obama, who made her the first federal Jewish judge in Tennessee history. These naturalization ceremonies are always a moving experience as many of these new Americans have waited years to become citizens. It’s a good reminder that we are a nation of immigrants. 
Flagging Open Enrollment Now Available at HealthCare.gov   
￼ 
Open enrollment for 2019 HealthCare.gov insurance plans ends tomorrow, Saturday, December 15. Listen for my public service radio announcement that encourages signing up.For more information on signing up for health care, see Healthcare.gov.    
Remembering O.C. Pleasant Jr. 
I was saddened this week to note the passing of my old friend O.C. Pleasant Jr., the longest-serving member of the Shelby County Election Commission. O.C. and I became friends when we were elected as delegates to the 1977 Tennessee State Constitutional Convention. We got to know each other well during the five months of the convention and we maintained that friendship over the next 40 years. He was a stand-up member of the County Election Commission who served with great distinction and heroism, and was noted for speaking truth to power. I extend my sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, his children and his many friends. He was a good man and his was a life well lived. 
Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars   
￼  
My office has a limited number of 2019 U.S. Capitol Historical Society calendars available. If you would like to receive a calendar, please complete this form on my website. Due to the rules of the House, I can mail calendars only to residents of Tennessee’s 9th Congressional District. Please feel free to share this email with other residents of the 9th District who may be interested in receiving one but who do not receive my e-Newsletter.   
Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter  

￼  

I enjoy meeting regularly with constituents in the district and helping get answers for them to questions about dealing with federal agencies. If you are interested in attending one of my “Congress on Your Corner” events, you can sign up here to receive notification as soon as the next event is scheduled.   

For those who haven’t participated in a telephone town hall, it’s easy to sign up for them by using this form.     
If you would like to receive this weekly e-Newsletter, or share it with others, you can do that with this form.   
Weekly Health Tip

￼   
Each week, I share a health tip in the hope of promoting a healthy lifestyle for residents of the 9th Congressional District. As always, it is best to check with your doctor before making any changes to your diet, exercise routine or lifestyle.   
Rainy and windy conditions this week are likely get colder as the Mid-South transitions from fall to winter. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) offers advice about getting prepared for wintry weather by repairing leaking roofs at home, having your furnace inspected, and being prepared for emergencies in your car by having booster cables, blankets and flashlights available. See all the CDC’s advice here.  

The Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division inspects gas appliances with its ongoing Pilot Safety Inspections that are free to those over 60. See details including how to make an appointment here.  
Quote of the Week 
“You want to know something? I’ll tell you what: I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck…I will be the one to shut it down – I’m not going to blame you for it.” – President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday during a meeting with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer about a Homeland Security spending bill.
Note: Trump campaigned on a pledge to build a southern border wall and to make Mexico pay for it. 
As always, I remain Most sincerely, 
￼ 
Steve Cohen Member of Congress

Subject: Vicky's View from the Capitol
Message:
￼ 





Dear Friend, 
Please read to the end of my newsletter this week for some personal news from me.  
We Have a Farm Bill
￼ 
After months of working with fellow conferees on behalf of rural America, I was pleased to sign the 2018 Farm Bill that provides much needed certainty for producers and consumers both in Missouri and across our nation. 
We have a Farm Bill! On Wednesday the House passed a finalized conference report, which I have worked on for over the last four months, that will provide our farmers and ranchers with much needed economic certainty. The bill ensures consumers continue to enjoy the safest, most abundant food supply in the world by improving public/private risk management programs and supporting local, national, and international efforts vital to protect and promote American agriculture. Significant investments in rural broadband, trade promotion, research and development, and conservation initiatives will positively impact rural America for years to come.
While we did not achieve all that we wanted in the final version of the bill, this legislation is a good bill for farmers, ranchers, conservationists, and consumers. I am pleased to see many of my priorities for MO-04 included in the legislation. The Farm Bill does the following things, which are items on which I specifically worked:
	•	Expands access for guaranteed loans under the Community Facilities Program to communities with populations of 50,000 or less.
	•	Includes language I authored to increase minimum speed requirements for rural broadband and recognizes the importance of expanding rural broadband. 
	•	Maintains crop insurance and improves insurance options for dairy producers, while also strengthening and providing flexibility for Agriculture Risk Coverage and Price Loss Coverage programs.  
	•	Invests and streamlines conservation initiatives for farm families to continue to improve and protect our natural resources and includes language I authored to allow grazing on CRP lands.  
	•	Enhances integrity of the SNAP program by improving education and training programs at the state level, reducing monthly work requirement exemptions from 15 to 12 percent, eliminating the ability for participants to receive benefits in multiple states. 
	•	Includes language I authored to increase private investment in rural broadband, modifying Rural Utilities Service (RUS) broadband programs to include loan guarantees in addition to existing direct loans.  
	•	Promotes American exports by enhancing and permanently funding trade promotion programs necessary for producers to secure additional markets.  
	•	Improves clarity and consistency for small meat processors by including language I authored requiring the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to report on the effectiveness of existing regulations for small meat processors. 
  
The Farm Bill 2018 is good for rural America.  The Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 also: 
	•	Prioritizes funding for opioid prevention, treatment and recovery facilities in rural communities. 
	•	Ensures agriculture is on the cutting edge of technology and innovation by investing over $600 million in funding for agriculture research, extension and education.  
	•	Establishes new programs and funding to protect the health of our nation’s livestock while also creating a feral swine eradication pilot program. 
	•	Improves assistance for specialty crops and reduces fraud in organic imports.  
	•	Helps beginning farmers and ranchers establish themselves in agriculture and provides support for youth to get engaged in agricultural careers. 
	•	Recognizes the hardship currently facing farm families by reestablishing the Farm and Ranch Stress Assistance Network to help combat farmer suicides.  
	•	
  
The President is expected to sign the 2018 Farm Bill into law next week.
 
Commemorating a MO-04 Hero
￼ 
I am pleased to share good news: the President has signed into law my bill to name the downtown Columbia post office in honor of Army Specialist Sterling Wyatt, who was killed in action in July of 2011 in Kandahar, Afghanistan. 
Specialist Wyatt was born and raised in Columbia and graduated from Rock Bridge High School in 2009. As a youngster and teenager, he earned the rank of Eagle Scout, a first-degree black belt in taekwondo, and certification as a Certified Nurse Attendant. His military awards and decorations include the National Defense Service Medal, Afghanistan Campaign Medal, Global War on Terrorism Service Medal, Army Service Ribbon, and Combat Infantryman Badge.
I initially introduced the bill to name the Columbia post office in his honor after receiving letters from Columbia constituents asking me to do so and after meeting Sterling’s parents, Randy and Sherry. There will be a formal ceremony in Columbia to dedicate the downtown post office to Spc. Wyatt on a future date to be announced.
Having Sterling’s name on the Columbia Post Office will inspire future generations and commemorate his patriotism forever. 
 
On Track in Sedalia
￼
Last week I had the privilege of announcing a $10.09 million grant the U.S. Department of Transportation awarded to the City of Sedalia to extend its existing railroad tracks to the new Sedalia Rail Industrial Park. This grant funding will help keep the Sedalia Rail Industrial Park on track to become the largest, exclusive rail-served industrial park in the Midwest. It will also expand the current network of railroad tracks to the site of Nucor Steel’s new steel rebar micro-mil facility that is estimated to bring 250 new jobs to Sedalia. 
The city has worked hard alongside the Sedalia-Pettis County Community Service Corporation, whose Executive Director Jessica Craig applied for the grant, Pettis County, Senator Blunt, and my office to obtain the funding. The project will create even more good-paying jobs for hardworking Missourians in the Fourth District, and I’m pleased Sedalia received this important grant.
  
Meet the Interns
￼ 
The Hartzler Office interns, from L-R, clockwise: Jaclyn McLean, Austin Bruce, and Max Beckert. 
Behind every well-functioning Congressional office is a group of helpful and chipper interns, helping operations run smoothly. The Hartzler Office is no different. As such, I would like to introduce you to the great group of interns who are currently helping out in my offices: Max Beckert, Jaclyn McLean, and Austin Bruce.
Our interns answer phones, run errands, research legislation, attend hearings and briefings, draft responses to constituent letters, help with casework, and support staffers on various projects. In the process, they learn about the legislative system, the state of Missouri, and the many other functions of a Congressional office.
Max Beckert came all the way from New Zealand to intern with us, so if you call into the Washington office and are greeted by a friendly voice with a New Zealand accent, you’ll know who you are talking to!  He is finishing his Bachelor of Laws and Commerce degrees, and he learned of the Washington internship through his networks with the New Zealand Embassy and the NZ-US Council. Max is an athlete and avid sports fan, and he has competed in cycling competitions domestically and internationally. He also enjoys hiking, hunting, skiing, and surfing.
Jaclyn is from Arlington, Texas, and she has been with my D.C. office since August. She found out about this internship through her sister, who works on Capitol Hill, and she is working to complete her degree in American Sign Language Interpreting and Global Studies. Jaclyn is a college softball athlete and enjoys adventures in the outdoors, working with her hands, and design and construction projects.
Austin Bruce, who interns in my Columbia office, hails from the small farming community of Unionville. He learned of our internship through the Handshake platform at the University of Missouri, where he is studying psychology. Austin enjoys traveling, attending live music events, reading, studying other cultures, and hiking in Columbia’s parks with his dog. He hopes that his experience here will help him positively impact his community and his future career.
If you would like to apply for an internship, you can visit my website at hartzler.house.gov, hover over “Serving You,” and select “Internships.” You will then be required to answer various questions about your academic history and submit a cover letter and resume. My staff will review your submission, and depending on the volume of applications they receive, they may call you to conduct a follow-up phone interview to determine if our office would be a good fit for you.
  
Supporting Our Veterans and Servicemembers
￼ 
This week I was pleased to support a bill the House passed to improve the way we serve our veterans and servicemembers. The bill includes many provisions from stand-alone legislation the House passed earlier this year. 
Specifically, S. 2248, the Veterans Benefit and Transition Act of 2018, would ensure that students using their GI Bill benefits to go to college are not penalized if the Veterans Administration is late making payments to their school. The bill would also allow service members who are deployed or relocated to cancel their television and internet contracts without being penalized by local providers. Additionally, the legislation would authorize the VA through 2024 to allow the burial of spouses and dependents of veterans in national cemeteries.
I’m pleased to see common-sense reforms for our nation’s veterans move forward. This legislation makes practical changes to strengthen the way we care for those who have served and those who still serve our country today. It is expected to be voted on by the Senate before the year’s end and be sent to the President to become law.
  
Weekly Dose of Good News
A $3.5 million grant is headed to Katy Trail Community Health, a local health program with clinics in several Missouri communities, including Sedalia, Versailles, and Warsaw. I was pleased to support this grant, which Congress authorized in the Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act. The money will allow Katy Trail’s Community Health Centers to continue providing health care services to Missouri communities, especially those with increased poverty and fewer physicians. Their clinics are cost-effective, saving the national health care system an estimated $24 billion a year by reducing emergency, hospital, and specialty care - all of which are very costly. Katy Trail Community Health, which employs 126 people, will continue to provide high quality care to improve the health of many of the most vulnerable people in central Missouri thanks to this grant.
  
Photo to Share
￼  
I was honored to participate in the Reagan Defense Forum at the Reagan Library a week ago, looking at ways to build “Peace Through Strength in an Era of Competition.”  It was a unique opportunity to hear from leaders from the Department of Defense, the defense industry, Congress, and civilian leaders. 
  
Some Personal News
￼ 
On Tuesday, my Daddy, Ted Zellmer, went to heaven after suffering a massive stroke a week ago. It was a shock, as he was only recently out chopping wood and running the combine during corn harvest. He spent his life raising livestock, crops, a church, and two daughters who love God, love others, and love our country. He served his country in the U.S. Army Reserves and was a leader in his church. He lived his life to honor God and was a good neighbor. He made a difference and his legacy lives on through the many lives he impacted. 
This time has been bittersweet - filled with sadness over losing him but also with gratitude to God for allowing me to be his daughter. My sister and I feel truly blessed to have had such a wonderful father for so many years, and I was thankful I got to spend his last days with him. What a gift.  
I also appreciate the many condolences my family and I have received since his passing. Thank you. It’s a blessing to not only represent this district in Congress, but to also experience the love and goodness of the people who call MO-4 home. May God bless each of you and may we all be inspired to live our lives with as much meaning and heart as my father.

 
Yours in service,
￼ 
Vicky Hartzler
Member of Congress

Subject: Work Week with Congressman Faso
Message:
￼ 
  

Share on: 
￼ ￼
Work Week with Congressman Faso
Table of contents
	•	Staatsburg Marine Dies in Training Accident
	•	Congress Sends the Farm Bill to President's Desk
	•	Closing Loopholes in Limousine Safeguards
	•	Final Speech on the House Floor
	•	Congressional Accountability Act Passes Senate
	•	USDA Launches New Rural Broadband Program
	•	Ichabod Crane Visits the Capitol

Staatsburg Marine Dies in Training Accident
This past week, Maj. James M. Brophy of Staatsburg died in an accident off the coast of Japan during a training exercise. Maj. Brophy and his fellow Marines were on a refueling aircraft when it collided with a fighter jet. My thoughts and prayers are with his family, friends, and community as the nation struggles with another tragic loss of life during a military training exercise.

Congress Sends the Farm Bill to President's Desk
This week, the House and Senate passed the conference report for H.R. 2 – the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018, more commonly known as the Farm Bill. Since joining the Agriculture Committee in January 2017, it has been a top priority of mine to construct a Farm Bill that helps reverse the troubling economic headwinds farmers have faced the past five years - an unfortunate reality known all too well in Upstate.
H.R. 2 has gained support from the New York Farm Bureau, the American Farm Bureau Federation, the National Milk Producers Federation, the Organic Trade Association, and the Specialty Crop Farm Bill Alliance, among others.
This bill is the result of thousands of hours of farm visits, discussions with producers, and negotiations among members of the Committee and the Senate. I am proud of the bill we’ve produced and the bipartisan manner in which we came to this agreement. The bill includes changes to help Upstate dairy farmers, improves the nutrition title to put people on a path toward self-sufficiency, and strengthens incentives and protections for important Upstate agriculture industries, including specialty crops and organics.
A full breakdown of my priorities for the bill is available on a fact sheet here: https://faso.house.gov/uploadedfiles/2018_farm_bill_detailed_summary.pdf.

Closing Loopholes in Limousine Safeguards
In October, a limousine crash in Schoharie County, New York killed a total of twenty people. The deadliest accident in nearly a decade, this devastating incident is currently under investigation by authorities to determine what happened and how we can increase the safety of travelers on our roads. Representatives Paul Tonko (D-NY), Elise Stefanik (R-NY) and I have come together to identify legislative changes we can make in Washington to prevent another crash like this from happening.
We identified a loophole that allows retrofitted limousines to skirt requirements as re-sold vehicles and to avoid compliance with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) regulation. Currently, vehicles that are purchased and then lengthened to increase capacity are not subject to the same safety regulations as other new vehicles that are offered for sale, such as seat belt and egress point requirements.
It’s vital that vehicles which are significantly modified undergo a strict amount of scrutiny - Congress must move to close this loophole and enact stricter rules on modified vehicles. While there were certainly other factors surrounding this crash, which are subject to federal and state investigation as well as a criminal prosecution, making sure modified vehicles are safer is a critical step.
Read more about the legislation here: https://faso.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=1406.

Final Speech on the House Floor
This week, I gave my farewell address on the Floor of the House of Representatives. The last two years have been one of the greatest honors of my lifetime, and I’m thankful for the opportunity to have served the 19th district.
I’m proud of the work we’ve done. One of the more notable things we accomplished this session is a comprehensive opioid bill that puts a historic investment into combating the opioid and addiction crises. Included in that legislation were two bills that I was the primary sponsor of in the House.
The first of those bills is the STOP Act, which will help crack down on the amount of synthetic opioids, such as fentanyl, that are coming into the country from China. Fentanyl can be fifty times as potent and heroin, but has an appearance that is indistinguishable. This makes it extremely dangerous for people already addicted to drugs who have a hard time knowing what they are using. This has caused a spike in overdose deaths nationwide.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there were over 72,000 overdose deaths in 2017. Of that number, 30,000 deaths are attributed to synthetic opioids, nearly 16,000 to Heroin, and almost 15,000 to natural or semi-synthetic opioids.
The second bill included in the comprehensive package will improve the educational materials provided to seniors when they join the Medicare Part D program.  A 2017 Department of Health and Human Services study indicated that one-third of all Part D beneficiaries were prescribed some kind of opioid in 2016. Close to 100k beneficiaries were deemed to be at serious risk due to “extreme” prescription amounts.
Currently, the ‘Medicare and You’ handbook does not have comprehensive educational materials to inform seniors on the risk of opioid use, information on their addictive nature, or information on alternative treatments. My legislation will fix that and ensure seniors know what their options are before proceeding with care.  Watch the entire speech here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vJYAdtB_8QU. 

Congressional Accountability Act Passes Senate
I'm happy that a much-needed overhaul of the Congressional harassment and discrimination complaint and investigative processes passed the Senate. In February, the House passed its overhaul. 
It is appalling that through the years, members of Congress were able to utilize taxpayer money to settle claims of sexual harassment. These reforms will help ensure unacceptable behavior won’t be covered over with taxpayer dollars.
Harassment, abuse, and discrimination in the workplace are unacceptable, and Americans expect far better from those elected to serve.
Read more about the new policy and how it was passed in this CNN article: https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/13/politics/senate-passes-sexual-harassment-bill/index.html?fbclid=IwAR35I-4PTefmjkLSYoQxCzyZU28QUuyy5NUXuOEeE9psFZzntZu3nLnBiHo.

USDA Launches New Rural Broadband Program
This week, USDA Secretary Sonny Purdue announced the Rural Utilities Service (RUS) e-Connectivity Pilot Program. This new program will issue funds for broadband expansion in unserved and underserved communities.
Earlier this year, I held a meeting with local telecom leaders to discuss and gain input on this rural broadband initiative. As a result of that meeting, I submitted official comments to RUS on behalf of these key stakeholders to ensure that New York may fairly access these funds.  Additionally, the comments urged higher broadband speeds, improved mapping of coverage, and stringent standards for applicants to ensure effective broadband expansion and prevent fraud.   Residents of Upstate New York are all too familiar with the lack of broadband in our communities. I look forward to the implementation of this new rural broadband initiative and am hopeful our comments will shape how this important funding is used. Seniors expecting telemedicine, telecommuting professionals, and children researching schoolwork online all depend on access to reliable broadband internet.

Ichabod Crane Visits the Capitol
I had the opportunity to spend time with Ichabod Crane’s eighth grade class on their annual trip to our nation’s Capital. 
I took them down to the House floor to talk about some of the important duties Representatives have as well as the importance of civic participation. We were also joined by a House historian who told us some of the fascinating history that has occurred in the House chamber. 
Young people are the future of our great nation, and it’s critically important that people, both young and old, are engaged and participate in our government.

Subject: Just the Facts
Message:
Just the Facts
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 Share on Facebook
Share on Twitter 
Twenty-five percent of U.S. carbon dioxide emissions from 2005 to 2014 came from the extraction and burning of fossil fuels from federal lands. Earth’s climate is changing more rapidly than ever before in modern civilization. In 20 years, we will see Arctic summers free of sea ice and a substantial sea level rise unless we act soon. These are highlights from three recent reports on climate change.  
The first, from the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), had the data on federal lands. The report was issued on Black Friday, when few Americans follow the news. It is particularly important because it cites the federal government’s own contribution to climate change. This is a reminder of the crucial role of Congress and public lands policy debated through the Natural Resources Committee, on which I serve. We must curb the nation’s contribution to the buildup of greenhouse gases. You can see my reaction to the report here.
The second report, also released by the Trump Administration on Black Friday, is the fourth National Climate Assessment (NCA). Required by Congressional mandate established during President George H.W. Bush's administration, it uses projections of climate change to estimate the toll a changing climate may exact on various economic sectors. The NCA is, to date, the most comprehensive evaluation of the consequences of climate change, the risks of inaction, and potential adaptation strategies for the United States.
According to the NCA, “without more significant global greenhouse gas mitigation and regional adaptation efforts, climate change is expected to cause substantial losses to infrastructure and property and impede the rate of economic growth over this century.” It also makes clear that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the only explanation for the global warming of the last six decades. Without intervention, we will see record heat waves, more acidic oceans, raging wildfires, rising sea levels, and a surge in extreme weather events – all in our lifetime. 
The third report is a special report from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). As part of the Paris Agreement, the IPCC was invited to report on how the world can limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The report found that the planet has as little as 12 years to take meaningful climate action if we are to achieve this goal. It was authored by the world’s preeminent scientists drawing on thousands of peer-reviewed research papers, and represents a broad scientific consensus on the latest climate change information. 
The report concludes that stunning impacts such as sea-ice free Arctic Summers, substantial sea level rise, mass die offs of coral reefs, and intense and unprecedented heatwaves will become reality as soon as 2040 unless we slow the current pace of climate change. In addition, the report highlights impacts we will avoid by limiting global warming to 1.5°C compared to 2°C, or more. The IPCC report also makes it clear that the world has the scientific understanding, the technological capacity, and the financial means to tackle climate change. We only need to act.
To keep current with the latest climate change news and information, follow the Safe Climate Caucus on Facebook and Twitter.

Subject: Supporting our family farmers
Message:
News from Representative Bustos 
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
Finishing the Farm Bill 
￼
Congresswoman Bustos signing the final version of the Farm Bill Conference Report 
This week, I supported the passage of a bipartisan Farm Bill that will provide Illinois’ family farmers the support they need to continue putting food on the plates of Americans across our country. As a Farm Bill Conferee, I worked alongside my colleagues to merge the House and Senate versions of the Farm Bill into a final piece of bipartisan legislation. 
I’m proud to have included several of my provisions to help young farmers and veterans launch first generation family farms. I also included language in the bill to strengthen our rural communities by giving them the resources they need to combat the opioid epidemic and grow our economy through expanded rural broadband. However, the fight for our family farmers is far from over. As our producers continue to grapple with a downturn in the agricultural economy, the impact of President Trump’s trade war and the Administration’s undermining of the Renewable Fuel Standard, a lot of work remains to be done. Although this was a step in the right direction, I will continue to fight for our hardworking Illinois farmers. Click here to read more. 
To keep up on the work that I am doing to fight for the hardworking families of Illinois, make sure to stay connected with me @RepCheri!           
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
Have a great weekend, Cheri

Message:

News from Representative Mooney 
￼
 
￼
￼
￼
￼
 
This Week in Congress
WOTUS Rollback 
This week, President Donald Trump announced a rollback of the Waters of the United States Rule. The Obama-era rule represented the very worst of federal government overreach by regulating any puddle or trickle of water. This rule hindered farmers, land owners and communities across West Virginia, including my constituent Lois Alt of Hardy County. 
I applaud the Trump Administration for crafting a rule that respects private property rights and gives states flexibility in managing water within their borders. You can read more about the announcement here. 
 UMWA Meeting
I held my first constituent meeting in my new Washington, D.C. office located in the Rayburn House Office Building with my friends from the United Mine Workers of America. I will continue working to ensure we keep our promises to retired coal miners.  
￼ 
 Always a pleasure to meet with my friends from the UMWA 
 Cards for Soldiers
I took a moment this week to write notes and wish a Merry Christmas to service members, veterans, and their families. I hope everyone will join me this Holiday Season in thanking those who have given so much in service to our country. Thank you to the  American Red Cross for organizing this event!
￼ 
Please remember our service members, veterans and their families this Christmas season 
The Mountaineer Recovery Center
Today, I had the pleasure of visiting the Mountaineer Recovery Center in Martinsburg, West Virginia. This center is going to make a huge impact on the lives of those seeking recovery. This project has been years in the making and I was pleased to speak today at their renovation kick-off. Thanks to everyone, especially Kevin Knowles, who made this project possible!  
￼ 
Visiting the Mountaineer Recovery Center in Martinsburg 
Term Limits
I was proud to be recognized by U.S. Term Limits for signing their pledge to fight for term limits in Congress. My pledge includes a commitment to co-sponsor and vote for legislation that limits House members to three terms, and Senators to two terms. 
￼ 
Proud to be recognized for my pledge to fight for Congressional term limits 
 New Office
My Washington, D.C. office has moved from 1232 Longworth House Office Building to 2440 Rayburn House Office Building! Our phone number remains the same. Please stop by our new office if you visit the D.C. area!
￼ 
Mobile Office Hours
Helping my constituents cut through the massive red tape of federal bureaucracies is a top priority of mine and my staff. Although I have district offices in Charleston and Martinsburg, I want to make it as easy as possible for constituents to contact my office for assistance. Listed below are my Mobile Office Hours for this upcoming week:

Subject: Rep. Lowenthal eNewsletter – December 14 – Vietnamese Refugees, Human Rights Day, 116th Congress
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Lowenthal
￼
 
HOW CAN ALAN HELP?
LEGISLATION
47TH DISTRICT
ABOUT ALAN
CONTACT ALAN
 

In This Edition 
I was deeply disturbed by the Trump Administration’s efforts this week to subject thousands of immigrants from Vietnam to deportation, and led my House colleagues in speaking out against this misguided plan.  
On Monday, I was proud to introduce a bipartisan House Resolution honoring the 70th Anniversary of Human Rights Day and the 1948 ratification by the United Nations of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). 
This week, I spoke at a reception recognizing 10-year anniversary of the Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission, on which I proudly serve.   
As we move closer to the end of the 115th Congress, I wanted to share some of my plans and priorities for the upcoming 116th Congress.  
In this edition of Alan’s Inbox, see my response to constituents who have contacted me to express their desire to see the issue of malnutrition in America addressed by Congress.  
Check out Congress U, where this week I discuss the history of U.S. Capitol Christmas Tree. 
Lastly, don’t forget to take this week’s poll in the right-hand column. 
￼ 
￼ 
CONNECT WITH ME
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
  
Should President Trump compromise on his insistence on an additional $5 billion in funding for a border wall in order to avoid a government shutdown next week? 
 

Yes

No

Unsure


 

If you have a problem, click here to open survey in a new window
  
  





￼
Defending Vietnamese Refugees 
I was deeply disturbed by the Trump Administration’s efforts this week to subject thousands of immigrants from Vietnam to deportation. Both the Obama and Bush administrations recognized the moral imperative to continue to protect this group of people, which includes Vietnam War-era refugees who have lived in the US for decades.
Vietnam and the United States have a complex history, and our immigration system must acknowledge and accommodate that fact. Thousands of Vietnamese Americans living in the United States fought alongside American troops. These people, and their families, made grave sacrifices and have no home in which they are welcome outside the United States. It would be a betrayal to turn our backs on these men and women.
Our agreements with Vietnam only allow the deportation of those who arrived in the United States from Vietnam after 1995, the date when the United States and the Vietnamese government reestablished diplomatic relations. I am proud to have led 25 of my colleagues to call on the Trump Administration to halt any effort to renegotiate agreements with Vietnam and to jeopardize the futures of Vietnamese Americans who came to the United States prior to 1995 as refugees.
Click here to read the full letter. 
Honoring the 70th Anniversary of Human Rights Day 

On Monday, I was proud to introduce a bipartisan House Resolution honoring the 70th Anniversary of Human Rights Day and the 1948 ratification by the United Nations of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). The rights enshrined in the UDHR uphold the basic principles of life, freedom, and humanity that our nation was founded on, and which are enshrined in our Declaration of Independence and Constitution. Congress, and the world, must recognize that those who are denied basic human rights, such as the freedoms of speech, religion, and political expression, are also denied basic human respect and dignity.
Championed by First Lady and first chair of the UN Commission on Human Rights Eleanor Roosevelt, and adopted by the United Nations in 1948, the UDHR represents the first comprehensive international agreement about the specific rights and freedoms of all human beings. Today, the UDHR is the world’s most translated document, with over 416 different translations.
Since 1948, the UDHR has been the foundational document for enumerable international treaties, regional human rights instruments, national constitutions, and is a key component of the International Bill of Human Rights which went into effect in 1976. 
Click here to read the full text of the resolution. 
￼
Rep. Lowenthal meets with UN Association college students who are gathering support for his human rights resolution. 

Celebrating 10 Years of the Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission  
This week, I spoke at a reception recognizing the 10 year anniversary of the Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission, of which I am a proud member.  Since 2008, this bipartisan organization has worked to defend and advocate for international human rights in complex and challenging circumstances around the world. Through dozens of hearings, briefings, letters and other actions, and by taking up cases of prisoners of conscience, the Commission has sought to live up to the legacy of the late Congressman Tom Lantos and his steadfast commitment to ensure the protection of the individual, universal freedoms endowed upon every human being. I look forward to continuing to advocate for human rights worldwide alongside other members of the Commission in the coming Congress. 
￼
Congressman Lowenthal speaks at the Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission 10-year anniversary
Looking Ahead to the 116th Congress 
 As the 115th Congress draws to a close, I wanted to take a moment to share my plans for the coming Congress. I will continue to serve on the House Natural Resources Committee (HNRC), and will likely be named Chairman of the HNRC Energy and Mineral Resources subcommittee. In this role I will continue to champion clean, renewable energy policies that protect human health and reduce the greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change. I will also remain an advocate for the protection of our nation’s National Parks, Wilderness Areas, Recreation Areas, and other public lands. 
As a member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I will champion investments in freight infrastructure to alleviate the bottlenecks that slow goods movement throughout the United States. I also will advocate for increased federal support for the low- and zero-emissions transportation technologies we need to combat climate change.
Expanding access to and reducing costs of healthcare, and specifically mental health, advocating for our nation’s veterans, ending partisan gerrymandering, protecting DACA recipients, and defending human rights at home and abroad will also remain at the top of my list of priorities.   These are some of the priorities that I have worked hard on in the past and will continue to focus on in the coming Congress, along with the many other issues that impact my constituents in the 47th District. 
I would like to thank all of you who engage with my office by emailing and calling me, keeping up with my work in Congress by following me on social media, and subscribing to my weekly e-newsletter. An informed citizenry is vital to a successful democracy, and hearing from you each week allows me to better represent you in Washington. It is a tremendous honor to serve California and the 47th District, and I look forward to representing the district again for the next two years.  
  
￼ 
Each week hundreds of constituents contact my office to share their views on a variety of topics. I have recently received many messages from constituents expressing their desire to see the issues of malnutrition in America addressed in Congress. Below is a portion of my response to those messages:
  
“All Americans should receive quality health and nutrition education, as well as access to healthy food. As a community psychologist, I believe that providing clear nutrition information, such as restaurant menu labeling, will help Americans make healthier food choices.  You will be glad to know that I have co-sponsored legislation such as the Nutrition Education Act, which would require local educational agencies that participate in school breakfast or lunch programs to give students 50 hours of nutrition education to each student per year.  This bill aims to deliver informative material that is consistent with school meal program requirements. 
I understand the need for a school environment that is conducive to our student’s success—including access to healthy food.  It is essential that we encourage healthy eating and exercising habits from an early age to lay the foundation for healthy living as adults.  I am also a cosponsor of the Healthy Breakfasts Help Kids Learn Act, which would provide commodity support for school breakfast programs, allow more students to receive the benefits of a nutritious school breakfast, as well as increase access to a greater variety of American-grown foods.  
I also support the work of organizations such as the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, which is the world’s largest organization of food and nutrition professionals.  Since its founding, the Academy was founded to improve public health and advancing the dietetics profession by means of research, education, and advocacy. I support legislation that allows hardworking American families to live longer, healthier lives.” 
  
If you have written in to me, please continue to do so. If you have not, I encourage you to share your views and concerns with me, as it is the best way for me to find out which issues you care most about.   You can find out how to contact me on my website by clicking here. 
  
￼ 
The People's Tree 
Each year since 1923, a large evergreen tree has been placed on The Ellipse near the White House in Washington, D.C. to serve as the National Christmas Tree. 
Congress has its own version of the National Christmas Tree called the U.S. Capitol Christmas Tree. Also known as "The People’s Tree," the Capitol Christmas Tree is placed each year on the West Front Lawn of the U.S. Capitol in celebration of the holiday season. The tradition began in 1964 when Speaker of the U.S. House, John W. McCormack (D-MA), placed a live Christmas tree on the Capitol lawn. This first Capitol Christmas Tree was a live tree that was redecorated each of the subsequent three years as the Capitol Christmas Tree before succumbing to wind and root damage after the 1967 holiday season. White pines from Maryland served as the Capitol Christmas Tree for the following two years, before the Capitol Architect decided in 1970 to obtain all future Capitol trees from various National Forests via the U.S. Forest Service. 
The Capitol tree is lit in a ceremony normally preceded over by the sitting Speaker of the House. 
From 1990 to 2004, the tree was officially renamed the Capitol Holiday Tree, before reverting back to the original name of Capitol Christmas Tree for the 2005 season. The name has remained unchanged since 2005. 
Since 1964, California National Forests have provided the Capitol Christmas Tree on four occasions--in 1986, 1993, 1995, and most recently in 2011. 
  
￼ 
  
Which of the following descriptions comes closest to your opinion about special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and possible collusion with the Trump campaign? 
  
73%  It is a necessary and fair investigation  
24%  It is an unfair and politically motivated investigation  
3%    Don’t know/Unsure 
  
  
Thank you, ￼  Alan Lowenthal Member of Congress
