Subject: Rutherford Roundup for December 14th
Message:
News from Representative Rutherford  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
 

Contact Me | Subscribe
￼
RUTHERFORD ROUNDUP
For December 14, 2018

Welcome to another edition of the Rutherford Roundup with updates about my work in our community and up in Washington. It is my honor to serve you, and I am always grateful for the opportunity to share information with you about the work we are doing on behalf of the people of Northeast Florida.

￼ 

No Seismic Testing Off Our Beaches
￼  
Earlier this month, I shared my concern over efforts to conduct seismic testing - the first step to offshore drilling - off our Atlantic Coast. Last week, I authored a bipartisan letter with 92 of my colleagues to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross urging that they not allow seismic testing to move forward in the Atlantic. This is a matter of protecting not only vulnerable marine mammals and fisheries, but also naval operations, our coastal communities, and our national security. I am encouraged by the strong showing of bipartisan opposition to opening the Atlantic to seismic testing. 
To read the full letter to Secretaries Zinke and Ross, please click here. 
 ￼
Major Funding to Improve Our Infrastructure
￼ 
I am pleased to announce that the Department of Transportation awarded Jacksonville $25 million in federal funds for the Bay Street Innovation Corridor and Urban Core Riverfront Revitalization projects. As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I sit on the subcommittee that funds the Department of Transportation and have used my position to strongly advocate for these grant projects. This federal investment in improving our transportation infrastructure and in applying new technologies to our transit system is key to the next stages of growth for our city. 
Click here to read more about these exciting projects. 
   
￼ 
Paying Tribute to Miss Carrie
￼
￼
Many of you may have heard the sad news that Miss Carrie Johnson of Lincolnville passed away last month. I recently had the opportunity to honor her extraordinary life from the House floor. Her mission of love and message of hope will live on through those she touched. America needs more people like Miss Carrie. Please click to watch the video above. 
 
  
￼ 
Hats Off to Our Service Academy Nominees
￼ 
I recently had the privilege of nominating 43 students to be considered for appointments to the United States Air Force Academy, United States Merchant Marine Academy, United States Military Academy, and the United States Naval Academy. These outstanding students are tasked with ensuring America remains the strongest beacon of hope and freedom in the world. I am confident that those we have nominated possess the leadership, integrity, and commitment to represent our country honorably at these prestigious academies. I look forward to supporting these exceptional young leaders as they progress through their careers. Congratulations! 
To read the full list of nominees, please click here. 
￼ 
Legislative Update
On Tuesday, I voted to support H. Res. 1165, a House resolution which publicly condemns the Assad regime and its supporters for their continued support of war crimes and atrocities committed against the Syrian people. For several years, the reign of Assad in Syria has led to the death of countless civilians and endless violence in Syria. This abuse from Assad must end. 
On Wednesday, I voted to pass H.R. 2, the 2018 Farm Bill. This important bipartisan legislation attacks fraud and abuse while supporting our farmers and agriculture industry, which is critical to the Florida economy. The House also passed H.R. 1318, the Preventing Maternal Death Act, of which I am a proud cosponsor. This bill supports states in their efforts to protect the health of mothers during pregnancy, childbirth, and in the postpartum period by helping to identify means of improving both health care quality and outcomes for mothers. 
Yesterday, I voted for H.Res. 1091, a House resolution that urges the government of Burma to release two journalists who have been sentenced to seven years in jail for simply doing their jobs – investigating attacks against civilians by Burma's military and security forces. A free press is fundamental to supporting human rights and holding governments accountable for their actions.  
  
￼ 
Snapshot: Recent Photo Highlights 
￼ 
I had the opportunity to address the Society of American Military Engineers at their 2018 Industry Day and expressed my appreciation for the work they do to support our men and women in uniform.   
 
￼ 
I was honored to join the American Red Cross in writing Christmas cards to our brave men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. I am forever grateful for the sacrifices they make to keep our country free and safe. 
￼ 
Stay Connected
As your voice in Washington, it is important that I hear from you. I want to hear your ideas and opinions, and I hope to keep you informed on what is happening in Congress. You can visit my website for press releases and recent news, and follow me on Twitter and Facebook to find out how I’m fighting for the people of Northeast Florida. It is an honor to serve the 4th District and I look forward to hearing from you. 

￼

Subject: Conaway Chronicle: Farm Bill Passes Congress, Heads to President Trump's Desk, House Passes George W. Bush Childhood Home Act, House Passes Resolution to Oppose Nord Stream II
Message:
￼
December 14, 2018

Conaway Chronicle: Farm Bill Passes Congress, Heads to President Trump's Desk, House Passes George W. Bush Childhood Home Act, House Passes Resolution to Oppose Nord Stream II
__________________________________________


Thank you for reading The Conaway Chronicle, a review of my activities in Congress and the 11th District. 

Farm Bill Passes Congress, Heads to President Trump's Desk

House Republicans refused to stop fighting for rural America and this week, we approved a bill that sets us on a better path – for farmers and ranchers, for rural communities, and for the American consumer. I am proud of the work we have done to fight for the hard-working farm and ranch families who feed and clothe this nation, to fight for better policy that strengthens the farm safety net and our rural communities, improves conservation initiatives, expands exports, and enhances the integrity of our nutrition programs.

I’ve maintained from the beginning that this farm bill ought to be about standing up for America’s farm and ranch families who are going through some very hard times. And we have kept faith with that commitment. Farm country and rural America will be better off under this farm bill than they were before. I want to thank our leadership in the House, Secretary Perdue and President Trump. Because of our work this year, rural America and farm and ranch country know we have their backs.

￼


House Passes George W. Bush Childhood Home Act

George W. Bush’s childhood home in Midland, Texas is a piece of our nation’s history. Two Presidents, two governors, and a first lady have called this house their home. As the nation mourns the passing of George Herbert Walker Bush, our 41st President, we are especially reminded of the importance of preserving living landmarks for future generations.

Monday, the House of Representatives passed my bill, H.R. 3008, the George W. Bush Childhood Home Study Act. This legislation, which passed 382-4-2, aims to preserve the Midland home of the Bush family as a national landmark. 

Currently open to the public as a museum, my legislation will work to protect the home as a national historic landmark. I’m grateful for the outpouring of support this bill received, which will ensure that all Americans have the opportunity to be inspired by the lives of the Bush family.

￼


House Passes Resolution to Oppose Nord Stream II

Vladimir Putin is once again attempting to flex Russia’s energy muscle to exert control over Western Europe through the construction of Nord Stream II, an underwater gas pipeline that would connect the Russian Federation to Germany through the Baltic Sea. Despite a 55 billion cubic meter surplus in existing transit lines through Ukraine, Russia is determined to build a pipeline that would be 100 percent Russian owned and operated by a company whose chairman is currently sanctioned by the United States. 

Tuesday, the House of Representatives unanimously passed H. Res. 1035, a resolution I authored to express opposition to the completion of Nord Stream II. 

Russia has continually defied global norms, sovereign boarders, and international law. We would be foolish to allow Vladimir Putin a stronger grip on our European allies and the global energy market.

My speech on the House Floor in support of H. Res. 1035 can be found here. 


As always, you can follow me on Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter. 

Sincerely, 
￼
Rep. Mike Conaway, 11th District

Subject: Fighting for Ohio GM Workers
Message:
Can't see the pictures? Select "Always display images" or view this message in your browser.

￼
 
Fighting for Ohio GM Workers 

 ￼
  ￼
  ￼
  ￼
If you love this country, you fight for the people who make it work – people like the workers at Lordstown. 

That’s why last week, Senator Portman and I met with General Motors CEO Mary Barra and demanded answers, calling on GM to work with us to find solutions and save Ohio jobs, after GM announced it would lay off its final shift of workers and close its Lordstown plant in March of 2019.

That decision came on the heels of GM’s announcement this summer that it would lay off the second shift of workers at the plant, on the very same day that we got word that GM plans to build its new Chevy Blazer in Mexico.

During last week’s meeting, we urged Barra to work with us to save these Ohio jobs, and consider retooling the Lordstown plant to build a new vehicle. We know Ohio workers are the best in the world – the plant was rated the top GM plant in North America by J.D. Power and Associates this year.

Ohio has stood by GM. And now GM needs to stand by Ohio, and the workers who make their company successful.

The Mahoning Valley isn’t giving up. The community is waging a grassroots campaign with labor and business and local leaders to make it clear to GM how vital this plant and the entire Ohio supply chain is. I stood with them last month as they launched that effort. 

And I spoke to President Trump, and called on him to join us in working to save these jobs, and support my American Cars, American Jobs Act. 

The bill has two simple parts: it gives customers a discount when they buy American-made cars, like those built in Lordstown, and it gets rid of incentives that reward car companies for sending jobs overseas. 

Communities like the Mahoning Valley trusted Donald Trump when he said in 2016, “If I’m elected, you won’t lose one plant, you’ll have plants coming into this country…I promise you that.”

If he meant that, I’m calling on the president – help us pass the American Cars, American Jobs Act.

Let’s end the tax cut for corporations that shut down these American plants and move American jobs overseas, and let’s keep workers on the job in Lordstown.

Sherrod

￼
￼
Weekly Update From Congresswoman Anna G. Eshoo 
Highlights of Legislation the House Took up This Week 
Passed S. 3029, the Prematurity Research Expansion and Education for Mothers who deliver Infants Early (PREEMIE) Reauthorization Act 
This week the House passed my legislation to reduce infant deaths related to premature births, defined as a birth before 37 weeks of pregnancy, and it will now be sent to the President for his signature. This bipartisan, bicameral bill will reauthorize legislation I shepherded into law in 2006.
This bill specifically expands research, education and intervention activities aimed at preventing premature births. Every year in the U.S., ten percent of babies are born prematurely, placing them and their mothers at an increased risk of complicated health problems. Since this legislation became law in 2006, the PREEMIE Act has helped researchers and doctors identify the causes of premature births and work to prevent them. The number of preterm births decreased from 2007 to 2014, but they’ve begun to rise again. I look forward to the President signing this reauthorization into law to ensure that every child has a healthy start to life. 
Passed S. 428, the Advancing Care for Exceptional Kids Act (ACE Kids Act)  
This week the House passed legislation that will advance care for the sickest children who are Medicaid beneficiaries. Children with complex medical conditions require a multi-pronged level of health services which are expensive and difficult for families to coordinate. The ACE Kids Act aims to better coordinate this care while reducing overall Medicaid spending by creating a Medicaid care coordination program. Every state program will be specifically tailored to fit each child’s needs and will provide families with a care coordinator. This legislation is based on existing programs that save money by decreasing hospital visits and improving care. I salute the work of Lucile Packard Children’s Hospital on this issue and I look forward to the President signing this legislation into law.
Voted NO on a Rule Blocking the House from Voting on Resolution to withdraw U.S. forces from the conflict in Yemen 
The ongoing civil war and humanitarian crisis in Yemen is horrendous. Since the war in Yemen began in 2015, at least 6,000 civilians have been killed and 10,000 injured. A recent report by the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) Group of Experts found that the Saudi-led coalition which the U.S. supports, has committed acts including rape and the use of child soldiers, that likely amount to war crimes.
This week the Senate sent a powerful message to the Administration by voting on a Resolution to withdraw U.S. forces from the conflict in Yemen. Unfortunately, the Speaker of the House prevented any Resolution related to the war in Yemen from being brought directly to the full House for a vote during the remainder of this Congress. 
Legislation Anna Cosponsored This Week 
Introduced H.R. 7277, the Prevention of Unconstitutional War with Iran Act 
In my view, the President’s decision to walk away from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) with Iran represented an abdication of U.S. leadership. Since he withdrew the U.S. from the agreement, he has made repeated threats to wage war on Iran. 
This week I introduced the Prevention of Unconstitutional War with Iran Act, legislation prohibiting the use of any funds for military operations in or against Iran without Congressional authorization. This legislation guarantees that any decision to take military action against Iran must first be authorized by Congress which has the sole authority to declare war under Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution. 
Letters Anna Wrote and Cosigned this Week 
Letter to the Trump Administration Urging Action on Climate Change 
During the Thanksgiving holiday, the U.S. Global Change Research Program (USGCRP) released an assessment that is the most comprehensive, science-based evaluation of the consequences of climate change, the risks of inaction and potential adaptation strategies for the United States to date. The assessment adds to the overwhelming research indicating that the consequences of inaction on climate change will be serious and swift. Sadly, the President has dismissed the report and questioned the validity of climate science.
This week I joined colleagues in writing to the President urging him to address climate change in response to the assessment. To read the full letter, CLICK HERE.  
Letter to the State Department Opposing Closure of Bay Area Refugee Resettlement Agencies 
Refugee resettlement has been a cornerstone of American foreign policy for decades. Historically, the U.S. has admitted an average of about 80,000 refugees annually, but for Fiscal Year 2019 the Trump Administration has set a historically low ceiling of 30,000 refugees. This means that resettlement agencies, including nine in the Bay Area, will have to close their affiliates and further reduce staffing. 
I joined colleagues this week in writing to the Secretary of State, urging him to reconsider these short-sighted cuts and instead utilize the full capacity of these agencies. Resettlement agencies have helped nearly all refugees find jobs, provide training to establish new businesses, and helped children enroll in schools. These agencies work hard to ensure that each refugee becomes economically self-sufficient and proud American citizens who can fully contribute to their new nation. To read the full letter, CLICK HERE.  
In the Words of My Constituents 
Every week hundreds of my constituents call and write to me to express their concerns, share their passions and ask questions regarding a wide range of legislation and policies. I actually read every communication and every constituent receives a personal response from me regarding their specific questions and comments.
Here’s a snapshot of the issues constituents wrote and called me about this week:    
·         294 constituents wrote to me to express their support for the Green New Deal. 
·         40 constituents wrote to me to express their support for H.R. 1847, the Prevent All Soring Tactics (PAST) Act which takes significant steps to halt the disturbing practice known as "horse soring.” Horse soring involves the intentional infliction of pain to a horse's legs or hooves in order to force the horse to perform an artificial, exaggerated gait.
·         22 constituents wrote to me about their concerns with funding for the U.S. border wall.  
Weekly Highlights 
This week the Communications and Technology Subcommittee held a hearing on the RAY BAUM’S Act, which reauthorizes the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). This law makes the FCC more transparent, efficient, and modern, strengthens our nation’s critical telecommunications services. I’m especially proud to have two bills I wrote and have championed for many years included in this legislation: ‘Dig Once’ and the RESPONSE Act. Both bills are commonsense and won’t cost a dime.
My ‘Dig Once’ policy will help eliminate the need to dig up recently-paved roads to expand broadband infrastructure, significantly reducing the cost of increasing Internet access to rural communities across the country.  
The RESPONSE Act will provide first responders with the precise location of a 9-1-1 caller, whether they’re on the 20th floor of a hotel or the 30th story of an office building. Every second counts to save lives during emergencies, and location technology is essential for first responders to get to those in danger as quickly as possible. 
Anna’s Recommended Reading 
I frequently read articles or see videos I think my constituents would benefit from.   
Time Magazine Person of the Year (2018) “The Guardians and the War on Truth”  
This year Time Magazine chose slain journalist Jamal Khashoggi and staff members of the Capital Gazette of Annapolis, Maryland, along with journalists punished for attempting to report facts as their Time Person of the Year for 2018. Time calls them the "Guardians" in a struggle against lies and misinformation that has pit news agencies against political groups and governments. 
Staying Informed      
You can find more press releases, commentary and information on issues at my website, eshoo.house.gov. And please visit Instagram, Facebook and Twitter for more ways to stay informed.                                                                                  
 All my best, ￼  Anna G. Eshoo

HOME
CONTACT 
SERVICES
MEDIA CENTER
OUR DISTRICT
ABOUT ME
￼
￼
Dear Lindsey,
I know it may be hard to believe, but I actually have some good news to report from Washington.
This week, we passed the Farm Bill, which is a bill Congress is supposed to pass every five years to guide our nation’s agriculture and nutrition policy. One of its most important parts is the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which literally puts food on the table for our nation’s neediest and is one of our most effective anti-hunger programs. Originally, House Republicans tried to make deep cuts to SNAP that would have kicked millions of low-income families off the program with no other way to put food on their table. I, and every other Democrat, refused to go along, and I am proud to say that bill we passed this week rejected all of these cuts and even found ways to invest nearly $1 billion in additional support for food banks nationwide, the Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations, the SNAP Employment and Training program, and in incentives for healthier eating for SNAP beneficiaries.
I’m also proud to report that the House and Senate have finally agreed on a final bill to contend with Congress’s own #MeToo problem. With this legislation, we are creating a fair process for Capitol Hill staffers to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment and assault and enacting tougher punishments for perpetrators. This means that House of Representatives staff will now have access to House counsel, have a dedicated advocate to guide them through the process before making a formal complaint, and be able to work remotely or request paid leave without fear of retribution. It also requires public reporting of any settlements and identifying if a Member of Congress was personally liable. It also importantly requires that Representatives and Senators use their own money for harassment and retaliation settlements, instead of misusing taxpayer money.
I will return to Washington, DC next week in the hopes of voting on bills to keep the government open and funded. Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi made it clear in the Oval Office this week that there are several reasonable options on the table to prevent a shutdown. Republicans in Congress would be wise to ignore the President’s desire for a shutdown and work with us to keep the government open and serving the people.  
As always, your concerns remain my top priority. Please do not hesitate to reach out to my office via my website to share your thoughts.
Sincerely,
￼
Carolyn B. Maloney
Member of Congress

Subject: The Farm Bill: keeping our promise to NC farmers and families
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
About David    |     Serving You    |     Issues  |       Newsroom    |     Contact 
GET CONNECTED: 
￼ ￼ ￼  
Dear Lindsey,
 As you may know, the Farm Bill, which expired on October 1 of this year, came to the House floor again for a vote this week. 
Agriculture has always been an integral part of North Carolina's history and economy, and the Farm Bill plays a crucial role in supporting our farmers and ranchers—improving quality of life, and addressing food insecurity, which impacts more than one in six North Carolinian families.  Although I do not serve on the Agriculture Committee which oversees the Farm Bill, as our state’s only member of the Appropriations Committee, I have advocated for robust funding for anti-hunger initiatives, agricultural research, and rural development programs that benefit our state.  In the current Congress, I have also cosponsored legislation to increase Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits (H.R. 1276, the “Closing the Meal Gap Act”) and to invest more in organic agriculture (H.R. 2436, the “Organic Agriculture Research Act”). 
The Farm Bill that came to the House floor for a vote on December 12 was a result of extensive bipartisan negotiation and compromise. I’m pleased that harmful provisions in the original House version that would have drastically reduced SNAP benefits and funding for conservation programs were ultimately omitted from the final legislation. The bipartisan bill, which I’m proud to have voted for, protects SNAP benefits for American families, maintains critical funding for farming conservation programs, supports cutting edge federal agricultural research, and strengthens rural development programs across the country. 
As your member of Congress, you can rest assured that I will continue to protect anti-hunger programs, advocate for our farmers and ranchers, and support legislation that will improve the lives of all North Carolinians. 
To stay in touch regarding agriculture policy and many other important issues, please connect with me on Facebook and Twitter or subscribe to my e-newsletter.

Sincerely, 
￼
DAVID E. PRICE
Member of Congress

Home 
Services

December 13, 2018 
Honoring Our Veterans 
           ￼ 
Dear Friends,  
As a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, I learn every week about the bravery of our military service members. The sacrifices they make to defend our freedom are truly awe inspiring, and we owe them an immeasurable debt. From the earliest days of the Republic, caring for our returning soldiers has been a sacred duty of Congress. And while it is important that we take the time to demonstrate our appreciation throughout the year, each Veterans Day is a special opportunity to show our gratitude to the thousands of veterans who reside here in Rhode Island.  
November 11 was chosen as Veterans Day because it is the day World War One ended, and this year’s commemorations were particularly poignant as they fell on the 100th anniversary of that armistice. Over the weekend, I joined several of my colleagues in federal and state government at the WaterFire Salute to Veterans lighting ceremony. This particular edition of one of Rhode Island’s iconic traditions served as a fitting tribute to those who have served in uniform. I also had the pleasure of participating in the North Kingstown Veterans Day Parade. From Wickford Village to North Kingstown High School, it was wonderful to see so many Rhode Islanders on the parade route.  
More recently, I was pleased to help usher legislation through the House of Representatives to memorialize Army Captain Matthew J. August, a North Kingstown native who was tragically killed in action when his convoy was ambushed in 2004. Captain August was the first Rhode Islander to be killed as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom. This legislation will designate the post office in Saunderstown as the “Captain Matthew J. August Post Office” in his honor.  
If you are a veteran in need of assistance with your benefits, I encourage you to call my Rhode Island office at (401) 732-9400. For more information on veterans’ issues and my visits around the Second District, please visit my website and follow me on Twitter, Facebook, YouTube and Instagram.  
            Sincerely,  
           ￼ 

￼ 
Getting Down to Small Business 
Small businesses are the heart and soul of retail districts here in the Ocean State. On “Small Business Saturday,” I joined the Rhode Island SBA and my colleagues in the federal delegation to celebrate the local shops and restaurants that line the Main Streets of communities across the state. Shopping small is a great way to support the local economy and find unique gifts for your loved ones this holiday season. 
  
￼ 
Reducing Waste 
The Center for EcoTechnology was recently awarded a federal grant to help address the issue of food waste in Rhode Island. According to the Natural Resources Defense Council, up to 40% of the food in the country goes uneaten. This grant will help restaurants and other businesses find cost-effective ways to reduce this waste through composting or programs aimed at battling food insecurity. 

Join the Conversation: 

￼
￼
￼
￼

OPEN ENROLLMENT 
Health Source RI’s open enrollment period closes December 31. Make sure you purchase or make any desired changes to your health coverage before the end of the year. 
Did You Know...? 
A SYMBOL OF FREEDOM 
You can order U.S. flags from my office, including ones that have been flown over the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. ›› 
FAST FACT 
The Roger Williams Park Zoo has opened its new “Faces of the Rainforest” exhibit, which brings over 100 species from the Amazon Rainforest to Rhode Island. ›› 
In Other News 
REMEMBERING A PRESIDENT 
Rep. Langevin joined CNN’s John King to discuss President George H.W. Bush and his enduring legacy as a champion for people with disabilities. ›› 
OVERSIGHT NEEDED 
Rep. Langevin called for increased Congressional oversight of the Department of Defense’s new cybersecurity strategy. ›› 
SUPPORTING FIREFIGHTERS 
Rep. Langevin joined Senator Jack Reed to announce over $200K in federal grant funding to help the Kingston Fire District attract more volunteers. ›› 
BUILDING INFRASTRUCTURE 
Rep. Langevin celebrated the ground breaking of the new Pawtucket-Central Falls commuter rail and bus station. ›› 
CREATING SAFE HOMES 
The Atlantic highlighted the troubling phenomenon of “second-chance adoptions” and Rep. Langevin’s efforts to protect children from unregulated custody transfers. ›› 
SECURING ELECTIONS 
Rep. Langevin hosted one of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s top cybersecurity officials to discuss Rhode Island’s leadership in election security. ›› 
ADVANCING AQUACULTURE 
Rep. Langevin announced nearly $750K in funding to support the development of the aquaculture workforce in Rhode Island. ››

Subject: HAPPENING SOON: I’m Hosting a Live Telephone Town Hall
A Message from Amata
Message:
￼
￼


Talofa Lindsey,

Congress is wrapping up 2018 after an eventful year, and I wanted to report back once more before we start the new 116th Congress in January with our priorities for American Samoa. 

We always have Veterans’ legislation moving through Congress, and this time of year is no exception. Much of this activity is dedicated to continuing bipartisan VA reforms based on the comprehensive VA MISSION Act which became law this year to ensure future services are available and prompt. Our Veterans should have confidence in these federal programs for their well-being and health, and in American Samoa – where our Veterans travel long distances for many services – there are long term needs for better facilities and access.
﻿
A personal highlight recently has been the opportunity to congratulate two of our own from American Samoa, retiring after lengthy and impressive careers in the U.S. Army. Chief Warrant Officer Taufaga’afa Lincoln P. Glenister served under seven U.S. Presidents in over 40 years, and Master Sergeant Christabel “Chris” Lupetaliaami Jennings Joyner retired after 26 years of service and deployments. It’s a privilege to serve on the Committee that oversees our nation’s commitments to our Veterans through these legislative efforts to reduce VA wait times and improve claim responses. Read more about our oversight of the VA’s implementation of new laws. 


Soifua,

￼

‌

 

Congress Honors Our 41st President
￼

Former President George H. W. Bush lay in state in the Capitol Rotunda. 

Legislative efforts in Congress came to a halt last week for something even more important, the national remembrance of former President George H. W. Bush. The House passed House Resolution 1167 to express “profound regret and sorrow” as “the House tenders our deepest sympathies to the family.” Congress hosted former Presidents and dignitaries to honor his many decades of service. He was at one point the youngest Navy pilot as he served in combat in World War II, then went on to remarkable public service, including Director of the CIA, envoy to China, Ambassador to the UN, Vice President and President. Following the invasion of Kuwait, he united much of the world in an international coalition to liberate Kuwait, and he was President during the historic fall of the Berlin Wall. Last week, Congress commemorated this extraordinary role in our national history, as thousands of Americans lined up to view President Bush lying in State in the Capitol. 

This year, Congress also paid tribute to the memory Senator John McCain of Arizona, another Veteran with heroic wartime service followed by lengthy public service. Congress passed House Concurrent Resolution 140 to commemorate his contribution to our nation and the causes of human rights and peace, and named in his honor the Defense Authorization Act which secured a pay raise for our troops. 
﻿
Finally, the House Natural Resources Committee, on which I serve, paused recently under the leadership of Chairman Rod Bishop to remember the life of Utah’s longest-serving Congressman, Rep. James “Jim” Hansen, who started his life of service with a stint in the Navy and a two-year mission for his faith, and ended his public role as Chairman of the Natural Resources Committee. We also honored Rep. Hansen in the Western Caucus, a group which he led and started in his time in Congress.
￼

Pacific World War II Heritage
￼

￼

American Samoa’s own Peter Tali Coleman, pictured here in the U.S. Army in World War II, is a Pearl Harbor survivor.

On December 7th, as we do each year, the nation commemorated Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day, and in American Samoa our history includes the presence of American Samoa’s first Governor, Tali P.T. Coleman, on Oahu during the attack, and my statement on the 73rd V-J Day recalls American Samoa’s role in World War II. 

﻿Recently, Congress passed a bill to establish Pearl Harbor National Memorial and the Honouliuli National Historic Site. I cosponsored and voted for this legislation in the Natural Resources Committee, called the World War II Pacific Sites Establishment Act (H.R. 5706). 
￼

News to Know 
￼

Airport and Infrastructure

In October, the President signed our cabotage bill for American Samoa into law following passage by both houses of Congress. Over time, this change to regulations will help hold down costs for our people as they travel among the islands. This dovetails with recent federal action to invest $23 million in better pavement at our Pago Pago International Airport. American Samoa’s population, combined with our economic and geographic isolation, necessitate dependence on federal backing for our regular programs and especially infrastructure enhancements, often through federal grants. The role of Congress is to authorize and appropriate funds for the departments and agencies, which then follow Congressionally established priorities to distribute funds. 
￼

Fishing and Environment

This week, the House passed a bill which I cosponsored that establishes more funding support for coral reef preservation. The bill asserts each Territory’s right to determine for themselves whether to consider offshore wind energy. I support our friends in these other Territories in this legislation, and the bill confirms an important principle that our Territory and our people are the ones who should decide when it comes to any offshore wind proposals in the future. American Samoa recently received federal funds for coral reef preservation efforts. In November, the House Natural Resources Committee passed a bill I recently introduced (H.R. 5025) to put sensible time limits on any government fines and penalties for fishing vessels. These limits are important to address violations in a timely way for the protection of workers. 
￼

Constituent Services
￼

We’re proud of our high rate of Armed Forces enlistment in American Samoa. As always, our office each year seeks highly qualified applications for the nation’s service academies. If you’re a parent, teacher or student don’t forget to be thinking about participating in the Congressional Art Competition! Finally, we also have a very specific eligibility for a service-disabled Veteran for a potential two-year fellowship in the District Office working with our large population of Veterans. To qualify, veterans must meet all the following requirements: 

• Honorably discharged, released from active duty within the last five years 

• Terminal pay grades at or below E-5 or O-3, 

• 20% or greater service connected disabilities (waived if you have a Purple Heart). 

Veterans who are in receipt of a 20-year or Temporary Early Retirement Authorization (TERA) retirement are not eligible for the program. Interested veterans should go to https://www.usajobs.gov/ and search “Wounded Warrior Fellowship Program” for more information and how to apply. Please address any questions to the points of contact below. Mac Tolar, Director, Wounded Warrior Program, U.S. House of Representatives 202-226-1965; or Solomon “Sol” Jennings IV, Program Manager 202-226-1944, or their email address housewoundedwarriors@mail.house.gov. 
￼

A Congressional Tradition
￼

Each year, Congress beautifies the Capitol grounds with a special tree selected by the Architect of the Capitol with the aid of the U.S. Forest Service. This year’s is an 80-foot noble fir tree brought all the way across the U.S. mainland from the West Coast in Oregon’s Willamette National Forest to the East Coast. On December 6th, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan presided over the tree lighting and unveiling. 
￼

Subject: Thank You
Message:
News from Representative Elizabeth Esty 
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME | CONTACT | SERVICES | PRIORITIES | RESOURCES






December 13, 2018 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
icons
Dear Lindsey,   It has been an extraordinary honor to serve the residents of central and northwest Connecticut as their Representative in the U.S. House of Representatives over the last 6 years. Earlier this week, for the last time as a Member of Congress, I went to the well of the House and offered my final floor speech.  I wanted to make sure that you had an opportunity to see it. 
￼ 
Thank you to my constituents who entrusted me to work on their behalf, my amazing family for their love, support, and sacrifices over more than a dozen years of elected office, my staff who worked so hard and ably, and my many colleagues who generously guided me for an amazing 6 years in Congress. 
                       
Sincerely,
￼ 
Elizabeth Esty 
Member of Congress
  
Thank you, Mr. Speaker.  
I rise today for the last time as a Member of Congress.  For the past 6 years it has been an extraordinary honor to serve the residents of central and Northwest Connecticut as their representative in the House. 
The title for this job is a humble one – Representative.  Not Emperor.  Not Knower-of-all-Things.  Representative. 
Congress was not my dream – but making a difference was. In 2005, my then-15-year-old daughter challenged me to either run for the local Town Council or stop complaining.  I ran. 
And I found that I could get things done, first on the Town Council and then as a state representative.  I came to Congress with a desire to make a difference for people, to help solve their problems, fight for affordable quality health care, ensure education that addresses the needs of every child, work across the aisle for better jobs and better pay for Americans, and keep us all safe and free. 
Yet I arrived in Congress in the aftermath of the terrible shootings of 20 six- and seven- year old children and 6 educators in the town of Newtown in my district, 6 years ago this coming Friday.  My task immediately became how to truly care for and represent those families, and be an effective voice for taking action to prevent gun violence.  
At the time, I did not even know how to find the elevator to get to my attic office in the Cannon House Office Building.  John Dingall, longest serving member of Congress, took me under his wing and helped me navigate these halls.  He gave me invaluable advice.  He said, “Elizabeth, always remember this.  What you DO is very important.  But YOU are NOT important.”  He also told me, “It is your job to know your district, and vote your district.”  
How right he was.  I learned my district. My team and I worked with others to get lots of legislation passed to help veterans and their families; to support STEM education for women and girls and children of color; to modernize and upgrade our infrastructure; and to fight the scourge of opioid addiction.  
And we helped thousands of individuals at home cut through red tape and get much needed support.  By working WITH people, we were able to help government work FOR people. 
Here are some things I have learned: 
The American people are good and great, and eager to see our democracy work better. Sharing credit is not only the right thing to do, but it works. If you listen to others, if you look for and build on common ground, you can get things done even with people with whom you disagree on many issues. The first step is often the hardest. In politics, you need to earn support. You’re not entitled to it. You will fail sometimes. You won’t meet your own high expectations. You will disappoint people. You will lose an election. But you get up the next day and you try harder. If there’s nothing you would be willing to lose an election over, you shouldn’t run for office. 
Democracy needs people who are prepared to lose their job to make a difference. Democracy is not about perfection. Democracy is about trying your best every day. And bringing out the best in others. And when we fall – which we will – we should not give up. We should get right back to work. You shouldn’t run because you know you’ll win. You should run because there are things worth fighting for. If we remember our common values, rather than call into question each other’s integrity, there is much we can do together. Democracy is something we do, not something we tweet about. Democracy is hard – it is not a spectator sport. You don’t need permission in this great country. Democracy gives us – each and every one of us – the opportunity, the right to run, to serve, and to make a difference. American democracy is a great thing. But it requires us to pitch in. To do our part. We have the opportunity – and in these challenging times for our nation and the world, I believe we have an obligation – to get involved. 
I thank my amazing family for their love and support, and their sacrifices over more than a dozen years of elected office. I thank the voters who entrusted me to work on their behalf. I thank my excellent staff who have worked so hard and ably.  And I thank the many colleagues who generously guided me, and worked with me on issues of common concern for the American people. 
In closing, John Dingall’s words return to me – “If you ever look up at the Capitol Dome at night, Elizabeth, and it doesn’t send shivers down your spine, you don’t deserve to be here because you aren’t sufficiently in awe of Democracy.” I can say without hesitation -- the white of the Capitol Dome gleaming in the night still sends shivers down my spine.  And it always will.  For we are fortunate enough to live in this amazing country where we have the right to choose our leaders, to raise our voices, and together to forge a better nation and a better future for all our children. 
                          
To stay in the know: 
￼          ￼

Subject: The Beatty Bulletin - Fall 2018
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

BEATTY BULLETIN FALL 2018

 Fighting for Affordable, High-Quality Healthcare and Education  
In August, U.S. Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03) held separate events on healthcare and education, including her Healthcare Listening Session and Roundtable for Ohio’s Third Congressional District and a Community Conversation on science, technology engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. 
More than 30 healthcare executives, community leaders, government officials, and nonprofit organizations participated in the August 15th Listening Session and Roundtable, sharing their perspectives on improving access to and the delivery of healthcare, as well as fresh ideas to make sure more individuals and families can live happier, healthier lives. Attendees discussed the social determinants of healthcare and how to best help people overcome obstacles to obtaining healthcare. 
“This event is all about strengthening the dialogue between policymakers, stakeholders, and the healthcare community in Central Ohio. My constituents are concerned about rising healthcare and prescription costs and quality of care.” Beatty continued, “Your insight will allow me to work closely with my Congressional colleagues to develop positive, sustainable policy solutions to the important healthcare issues facing our nation.” 
The August 14th Community Conversation at St. Stephen’s Community House served as an opportunity for constituents of Ohio’s Third Congressional District to speak one-on-one with Beatty and to get an update on the positive impact of STEM in Central Ohio. 
“We need a highly trained workforce ready for the jobs of tomorrow. Unfortunately, our country is facing a massive shortage of workers skilled in these areas. To help fill the void, St. Stephen’s Community House, countless local nonprofits, and community stakeholders are working overtime to equip more people with the much-needed tools, expertise, and education to succeed in the 21st century, and I am working in Congress to make it a reality.”


￼



Congresswoman Beatty hosts a Community Conversation at St. Stephen’s Community House to highlight her legislative efforts to expand STEM education in public schools across the country. (August 14, 2018)

 

A Voice "For the People"
Congresswoman Beatty recently lead a press call with national and local media, highlighting her commitment to better jobs, better healthcare, and a better future for all Americans. Coinciding with the call, Democrats released a new report on the economic struggles facing hardworking families and middle-class Americans. Highlights from “For the People: Report on Impacts of GOP Agenda on Health and Economic Security of Ohioans” include:
• 78 percent of full-time workers are living paycheck-to-paycheck.
• Real wages have fallen in Ohio since 2017.
• One million Ohio taxpayers will see no tax benefit by 2019. 
• Health coverage for more than 4.8 million Ohioans with pre-existing conditions is in jeopardy if the  Affordable Care Act is repealed. 
Reacting to the new report, Beatty said, “Americans want a government for the people. This report shows that many of my constituents, their families, and our seniors are struggling to simply make ends meet. That is why I will continue to do everything in my power to ensure all their voices are heard, and that we work to close the wage gap and growing wealth inequality.”
 
 
Working to Improve Central Ohio’s Mail Delivery
Following several complaints about mail being delivered to incorrect addresses, unacceptable delays, and—even worse—lost mail, Congresswoman Beatty sprung into action. 
Since first becoming aware of potential problems in March 2018, she and her District staff have held weekly phone calls with local and regional officials regarding service, hiring efforts, and individual cases. Staff has traveled across the state on multiple occasions for one-on-one meetings with United States Postal Service (USPS) leadership and secured a commitment from the agency to hire more than 800 carriers throughout the area. Also, the USPS created a new Consumer Advisory Council to provide feedback and suggestions on how to improve quality of services. This is the third such council ever created and came about after communication between Deputy U.S. Postmaster General Ronald Stroman and staff.  
Please note, residents of Ohio’s Third Congressional District with unresolved issues are strongly encouraged to call the USPS consumer affairs line at (513) 684-5794 or Beatty’s District Office at (614) 220-0003 for assistance.   ￼ 
Congresswoman Beatty provides an update on mail delivery, speaking with ABC6’s Terri Sullivan. (October 15, 2018)
 

In the Community: Central Ohio-Mauritanian Listening Session and Moms2B Visit

       ￼        ￼
Pictured above, Congresswoman Beatty convened a meeting on October 9, 2018, between representatives of Central Ohio’s Mauritanian community, national experts, and various stakeholders, to discuss the plight of local families facing deportation because of recent executive action. 
On August 13, 2018, Congresswoman Beatty visited New Salem Baptist Church in the Linden neighborhood to see firsthand the impact of Central Ohio’s Moms2B campaign and talk about her work to address the community infant mortality crisis. 

 

Looking Toward the New Year and New Congress
As the 115th Congress comes to a close, and with the New Year and new Congress on the horizon, it is my hope that 2019 will usher in a sense of urgency and renewed commitment to civility. 
Still today, too many hardworking Ohioans and middle-class families are struggling to make ends meet and want Congress to do something about it. They want better wages, better jobs, and a better future. 
They want affordable, high-quality healthcare, education, and childcare. They want to be able to pay their bills, afford a mortgage, save a few extra dollars at the end of the month, and equal opportunity at the American Dream. Finally, and equally as important, they want a government that is accountable to the people. 
In that spirit, I will work in Congress with Democrats and Republicans to deliver real progress on these issues and the many economic, social, and global challenges facing our country.
Unfortunately, civility and bipartisanship are sorely missing right now. It is time we move beyond the divisive and hurtful rhetoric poisoning our political landscape and realize that, first and foremost, we are ALL Americans. Violence cannot be the answer. That is why I will continue to fight in D.C. and Central Ohio to be a bridge builder and spearhead efforts in Congress to ratchet down the rhetoric. 
I look forward to talking, listening and working with you in the weeks and months ahead to make these goals a reality.
Best wishes in the New Year! 
Sincerely,
￼ 
 

Getting to Know the District:
Highlighting the Franklinton Neighborhood 

Franklinton is located on the banks of the Scioto River and immediately west of downtown Columbus. Franklinton was founded by Lucas Sullivant in 1797 as the first American settlement in Franklin County, Ohio. As the City of Columbus grew, the city annexed and incorporated the existing Franklinton neighborhood.
Approximately 36,000 people call Franklinton home, and under former Columbus Mayor Michael B. Coleman a concerted effort was made to revitalize and reinvest in the neighborhood. These efforts are still ongoing, and the City of Columbus is squarely focused on further modernization and strengthening of the area economy. 
As the Member of Congress for Ohio’s Third Congressional District, Congresswoman Beatty has the privilege of representing residents of Franklinton in the U.S. House of Representatives. In Congress, she is working with state and local officials to attract new business opportunities and housing development projects to the community and is committed to helping constituents resolve problems with their Social Security, Medicare, VA, and many other federal issues. 
￼ 
￼
Scenes from around Franklinton (October 20, 2018). 
 
 Get Covered Now! 
 Individuals and families looking to enroll or change their healthcare plan can do so from now until    December 15, 2018. This is a shorter Open Enrollment Period than in previous years, so customers are   encouraged to enroll ASAP. 
 For more information, please visit: www.healthcare.gov

Subject: Capitol Hill Update from Congressman Castro
Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
Only two more days to get health insurance coverage for 2019. Most Americans can find cheaper plans that work for them and their families by logging onto healthcare.gov.  
￼ 
Latino Guidelines for ACA Enrollment 
This week, I joined Congressman Ben Ray Luján (NM-03) in sending a letter demanding an explanation from the Administration on reports that they had removed a document titled “Marketplace Outreach: Best Practices for Outreach to Latino Communities” from its Health Insurance Marketplace website.
￼ ￼ 
The removed PDF was a slide presentation intended as a training resource for assisters. It focused on the challenges Latinos might face when enrolling for coverage and included guidance on making services culturally and linguistically appropriate. You can read the letter here. 
Honoring our Nation’s Veterans 
Team Castro attended the Unaccompanied Veterans Funerals for Mr. Maximo Elizondo Garcia and Mr Robert Wayne Calcote. We thank them for their service to our nation.  
￼ ￼ 
Ensuring Safety and Wellbeing of Children in Government Custody 
In May, an 18-month-old toddler died just days after leaving government custody. I joined House Oversight and Government Reform Committee Ranking Member Elijah E. Cummings, House Homeland Security Committee Ranking Member Bennie G. Thompson, and House Judiciary Committee Ranking Member Jerrold Nadler in asking for the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General to conduct a review into the medical care provided by ICE Health Service Corps. You can read the letter here and read about the broader story on Vice News here. 
￼ 
Preventing Government Shutdown 
Americans don’t want a border wall, nor do they want to see our government shutdown. We’ve offered bipartisan compromises that could pass both chambers. Instead of pursuing partisan promises, the President should stop undermining our country’s ability to perform vital functions and agree to the proposals put on the table. You can read my full statement here on the President’s comments about a possible government shutdown next week. 
District Updates 
Team Castro joined Alamo Area Metropolitan Planning Organization for updates on transportation plans and roadway safety; met with SAStands for an update on their work in immigration and criminal justice reform; and joined fellow San Antonio residents at the City Council District 1 Holiday Open House.
￼ ￼ 
￼ ￼  
Team Castro also participated in the Ribbon Cutting and Grand Opening of the SGI-USA San Antonio Buddhist Center. 
Russia Investigation 
It’s clear that the Special Counsel’s investigation is working and we must protect him and his investigation so the American people can get the truth they deserve. I spoke to MSNBC’s Ali Velshi on All In with Chris Hayes to discuss the Mueller sentencing memos for Michael Cohen and Paul Manafort. I also spoke with MSNBC’s Chris Matthews this week to discuss Maria Butina’s plea deal with federal prosecutors.  
￼ 
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov.  
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress 
 
  
￼
￼

￼

Subject: Big Win Against Animal Cruelty
Message:
December 13, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
Big win for animal lovers this week! Congress passed and sent to the president my bill to ban the slaughter of dogs and cats for food. Two other animal welfare bills I co-sponsored also passed and will be signed into law.   My Dog and Cat Meat Trade Prohibition Act, amends the federal Animal Welfare Act to make it illegal to knowingly slaughter dogs or cats for human consumption. Although rare, the practice is still legal in 44 states. A restaurant in Philadelphia was closed several years ago after a worker was caught slaughtering cats chained in the basement to be served as meals, according to the Animal Welfare Institute.  The other animal welfare bills I co-sponsored are:   Pet and Women Safety (PAWS) Act makes it easier for women to bring their pets with them to domestic violence shelters when they leave abusive relationships by providing grants for shelter and housing assistance for domestic violence victims with pets. And the Parity in Animal Cruelty Enforcement (PACE) Act ends animal fighting in all United States territories. An animal fighting ban currently applies to the United States, but not territories, including Puerto Rico.   As chair of the Animal Protection Caucus in Congress, fighting against cruelty to animals will always be a priority. That is why I received a 100 percent score from the Humane Society for my leadership and votes in 2018. I am also a past recipient of the Humane Society’s “Legislator of the Year” award.  Please let me know your thoughts on how we can continue to promote efforts to protect animals and wildlife. I look forward to hearing from you. 
Vern

Subject: I cannot thank you enough
Message:
￼ 
 
Dear Friends,
I took to the Senate floor for the final time today to deliver my farewell address and to thank the people of Florida for the honor they've given me to serve as their voice in the United States Senate.
Grace and I have been overwhelmed by the outpouring of support we have received over the last few weeks, and I don't think anyone could have been more blessed.
It's not easy to take leave from the people and the work that I love, and it has caused times of intense reflection for me.
For instance, I remember the weeks leading up to our eventual launch aboard the Space Shuttle Columbia in 1986. We had been scrubbed four times before we successfully launched from the Kennedy Space Center on January 12, 1986.
It's not the flight itself that I have been focused on lately, instead it's the fact that after each of those four failed attempts, NASA engineers - after reexamining the shuttle - determined that all four would have likely ended in a catastrophic disaster had those flights not been aborted. 
I have been asking myself lately: Why was I spared? And only now, upon intense reflection in recent weeks, I think I'm beginning to understand why.
You see, it has been the great honor of my life to serve our country and the people of Florida - but, as I told my colleagues on the Senate floor today, we still have much work to do.
Now, more than ever, we need leaders who will focus on building the kind of relationships in Washington that can solve the great problems that our nation faces. We need our leaders to resist the forces that seek to divide us and, instead, demonstrate the moral courage it takes to choose country over party, or over power.
As I leave the Senate, I do so filled with hope for the future and with the fondest memories. I intend to keep fighting for all that we've accomplished in recent years, and will never stop fighting for the people of Florida.
Because, at the end of the day, I'm just a country boy who loved serving my state and our country. It's been an incredible honor, and I can't thank you enough.
￼
Sincerely,  ￼

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: 3 DAYS LEFT! Enroll in Healthcare
Message:
￼ 
 


Lindsey,  Don’t wait, there are only 3 DAYS left in the 2019 open enrollment period to get covered! Whether you’re uninsured, exploring available options, or updating life information, you have until December 15th to find coverage through the Marketplace that meets you and your family's needs. 
￼
Quality health coverage is more affordable than you may think. An average of 8 in 10 Delawareans qualify for financial help and premiums may be more affordable than previous years. The Marketplace and the expansion of Medicaid helped lower average health coverage costs by bringing the rate of uninsured Americans to a historic low at just 8.8 percent(1) — a win-win for everyone.
While there’s still time, visit www.HealthCare.gov to create an account and find a quality health insurance plan that works for you and your budget. And if you currently have health coverage from the Marketplace, now is your chance to review your application and ensure it’s up to date.
If you have any questions about signing up, or want to talk to a trained Marketplace navigator, free help is just a call or click away. To apply and enroll quickly online, visit www.HealthCare.gov or www.choosehealthde.com. You can also call the Marketplace call center 24 hours a day, 7 days a week at 1-800-318-2596, and a trained representative will be able to assist you in the enrollment process as well as to answer any questions you may have.  Sincerely,   Lisa Blunt Rochester Member of Congress  1. Coombs, Bertha. "Rates of uninsured in US hold steady at historic low 8.8 percent." CNBC, 13 Sept. 2018, . https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/12/rates-of-uninsured-in-us-hold-steady-at-historic-low-8point8-percent.html.  Accessed December 6, 2018.

Kwentoria A.Williams

Congressman Al Green's Statement on 2019 Open Enrollment Period 
(Houston, TX) - On Wednesday, December 12, 2018, Congressman Al Green made the following statement regarding the severity of enrolling in a health plan before open enrollment ends on Saturday, December 15, 2018:
“As the deadline for open enrollment rapidly approaches, I urge all of my constituents and everyone in this country to be sure to secure healthcare coverage for 2019. According to Community Health Choice, more than 185,000 constituents of the Ninth Congressional District of Texas, which I am proud to serve, do not have health insurance. This includes residents of both Fort Bend County and Harris County. In 2018, 13% of Fort Bend County’s uninsured population were eligible for Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and 17% were eligible for premium tax credits. In 2018, 13% of Harris County’s uninsured population were eligible for Medicaid or CHIP and 15% were eligible for premium tax credits. 
“If you do not have health insurance, please sign up for coverage at www.HealthCare.gov. If you feel you cannot afford coverage, visit www.HealthCare.gov to learn more about Medicaid and tax credit eligibility. For free, in-person assistance, call 1-800-318-2596 or visit Localhelp.HealthCare.gov. For assistance in other languages, visit www.HealthCare.gov/Language-Resource/.  
"Healthcare coverage is a life or death decision. Please, get covered. Make the December 15, 2018 deadline your lifeline to health care."

Subject: Where to find me in D.C.
Message:
News from Representative Heck  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

                                                     
My D.C. office is on the move
After three terms and six years in 425 Cannon, it's time to move on. Like a first home, our original office in D.C. will always be special to me. It's where I met with thousands of you who helped inform me of the many important decisions we've made since 2013. It's where we made plans to pass Export-Import Bank reauthorization, protect consumer protections for military servicemembers, and add Billy Frank Jr.'s name to the Nisqually National Wildlife Refuge, among many other initiatives. 
My D.C. office will be moving to 2452 Rayburn House Office Building for the next Congressional session. While Cannon is 110 years old, Rayburn is the newest, finished in 1965. My new office was first occupied by the legend, Congressman John Dingell, Jr. Representative Dingell is the longest-serving Congressperson in U.S. history, representing his seat in Michigan from 1955 to 2015. Nowadays you might appreciate his hilarious quips on Twitter, and I'm proud to serve with his wife, Congresswoman Debbie Dingell.  
The numbers of the house office buildings can get confusing, so it's useful to think about in terms of 0 as Cannon, 1 as Longworth, and 2 as Rayburn, with the second number indicating the floor. So we are going from the fourth floor of Cannon (0425), to the fourth floor of Rayburn (2452), and our friend Congressman Kilmer won't be far away on the fourth floor of Longworth (1410).
It's fitting as we both start our fourth term in Congress. I know we are both excited to represent the South Sound and continue to build on our Puget Sound recovery efforts. 
See you soon, either in our new digs in D.C. or in our district offices in Lakewood and Lacey - those will still be in the same locations.
Sincerely, 
￼
Denny Heck
Your Member of Congress

Subject: Poll: Border Wall Funding
Message:
￼ 

Poll: Border Wall Funding
Hoosiers,

Current government funding expires next Friday, December 21. Congress must pass a spending bill before December 21st to avoid a lapse in funding and a partial government shutdown. President Donald Trump has called on Congress to include $5 billion in the funding bill to pay for a wall along our country’s southern border. 

As Congress and the White House negotiate the contents of the bill, the president stated he would be willing to not sign the bill and shut down the federal government if this border wall funding is not included in the spending bill. 

Question of the Week: Do you support President Trump not signing a government spending bill into law if funding for the border wall is not included?

[_] Yes. We need to fund a wall along the southern border.
[_] No. We need to compromise and keep the government open.
[_] I don’t know.
[_] Other (share your thoughts).

Take the poll here.
Be sure to connect with Trey online:

Subject: HouseWatch Alert for the Week of Dec. 12, 2018
Message:
￼ 
Dear Friend,
Good news: families of children with complex medical conditions can celebrate passage of the ACE Kids Act in the U.S. House after many years of advocacy! The bill authorizes the creation of new cost-saving and time-saving medical homes where specialized care is coordinated in a high quality setting. I wrote the ACE Kids Act many years ago with the simple but important goal of putting children with complex medical conditions and their families first. The children served at St. Joseph's Children's Hospital Chronic-Complex Clinic in Tampa were my inspiration. Now, I am urging my colleagues in the U.S. Senate to pass the important bill before Congress adjourns for the year. 
￼
Florida is leading the nation again in sign-ups for affordable health coverage during Open Enrollment! With only three more days left until the December 15 deadline to sign-up, make sure you, your family, your friends and everyone you know has coverage.  Check out HealthCare.gov today and be ready for 2019! You can receive free, independent advice from Covering Florida Navigators at coveringflorida.org and other grassroots experts to find the right plan for you and your family. 
￼
In the waning days of the Republican House majority in the House the following votes are scheduled:  The 2018 Farm Bill (Conference Report for H.R. 2) was passed in the House and is on the way to the President’s desk. Most importantly, a bipartisan group of lawmakers were able to beat back devastating cuts to supplemental nutrition proposed by House Republicans. I was able to add provisions that aim to improve water quality by reducing nutrients relating to agriculture in response to one of Florida’s worst outbreaks of red tide and harmful algal blooms in our state’s history. These clean water provisions seek to better target conservation spending on the right practices in the right places, prioritizing clean water investments and addressing obstacles that get in the way of continued improvements in water quality and algal bloom prevention. Florida is a diverse agricultural state and the Farm Bill’s inclusion of conservation programs can play an important role in addressing our water quality challenges.  President Trump said this week that he would “be proud” to shut down the U.S. government at the end of next week over a border wall that he promised Mexico would pay for. That is irresponsible. Instead, Democrats and Republicans in Congress are ready to compromise, provide effective border security and not leave people out in the cold this holiday season. I hope the President listens. 
￼

Sincerely, 

Kathy Castor 

P.S. Remember to join me on Facebook for more pictures and information about issues important to our community.

To unsubscribe, please visit my web site .

Subject: Rep. Cuellar Votes in Support of Farm Bill
Message:
￼ 
HOME
ABOUT
28TH DISTRICT
SERVICE
ISSUES
NEWSROOM
STUDENTS
CONTACT
December 12, 2018
Rep. Cuellar Votes in Support of Farm Bill
WASHINGTON— Today, Congressman Henry Cuellar (TX-28) joined his colleagues in the U.S. House of Representatives by voting for H.R. 2, the Agriculture and Nutrition Act of 2018, also known as the Farm Bill. The bill, which passed the House by a vote of 369-47, will extend all agriculture and nutrition programs for the next five years, that includes support for farmers and ranchers in Texas and across the country. This legislation passed the U.S. Senate, and now moves to the President’s desk to be signed into law. 
“This bill is a direct investment for our farmers and cattle ranchers,” said Congressman Cuellar. “It will also ensure that Americans in rural and urban areas across the country continue to be provided with the safest and most abundant food supply in the world. Specifically, this legislation will modernize our agriculture support systems, save American taxpayer dollars, and offer our farmers and ranchers certainty on how American agriculture policy will be regulated.”
Congressman Cuellar continued, “I would like to thank House Agriculture Chairman Mike Conaway (TX-11), Ranking Member Collin Peterson (MN-7), and my fellow colleagues for working across the aisle to get this crucial bill passed.”
Nutrition & Hunger
This bill preserves crucial benefits for millions of Texans and their families, such as:
·         Reauthorizes SNAP for five years;
·         Expands funding for food banks with $206 million for The Emergency Food Assistance; Program (TEFAP), which helps supplement the diets of low-income Americans, including the elderly;
·         Makes donating fluid milk for food banks and other feeding programs easier; and
·         Provides $238 million for the Commodity Supplemental Food Program, which works to improve the health of low-income elderly persons by supplementing their diets with nutritious foods.
 
Support for Farmers & Ranchers
·         Maintains the core provisions of the federal crop insurance program, which is permanently authorized;
·         Increases farm loan authorization level from $4.23 billion to $10 billion, including a 50 percent set-aside for direct operating loans for beginning farmers and ranchers;
·         Combines and establishes mandatory funding for important programs to promote U.S. agricultural exports;
·         Improves the Agriculture Risk Coverage and Price Loss Coverage programs and offers producers choices;
·         Allows farmers to update their program yields, boosting their eligibility to receive support;
·         Increases marketing loan rates to improve farmers’ cash flow and access to credit when prices are low during harvest time;
·         Updates limits on Farm Service Agency (FSA) farm loans to keep pace with increasing costs and land values; and
·         Expands access to FSA farm loans for veteran and beginning farmers.
 
Partnerships with HSIs
·         Reauthorizes National Institute of Food and Agriculture education grants programs for Hispanic-serving institutions (HSIs), which prepare underrepresented students for careers related to the food, agricultural, and natural resource systems. HSIs in South Texas include: Laredo College, South Texas College, Texas A&M International University, University of Texas at San Antonio, and the University of the Incarnate Word. 
Conservation
·         The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP), which received $1.75 billion for FY19, would receive $2.03 billion by FY23. The program helps agricultural producers confront challenges while conserving natural resources like soil, water and air. Through EQIP, the National Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) provides agricultural producers with financial resources and one-on-one help to plan and implement improvements and conservation practices. Using these practices can lead to cleaner water and air, healthier soil and better wildlife habitat, all while improving agricultural operations for farmers in the 28th District;
·         Increases the amount of land allowed under the Conservation Reserve Program, which pays farmers not to produce crops on environmentally sensitive land; and
·         $450 million annually for the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program, which provides financial and technical assistance to help restore, protect, and enhance agricultural lands and wetlands.
 
Rural Development & Transparency 
This legislation includes provisions that helps struggling rural hospitals to gain better financial footing, reauthorizes critical rural water and sewer infrastructure programs, and boosts technical assistant for rural development programs in rural communities. It additionally increases USDA transparency. Provisions include:
·         $350 million annually for new broadband infrastructure. New projects would have to be in areas where at least 90 percent of households are unserved by broadband, instead of 15 percent under current law;
·         $82 million for Distance Learning and Telemedicine Grants, which help rural communities use the unique capabilities of telecommunications to connect to each other and the world;
·         $65 million for Rural Business Development Grants;
·         $50 million for Emergency Community Water Assistance Grants;
·         Requires USDA to establish a rural health liaison; and
·         Improves transparency through annual reports of USDA lending activity. 
 
Animal & Plant Health
·         $120 million from FY19 through FY22, and $30 million annually after that, for animal disease management programs, including research on cattle fever ticks;
·         Beginning in FY23, $18 million for a new National Animal Disease Preparedness and Response Program;
·         Funding would also be allocated for a new National Animal Vaccine and Veterinary Countermeasures Bank and for the National Animal Health Laboratory Network;
·         Provides $25 million annually for a new Citrus Trust Fund for research into citrus diseases and pests; and
·         $15 million annually for five years for USDA to establish a National Plant Diagnostic Network to monitor threats to plant health. 
 
For more information about the Farm Bill’s provisions, please click here.

Subject: Saturday (Dec. 15) is DEADLINE for Health Coverage!
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼ 

HOME
ABOUT G.K.B.
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
 
Dear Friend, 
We are now only 3 days away from this year’s December 15 deadline to sign up for health coverage at HealthCare.gov. 
Now is the chance to compare plans and benefits, find the best prices, and sign up for coverage.   
Hundreds of thousands of people are at risk of not having health insurance next year should they miss the Open Enrollment deadline.  I urge you, your friends, and your family to ensure they do not miss this opportunity for high quality, affordable health coverage.  If people miss the deadline, they will have to wait until the end of 2019 to obtain affordable coverage.
If you or someone you know needs health insurance, the time to act is now: 
Visit HealthCare.gov or call 1-800-318-2596 right now to enroll in coverage. 
￼ 
Accidents and illness can happen at any time – that’s why affordable, comprehensive health insurance is the smart choice.  Plans covered under the Affordable Care Act provide important benefits like prescription medicine coverage and are available to anyone, even those with pre-existing conditions.
I hope you’ll visit HealthCare.gov today and find a plan that works for you. 
  
Sincerely, ￼  G. K. Butterfield Member of Congress, NC-01 
  

￼ 
4 fast facts about getting covered through HealthCare.gov: 
	1.	Financial help is available.  More than 500,000 North Carolinians took advantage of this opportunity last year, and many of them received financial help to make their premiums more affordable.  During last year’s enrollment period, 9-in-10 North Carolinians who applied qualified for financial help- for most people, that meant they could find insurance premiums between $50 and $100 per month.
	2.	Don’t forget: You must sign up by this Saturday, December 15.  Enroll today on healthcare.gov.
	3.	Free, expert help is available.  Call 1-800-318-2596 for confidential assistance or visit localhelp.healthcare.gov to talk through your options with a trained professional.
	4.	New plan options for 2019.  This year, it is more important than ever to head back to HealthCare.gov to shop and save – comparing options for 2019.  In many areas, there will be more plans to choose from and you may save more.
Need additional help? 
The Get Covered Connector is updated by the enrollment-application assisters themselves.  When you put your zip code in, the website provides the address and phone number of various organizations in your area that can provide you with in-person assistance.  The tool allows you to book an appointment online with an assister, and will send email and text reminders to both the consumer and the assister.  
￼

Subject: Bergman Supports First District Farmers, Sends Farm Bill to President's Desk
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Dec 12, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158

 
Bergman Supports First District Farmers, Sends Farm Bill to President's Desk

Washington - Upon House passage of the 2018 Farm Bill conference report, Rep. Jack Bergman released the following statement:
"First District farmers supply our district, country, and world with food. I'm thankful the House and Senate were able to reach an agreement to pass a Farm Bill that protects our nation's farmers, ranchers, and rural families. Streamlining and reducing unnecessary regulations, ensuring our farmers remain protected from outside unfair trade practices, and ensuring a safety net remains in place especially for specialty crops such as cherries were key to this bipartisan victory.  "Additionally, the 2018 Farm Bill will help work towards the goal of ensuring high-speed broadband access for rural communities. Provisions included in the Farm Bill will help level the playing field for rural communities by continuing investments in broadband deployment across rural America."
In addition, the Farm Bill: 
	•	Protects Michigan cherry farmers by maintaining crop insurance framework so farmers, bankers, and businesses in the First District have a responsible support structure in cases of adverse weather or unexpected loss;
	•	Eliminates duplicative and unnecessary regulations, getting the government off the backs and out of the pockets of American farmers;
	•	Dedicates funding to help communities battling with the effects of the opioid epidemic;
	•	Makes significant investments for low-income Americans seeking further education;
	•	Maintains Good Neighbor Authority provisions, allowing the Forest Service to enter into agreements with States for forest management services; and
	•	Reduces the threat of catastrophic forest fires by allowing an expedited reduction of hazardous fuels in our forests.
bergman.house.gov
