Subject: A Truly Great American
Message:
District Update | December 9, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friends,

Martha and I have joined the rest of the nation in mourning over the loss of a faithful servant, President George H.W. Bush. He was truly a great American. This week, we have spent time reflecting on his strength of character and his devotion to our country and his loved ones. 

￼
It was a privilege to attend the funeral honoring a president, patriot, and faithful friend – President George H.W. Bush. Delivering his father’s eulogy, President George W. Bush said, "Through our tears, let us know the blessings of knowing and loving you, a great and noble man." I will treasure my memories of President George H.W. Bush and his sense of humor, kindness, and thoughtfulness. Martha and I will dearly miss him and are truly blessed to have known and worked for him.

Remembering a Truly Great American
￼
The train engine in Air Force one colors was painted in North Little Rock at the Union Pacific facility, and it transported President George H.W. Bush home to his final resting place in College Station,Texas. I spoke with Harris Faulker on Fox News about how fitting that the last ride is with the Union Pacific 4141 train. Listen to my interview here. 

Toy Drive for Our Arkansas Children 
￼
Rodney's Cycle House has hosted the Toys for Tots Foundation's Toy Run in Little Rock for the past 34 years and this year was no exception. Thank you, Rodney (pictured above), for helping put gifts under children's Christmas trees year after year. Find out more about this generous organization here. 

Lighting the Menorah
￼
Happy Hanukkah to all Arkansans who celebrate the Festival of Lights! ‬I was grateful to be a part of the 28th year of lighting the menorah at Centennial Bank in Little Rock with Rabbi Yosef Kramer, Rabbi Pinchus Ciment, Governor Asa Hutchinson, and First Lady of Arkansas Susan Hutchinson.

Honoring our Heroes at Wreaths Across America
￼
I was humbled to decorate tombs at the Arkansas State Veterans Cemetery in North Little Rock with holiday wreaths for Wreaths Across America. I saluted the volunteers and honor the memories of the brave men and women who wore the uniform.

“A day that will live in infamy”
￼
On Friday, we reflected on “a day that will live in infamy” as President Franklin Roosevelt famously called the attack on Pearl Harbor. What began as another peaceful day in Hawaii became one of the worst days in American History.
Navy Water Tender 2nd Class Clarence Lockwood and Seaman First Class Henry Tipton, both of Arkansas, were assigned to the battleship USS Oklahoma. The USS Oklahoma was moored at Ford Island, Pearl Harbor, when the ship was attacked by Japanese aircraft, killing 429 crewmen, including Lockwood and Tipton.
Earlier this year, their remains were finally identified and accounted for after 77 years of analysis. Their lives have become a symbol for the determination and heroism of the American people and our warriors.
We are all reminded of the lives lost that day and the sacrifice of their entire generation to rid the world of one of the most evil alliances ever created.
Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I'm doing on your behalf. If I can be of any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at (501) 324-5941 or Hill.House.Gov. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Representative French Hill

 Remembering 41



This week, we said goodbye to former President George H.W. Bush after his passing at the age of 94.
￼
Click to here to view Sen. Cornyn's floor remarks
“We know to his family he was a loving and caring father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. To his country, he was a devoted public servant who fought to defend our freedoms and led the nation at the end of the Cold War and at the fall of the Berlin Wall.”
“After graduating from college, he went to Midland, Texas, kind of an improbable place to go in those days, but he wanted to get involved in the oil business.”
“He later, after his successes in Midland, Texas in the Permian Basin, which continues to be one of the greatest reserves of oil and gas in the United States, he went on to Houston and grew his business and ultimately, as I said earlier, ran for Congress.”
“Even though Texas was an adopted home for him, Texans loved and embraced him, as we did the entire Bush family. We were privileged to have President Bush as one of our own."
“He once said, ‘I’m a Texan and an American. What more could a man ask for?’ I don't think anyone could have said it better.”
“Throughout his time in public service and even afterwards, he could have moved anywhere in the world, but he chose to live his life in Texas, and in the warm embrace of the state and the people he loved.” 
“President Bush felt a kindred spirit at Texas A&M University, choosing it first to bear his legacy through his presidential library and a graduate school of government and public service, and then later to be his and Barbara Bush's final resting place.” 
“President Bush, I think, identified with the university's unique culture, including its inculcation of patriotic values and the emphasis it places on hard work and public service.”

NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend, 

This week, we said goodbye to an American hero. President George H.W. Bush was honored at the United States Capitol where thousands came to pay their respects. Thank you to President Bush for all that you did for our great nation.

Please read about my week below: 

F-35s Coming To Tyndall
This week, Air Force Secretary Heather Wilson announced Tyndall Air Force Base as the future home to three squadrons of F-35 fighter jets. These squadrons of F-35s are the future of the Air Force and will strengthen our national security, while reinforcing the role of our airmen at Tyndall Air Force Base. It’s clear the Air Force recognizes the importance of investing in Tyndall as a part of our defense strategy and we are working to get the base back to mission ready capability as soon as possible. Bringing these next generation warplanes to Tyndall is in line with our efforts to rebuild a modern and state-of-the-art Air Force base post-Hurricane Michael. I look forward to working with the defense community to bring these squadrons in for a landing in our community. 
Click here to learn more. 

Working With VA Secretary Wilkie
￼ 
On Friday, I met with Department of Veterans Affairs Secretary Robert Wilkie regarding the future of implementation of the VA MISSION Act, including the Department’s commitment to working with the Senate and the House during this period. The Secretary also discussed the importance of ensuring our veterans are able to seek transplant care, an initiative I was able to get signed into law through the MISSION Act. 
Keeping Our Students Safe On Monday, I joined Congressman Paul Mitchell of California in introducing H.R. 7209, the School Resource Officer Act. Every day in schools across our country, school resource officers carry out the critical job of serving and protecting our children. Unfortunately, many school systems do not have the resources to employ a permanent resource officer. The School Resource Officer Act is an important component in changing this. By streamlining resources and working with local law enforcement, we can ensure that all of our schools have proper security and remain safe havens for our students. Click here to learn more.   
Mobile Office Hours 
My district staff will be hosting Mobile Office Hours in Jackson and Bay Counties this week. I encourage you to stop by to see how my office might be able to help you.  Jackson County  Date: Tuesday, December 11th Time: 9:00AM-12:00PM CT Location: Jackson County Public Library, 2929 Green St, Marianna, FL 32446  Bay County Date: Tuesday, December 11th Time: 9:00AM-12:00PM CT Location: Lynn Haven Library – Temporary tent located in the parking lot next to Sheffield Park, 901 Ohio Avenue, Lynn Haven, FL 32444  Date: Thursday December 13th  Time: 1:00PM-4:00PM CT Location: Lynn Haven Library – Temporary tent located in the parking lot next to Sheffield Park, 901 Ohio Avenue, Lynn Haven, FL 32444 
Thank you for your continued energy and enthusiasm, as reflected in your letters and Facebook posts. If you haven’t already, LIKE my Facebook page. You can also follow me on Twitter @DrNealDunnFL2. 
Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in Congress! 
 Sincerely,  ￼  Dr. Neal Dunn Member of Congress

Subject: Cruz News: December 9, 2018
Message:
￼
 
 
December 9, 2018
Greetings,
This week, Americans paused to honor the life of former President George Herbert Walker Bush. His love for America and calm, steady leadership secured him a special place in the memory of every Texan. He was an extraordinary man, who will be remembered for living his life committed to principles and values larger than himself. Now, President Bush and his beloved Barbara are together at last with their daughter Robin, and enjoying a well-deserved rest from their labors. May God bless the memory of President George H.W. Bush, and the legacy of service that he and Barbara instilled in generation after generation of the Bush family.
I have long supported criminal justice reform, and believe in reducing mandatory minimum sentences for non-violent drug offenders, and providing greater opportunities for offenders to be rehabilitated. At the same time, I do not believe we should be granting early release to violent offenders. That is why I drafted an amendment that would exclude violent offenders from being released early. I'm happy to report that, after working closely with the White House and the sponsors of this bill, they have decided to accept my amendment. This new version of the bill resolves my concerns, and is one that I wholeheartedly support and cosponsor. With these necessary improvements, I believe the Senate should take up and pass this important legislation. I look forward to working hand-in-hand with the White House and the bill sponsors to make sure that happens. Read my full statement here.
On Wednesday, I joined my colleagues Sens. Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.), Mike Rounds (R-S.D.), and John Kennedy (R-La.) in introducing the WALL Act. This bill would fully fund the border wall along the southern border by closing existing loopholes that provide illegal immigrants with federal benefits and tax credits, without affecting the benefits and tax credits used by Americans. The overwhelming majority of Texans and Americans want to see the border secured, and I have long called for building a wall as a necessary step in defending our border and stopping the flow of illegal immigration into our country.
In the weeks after Hurricane Harvey made landfall, Congress passed the Cruz-Cornyn-Rubio bill, which provided crucial tax relief for hurricane survivors. An important part of this bill eliminated the tax penalty for hurricane survivors who wanted to withdraw from retirement accounts to pay for the costs of repairs from storm damages. Retirement account withdrawals must be made by December 31, 2018 – a deadline that is quickly approaching. I strongly urge my fellow Texans, if you are still in the process of rebuilding and recovering from the ravages of Harvey, to contact your tax advisor or for more information go to the IRS website at irs.gov. I am encouraged by the progress we have seen in the Texas communities that were affected by Hurricane Harvey, and will continue working each day to ensure Texas rebuilds stronger than before.
Please read below for an update from this last week.
Keep Texas Strong,
￼ Ted Cruz
￼
Sen. Cruz last week penned a letter to FEMA Administrator Brock Long urging him to amend the scope of the existing FEMA dredging project on the San Jacinto River near Kingwood to include the mouth bar located on the West Fork of the river. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz along with ten senators sent a letter to Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, and Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross raising concerns that the Qatari government may be violating its Open Skies agreement with the United States. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz, member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Armed Services, participated in the nomination hearing of Lieutenant General Kenneth F. McKenzie, Jr. of the United States Marine Corps to be the next Commanding General of U.S. Central Command. Read more...
￼
￼
Sens. Cruz and John Cornyn (R-Texas) introduced a Senate resolution honoring the late President George H.W. Bush. The full text of the resolution can be read here. Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz and Ed Markey (D-Mass.) issued statements after President Trump signed into law their bipartisan National Timing Resilience and Security Act. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement in response to Israel launching Operation Northern Shield. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz delivered remarks on the Senate floor honoring the life and legacy of former President George H.W. Bush.  Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz on Tuesday sat down with several Texas stations to discuss the life and legacy of former President George H.W. Bush, calling him an extraordinary man who dedicated his life to public service and civility. Read more...
￼
￼
Sens. Cruz, Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.), Mike Rounds (R-S.D.), and John Kennedy (R-La.) on Wednesday introduced the WALL Act, legislation that would fully fund the border wall along the southern border. Reads more...
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement after voting in favor of the nomination of Bernie McNamee to be a Commissioner on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz, John Cornyn (R-Texas), Reps. Will Hurd (R-Texas), and Vicente Gonzalez (D-Texas) introduced the Missing Persons and Unidentified Remains Act of 2018, a bill to help local jurisdictions improve the recording and reporting of missing persons and unidentified remains found along the U.S.-Mexico border. Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz, John Cornyn (R-Texas) and U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Texas) released statements after the President signed their bill to rename the U.S. Postal Office in Mission, Texas as the "Mission Veterans Post Office Building" into law. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz released a statement on his support for a revised version of the First Step Act. Read more...

Subject: Rep. Lynn Jenkins Weekly Update: Remembering President George H.W. Bush.
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
HOME 
CONTACT US 
CONSTITUENT SERVICES 
ISSUES AND LEGISLATION 
December 09, 2018 
Remembering President George H.W. Bush:
 
As the nation mourns the loss of President George H.W. Bush, may we remember him for the man of character and integrity that he was. President Bush taught us all what it means to be an American first before any political party or ideology and to serve our fellow citizens. George H.W. Bush was kind and decent to all and yet faced questions about whether that meant he was not a tough enough president. In our polarized times, it seems we need more of his temperament, more of his decency, and more of his sense of humor. 
 
If his funeral sends a message, it is that Americans really can put aside our differences and come together for the good of the country. Thank you, Mr. President, for giving us such an excellent example of a life well lived.  
 
￼

Subject: Working for PA-10
Message:

￼
￼
ABOUT
CONTACT
ISSUES
MEDIA CENTER
SERVICES
￼
December 09, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
This week in Congress,a grateful nation paid its respect during President George H.W. Bush’s state ceremony in the United States Capitol Rotunda.
￼
Honoring the Life of President George H.W. Bush
Revered as one of America’s last great soldier-statesman, George H.W. Bush’s life was defined by his service to our nation. Thousands came to honor the late President at the United States Capitol. President Bush’s unrivaled character allowed him to guide our nation with integrity, vigor, and grace and he will be remembered not only for his numerous contributions to our society but also for the kindness he showed to others. Thank you for your service to our country. Rest In Peace, President Bush.
Advocating on Behalf of Our Dairy Farmers
For several years, dairy farmers have sustained low milk prices. Though there are many factors that have contributed to this struggle, recent trade challenges in critical markets have made the problem worse. That is why I co-signed a letter to the U.S. Department of Agriculture to increase USDA’s tariff mitigation program payments to better account for the significant damages dairy farmers have incurred. Dairy Farmers play a major role in Pennsylvania’s economy and I support developing a plan that reflects the struggles that these hard-working families have faced due to retaliatory tariffs.
Taking Action to Support Rural Farmers and Businesses
I joined a group of my colleagues in sending a letter to the Small Business Administration to voice my concern regarding the SBA proposed rule on the Express Loan Programs and Affiliation Standards. These rules would effectively limit rural American businesses from accessing needed capital to grow and expand. In the 115th Congress, I proudly supported H.R. 4743, the Small Business 7(a) Lending Oversight Reform Act to enhance oversight of SBA’s loan programs. I will continue to support legislation that puts the interests of our growers and local businesses first.
Keystone College Receives USDA Loan
I am pleased to hear that Keystone College qualified for, and received, a loan from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) that will undoubtedly improve the university’s ability to serve its students.
￼
USDA’s Community Facilities Direct Loan Program helps rural small towns, cities, and communities make critical infrastructure developments to support economic prosperity. As a major employer and economic anchor in rural Northeastern Pennsylvania, Keystone College has had a $150 million impact on the region’s economy in the past 10 years. Keystone will use this loan to restructure its debt, improve its financial position, and benefit the college’s 1,523 students. I look forward to watching Keystone College utilize this loan to continue their hard work in improving economic opportunity and jobs in PA-10.
Lackawanna Trail High School Battles for State Championship
For the first time in Lackawanna Trail High School’s history, the Lions took a trip to Hershey Park Stadium for the state “Single A” football championship. Taking on the Farrell Steelers on Thursday, the Lions entered the game with a 14-1 record. Both teams put on a show put it was the Steelers who ultimately took home the title with a final score of 55-20. Though their bid for the championship has come to an end, the Lions should be proud of their commitment to the sport and their tenacity on the field. Congratulations on a historic, and well earned, post-season!
End of Insurance Period Information for Producers with Excess Moisture in Fields
Due to the frequency of rain and resulting flooding in Pennsylvania this year, I have been contacted by producers in PA-10 concerned if they will be able to get into their fields prior to the end of the insurance period on December 10. USDA’s Risk Management Agency (RMA) has a fact sheet as a reference for those producers suffering the effects of excess moisture. Along with this guide, growers are encouraged to reach out to their crop insurance agent for additional information on claims made for crop losses.
As Always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA
￼Share on Facebook
￼Share on Twitter
￼Share on LinkedIn
E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.*
￼ 
*By subscribing to my  e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e-mail account. 


 
 
Thank you for subscribing to my eNewsletter and please remember to forward this to your friends!  This is a great way for me to communicate directly with you about what's going on in Washington, as well as providing you with exciting news from Pennsylvania's 10th District.  My Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube accounts are also excellent tools for you to share your thoughts with me and get up-to-the-minute news about what's happening.
As always, my staff and I are ready and willing to assist you.  If you would like to schedule a meeting, request a tour or flag, voice an opinion, or make a suggestion please contact my Washington, D.C. office.
If you need assistance working with a federal agency or applying for a grant please contact one of my Constituent Service Centers, located throughout the district.
I am here to serve you and represent your views, as a resident of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District.

Subject: Remembering President Bush
Message:
News from Representative Bradley Byrne
  
￼
ABOUT BRADLEY | HOW CAN I HELP | CONTACT BRADLEY | WANT TO RECEIVE MY UPDATES?
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
Our nation came together last week as we mourned the loss of a truly great American. No matter our race, religion, creed, or political party, we were drawn toward the light that was President George H.W. Bush.  
His life spanned nearly one hundred years of American history and was dedicated to serving the United States.
I had the honor to pay my respects to President Bush in the Capitol Rotunda and attend the funeral service held at the National Cathedral last week. It was the most moving church service I have ever attended. The testimony shared by everyone there spoke to a life well lived and firmly grounded. 
￼ 
He loved life and loved the people he spent it with. As his son, President George W. Bush, said at the service, “The idea is to die young as late as possible. … As he aged, he taught us how to grow old with dignity, humor and kindness -- and, when the good Lord finally called, how to meet Him with courage and with joy in the promise of what lies ahead.”
President George H.W. Bush will be remembered as a true American leader: someone who served totally, cared deeply, laughed fully, and loved completely.   
Pearl Harbor Day 
￼ 
Friday marked the 77th anniversary of the Attack on Pearl Harbor. 
At 7:55 AM local time, the attack commenced. At its end, 19 ships were destroyed or damaged, hundreds of aircraft were lost, and over 2,300 American service members were killed. 
We remember their sacrifice, and the service of all our soldiers, sailors, airmen, and Marines who fought in WWII. For the freedoms we enjoy today, we thank you. 
Red Snapper Update 
We had some great news this week from NOAA regarding Red Snapper!  
Even though we are getting close to Christmas, it's never too early to think about the next Red Snapper season. NOAA Fisheries published a new rule to increase the annual catch limits and annual catch targets for the Red Snapper fishery in the Gulf of Mexico. 
This increase from NOAA shows exactly what those of us on the Gulf Coast have known for years: the health of the Red Snapper fishery is incredibly strong.  
Under the proposed rule, the total catch limit for recreational Red Snapper fishing in the Gulf of Mexico would increase from 6.7 million pounds to 7.4 million pounds, a 10.45% increase.
Last year, I worked with Senator Richard Shelby and other Gulf Coast congressmen to secure a full Red Snapper season for Alabama’s recreational fishermen. 
These latest numbers will further drive us to continue fighting for greater state control over the Red Snapper fishery and a full and adequate Red Snapper fishing season. 
Coast Guard Authorization Bill 
 ￼  
On Tuesday, President Trump signed the Coast Guard Authorization Bill into law, authorizing funding and setting policy for the Coast Guard.  
This is critical as they carry out their mission to keep our waterways and coasts safe.  
Special thanks to the men and women serving right here in our area in the U.S. Coast Guard Sector Mobile and at the Aviation Training Center. 
In Case You Missed It!  
Here are a few articles from the past weeks that are worth a read:     
" Alabama officials react to President George H.W. Bush’s passing." - Yellowhammer  
“Opinion | Down the home stretch.” - AL Reporter  
“A Life in Pictures: Remembering George H.W. Bush.” – Bloomberg  
“Bradley Byrne reveals positive red snapper development.” - Alabama Today  
“How an Alabama company is getting President George H.W. Bush to his final resting place.” – Yellowhammer 
“Bradley Byrne: Let us give thanks.” - Alabama Today  
“Jimmy Parnell re-elected as Alabama Farmers Federation president.” – Yellowhammer 
“Ivey speaks at USA Hospital Trauma Center groundbreaking.” - AL Reporter 
“Congressman Bradley Byrne attends Bush funeral.” –  Rocket City Now  
Photo of the Week  
￼ 
It was great to be at the Capitol Christmas Tree Lighting Ceremony Thursday night on the West Lawn of the Capitol. Rebecca and Laura were able to join me for this festive tradition making it even better! 
What's Ahead  
This upcoming week in Washington could be the last legislative week of this year, this Congress, and this Republican majority.  
The big priority for the remainder of the year is to secure funding for the rest of the federal government. The deadline to pass a new funding bill is December 21st. Thankfully, we have passed funding for almost 75% of the federal government already, including critical funding for our military. 
The focus now is on ensuring our borders are protected, and that means including money in the funding bill for President Trump's border wall. That is a priority for me, so I will be working hard to see our border secured. 
As always, if you need help with a federal agency or have questions about anything under debate in Washington, please contact my office. You can call my Mobile office at 251-690-2811 or you can click here to send me an email directly. I also invite you to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to get up-to-the-minute updates from Washington. At the end of the day, my staff and I are here to serve you!  
Stay in touch, 
￼
Congressman Bradley Byrne
PS: Do you enjoy my email updates? If so, please forward these updates to your friends and family. They can also sign up to get my updates by clicking here.

Subject: Honoring President George H.W. Bush
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
This week I was very honored to attend a ceremony in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol Building honoring the life and legacy of our 41st President, George H.W. Bush. It was a beautiful ceremony, and the thousands of people who came to the Capitol to pay their respects is a testament to the great influence he had on our country.
During this very difficult time, our prayers remain with the entire Bush family as we mourn the loss of an American hero and statesman. His impact on our country as a WWII vet, Congressman, CIA Director, Vice President, and President cannot be understated. 
￼ 
The body of President George H.W. Bush lies in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol Building.  
  
THIRD ANNUAL MIDDLE GEORGIA CONGRESSIONAL BREAKFAST 
On Wednesday this past week, Senator Johnny Isakson and I were honored to host the 3rd Annual Middle Georgia Congressional Breakfast in Washington, D.C. The event brought together over 100 Middle Georgia civic leaders and Air Force Leadership to highlight the positive impact Robins Air Force Base and the greater Warner Robins community have in Georgia and to our military as a whole.
I’d also like to thank U.S. Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment Bob McMahon for taking the time to speak to the group. It was a great event all around, and I look forward to continuing to work with the Middle Georgia community to bring more jobs and economic development to the region.
￼ 
Thank you to everyone who could make the trip to D.C. for the Third Annual Middle Georgia Congressional Breakfast. 
  
 FIRST ANNUAL APP CHALLENGE WINNERS HONORED 
This past week we held an awards ceremony for the 1st Annual Eighth District Congressional App Challenge. The Congressional App Challenge is a great way to showcase the innovative and technological talents of students across the Eighth District, and the submissions we received this year did not disappoint. 
I would like to personally extend a "congratulations" to this year’s winner, as well as to each and every submission we received, and extend a ‘"thank you" to the teachers who inspired Eighth District students to participate in this competition and expand their skills and knowledge in the STEM, coding, and computer science fields. The demand for these skills will only continue to grow, and we are glad to host this event to give students and educators the opportunity to implement them in our Georgia classrooms. If you are interested in participating in next year’s contest, please contact my Warner Robins office for more information.
	•	FIRST PLACE: A first aid medical assistance app for educating K-12 students on proper medical interventions, “AidMe” by Rumi Lee from Houston County High School. (Click here to watch Rumi's app presentation.)
	•	SECOND PLACE: An app to create entertainment by providing fun, challenging gameplay, “Wraith’s Wrath” by Tien Tran, Donghyun Kwak, Carter Richter, and Connor Richter from Houston County High School. (Click here to watch Tien, Donghyun, Carter, and Connor's app presentation.)
	•	THIRD PLACE: An app to make choosing your next movie an easier experience, “Rate-It R” by Christopher Saetia, Nikita Shetty, and Aaron Mathieson from Houston County High School. (Click here to watch Christopher, Nikita, and Aaron's app presentation.)
	•	FOURTH PLACE: An app to allow kids with verbal disabilities to be able to better express their feelings, decompress from stress, and better communicate with their parents, teachers, and peers, “Inside Out” by Kaitlynn Stalvey and Sara Whiddon from Hahira Middle School. (Click here to watch Kaitlynn and Sara's app presentation.)
￼ 
First through third place winners, their teachers, and our competition judges. Our fourth-place winners were unable to attend due to severe weather. They will be presented their certificates at a  later date. 
  
HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends, 
 
As a nation, we came together last week to say farewell to a beloved patriot and hero, President George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States. Renee and I join our great country in mourning the passing of President Bush, and we continue to pray for peace and comfort for the Bush family. 
 
Last week, President Bush’s casket lain in state in the rotunda of the United States Capitol surrounded by the Honor Guard representing each branch of the U.S. military. Many gathered from around the country to celebrate his life, including his family, led by President George W. Bush – his son and our 43rd president – the Supreme Court Justices, the Joint Chiefs, members of the former President’s cabinet, three former Vice Presidents and his former political rival and good friend, Bob Dole. As your Congressman, I was honored to attend this important ceremony on your behalf. 
 
It was a moving experience – one that will stick with me for a lifetime.
 
Before starting a career in politics, President Bush served as the Navy’s youngest pilot during World War II. He earned the Distinguished Flying Cross, which would be enough legacy for any American. But that’s where his story merely began. He then served two terms as a U.S. Congressman from Texas, the Ambassador to the United Nations, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, Chief of the U.S. Liaison Office in the People’s Republic of China, and Director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). 
 
￼
 
From 1980 to 1988, he served as Vice President under the great President Ronald Reagan. And in 1988, Bush became the 41st President.
 
During his presidency, Bush navigated America through the end of the Cold War and the dissolution of the Soviet Union. President Bush served our country with an uncommon humility and made monumental contributions to freedom around the world.
 
When I was a student at Myers Park High School, I volunteered on his first presidential campaign. It was an incredible experience that helped guide me and fuel my interest in public service, and led to me running Students for President Bush at UNC Charlotte. In 1992, President Bush came through campus as part of his nationwide train tour for his presidential campaign. I’ll never forget it — we gathered a ton of supporters to cheer him on, and the crowd of students erupted when President Bush appeared from the back of the train to wave to all of us. 
 
I find myself in awe of President Bush’s commitment to a lifetime of selfless service and his devotion to his family. President Bush and his wife, Barbra, were married for 73 years. For decades after leaving public office, President Bush showed the country how to be a man of character while living life to its fullest.
 
As I reflect on his life of service, I am reminded how grateful I am to serve you. I’ll continue to strive to live up to President Bush’s example and belief that, “there could be no definition of a successful life that does not include service to others.” 
 
 
Until next week, 
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress (NC-08)
 

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
December 9, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


Honoring the Life and Legacy of an American Hero



This week I joined with the rest of the country in honoring the life and legacy of President George H.W. Bush. President Bush was a patriot who dedicated his life to serving our nation and I was humbled to have the opportunity to pay respects to this great leader, first in the Capitol Rotunda with my daughter Cecelia and later at the funeral service in the National Cathedral.

             ￼  

At Wednesday's service we heard the deeply moving words of his son President George W. Bush and others whose lives he had touched. Click here or on the image below to watch Wednesday's beautiful service.

￼





Remembering Pearl Harbor


On December 7, 1941 our nation was attacked. We will never forget the American men and women who lost their lives at Pearl Harbor. It is also a time to remember the brave men and women have defended our nation throughout the years against those who threatened the freedoms and values we hold dear. Please join me in honoring all the brave American servicemen who perished on that fateful day. 
￼





The Tenth District Comes to DC



On Tuesday, I had the opportunity to get a sneak peak of the UNC Asheville Singers performance at Walter Reed Army Medical Center when they stopped by my DC office. Cecilia and I loved hearing you sing!!

￼

On Thursday, I was blessed to pray with Pastor Andrew Brunson, his family, and some of my colleagues in the House and Senate. Pastor Brunson, who is originally from Black Mountain, North Carolina, was wrongfully imprisoned by the Turkish government for over two years. He was finally able to return to his family this October and I am so thankful for his safe return. Click here to watch the speech I delivered on the House Floor calling for his release. To read the letter I sent with 154 of my House colleagues to President Erdogan of Turkey demanding his release please click here.

            ￼





What I Have Been Reading



US Marine Corps planes involved in deadly midair collision off coast of Japan

CNN 

Please join me in praying for the family and loved ones of the Marines involved in Wednesday's deadly midair collision off the coast of Japan. The brave men and women of the U.S. military put their lives on the line every day to help keep our nation secure and I am deeply saddened by this loss.                                              


Asheville man remembers time President George H.W. Bush visited his home

WLOS 

In 1992, Roy Harris invited President Bush to his home to come talk to his young daughters about the importance of education. A couple of months later that is exactly what the President did. This touching story is just one of the many ways President Bush will be remembered not only as a great leader but also as a kind and decent man.


Kathleen Kraninger confirmed to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

ABC News 

Congratulations to Kathleen Kraninger on her confirmation as the director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. With a full-time Director in place, the BCFP can focus on its important work protecting American consumers. I look forward to working with Director Kraninger in the months ahead as we help ensure American families and small businesses have greater access to our financial system. 

￼

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
Remembering President George H. W. Bush
 
 
It was a solemn week in D.C. as the entire nation mourned the loss of President George H.W. Bush. Thousands of people came to see President Bush lie in state and celebrate his extraordinary life. From serving in the Navy to serving in the Oval Office, he was a true patriot and selfless public servant. He loved his family and cared for his friends deeply. One quote from President Bush's inauguration, which his son read at his funeral, particularly struck me: “We cannot hope to only leave our children a bigger car, a bigger bank account. We must hope to give them a sense of what it means to be a loyal friend, a loving parent. A citizen who leaves his home, his neighborhood, and town better than he found it." RIP, 41. 

Read More »
 

￼
 
 
A Date Which Will Live in Infamy
 
 
"Yesterday, December 7, 1941 — a date which will live in infamy — the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan." - President Franklin Delano Roosevelt 

Pearl Harbor changed the course of our history. Millions of brave men and women answered the call of duty to serve our country in World War II and many paid the ultimate sacrifice to defend our precious freedoms. Their service and sacrifice will never be forgotten! This Friday, on the 77th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, it was announced that part of a ship that sunk during the attack will be displayed at the Florence Veterans Park. We are honored that this piece of history is coming to Florence! 

Read More »
 

￼
 
 
Charleston Defense Summit
 
 
This week, leaders in the defense industry gathered at the Charleston Defense Summit to discuss innovative solutions to the wide array of security threats faced by the United States today. I am proud that South Carolina's defense industry has risen to meet these challenges and I know the groundbreaking work that takes place in our state will continue to drive our national security efforts. While I couldn't attend the summit, I recorded a video thanking attendees for their leadership on this important issue and look forward to learning more about their efforts!
 

 
One Year Later
 
 
A year ago this week, President Trump officially recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and announced his intention to to relocate the American embassy to Jerusalem. While others had made this same promise, President Trump was the only one to keep his word. I was honored to attend the moving of the embassy to Jerusalem in May and will continue to work with the Administration to strengthen our special relationship with Israel. 
 

￼
 
 
Here to Help 
 
 
While the deadline to apply for federal disaster assistance passed this week, the recovery process is not over for many people in the Seventh District. My team and I will be here for you every step of the way. If you need assistance or have any questions about disaster relief, please do not hesitate to reach out to one of my offices. We are here to help in any way that we can! If you applied for federal assistance, you can get updates about your registration, learn about the appeals process, and check the status of your appeal online at DisasterAssistance.gov. 
 

Have a great week, 
￼

Tom Rice

Subject: Honoring the Life of 41
Message:
Babin Bulletin | December 9, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Honoring President George H.W. Bush
￼
My heart is heavy over the passing of George H.W. Bush, an exemplary man and patriot whose service to his country ranks him among our most beloved Presidents. President Bush served at the highest levels of our government while setting an unmatched example as a loving husband and father. His legacy will continue to grow after his passing.

Rest in peace, Mr. President.
￼
 
NASA Day on the Hill
￼
I had a great discussion with my friend, NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine on Tuesday. He answered many questions I and my Space Subcommittee colleague Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson had about current NASA projects and initiatives. Afterward, I was able to introduce Administrator Bridenstine at NASA Day on the Hill. 
￼
While there, my colleague Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (pictured on right) and I had the treat of meeting NASA astronaut Mark Vande Hei (pictured in middle) as well as speaking with other NASA employees about the exciting work being done to advance America’s leadership in space.


￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Recognizing Lamar Smith
I enjoyed attending the portrait unveiling of my great Texas friend and colleague, Science, Space and Technology Committee Chairman Lamar Smith of San Antonio. 
￼
The painting will appropriately hang in the committee hearing room where so much has been accomplished for our nation’s space program. I was proud to serve as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Space over the last four years under his leadership.
Meeting over Hurricane Funds
I met with officials from FEMA, HUD, SBA, and OMB on Thursday over concerns about Duplication of Benefits and Low to Moderate Income (LMI) requirements for access to Hurricane recovery funds. It is critical that those affected by Hurricane Harvey are able to get the assistance and funding necessary to put their lives back together.
￼
 Trip to Mexico City
 I was honored to accompany a Congressional delegation to Mexico City for the inauguration of Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador. We met many government officials as well as Mexican business and industry representatives to discuss border security and trade. Texas is the largest trading partner with Mexico of any state, and I am looking forward to working with President Lopez Obrador to advance trade policies which benefit the U.S. and Texas.
￼
Remembering Pearl Harbor
On the morning of December 7, 1941, the skies over Pearl Harbor turned black with smoke as American soldiers fought hundreds of Japanese aircraft as they dropped their bombs on our Pacific Fleet. 
￼
As President Roosevelt stated, “a sleeping giant” was awakened that day, and America soon proved to the world that our commitment to freedom could not be sunk with our battleships. This week, we remember all who were lost 77 years ago and the incredible courage displayed by our brave service members that fateful day and the years that followed.

Share What is Important to You | Share on Facebook | Share on Twitter

Subject: A Date Which Will Live in Infamy
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Sunday, December 9, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
A Date Which Will Live in Infamy
 

"Yesterday, December 7, 1941—a date which will live in infamy—the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan." - President Franklin D. Roosevelt

On Friday, we reflected on the sacrifices of the 2,403 military men and women who lost their lives during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor 77 years ago. A turning point in America's history, pushing America to declare ourselves part of the second world war. 

It is in these times that America has been wounded, where from the shadows,  we emerge in pride and dignity for our country. We owe a great deal of gratitude to those who lost their lives, were injured in the attack, and those who then answered the call to defend our nation against foreign attacks. 

This day serves as a reminder for us to be grateful for our freedoms that so many have defended before us. We live in the greatest country on God's earth and should not take our liberties for granted. We remember these heroic individuals who were part of the Greatest Generation. 

￼


Congressional Expatriate Caucus
As Chairman of the Congressional Expatriate Caucus, I am pleased to announce that we have officially launched our new website.
Our website is set up to serve as an accessible resource to expatriates, regardless of their location in the world. For the 9 million Americans, including many Mississippians, that live and work overseas, our site and social media platforms will allow them to stay connected and informed.   You can visit the Congressional Expatriate Caucus website by visiting the link here.
￼


#Remembering41
This week, Americans watched as we honored the life and legacy of President George H.W. Bush, a devoted family man, veteran, and 41st President of the United States. He was one of only 35 individuals to lie in state in the United States Capitol building, and is now in his final resting place in Texas.  
Thank you President George H.W. Bush, for your lifetime of dedicated service to our beloved homeland. Please join me in continuing to pray for the entire Bush family during their time of mourning.
￼

As always, I'd like to remind you to connect with me on social media so you can receive frequent updates on the work I am doing in Congress through Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

In your service,
￼
Steven
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: The Last President from the Greatest Generation
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
The Last President from the Greatest Generation

￼

Dear Friend:

This week was dominated by the passing of President George H.W. Bush – the last President to have served in WWII. I believe our nation lost an extraordinary leader and I have spent some time reflecting on what his life has meant both to our nation and to me personally. My most significant memories of the late 41st President were from Operation Desert Shield and Operation Desert Storm (1990-1991) where I served as an officer with the Marines in a light armored infantry battalion.

President Bush understood the cost of war from his own experiences in WWII and demonstrated his skills as a commander-in-chief by recognizing the value of building up enough combat power to overwhelm the Iraqi army – then the 4th largest army in the world – to quickly break their will to fight, decisively defeat them, and ultimately liberate Kuwait.

He also understood the art of diplomacy as few do, given his background as the former Ambassador to the Peoples Republic of China and to the United Nations. He skillfully put together a coalition of 34 nations and united them under a singular principle: “this aggression will not stand.”

President Bush was also a man of great character. I think the best example of this is a heartfelt letter he wrote following the loss of his daughter, Robin, to leukemia when she was just three years old. The letter concludes with:

"But she is still with us. We need her and yet we have her. We can't touch her and yet we can feel her. We hope she'll stay in our house for a long, long time.”

See the full text of his letter here.

We will all miss him. 

Next week will be a busy one in Washington, D.C. with critical votes on everything from the reauthorization of the Farm Bill to a Homeland Security Appropriations Bill.

Finally, I invite you to stay in contact with me via my website, Facebook or Twitter. See you around the district!
 
Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative 
￼

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
Friends,
On November 30, 2018, we lost an American hero. President George Herbert Walker Bush, the 41st President of the United States and father of the 43rd President of the United States, dedicated his life to serving our great nation. A trained diplomat and naval aviator, President George H.W. Bush navigated our country through some of the most tumultuous times in our history. 
Hailing from New England, young 41 enlisted into the U.S. Navy upon graduation from high school in 1942. As a lieutenant in the Japanese Bonin Islands, President Bush's aircraft was hit by flak during an attack and crashed. After floating for hours on a raft, President Bush was rescued by the submarine USS Fishback. Over the last week, we have learned that this experience profoundly shaped President Bush's outlook on life, leading him to question why God had spared him and not others. 
While still in the Navy, President Bush married Barbara Pierce in 1945. Together they had six children, President George W. Bush, Robin, Governor Jeb Bush, Neil, Marvin, and Doro. After earning his bachelor's degree from Yale University in 1948, President Bush moved his family to Odessa, Texas as he ventured into the oil business. In 1966, President George H.W. Bush was a self-made millionaire and won an election to the U.S. House of Representatives. 
President George H.W. Bush was a successful businessman, a Member of Congress, an Ambassador, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, United States Envoy to China, Director of Central Intelligence and Vice President under President Ronald Reagan. Even before being elected President, Bush had been on the forefront of history making enormous strides in opening the doors for diplomatic relations with China and tackling matters of national security. During his tenure as Vice President, Bush assisted President Reagan to successfully navigate the waters of a politically divided Congress. 
President Bush assumed office on January 20, 1989, to become the 41st President of the United States. During his time as President, President Bush led the United States to the end of the Cold War, the fall of the Berlin Wall and the collapse of the Soviet Union. He never once boasted about these tremendous diplomatic feats. President Bush was the same man that he was on Saturday night that he was at church on Sunday morning, and I will always admire him for that. 
The life and legacy of President Bush will be defined by his goodwill and friendship. In his late years, some of his best friends were once his harshest political rivals. From President Bill Clinton to Senator Bob Dole, President Bush put personal qualms and politics aside to form firm friendships, which is an inspiration for us all. 
President George H.W. Bush was a family man, war hero and a statesman. I was humbled to attend the funeral honoring the life and legacy of President Bush. To quote President George W. Bush's eulogy, "When the history books are written, they will say that George H.W. Bush was a great President of the United States -- a diplomat of unmatched skill, a commander in chief of formidable accomplishment, and a gentleman who executed the duties of his office with dignity and honor."
Thank you, President George H.W. Bush, for showing Americans what it means to serve with love and lead with courage. You will be dearly missed, but your legacy is eternal. 
Dave

Subject: Honoring those who served and sacrificed for our nation
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
December 9, 2018
Dear Friend,  
The celebration of President George H.W. Bush’s life and lasting contributions to our nation took center stage last week, causing a shift in the Congressional calendar.  I was honored to be able to attend the funeral, and pay my respects to his family.  It was a very moving tribute to a man who will be remembered for his service, patriotism and love of family.  
As a result of the calendar changes, we passed a temporary extension of the budget and other important programs such as the Violence Against Women Act and the National Flood Insurance Program.  This provides a few more weeks to reach consensus on these matters.  Please be assured that I will continue to work in a cooperative manner to ensure effective governance and responsible spending while prioritizing those items which are most vital to our community.
Please continue reading for highlights of my work on your behalf last week!  
Fighting for our Nation’s Heroes 
Last week, I had the distinct pleasure of speaking to the VA’s COVER Commission, which hosted an important meeting at James A. Haley Hospital this week. The Commission was created by a bill I authored, the COVER Act, for the express purpose of evaluating alternative and complementary evidenced-based therapies to be provided to Veterans by the VA. It was born out of my belief that one size does not fit all, especially when it comes to an issue as sensitive as addressing the mental health needs of our nation’s heroes. I was encouraged by the dialogue and look forward to reviewing the Commission’s findings.
￼ 
Additionally, on Friday we honored the memory of those brave men and women who lost their lives during the attack on Pearl Harbor. We must never forget their service and sacrifice – truly the Greatest Generation!
￼ 
Facilitating Economic Success 
I have been a vocal skeptic of the tariffs imposed on various countries because of my concerns that they would ultimately hurt consumers.  However, I believe in giving credit where credit is due.  It is hard to argue with results, and the most recent concession by China to drop its 40% tariff on the import of American-made automobiles is a huge win. I remain confident that a final US-China trade deal can be reached, optimistic about the next 90 days, and look forward to an agreement that ensures an enforceable level playing field for American innovators and businesses.  
Additionally, recent reports  indicate that home values throughout the Tampa Bay area are expected to rise slightly higher than the national average next year, signifying the health of our local economy.  While this is great news for homeowners, it does highlight the need for us to continue efforts to ensure affordable housing for vulnerable populations.  Additionally, it is critical that we reauthorize the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP)- failure to do so would be catastrophic to our housing market.  
Ensuring Access to Quality Healthcare 
This local news report certainly contains disturbing news about the increase in uninsured children in Florida.  What the article doesn’t mention is that the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) is fully funded and received the longest extension in history, being fully funded until fiscal year 2027.  The legislation which made this possible included a provision of mine that protected and assisted Florida CHIP’s full-pay plan.  In Florida, all children are eligible for Medicaid or CHIP coverage, with subsidized and unsubsidized CHIP plans based on family income, with some plans as low as $15 a month.  I will continue to work with state leaders to ensure that families are aware of these options.
￼ 
Last week I was also pleased to begin reviewing the recently released report by Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar suggesting ways we can build upon recent efforts to lower the costs of delivering high quality healthcare to Americans. This is a critical issue, and I look forward to exploring his ideas in greater detail.   
Additionally, the information presented in the Tampa Bay Times’ report related to the spike in death rates over the last three years at the John Hopkins All Children’s Hospital Heart Institute is extremely concerning.  As the sponsor of the Congenital Heart Futures Reauthorization Act of 2017, I have had the opportunity to speak with countless families who are coping with congenital heart defect.  Their stories are truly heartbreaking.  We want to ensure continued investment in critical research that offers hope to these patients and families.  However, we must also ensure that best practices are utilized when treating these high risk patients.  I will certainly be working closely with appropriate officials to examine the causes of this disturbing trend and identify potential solutions. 
Protecting our National Interests and Global Security 
The House recently passed H.R. 4591, the Preventing Iranian Destabilization of Iraq Act, introduced by Rep. Adam Kinzinger. This bill will make sanctions imposed on foreign entities that threaten peace, stability, economic reconstruction, humanitarian assistance, political reform, or democracy in Iraq, official. It also allows visa denial and entry into the United States for those committing these awful acts against Iraq. Furthermore, the bill requires the President to research and report to Congress whether certain entities and individuals meet criteria to be labeled as foreign terrorist organizations, or face sanctions. Under the bill, The Department of State must establish and maintain a list of armed groups that receive support and influence from Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps.
Constituent Corner 
As a new feature of this newsletter, each week I am going to highlight a local story of how my team and I advocate for the needs of our constituents.   A constituent in Tarpon Springs did not realize he needed to obtain a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers prior to constructing a dock on his property.  Initially, the constituent was told that the dock would have to be disassembled until a permit could be granted.  The constituent contacted my office several weeks ago and asked for help.  A member of my team reached out to the Corps and requested a meeting at the property to discuss potential solutions.  My staff member attended the meeting last week, and a permit has now been issued.    This is just one example of the work we do each and every day.  Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you. 
Highlights from Around the District 
I have a great team, both locally and in Washington, D.C.  When I am in Washington, members of my team are working each and every day to provide excellent constituent service and to be my eyes and ears on the ground as they attend community events.  Here are just a few highlights of their efforts this week.
Bob, a member of my district staff, attended a Pearl Harbor Remembrance Celebration 
￼ 
Dan, also a member of my district team, attended the Grand Opening of Springhill Suites in Wesley Chapel.  Its great to see how much our community is growing!
￼ 

Rob, my Outreach Director and Veterans Liaison, participated in the ribbon cutting ceremony for the National Church Residences in New Port Richey.  It is vital that we continue to support investment in affordable housing for vulnerable populations.
￼ 
Rob also attended the kick off for the Healthy HOP program in Tarpon Springs.  This innovative initiative will provide free transportation for seniors who need help getting to and from their medical appointments. Click here to learn more.   
Summer, my Deputy Chief of Staff, participated in the YMCA's annual prayer breakfast at Spartan Manor.  It is great to see so many people in our community coming out to support such a good program.    
￼ 
Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! 
Additionally, I hope everyone observing Hanukkah is enjoying a happy and safe celebration.  Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.   Sincerely, ￼  Gus Bilirakis

Subject: A Wintry Mix has arrived. Be Safe!
Message:
Dear Friend, 

The wintry mix has arrived. Please be careful and stay off the roads if possible. If you must be on the roads, please drive with caution as there could be ice, which makes driving dangerous.   You can follow all news and weather on the winter storm through the National Weather Service or via local news stations such as WCNC, WBTV, WSOC and Spectrum. 
Due to the cold temperatures, it is important that you leave a faucet running so your pipes do not freeze. 
Due to freezing rain forming on power lines, there is a chance that the power could go out. Please report all power outages and power line hazards to the following phone numbers:
Duke Energy Carolinas customers – 800-769-3766
Duke Energy Progress customers – 800-419-6356
For all emergencies please make sure you call 9-1-1. 
As always, prepare, be safe, stay warm and look out for your neighbors! 
 

Best Regards,  
￼

Congresswoman Alma S. Adams, Ph.D.

Subject: This Week In Washington
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Celebrating the Life and Legacy of President George H.W. Bush
President George H.W. Bush was a great American patriot, dedicated public servant, tireless humanitarian, and caring family man. I was humbled to attend his funeral and celebrate the life and legacy of our 41st president.
Kris and I join the nation in mourning President Bush's passing and send our condolences to the entire Bush family. You can watch President George W. Bush's moving eulogy of his father here.
￼
￼
Remembering Army Sergeant Jason McClary
On December 2nd, Army Sergeant Jason McClary of Westmoreland County succumbed to injuries he sustained a week earlier when his vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device in Ghazni Province, Afghanistan.
Sergeant McClary was a patriot who gave his life serving our country. His death serves as a sobering reminder of the sacrifice members of our armed services and their families make every day to keep us safe here at home.  
Kris and I extend our heartfelt condolences to Jason's wife, sons, and all those who loved him.
You can read more about Sergeant McClary here.
￼
￼
Stopping Deadly Fentanyl Imports
Far too many Americans are dying from heroin that is laced with Chinese fentanyl. This week, the Trump administration secured an initial commitment from Chinese President Xi Jinping to crack down on the production of fentanyl and all fentanyl-like drugs. I applaud the president for this important, potentially life-saving development.
In recent years, the emergence of fentanyl has significantly contributed to the lethality of the opioid epidemic. Just two milligrams of fentanyl is enough to kill the average adult, and estimates have shown two-thirds of opioid overdose deaths in Pennsylvania involve fentanyl.
While this week's news is a good step forward, we have to do more to stem the tide of the opioid and heroin epidemic. Congress should strengthen the administration's hand in its negotiations with China by passing my bipartisan Blocking Deadly Fentanyl Imports Act, which punishes countries that fail to implement and enforce internal controls on fentanyl production.
￼
￼
Speaking with the Journal Editorial Report
Last week, I joined the Wall Street Journal's Paul Gigot on the Journal Editorial Report to discuss various issues of the day. Specifically, we talked about the renegotiated NAFTA, known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). I do not support this agreement in its current form, but am eager to work with the administration to move us towards freer trade. We also discussed the need for a debate regarding U.S. military involvement in Yemen, and our relationship with Saudi Arabia following the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. You can watch our full conversation here. 
￼
￼
Supporting Infrastructure Across Pennsylvania 
I am pleased to announce that two major federal grants have been awarded for infrastructure projects in both Southeast, and Southwestern Pennsylvania.
The first grant, totaling $15 million, will be used to expand the capacity of Philadelphia's 30th Street Station. Specifically, it will finance improvements that make travel in the city easier for millions of commuters and visitors, and help to accommodate increased traffic from the Schuylkill Yards project.
The second grant, totaling $20 million, was awarded to Butler County to improve Route 228. This 26-mile economic thread is the County's primary link between southern Butler County, and Shell Chemical's $6 billion ethane cracker plant in Beaver County. Currently, there are several transportation challenges along the route, such as inadequate capacity, an excessive number of accidents, and lack of access to key employment centers, schools, and residential neighborhoods.
The awarded grant funds will realign and widen the Balls Bend and Haines School-Commonwealth sections of Route 228 to four lanes, including adding turn lanes, medians, connecting access roads, and pedestrian/bicycle facilities.

Subject: Remembering 41, Federal Funding for Local Communities, Celebrating Illinois' Bicentennial, and much more...
Message:
News from Representative Darin LaHood

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward
￼ 
 
WEBSITE 
CONTACT
SERVICES 
NEWS
 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼


Dear Lindsey,
Remembering George H.W. Bush
￼ 
This week our country mourned the loss of President George H.W. Bush. He was an amazing person who had a lifetime of public service. President Bush was a loving husband, father, grandfather, and friend. He served with distinction as a pilot in the U.S. Navy during WWII and went on to succeed at the highest levels of business and government before serving as our 41st President of the United States. Prior to that, he served as Vice President under President Ronald Reagan, Director of the CIA, and as a Congressman from Texas. He led a full life, and we will be forever grateful for his service to our country. 
￼ 
I often think back on this photo that sits in my office and the strong example President Bush set for me. A man of high character, 41 spent his life committed to serving our country with decency and humility. May we never forget his selfless service to our nation. 
￼ 
Around the District
BUILD Grant Secured for Springfield Rail Improvements
￼ 
This week's announcement by Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao is great news for the Springfield community. The $22 million BUILD grant award will be used for construction of the Springfield Rail Improvements Project, specifically Usable Segment IV. Click below to learn more.
Springfield Journal Register: City of Springfield secures $22 million grant for continuing rail project  News Channel 20: Springfield awarded federal grant for rail project 
La Harpe Receives Rural Development Grant
￼
￼
Strategic investment in our rural communities is essential to supporting existing infrastructure and ensures residents in these communities have the up to date resources. The money awarded today will provide critical assistance to a project that will allow La Harpe to build a new water treatment plant, enabling them to provide higher quality drinking water to over 1,200 residents. I am grateful to Secretary Perdue, State Director for USDA Rural Development Doug Wilson, and the USDA for their commitment to supporting rural development projects in central and west-central Illinois. I have no doubt this investment will leave a meaningful impact on the La Harpe community.
WMBD: Federal grant allows water treatment upgrade to move forward 
Meeting with Illinois Farmers
￼  ￼ 
I attended the Illinois Farm Bureau Annual Meeting last weekend and had the opportunity to discuss numerous topics related to our agriculture community, including the recent trade news with China and the USMCA agreement with Mexico and Canada, funding for our locks and dams, the Farm Bill, as well as the renewable fuel standard.
Celebrating 200 Years of Illinois!
￼
￼
This week, we recognized Illinois' bicentennial and the rich history that makes up our great state! In the video above, I speak to Illinois' history and a number of incredible influential political figures that have emerged from not only our State of Illinois, but from the 18th District. I was able to make these remarks from within the "Lincoln Room" at the US Capitol where it is said Abraham Lincoln would regularly tell stories and converse with fellow colleagues in Congress. More on that, here. 
ICYMI: Federal Funding Secured for La Grange Lock and Dam
 ￼  ￼ 
WLDS: Congressman LaHood discusses federal funding for LaGrange Lock & Dam 
Hannuka Sameah! Wishing all a happy Festival of Lights!
￼ 
￼
Around DC
Legislation to Honor Fallen Army Ranger Joshua Rodgers Passes U.S. House of Representatives
￼
￼
Last week, my legislation to rename a Normal post office for Army Ranger Joshua Rodgers passed the House. For more on this story, click the video above or the link below!
The Pantagraph: Bill to name Normal post office for soldier OK'd by House
USMCA Signing
￼ 
Farmers, manufacturers, and workers in Illinois’ 18th District rely on open export markets with Mexico and Canada to move their product and remain competitive across the globe. The signing of the USMCA last week is a positive step towards an improved trilateral trade agreement with our neighbors and is welcomed news for the agricultural and manufacturing industries in Illinois who have been hurt by the recent trade uncertainty caused by tariffs. As I have stated in the past, an updated NAFTA must include Mexico and Canada, and I applaud the Trump Administration for bringing them together on this agreement. I look forward to working with my colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee to ensure that the USMCA serves in the best interest of the farmers and workers across central and west-central Illinois.
Questioning Ambassador Jeffery
￼
￼
I was granted the opportunity to join the House Foreign Affairs Committee to question Ambassador Jeffery, the U.S. Department of State's new Special Representative for Syria Engagement. I was able to address numerous issues including the Syrian refuge crisis in Lebanon and the impact on the region. I look forward to continued engagement with the State Department on this issue.
Awakened A Sleeping Giant
￼ 
77 years ago, on December 7, 1941, our country was attacked at Pearl Harbor. May we never forget the over 2,000 Americans who lost their lives on that infamous day and always honor their sacrifice. 
￼   Sincerely, ￼  Darin LaHood Member of Congress

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
￼ 
  

REMEMBERING 41

This week, a grateful nation honored and remembered our 41st president, President George H.W. Bush. 

President Bush lived a life dedicated to our great nation. Looking back on his life, it's truly remarkable to see how many ways he served our nation. He was a pilot in the Navy and he flew combat missions in World War II. He went on to represent his home in Congress then served as Ambassador to the United Nations, Chief of the U.S. Liaison Office in China and Director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Finally, he served as Vice President then President of the United States. 

￼

It's easy to see that he will leave a legacy of leadership and service that will inspire Americans forever. However, even more honorable than his service to our nation was his dedication and love for his family and beloved wife Barbara. 

I believe his son, President George W. Bush, said it best when he said, "Dad taught us that public service is noble and necessary; that one can serve with integrity and hold true to the important values, like faith and family. He strongly believed that it was important to give back to the community and country in which one lived. He recognized that serving others enriched the giver's soul. To us, his was the brightest of a thousand points of light."

Votes in the House were canceled this week as Americans from across the nation paid their respects to the president in the United States Capitol. In the Capitol, President Bush's casket laid upon the catafalque constructed in 1865 for President Abraham Lincoln as he laid in state. 

Click here to view the ceremony in the U.S. Capitol honoring President George H.W. Bush. 

PEARL HARBOR REMEMBRANCE CEREMONY

Each year on December 7 we honor and remember those who lost their lives and all those who served our country during the attack on Pearl Harbor. 

Earlier this week, I was honored to participate in a Pearl Harbor Remembrance Ceremony in Pooler at the National Museum of the Mighty Eighth Air Force. 

￼
Rep. Carter at the Pearl Harbor Remembrance Ceremony at the National Museum of the Mighty Eighth Air Force

We will never forget those who fought and sacrificed so much for our freedom that day.

Subject: Remembering President George H. W. Bush
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: December 8, 2018 
￼  This photo was taken on Monday, December 3 as former President George H. W. Bush's casket arrived at the U.S. Capitol to lie in state. 
 Remembering President George H. W. Bush  
This week, we said goodbye to former President George H.W. Bush after his death at age 94 at his home in Houston. At the time of his wife’s death in April of this year, he and former First Lady Barbara Bush had been married for 73 years, which is the longest presidential marriage in history. President Bush will be remembered for many things, chief among them his governing during the collapse of the Soviet Union and his leadership during the Gulf War.  I appreciate President Bush for his leadership in negotiating and signing NAFTA. Despite being ratified by Congress during the Clinton administration, NAFTA had already been signed when President Clinton took office. In fact, President Bush was one of the earliest and most vocal proponents of free trade to lead the United States.   He believed countries with strong trade ties were less likely to go to war and that economic development was shared by all parties when barriers to trade were lifted. Nearly half of all agricultural products exported from Nebraska, worth around $3 billion annually, are consumed by Canada and Mexico under NAFTA. Its replacement, the USMCA, was signed by the United States, Canada, and Mexico on the same day President Bush passed.  President Bush’s entire life was characterized by humility and selfless service to his country. He served as a Navy pilot in the Pacific Theater of World War II during which he flew 58 combat missions. On one sortie, he was forced to bail out of his badly damaged aircraft. He was rescued several hours later, but the other two members of his crew did not survive. In 1967, President Bush was elected to Congress where he served until President Nixon appointed him Ambassador to the United Nations. He also served as Chief of the U.S. Liaison Office to China and Director of Central Intelligence, both under President Ford.   President Bush served as vice president under President Reagan for eight years before being elected president himself in 1988. Throughout his presidency, the United States faced a number of challenges to which President Bush rose with the honor, even-temperament, and respect we should all seek to emulate in our day-to-day lives.   I was honored to pay my respects as former President George H. W. Bush’s body laid in state at the U.S. Capitol and to attend his funeral service at the National Cathedral. Eulogies delivered by his son, former President George W. Bush, and others highlighted a number of lessons we should remember as a nation moving forward. My wife and I will continue to keep the Bush family in our prayers as they celebrate the life of a great man who served his country with distinction. 
Sincerely,
￼ 
ADRIAN SMITH
Member of Congress

Subject: American Hero
Message:
￼ 








Here are a few things from this week: 
  
1. American Hero 
  
￼ 
  
President George H.W. Bush was a skilled leader who showed tireless dedication to our nation during some of our most trying times. George and Barbara's sacrifice, service, and love for our country was unmatched. Bonnie and I were honored to join the Bush family to pay our respects to 41. 
  
View a photo gallery of President Bush through the years in The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. 
 
2. Bringing Together HBCUs & Business Leaders 
  
 ￼ 
  
As a member of the HBCU Caucus, one of my top priorities is increasing engagement between the business community and our education centers. This week, we had an open and candid conversation between Morehouse University and Georgia business leaders, and it was great to hear everyone's insight and ideas. 
  
Read more in Insider Advantage. 
  
3. Relief For Georgia Farmers 
  
￼ 
  
Georgia's agriculture industry was devastated by Hurricane Michael. Senator Isakson and I are doing all we can to help our farmers get back on their feet. If you were impacted by Hurricane Michael, remember to register with FEMA before the December 13th deadline. 
  
Read more in Albany Herald.

Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you.

ICO Bill, CFPB, President Bush
Congressman Warren Davidson was in Washington, D.C. this week as Congress was in Session. 
On Monday, Congressman Davidson spoke to attendees at the Blockland Solutions Conference in Ohio about his ongoing efforts to bring clarity and certainty to the Initial Coins Offering (ICO) market. He was invited to talk with attendees about his plans to introduce legislation to address the ICO issue. Read more about the visit here.  
Tuesday was President George H.W. Bush’s funeral in Washington, D.C. Read Congressman Davidson’s remarks here. 
On Thursday, Kathy Kraninger was confirmed by the U.S. Senate to become Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. Congressman Davidson said he was thankful that Director Kraninger was finally confirmed and is on the job working to protect consumers. Congressman Davidson sits on the House Financial Services Committee which has oversight of the CFPB. Read his statement here.  
The following picture is Congressman Davidson speaking at the Blockland Conference.
