Dear Friend,  This week the United States laid to rest a president who served the country he loved in more capacities than could ever be expected of one man. We commemorated and celebrated the life of a war hero, Congressman, Ambassador, CIA Director, Vice President, and President of the United States. This week we said goodbye to President George H.W. Bush...KEEP READING HERE


WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH

￼ 
Yesterday was the 77th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor. To honor the occasion, WWII Air Force veteran Lloyd Fitzwater, one of three remaining WWII veterans in Potosi, presented a memorial wreath to honor all those we lost on the day that will forever life in infamy. 

￼￼
Honored to speak at the Missouri Farm Bureau's annual meeting and receive the Friend of the Farm Bureau award. The theme was 'gratitude' and I'm especially grateful to represent the hard working men and women who feed and clothe the world. 
￼ At the Farm Bureau's annual meeting, Wyatt Wilson was named the first ever ambassador from Douglas County! Wyatt is a 2018 graduate of Gainesville high school and now a freshman at Missouri State University. Congratulations Wyatt, we are all very proud of you! 
￼
Congratulations to the Hayti Indians football team, the new Class 1 State Champions! This week they capped off a perfect season and shutout Lincoln 44-0 to capture the first state championship in the program's history. (📸by David Jenkins, Standard Democrat) 
￼  Great to see the John J. Pershing VA Medical Center break ground on the new urgent care facility. It will add nearly 10,000 square feet and increase access for veteran patients with multiple new exam rooms. 


THIS WEEK IN DC
￼

I was honored to attend the beautiful memorial services for President George H.W. Bush in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda and at the National Cathedral. They were beautiful ceremonies honoring a dedicated public servant and a life well lived.

￼ 
I was thrilled to join President Trump in the Oval Office as he signed the Coast Guard Authorization Act. It supports our men and women of the Coast Guard and allows the historic Delta Queen to resume operation.
 (Official White House Photo by Joyce N. Boghosian)

￼
￼

When Mike Janchyshyn contacted my office saying his family would be in D.C. for his retirement ceremony from the Army, we knew we had to make it special for them. I was thrilled to be able to help the Janchyshyn family into the White House. What better way to celebrate 20 years of dedicated service in the Army than by being able to see where our Commander in Chief lives?

￼
Congress needs to hear from you. What are YOUR priorities for 2019?

Subject: Jackie's Reads for December 8, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

December 8, 2018 
Dear Friends,  Given the ongoing political turmoil that has gripped our country, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.    
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world.
When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change.     
Happy reading and all the best,   ￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼ 

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
Manafort, Cohen, and Individual 1 Are in Grave Danger
Robert Mueller is closing in on the president and all his men.
By Ken White, attorney and former federal prosecutor, The Atlantic
￼
Federal prosecutors filed three briefs late on Friday portending grave danger for three men: the former Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort, the former Trump fixer Michael Cohen, and President Donald Trump. In an age when Americans usually get mere squibs of breaking news from Twitter, Facebook, and red-faced cable shouters, many started their weekend poring over complex legal filings and peering suspiciously at blacked-out paragraphs. The documents were stunning, even for 2018. 
In brief No. 1, Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s office argues that Paul Manafort breached his cooperation agreement with the government by lying to the FBI and the Special Counsel’s Office in the course of 12 meetings. The brief oozes a level of confidence notable even among professionally hubristic prosecutors: Mueller says he’s ready to present witnesses and documents, and that he gave Manafort’s lawyers an opportunity to refute the evidence but they could not. Mueller is sure he has the receipts. 
To read the complete Atlantic article, please click here. 
150 Minutes of Hell
￼
The inside story of death and survival as the Carr Fire's tornado of flames stormed Redding — and changed firefighting in a warming California
By Lizzie Johnson, The San Francisco Chronicle
Death blew east on a savage wind, driving flames over foothills and across a river, spitting glowing embers and scrubbing the earth bare. 
It was coming for Don Andrews. 
His bulldozer’s windows shattered, flinging glass into his face. The blue-green shards were everywhere: on the floor, inside his helmet, in his skin and eyes. He was alone and blinded. The firestorm shook the ground and roared as loud as a passing train. 
I’m not going to survive this, he thought. 
To read the complete San Francisco Chronicle article, please click here. 
  
Louisiana School Made Headlines for Sending Black Kids to Elite Colleges. Here’s the Reality.
T.M. Landry, a school in small-town Louisiana, has garnered national attention for vaulting its underprivileged black students to elite colleges. But the school cut corners and doctored college applications.
By Erica L. Green and Katie Benner, The New York Times
BREAUX BRIDGE, La. — Bryson Sassau’s application would inspire any college admissions officer. 
A founder of T.M. Landry College Preparatory School described him as a “bright, energetic, compassionate and genuinely well-rounded” student whose alcoholic father had beaten him and his mother and had denied them money for food and shelter. His transcript “speaks for itself,” the founder, Tracey Landry, wrote, but Mr. Sassau should also be lauded for founding a community service program, the Dry House, to help the children of abusive and alcoholic parents. He took four years of honors English, the application said, was a baseball M.V.P. and earned high honors in the “Mathematics Olympiad.”  The narrative earned Mr. Sassau acceptance to St. John’s University in New York. There was one problem: None of it was true. 
“I was just a small piece in a whole fathom of lies,” Mr. Sassau said. 
To read the complete New York Times article, please click here.
  
It Happened One Night . . . at MGM
When Patricia Douglas was raped by an MGM salesman at a 1937 studio party, the 20-year-old dancer filed charges, taking on Hollywood's most powerful institution. Today, as Douglas breaks a 65-year silence, the author exposes the perjury, bribes, and smear tactics used to destroy her.
By David Stenn, Vanity Fair
"What,” asked Jacqueline Onassis, “are we going to do next?” It was September 1993. She had just edited Bombshell: The Life and Death of Jean Harlow, in which I solved the long-standing mystery of how Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer’s beloved Blonde Bombshell died suddenly and inexplicably at 26. (Unbeknownst even to herself, Harlow had been suffering from kidney failure since she was 15.) Now, over lunch at the Peninsula hotel in Manhattan, I told Jackie of an intriguing topic I’d stumbled onto in my Harlow research. A month before the star’s death, in 1937, a dancer named Patricia Douglas had been raped at a wild MGM party thrown by Louis B. Mayer. Instead of bartering her silence for a studio contract or cash, Douglas went public with her story and filed a landmark lawsuit. One person I interviewed told me, “They had her killed.” 
I didn’t believe that, I told Jackie, because, though MGM was then the world’s most powerful movie studio, with its own railroad and in-house police force, it would never have gone to such an extreme. Jackie smiled and said, “Well, why don’t you find out what did happen? You’re the only person who can, David.”  To read the complete Vanity Fair article, please click here.

Subject: Congressman Gonzalez Applauds New Medicare Drug Pricing Rule Aimed at Lowering Prescription Drug Prices
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
On Monday, I announced that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services has issued a proposed rule that lowers prescription drug costs and increases transparency surrounding Medicare Parts C and D. 
In May 2018, I joined Congressman Doug Collins (GA-09) to introduce the bipartisan H.R. 5958, the PHAIR Pricing Act of 2018, to lower drug costs to Medicare recipients at the point of sale. The new rule includes language from this bill. 
￼ 
Medicare recipients deserve transparency when utilizing their life-savings. Prescription drug prices should not be decided behind closed curtains and the final cost should not be almost equal to 50 percent above the negotiated price. The road to fixing America’s prescription drug market may be long, but I commend the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for taking this important step. 
It is my mission in Congress to make affordable, accessible healthcare and prescription drugs readily available to Central and South Texans. 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.    
Sincerely,
￼ 
Vicente Gonzalez Member of Congress

Subject: Weekly Update: A Legacy of Honor
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
CONTACT
Weekly Update: A Legacy of Honor By Congressman Rob Wittman December 8, 2018  Hail to the Chief we have chosen for the nation, Hail to the Chief! We salute him, one and all. Hail to the Chief, as we pledge cooperation In proud fulfillment of a great, noble call.  This week, the nation mourned the loss of our 41st president, George Herbert Walker Bush. A man who indeed fulfilled his great, noble call to serve with integrity, courage, and honor.  President Bush’s list of achievements was impressive to say the least: Navy pilot, congressman, Ambassador to the UN, Republican National Committee Chairman, Head of U.S. Liaison Office in China, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Vice President, and finally President of the United States. He was America’s Commander-in-Chief to serve in the military during combat.  Mr. Bush, a top negotiator on the international stage, approached the changing world with a view that was pragmatic rather than ideological. Under his leadership, the Berlin Wall, a symbol of communist oppression, fell. In Latin America, Mr. Bush restored free elections in Nicaragua, ultimately leading to the Sandinista government being voted out of power. In the Middle East, the United States successfully kept Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, protecting global stability.     However, as I stood in the Capitol Rotunda surrounded by family and friends of the Bush’s, Vice President Pence, and my colleagues, I remembered something else the president brought to American politics: civility. Although our president almost three decades ago, Mr. Bush’s voice of bipartisanship and humility remained strong and his dedication to our country unwavering. He once said, “When the really tough choices come, it's the country, not me. It's not about Democrats or Republicans, it's for our country that I fought for.” 
￼

In my life, I have tried to replicate this behavior. The only way to get real change is to put your pride aside and work on the issues that matter – regardless of party lines. Here in Congress, I always try to work across the aisle to get the things done that are important to my constituents. Mr. Bush’s voice of civility and diplomacy will be missed.

Winston Churchill once said, “We make a living by what we get, we make a life by what we give.” President George Herbert Walker Bush contributed so much to our great nation, dedicating his life to public service. As we remember our 41st President of the United States, we remember a patriot, a man of virtue, a class act.

Rest in peace, Mr. President. Your legacy lives on and will continue to inspire future leaders.
￼ ￼ ￼

￼ 
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
December 8, 2018


REMEMBERING 41 On Wednesday, the nation said goodbye to our 41st president. President George H.W. Bush was a dedicated public servant, outstanding statesmen, brave leader of the free world, and above all: a loyal husband and father. Rest in Peace, 41.  
￼
Photo credit: Jabin Botsford, The Washington Post
ONGOING TRADE TALKS I joined Fox Business on Tuesday to talk about ongoing trade talks with China and President Trump’s negotiation strategy. Watch the full interview on my Facebook page.   
￼
 TOURING TORNADO DAMAGE I had the opportunity to join GRDA and tour several counties by helicopter this week. We assessed tornado damage and viewed the recovery efforts that have already begun. Despite the damage, I have faith that the Oklahoma Standard will continue to be our guiding light as our communities rebuild and repair damage to their homes. If you need assistance, please contact my Muskogee office at 918-687-2533.  
￼


￼

￼


APPLY FOR AN INTERNSHIP
Are you interested in a congressional internship? My Washington, D.C. office is accepting intern applications for the spring 2019 semester. Interns will have the opportunity to see the inner workings of Congress firsthand, assist legislative staff in policy research, work alongside my team to provide constituent services to Oklahomans in the Second District, and much more. For more information, contact my D.C. office at 202-225-2701 and ask to speak with the intern coordinator. Interested applicants can apply on my website at this link.

WEEKLY WRAP-UP It was an honor to attend the funeral of President George H.W. Bush with Christie. He truly was a hero and will be missed dearly by his family, friends, and a grateful nation. Particularly this week, I was reminded of how proud I am to be an American. Watch this week’s wrap up on my Facebook and YouTube pages.  
￼

See more from this week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way. 

Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Saturday, December 8, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week, I attended the Inauguration Ceremony of new Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador in Mexico City. I also provided district media and members of the community with updates on current topics including trade, border security and appropriations impacting the district. 
In the district, my staff attended several events, including the Fifth Annual Lamar Bruni Vergara Trust IMPACT Economic Development Forum and presented several Congressional Certificates of Recognition to different outstanding constituents throughout the district. 

I have also included a video from fema.gov that talks about steps you can follow to ensure you are taking the necessary fire-prevention precautions this holiday season. 

This week, we remember President George H.W. Bush and the incredible legacy that he leaves behind. His unyielding leadership, commitment and servitude to his family and to our country will be matched by none. My heartfelt condolences go to the Bush family during this difficult time. 

As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Rep. Cuellar Attends Mexican President Inauguration in Mexico City 
￼

On Saturday, I attended the inauguration of President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador in Mexico City. I had the opportunity of meeting with President Lopez Obrador’s new cabinet and high-level officials. I am looking forward to working with President Lopez Obrador and his administration on a variety of matters important to both countries.
Top photo: On Saturday, December 1, Congressman Cuellar (TX-28) attended the inauguration of President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador in Mexico City. Bottom photo from left: Congressman Michael McCaul (TX-10), President of Mexican House of Representatives Mario Delgado and Congressman Cuellar (TX-28), and Mexican Congressman of Nuevo Laredo Salvador Rosas in Mexico City on Saturday.


Providing the Community with Legislative Updates 
￼

This week, I provided district media and members of the community with updates on current topics including trade, border security and appropriations impacting the district. 


Hidalgo County Commissioners Court-Special Recognition 
￼

On Tuesday, December 4, my Outreach Coordinator for Starr and Hidalgo counties Nichole Hernandez presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Commissioner Joseph Palacios of Precinct #4 for his commitment to public service: Senator Chuy Hinojosa; Rep. Alex Martinez; Nudin Kulum, Constituent Field Representative from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez’ Office; Yolanda Chapa, representing Hidalgo County Judge Ramon Garcia; Raul Sesin, Hidalgo County Drainage Director; District Attorney Ricardo Rodriguez; Judge Renee Betancourt; David Fuentes, Commissioner for Precinct 1; Eddie Cantu, Commissioner for Precinct 2; Sabrina Walker, Director of the Edinburg Boys and Girls Club); Martha Sanchez, Community Organizer of La LUPE; and many others were in attendance. 


Defense Fellow Completes 2018 Air Force Legislative Fellowship Program 
￼

On Tuesday, December 4, my Defense Fellow David Kolcun graduated from the 2018 Air Force Legislative Fellowship Program. I congratulate him on this great achievement, thank him for all his hard work, and wish him the best in all his future pursuits. My D.C. staff attended this prestigious ceremony. Pictured from left are Olya Voytovich, Patrick O’Connor, Travis Knight, David Kolcun, Nina Andrews, Roger Misso, and Zack Linick. 


Recognizing Hidalgo County Judge
￼

On Wednesday, December 5, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr counties Nichole Hernandez presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Hidalgo County Judge Ramon Garcia in honor of his retirement as Chief Administrative Officer for the County of Hidalgo. Judge Ramon Garcia made a positive economic impact in Hidalgo County by attracting and retaining businesses in the area. We thank him for all his work and wish him the best in all of his future endeavors. 


Fifth Annual Lamar Bruni Vergara Trust IMPACT Economic Development Forum
￼

On Wednesday, December 5, my Laredo District Staff attended the Fifth Annual Lamar Bruni Vergara Trust IMPACT Economic Development Forum in Laredo. At the event, my staff presented Congressional Certificates of Recognition to the event’s honorees for their dedication to economic development in Laredo. Pictured from left are Texas Workforce Commission Commissioner Representing Labor Julian Alvarez III, Carlos Garcia, Falcon International Bank President Gilbert Narvaez Jr., Outreach Coordinator Francis Atwell, Uni-Trade Group CEO Lic. Eduardo Garza-Robles, TUM Logistics Founder Rafael Tawil, External Affairs Manager for AEP Texas Tony Arce Jr., Executive Director of Strategic and External Initiatives at Laredo College Dr. Rodney Rodriguez, and President of the San Antonio Global Chamber of Commerce Christopher Herring. 


Recognizing Winners of 2018 Congressional App Challenge 
￼

As we celebrate National Computer Science Education Week, I want to recognize two high school students from Laredo Independent School District, Antonio Portos and Andres Gutierrez, for winning the 2018 Congressional App Competition in the 28th District of Texas. Their app titled “Ode to the Stars” was chosen among numerous entries and they will proudly represent the 28th District in the Spring of 2019 during the national exhibit #HouseOfCode in Washington, D.C. Pictured from left are Cigarroa High School Teacher Alexander Castro and Cigarroa High School students Antonio Portos and Andres Gutierrez. 


Intern Spotlight: Alexander Molina 
￼

Meet our intern Alexander Molina. He is a senior at Texas State University where he is pursuing a Bachelor’s Degree in Political Science and Spanish. He is currently interning in our Washington, D.C. office through the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute Internship program. To learn more about Alexander and our other interns, please click here. 


Holiday Season Fire Prevention Steps
￼

This video from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) talks about small steps you can take to fire-proof your home as you are decorating for the holidays this December. 


 
 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

December 8, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review




December 3

Technology and the Workforce: This weekend, I had the chance to read through a portion of the Jobs Lost, Jobs Gained report by the McKinsey Global Institute. It predicts that, by 2030, technological breakthroughs in artificial intelligence and robotics will displace as much as a third of the US workforce.
Let me say that number again...one third of the American workforce will be displaced as a consequence of technology. Many of us worry about immigration, but the big upheaval in our lives on the employment front is going to come through technology...and it’s something all of us should work to be prepared for.
The saying is that the only constant in our lives is change. These statistics underscore this. They also underscore how important lifelong learning is, and will be over the years ahead. Gone are the days of one place of work over our working lives, instead it’s predicted that each one of us will hold a succession of different jobs over the course of our lives. That’s in fact something that I’m looking square in the eyes come January 3rd!
What I’ve furthermore found interesting in thinking about this report is how this is not the first time the U.S. has gone through a major shift in the composition of employment. Click here to read more.

￼
 

￼

December 4

Offshore Drilling Update: A quick update on offshore drilling…
I suspect you already saw the news last Friday, but in case you didn’t, the National Marine Fisheries Service authorized permits under the Marine Mammal Protection Act for five companies to begin seismic surveys in the Mid-Atlantic, from Delaware to central Florida.
This obviously includes the offshore waters of South Carolina.
I have made my stand here in opposition based on my belief in the importance of federalism. Ultimately, this was never a debate about whether one was pro or con on offshore drilling but rather a question of whether or not one believes all decisions should be made in Washington.
As I said repeatedly back in the primary, one is with only two choices when nearly every mayor and city council of the coastal towns that you represent in this 1st Congressional District come to you with formal proclamations stating their opposition to offshore drilling and exploration. You can either say, “you don’t know what you are talking about...” or “it is legitimate that you have a point of view in deciding the way that your communities grow and develop. This was always particularly the case, given that their opposition had little to do with the offshore issue and everything to do with where the infrastructure was going to go to support offshore operations. For this, back in the primary, I was castigated for being against the president… Click here to read more.
￼

December 5

President George H.W. Bush's Funeral: I was at the National Cathedral today for the funeral service for George Bush. It was inspiring in many different ways, given the very full life that our 41st President lived.
But may I tell you a more local story that I think says everything about the former president’s remarkable sense of duty and service?
Our second son, Landon, about a year ago decided to write a host of living legends in hope that they might offer him wisdom. His question to each of them was: what would you say to yourself at age 20 if you could indeed go back in time and give yourself wisdom?
Long story short is that the only legend to write back was former president H.W. Bush.
I have included a copy of that letter below.
It says everything about the class, decorum, humility, and compassion that marked the president’s service that he would respond as he did.
So many great things were said today. Jon Meacham began his eulogy telling the story of Bush as a young navy airman at the age of 20 being shot down and praying for deliverance. Those prayers were answered, and in many ways, the rest of President Bush’s life reflected his thanks for that deliverance and his service became part of his own answer to the question any survivor asks himself: why was I spared when others were not?
The former Prime Minister of Canada, former Senator Simpson, and Reverend Russell J. Levinson Jr. spoke eloquently on President Bush’s remarkable legacy of service.
Former President W. Bush gave a spectacular eulogy on his life and service, and I thought so much of it that I will include it in the Friday post later this week….
But what I was struck by today was the way that those great words matched perfectly with the simple letter this former president had sent my son in March of this year. It is a reminder again of how the little things in life can be reflections of the great things that were celebrated on a day like today, and how those little things can make such a big difference in others’ lives.
￼
President Bush's Letter to our son, Landon


￼


December 6

Economic Warning Signs: We have another warning sign before us.
Not that any normal person is into studying yield curve numbers, but our yield curve is flattening.
Historically, this has not meant good things - and has, in most cases, served as a harbinger of bad things coming in the economy. In fact, almost without exception, flattening yield curves have meant that a recession will soon be on the way.
If this happens, the anticipated trillion dollar deficits that our federal budget will soon see will grow exponentially. This will occur at the very time when many people’s wallets and pocketbooks get hammered with a downward turn in the economy.
There’s certainly no crystal balls on what come next, but there are signs and this is an important one.
Specifically this Tuesday, the yield curve hit its flattest level since before the most recent recession.
The interest rates for 1 month Treasury bonds have jumped up above the interest rates for 1 year Treasury bonds. This is technically called an inverted yield curve.
This isn’t normal and here’s why.... Click here to read more.                     
￼
December 7  President Bush's Eulogy of his Dad - President Bush: I promised earlier this week to send President Bush’s eulogy for his dad and do so now.   I could not more strongly agree with everything he said with regard to living life to the fullest, humility on the journey, the importance of service, family, and faith…and the joy to be found in a good covey rise.   Life is indeed short, and the parable of the talents says that we are to make the most of the time that we do have here on this Earth. President Bush certainly did, and the demonstration that he lived in a life well-lived is inspirational and well-encapsulated in the words below.   Take a listen; it will brighten your Friday…. Click here to watch the eulogy.
￼
 
￼
Click above to see the letter




￼  ￼  ￼  ￼

INTERN IN MY OFFICE

My office is currently looking for spring interns in both my Washington D.C. and Colorado district office. Students must receive some form of academic credit for their internship. Click here to learn more and to submit your resume today! 

￼


REMINDER - FILL OUT YOUR FAFSA
 Did you know that completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) significantly increases the odds of students continuing their education—especially among low-income and minority students? Studies show that 90 percent of high school seniors who complete FAFSA attend college directly after high school, compared to just 55 percent of seniors who do not complete the form. Last year, only 48 percent of Colorado high school seniors completed the form, leaving $47 million in federal financial aid unused.
The 2019-2020 FAFSA form became available October 1, 2018 and students are encouraged to fill it out as soon as possible. Here are seven tips before you fill out the form and the FAFSA form can be accessed here.  

TAX SECURITY AWARENESS WEEK
 Do you know the signs of tax-related identity theft or how to recognize and avoid phishing scams that pose as trusted sources? Learn how to protect yourself at www.irs.gov/securitysummit. 
￼

THANKS FOR STOPPING BY
 On December 1st, my office hosted our annual District Office Open House. Thank you to those of you who stopped by to visit and let me know what’s on your mind. I enjoyed talking with many of you and enjoyed meeting several of our U.S. military service academy nominees and their families.
My office is your office, and my constituent services team is always here to help. Contact us at perlmutter.house.gov or (303) 274-7944.

Subject: Congressman Jeffries E-News
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
 E-Newsletter Sign Up
December 8, 2018  


                               
 
 
REP. JEFFRIES ELECTED DEMOCRATIC  CAUCUS CHAIR
 
 
 
￼


 
READ
 
Last week, Rep. Jeffries was elected by his colleagues to serve as Democratic Caucus Chair, the fifth-highest ranking position in House Democratic leadership. In the most competitive race of the day, Jeffries prevailed with a 123-113 victory. Not only does this make the Congressman one of the youngest members in leadership today, it also marks the first time two African Americans (incoming Majority Whip Jim Clyburn of South Carolina being the other) have ever served simultaneously in top House leadership positions. Rep. Jeffries looks forward to continuing his advocacy on behalf of constituents in Brooklyn and Queens as Democrats take the majority.   
 
 
 
 
￼



 
Hakeem Jeffries Emerges as New Face of House Democrats
 
 
 
At a leadership table of septuagenarians, Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York has just emerged as the Democrats’ face of generational change.
 
Mr. Jeffries, a 48-year-old Brooklynite with a golden tongue, was elected by his fellow Democrats on Wednesday to the relatively obscure position of chairman of the House Democratic caucus. It is the No. 5 leadership spot, but Mr. Jeffries is now on the fast track, with the potential to make history as the first black speaker of the House.
 
“Hakeem represents the leading edge of a new wave of Democrats,” said Steve Israel, the former New York congressman and onetime chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. “I think he tapped into a sense in the caucus that the next generation of leaders needs to begin crystallizing.”
 
READ MORE
  
 
                                     
 
 
￼
 



 
WATCH
 
In a recent interview with Errol Louis on NY1, Rep. Jeffries discussed his new leadership responsibilities and how his focus will remain on helping his constituents in the 8th Congressional District.

Subject: Latest from Lamar: Honoring the memory of President George H.W. Bush
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Honoring the memory of President George H.W. Bush
George H.W. Bush may have been the only person ever elected President of the United States primarily by being nice. I had the honor of serving as his Secretary of Education and have dozens of handwritten notes from him—as do, I suspect, hundreds of Americans. His presidency is increasingly admired for his courage and restraint: for unifying Germany, for making hard decisions that balanced the budget, and for challenging aggression in Kuwait with decisive but measured military action. America is fortunate to produce leaders who bring out the best in us, as President George H.W. Bush did.
Honey and I were honored to attend President Bush’s memorial service. It truly was a celebration of a remarkable life and of the life of our country. Presidents Trump, Obama, George W. Bush, Clinton and Carter were there. The tributes were eloquent and moving, especially George W.’s pausing to reflect upon how President Bush lived his life, which is a wonderful lesson for all of us about how to try to live our own lives.  
 
￼
 
 
In 1991, I persuaded President Bush to use a computer for the first time. We were in his private office next to the Oval Office in the White House. This was well before most people had ever heard of or used the internet.
 
 
 
￼
 
 
I had the opportunity to share my memories of our 41st President on Fox News and spoke on the floor of the United States Senate about George H.W. Bush’s legacy.  
 
 
 
Agreement between President Trump and China to control deadly fentanyl will save thousands of American lives
This week, President Trump reached an agreement with Chinese President Xi in which China will make fentanyl a controlled substance, meaning those who manufacture and try to sell this deadly drug to the United States will be prosecuted. Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid that can be 100 times stronger than opioid prescription pills, and almost all of it coming into the United States is produced in China. This drug is the source of the greatest increase in opioid overdoses and deaths in our country, and resulted in the deaths of 77,000 Americans last year alone.
Last month, I led a congressional delegation to China where, at the urging of U.S. Ambassador Terry Branstad, I discussed this proposal with Chinese officials and made fentanyl and the opioid crisis the primary point of our visit. I talked with Ivanka Trump about our trip and encouraged her to get the White House to make this a priority, and she understood that this would save lives and help thousands of Americans. I also urged President Trump to ask the Chinese to continue working with us to stem the flow of fentanyl into the United States. As President Trump said, the deal reached this week is a “game changer,” and he deserves great credit for persuading China to make the selling of fentanyl subject to the maximum penalty under Chinese law.
President Trump posted the following tweets on this agreement:
￼
￼
 
Introducing Tennessean A.B. Culvahouse, Jr., at his confirmation hearing to serve as U.S. Ambassador to Australia
￼
Click here to watch me introduce A.B. to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
It was my privilege to introduce Tennessean A.B. Culvahouse, Jr., at his confirmation hearing to serve as U.S. Ambassador to the Commonwealth of Australia. He is the most accomplished lawyer I know, and I do not know many public servants more accomplished than he is. That might sound like an extravagant claim, but I mean it sincerely. He had the great advantage of being born and raised in Ten Mile, Tennessee. A.B. became legislative counsel to Howard Baker, our former senator for Tennessee who later became majority leader of the United States Senate. He was counsel to President Ronald Reagan while he was in the White House. He became counsel to both John McCain and Donald Trump during their presidential campaigns as they began to consider vice presidential selections. And in the midst of all of that, he has been the chairman of one of the world’s largest law firms, O’Melveny and Myers. All of these activities have established him as enormously well-qualified for this position. I’m more than a little jealous that he is the Tennessean who gets to be the Ambassador to Australia.
￼
I spoke on the Senate floor this week about my good friend, Bob Corker. While I am looking forward to working with Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, as Peyton Manning said, I wish Bob would serve until he was 100 years old. It's been a privilege to serve with him, and I look forward to watching what has to be one of the best upcoming shows in town, which will be whatever Bob Corker decides to do next.
 
Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:
Knoxville News Sentinel: Handwritten notes and White House strolls: How George H.W. Bush touched Tennessee politics
WVLT-CBS Knoxville Channel 8: Sen. Alexander remembers Pres. Bush in social media post
The Sydney Morning Herald: US-Australia 'as rock solid as ever' says incoming US ambassador
Oak Ridge Today: DOE awards $91 million contract for Mercury Treatment Facility at Y-12
 
If someone on behalf of the president asks you to do something for the president, ask to speak with the president.
#296 in Lamar Alexander’s Little Plaid Book

Subject: Our Future Is Bright
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2nd District | CONTACT
OUR FUTURE IS BRIGHT
￼
This week is Computer Science Education Week, and I celebrated with a visit to a computer science class at Plymouth High School.
To highlight the amazing opportunities STEM education and computer-based skills bring to our future Hoosier workforce, I paid a surprise visit to Ms. Moore’s cybersecurity class and announced the winner of the 2018 Congressional App Challenge.
￼
It was an honor to congratulate Kobe Johnson for his hard work, ingenuity, and innovative spirit that helped him create his winning app, “Homework Helper.”
I was impressed by the hard work and dedication shown by each student who participated this year, and I’m grateful for the opportunities Hoosier students have not only to learn about computer programming but also to showcase their talent through this competition.
￼
I also visited students at New Paris Elementary this week to speak to them about freedom, democracy, and the things that make our country strong.
These fourth and fifth grade Hoosiers have some amazing teachers and school administrators who are putting them on the path to success.
It was an exciting experience to hear from them and answer their thoughtful questions about my work in Congress. I got a peek at our future this week, and it is certainly looking bright.
DAY OF INFAMY
￼
On December 7th, 1941, our country was changed forever.
Yesterday marked 77 years since the attack on Pearl Harbor. On this solemn occasion, we remember those who gave their lives on that day of infamy.
We honor all who answered the call to defend our freedom and democracy when our way of life was under threat, and we reflect on all that they gave to our country.
I want to thank the brave men and women who serve – past, present, and future – because our great nation is strong, resilient, and free because of their sacrifices.

Subject: Remembering President George H.W. Bush
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Remembering President George H.W. Bush
Today, on this National Day of Mourning for President George H.W. Bush, we reflect not only on what he has done for our country, but the extraordinary man he was. Although I did not personally know him, having been on this earth during his extraordinary lifetime has been a great honor. As our president, he was a very respectable man, but he did so much more. He served our country as our Vice President, Congressman from Texas, CIA Director, Ambassador and – more importantly – as a father and a friend.  
President Bush wasted no time in answering the call to serve our country, he joined the Navy right after he graduated high school after the attack on Pearl Harbor. President Bush will forever be known as the youngest naval aviator of World War II when he joined the Navy at age 19; and even after he was shot down, he continued to serve on behalf of our nation. When he was honorably discharged from the Navy, he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his heroism and achievement. I personally would have liked for him to be my commander-in-chief while I served during Vietnam because of his experience and knowledge of the battle field. He took a self-financed visit to Southeast Asia to tour the U.S. positions during the Vietnam War; but most importantly, he was proud of our nation at a time that many were not. President Bush is one of the greatest examples of why we must remain committed to taking care of our servicemembers and veterans.  
It is also well known that President George H.W. Bush had a warm and caring heart, best exemplified by his actions over the years. During his time in the White House, he recognized more than 1,000 people for making a difference in their communities through his Daily Point of Light Award. This movement, and his term “a thousand points of light,” gave new life to volunteerism, which inspired so many to do good in their communities and across the country. The president also joined President Clinton in a disaster relief partnership after the tsunami devastated Southeast Asia in 2004. In 2011, President Bush rightfully received the Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama in recognition for his public service.  
President Bush was also a friend to many and he knew how to have fun. I remember Dana Carvey, who impersonated him on Saturday Night Live, ended up being a good friend to the family. Dana spoofed him, but not in a way that was disrespectful. Both the president and the first lady enjoyed Dana’s impersonation of him so much that they invited Dana to the White House; from then on the two became good friends. President Bush was the same man whether the camera was on or off, and he exemplified what is was to be a gentleman to others and his wife. It has been an honor for me to serve in the same House, “the People’s House,” that the president served in early in his career. I hope many will use President George H.W. Bush’s life as an example for their own, for he was a rare public servant that I hope inspires more people to follow his example in the future. My wife and I continue to extend our deepest sympathies to his family during this time of mourning, and I know our country will never forget the great legacy of 41.  
Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼

GET HELP
NEWS
CONTACT

SIGNED INTO LAW FOR OUR ENVIRONMENT
￼ 
Lindsey - 
Florida’s environment is a non-negotiable priority - central to our economy, quality of life, and most importantly, the health of every family. The well-being of the Everglades, our beaches, our waterways and other ecosystems impact everybody that lives in Florida. 
The good news is that we are making progress: 
The President just signed my bill into law, called the Jupiter Island Land Transfer Act, to ensure that the habitats of endangered turtles and other animals are preserved by expanding the Hobe Sound National Wildlife Refuge. Being good stewards of our environment begins with strong conservation efforts and protecting our environment is critical to our businesses and livelihoods. 
Watch this week's Week In Review video to learn more: 
WATCH NOW 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media: 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman

Subject: Good news inside:
Message:
￼ 


Saturday, December 8, 2018


Good news inside:



Dear Friend:
Welcome to your weekly update. As always, you can learn more about these and other legislative issue at my website: upton.house.gov. 
Announcement of $20M grant for US-31 
The good news we promised: The US-31/I-94 project finally got the federal funding needed this week to complete the project. On Thursday, our office announced that the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) was awarded a $20 million discretionary grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) to complete the US-31 relocation project from Napier Road to I-94 in Berrien County. 
For years, we have been working diligently with local, state, and national leaders to get this done. The DOT has long-said ‘hang on, help is on the way’ and this week that help finally came. Completing this project will ensure Southwest Michigan remains a hub for economic competitiveness, jobs, and growth now and into the future. 
Learn more here or do a deeper dive below: 
WSJM: Upton talks US-31 funding project MLive: $20M federal grant funds completion of U.S. 31 link to I-94 South Bend Tribune: Funding secured to complete U.S. 31 connection to I-94 in Berrien County Herald-Palladium: A long road ahead WSJM: US-31 to be expanded to I-94 Moody on the Market: U.S. Department of Transportation finally produces funds to finish US-31 to I-94 Fox17: M-Dot awarded $20M to complete US-31 connector to I-94 WOODTV8: Feds give $20M to connect I-94 and US-31 WSBT22: U.S. Department of Transportation awards M-Dot grant to finish U.S. 31 in Berrien County
Strong and steady job growth
According to the Department of Labor, the unemployment rate remains at the lowest point since 1969 at 3.7% in November for the third month in a row.
The U.S. economy added an additional 155,000 jobs in November.
This follows a year of growth for our country. Wages are also on the rise for workers and it is making a real impact for families across Southwest Michigan.
Click here for more information on my work promoting job creation and economic growth. 
Remembering President George H.W. Bush
On a more somber note, we remembered the life and legacy of President George H.W. Bush this week. This is an individual who leaves behind a powerful legacy as a war hero, statesman, and consummate public servant. Above all else, he was a dedicated family man. A husband, father, and grandfather whose faith guided his life in everything he endeavored. 
The WWII generation often spoke to the rest of us about the character and standing of our nation. President Bush’s passing certainly reminds us what we desire in our leaders: compassion, honesty, grit, and a duty to try and do the right thing.
I knew President Bush well from my days in the Reagan White House. His office was right around the corner from mine. In fact, his was among the first congratulatory calls on my first election win. I also fondly recall campaigning with him in New Hampshire, and traveling together on Air Force One and Two. Never a day he let his country down. 
He now joins his wife Barbara in eternal peace. Amey and I joined with all Americans this week in celebrating his life and mourning his passing. 
Have a great weekend and God bless,
￼
Fred Upton
Member of Congress

Subject: George H.W. Bush
Message:
News from Representative Crawford 
￼ 
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   
￼
 Saying Farewell to 41
Last Friday, the Nation was saddened by the passing of George H.W. Bush. President Bush had a lifelong dedication to public service, serving in the military, Congress, the foreign service, the intelligence community, and ultimately the White House. His life touched us all, including me. In my time in the Army, I had the honor and privilege of supporting his Secret Service detail. While we all mourn his passing, we must all aspire to be more like George H.W. Bush. The President put it best: “America is never wholly herself unless she is engaged in high moral principle. We as a people have such a purpose today.” As the memorials to the President conclude this weekend, please join me in keeping the Bush family in thoughts and prayers and reflect upon how to follow his example and espouse his values in daily life.

FAQ (What folks have been calling/texting my office about this week)
Q: What is the latest update on the Farm Bill?  A: The Farm Bill negotiations have officially concluded and Conference Committee is waiting for the Congressional Budget Office score before releasing the exact details on the final bill. Although it has been a very slow process I am very excited about the final piece of legislation. I look forward to delivering on my promises and giving rural America an updated Farm Bill that works for everyone.
You can text me legislative concerns or questions at 870-292-6747
￼ 
TB&P
New North American trade agreement heads to Congress
The United States, Mexico, and Canada reached a tentative agreement to strike a new North American trade deal, and President Donald Trump has given Congress six months to approve the measure. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), would replace the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford, R-Jonesboro, told Talk Business & Politics he doesn’t think the agreement will be decided during the lame duck session of Congress, but it could be considered in the first couple of months after the New Year.

NW Arkansas Democrat Gazette
Bush's state ties recalled; Arkansans note his visits, encouragement

U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford, a Republican from Jonesboro, who served as an explosive ordnance disposal technician in the U.S. Army, helped with security when then-Vice President Bush was traveling.
In that capacity, he was able to observe Bush up close.
While they never spoke, Bush made it clear that he valued the security team's work.
"There was eye contact and head nods, you know, just gestures that he was aware we were there. ... There was a sense of appreciation and a kindness from him," Crawford said.
Crawford left the military in 1989, just as the Bush presidency was beginning. The voters in 1988 chose well, Crawford said.
"The historic perspective shows that he was a phenomenal commander in chief. He had all the credentials and handled it probably as good or better than anybody in my lifetime," he said.
￼

KAIT 8 - Research reveals new Craighead County ties to Pearl Harbor

Dear Friend,

We've heard from many of you regarding the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) announcement on coastal barrier protection. As you may be aware, USACE is working closely with the Texas General Land Office (GLO) to study the feasibility of constructing coastal storm risk management and ecosystem restoration (ER) projects along the Texas coast. 

On October 26, the study team released a Draft Report and Environmental Impact Statement detailing a Tentatively Selected Plan (TSP) that employs a "multiple lines of defense" strategy, combining structural, natural, nature-based, and non-structural measures to provide resilient, robust, and adaptable solutions to promote life-safety based on local site conditions and the values of the coastal community. 

If you'd like to learn more about the plan, visit coastalstudy.texas.gov to review the coastal barrier plan and offer comments on the proposal; the comment period ends on January 9, 2019. The study team will also be hosting public meetings in our area:

Tuesday, December 11, 2018 (5:30 – 9:00 p.m.)
Winnie Community Building
1301 Park St.
Winnie, TX 77665

Wednesday, December 12, 2018 (5:30 – 9:00 p.m.)
Galveston Island Convention Center
5600 Seawall Blvd.
Galveston, TX 77551

Saturday, December 15, 2018 (1:00 – 4:30 p.m.)
Crenshaw Elementary & Middle School
416 State Hwy 87
Crystal Beach, TX 77650

Tuesday, December 18, 2018 (5:30 – 9:00 p.m.)
Bay Area Community Center
5002 E NASA Pkwy.
Seabrook, TX 77586

The public is invited to attend and provide comment on the proposed plan. As always, my office is here to help. I would love to hear your thoughts regarding the matter.

Sincerely,
￼
Randy K. Weber
  

GEORGE HERBERT WALKER BUSH
George H. W. Bush was one of our great statesmen. His conviction and principle were evident in all that he did. His love for his nation was bested only by his love for his family.

Shortly after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Bush 41 joined the Navy and became one of the youngest pilots. He went on to serve in the House of Representatives, as Ambassador to the UN, Envoy to China, Director of the CIA, Vice President to Ronald Reagan, and finally as our 41st President. In each of these roles, he acted with prudence and sound judgement.

For decades, he served our nation honorably and with distinction. GOD bless the Bush family, friends, and former staffers during this difficult time.

To attend his ceremonies in Washington was an absolute honor. This great and good man brought our nation together and quieted some of the divisiveness, which is on display all too often. We have a lot to learn from his mission and his life.

As he arrived at his final resting place in College Station, with Barbara and Robin at either side, he was finally home.

Fair winds and following seas, Mr. President.

￼


HOMEOWNER ASSISTANCE PROGRAM
The Texas General Land Office opened the application for residents to apply for the Homeowner Assistance Program. If you owned your home that was damaged or destroyed by Harvey, and it was your primary place of residence, you are potentially eligible for the Homeowner Assistance Program. Applications are being considered on a first-come, first-serve basis. Federal money is allocated through the Texas General Land Office for distribution.

You may fill out the application and mail it to the Homeowner Assistance Program office or schedule an appointment to drop it off.

Subject: George H. W. Bush Mourned, Celebrated, Remembered
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online. 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT  |   SERVICES  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   OUR DISTRICT  |   CONTACT 
December 8, 2018 
George H. W. Bush Mourned, Celebrated, Remembered 
This week we mourned the death of President George H. W. Bush. He and Barbara were gracious leaders and dignified and true servants. America will miss his quiet leadership. While this was a week of mourning, it was also a time to celebrate his remarkable life. Rest in peace.   Click here to read more Click here to watch the funeral service 
￼

McKinley Talks Criminal Justice Reform, Opioids With Local Law Enforcement 
This week we had a productive meeting with leaders from local law enforcement agencies in Monongalia County. We discussed the drug crisis and criminal justice reform proposals in Congress. We are searching for solutions to help reduce the overdose death rate that continues to rise in West Virginia. This was an opportunity to hear about the impact this is having every day in our state from the people who see it firsthand. I look forward to bringing their ideas back to Washington. 

Click here to read more
￼

DOE Releases Study On Ethane Storage Hub
This week Secretary Rick Perry announced the release of a new study by the Department of Energy detailing the potential for a petrochemical hub located in the Appalachian region. The reports reaffirmed what we have been saying for years- we need to capitalize on the resources we have in West Virginia and Appalachia, while using our natural gas liquids to attract manufacturing, investment, and jobs. 
We thank Secretary Perry for his leadership and for working with us to highlight the potential and need for an ethane storage hub in Appalachia. Not only is it good for our region, this is good for America. West Virginia and surrounding states are poised to become a leader in petrochemicals and manufacturing, but we need the necessary infrastructure to make it work.  Click here to read more 
￼

Corridor H Rewarded $20 Million In Grants
West Virginia will be receiving $40 million through the U.S. Department of Transportation’s Better Utilizing Investment to Leverage Development (BUILD) Grants.  $20 million will go toward the Tucker County expressway project along Corridor H while $20 million will go into the Berkeley Spring bypass project on U.S. Route 522. These grants are given to states, regions, and communities through need and the potential impact it could have on the area.
This is a much needed investment that will make West Virginia roadways more safe and efficient. By investing in infrastructure, we will be able to put people back to work and continue to help our booming economy.   Click here to read more 

McKinley Remembers Pearl Harbor 
This week we remember devastating events at Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, “A day which will live in infamy.” Each year fewer and fewer Americans are left who actually remember or were a part of Pearl Harbor. It is up to the rest of us to carry on the memory of the Americans killed there, and the attack that spurred America to action and changed history forever. 
￼

Subject: The Scoop: President George H. W. Bush, EpiPen Legislation, Foster Youth
Message:
￼ 

About Grassley
Constituent Services
News Center
Contact Grassley


Grassley Direct
On my weekly "Capitol Hill Report," I spoke with Mike Peterson of KMA Radio in Shenandoah and Dale Wegner of the Sac Sun in Sac City about President George H. W. Bush, the Farm Bill and the newly-signed trade deal with Mexico and Canada (USMCA).  
Q&A: From Judiciary to Finance 
Q. Did you achieve what you set out to do in four years as chairman of the Judiciary Committee? Q. Looking ahead, what priorities will you pursue as incoming chairman of thye Committee on Finance? 
Quick Links
President George H. W. Bush led an incredible life. He served with distinction as a naval aviator in World War II, flying 58 combat missions. He represented his community and neighbors as a congressman. He built bridges as an American diplomat in China. He helped keep our nation safe as the head of the Central Intelligence Agency. He honorably served as vice president to President Ronald Reagan before leading our nation as America’s 41st president. He will be remembered not only for his professional achievements, but for the warmth and kindness he showed to his friends and political opponents alike. President Bush will be missed, but his life and service to our nation will be remembered.
￼ 
KCRG: Grassley Remembers President George H. W. Bush 
After Iowans contacted me with concerns about the skyrocketing price of the anti-allergy prescription drug device EpiPen, I began a years-long oversight effort into why it happened and how to fix it. I found that Mylan, the distributor of EpiPen, misclassified the drug as a generic, cheating taxpayers out of billions of dollars. With Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon, I introduced the Right Rebate Act of 2018. It would close a loophole in Medicaid that has allowed pharmaceutical manufacturers like Mylan to misclassify their drugs and overcharge taxpayers. The legislation would also provide the Department of Health and Human Services with additional authorities to ensure drugs are properly classified. It’s a significant step forward to fixing some of the problems in our health care system that have allowed pharmaceutical manufacturers to price gouge taxpayers and consumers for too long.
I wrote to the Justice Department’s Inspector General and the FBI Director seeking answers about the Bureau’s raid on the residence of a whistleblower who reportedly disclosed information about the Clinton Foundation and the Uranium One transaction. I asked about the FBI’s awareness of the protected disclosures made by the whistleblower, the basis for the raid and whether any of the material seized during the raid was classified. Whistleblowers have exposed waste, fraud and abuse in just about every industry and agency in this country. Congress must take action to make sure they're protected, that includes oversight of matters whistleblowers report and how agencies treat America's truth tellers. 
Health and Human Services (HHS) Assistant Secretary for Family Support Lynn Johnson sent me a letter in response to an October 15 inquiry I sent urging her to implement recommendations from an HHS Office of Inspector General report that would help foster children who are prescribed psychotropic medications. Ensuring children in the foster care program are safe and receiving the proper treatments and support is critical. Iowa has a particularly high rate of foster children being treated with psychotropic medication and it’s imperative the state and federal government monitor treatments to make sure they are receiving the proper care. 
Post of the Week
￼ 
Every VP, except for Gore & Biden, currently have a bust in the Senate surrounding the chamber. The custom started from a resolution in 1866. Pictured is the bust of George H. W. Bush who served as president of the Senate for 8 yrs. He will be remembered for the public respect he brought to public service by setting such a good example and being an ethical & moral leader. Pres. H. W. Bush was a selfless public servant throughout this life. 
A photo by @senatorchuckgrassley on December 4, 2018

Subject: Butterfield Weighs in on NC-09 Developments
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 

￼  

HOME
ABOUT G.K.B.
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
The Washington Rundown 
There is just one week left before the end of Open Enrollment on HealthCare.gov.  Scroll down to read more on Open Enrollment.  This week, Congress passed a two-week funding extension, pushing back a partial government shutdown deadline to December 21.  The funding measure covers about 25% of federal government operations that aren’t yet funded by full-year appropriations (the other 75% of government agencies are already funded for FY 19 and aren’t subject to any shutdown).  Disagreement remains surrounding President Trump’s proposal for $5 billion for a border wall that he originally said Mexico would pay for.  State election officials continue an investigation into North Carolina’s 9th Congressional District race, in which campaign officials allegedly tampered with and destroyed mail-in absentee ballots from voters.  The News & Observer reports, “What we know (and what we don’t)” about the NC-09 election fraud allegations.  Congressman Butterfield continues to call for a full and thorough investigation before certifying the outcome of the election.  An unfairly influenced election could result in a different outcome or a new election.  House Leadership announced that a Member of Congress from NC-09 may not be seated before the investigation results are complete. 
  
Remembering President George H.W. Bush 
As the nation remembered the life and legacy of President George H.W. Bush this week, Congressman Butterfield honored his leadership and service to our nation during President Bush’s funeral at the National Cathedral on Wednesday. 
WATCH: Congressman Butterfield Remembers President Bush 
￼  Rep. Butterfield appeared on WNCT to remember President George H.W. Bush and discuss his attendance at Wednesday's state funeral in Washington, D.C. 
  
National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day 
As we continue to honor the life of President George H.W. Bush, we also paused this week to observe National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day on Friday, December 7.  Friday marked 77 years since the attack on Pearl Harbor, where many American men and women lost their lives.
￼ 
Need Health Insurance? Time is Running Out! 
If you - or someone you know - needs health insurance, the time to act is now:
Visit HealthCare.gov right now to enroll in coverage. 
￼  
Here are a few fast facts about getting covered through HealthCare.gov. 
	•	Coverage could be cheaper than you think. Most people signing up for coverage on HealthCare.gov can find plans with monthly premiums for $50-$100 per month thanks to financial assistance. Last year, more than 8 in 10 people qualified for financial assistance to make their monthly premiums more affordable.
	•	Don’t forget: You must sign up by December 15. Enroll today!
	•	Free, expert help is available. Call 1-800-318-2596 for confidential assistance or make a one-on-one appointment now.
	•	HealthCare.gov plans offer coverage you can count on. Make sure you have comprehensive coverage that guarantees you have care when you need it the most by signing up for a HealthCare.gov plan.
Don’t miss your chance to get covered and tell your friends why they should, too! 
In The News 
 
Post Bulletin: Alleged fraud clouds North Carolina’s 9th District vote. Is a new election possible? 
RALEIGH, N.C. — North Carolina has held special elections to fill vacant congressional seats when, say, a member has resigned. But, if the State Board of Elections and Ethics Enforcement calls for a new election for the 9th Congressional District, it will apparently be the first time in N.C. history that alleged fraud has caused voters to go to the polls a second time to decide the same congressional race.
Fraud has caused some rematches in local elections in the state, said Gerry Cohen, who drafted election laws during his 37 years — 1977 to 2014 — as special counsel for the N.C. General Assembly. But, he said, this would “absolutely be the first time for a congressional election.”
*** 
The state’s three congressional Democrats, meanwhile, have called on the state board to not certify the election until it could “guarantee that the outcome of this election reflects the will of the voters and (ensures) accountability for any misconduct.”
The statement signed by Alma Adams, David Price and G. K. Butterfield also endorsed the calling of a new election if “investigations produce clear evidence of voter fraud.” 
  
Charlotte Observer: North Carolina leaders react to President Bush’s death 
RALEIGH - North Carolina leaders are remembering former President George H. W. Bush following his death Friday night. 
Gov. Roy Cooper ordered flags lowered to half-staff at state facilities in honor of the passing of the nation’s 41st president. Bush was 94.
*** 
Congressman G. K. Butterfield offered his condolences on social media. 
“I join the country in mourning the loss of President George H.W. Bush,” he said in a tweet. “He led a life of public service with dignity, honor, and respect. Prayers to the Bush family as we reflect on a life well lived.”
  
Pacific Standard: MEMBERS OF A CHRISTIAN COMMUNITY IN NORTH CAROLINA ARE DEVASTATED AFTER A SANCTUARY DWELLER'S DEPORTATION 
The Trump administration has deported an undocumented North Carolina man who had been living in a church basement sanctuary space for nearly a year. 
Samuel Oliver-Bruno, whose wife and son remain in the United States, was arrested the day after Thanksgiving, during what he was told would be a routine appointment with U.S. immigration authorities. At the meeting, he was being fingerprinted for what he anticipated would be an application to have his deportation deferred at a U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services office in Morrisville, North Carolina.
*** 
"We believe the actions taken by ICE and USCIS in Mr. Oliver-Bruno's apprehension are extremely concerning and deserving of scrutiny," North Carolina Representatives G. K. Butterfield and David Price, both Democrats, said in a joint press release late last week.
  
￼

REMINDER: 40 Days to Get Covered

Dear San Franciscan, 
Did you know health insurance can be cheaper than your cell phone bill? In fact, 80% of people can find plans for less than $75 per month. Covered California is the only insurance marketplace in California where eligible consumers can receive financial assistance to help pay for their health insurance. 
Key Dates: 
• December 15, 2018: Deadline to sign up for coverage starting January 1, 2019. • January 15, 2019: Last day consumers can sign up for coverage starting February 1, 2019. 
  ￼ 
Californians currently enrolled can use Covered California's “shop and compare” tool to see if there is a health plan that could work better for you in 2019. Current members may also qualify for a different amount of financial help than last year. Enrollees have until January 15th to change their plan for 2019. Individuals with special qualifying life events can enroll at any time of the year and Medi-Cal enrollment is also year-round.   
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
    Need Help? 
￼ 
Almost nine years ago, with the signing of the Affordable Care Act, America added a new pillar of health and economic security to Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. The ACA has delivered historic progress expanding coverage, lowering costs and improving benefits for every American – no matter where they get health coverage. 
￼ 
March 21, 2010: Speaker Pelosi and House Democrats pass the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Two days later, President Obama signed the legislation and the ACA officially became law.

Home
Contact Me
Press Releases
Videos

Dear Friend, 
The nation will always remember the life and legacy of President George H.W. Bush. View my remarks reflecting on the 41st President of the United States here. 
Land and Water Conservation Fund
I hosted a bipartisan press conference last week calling for the reauthorization and full funding of the crown jewel of conservation programs, the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF). I joined my fellow LWCF champions in both the House and Senate to fight and save this vital conservation program before the end of the year.
I also gave a speech on the Senate floor stressing the importance of this crucial conservation and recreation program that protects Colorado's public lands. 
￼ 
View my remarks from the press conference by clicking on the photo above or here. 
View my floor speech on LWCF here. 
Energy Innovation Grants Awarded to Colorado Universities
I recently announced with my colleague Senator Michael Bennet that the U.S. Department of Energy's Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E) awarded Colorado School of Mines and the University of Colorado Boulder over $2 million. This grant aims to continue their cutting edge work in innovative energy technologies. I have always advocated for continued research and development programs and will continue to do so because of the enormous benefits these programs bring to Colorado. 
Bipartisan Legislation to Help Improve Veterans' Health Care
I joined several of my colleagues this week to introduce bipartisan legislation to help improve veterans’ health care by increasing collaboration among federal agencies and authorizing the Department of Energy (DOE) to develop technologies that solve complex data challenges. This bill will help provide world class care to our veterans by leveraging cutting-edge technologies at our National Labs. I’m proud to lead this bipartisan effort and I will make sure the collaboration between the Department of Veterans Affairs and our National Labs continues. 
Full Legislation is available here. 
Receiving the Guardian of Small Business Award
Colorado small businesses are crucial to the economy and to our communities and I am proud to be a voice for them in Congress. I appreciate the National Federation of Independent Business recognizing my hard work for the small business community by awarding me the Guardian of Small Business Award from the President and CEO Juanita Duggan. 
￼ 
Working to Extend the Secure Rural Schools Program
I sent a bipartisan letter to Senate leadership recently urging the reauthorization of the Secure Rural Schools and Community Self-Determination Act. I am pressing for an extension of the Secure Rural Schools (SRS) Program in any end-of-year legislation so that the schools, libraries, and jails will continue functioning in their counties. 
View letter here. 
Read more about my efforts to save rural funding via Colorado Politics here. 
Meeting with Coloradans in Washington
Last week, I met with many Coloradans to discuss a variety of important, bipartisan issues. I had the opportunity to meet with President Sweeting from Colorado Christian University, We Work for Health Colorado, the new Fort Lewis College President Tom Stritikus, and former Senator Campbell Nighthorse. I also visited with military personnel from Fort Carson, and Mayor Lofgren, the new Mayor of Lochbuie. 
Below are a few pictures from this week's meetings.  
￼

ICYMI: Exciting news for the Denver Airport being named the #1 large airport in the country by the Wall Street Journal. Congrats to the airport and its staff, this is a testament to the hard work it takes to operate a world-class facility and commitment to excellent service.  





Need Help with a Federal Agency? 
My staff is available to assist you with finding out the status of a case and requesting additional information from a federal agency. I have offices in Denver, Durango, Pueblo, Grand Junction, Fort Collins, Greeley, Yuma, and Colorado Springs. Learn more about how we can help here.  
Thank you for taking the time to read my weekly update. If I can be of any assistance to you, please contact my Washington, D.C. office at (202) 224-5941. 
  
Sincerely,
