Subject: Gohmert Response To Letter From Mr. Gaspard of the “Open Society Foundation” re: Mr. George Soros
Message:
December 6, 2018
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view the plain text.
￼
Gohmert Response To Letter From Mr. Gaspard of the “Open Society Foundation” re: Mr. George Soros 
WASHINGTON, D.C. - In response to a letter from Mr. Gaspard of the “Open Society Foundation” regarding Mr. George Soros (attached below), Congressman Louie Gohmert issued the following statement:  “Mr. Gaspard, with the misnamed Open Society Foundation, has been very diligent to condemn opinions or allegations about Mr. Soros’ activity. Yet, he surely knows that in his interview with Steve Kroft on December 20, 1998, Mr. Soros as a mature adult verified that he had no sense of guilt about the role he played in Nazis’ confiscation of property from the Jewish people during the Holocaust. As a very mature adult, if Mr. Soros had deep regrets about what he did when he was 14 years old and apologized, I would have nothing but sympathy and admiration. Were he ever to do that in the future, I would still have those same warm, respectful feelings.
“Instead, Mr. Soros statement went on to say that if he weren’t there, someone else would have been in his role.  Those are things HE said, that HE admitted as an adult. Any person with any sense of empathy for his fellow human beings would regret the part they played in assisting the Nazis.
“Mr. Soros also admitted in that same interview regarding his financial dealings that, ‘I cannot and do not look at the social consequences of what I do.’ That’s breathtaking.
“My remarks were not anti-Semitic; the Israeli government itself stated last year that it did not mean to ‘delegitimize criticism of George Soros, who continuously undermines Israel’s democratically elected governments by funding organizations that defame the Jewish state and seek to deny it the right to defend itself.’
“As for any attempt to invoke fear of violence or violence itself whether against Mr. Soros or anyone whomsoever, I have spent an adult lifetime working in our justice system to try to ensure that anyone who takes justice into his or her own hands must answer to that justice system. If a person who sent a bomb to anyone came before me as a judge for sentencing, I would have no problem assessing a significant time of incarceration. In that manner, the rest of us can maintain our freedom of speech, a God-given right enumerated in the very First Amendment to the United States Constitution. Freedom of speech should not be undermined by heavy-handed attempts to stifle criticism.”  
￼
 
￼

Subject: WATCH: Senator Blunt Honors President George H.W. Bush
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
HOME
ABOUT
SERVICES
ISSUES
NEWS
CONTACT
Dear Friend,
￼
This week, I went down to the Senate floor to pay my respects to a great statesman, president, husband, and father.
  President George H.W. Bush had the best qualities of his generation, the Greatest Generation. He stood up straight, took responsibility, shared the credit, and took the blame.
 When the Soviet Union collapsed during his presidency, he exemplified the best of American diplomacy and helped steer Eastern Europe toward democracy. From World War II naval pilot to president of the United States, George H.W. Bush's example and service made a world changing difference.
 You can watch the full remarks here and read the excerpts below:
 “Certainly in Missouri, we claim part of the Bush family. His mother grew up in Missouri. The Walkers were from Missouri, and he treated Missouri like it was one of the states that he was connected to by relationship. His Uncle Herbert, along with his grandfather and later his Uncle Herbert and the rest of the family, would go in the summer to Walker's Point, named after that Missouri part of his family, just like the Walker's Cup is named after that part of his family. The impact of his mother is pretty great. I heard the president talking the other day on an interview with Jenna Bush about who he would look for when he got to heaven and that was a couple years ago, I think and he said, well, if Barbara has gone there first, I think the right answer would be, I'm going to look for her first. But then he said, and I think my mom and my dad. He said their daughter that they had lost when she was three, Robin, but his mother was an important part of his life. And you could tell that in talking to him or his children that remembered their grandmother and you could see a lot of what she taught him in him. …
 “Another part of his upbringing was sort of the upbringing of in many ways the best values of that World War II generation. Stand up straight, take responsibility, share credit, take blame. Those were all part of who George Herbert Walker Bush had become. That idea that you should do what you're supposed to do; that idea of the importance of service to others. …
 “And then, Mr. President, the collapse of the Soviet Union. We have just enough time now to look back and I've heard many others in the last few days talk about how that could have gone so badly wrong for all of the other countries that were trying to emerge from the domination of Russia and the Soviet Union. But George Herbert Walker Bush on the phone, reaching out, talking to leaders, seeing the things that had just been predicted by the West Germans themselves to be impossible, that somehow East Germany could become part of West Germany is exactly what happened. The President encouraged, stood beside, went out of the way to be sure that Helmut Kohl, the leader of West Germany, had the kind of support that he and his government needed to reach out and bring this country that had been isolated for 40 years, this part of the country back into the country, that all of these East European countries that were emerging from Soviet domination had a chance to move from domination to democracy. That would not have happened the way it happened if somebody less prepared and less capable had been there.”
 
Sincere regards, 
￼

Subject: Be Prepared For Winter Weather
Message:
Dear Friend,
 This week inclement weather is expected to arrive in the district. The National Weather Service is forecasting a wintry mix of snow and freezing rain, both of which can make getting around dangerous. Let’s all be cautious as we move about.
Keeping a few things in mind can help us all stay safe, should the weather take a turn for the worse.
Before driving, make sure to give yourself enough time to melt or remove any snow or ice that may have formed on your vehicle. Drive a little slower than normal and be cautious of ice that may have formed on the roads. Give yourself plenty of room between you and the vehicle in front of you so that you have ample space and time to stop when needed.
Due to the wintry mix, ice that may form on power lines could cause power outages, so make sure you have your batteries and generators ready, just in case.
As always, prepare, be safe and look out for your neighbor.  

Best Regards,     
￼

Congresswoman Alma S. Adams, Ph.D.

Subject: Serving our Veterans
Message:
<
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT SUZAN  |   HOW CAN I HELP?  |   NEWSROOM  |   ISSUES  |   CONTACT 
SERVING OUR VETERANS
Dear Friend,
Washington’s First District is home to more than 40,000 veterans. Given all they have done for us, we must ensure that our local veterans receive the best health care and benefits.
My office works with veterans to help communicate with and navigate through our federal system. During my time in office, we have helped more than 192 veterans gain access to quality health care and helped retrieve $1 million in back pay. I recently advocated on behalf of Bill, a terminally ill Air Force veteran whose appeal was being delayed. Bill was awarded over $200,000 in back pay for his stage IV cancer resulting from Agent Orange exposure. It also sparked systematic action, producing a nationwide review of all terminally ill veteran records.
If you need assistance, please do not hesitate to contact my Bothell office at (425) 485-0085. Although I cannot guarantee a particular outcome, we are always ready to listen to your concerns and work to find a solution. Here are some actions we routinely take to assist veterans:
Veterans Health Administration
	•	       Assistance with scheduling an appointment
	•	       Assistance with getting authorization to use the Choice Program
	•	       Clarifying notices from the VHA
	•	       Connecting veterans with a patient advocate
	•	       Helping with the authorization of emergency treatment outside the VHA
Veterans Benefits Administration
	•	       Connecting veterans to a local Veterans Service Officer
	•	       Clarifying notices from the VBA
	•	       Walking veterans through the appeals process for denied claims
	•	       Cutting red tape to get long overdue appeals processed
	•	       Helping veterans access their military records or a DD214
	•	       Assisting veterans navigate the VA home loan program
	•	       Helping manage debt that the VA should rightfully be paying
Department of Defense
	•	      Assisting veterans appeal a DFAS decision
	•	      Clarifying notices from DFAS
As always, I am here to help you. If you have questions or comments about the topics that matter most to you, I encourage you to contact me through my website. You may also keep up-to-date on what I’m doing by following me on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook.
Sincerely, 
Suzan

Subject: A Solemn Goodbye to an Iconic Houstonian, Former President George H.W. Bush
Message:
News from Representative Olson

Clicks open in browser window     Clicks open plain text version
￼
 
Website
Contact Us
How Can I Help?

Our District
About Pete
 
December 6, 2018
￼

￼


CONNECT WITH ME
￼
￼
￼
  
Dear Friend,  Texas and America’s hearts are heavy with the loss of a true patriot, a great president and one of the most decent men ever, George Herbert Walker Bush. George and his wife Barbara never let the pressures of their chosen lives take away their humanity. They lived their lives purely and respectfully, serving as shining examples to us all. George is now in Heaven with Barbara and their 4 year old daughter Robin by his side.   This week, it was an honor to pay my respects to former President Bush as he lay in state in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda. This honor is reserved for our nation’s greatest public servants and the catafalque, the platform his coffin rested upon, has been used since Abraham Lincoln lay in state in 1865. I was moved by the outpouring of love and support from thousands of folks across America who came to DC to pay tribute to this iconic American. It is a true testament to his leadership and love of family, faith and country. Even as the most powerful man in the whole world, he never, ever lost his humanity. ￼  Former President George H.W. Bush lies in state in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda   I’m honored to represent you in Congress. For more information on constituent services, current legislation or to sign up for my E-newsletter, please visit my website, www.olson.house.gov.    Very respectfully, Pete Olson

Subject: HouseWatch Alert for the Week of Dec. 6, 2018
Message:
￼ 
Dear Friend,
President George H.W. Bush’s funeral at the National Cathedral yesterday was an important moment for the country to honor his life of service and reflect on America’s democratic values and leadership at home and abroad.  I was proud to represent the citizens of the Tampa Bay area and honor the achievements of President George H.W. Bush.  He served during a tumultuous time, including the bloodless and hopeful end to the Cold War.  On behalf of my neighbors, I was also proud to cosponsor a resolution to honor the life of President George H. W. Bush, and his service to our country. 

￼

I traveled to the former East Germany and Czechoslovakia in 1990 after the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Velvet Revolution.  There I witnessed firsthand how the United States under President George H.W. Bush was directly engaged with those nations during their transition away from Soviet influence.  Importantly, Americans were free to travel and interact with the people there.  President George H.W. Bush’s wisdom and the respect he engendered from our allies and the world ensured that American legal and economic experts, along with businesses, could be present to directly aid the countries as they transitioned to greater freedom and personal economic opportunity.

￼

Our nation will remember President George H.W. Bush as a patriot, who saw his duty and was dedicated to his country.

Sincerely, 

Kathy Castor 

P.S. Remember to join me on Facebook for more pictures and information about issues important to our community.

Subject: To Infinity and Beyond 🚀
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this email, please view it on my website.
￼ 

To Infinity and Beyond   


￼ 
   
One of my goals as a United States Senator is to create and foster an environment where young Kansans interested in STEM can receive a quality education and enjoy robust career opportunities right here at home.
As part of this mission, I hosted NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine and NASA Astronaut Don Pettit this past weekend in Wichita to speak with students interested in STEM and space exploration. Over 150 Kansas students, educators and families heard from Astronaut Pettit on his path to becoming an astronaut and his many missions to the International Space Station. Astronaut Pettit shared exciting stories from his time in space and encouraged students to “find their frontier” and chase after their dreams. I am certain that we had numerous future scientists, engineers, mathematicians – and even astronauts! – in the room with us. 
Events like this are important as we work to inspire and train the next generation of inventors and innovators. And through my positions as a member of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies, I’m committed to making certain we support agencies, projects and programs that increase opportunities for our young people so that they can have rewarding, meaningful careers right here in Kansas.
To watch a recap of our day in Kansas, click here.  
Very truly yours, Jerry

Hoosiers,

Last week at the G20 summit in Argentina, President Trump signed the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement. According to the White House, this renegotiated NAFTA trade deal with Canada and Mexico aims to benefit America's workers, manufacturers, farmers, and businesses by incentivizing billions in new auto production, increasing market access to farmers and ranchers, safeguarding America's intellectual property against foreign competitors, and putting small and medium sized businesses first. You can read more about the trade deal here.

Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window

￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
The world lost a true statesman this week with the passing of former President George Herbert Walker Bush. President Bush personified class, importance of family values, and above all a long commitment to public service on behalf of Texas and our nation. You can read my full statement here. 
I sat down with NPR’s All Things Considered to honor the life and legacy of former President Bush, which you can listen to here.  
Open Enrollment 
￼
There is still time left to get health insurance coverage for 2019. Most Americans can find cheaper plans that work for them and their families by logging onto healthcare.gov.  
District Updates 
Team Castro attended the Ingram Hills Neighborhood Association Holiday Party this week where good food and music was shared by all; joined Cyber Signing Day in San Antonio at the United States Department of Commerce’s National Institute of Standards and Technology #NICEK12 conference to recognize talented students who recently joined teams with local cyber firms; and participated in the City of San Antonio’s Immigrants and Health Care Convening session on the public charge with other folks that share similar interest and concern.
￼ ￼ 
Team Castro also joined CyberSecurity SA at St. Philip’s College to hear about efforts to enhance our cyber ecosystem and workforce opportunities; and joined other educators and students from across the city at Trinity University to discuss the future of higher education as part of the city’s tricentennial celebrations. 
￼￼ 
￼  ￼ 
Hispanic Caucus 
It was an honor to be elected Chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus for the 116th Congress. You can read my statement here. 
Continued Family Separation 
I’m deeply concerned about reports that the Administration may have resumed separating families under a false premise that they are protecting children from ‘criminal’ parents. Congress needs answers on the standards and the evidence this Administration is using to designate certain parents as ‘criminals’ and whether this is just cover to resume the Administration’s cruel and xenophobic position towards immigrants. You can read my full statement here.  
Protecting Mueller 
It’s clear that the Special Counsel’s investigation is working and we must protect him and his investigation so the American people can get the truth they deserve. Here is my statement on this week’s developments as Mueller submitted his sentencing memo for General Michael Flynn.  
You can also listen to my NPR’s All Things Considered interview where I discussed Michael Cohen’s guilty plea last week.  
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress

Subject: A Winning Week for Trade
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Graves
￼
 
Website
Meet Sam 
Legislation
News 
Services
6th District
Contact Sam
 
December 5, 2018
￼ 

E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.* 
 ￼ 
 *By subscribing to my e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e- mail account.

Dear Friend, 
Free trade needs to be fair trade and farmers received several pieces of good news last week on that front. 
President Trump announced that negotiations with China have taken a major step forward. Because of some very important concessions from China, the President struck an agreement that he won’t raise the tariffs on Chinese goods while negotiations continue. As a result, China has agreed to purchase a “very substantial amount of agricultural, energy, industrial, and other product from the United States.” These purchases are designed to reduce the trade imbalance between our two countries and put us in a much better position than we have been for quite some time. 
Most importantly, China has agreed to begin purchasing US soybeans immediately. Prices have surged. This is welcome news across rural America. Meanwhile, negotiations with President Xi will continue in the hopes that China will quit ripping off our country. We continue to play the long game knowing that the best deal isn’t going to happen overnight. 
Closer to home, the trade “long game” is just about over and it looks like a win. 
President Trump, along with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, signed the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA. It replaces NAFTA, which had put the US at a disadvantage in several key areas. 
The new agreement will increase market access for America’s farmers and ranchers, incentivize billions in new auto production, install new protections to safeguard America’s intellectual property against foreign competitors, and create a new chapter to benefit America’s small and medium sized businesses. 
The President kept his promise to deliver a new agreement and getting his counterparts in Mexico and Canada to the table to sign the agreement was a huge win for America. The ball is now in Congress’ court and I hope we will act quickly in the new year to ratify the agreement. 
Trade is critical to North Missouri and these developments are huge. Our farmers, ranchers, manufacturers and businesses are one step closer to having the certainty and market access they need. We’ve still got a long way to go but I am committed to helping us get the best possible trade deals we can get. With a little patience, I think we can even out the imbalances and right the ship. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Sam Graves

Subject: Rutherford Roundup for December 5
Message:
News from Representative Rutherford  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
 

Contact Me | Subscribe
￼
RUTHERFORD ROUNDUP
For December 5, 2018

Dear Friends, 
Today our country observed a National Day of Mourning for the loss of our 41st President George Herbert Walker Bush. His legacy as a father, husband, decorated veteran, public servant, and leader is a shining example of the best our nation has to offer. His devotion to our country was matched only by his dedication to his wonderful family.
President Bush built an incredible record of service and accomplishment, serving in the Navy, the House of Representatives, the CIA, as Vice President, and ultimately as President. But more importantly, he was a man of tremendous character and humility who fought for justice, freedom, and peace throughout his career and life. I hope each of you took time in recent days to celebrate a life well-lived, mourn his passing, and reflect on the exceptional values that President Bush’s words and deeds demonstrated. May he rest in peace.  

￼ 

Our Coastal Communities Must Be Protected
￼ 
I was disappointed to see NOAA Fisheries announce their approval of five Incidental Harassment Authorizations, or IHAs, that could allow five companies to conduct seismic testing off our Atlantic Coast – the first step to offshore drilling. I am very concerned about what this may mean for our vulnerable marine mammal populations and other marine life, but I also have many questions about how this will impact naval operations and training missions that operate off the East Coast. We have very little information on what this would mean for our national security, the health of our recovering fisheries, or our coastal economies. Not to mention that any data collected about oil and gas reserves off our coast would be proprietary, meaning neither the public nor government officials would have access to this information.
Last June I led a bipartisan letter with 104 of my colleagues requesting that Interior Secretary Zinke not approve seismic airgun blasting in the Atlantic Ocean. Click here for a link to that letter. Please know I will keep fighting to stop unnecessary threats to our economy and our security off our coast. 
  
￼ 
Improving Veteran Job Readiness Programs Honors Their Service
￼  
Although Veterans Day has come and gone, we are reminded that we must not put our gratitude, our patriotism, and the needs of our veterans on the shelf until next November comes around. Each of us, and especially those of us in Congress, must keep focused on the many challenges our veterans face and maintain our commitment to their needs all year long. One such challenge is the transition from service to civilian life, which can be a difficult adjustment for service members and their families. I recently wrote an op-ed for Military.com where I discuss the importance of improving transition assistance programs, which can do more to help those who sacrificed so much for us. To read the op-ed in its entirety, please click here.  
   
￼ 
JAXPORT Receives Continued Federal Investment
 ￼ 
Last month, the Army Corps of Engineers awarded JAXPORT $46 million in additional federal funding to continue the progress on its deep draft navigation project. I have been fighting relentlessly for sustained investment in this project and this good news signifies a major victory for our region. JAXPORT is a significant economic engine supporting tens of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in economic output. Read more about this exciting news here. 
  
 ￼ 
Using Innovations to Keep Troops Safe 
￼ 
As Co-Chair of the bipartisan Congressional Modeling and Simulation Caucus, I have the opportunity to support emerging technologies that strengthen our national security. Last week at the annual Interservice/Industry Training, Simulation, and Education conference, I witnessed the cutting edge developments that are improving the education and training for our servicemembers. These technologies help prevent future disasters like the collisions of the USS McCain and USS Fitzgerald. 
We secured $111 million in federal funding for training facilities at Mayport that will prepare the Littoral Combat Ship crews as these mission critical ships continue to enter the fleet. I am encouraged by Vice Admiral Brown’s comments in the story below and am committed to working with the Navy to ensure our sailors have the best technology, methods, and training available to ensure successful and safe missions around the world.
To read more about improving these training standards, please click here.  
￼ 
Honoring Local Heroes
￼ 
I had the privilege of attending the Jacksonville Beach Police Department Award Ceremony to honor Patrol Corporal William Eierman, K-9 Officer Benjamin Gray, and Patrol Officer Jason Murphy for their selfless service to our community.
Corporal Eierman received the Medal of Valor and Law Enforcement Purple Heart for his heroic actions on August 8th of this year when he was shot twice while engaging a shooter near a local establishment. Officers Gray and Murphy also received the Distinguished Service Award for the bravery they displayed on the same evening. Their remarkable actions most likely saved the lives of fellow officers and civilians they are sworn to protect. On behalf of a grateful community, I want to thank Corporal Eierman, Officers Gray and Murphy, and the entire Jax Beach Police Department family for what they did that evening and for what they do every day to help keep Northeast Florida safe.
  
￼ 
Snapshot: Recent Photo Highlights
￼ 
I attended the 16th Annual JAX Chamber Military Appreciation Luncheon and heard an inspiring message from Vice Adm. Mary Jackson. Congratulations to Capt. Clarence Hill who received the RDML Kevin F. Delaney Hall of Fame Award, which honors veterans who have positively impacted our communities. 
  
￼ 
I was honored to speak at the 2018 Celebration of Valor in Jacksonville. In partnership with the Jacksonville Jaguars Foundation, the City of Jacksonville’s Military Affairs and Veterans department awarded $50,000 in community grants to eight local veteran serving organizations. 
￼ 
Stay Connected
As your voice in Washington, it is important that I hear from you. I want to hear your ideas and opinions, and I hope to keep you informed on what is happening in Congress. You can visit my website for press releases and recent news, and follow me on Twitter and Facebook to find out how I’m fighting for the people of Northeast Florida. It is an honor to serve the 4th District and I look forward to hearing from you. 

￼ 

￼
￼

Subject: Our Most Important Conservation Program
Message:
￼
December 5, 2018
Dear Friend,
The Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) is America's most successful conservation program. LWCF expands opportunities for outdoor traditions like hunting, camping, and fishing that are among the pillars of Western culture. In New Mexico, LWCF has helped preserve many treasured places-including the Valles Caldera, Ute Mountain, and Valle de Oro National Wildlife Refuge-that power our thriving outdoor recreation economy.
However, despite our best efforts to save LWCF, congressional inaction allowed the program to expire earlier this year. I am doing everything in my power to permanently and fully fund LWCF before the end of the year. I recently joined a bipartisan group of lawmakers and conservation leaders at the U.S. Capitol to express how critical this program is for New Mexico. I hope you can take a moment to watch and share my remarks.
￼ 
VIDEO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich joins Democratic and Republican lawmakers and conservation leaders to stand up for the Land and Water Conservation Fund, November 29, 2018.
LWCF has built a proven track record over the last half century as a successful program. The broad support LWCF has from both Republicans and Democrats is a testament to how well the program has worked all across the nation. We must renew it to continue protecting our drinking water, providing public land access, and funding neighborhood parks, soccer fields, and baseball diamonds for our children.    We have lots of things that are worth debating in Congress. LWCF is not one of them. We need to get permanent reauthorization and mandatory, full funding for LWCF across the finish line to ensure that the outdoor places we all treasure will be protected for future generations to enjoy. 
Sincerely,
￼
MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window
 Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative John Ratcliffe 
￼ 

WEBSITE
SERVICES
CONTACT
FACEBOOK
INSTAGRAM



￼ 
Today marks the national day of mourning for former President George H. W. Bush, who passed away last week at the age of 94. But as we mourn his loss, we should also celebrate his distinguished service to our country.  
￼ 
President Bush’s public service began many years before he became the 41st President of the United States. The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor inspired him to enlist in the Navy on his 18th birthday and become the nation’s youngest naval aviator. 
He went on to serve as a Texas member of the U.S. House of Representatives, the ambassador to the United Nations, an envoy to China, director of the CIA, and as Vice President for eight years before winning the presidency.  
President Bush was a man of great integrity whose dedicated life of service to his country and devotion to his family should inspire us all. Our nation will always be grateful for his legacy.  
  
Sincerely, 
￼

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window
 Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative John Ratcliffe 
￼ 

WEBSITE
SERVICES
CONTACT
FACEBOOK
INSTAGRAM



￼ 
Today marks the national day of mourning for former President George H. W. Bush, who passed away last week at the age of 94. But as we mourn his loss, we should also celebrate his distinguished service to our country.  
￼ 
President Bush’s public service began many years before he became the 41st President of the United States. The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor inspired him to enlist in the Navy on his 18th birthday and become the nation’s youngest naval aviator. 
He went on to serve as a Texas member of the U.S. House of Representatives, the ambassador to the United Nations, an envoy to China, director of the CIA, and as Vice President for eight years before winning the presidency.  
President Bush was a man of great integrity whose dedicated life of service to his country and devotion to his family should inspire us all. Our nation will always be grateful for his legacy.  
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
John Ratcliffe U.S. Representative for Texas’ Fourth District

Subject: Only 10 days left!
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼￼￼￼￼￼￼
￼
Carper's Connection
December 5, 2018
Dear Friend,                                                    
It’s official: the holiday season is here! Like many Americans, you may be thinking about what gifts to get your loved ones this month. Perhaps something they’ve always wanted. Perhaps something especially thoughtful. Maybe something you think that they need. 
￼
As you start your holiday shopping during this busy season, don’t forget about something that we all need for a happy and healthy 2019: health care coverage. 
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) marketplace is up and running, and there are only 10 days left to sign up for health insurance for the coming year. If you don’t get health insurance through your employer, Medicaid, Medicare or the Children’s Health Insurance Program, you can find a high-quality, affordable health care plan that works for you through the ACA marketplace. 
And this isn’t a holiday purchase that will break the bank: many health plans in the ACA marketplace have premiums that are $50 to $100 per month, and 8 in 10 people will qualify for financial assistance.
If you’re new to the health insurance market place or have questions, you can visit healthcare.gov to learn more about plans that might work for you and your family’s budget. You can also visit any Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC), like La Red in Georgetown, that are committed to finding plans and providers tailored to fit your lifestyle. 
￼
Recently, I visited La Red and saw firsthand how staff, who are experts at navigating the health insurance marketplace, are working directly with Delawareans to help them find a plan that fits both their health needs and budget. If you’re in Seaford, Milford or Georgetown, you can call them directly at 302-855-1233. 
Do you live in Kent County or New Castle County? No problem. There are other FQHCs all around the First State! For a comprehensive list of where you can go for direct help, click here. 
Don’t forget: Saturday, December 15th is your last day to enroll through the marketplace for 2019. So as you buy your presents and spend time with friends and family, remember there is no better gift than knowing you are covered for year ahead. 
Every family in the First State and across our country deserves access to high-quality and affordable health care, and it’s one of the wisest investments you can make. This holiday season, help your family and loved ones find coverage that works for them so that everyone can have a happy and healthy New Year.  
￼

Subject: Traverse City Central Student Wins Congressional App Challenge
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Dec 5, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158


Traverse City Central Student Wins Congressional App Challenge

Traverse City - Today, as part of Computer Science Education Week, Congressman Jack Bergman announced that Elizabeth Saunders, a Traverse City Central High School student, had won the 2018 Congressional App Challenge. Rep. Bergman issued the following release:

"Congratulations to Elizabeth on winning the 2018 Congressional App Challenge for the First District. Thanks to the efforts of teacher Paige Paul, I had the opportunity to Skype into Elizabeth's class yesterday to let her know that her app 'CalcuSaver' had won the competition," said Rep. Bergman.

"I'm proud of everyone that participated this year, and look forward to hosting the 2020 Congressional App Challenge next year."

By winning the Congressional App Challenge, Elizabeth will be invited to visit Washington, D.C. in the spring to showcase her app to Members of Congress and members of the tech community at the #HouseOfCode reception. 

CalcuSaver, the app created by Elizabeth, will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol and featured on the House of Representatives website along with other winning entries from around the country. Elizabeth will also receive Amazon Web Service credits, donated by Amazon Web Services. 
bergman.house.gov

Subject: honoring a great man
Message:
￼ 
 

December 5, 2018
 
Dear Friends, 
 On Sunday, November 30, our 41st President, George H.W. Bush, died at the age of 94. 
President Bush was an incredible man who dedicated his entire life to serving our country. He served as a naval aviator in World War II. He was a man of faith, humility, and undying optimism for our nation's future.  Rachel and I continue to pray for the Bush family and friends. May the Lord may comfort them in this time of mourning. 
His funeral can be viewed LIVE by clicking HERE. It begins at 10am central today.  
 I wanted to share with you a few touching moments from the last few days, as America honors the memory of a great man. 
  
President Bush's Service Dog  
Here is a picture of President Bush's faithful service dog, Sully. Click HERE or the image below to share the picture of this faithful yellow lab. 
￼ 
  
Bob Dole's Salute 
Senator Bob Dole, also a World War II veteran, stood to salute President Bush as 41 was lying in state in the United States Capitol. 
Click HERE or the image below to "like" and SHARE this incredible moment. 
￼  
  
Honor President Bush's Memory On Facebook 
Click HERE or the image below to "like" and SHARE on Facebook. He was an incredible man, and we will never forget his dedication to service and his love of country.
￼ 
  
  
 
Until next week!   God bless, 
￼ 
Sean Duffy

Subject: Our humble hero
Message:
News from Representative Heck  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

                                                     
In Memoriam
President George Herbert Walker Bush was our last combat veteran to serve in the highest office in the land. He was one of the finest members of the Greatest Generation, entering public service following a decorated career as a Navy pilot in World War II.
I had the privilege to meet President Bush. Despite our policy differences, he was a very gracious and kind person.  
Back in 1989 when he was president and Washington's own Tom Foley was House Speaker, he visited Spokane to celebrate our state's centennial. He flew across the country to the hometown of the speaker of the opposite party, and celebrated alongside him and other Washingtonians. And keep in mind, our state went for Dukakis! His devotion to bipartisanship and mutual celebration was truly extraordinary.  
￼  President Bush with House Speaker Tom Foley in 1989 (courtesy of WSU) 
Last week I invited a freshman Republican from Texas into my office. He will be moving into my former office, 425 Cannon, as we go into this next Congress. It was great to get to know a new Member of Congress and welcome him to our deliberative body. 
In the spirit of our 41st President, I hope we can work together to build an economy and national security apparatus of which we can all be proud.  
Rest In Peace, Mr. President.
  
Sincerely, 
￼
Denny Heck
Your Member of Congress

Subject: News From Washington And Across West Texas
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Congressman Arrington
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
NEWS FROM WASHINGTON AND ACROSS WEST TEXAS
Dear Friend, 
As we near the end of the 115th Congress, it is imperative we finish strong, passing critical legislation before the year’s end – included in that is the 2018 Farm Bill and the final government spending package. 
President George H. W. Bush 
My heart grieves with my friend, President George W. Bush, and his family over the passing of his father, George H. W. Bush. 
President 41 was a great American and one of the most decent men I’ve ever met. He reminded us over the years that loving families are the fabric of a strong nation. He also taught us that public service is a noble calling and that being a gentleman and a politician do not have to be mutually exclusive. 
America is better because of his humble leadership, strong character, and selfless commitment to God, family, and country. 
￼
Farm Bill Agreement 
I am pleased that we’ve reached a bipartisan agreement in principle on the 2018 Farm Bill. This legislation will be tremendously helpful for our farmers, ranchers, and rural America because it significantly strengthens the agriculture safety net, makes important investments in rural infrastructure, and improves other aspects of the Farm Bill.
I am deeply disappointed that the Democrats and Republicans in the Senate made little effort to improve one of the largest welfare programs in the country, the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, which, in its current form, has trapped millions of Americans in a cycle of government dependence. 
Even so, it was imperative we closed the deal in order to provide our producers with the economic certainty they so desperately need and so we don’t have to start over in the 116th Congress with Democrats writing the Farm Bill in a Pelosi-led House. I expect the conference report to pass both the conference committee and House and Senate chambers within the next two weeks.  
￼ 
No Budget, No Recess
Over the past twenty years, Congress has failed to meet its most basic responsibility to fund the government on time. In fact, between 1977-2017, Congress enacted over 170 stopgap spending measures referred to as continuing resolutions, leaving our military in limbo, creating uncertainty in the markets, and costing taxpayers billions of dollars.  
Last week, to prevent Congress from adjourning until it passes a budget, I introduced bipartisan legislation, the No Budget, No Recess Act, with my colleague from Washington State, Congressman Derek Kilmer. This legislation would hold Congress to the same standards as the American people, ensuring that they do their job before they go home. 
￼
Stronger Trade 
With more than 95% of the world’s population and 80% of the world’s purchasing power outside the United States, economic growth and job creation for West Texas and our nation increasingly depend on expanding U.S. trade and investment opportunities in the global market.
I commend President Trump for negotiating from strength, ensuring that our producers and manufacturers are treated fairly, and I look forward to reviewing the USMCA with my colleagues in the 116th Congress. Read the Washington Time’s write up on the ceremonial signing here. 
Cotton Capital of the World 
I am proud to see West Texans fill critical U.S. Department of Agriculture Cotton Board positions as appointees! Julie Holladay of Lubbock, Jeffery Posey of Roby, Steven Olson of Plainview, Jason French of Snyder, and Brett Schniers of Wall have been appointed to the Cotton Board as members and alternate members.
Secretary Sonny Perdue said the following of their appointments: “The Cotton Board carries out research and promotional activities that help cotton compete in domestic and foreign markets, improve fiber quality and lower production costs. I want to thank these board members for the time and effort they have committed to serving the cotton industry."
With our region being the cotton capital of the world, our Cotton Board representatives bring the experience and knowledge needed to advocate for and voice the needs of cotton producers throughout the nation.  
￼
Please know, it is an honor to be your Representative. Feel free to reach out to my office and let me know how I can best serve you. 
Your friend and fellow West Texan, ￼  Jodey C. Arrington Member of Congress

Subject: Open Enrollment for Rhode Islanders Is here
Message:
Rhode Islanders, 

Need to sign up for or renew your health insurance coverage for 2019? Open Enrollment for Rhode Island residents to sign up for health insurance ends December 31. You can head to HealthSource RI right now to learn about coverage options, find the plan that works best for you and your family, and get covered. 

The Affordable Care Act is here to stay, and Rhode Island's health insurance marketplace is open for business. You may even qualify for financial assistance. 

Signing up is easy. Here is some additional information to help you get started:
	•	FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: Last year, more than 8 in 10 Rhode Islanders qualified for financial assistance to purchase coverage or reduce their out-of-pocket costs. You can use this calculator to figure out how much you can save through Health Source RI.  
	•	SHOP FOR SAVINGS: Even if you found affordable health insurance last year, you should shop around to see if you qualify for a better deal this year. You can compare plans using the calculator linked above, or check out a brochure here.  
	•	GET HELP SIGNING UP: You can contact HealthSource RI at 1-855-840-4774 or drop by the walk-in center at 401 Wampanoag Trail in East Providence. Enrollment events will also be held throughout the state. Check out the schedule to find events near you.
Again, the deadline for enrolling in coverage for 2019 is December 31. Don't wait, you can sign up at HealthSourceRI right now. As always, please contact my office with questions. 

Sincerely, 

￼
U.S. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse

Subject: November Update From Congressman Kurt Schrader
Message:
￼
 
November Update
 

￼
￼
Every year in November, we take time to honor the brave men and women who have sacrificed so much for our country. This year, I was able to honor and celebrate our veterans and servicemembers in a number of ways. I participated in the opening of the new Lincoln County Veterans Resource Center, a resource for veterans along the coast who face a unique set of challenges living in rural, more remote areas. In Salem, I had the honor to welcome home the brave men and women of 3rd Platoon, G Company, 1-189 Aviation from their recent deployment to the Middle East where they conducted over 80 medical evacuations. After putting their civilian lives on hold for a year, these servicemembers have finally reunited with their loved ones. I was also able to speak with students at Molalla River Middle School during the holiday about the importance of Veterans’ Day. It’s so important that our next generation never forget the sacrifices our veterans have made to protect our American values and our freedom.

Don’t forget: it doesn’t have to be Veterans’ Day to thank the brave men and women who protect our country!
￼
￼
Did you know? The United States Library of Congress (LOC) receives millions of books every year, and often receives so many copies of the same book that they do not have the space to store them all. As a result, the LOC created a Surplus Book Program, where institutions like schools and public libraries are able to receive these surplus books to add to their own collections. For months, my staff and interns in my Washington, D.C. office have taken on a “heavy lifting” project selecting and shipping hundreds of books to Mount Angel Abbey Library to add to their collection. This month, I stopped by the library to see all of the books we’ve been able to send, and help add a few to the shelves.

At the end of the month, we passed the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2018, which includes legislation that will keep the Newport air facility permanently open. Due to budget cuts, the Newport air facility, which handles half of the emergency response calls on the Central Oregon Coast, was nearly closed a few years ago. Newport, which is part of our 5th district, is home to one of Oregon’s three deep draft ports, the state’s largest-grossing commercial fishing fleet, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Pacific Operations Center, Oregon State University research personnel and vessels, and a robust recreational and sport fishing industry that is critical to the local economy. The bill we passed includes a provision that guarantees the Newport air facility will stay open and serve Oregon’s coastal communities into the future.

It has been more than two years in the making, but we finally cut the ribbon on the Highway 101 improvement project in downtown Tillamook this month. Safer and more efficient, these changes have totally changed the face of the town. This new downtown is also the home of Tillamook’s growing and vibrant business community. Thank you to the Tillamook Chamber of Commerce for taking me around earlier this month to meet the business owners who are continuing the tradition of innovation in this community. Congratulations, Tillamook, I look forward to seeing what more is to come.
￼

￼
￼
An outsider passing through Depoe Bay might not know that the World’s Smallest Navigable Harbor hosts one of our coast’s most vibrant charter and recreational fishing fleets. Right now, however, silt in the harbor is slowly making it impossible for boats to access the local fuel dock. Due to the silt, the fuel dock is only usable for a few hours each day, and even that period is quickly shrinking. My office, along with all your elected representatives, has been working to secure US Army Corps funding to get the harbor dredged and keep our fishermen on the water. I had the opportunity to visit the harbor toward the end of the month and get an update, and I am very pleased to announce that we were able to secure the desperately needed funding to dredge both the harbor and the check dam.
￼
Make sure you and your family have health coverage for 2019! The open enrollment period – when you can sign up for health insurance – ends on December 15, 2018 and is only six weeks. That is half the length of the enrollment period of years past. Whether you already get coverage through the exchange and want to make a change to your plan, or you're looking to get covered for the first time, December 15th is a hard deadline for everyone, so don't wait! Visit healthcare.oregon.gov today to enroll in a new plan or make changes to your current plan.

￼

Follow Us On Twitter

Subject: New edition of Himes at Home!
Message:
News from Representative Jim Himes
Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward

 
￼
 
Home
Biography 
Contact Us
Constituent Services
Issues
Newsroom
District
 
Friends,  Following the Thanksgiving recess, my colleagues and I returned to Capitol Hill to act on a pile of unresolved, but necessary, legislation. In Connecticut, I have been busy meeting with constituents and hearing from them about issues that should be addressed before the end of the legislative session.
￼
Rep. Himes touring Community Health Center, Inc.’s new location at 22 Fifth Street to hear about how federal resources can support community care centers.
Community Health Center, Inc. Grand Opening  Earlier this year, Congress passed with my support a budget that includes $7 billion in funding for Community Health Centers nationwide. Many of those funds will be used to supplement renovation and construction costs so that management personnel can grow and modernize their facilities. In Connecticut, we are beginning to see the payoff of investments like this with the opening of Community Health Center, Inc.’s (CHC, Inc.) Stamford facility. To better serve the Stamford community, CHC, Inc., will move its primary medical and behavioral health services to its new facility at 22 Fifth Street, which will offer more exam rooms, community spaces, and significant technological upgrades. I am hopeful that these new resources will help CHC, Inc., continue to deliver quality, affordable, patient-centered coverage. 

Greenwich High School Civics Discussion Like you, I have been disturbed by the decline of civility in political debate. This nasty strand of political discourse has turned off many young people from engaging in the political process. Our schools and classrooms should offer a safe forum for students to exchange ideas, receive feedback on their opinions, and learn to communicate effectively. On Monday, Republican State Representative Fred Camillo, State Representative-Elect Stephen Meskers, and I took questions from a Civics class at Greenwich High School about legislation that they would like for us to support in the Connecticut General Assembly and the House of Representatives, respectively. It is vital that we continue to give a voice to young men and women, and I was proud to hear from these students about their bold ideas to move our country forward.   
I look forward to meeting with my constituents and hearing from you about the issues that impact you. If you would like to schedule a meeting or make me aware of an upcoming event in the Fourth Congressional District, please visit my website here. If it is possible for me to attend, one of my staff members will follow up regarding my availability.  
Sincerely, Jim

Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
 
￼

December 4, 2018 

 
Upcoming Events
Manchin Mobile Monday  
Every Monday, my staff members are available in easily accessed locations across the state to assist with constituent services and to take your thoughts and concerns directly back to me.  Below is next week's time and location for Monday, December 10.          
          
Philippi:            
Philippi Public Library  
91 South Main Street 
Time: 12 p.m. to 2 p.m.       
Staff: Michael Garcia    

To invite the Senator to your event, click here. 



  
 





























From the Hill to the Mountains
Statement on the Passing of President George H.W. Bush 
Gayle and I were so heartbroken to hear of the passing of President George H.W. Bush. The President dedicated his life to our country through his patriotism, his public service and humanitarian efforts. He was a man who put country and citizens before party and politics and will be remembered as one of the greatest presidents in our history. It was truly an honor to know him and call him and Barbara friends. While our nation will mourn his loss, and pray for the entire Bush family, I will find joy in the knowledge that he is now in heaven with Barbara, the woman he loved more than anything else in this world. West Virginia will be praying for the entire Bush family and thanking them for the legacy President Bush has left on our nation and the entire world.
  
Honoring Our Veterans on Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day 
The surprise attack on December 7, 1941, was a monumental event not only in American history but in all of world history.  It awakened a “sleeping giant,” as some Japanese leaders feared. It gave every man, woman, and child in America a personal stake in a global war over the very survival of human civilization. Millions of brave souls boarded planes and ships to join the fight.  At home, brave Americans entered the factories and shipyards to supply the war effort, sacrificing to support their family members who were fighting for the freedom of the world.
These Americans, our “greatest generation,” persevered, but they did so with the same firm belief in the greatness of America, with the same love of country greater than of life itself.  America became, and remains, a free nation under God because of such men and women.
President Franklin Roosevelt said in his address before Congress that the attack on Pearl Harbor would be “a date which will live in infamy.”  In 77 years we have never forgotten.  We must make sure that each year, and more importantly every day, that we remember those past sacrifices and the ongoing sacrifices being made to protect our homeland and to secure our freedom.
Let us also pay special tribute to the men and women from our great state who served in World War II, and in every American conflict.  Our home state has mined the coal that forged the steel that built the great ships and tanks that Americans have served on.  West Virginia has given much, and we have much to be proud of.  
  
Encouraging West Virginians to Get Covered During Open Enrollment Period 
While the ACA is not perfect, the number of uninsured West Virginians has decreased by 56% as a result of the Affordable Care Act and the Medicaid expansion. Every West Virginian deserves access to quality and affordable healthcare. I encourage those without health insurance coverage to visit www.healthcare.gov  during the Open Enrollment Period to find a plan that works for them and their families. 
The Affordable Care Act Open Enrollment Period ends on December 15, 2018. West Virginians can register for health insurance coverage by visiting www.healthcare.gov/get-coverage/ or call 1-800-318-2596.  
Click here to read more. 
  
Challenging the Mobility Fund Coverage Map 
Senator Manchin (D-WV) submitted to the Federal Communication Commission (FCC) a formal challenge to Mobility Fund Phase II initial eligible areas map. The data Senator Manchin submitted proves the coverage map released by the FCC does not accurately depict broadband coverage throughout West Virginia. Senator Manchin was the only member of Congress to submit a formal challenge. 
The data I submitted last week proves what every West Virginian already knows to be true: there are too many areas throughout our state that still lack reliable broadband coverage. West Virginia faces unique challenges when it comes to providing broadband access, and the first step to fixing that is making sure these maps accurately reflect coverage on the ground. This map determines who is eligible for a portion of the $4.5 billion that will be made available later this year, and I will continue fighting to ensure every community in West Virginia has the reliable, affordable broadband access they deserve.
To view the eligible areas map released by the FCC click here. 
Click here to learn more about Senator Manchin's efforts on this issue. 
  
 
On the Road
Last week, Regional Coordinator Mary Jo Guidi, attended the Investiture Ceremony for Judge Jim Mazzone on my behalf. Judge Mazzone is now United States Magistrate Judge for the Northern District Court and brings a wealth of professionalism and knowledge to his new role. 
￼ 
  
Outreach Manager, Mike Browning, presented a flag and certificate to the caretaker of the West Williamson Cemetery, Willard Justice, for his faithful years of service. 
￼ 
  
KEY FEDERAL RESOURCES
When West Virginians compete, they win. 
Below is a grant that was recently awarded through the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).  I encourage West Virginia communities to apply for federal funding opportunities, and will be happy to provide a letter of support for eligible applications.  For further information, please contact my Martinsburg office at 304-264-4626 or click here to email me. 
	•	Community Health Systems, Inc., Beckley, HHS, Affordable Care Act Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education Payment Program grant award will be used by qualified teaching health centers to support the expansion of primary care medical and dental residency training in community-based ambulatory settings.  - $1,231,767.00 grant.
Internships
Click HERE to complete your application.  
The State Offices are accepting applications year-round. 
￼ 
In Your Community
The 11th annual College Student Congress will take place from May 13-24, 2019 in Lexington, Kentucky and Washington, D.C. One college junior from each state in the union and the District of Columbia will be selected to participate in a two-week program focused on developing our country's future statesmen and women.  
Each student receives a full scholarship for attendance, including program fees, housing, meals, and air transportation. Applications are available online at www.henryclaycenter.org.  
  
  
To learn more, call my office Toll Free at (855) 275-5737, email me,or find me on social media:

Subject: Medicare Enrollment Ends this Week!
Message:
December 4, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
If you or a family member are on Medicare, I wanted to remind you that open enrollment closes at the end of this week.   The next three days are when seniors can change their prescription drug plan or Medicare Advantage coverage for 2019.     This once-a-year window gives Medicare recipients the opportunity to select a new plan based on annual changes in cost, coverage options and available providers or pharmacies. 
The enrollment period began on Oct. 15 and ends this Friday Dec. 7.    Everyone with Medicare is eligible for prescription drug coverage, regardless of income and resources, health status or current drug expenses. Seniors who are happy with their current coverage do not need to do anything.   Seniors may sign up or update their plans in two ways:   1) Phone: Call 1-800-MEDICARE. Seniors should have their Medicare card, a list of drugs they use and the name of their pharmacy on hand to get immediate help in choosing a plan.   2) Online: Go to Medicare.gov to review prescription drug coverage options.   The Medicare program can often be confusing, so please do not hesitate to call my Sarasota office at 941-951-6643 or my Bradenton office at 941-747-9081 for assistance with open enrollment.   More details on Medicare Open Enrollment are available online in the U.S. Government Medicare handbook.     Vern

Subject: Terri Sewell's Facebook Photo Contest
Message:
News From Congresswoman Sewell Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼ 
  Dear Lindsey, 
As a lifelong Alabamian, I believe that we truly live in one of the most beautiful states in the nation. From our rugged mountains to our rolling fields, from bustling cities to our quaint towns, the 7th Congressional District is one of the most diverse in the country. That’s why I’m hosting our second annual Facebook Cover Photo Contest, featuring photos taken in Alabama’s beautiful 7th District! The winning photo from this year’s competition will be featured as the new cover photo on my Facebook page.
￼
If you have a photo you’d like to submit, email it to AL7.PhotoContest@mail.house.gov along with your name, where you’re from, the location of the photo and a brief description of what makes the place special!  Photos for the competition are due on Monday, December 17, so submit your photos as soon as possible! After the deadline, the top five photos will be put up for a vote on our Facebook page. Whichever picture receives the most likes will be our 2019 Facebook cover photo!  If you don’t have photos you can share but you still want to be a part of our annual photo competition, take a moment to like my Facebook page here, and keep an eye out for finalists in this year’s competition. When we post pictures, like your favorite one. 
Take a moment to enjoy the cooler weather and enjoy the beautiful landscapes that Alabama has to offer! Then send in your photos to AL7.PhotoContest@mail.house.gov. 
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Terri A. Sewell Alabama’s Seventh Congressional District 
Connect on Social Media
Please be sure to “like” us on Facebook, and follow us on YouTube and Twitter to receive Congressional updates and keep abreast of office events! 
It is an honor to serve the 7th District in Congress. I’ll be back in touch again soon!

Subject: With Voters’ Revolt Against Tax Hike Bill, Time to Restore SALT is Now
Message:
￼
 
With Voters’ Revolt Against Tax Hike Bill, Time to Restore SALT is Now
￼
If you look at the map, and add up the numbers, there were few things clearer on this November. The states that got stuck with paying the bill for the federal Tax Hike Bill last year, the states where gutting the State and Local Tax (SALT) deduction had the biggest impact on their pocketbooks, revolted. 

I joined Congressman Bill Pascrell, Ramsey Mayor Deirdre Dillon, and members of the Ramsey Borough Council at the Ramsey salt depot to officially launch the bipartisan fight to reinstate the SALT deduction in the new 116th Congress. 

I look forward to working with my new colleagues in Congress to stop double taxation, actually cut taxes for northern New Jersey, kill the New Jersey-targeted political games coming out of the IRS, and prevent more people and businesses from moving out of Jersey to the Moocher States.

The full video of our event can be found HERE.

You can find The Record’s reporting on the event HERE.

This Veterans Day, Securing Housing & Saving 84-Year-Old Veteran $145,000 a Year 

In honor of Veterans Day, I visited former Specialist 3rd Class Ronald Mitchell at the Paramus Veterans Memorial Home. Earlier this year, I helped Ronald access veterans housing after he lacked the appropriate documentation.

Ronald reached out to my office to help him access the veteran home benefits he had earned through his service in the United States Army in Germany in the 1950s. At the time, he was staying at a nursing facility that cost him approximately $400 per day, or about $145,000 a year. Admission to the Paramus Veterans Memorial Home requires proof of military service and Ronald's copy of his service documents were destroyed in the flooding during Hurricane Sandy. 

After contacting multiple agencies and previous employers, my office was able to produce the necessary forms through the National Archives to prove Ronald’s service and he moved into Paramus Veterans Memorial Home in September of this year.

To me, there is no commitment more sacred than the one to those who have bravely served our nation. Ronald bravely served our country overseas in Germany, I am proud to help him and make sure he gets the same care as when he took care of us during his time in the military.

If you are having trouble with your veterans benefits or a federal agency, contact my office HERE.
￼
In Face of Growing Opioid Crisis, Helping Mahwah Secure Competitive $300,000 Federal Grant 

With more than 40,000 deaths per year, the opioid crisis in this country is devastating our families, neighbors, and communities. New Jersey is not immune. In 2017, we lost 2,221 New Jersey mothers, fathers, sons, and daughters to this terrible epidemic. Six of our friends and family every single day. One of our neighbors every 4 hours. It shouldn’t be this way.

I joined Mahwah Police Chief James Batelli, Ramapo College President Peter Mercer, and local community health experts to celebrate Mahwah securing a $299,360 grant from the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) to combat the devastating opioid abuse epidemic.

We need to do more. I am proud of Mahwah for being one of only two New Jersey towns to claw back this competitive grant back from Washington to battle the crisis head on. At the event, I also thanked our brave first responders, who are on the front lines of this epidemic fighting to keep our communities safe and healthy.

The full video of our event can be found HERE.

More information about federal grants available in your town can be found HERE.
￼

In Wake of Pittsburgh Tragedy, Visiting Synagogues and Emphasizing Increased Security
￼
In the aftermath of the deadly attack on worshipers at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, PA, I visited congregations across North Jersey to mourn the devastating tragedy and reaffirm the Fifth District’s commitment to combating anti-Semitism and protecting houses of worship.

At Congregation Keter Torah in Teaneck, I joined Dr. Mort Fridman, President of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), to pledge to continue working to secure grants for temples and synagogues to better protect our community. 

I also joined Senator Cory Booker and Congressman Bill Pascrell at a vigil for the Pittsburgh victims at the Kaplen Jewish Community Center on the Palisades in Tenafly, and attended a vigil at the Jewish Community Center in Paramus alongside Senator Bob Menendez and congregations from across North Jersey.

I am proud that synagogues and religiously-affiliated nonprofits across the Fifth District clawed back nearly $2 million in grants, including $150,000 for Keter Torah, from the Department of Homeland Security’s Nonprofit Security Grant Program (NSGP). These grants help protect our families and communities from growing threat of anti-Semitism and violent extremism.

The safety and security of our places of worship is a bedrock American value. I am committed to working across party lines to make sure that all Americans can observe their religion free from fear. 

Video from my visit to Congregation Keter Torah can be found HERE.

Demanding Action at Vernon Waste Pile
￼
Dumping potentially contaminated waste next to Vernon's water wells is a threat to our community. I visited the Waste Mountain on Silver Spruce Drive in Vernon with Mayor Harry Shortway, Freeholder Herb Yardley, and other town officials to survey the site and document my findings to send back to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). Simple testing of the waste mountain would provide critical information on its safety for the community.

We need discrete environmental testing, which I believe is necessary to assess any chemical compounds or contamination. I’ve written to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the Governor’s office because a simple test could prove if the water is safe. The people of Vernon deserve an answer. 

I am very concerned for the safety and health of the residents of Vernon, and I will continue to fight for their clean water by pushing officials in New Jersey and Washington to deal with these ongoing potential public health issues.

A copy of my letter to Catherine McCabe, Commissioner of the New Jersey DEP, can be found HERE.

A video of my visit can be found HERE. 



Running and Raising for Charity for Thanksgiving at Upper Saddle River 5K
￼
On Thanksgiving morning, before digging into a great turkey dinner with my family, I joined more than 2,000 runners for the 20th annual Upper Saddle River 5K Run. The event benefited the Upper Saddle River Ambulance Corps and the Upper Saddle River Fire Department, as well as local charities like the Boys and Girls Club, the Center for Hope and Safety, the Upper Saddle River Education Fund, and the “Extra Mile” Scholarship Foundation.

This time of year, we should all be thinking about what we can do for others. This race was a great way to make an impact on our community. It was great to see everyone coming out on Thanksgiving morning to show their support for these important causes.

Thank you to the Upper Saddle River Police Department and the Fire Department for giving up their time on Thanksgiving morning to make sure runners were safe and the race went smoothly. 
￼



Accepting “Legislator of the Year” Honor from the New Jersey State PBA
￼
Earlier this month, I was proudly received Legislator of the Year award from the 33,000 members of the New Jersey State Police Benevolent Association (PBA).

Our police officers are heroes. They deserve our deep appreciation for their work and deserve our full support for everything they do to protect our communities from crime and Lone Wolf terror.

That’s why I will continue to do everything I can in Congress to make sure our law enforcement and first responders have the resources they need to keep us safe and keep themselves safe, including clawing back more of our federal tax dollars for our first responders.

More information on the work I’m doing in Congress to have the backs of our law enforcement and first responders can be found HERE. 



Helping Out the Applebee’s Lunch Rush on my ‘Josh on the Job’ Tour

I joined the staff at Applebee’s in Paramus to wait and bus tables for lunch as part of my “Josh on the Job” Tour. 

Applebee’s in Paramus has been a neighborhood institution since opening in 1994. With great food and a welcoming staff, Applebee’s also provides a great opportunity for how so many in our country to get their first job or their start in a small business.

There is nothing small about the impact of small businesses on the North Jersey economy. They’re the key to strong economic growth. In Congress, I will continue to fight to lower taxes, cut red tape, and invest in New Jersey infrastructure, so that small businesses like Applebee’s can come, stay, and thrive here.

￼



You can keep in touch with me and my office by ‘liking’ my Facebook page and following me on YouTube, Twitter, and Instagram.

Know someone else who should get these updates? Forward this email to them and encourage them to click HERE to sign up.

Got something on your mind? You can always send me an email HERE or request a meeting HERE.

Yours,

Josh

￼

Subject: Congresswoman Beatty Hosts Community Leaders Forum Recognizing the Power of One
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Congresswoman Beatty Hosts Community Leaders Forum Recognizing the Power of One 
Beatty led effort to make Buckeye State first in the nation to recognize “Rosa Parks Day”
 Last night, U.S. Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03) held her Community Leaders Forum, “Footsteps: We All Have a Role to Play.” The Forum recognizes the courage and legacy of “the Mother of the Modern Civil Rights Movement,” and provides an important venue to discuss the "Power of One," its continuing importance to Central Ohio and the nation, as well as on the legislative work of the upcoming 116th Congress. Special guests Andrea Davis Pinkney, author of Boycott Blues: How Rosa Parks Inspired a Nation; Joanna Pinkerton, President and CEO of the Central Ohio Transit Authority (COTA); Andrew Ginther, Mayor of the City of Columbus; and Dr. Michael Drake, President of The Ohio State University, joined Beatty at the Forum held at the Fawcett Event Center Auditorium. 
 
“Rosa Parks forever changed the world. She was the embodiment of the ‘Power of One,’” Beatty said. “Her life and actions on that historic December day is a touchstone moment for me and so many Americans—not to mention people across the world. By sitting down, Rosa Parks stood up for what is right and just.” Beatty continued, “It is our collective responsibility to honor Rosa Parks and the ‘Power of One’ by following in her footsteps. We all have a role to play."
 
Ginther, Drake, Pinkerton, and Pinkney echoed Beatty’s message, highlighting how they too are walking in the footsteps of Rosa Parks and living the “Power of One.” During the Forum, Ginther made a surprise announcement that High Street, between Broad and Gay Streets, would be renamed “Rosa Parks Way” in honor of Parks and to celebrate the kickoff of the 15-year anniversary of Ohio’s Rosa Parks Day.
 
Beatty’s Community Leaders Forum coincides with the State of Ohio’s annual observance of “Rosa Parks Day,” a statewide tribute first conceived by then-State Representative Joyce Beatty. In 2005, Beatty wrote, advocated, and won unanimous support for a bill to designate December 1st as “Rosa Parks Day” in the Buckeye State. Her piece of legislation was signed into law by former Governor Bob Taft and made the State of Ohio the first state in the nation to recognize “Rosa Parks Day.” 
￼
(Left to Right) Bexley Mayor Ben Kessler, Columbus Mayor Andrew Ginther, Congresswoman Joyce Beatty, author Andrea Davis Pinkney, COTA President Joanna Pinkerton, and Ohio State President Michael Drake celebrate the dedication of Rosa Parks Way during Beatty’s Community Leaders Forum. (December 3, 2018)

Subject: Apply for a Spring Internship in My Office!
Message:
￼ 
ABOUT  |   HOW CAN I HELP  |   ISSUES  |   LEGISLATION  |   NEWSROOM  |   11TH DISTRICT  |   CONTACT 
￼

Dear Neighbor,

This is just a quick reminder that my office is accepting internship applications for the spring semester until Monday, December 10th! 

Working in a Congressional office can be an incredibly rewarding and exciting experience. An internship provides an excellent opportunity to gain valuable experience, and observe first-hand how our government operates. 

Interns in the Washington office draft constituent correspondence, attend briefings and Congressional hearings, and prepare memoranda for me and members of my staff. Interns in the District Office conduct research, assist with constituent casework and draft correspondence. Interns in both offices assist with answering phones, data entry and general office systems operations. Interns are an important part of my staff.

Interns are accepted throughout the year on a part-time basis, and priority is given to college-level students from the 11th District. Selection is based on an applicant's general office and computer experience, interview, and a short writing sample. Please submit a cover letter, resume and a brief writing sample to the office of your choice.

The application deadline for the spring semester is December 10th. Please email your information to:

Subject: Need Health Coverage? Sign Up Today!
Message:
News from Representative Carson
￼
WEBSITE   |   CONTACT ME
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Forward to a Friend 
Upcoming Events: 
Office Hours in Your Neighborhood 
Where:  Indianapolis Public Library West Indianapolis Branch 1216 S Kappes Street Indianapolis, IN 46221    When:        Thursday, December 6 10:00am - 12:00pm 
  
December 4, 2018  
Dear Friend, 
With less than two weeks left of the open enrollment period to sign up for health coverage, now is the best time to compare plans and find the best one for you. 
Why is it important to get covered?
Health care is expensive. Without coverage, families can face extreme financial burdens for unexpected illnesses and injuries. The cost of a three-day hospital stay averages $30,000. Health coverage helps to ensure that your family can afford a health care emergencies and that one bill will not send you into bankruptcy. 
In addition, the vast majority of those seeking coverage through healthcare.gov qualify for some form of financial assistance. Last year, approximately 80 percent of those using healthcare.gov found plans for $50-$100 per month.  
￼ 
Need help enrolling? Free help is available via healthcare.gov and through a toll-free Consumer Call Center at 1-800-318-2596 where trained operators are available to assist with comparing plans, enrollment applications, and determining eligibility. In addition, you can look for in-person assistance by clicking here. 
There is a shorter enrollment period this year. With the deadline of December 15th fast approaching, please take the time to ensure that the health of your family is prioritized during the upcoming year and enroll in health coverage. 
 
Your friend,  ￼  André
