Subject: Congressman Cook's Newsletter: December 4, 2018
Message:
District Update | December 4, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
CONNECT: 
￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼
Remembering President George H.W. Bush
￼
Statement from Congressman Cook:

"America lost a statesman and true patriot. President Bush spent his entire life in service to our nation. His service began as a naval aviator during World War II and continued as a Congressman, Ambassador, CIA Chief, Vice President, and President. Even after leaving office, Bush continued to serve through his tireless work to raise money for disaster relief and other charitable causes. America will never forget President George H.W. Bush's steadfast leadership and unwavering commitment to our nation." 

On Monday, a eulogy ceremony was held in the Capitol to honor and remember former President George H.W. Bush. Our nation's 41st president is now Lying in State in the Capitol Rotunda until Wednesday, December 5, for the public to come inside and pay respects. A funeral service for President Bush is planned for Wednesday at the Washington National Cathedral before he is flown back home to Texas for a funeral on Thursday at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston. President Bush will then be laid to rest at the site of his presidential library on the campus of Texas A&M University beside his wife of 73 years, Barbara Bush, and daughter Robin, who was 3 years old when she died of leukemia in 1953. President Bush lead an admirable life of service to the American people and will be remembered for generations to come.

￼

Victorville: Veterans' Hiring Event
￼
The Federal Correctional Complex in Victorville, California is currently hiring under the Veterans' Recruitment Appointment (VRA). This expedites the hiring process, allowing applicants to apply for Correctional Officer positions without having to go through USAJobs. If you are a veteran or know a veteran interested in a career with the Federal Bureau of Prisons, the required documents and qualification are listed below.

What to bring:
• Resume with full addresses of employer(s) - Resume must show three years of supervisory experience or one year of law enforcement service
• DD-214 - Member Copy 4 (if separated)
• DD-214 - Member Copy 4
• VA Disability Certificate (if applying as disabled veteran)

Qualifications:
• are in receipt of a campaign badge for service during a war or in a campaign or expedition; OR
• three years of active duty, OR less than 3 years discharges as a disabled veteran, OR
• are in receipt of an Armed Forces Service Medal for participation in a military operation, OR
• are a recently separated veteran (within the last 3 years) AND
• separated under honorable conditions (this means an honorable or general discharge)

The mass hiring event will be held at:
Central Administration Building
13777 Air Expressway Blvd.
Victorville, CA 92394

Subject: Open Enrollment
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
Dear Friend,

Health insurance can protect you when a serious accident or illness occurs and provide preventative care. Did you know that the average cost for a three-day hospital stay is $30,000? Or that a broken leg can cost up to $7,500? Health insurance helps protect you from unexpected costs like these, and coverage could be more affordable than you think.     

November 1st marked the start of HealthCare.gov’s open enrollment period for 2019 coverage.


From now until December 15, you can purchase a plan or renew your coverage through HealthCare.gov. Once you sign up, you will get coverage that starts on January 1, 2019.

Here are four facts you need to know about enrolling in coverage or renewing your coverage:

	•	The open enrollment period for HealthCare.gov for 2019 ends on December 15. The open enrollment period is only 45 days. Beat the rush and sign up early.
	•	Coverage could be more affordable than you think. That’s because financial help is available. During last year’s enrollment period, 8-in-10 people qualified for financial help.
	•	If you had coverage through HealthCare.gov for 2018, make sure to head back to update your information and compare your options for 2019, by December 15. Every year, plans and prices change. You may find a plan that fits you better, for cheaper.
	•	Free help is available. If you have questions about signing up or want to talk through your options with a trained professional, free help is just a call or click away. The Call Center is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week – call 1-800-318-2596. Or visit https://localhelp.healthcare.gov where you will find organizations in your area that have trained enrollment assisters.
Take the time to learn about your options. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact my office.
Remember, I am here to work for you. If you have any questions or concerns please feel free to e-mail me, call my office, or connect with me on Facebook and Twitter.
Sincerely,
￼
Bill Foster
Member of Congress

Subject: Update from Congressman Peter DeFazio: Climate Change, Working Families, Special Counsel, Voter Suppression
Message:
A Message From Congressman Peter DeFazio 
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
 
￼
￼
Update from  
Congressman Peter DeFazio 
   
No More Time to Waste 
In 2016, policymakers at the Paris climate talks commissioned the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) to conduct research on the impact that global warming of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial levels would have on the planet. In October, the IPCC released their alarming findings: we only have twelve years to significantly curb carbon emissions in order ensure that global warming does not exceed 1.5 degrees Celsius. Even a half degree above 1.5 degrees Celsius would considerably worsen droughts, flooding, fires, and other extreme weather events, which in turn would exasperate global poverty, harm public health, damage the economy, spur large migration flows, and cause massive environmental damage that may not be reversible. 
Additionally, thirteen U.S. federal agencies – including the Environmental Protection Agency – jointly published a climate report on November 23. This report, the National Climate Assessment, makes clear that every region of the country is already experiencing the detrimental effects of climate change, and it warns that “[f]uture impacts and risks from climate change are directly tied to decisions made in the present.” The report also predicts that, by the end of this century, global warming will damage the U.S. economy even more than the Great Recession did. The Trump administration released the report on the Friday after Thanksgiving, hoping it would be ignored. President Trump said he didn’t believe his own administration’s findings.  
Despite what President Trump tweets, the IPCC and U.S. reports cannot be ignored. I have long believed and emphatically stated that climate change is an existential threat to the planet. We need a bold, dramatic change in policy to address the growing threats. 
In the November election, voters sent Congress a strong message that they demand immediate action to combat climate change. I will support any committee that would implement ambitious new ideas to address the threat of climate change head-on. I look forward to continuing work with my colleagues on an agenda that includes a massive federal investment in new technologies, a radical reduction in greenhouse gasses, and other bold ideas.
A decade ago I was one of the first sponsors of a bill to cap, regulate, and reduce emissions. I was also an original member of the first Climate Change Caucus in the House. But with climate deniers still in control in the White House and Senate, we need renewed energy and activism to achieve real change. You can be sure I will continue to do everything in my power to advance effective legislation that reduces carbon emissions and other greenhouse gasses.
  
Fighting for Working Families 
Earlier this week, General Motors announced plans to eliminate 14,000 jobs, or 15 percent of its workforce, and halt production at four U.S. plants. I am appalled that GM has taken its massive savings from the Republican tax plan, totaling over $500 million, and not only failed to invest in new American jobs but put thousands of hardworking Americans out of work. The federal government has given a wealth of support to GM over the years, from the 2009 auto industry bailout to the recent Republican corporate tax cut costing Americans $1.5 trillion. Yet GM has taken that money and invested it in factories abroad, as well as spent over $10 billion in stock buybacks – double what their recent job cuts will save.
Furthermore, last week House Republicans attempted to push yet another partisan tax package to the House floor, which would have added an additional $53 billion to the deficit this year and made dozens of changes to the poorly written tax law that Republicans pushed through last December. To be clear, I support changes to improve this terrible tax law and provide real relief for hard-working Americans. However, this most recent tax package would do nothing to address the staggering inequality exacerbated by the GOP’s tax law, which was a massive handout to millionaires and huge corporations that left American workers behind and exploded our national debt. If Republicans were serious about addressing the mess they’ve made with their tax law, they would work across the aisle on these technical corrections rather than give another handout to big business.
In fact, another corporate handout could not be more poorly timed. According to a recent report from the St. Louis Federal Reserve, the total wages of American workers are lagging further behind corporate profits than they ever have before. As seen in the graph below, while the two increased evenly from 1947 through 2003, workers’ wages have remained relatively stagnant for the past 15 years while corporate profits have skyrocketed.
￼  
The report shows that workers have become much more productive in recent years, but companies haven’t been sharing their profits with the employees who make them possible. Further, despite rising health-care costs, companies continue to shift more and more of these expenses onto workers. Instead of granting pay raises to workers or improving employee benefits, corporations have selfishly enjoyed their massive $1.5 trillion tax cut by spending $1 trillion in stock buybacks, not to mention the additional funds they have put towards inflating CEO bonuses and sending factories and manufacturing plants abroad.
Meanwhile, American families have paid the price. One in four American families skip doctor visits for fear of medical costs. Low-income families spend half their monthly income on child care. A quarter of workers make less than $10 an hour, below the federal poverty line. Thirty percent of individuals in Lane County alone pay over half of their income on rent.
I oppose the GOP tax law, and I will continue to introduce common-sense fixes to refocus our economy toward supporting working Americans. I also support closing tax loopholes that reward multinational corporations like GM for moving abroad. In fact, while Republicans promised their tax bill would bring jobs back to the U.S., it has instead encouraged multinational corporations to move overseas to avoid paying U.S. taxes. 
That’s why I introduced H.R. 6015, the Per-Country Minimum Act, to require the international tax rate to be applied on a per-country basis and eliminate the Republican tax break that encourages factories to move abroad. Last week, I was pleased that Senate Democrats introduced a companion to my bill. 
We simply cannot afford to enrich corporate interests while working families are struggling to make ends meet. From ensuring manufacturing jobs remain in the United States to supporting tax changes that actually benefit working Americans, you can be sure I will never stop fighting for American families and against corporate greed.
  
Protecting Special Counsel Mueller 
On November 7, President Trump forced Attorney General Jeff Sessions to resign, installing Sessions’ chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker, as Acting Attorney General. Throughout Sessions’ tenure, President Trump made clear that he was unhappy with Sessions’ decision to recuse himself from overseeing Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russia’s attempts to interfere in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Because of Sessions’ recusal, oversight of the Mueller investigation fell to Trump-appointed Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein. 
President Trump’s decision to appoint Whitaker, who has publicly stated his opposition to the Mueller investigation and declared it a “witch hunt,” is a blatant attempt by the president to sideline Rosenstein and undermine the Mueller investigation. So far, Whitaker has yet to recuse himself from the investigation. This is absurd. Special Counsel Mueller must be allowed to complete his investigation free from political influence, including from President Trump.
That’s why I am a cosponsor of H.R. 5476, the Special Counsel Independence and Integrity Act, which would protect Special Counsel Mueller’s investigation by ensuring that the Special Counsel can only be removed by the senior most Department of Justice (DOJ) official not recused from the matter. This legislation would also prevent the president from installing an acting Attorney General who could then fire the Special Counsel at the president’s request. Additionally, if the Special Counsel is fired, H.R. 5476 would provide the Special Counsel with a 10-day window to seek expedited judicial review to determine whether the firing was for good cause. If the judicial panel determines that the firing was not for good cause, the Special Counsel’s removal will not go into effect.
I was pleased to see the Senate version of this legislation pass the Republican-led Senate Judiciary Committee in April. However, while the Committee’s action was a step in the right direction, the bill still needs to pass the full Senate and the House. Encouragingly, Senator Jeff Flake has committed to holding up votes for judicial nominees in the Senate in order to force a vote on this legislation, and House Democrats are currently working to include language to protect the Mueller investigation in the Fiscal Year 2019 spending bill that must pass before Congress adjourns. 
You can be sure I will continue to speak out against Republicans’ dangerous attempts to discredit the Mueller investigation by trying to undermine public trust in our law enforcement and intelligence agencies. 
  
Defending Voting Rights  
and Ending Voter Suppression 
During the recent mid-term elections, contests across several states were plagued by blatant voter suppression efforts, many of which disproportionately affected low-income and minority voters. Voter suppression is an embarrassment to the democratic values we hold in the United States, and they must not be allowed to continue.
Voters should not be forced to wait in line for hours. They should not have to contend with faulty voting machines that break or miscount their votes. They should not be subjected to onerous registration laws that disenfranchise them, such as the suppression efforts against Native American tribes in North Dakota. Yet, voters across the nation face issues like these every Election Day.
In fact, the United States is consistently ranked as having one of the worst levels of electoral integrity of any Western democracy. That’s downright embarrassing. 
Thankfully, in a recent study ranking states by ease of voting, Oregon was ranked number one as the easiest state to vote in. That's why I am a strong supporter of Oregon's system of mail-in ballots and automatic voter registration, which increases voter turnout and eliminates the voter suppression efforts that come with physical polling places and opt-in voter registration.
I believe more states should follow our example, which is why I’m a co-sponsor of the Vote By Mail Act and the Automatic Voter Registration Act. I’m also a co-sponsor of several bills that would protect and improve voting rights across the United States, such as the Voting Rights Advancement Act, the Voter Empowerment Act, and the Redistricting Reform Act.
The right to vote is a foundation of our democracy. I have—and always will—fight for every American citizen to have access to free, fair, and transparent elections. 
 
Sincerely, ￼  Peter DeFazio

Subject: Protecting the Great Lakes
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
As someone who was born and raised in Northeast Ohio, I cherish my memories fishing and swimming in Lake Erie. Knowing the Great Lakes hold a special place in our hearts, Kelly and I made sure to share with our children the beauty and many benefits of the Lakes. 
Aside from the obvious recreational benefits the Lakes offer, the Great Lakes constitute the largest system of surface freshwater on Earth. Our Lakes generate more than 1.5 million jobs and $60 billion in wages annually. Congress must continue to protect this critical resource so our future generations can reap the same benefits. 
In Congress, I am known as the "Great Lakes guy." I am a proud champion of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI). This program provides vital funding to federal agencies and local communities to restore the Great Lakes ecosystem and economic health of the Great Lakes region. The GLRI funds important efforts to combat Harmful Algal Blooms on Lake Erie and keep aquatic invasive species, like Asian carp, out of the Lakes. 
We all know that the Great Lakes are a national treasure. Yet year after year, no matter who is in the White House, funding for the GLRI is either proposed to be slashed or eliminated altogether. After another successful year of securing the full $300 million for the GLRI, I am proud to lead yet another effort to secure robust funding for the GLRI in the upcoming fiscal year. 
Do you support the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and my efforts to preserve and protect our Great Lakes? 
Yes
No
Undecided

Subject: Fall Newsletter NY09
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
About | CONTACT | SERVICES | MEDIA CENTER | LEGISLATION | ISSUES | RESOURCES | STAFF
Congresswoman Yvette D. Clarke  New York's Ninth Congressional District
Fall 2018 Newsletter
Greetings,
Fall recess has been wonderful in New York’s Ninth Congressional District, from connecting with constituents, to visiting local businesses, and attending events across Brooklyn. I am back in Washington to continue my work on behalf of my constituents. Looking ahead to the 116th Congress, we will have one of the most diverse bodies of Congress in our nation's history; a more accurate reflection of our nation and a better representation of the priorities of the American people. I am working with my colleagues to ensure your voices are heard as we tackle issues such as housing, immigration reform, Medicaid and Medicare, and lowering prescription drug prices. As always, I encourage each of you to reach out to my office with any questions or concerns, where my staff can assist you. In this newsletter, you will find the latest legislative updates, as well as recent events and hot-button issues within our community. I am grateful for your continued trust and support.
Yours in Service,
￼
Updates from 'The Hill'
	•	Congresswoman Clarke and Congressional Black Caucus Chairman Cedric Richmond sent a letter to Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen calling upon her to desist from plans to move forward with the DHS proposed public charge rule. This rule would permit the Department of Homeland Security to deny green cards to those who received more than $1,800 in specified government benefits in a given year. These benefits include Temporary Assistance for Needed Families (TANF), Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP), Social Security Income, Medicare, Medicaid, and other programs. Click here to read the letter.  
	•	Congresswoman Clarke is an original co-sponsor of Representative Judy Chu's “No Federal Funds for Public Charge Act” (H.R. 7052), which would block funding for the proposed public charge rule. 
	•	Congresswoman Clarke is a proud original co-sponsor of H. Res 1110 to recognize the week of October 1st-October 8th 2018 as "Smart Cities Week." This resolution would support further research, development and adoption of technology designed to improve efficiency, connectivity, sustainability, and mobility in transportation, infrastructure, and workforce opportunities in American cities. Congresswoman Clarke and Congressman Darrell Issa (CA-49) launched the Congressional Smart Cities Caucus earlier this year to encourage lawmakers engage on smart cities and to think about how technology can improve their constituent's lives.  
	•	November 5, 2018 marked the 50th Anniversary of Shirley Chisholm's historic election to the United States Congress. In Ms. Chisholm’s honor, Congresswoman Clarke joined Congressman Hakeem Jeffries (NY-08) and other members of the New York Delegation to announce H.R. 7170. H.R. 7170 is a bill that would award Shirley Chisholm with the Congressional Gold Medal posthumously. This bill, similar to Congresswoman Clarke's bill, H.R. 4856 and its Senate companion bill S. 2467, would commemorate Shirley Chisholm's life and her contributions to our nation in the U.S. Capitol. Chisholm, the first Black woman and Caribbean-American legislator elected to the United States Congress, created a path for the Congresswoman and over 40 Black women who have served in Congress after her. It’s only fitting that her incredible life and living legacy honored. This bill is supported by the National Urban League, League of Women Voters and Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc., among others. Congresswoman Clarke also introduced a bicameral resolution to honor Shirley Chisholm along with Congresswoman Barbara Lee (CA-13) and Senator Charles Schumer (D-NY). 
***Constituent Highlight***
Constituent, Maria Munyangire has been working with our office since August 2016. She is a mother of two who immigrated to the U.S. from the Democratic Republic of Congo seeking opportunities and a better life. After losing touch with her two sons, who she assumed were deceased, Maria fought through physical and mental health challenges to advocate for her sons. With the help of our office, led by Director of Constituent Services Mary Bishop, Maria was reunited with her sons Dennis and Jerry on October 2nd, 2018. Read her story:
"It feels as though a dream has come true. I haven't seen my boys in nineteen years, since one was two and the other two months old and I thought I would never see them again."
Maria filed for her sons to come to the United States in 2015, but she was having difficulty getting her case expedited. Her lawyer suggested she reach out to the office of her member of Congress, where she first met Mary Bishop. Maria was admittedly broken and a bit hopeless. Her sons were taken and raised by her late husband's family, who changed their names and birthdates to conceal their identity. She had long been diagnosed with depression and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) derived from her experience losing her children in 1999, but recalled the warm environment of the office making her feel comfortable. "I came here crying, not knowing what to do because they were in Kenya, living on the streets with no food and sick with pneumonia. I explained this to the office and they calmed me down and introduced me to Mary Bishop. She told me 'You're in the right place, we will help you get your children.' I didn't believe, but she never stopped encouraging me."

￼ (Mary Bishop, Maria Munyangire, and sons Jerry and Dennis)
With the help of our office, Maria was pointed to resources that would help her case. She was able to use the church community in Kenya to get medical documents for her sons and get documentation regarding her own medical condition to make a case for expedition. Throughout every step, Maria kept in touch with Mary, who she said provided a sense of comfort despite the chaos. "I usually came here whenever there was an update, I would say 'Today I'm going to bother Ms. Mary again'. All the time for two years, I felt like my life was just crying, crying, crying..." Maria was worried that she would not be able to reunite with her sons before the eldest's 21st birthday. "So, I came to Ms. Mary again to bother her. She helped."
Our office made inquiries requesting that Maria's case be expedited by USCIS and by the National Visa Center and was successful. "When [the office] told me my sons got visas, this was a miracle," Maria said through tears, "I was overwhelmed with joy. I was happy and emotional, both together. Once they got visas, I got a little bit stronger, I began to work and with the help of my church and we raised money to get tickets for them Now they're here!" Maria's sons arrived in the United States on October 2nd, two weeks before Dennis' 21st birthday. 
"I know this would not have happened without this office. My son would have turned 21 in Kenya and I would have been hopeless."
Now that they've been reunited, Maria says that she wakes up grateful to be reunited with her sons. When asked what their goals are, Maria stated that she would like to get her High School Equivalency and work toward becoming a nurse. Dennis, 21, would also like to earn his High School Equivalency, get a part-time job to help his mother and ultimately become a stylist because he loves fashion. Jerry, 19, is unsure, but knows he wants to go to school and work. He's just happy to be reunited with his mother.
Our office will continue to work with Ms. Maria Munyangire throughout this life changing transition.
Congresswoman Clarke Presents SSG. Edward Mrozik a Congressional Gold Medal Replica
On March 21st 2018, the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), our nation’s first intelligence agency preceding the CIA, was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal for its service during World War II. There are fewer than 100 living members of this trailblazing organization and one of them is a constituent of the Ninth Congressional District of New York. Congresswoman Clarke was honored to present Staff Sergeant Edward Joseph Mrozik with a replica of the Congressional Gold Medal in honor of his service to our nation as a member of the OSS. Read more here.
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke with Edward Mrozik and Family)
The Congressional Award
The Congressional Award is the United States Congress’ award for young Americans and is Congress’ only charity. The program is non-partisan, voluntary, and non-competitive. Young people may register when they turn thirteen and a half years old and must complete their activities by their 24th birthday. The young people who receive this award represent the very best of our nation and embody the ideals that America was built upon; hard work, commitment, camaraderie, and service to mankind. This year, Congresswoman Clarke served as co-chair for the Congressional Awards in New York where she presented the award to over 30 scholars. Read more here.
￼
(Congresswomen Clarke and Maloney host New York Congressional Award Ceremony)
Emergency Preparedness Training in Crown Heights
Congresswoman Clarke teamed up with the American Red Cross of Greater New York, Assemblywoman Diana C. Richardson (AD-43) and Assemblywoman Jaime R. Williams (AD-59) to host an Emergency Preparedness Training in Crown Heights. Crown Heights has a vibrant and rich history with many historic buildings. These buildings, though beautiful, have not been updated to suit the needs of today's families. These buildings are more susceptible to disasters due to issues like poor ventilation and lack of emergency access points. 
It's important to have an emergency preparedness procedure for your family to plan, execute, and recover from any disaster. For more information about emergency preparedness, please contact our district office. Click here for a full recap of the training. 
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke speaking to attendees at Emergency Preparedness Training)
￼
(Congresswoman Clarke and Brooklyn elected officials at Emergency Preparedness Training)
Washington Highlights
Congresswoman Clarke joined Leader Pelosi, Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Bernie Sanders, and other Members of Congress for National Action Network’s Annual Legislative and Policy Conference in Washington, DC. The Congresswoman discussed priorities for the 116th Congress including lowering prescription drug prices, strengthening the middle-class, affordable housing, and more. 
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke speaking at NAN Conference in Washington, D.C.)
Congresswoman Clarke joined Congresswoman Maxine Waters for a roundtable discussion with student leaders on student civil rights. The Congresswoman is an original cosponsor of the Education Department Civil Rights Transparency Act (H.R.6537). This bill would hold Education Secretary Betsy DeVos accountable for any actions she takes to undermine students' civil rights.
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke and Congresswoman Waters with student leaders)
District Highlights
Youth in the Ninth Congressional District of New York
P.S. 321 Family Friday
Congresswoman Clarke joined P.S. 321 William Penn School for Family Day this year. In addition to meeting with parents and educators, Family Day reaffirms our commitment to fostering an environment where parents, educators, and students play a collective and collaborative role in the development of our youth. Spending some time with our leaders of tomorrow prepares Congresswoman Clarke to be refreshed and renewed as she returns to the hustle and bustle of Washington.
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke with teachers and students at P.S. 321 Family Day)
Girl Scouts Troop 2010
The future is female. Congresswoman Clarke was invited to Girl Scouts Troop 2010's meeting in Sheepshead Bay to talk about what it means to be a woman in Congress. The girls enjoyed a vibrant discussion about their goals and how they can incorporate service into everything they do. From veterinarians to entrepreneurs, to Congress, girls can do anything! A record number of women from diverse backgrounds were elected to Congress, all with the common goal of making a difference on behalf of their constituencies. Maybe one of these troop members will come to Congress one day! 
￼ (Congresswoman Clarke with Girls Scouts from Troop 2010)
 
Meet our 2018-2019 Fellows
￼ Keely Childress
Keely Childress is a legislative fellow for the DC office. She handles the healthcare portfolio, focusing on emerging healthcare problems and innovations in the Brooklyn area. Keely, a former charter school educator and Teach for America corps member, has a Master in Public Health. Her office work includes monitoring activity on issues like the opioid crisis, disease control, Medicare, and nutrition. When she’s not writing speeches or memos for the Congresswoman, she continues to build  relationships with healthcare organizations in Brooklyn.  Keely is always happy to take meetings with constituent groups and health advocacy representatives from Brooklyn.
 
￼ Christopher Cox
Christopher Cox, a Congressional Black Caucus Foundation fellow, has joined the office as our Diversity and Tech Fellow. He is currently supporting the Legislative Director with the Congresswoman’s Energy and Commerce portfolio focusing on the intersection of health and technology. Christopher obtained his Bachelor of Political Science degree and his Master of Public Health Policy and Management degree from Jackson State University.  Christopher is happy to attend committee hearings and help staff plan and execute Congressional briefings. He is a native of Moss Point, MS and will work in the Congresswoman’s office throughout 2019. 
 
Media Corner
112BK with Ashley Ford
Congresswoman Clarke sat down with Ashley Ford of 112BK for an important conversation on the Kavanaugh hearings and what Judge Kavanaugh's U.S. Supreme Court confirmation means for our nation, the Public Charge rule expansion and more. Click to see the full interview (08:55).
￼
 
Interview on Talk Back with Bob Law
Click here to listen to a chat between WBAI Talk Back with Bob Law host, Bob Law and Ann Tripp of WBLS where the three discuss the importance of engaging black communities in politics, changing demographics in Brooklyn and the insurgence of progressive members in government. (00:35:45)
Important Constituent Information
USCIS
Use of Digital Tablets
On Oct. 1, USCIS began using digital tablets to administer the English reading and writing tests during naturalization interviews as part of the agency’s ongoing business modernization efforts. Although USCIS applicants already use digital tablets to sign or verify parts of their applications, this new approach expands tablet usage, allowing the device to be used for a greater portion of the application process. USCIS will continue to use the paper process on a case-by-case basis.
While the eligibility requirements and the subject material of the naturalization test have not changed, applicants are now using a stylus on a digital tablet instead of a paper application. Immigration Services Officers (ISO) will carefully instruct applicants on how to use the tablets before administering the tests:
	•	For the reading test, a sentence will appear on the tablet and the ISO will ask the applicant to read it.
	•	For the writing test, several lines will appear on the tablet, replicating the appearance of a piece of blank paper. The ISO will read a sentence aloud and ask the applicant to write it on the tablet.
Applicants will continue to take the civics test verbally, without the tablet.
 
Pilot Fee Payment Program at Two USCIS Los Angeles Field Offices may come to New York if successful
On Nov. 5, 2018, applicants, petitioners, or other requesters who are paying a filing fee at the Los Angeles Field Office and Los Angeles County Field Office will no longer be able to pay by money orders or cashier’s checks. They can still pay by check, debit card, credit card, or reloadable pre-paid credit or debit cards, which USCIS personnel will process through a new electronic system. USCIS is launching a pilot at these two field offices to test electronic payment processing, which will increase transaction security and reduce processing errors that could cause USCIS to reject applications and petitions. Beyond limiting the kind of payment USCIS will accept through this new system, applicants will not experience a change in how they pay their fees.
This internal transition is part of USCIS’ ongoing efforts to modernize its business practices, allowing USCIS field office staff to process applicants’ payments in a quicker, more secure online system. This will reduce processing errors on applications that would previously have led to rejection for non-payment. It will also increase security and traceability of payments for applicants.
Open Enrollment
￼
 
The Office of Adult and Continuing Education has many new initiatives that will greatly benefit our community: 
- Math and English Literacy focused classes for TASC (HSE) students
- Integrated technology for select English as a Second Language (ESL) classes
- HS transcript evaluation to receive credit for TASC subject area
Please see below and contact our office if you or someone you know is interested in these services.
￼￼
￼
KEEP Healthy event sponsored by the National Kidney Foundation
Sunday, December  2, 2018
12:00 pm - 4:00 pm
￼
What is KEEP Healthy?
The National Kidney Foundation's community-based initiative to educate communities about the kidneys, risk factors for kidney disease, and steps to take to keep kidneys healthy and reduce risk.
What does the KEEP Healthy Check-up include?
- Risk Survey
- Body Mass Index (BMI): Height and Weight Measurements
- Blood pressure check
- ACR urine test for albumin (a type of protein) – For individuals at risk only!
- Free educational materials
- Opportunity to speak with a health care professional
 
Who is at Increased risk for Kidney Disease?
- Anyone with high blood pressure, diabetes
- Anyone with a family history of kidney failure
- African-Americans, Hispanics, Asians, Pacific Islanders and American Indians
- Anyone age 60 and older
- Individuals who are obese (body mass index of 30 or above)

SHARE YOUR STORY
General Motor's decision to close the Lordstown plant has sent shockwaves throughout Northeast Ohio. The ripple effect of this has impacted families, friends, neighbors, and our community as a whole. 

Over the next few weeks, my mission is to show Congress, President Trump, and the American people how important GM Lordstown is to us and our community. I want you to share your stories with me so I can take them to Washington. With your help, the voice of our community will be heard.

Subject: Computer Science Education Week
Message:
News from Representative Tom Emmer
￼

Dear Friend, 
This week is Computer Science Education Week!  
STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) fields will only continue to grow in our workforce. In fact, today 58% of all new jobs are in computing.  
We must encourage the next generation to explore and innovate in order to meet the demands of future economy’s needs that we cannot yet predict. 
Since its inception, my office has participated in the Congressional App Challenge to encourage middle and high school students to develop their own software application (or, an “app”).   
Congratulations to this year’s Congressional App Challenge winners from Central Middle School in Norwood Young America: Josie Beneke, Kourtney Harms, Emma Hecksel, and Lauren Schmidt! 
Their app, ‘Lose it!’ is designed to manage the user’s weight. Those that use the app receive diet and exercise tips targeted towards weight loss. The app would also provide organic recipes and at-home exercises specifically for each unique user.  
Students like Josie, Kourtney, Emma and Lauren keep our nation moving forward to meet the needs of tomorrow’s workforce. Congratulations to these young Minnesotans! I look forward to seeing what they do in the future.  
Sincerely, 
￼
Learn more about the Congressional App Challenge here.

Subject: Last Chance to Apply for Federal Disaster Assistance
Message:
￼ 
  

￼
The deadline to apply for federal disaster assistance & low-interest disaster loans is tomorrow,
December 5th. 
If you suffered damage or losses from Hurricane Florence and need help rebuilding, funding may be available to help you recover. Homeowners, renters, and business owners have until December 5th to apply for assistance through FEMA and the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA). You can apply in the following ways: 
	•	Call FEMA at 800-621-3362 or 800-462-7585(TTY). Call the SBA at 800-659-2955 or 800-877-8339(TTY).
	•	Go online to DisasterAssistance.gov or DisasterLoan.sba.gov.
	•	Visit any open State/FEMA Disaster Recovery Center. Find one near you: www.fema.gov/DRC.
	•	Send an e-mail to disastercustomerservice@sba.gov.
Although funding is limited and priority will go towards those most in need, I encourage everyone to apply to see if you are eligible for federal assistance. If you have any questions, contact my Grand Strand office, Pee Dee office, or Washington D.C. office. We are here to help!

Sincerely,
￼
Tom Rice

Subject: Manistique, Bessemer Receive Major Federal Grants For Water Infrastructure Upgrade
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Dec 4, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158


Over $28 Million in Federal Grants and Loans Announced For Water Infrastructure Upgrade in Manistique and Bessemer

Marquette -Today Congressman Jack Bergman announced $21 million in federal grants, and nearly $8 million in federal loans to replace water and sewage systems in Gogebic and Schoolcraft counties. Congressman Bergman released the following statement and information:

"Clean water is essential to the well-being of Michiganders and water quality remains a concern for families throughout the First District of Michigan. This major investment by USDA in water infrastructure in Gogebic and Schoolcraft Counties is encouraging as we seek to ensure access to safe water throughout the state," said Bergman. "These grant dollars will be spent replacing miles of water systems that date back to the early 1900's. I appreciate the Administration's continued investment in rural communities water infrastructure."

USDA State Director Jason Allen noted, "Michigan residents are rightly concerned about ensuring water quality. These projects continue USDA’s historic investments in the health and future well-being of our rural communities."

Eligible communities and water districts can apply online on the interactive RD Apply tool, or they can apply through one of USDA Rural Development’s state or field offices.

The Project Announcements Can Be Found Below:

City of Manistique $4.8 million grant, $1.6 million loan.

City of Manistique $1.9 million grant, $638,000 loan.

City of Bessemer $7.8 million grant, $2.6 million loan.

City of Bessemer $8.2 million grant, $2.7 million loan.
bergman.house.gov  
###

Subject: Remembering 41
Message:
￼
Remembering 41
Dear Friends,

This weekend, Dee Dee and I joined the entire Nation in mourning the passing of George H.W. Bush, an American patriot who served our country in capacities few others can ever claim: warrior, lawmaker, ambassador, Intelligence Chief, Vice President, and 41st President of the United States. His entire life embodied service to others, and he leaves behind a remarkable legacy of character and decency, especially in the manner in which he befriended political foes, reminding Americans that there is always more that unites us than divides us. 

Beyond his service to our country and alongside his beloved wife Barbara, President Bush was a tremendous father and role model for every American. As we remember his extraordinary life this week and honor him with a National Day of Mourning on Wednesday, I hope that we can all embody his spirit of service and his love for country and family. If you are in the Washington, D.C. area and would like to pay your respects, the U.S. Capitol Rotunda will be open to the public via the Capitol Visitor Center (CVC) from Monday, December 3, 2018 at 7:30 p.m. until 7:00 a.m. on Wednesday, December 5, 2018. Please feel free to contact my D.C. office at (202) 225-4101 if you have any further questions. 

Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Bush family as they mourn the passing of a true statesman. May his wise words remind us of the importance of public service, volunteerism, and charity: “No problem of human making is too great to be overcome by human ingenuity, human energy, and the untiring hope of the human spirit.”
￼

Committee Action
Last week in committee, the House Oversight and Government Reform (OGR) Committee tackled a few major issues. On Wednesday, we examined policies at the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and discussed how to form prison programs that contribute to the successful transition from inmate to civilian life. 

Unfortunately, systemic abuse is running rampant throughout the BOP, and its leadership is filled with bad actors, abuse, misconduct, and whistleblower intimidation. I was glad to have the opportunity to speak with Inspector General Michael Horowitz on his findings within the BOP. Click here to watch me speak with IG Horowitz and Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons Hugh Hurwitz. 
￼

The following day, OGR held another hearing to discuss the effects and response of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in the wake of the 2017 hurricane season. With Georgia having been hit hard by many of these storms, I was happy to hear from FEMA Administrator William “Brock” Long on the status of ongoing assistance. Our state still has many counties, farmers, and other individuals reeling from hurricanes like Harvey, Irma, and Maria, and I was encouraged by Administrator Long’s words and work in the face of these and other storms. Click here to watch me question Long on his preparation and future disaster response plans.
￼

National Bible Week 
In celebration of National Bible Week, last Wednesday, I spoke on the House Floor about the impact of faith on my daily life as a pastor, a citizen, and a policymaker. I wholeheartedly believe that it is vitally important to recognize the essential role the Bible has played in the development of the history and culture of America and the world. I encourage you to listen to my remarks below. 
￼

Hice Helpers
Since coming to office, I’m proud that my team has hosted successful Mobile Office Hours events throughout each of the 25 counties that I represent. Holding these meetings in every corner of the district has provided another great opportunity to meet with local residents, elected officials, businesses, and organizations to hear what’s on their minds with regard to the Peach State and our Nation as a whole. These events provide you the chance to sit down with a member of my team to discuss your concerns, share their priorities, or seek help with a federal agency. 

This month, my constituent service representatives will be at the Greene County Chamber of Commerce on December 13th from 10:00 a.m. until noon and the AMVETS Post 10 in Athens on December 19th from 10:30 a.m. until 12:30 p.m. for those seeking assistance. I’m proud to have knowledgeable members of my team available to meet with you on a one-on-one basis to assist you during these upcoming events.
￼

More Holiday Safety Tips
The holidays are known for time spent with the family. Whether you are out of town or at home for the holidays, it’s important to make sure you are taking the proper precautions when it comes to keeping your home safe. Nothing is worse than an unexpected fire due to the improper use of your holiday decorations. Make sure not to overcrowd your outlets when you are plugging in those Christmas lights, keep any flammable objects away from your fireplace, furnace, or space heater, and securely place your tree in an area that is far enough away from causing any damage if it were to fall.

It only takes a few easy steps to protect your home this season. To add that extra layer of protection and give you the peace of mind you need during this busy time, I encourage you to read more tips about holiday travel, cooking, fire safety, and communication courtesy of ready.gov.
￼

The Week Ahead
For millions of people around the world who practice Judaism, Sunday marked the first night of Hanukkah. This beautiful celebration is manifested through public lightings of a menorah, oftentimes in public parks or outside synagogues in our neighborhoods. This year, after so much tragedy in Pittsburgh, I am certain that seeing the warm light of the menorah after the sun sets will be a heartening and uplifting inspiration. In America, there is the certain truth that we can come together to recognize and appreciate how faith, family, friends, and special traditions can bring light to the world. If you are celebrating Hanukkah or if you have friends and family who are, I wish you peace and joy this holiday season.  In the wake of President George H.W. Bush’s passing, the House has postponed votes and legislative business until Monday, December 10, 2018.   As always, I’m here to serve you. Please contact my office with any questions, comments, or concerns. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to keep track of upcoming legislation and events!  Sincerely, 
￼


FOLLOW US
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 

￼ 

￼ 

TOP NEWS
Mortality and Morality in America Patriot Post – 11/30 What do parking lots have to do with the new tax amendment? An awful lot if you’re a nonprofit. For the first time in history, charities and churches are being taxed over the benefits they offer their employees — like free parking or transportation. Most people didn’t know about the change, which was buried in last year’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. But now that they do, hundreds of organizations have called on Congress to fix it. And thanks to congressmen like Kevin Brady (R-Texas), House Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.), Mark Walker (R-N.C.), Jody Hice (R-Ga.), and Vicky Hartzler (R-Mo.), they are.
Guard departs Milledgeville for mission in Afghanistan Union-Recorder – 11/26 Hice said what makes the guard so phenomenal is that the governor or the president can call on them at a moment’s notice and they are ready.  “Every one of us just wants to say that our hats are off to you,” Hice said. “God bless you as you are about to be deployed and also for so many families who are here. Thank you, as well. Of course, November is the appreciation month for our families of our military. And you, likewise, know what service is all about. “Our prayers are with you,” Hice said. “And may God bless you in the task before you, and while you’re away, God bless your families.”
All 14 Members of Georgia Congressional Delegation Sign Letter Requesting Natural Disaster Relief All On Georgia – 11/27 The entire Georgia Congressional delegation has signed on to a letter sent to Speaker Paul Ryan and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi requesting legislative action in the next week and a half for the part of the state impacted by Hurricane Michael in October. The letter is also addressed to the chairman and ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee. When Hurricane Michael hit Georgia, it was still a Category 3 hurricane – the first to hit Georgia directly since the 1890s. The losses total more than $2 billion. The letter is signed by Austin Scott, Sanford D. Bishop, Earl L. ‘Buddy’ Carter, Dr. A. Drew Ferguson IV, Henry C. “Hank” Johnson Jr., John Lewis, Karen Handel, Rob Woodall, Doug Collins, Jody Hice, Barry Loudermilk, Rick W. Allen, David Scott and Tom Graves.

All 14 Members of Georgia Congressional Delegation Sign Letter Requesting Natural Disaster Relief All On Georgia – 11/27 The entire Georgia Congressional delegation has signed on to a letter sent to Speaker Paul Ryan and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi requesting legislative action in the next week and a half for the part of the state impacted by Hurricane Michael in October. The letter is also addressed to the chairman and ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee. When Hurricane Michael hit Georgia, it was still a Category 3 hurricane – the first to hit Georgia directly since the 1890s. The losses total more than $2 billion. The letter is signed by Austin Scott, Sanford D. Bishop, Earl L. ‘Buddy’ Carter, Dr. A. Drew Ferguson IV, Henry C. “Hank” Johnson Jr., John Lewis, Karen Handel, Rob Woodall, Doug Collins, Jody Hice, Barry Loudermilk, Rick W. Allen, David Scott and Tom Graves.

Subject: Protecting Our Communities from Catastrophic Fires
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼ 
Dear Friend, 

Like you, I’ve followed with horror the wildfires that burned across California for the month of November. While they are finally contained, the Woolsey, Hill, Sierra, and Camp Fires destroyed tens of thousands of homes and acres, and far too many lives. More than two dozen people are still missing, and a staggering 88 people were killed. Even as we grieve with our neighbors in California, terrifying flash floods are causing even more damage. 

My heart goes out to all of those who have been affected, and I am tremendously grateful to the first responders and firefighters, including Oregonians, who have worked tirelessly to protect communities from the wrath of these catastrophic fires. Their bravery and courage is making a huge difference each day. 

In addition to on-the-ground emergency efforts, we need long-term strategies to limit the impacts of these violent fires. As our climate continues to warm, larger and more severe wildfires will break out more easily—and that means we can’t just rely on the same old fire prevention strategies. We need guaranteed funding and a massive effort to put people to work thinning our forests and making them more fire-resilient in order to stop cataclysmic wildfires—and barely-breathable air—from becoming a staple of western summers and autumns. 

That’s why I introduced the Wildfire-Resilient Communities Act, which would create a $1 billion fund to provide stability and allow the U.S. Forest Service to speed up and broaden the scale of its response to catastrophic wildfires. The bill also includes a permanent reauthorization of the Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Program—which has proven effective in limiting fires in Oregon—as well as the creation of a County Stewardship Fund to provide counties with payments proportionate to the amount of federal land they contain. 

Communities are in dire need of the proper resources to protect themselves from these disastrous fires. Please know that I stand with communities at risk, and will continue fighting to fund the programs that keep them safe. 

All my best, 
Jeff 
￼ 
￼

Here are some of the ways women made strides in 2018  Vox Women around the world achieved some concrete accomplishments this year. Here’s a list.  Solemn public pays tribute as Bush lies in state in Rotunda  The Associated Press Members of the public lined up before sunrise to pay their respects as an honor guard stood watch beside Bush’s casket in the cavernous Capitol Rotunda, open until Wednesday’s funeral.   Outlook for trade deals is unclear  The Washington Post Uncertainty surrounds White House agreements on trade with China, North America.  Trump’s China Truce Calms Markets, but He Chooses a Hard-Liner to Lead Talks  The New York Times Even as the president cast farmers and automakers as major beneficiaries of the truce, confusion and deep divisions between the two countries posed threats to a final deal.   CIA Director Gina Haspel to Brief Senators Tuesday on Saudi Journalist’s Death  The Wall Street Journal CIA Director Gina Haspel will brief Senate leaders Tuesday on Jamal Khashoggi’s death at the hands of Saudi operatives. Several senators criticized the Trump administration after she was absent from an earlier briefing.  Congress agrees to push back shutdown deadline  The Washington Post Congress agrees to put off government shutdown deadline to Dec. 21.  Why We Sleep, and Why We Often Can’t  The New Yorker Does our contemporary obsession with sleep obscure what makes it special in the first place?  How to Connect Young People to Europe? Let Them See It All by Train  The New York Times Much has changed in the 46 years since Interrail pass was introduced, but the essence of what it offers — experiencing new cultures and meeting new people — has remained the same.   NASA spacecraft arrives at ancient asteroid, its 1st visitor  The Associated Press CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. — After a two-year chase, a NASA spacecraft arrived Monday at the ancient asteroid Bennu, its first visitor in billions of years.  The 50 Best Albums of 2018  NPR The best albums of 2018 are full of surprises: a cascade of discoveries, revelations and artistic rebirths.

Dear Friend,

We are here to help you recover and rebuild from Harvey's devastation. Federal money is allocated through the Texas General Land Office for distribution. If you owned your home that was damaged or destroyed by Harvey, and it was your primary place of residence, you are potentially eligible for the Homeowner Assistance Program. Applications are being considered on a first-come, first-serve basis.

The application may be found at: recovery.texas.gov/individuals/programs/homeowner-assistance/gulf-coast/index.html

You may fill out the application and mail it to the Homeowner Assistance Program office or schedule an appointment to drop it off.

Homeowner Assistance Program offices in the HGAC-E/Gulf Coast Region:

Subject: Honoring the Legacy of Our 41st President
Message:
News from Martha Roby
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼ 
Friends, 
This week, our nation joins together to mourn the passing of our 41st President, George H.W. Bush. He was a remarkable American who served this country honorably. He will be dearly missed. My prayers are with the Bush family during this time.
HURRICANE MICHAEL DISASTER LOAN CENTERS OPEN 
As we continue our Hurricane Michael recovery efforts, a number of resources are available to residents of Alabama’s Second District. The Small Business Administration opened two disaster loan centers to help Alabama business, homeowners, and residents impacted by the storm file paperwork locally. The centers will be open in Gordon and Slocomb through December 8th. You can find more information including locations and hours from the Dothan Eagle. 
UPDATES FROM THE COTTON INDUSTRY 
￼ 
Last Wednesday, I had a very productive meeting with members of the National Cotton Council. We discussed a number of issues facing the cotton industry, including rebuilding efforts after the devastation caused by Hurricane Michael. I assured them that I will continue to fight for those impacted. Thank you for stopping by!   As always, if you or your neighbors need help moving forward in the wake of Hurricane Michael, please contact one of my offices. My staff and I serve you, and we are engaged in this recovery process.   MARION MILITARY ACADEMY PRESIDENT VISITS DC 
 ￼ 
Marion Military Academy President Col. David J. Mollahan also visited my office last week. I always enjoy hearing about the exciting developments on campus. Thank you for meeting with me!   MEETING WITH FORT RUCKER'S INTERNATIONAL MILITARY STUDENTS 
 ￼ 
International military students from Fort Rucker stopped by my office as well. I always enjoy meeting with this group and hearing about their diverse backgrounds and views. These students are from many different countries across the globe including Brazil, Jordan, Indonesia, Taiwan, and Turkey. Thank you for meeting with me, and thank you for your service!   CELEBRATING ROSA PARKS DAY 
This past weekend, Alabama celebrated our first Rosa Parks Day. The City of Montgomery hosted a series of events honoring her legacy, including free Rosa Parks Museum admission. I believe this annual day of observance will serve as an important opportunity for our state to pay tribute to Rosa Parks and her bravery.  THIS WEEK IN WASHINGTON 
The House will be back in session next week with a number of agenda items to complete before the end of the year. The Farm Bill Conference Committee announced last week they have "reached agreement in principle on the 2018 Farm Bill." I'm very glad to see momentum towards finalizing this important legislation that farmers across our state and country depend on. 
You can stay up to date on my work in Congress via Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.          
It is an honor to serve you in Congress. Please never hesitate to let me know if there is a way my office can be of assistance.   Sincerely,  
￼  Martha Roby 
Member of Congress

￼￼ 

Kansas Common Sense  December 3, 2018
Hello,
 
Welcome to “Kansas Common Sense.” Thanks for your continued interest in receiving my weekly newsletter. Please feel free to forward it on to your family and friends if it would interest them.
Honoring the Life and Service of President George H.W. Bush President George H.W. Bush was a steadfast defender of freedom and liberty, from his time in the United States Navy to his many years of service in Congress, as vice president, and as our country’s 41st president. Our nation is grateful for his leadership through periods of conflict and uncertainty around the world. President Bush was a family man whose legacy of faith and service will live on. Robba and I offer our sincerest condolences to the Bush family and we pray that President Bush has been reunited with Barbara, his wife of 71 years, in Heaven.
Hosting NASA Administrator and NASA Astronaut for STEM Events in Kansas
On Saturday, I was honored to host NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine in South Central Kansas for a number events related to the aerospace industry in Kansas. During this visit, Administrator Bridenstine was able to clearly see our collective, vested interest in advancing the aviation and aerospace sectors and educating and training the next generation of STEM leaders and professionals.
Touring the National Institute of Aviation Research On Saturday morning, our first stop was at Wichita State University’s Innovation Campus where we toured the National Institute of Aviation Research (NIAR). Here, Administrator Bridenstine was able to see the innovative and groundbreaking work being done by Wichita State students and faculty to support the aerospace industry. WSU is a world-class example in educating students interested in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) with real-world, hands-on learning. 
 ￼ 
Hosting an Event for Students Interested in STEM and Space Exploration Following our tour at NIAR, we were at Exploration Place in Wichita were I hosted an event for students interested in careers and topics in STEM, space exploration and more. During this event, I was honored to be joined by Administrator Bridenstine as well as NASA Astronaut Don Pettit. We heard from Astronaut Pettit on his path to becoming an astronaut and the many expeditions he’s been a part of. I would like to thank CEO of WSU Tech Sheree Utash for moderating a panel discussion on opportunities in STEM, and the panelists for participating including Administrator Bridenstine, Astronaut Pettit, Superintendent of Wichita Public Schools Alicia Thompson and CEO of IdeaTek and Mayor of Buhler Daniel Friesen. 
One of my primary goals as a Senator is to create an environment in Kansas where young people who are interested in similar careers can receive a quality education and have robust career opportunities in Kansas following graduation. Events like this are important as we work to inspire and train the next generation of scientists, astronauts, researchers and more. 
 ￼ 
Attending Earthrising: The Celebration of Apollo 8 Saturday evening, following an afternoon tour of the Kansas Cosmosphere, it was an honor to speak at the 50th anniversary celebration of the Apollo 8 mission in Hutchinson. The honored guests included Apollo astronauts Jim Lovell, Walt Cunningham, Charlie Duke, Fred Haise, Jack Lousma and Harrison Schmitt. To so many of us, NASA astronauts like the distinguished few who came to Hutchinson this weekend are genuine American heroes. 
It always strikes me as I drive across Kansas when I see signs declaring the hometown of an astronaut. Astronaut Nick Hague, an extraordinary young man from Hoxie, will become the 4th Kansan in space this spring. He follows Steve Hawley of Ottawa, who flew five Space Shuttle missions, and Apollo-era astronauts Ron Evans of Topeka and Joe Engle of Chapman. One astronaut who didn’t fly in space but still made history was Kansas City, Kansas, native Captain Edward Dwight, who in 1963 became the first African American named to the astronaut program. Kansas has always had a pioneering spirit, and that was exemplified Saturday by our astronauts, engineers and manufacturers who contribute to the future of NASA space travel. Thank you to Jim Remar and Mimi Meredith for your leadership at the Cosmosphere, and for putting together a memorable event celebrating the Apollo 8 mission. 
 ￼ 
Finally, I want to thank NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine for making the effort to not only be here in Hutchison, but for his sincere interest in seeing firsthand how Kansans are making a difference in advancing space and science education, and for expressing NASA’s unequivocal desire to partner with Kansas. 
Chairing FTC Oversight Hearing on Data Privacy As chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Data Security, I held an oversight hearing of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) on Tuesday. In the subcommittee’s first hearing with all five new FTC commissioners since their confirmation this spring, we heard about efforts to meet their broad mandate to protect consumers from unfair and deceptive trade practices. The independent agency’s consumer protection mission includes protecting consumers from everything from robocalls, ticket bots, data breaches and beyond; and enforcing laws such as the Consumer Review Fairness Act, Fair Credit Reporting Act, and the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act.  
The discussion also included what federal consumer data privacy legislation should look like; as the main federal data privacy and security enforcer, the FTC’s input was valuable for our efforts to create a meaningful bipartisan bill. I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues and the FTC to protect consumers from unfair and deceptive business practices and anti-competitive behavior. To watch my opening statement, click here. To watch my questioning, click here. 
￼ 
Update on the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) On Friday morning, President Trump joined Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto at the G20 Summit to sign the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement – a positive development for the country. This is a step in the right direction and should inspire the purchasers of our products, as well as those around the world, that America will continue to be a reliable supplier of top-line goods. I look forward to taking this agreement up in Congress where we can discuss its many provisions. 
Over the past year and a half, I have expressed directly and repeatedly to President Trump, Ambassador Lighthizer, Secretary Ross and my colleagues that we need more trade, not less. I have been clear that both Canada and Mexico – Kansas’ top two export markets – must be part of any final agreement. I appreciate the administration working to make certain these markets remain available to Kansas farmers, ranchers and manufacturers, providing them some much-needed certainty. 
Dedicating a Memorial to the Women of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion I was honored to take part in a ceremony on Friday for the dedication of a monument honoring the soldiers of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion. The memorial was designed and funded by the Buffalo Soldier Educational and Historical Committee and is now located in its permanent home in the Buffalo Soldier Memorial Park on Fort Leavenworth. The legacy of the 6888th is unique and special as the only all-female, all African-American unit in the Women’s Army Corps deployed overseas during World War II. I was particularly honored to meet several members of the 6888th who attended the ceremony – their continued commitment to their unit and their comrades inspires me and many. In recognition of their service, strength and sacrifice, I introduced Senate Resolution 412 in February honoring the members of this unit, which passed the Senate unanimously in October.  
 ￼
Breaking Ground on New Facilities for the 35th Infantry Division at Fort Leavenworth On Friday, I also participated in the combined groundbreaking ceremony for two major National Guard construction projects on Fort Leavenworth: the 35th Infantry Division Readiness Center and the Mission Training Complex Barracks. I was honored to be joined by Director of the Army National Guard Lieutenant General Timothy Kadavy and Kansas National Guard Adjutant General Major General Lee Tafanelli as we marked the occasion and all that it means for Fort Leavenworth.   
As a member of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Construction, Veterans Affairs and Related Agencies, I worked to fund over $51 million for both of the projects, which will increase the readiness of our Army National Guard in Kansas and Missouri. I’m pleased these projects are entering the construction phase and look forward to visiting them when they are complete. 
 ￼ 
Announcing Kansas Projects from the Army Corps of Engineers Work Plan In a big win for Kansas and the long-term sustainability of our water resources and infrastructure, two key projects were included in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers recently-announced work plan for FY2019. The first, funding for the Kansas River Reservoirs and Sediment Study, is one of only six new studies across the country that sets the stage for future Army Corps projects to systematically address key areas of need and risk of our 18 federal reservoirs in the Kansas River Basin and associated water resources. I’ve advocated for this study and it’s funding in 2016 and 2017, and I’m pleased to see this project launch in the coming fiscal year. 
The second, $18.5 million in federal funding for a flood protection project in Manhattan, is one of only five new construction projects across the country and is a critical development to protecting people in the Manhattan community for generations to come. I worked to include this authorization in the 2016 Water Resources Development Act, and it’s inclusion in the work plan is good news for many in the Manhattan region. 
Kansas depends on Corps of Engineers’ lakes for roughly 60 percent of its municipal and industrial water supply needs. These projects we championed will help secure the future of our water supply across a significant portion of the state and make certain our federal reservoirs and rivers can continue to support the fast growing populations near them with flood protection. To read more about these projects, click here. 
Voting to Assert Congressional Authority Over the Saudi-led War in Yemen It’s Congress’s constitutional responsibility to authorize when the American military engages in war. On Wednesday, I voted in favor of S.J. Res 54, a joint resolution denying American military involvement in the Saudi-led war in Yemen without Congressional approval. The passage of this resolution should help force a diplomatic resolution on the nearly four-year-long war and reduce the humanitarian crisis where 14 million Yemenis are on the brink of death from starvation. 
This isn’t the first time I’ve advocated for this measure. In March, I was one of five Republicans who voted to proceed to consideration of S. J. Res. 54, which failed 55-44. I have repeatedly expressed concern to the administration regarding the humanitarian impact of the siege of Hudaydah, Yemen, and have questioned the certification of Saudi compliance with American law. 
Speaking at Judge Holly Teeter’s Investiture Ceremony On Friday, I had the privilege of offering remarks at Judge Holly Teeter’s investiture in Lawrence, following her appointment and Senate confirmation to a seat on United States District Court in Kansas this fall. I met Judge Teeter for the first time when her name was put forward for the nomination – she is a person full of character, honesty and integrity. Coming into this position without a political agenda, Judge Teeter has a deep understanding of the job: to interpret the law as written and make sound decisions based upon the circumstances of each case. Judge Teeter will be a tremendous judge for the state of Kansas. 
Release of a Report on Veterans and Toxic Exposures This week, the National Academies of Sciences Committee on Gulf War and Health released a report that fulfills a mandate in my Toxic Exposure Research Act, which became law in December 2015. Their report confirmed what I have long believed and fought to rectify – that there are significant gaps in research related to the impacts of toxic exposure on servicemembers, their children and future generations. Nobody who serves this nation anticipates that their service will adversely impact the health of their family, yet far too often I hear from veterans who believe their exposure to a toxic substance during military service resulted in their children developing a health condition. It is positive news for our nation's veterans that the National Academies of Sciences concluded that more research is both necessary and feasible, and I will work to make certain these findings are acted upon by the Department of Veterans Affairs. 
Attending the Kansas Farm Bureau Annual Meeting On Sunday night in Manhattan, I attended the annual Kansas Farm Bureau (KFB) annual meeting, where KFB leaders from across the state come together to set the organization’s policies and goals for the coming year. This year is special, as it marks 100 years for KFB. Over the past century, KFB has played a crucial role in agriculture across Kansas and throughout the nation: KFB members display a commitment and dedication to preserving the way of life in rural Kansas and continue to be the leading voice of agriculture. I want to thank KFB President Rich Felts and Terry Holdren for inviting me to this year’s annual meeting to celebrate such a great milestone. 
At the banquet, I spoke about the importance of KFB to our state and to countless communities and organizations within it. In communities of all shapes and sizes, members of the KFB work tirelessly to support production agriculture, develop young men and women, contribute to their local economies, lead civic organizations and help give back to their neighbors and fellow community members. KFB has made an outstanding partner in my work, and our state is better off because of the many contributions of the organization.  
 ￼  

Honored to Serve You in Washington It is an honor to serve you in Washington, D.C. Thank you to the many Kansans who have been calling and writing in to share their thoughts and opinions on the issues our state and country face. I appreciate the words of Kansans, whether in the form of a form of letter, a Facebook comment or a phone call, who wish to make their voice heard.  
Please let me know how I can be of assistance. You can contact me by email by clicking here. You can also click here to contact me through one of my Kansas offices or my Washington, D.C., office.
Very truly yours, Jerry 
	1.	
My email address is only equipped to send messages. I encourage you to send me a message through my website: www.moran.senate.gov. To unsubscribe from this newsletter, please click here.
