￼
December 02, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
This week in Congress,I, along with Representatives Doug Collins (R-GA) and David Cicilline (D-R.I.), introduced H.R. 7190, the Small Business Reorganization Act (SBRA).
Helping Small Businesses Restructure Debt
H.R. 7190 will streamline existing bankruptcy procedures and provide new tools to increase a small business’ ability to achieve a successful restructuring. The Small Business Reorganization Act is a tremendous step forward in streamlining bankruptcy procedures. By reducing unnecessary procedural burdens, enhancing oversight, and increasing the debtors’ ability to negotiate; we will ensure quick and successful reorganization and provide small business’ the ability to restructure in a way that meets their needs. I thank my colleagues for their work on the introduction of this bill.
Tobyhanna Army Depot Sees Major Overhaul
I learned that Tobyhanna Army Depot unveiled its latest modernization project, bringing a state-of-the-art working environment to its 3700 employees and adding more than 200 full time jobs.
￼
Monday’s ribbon cutting ceremony at Tobyhanna’s upgraded 30,000 square-foot facility marked the completion of a project 3 years in the making. One of the Depot’s major additions includes a high-tech electronics maintenance enclosure to test equipment and increase readiness across the Department of Defense. Tobyhanna Army Dept is one of Monroe County’s largest employers and I am proud of the work that has been done to bring diverse career opportunities to the area. Tobyhanna’s revamped space will undoubtedly improve logistical support for our warfighters now and in the future.
Tobyhanna Army Depot is looking to fill those 200 new jobs before the end of December. To see what is available and apply, click here.
Take the Broadband Speed Test
The Center for Rural Pennsylvania and researchers at Penn State University are collaborating to measure actual broadband access in Pennsylvania to better determine service needs. By taking an online broadband speed test, residents across the commonwealth can help map the current prevalence of high-speed broadband services in the state.
The challenges in providing broadband access to rural America is cost. It simply does not make sense for companies to make expensive investments in broadband infrastructure that will serve a relatively small number of customers. In order to change the incentive structure, I introduced H.R. 6871, the Rural Broadband Connectivity Act to make broadband deployment more affordable and comprehensive. Paired with my bill, the data gathered by the Center and their research partners at Penn State will have a major impact on future policy discussions that can effectively bring broadband access to more rural Pennsylvanians.
To help map broadband access in Pennsylvania and learn more about your broadband connection, take the test here.
End of Insurance Period Information for Producers with Excess Moisture in Fields
Due to the frequency of rain and resulting flooding in Pennsylvania this year, I have been contacted by producers in PA-10 concerned if they will be able to get into their fields prior to the end of the insurance period on December 10.
￼
USDA’s Risk Management Agency (RMA) has a fact sheet as a reference for those producers suffering the effects of excess moisture. Along with this guide, growers are encouraged to reach out to their crop insurance agent for additional information on claims made for crop losses.
Funding Directed to Assist Pennsylvanians Affected by August Flooding
President Trump declared that a major disaster exists in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and has ordered Federal assistance to supplement recovery efforts by the Commonwealth and local agencies affected by severe storms and flooding from August 10 to August 15, 2018.
Under the public assistance program, Commonwealth and eligible governments and certain private nonprofit organizations requesting aid can receive up to 75% of costs incurred in emergency work and recovery efforts. Repair or replacement of facilities damaged by the severe storms and flooding in the counties of Bradford, Columbia, Lackawanna, Lycoming, Montour, Schuykill, Sullivan, Susquehanna, Tioga, and Wyoming are eligible for federal assistance.
I am grateful for President Trump’s decision to issue a disaster declaration for much of Pennsylvania as a result of the floods that struck our communities in August. This declaration is a critical step of the rebuilding process that will unlock a tremendous amount of federal resources to support recovery efforts.  I look forward to more details on these contributions towards the recovery efforts and stand ready to work with officials from the Commonwealth and local governments to get our area back on track after these destructive storms.
Music Modernization Act Award
What a pleasure it was to meet with the Recording Academy and receive the GRAMMYs on the Hill Award for being a champion of music in the 115th Congress.
￼
I proudly supported the Music Modernization Act, the biggest update to music legislation in nearly 4 decades. This bill updates several key provisions of U.S. copyright law regarding music licensing and protections for music creators nationwide. Thank you for this wonderful award!
As Always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA
￼Share on Facebook

Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.*

Thank you for subscribing to my eNewsletter and please remember to forward this to your friends!  This is a great way for me to communicate directly with you about what's going on in Washington, as well as providing you with exciting news from Pennsylvania's 10th District.  My Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube accounts are also excellent tools for you to share your thoughts with me and get up-to-the-minute news about what's happening.
As always, my staff and I are ready and willing to assist you.  If you would like to schedule a meeting, request a tour or flag, voice an opinion, or make a suggestion please contact my Washington, D.C. office.
If you need assistance working with a federal agency or applying for a grant please contact one of my Constituent Service Centers, located throughout the district.
I am here to serve you and represent your views, as a resident of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District.

Subject: Weekly Highlights
Message:
District Update | December 2, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friends,

This week in central Arkansas and Washington was informative and productive as I met with job creators, our brave heroes, future leaders at Springhill Elementary School in Greenbrier, and others. 

It is also with heavy hearts that Martha and I mourn the passing of a loyal friend, mentor, and faithful servant, President George H.W. Bush. We lift up the Bush family during this time of grieving and honor the remarkable life and legacy of a strong leader and diplomat, a great father, and an American patriot.

￼
In our early careers, Martha and I treasured working President George H.W. Bush on his campaigns and the humbling responsibility of serving on his White House staff. We were grateful for his daily example of goofy humor, courtesy, friendship, and passion for writing handwritten thank-you notes. Truly, President George H.W. Bush and Mrs. Bush were the ideal neighbors, members of the PTA, and the answer to the question on that common form at school or work, ‘in case of emergency, please call..." We loved him very much.

Sharing Personal Stories of President George H.W. Bush
￼
I joined Ana Cabrera on CNN Saturday night and shared personal stories of my interactions and experiences working with President George H.W. Bush. We mourn his death but celebrate his life. He was a man who possessed a volunteer spirit and that of service above self. Watch here. 

Visiting with Conway's Manufacturers 
￼
 I started off my week touring the Virco headquarters in Conway with Steve Presley, the Vice President and General Manager, and his leadership team. I had the chance to see how their 100 percent American made products were crafted before they are sent out to schools all over Arkansas and the country. We talked about how tariffs are impacting their facilities and how I can better help support our local manufacturers as their representative in Congress. 

Meeting with Future Leaders at Springhill Elementary
￼
On Monday, it was a joy to speak with Springhill Elementary School's third grade class about the job and responsibilities of Representatives in Congress. They recently finished their U.S. Government module and had a lot of questions for me ranging from what I do in my free time, my favorite presidents, and how I spend my days while I am in D.C. representing them. These Arkansas students from Greenbrier are an impressive group.  

Honoring our Veterans at the Nabholz Wall of Honor
￼
Top picture, left to right: Rep. Hill, Charles Nabholz (founder, Nabholz Properties), FR Anthony Robbins (St. Joseph's Parish), Greg Williams (CEO, Nabholz), and Brad Hegeman (COO, Nabholz). Bottom picture, left to right: Rep. Hill, Don Greenland (Strategic Growth Officer, Nabholz), Mark Berry (Adjutant General, Arkansas National Guard), and Charles Nabholz. 

It was an honor to attend the unveiling of the new Nabholz Corporation's Wall of Honor memorial. The wall displays the names of the veterans who have worked in their corporation since it was founded in 1949. Nabholz further demonstrated its strong support for our veterans by donating $10,000 to the REBOOT Alliance, which is dedicated to helping our heroes and first responders deal with the stress and challenges they might face following a traumatic event. 

Congratulations, Scott McLean
￼
Congratulations to my good friend and Arkansan, Scott McLean, for being honored with the Marie Interfaith Civic Leadership Award, which is given annually to recognize people whose work addresses community issues in Arkansas. Scott founded the re-entry ministry program called the Pathway to Freedom in 2011. This program's goal is to change prison culture, break the cycle of recidivism in Arkansas, and help ex-prisoners successfully adjust back into their communities. Watch here. 

Securing Our Borders
￼
On the Rio Grande River with U.S. Border Patrol Agents in Del Rio, Texas and with Val Verde County Sheriff Joe Frank Martinez along the Rio Grande River. 

Many of you have reached out with questions about the recent crisis on our Southwest border. I wanted to offer some additional background on this matter. After being briefed by Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and reviewing documents from the Mexican government, it’s my understanding that each migrant in the caravan was offered asylum and a job in Mexico, but they all declined. Here are some additional myths and facts to provide clarity. 

I'm actively engaged on this issue, and in May of this year, I visited the southern border for the fourth time and met with border patrol agents, state and local officials, including the Val Verde County judge and sheriff. I continue to build my understanding of the strategic challenges we face and what the House can do to deliver on our promise to better secure our borders and protect our families. 

America is a nation of immigrants. We are the most generous and welcoming country in the world and we want people to come here, but the right way.

Arkansans are Focused on the Economy
￼
Over the last four years, I have heard from central Arkansans like you who have told me that they're focused on the economy and results in Washington. On Friday, I talked to Tom Keene on Bloomberg TV about the importance of bipartisan success on immigration, health care reform that's affordable, and trade opportunities that allow our job creators on Main Street to thrive. If you would like to watch, see here.  
 
Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I'm doing on your behalf. If I can be of any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at (501) 324-5941 or Hill.House.Gov. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Representative French Hill

Subject: A couple quick things
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
My fight for those impacted by Hurricane Michael continued this week as my colleagues in the Georgia Delegation joined me in sending a bipartisan letter to Speaker Paul Ryan, Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, and the Chairman and Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee requesting legislative action by the December 7th government funding deadline to address damages to agriculture and our rural communities in Georgia impacted by Hurricane Michael.
Recent projections conducted by University of Georgia Cooperative Extension estimate the losses for Georgia’s agricultural industry caused by Hurricane Michael at $2.5 billion. This is the third consecutive year that Georgia’s farmers and communities have been hit by a hurricane, and it is imperative that farmers have assistance as soon as possible or we risk losing next year’s crop and severely impacting our agricultural-reliant communities and economies for years to come. 
You can click here to read our bipartisan letter, and please let us know if we can be of assistance to you or your family as you recover from this storm. 
  
PRESIDENT TRUMP SIGNS NEW NORTH AMERICAN TRADE DEAL 
On Friday, Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, President Donald Trump, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau signed the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) in Buenos Aires. 
President Trump promised to deliver a modernized North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) that would be better for America’s farmers, businesses, and workers. I’m hopeful that this newly announced agreement will do just that and look forward to carefully analyzing the details of the agreement with my colleagues.  
￼ 
Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, President Donald Trump, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sign the new U.S. Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA) in Buenos Aires Friday. 
  
MEETING WITH MEMBERS OF CANADA’S PARLIAMENT 
This past week, I sat down with Members of the Canadian Parliament to discuss a number of issues that impact both the U.S. and Canada, including ongoing trade negotiations, the health of the North American agriculture industry, and our defense cooperation. 
The United States and Canada share a very special relationship, and I am thankful for the opportunity to discuss the issues that impact us both and look for ways we can strengthen our partnerships even further. 
￼ 
Thank you to Ms. Tracey Ramsey, M.P., The Honorable Jim Munson, M.P., and The Honorable John McKay, P.C., M.P. for meeting with me. 
  

MEDICARE PART D OPEN ENROLLMENT ENDING DEC. 7 
Staff in our Tifton and Warner Robins district offices are currently accepting appointment requests to answer questions and to speak with constituents to discuss their Medicare Part D options during open enrollment, which runs through December 7, 2018. 
We encourage anyone already enrolled for Medicare Part D to call either our Tifton office at 229-396-5175 or Warner Robins office at 478-971-1776 for assistance or to schedule an appointment with a member of our staff.  We are happy to work with you individually to find the prescription drug plan that is best for your needs. 
To find out more about Medicare Part D, you may also contact the Medicare offices at 1-800-MEDICARE or visit http://www.MEDICARE.gov or contact GeorgiaCares at 1-866-552-4464 to find a plan that best suits your needs. 
￼ 
The only time to make changes to your plan is during open enrollment. 
  
PHOTO OF THE WEEK 
It is beginning to look a lot like Christmas in Washington, D.C. I wanted to share this image from the White House Christmas Tree Lighting this past week. 
This holiday season, I am thankful for the privilege to serve the people of Georgia's Eighth District and for the many blessings God has granted my family and our great country. 
 ￼ 
Official White House photo by Andrea Hanks 

HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Play by the rules
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends, 
 
As your Congressman, my responsibilities extend beyond our district and our borders. The United States and our allies face a growing list of threats from abroad – from Islamic extremism in the form of ISIS, to illegal immigration and drug trafficking along our southern border, to the aggressive actions of Russia across Eastern Europe and the Middle East. These threats to our way of life are real, as we’ve seen by the recent arrest of a dangerous MS-13 gang member who admitted to authorities that he traveled with the caravan of Central American migrants trying to qualify for asylum in our country.
 
The threats to our security continue to grow in scope and scale. That’s why I’ve made national security a top priority and why I serve as Vice-Chair of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly’s Ad Hoc Committee on Countering Terrorism. This is a critical leadership position on the OSCE, the world’s largest regional security organization.
 
￼
Representing the U.S. at an international gathering of parliamentarians. 
 
As part of my responsibilities, I’m hosting the Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee on Countering Terrorism – a member of the Greek Parliament – for a series of meetings, briefings and discussions with representatives from the United Nations, the National Counterterrorism Center, and other security-related agencies this week. We will discuss where OSCE participating States converge and diverge on policies to counter terrorism and violent extremism, as well as the state of transatlantic counterterrorism cooperation.
 
In addition, I continue to be a strong and vocal critic of Russian aggression on the world stage. I have repeatedly condemned Moscow’s actions against Ukraine, and I have supported increased pressure and sanctions. That’s why I wrote a letter to President Donald Trump last week supporting his strong leadership regarding the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty and Russian aggression. Russia has broken the treaty, and the Trump Administration has been very clear that Russian noncompliance with the INF Treaty poses a grave threat to the security of our nation as Russia has shown an unwillingness to come back into compliance.
 
Earlier last week, Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats said, “The intelligence community assesses Russia has flight tested, produced and deployed cruise missiles with a range capability that are prohibited by the treaty. Russia has shown no sign that it is willing to acknowledge its violation, let alone return to full and verifiable compliance.”
 
The INF Treaty isn’t a one-way street, and we need to make it crystal clear that the United States will not tolerate Moscow’s brazen violations. We must show the United States remains committed to the reduction and prevention of the use of nuclear arms while condemning Russian violations in the strongest way possible in front of the international community. 
 
We cannot continue to allow our nation to be in a situation where we are bound by a treaty to which we are the only nation complying. I fully support the president’s leadership on this issue – to build a safer world, we have to play by the same rules.
 
 
Until next week,
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress (NC-08)

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
December 2, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


Honoring the Life of President George H.W. Bush



President George Herbert Walker Bush was a patriot who dedicated his life to serving our nation. Beginning in his teens when he enlisted as a Naval Aviator during World War II, service that led him to being shot down over the Pacific, he always put country first. During his time as Vice President and later President, he was an impressive world leader advancing our values abroad and helping end the Cold War. Personally, I will never forget gathering a group of friends to go see President Bush at a campaign rally in my hometown of Gastonia during his 1992 reelection campaign.

Beyond his service to our country, President Bush was a tremendous father and role model for all Americans. Alongside his beloved wife Barbara, he raised a wonderful family and throughout his political career, President Bush led with such decency, always treating political allies and rivals with the same level of respect. Giulia and I join the rest of a grateful nation in praying for the entire Bush family as they mourn the passing of a true statesman.

￼





My New Role in the 116th Congress



I am honored to have been elected to be the Republican leader of the House Financial Services Committee for the 116th Congress. I look forward to working with my colleagues—both Democrat and Republicans alike—as we continue to help families and small business right here in the Tenth District and all across the country. You can read my full statement by clicking here or on the image below.

￼

A couple of weeks ago I joined Bloomberg to discuss my candidacy to be the Ranking Republican on the House Financial Services Committee. There I had the opportunity to discuss what I hoped to achieve as Ranking Member during the 116th Congress and the importance of focusing on the families and communities that are impacted by financial services legislation. In addition, I shared my thoughts on a recent hearing with Fed Vice Chairman Randal Quarles on stress tests for banks and the need for new technologies to help banks address the challenges they are facing today. Click here or on the image below to watch the full interview. 

￼





America is Better Off



As we approach the end of the 115th Congress, it is a good time to reflect on the many positive things we have accomplished so far. Last December, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act became law, helping American families keep more of their hard-earned paychecks. Congress has also invested over $10 billion to address the opioid epidemic that has devastated our communities. Legislation has also been passed to help make our country safer and our communities stronger, including giving our troops their biggest pay raise since 2010. Click here or on the image below to learn more about why Americans are better off now. 

￼





What I Have Been Reading



3 US service members killed in Afghanistan roadside bomb blast; deadliest incident this year

Fox News 

Please join me in praying for the family and loved ones of the three American servicemen killed in Afghanistan earlier this week. Their service and sacrifice to this great country will never be forgotten. Every day I am thankful for the brave men and women of the U.S. military who put their lives on the line to defend our freedoms. 


Shelby to create Fallen Heroes Memorial, park

Shelby Star 

Our heroes deserve to be remembered for their service to their communities and to our country. Downtown Shelby is creating a Fallen Warriors Memorial that will honor local heroes like Shelby Police Officer Tim Brackeen who was killed in the line of duty two years ago. You can watch my tribute to Officer Brackeen that I delivered on the House Floor by clicking here.  


New nonprofit devoted to serving veterans

Lincoln Times-News 

Our nation's veterans have already done so much in their service to our country and yet many continue to serve their communities after their time in the military has ended. Local veterans Chris Duschel and Larry Cline are continuing to serve with their new nonprofit, the Veterans and Community Alliance, that helps repair vehicles for veterans and their families at little to no cost. I am thankful for the service of these two heroes first in our armed forces and now in the Tenth District community.

￼

Subject: FEMA Deadline Approaching
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
FEMA Update: Deadline This Week
 
 
The FEMA deadline to apply for disaster assistance for damage and losses from Hurricane Florence is this coming Wednesday, December 5th. You won't know if you are eligible for funds unless you apply, so I encourage you to do so! Please share this information with anyone you think may need assistance.
If you have questions, please visit the Hurricane Florence Disaster Page at www.fema.gov/disaster/4394 to find answers about FEMA assistance including: understanding your FEMA determination letter, the importance of returning your U.S. Small Business Administration disaster loan application and how to file an appeal.
 

￼
 
 
Promises Kept 
 
 
On Friday, President Trump signed the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement at the G20 Summit. The USMCA signing is another step toward a trilateral agreement that will open new export markets and provide much needed certainty to American businesses, farmers, and workers. I will continue to work with the Administration and my colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee to pursue trade deals that include South Carolina's priorities and strengthen our economy.
Read More » 
 

 
The Care They Deserve
 
 
Ensuring our veterans receive the care they deserve is one of my top priorities in Congress. Horry County has the second largest veteran population in South Carolina, so learning that the Horry VA is taking steps to improve their services is great news! They just implemented electronic claim filing and a more efficient appointment system. My office is dedicated to helping veterans in the Seventh District with any problems they may be having with the VA. If you are a veteran and need assistance, please don't hesitate to reach out to one of my offices! 

Read More »
 

￼
 
 
Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
 
 
We are experiencing an economic boom in South Carolina and this week we received more good news! B&B Crane Service is opening up shop in Loris and Conway, creating 48 new jobs through a $10 million capital investment! As the newest addition to our business community, B&B Crane will create new opportunities that will further grow and diversify our economy.  Read More »
 

 
Interested in Interning?
 
 
I have three offices to serve the people of the Grand Strand and Pee Dee. In Washington, D.C., my staff handles legislative issues like introducing bills and committee work. In my Myrtle Beach and Florence offices, my staff handles constituent casework like helping veterans process their claims at the VA or solving problems with Social Security. At both locations, interns are a valuable part of the team and help the office run smoothly.
Internships are open to any college or higher education student. If you or someone you know would be a good candidate for one of my internships, please see here for more information and to apply. We accept interns on a rolling basis for the spring, summer, and fall semesters.
 

￼
 Have a great week,
￼

Tom Rice

Subject: Recognizing National Bible Week
Message:
Babin Bulletin | December 2, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Recognizing National Bible Week
Last week, America celebrated the 77th annual National Bible Week. God’s word means everything to me. It has shaped the way that I live my life, and has helped me serve the people of the 36th Congressional District of Texas through two terms. Each year on the week of Thanksgiving we give thanks for the many blessings God has bestowed on each of our lives, but none shine more brightly than the book that has continued to weather the test of time and lead Christians for centuries. I feel privileged I could speak on the House floor on Wednesday about how much the Bible means to me.
￼
To watch my floor speech, please click here.
Congratulating NASA on Mars InSight Landing
Congratulations to the NASA Mars InSight Team for successfully completing the incredible challenge of landing on Mars! After traveling 300 million miles over the past six and a half months, this NASA robotic lander (Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport, or “InSight”) will explore Mars’ crust, mantle and core. This is a giant step forward in our preparations to reach the goal of eventually landing humans on the Red Planet. Outstanding job!
￼
To read article, please click here.
Illegal Immigrants, Not Asylum Seekers
Economic migrants from Central America are abusing U.S. humanitarian laws, including our asylum policy. Many migrants are passing through safe areas of Mexico – where they have been offered asylum – to the U.S., where they can achieve their true goal of earning up to 12 times more than in Central America. We need constructive debate in Congress on how we can improve our humanitarian and immigration laws to truly aid those we can while keeping the interests of American citizens paramount.

“[w]hile they are often referred to as asylum-seekers, few of the migrants from Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador — the chief sending countries — are likely to end up winning asylum in the U.S., according to the study… Adults are most likely to come for better jobs, the researchers said. They can improve their incomes by 1,200 percent in moving from Central America to the U.S… [f]ew people who leave their home country … will move to Mexico because the average wage increase is only 10 percent.”
￼
To read article, please click here.

￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Homeowner Assistance Program
Is your home still in need of repairs from Hurricane Harvey? If so, the Homeowner Assistance Program is now accepting applications. This program was designed by the State of Texas to assist those eligible in reconstructing their homes after Harvey. 

For more information, please click here or call one of my district offices.
Meeting with Secretary Azar
I had a great meeting with Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar on Thursday to discuss a strategy to lower drug prices for consumers. 
￼
Being a member of the GOP Doctors Caucus provides a unique opportunity for me to work with fellow medical professionals to develop patient-centered health care policy that will improve the lives of the American people.
￼
Photos of the Week
I was happy to show Judge Jacques and Leeza Blanchette (pictured below on left) as well as Judge Monte and Betty Lawlis (pictured below on right) around the U.S. Capitol this week. Judge Blanchette is the current county judge for Tyler County, which is my home county, and Judge Lawlis served as Tyler County's state district judge for many years. These good men serve their communities well, and it was a pleasure to visit with them and their wives while they were in town. 
￼
The Kent Family (pictured below on left) and Dow Family (pictured below on right) from Houston were also in town this week. It is always great meeting folks from home, and I am glad my staff were able to secure several tours for them while they were in Washington. 
￼

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
Friends,
In 1992, President George H.W. Bush came to Lake County fairgrounds on a campaign trip. As he was waiting in line to get his breakfast I asked if he would hold our son for a picture. He said "sure" and put down his plate and took our son in his arms. As Kelly was capturing the perfect picture, President Bush gently kissed Trenton on the forehead. A couple years later I had the pleasure of running into him again at a then Governor Voinovich birthday party. I asked if he could sign the photo. He said "sure" again. As he looked at the photo he laughed and recalled that I had used the photo in an ad for our campaign. 
No one had been better trained to be President. He had been a decorated Navy pilot, businessman, Congressman, Ambassador to the United Nations, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, United States Envoy to China, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency and Vice President, under Ronald Reagan. Most importantly, he was always himself. History will be kind to this respected elder statesman. 
￼
Last Saturday was Small Business Saturday - a day dedicated to supporting small businesses and all they do for our communities. I encourage all Buckeyes to continue to support our economy in Northeast Ohio by shopping locally this holiday season. 
￼
Since being elected to Congress, small business job creation and economic growth have been top priorities of mine. Small businesses employ millions of Ohioans and are a very important part of our workforce. I am always glad to visit small businesses in Northeast Ohio to chat with owners and workers about their goals, ideas and concerns and also about how we can continue economic growth in Ohio.
Small Business Success in Northeast Ohio
I recently toured Godfrey & Wing in Aurora, an industry leader for automotive, aerospace and industrial manufacturing in Northeast Ohio. Congress' pro-growth agenda helped Godfrey & Wing have the ability to purchase new equipment and renovate their offices. 
￼
Another local business which is a fast growing startup in our district is Chagrin Valley Soap & Salve in Solon. I always enjoy visiting this family owned business to see the production of USDA certified organic skin and hair care products. What started as one woman's hobby turned into a company that now ships products to every state in the U.S. and over 80 countries worldwide. It's wonderful to see this local company thriving. 
￼
Earlier this year, I had the opportunity to tour Ohio Industrial Sales in Twinsburg. Thanks to Congress' commitment to small businesses, Ohio Industrial Sales was able to give their employees holiday bonuses for the first time in their company's history. The company was overjoyed that they were able to reward their hardworking employees with well deserved bonuses. 
￼
I wholeheartedly believe America's small businesses and startups are the engines of job creation. I am pleased to share that two bipartisan, bicameral bills were recently signed into law which help startups succeed across America. After hearing from local small business advocacy groups and entrepreneurs, I joined my colleagues in supporting the Small Business 7(a) Lending Oversight Reform Act. This bipartisan measure ensures appropriate oversight of the Small Business Administration's (SBA) flagship loan program and improves access to capital for small business owners. In addition, the Small Business Investment Opportunity Act allows privately owned and management investment funds to invest in small businesses. Together, these measures ensure that small businesses and startups can secure affordable financing. 
We all know that government regulations and red tape can sometimes hinder small business growth, which is why I supported the JOBS and Investor Confidence Act of 2018, known as "JOBS Act 3.0." By a near unanimous vote of 406-4, my colleagues and I passed this common sense legislation to cut down on regulations that are holding back small businesses. This measure will help sustain 3% economic growth and ensure our hardworking small business owners in Northeast Ohio can compete in the global marketplace. 
￼
According to a recent National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Monthly Optimism Index, small business sentiment has reached incredible heights. The study conducted in August set a new record in the survey's 45-year history. I am proud of the pro-growth policies my colleagues and I have implemented to create this level of optimism. I will continue to work with local stakeholders, my friends across the aisle and SBA Administrator Linda McMahon to promote small business priorities in the 116th Congress. 
Dave

Subject: Defending our Border
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Sunday, December 2, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
Defending our Border
 
 
This week, we saw members of the migrant caravan rush our border, assault our Border Patrol agents, and attempt to illegally enter our country by breaking through the existing barricades. This behavior was completely predictable as the caravan has already violently entered other countries .   There are 8,500 members in the moving caravan and we have confirmed there are at least 600 convicted criminals traveling among the group. These criminals have been identified by law enforcement and have a know history of assault, battery, drug crimes, burglary, rape, child abuse and more.   I believe our President made the right decision by deploying troops to the southern border. The United States will not apologize for defending our borders against those who are assaulting our law enforcement agents, and also those who wish to circumvent our laws to enter the country illegally. I applaud our brave men and women currently at the border working to ensure we keep Americans safe and uphold our rule of law.   In Congress, I have supported multiple bills that work to secure our borders. As the Vice Chair of the Homeland Security Subcommittee on Appropriations, I have supported $5 billion in funding for the border wall. Additionally, I have supported legislation that eliminates the visa lottery, revises our annual immigration levels, mandates e-verify, ends catch and release, and closes the loopholes hurting our immigration system.   Border security is national security, and we must set politics aside when discussing the safety and security of our country. Secure the border, enforce the law.  
￼
  Mars Landing  It was a big week for NASA as they successfully landed the InSight Lander on the surface of Mars. InSight will remain stationary during the planned two-year mission and will collect data by capturing photos, allowing us to learn about the inside of Mars for the very first time.   President Trump's Administration has renewed its support for American space exploration and development and we are seeing major accomplishments from the hardworking men and women at NASA. As the former Chairman of the Space Subcommittee for five years, I understand the importance of America leading the rest of the world in space exploration.   National Cotton Council  This week, I had a productive meeting with members of the National Cotton Council. In our meeting, we covered many topics including the Farm Bill as well as supplemental assistance in response to the recent disasters that have made significant impacts on the cotton industry. 
￼

In your service,
￼
Steven
  ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: This Week in Washington
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Keeping in Touch with You
I could not be an effective representative without hearing directly from Pennsylvanians about the issues that matter most to them and their families. As part of my longstanding effort to do just that, more than 7,500 constituents joined me for my 56th telephone town hall this week. During the town hall I answered questions from callers about everything from commonsense gun safety legislation to the administration's steel and aluminum tariffs.
I've done nearly 80 town halls across Pennsylvania since being elected to the Senate - in person, on social media, and over the phone. Telephone town halls are an especially helpful way to keep in touch with constituents when I am in Washington.
I appreciate every opportunity I get to hear directly from you, answer questions, and share my perspective on some of the most important issues of the day. I look forward to hosting more forums like this in the future. You can also follow me on Facebook and Twitter where I provide advanced notice of upcoming town hall events.
Read more about my telephone town hall in the Sentinel.
￼
￼
Remembering Air Force Staff Sergeant Dylan Elchin
It is with heavy hearts we learned this week that Air Force Staff Sergeant Dylan Elchin of Hookstown, Beaver County was killed while serving our country in Afghanistan. He was a Special Tactics combat controller with the 26th Special Tactics Squadron, and was deployed in support of Operation Freedom's Sentinel.
Those who served alongside Dylan recall his leadership in combat and dedication to the mission. He was a decorated airman having received the Bronze Star and Purple Heart, and was a Distinguished Graduate of Airman Leadership School. Simply put, Dylan is a Pennsylvania hero. Kris and I mourn his loss, and are praying for his family in this difficult time. His sacrifice will not be forgotten.
You can see a full list of Dylan's awards and decorations, and read more about him, here.
￼
￼
Protecting PA Jobs from the Administration's Misguided Protectionism
Over the past two years, congressional Republicans and the Trump administration have placed an emphasis on growing our economy - and the results speak for themselves. The historic tax reform and elimination of numerous burdensome regulations are encouraging businesses to invest and expand. We have an overwhelming demand for workers to fill open jobs, and wages are on the upswing. This is the strongest our economy has been in decades.
Unfortunately, I am worried that current trade policies being pursued by the administration could stunt the progress our economy is making, which is why I am doing all I can to reassert Congress's constitutional role on trade. Over the past week, I continued to help employers and workers burdened by the administration's tariffs on imported aluminum and steel, and goods from China. In the case of steel and aluminum imports, the Department of Commerce has a sizable backlog of tariff exclusion applications from businesses that maintain they cannot obtain essential products from domestic sources. Applying businesses deserve a swift answer on their application. In order to get to the root cause of these delays, I have joined with two of my Democratic colleagues, Senators Doug Jones of Alabama and Tom Carper of Delaware, to ask the government's auditor's to review Commerce's operations on this matter.
President Trump has also established three different sets of tariffs on Chinese goods. For the first two sets of tariffs, the office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) developed a process for qualified importers to get tariff exemptions. Currently, there is no exclusion process for this third set of tariffs. This is unfair to companies that cannot obtain essential goods domestically. As such, I authored a letter requesting the USTR to develop an additional exclusion process. I was pleased that more than 30 other senators, from both sides of the aisle, co-signed my letter.
Finally, for the past few months, I have noted my concerns with the President's United States Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA), which is meant to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). For free traders like me, the USMCA is a mixed bag of trade-enhancing and trade-restricting changes to NAFTA. Unfortunately, the benefits of these enhancements are more than offset by the trade-limiting provisions. I have implored President Trump to work to incorporate free trade ideas into the USMCA's implementing legislation and then work with congressional Republicans to pass it before the end of this year.
Allowing the USMCA to fall into next year puts its implementation into the hands of a Democrat-controlled House of Representatives. This will result in either a decidedly more protectionist USMCA or it could be stalled entirely. You can read more about my thoughts on this topic in a column I wrote for the Wall Street Journal here.
￼
￼
Reevaluating Our Relationship with Saudi Arabia
As a great nation, we are challenged to maintain both our security and our values. Sometimes, our national security interests require us to work with regimes, like that of Saudi Arabia, that do not share our values and our views on human rights. This does not mean we can ignore atrocities committed by the governments of our allies.
This week's procedural vote to discharge the Yemen War Powers Resolution from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee will rightfully prompt further conversation on the murder of Jamal Khashoggi and our relationship with Saudi Arabia. However, it also affords the Senate an opportunity to have a broader debate concerning the appropriate balance between our values and maintaining our national security-based relationships.

￼
￼
Standing Up Against Russian Aggression
Vladimir Putin is a lawless autocrat who has no respect for the rights of his own people, let alone international laws and standards. On Sunday, Russian naval vessels unlawfully attacked three Ukrainian ships near the Kerch Strait in the Sea of Azov. During the confrontation, one Ukrainian ship was damaged, two were captured, and numerous Ukrainian sailors were injured.  
I joined a bipartisan group of my colleagues this week to condemn this violation of Ukraine's sovereignty, and backed a measure demanding the release of all Ukrainian sailors taken prisoner by Russia.
As a member of the Senate Ukraine Caucus, I have long condemned Russian aggression and supported Ukrainian sovereignty dating back to the Russian Aggression Prevention Act of 2014, which was introduced shortly after Russia illegally invaded Crimea. Since then, I've backed efforts to provide arms to Ukraine while supporting sanctions against Russia.
This week's blatant actions in the Kerch Strait are unacceptable and I stand ready to work with my colleagues and the president to assist our Ukrainian allies and punish Russian aggression.

Subject: Flood Insurance, Educational Benefits for Veterans and Remembering a Patriot
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
December 2, 2018
Dear Friend,  
Last week was extremely busy as we continued our efforts to address all of the pressing legislative matters that require attention before the end of the year.  Chief among those priorities for our district is ensuring the continued availability of affordable flood insurance.  The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was set to expire at the end of November.  We passed an emergency measure to extend it for one more week, and the Senate also passed a bill to extend it until May of 2019. Many of my constituents rely on this program. The availability of flood insurance is critical to our local economy and the stability of our housing market. In 2017, the House passed a bill to reform and reauthorize this vital program for a full five years. Unfortunately, the Senate has not passed a long-term bill, forcing Congress to pass a series of short term extensions, which is simply unacceptable. I urge my Senate colleagues to prioritize this important issue and expedite passage of legislation to reauthorize the program for the next five years.  The extension until next week aligns this program with the upcoming deadline for passing funding for continued operation of the federal government.  I will continue to work on resolving both of these important issues over the next few days.   
Sadly, our nation lost a true public servant and the Bilirakis family lost a long-time friend this weekend. All those who were privileged to know him, understood that George H.W. Bush was a man of unwavering love of country and unapologetic commitment to his family. His impressive career includes decorated service in WWII, leadership in the intelligence community, and a steady hand as Commander in Chief during tumultuous political and economic times which culminated in the end of the Cold War and led to the first Persian Gulf War. Later in life, he worked tirelessly in a bipartisan fashion to raise money for domestic and international humanitarian aid. My thoughts and prayers are with his family as they celebrate his legacy of service, patriotism and generosity. May his memory be eternal!
￼ 
Continue reading for a brief recap of my efforts on your behalf last week! 
Advocating for Our Nation’s Heroes 
There has been a great deal of attention paid to the problems the VA is having with delayed GI bill payments to Veterans.  As I mentioned in last week’s newsletter, we have held oversight hearings, and are working to hold the VA accountable for this unacceptable situation while ensuring that every Veteran receives the benefits to which he/she is entitled.  Despite news reports that the VA would not be retroactively repaying Veterans, Secretary Wilkie issued a statement last week confirming that all Veterans will be fully compensated. Please be assured that I will continue to monitor this situation into it is resolved.   
￼ 
Facilitating Continued Economic Success 
New reports show that U.S. consumer spending and personal incomes continued to rise last month, which is yet another indication that our economy is headed in the right direction.  It is more important than ever that we continue to reduce the tax burden on the middle class and on small businesses, so that our economy continues to work for everyone!
Part of ensuring continued economic success is investing in critical infrastructure needed to sustain economic prosperity.  Florida has been ranked as the best state for broadband deployment by a newly released RStreet report. This shows how our state will lead the development of next generation Internet services which will bring additional jobs, revenue, and amenities to our area. As a member of the Communications and Technology Subcommittee, I have worked to increase broadband availability and affordability and am proud of our state’s leadership of America’s technological future.
￼ 
Promoting Good Public Health Policy 
Last week, I was happy to vote for final passage of the Action for Dental Health Act of 2018, which I co-sponsored. This important bill improves oral health education and dental disease prevention while reducing the use of the emergency room to treat dental pain. Oral health is a vital component of overall wellness. This bill, which is now headed to the President’s desk to become law, is a step in the right direction.
￼  
Last week, I was also proud to vote in favor of HR 6753, the Strengthening Healthcare Fraud Prevention Task Force, which passed the House. Earlier this year, a related measure I authored became law. My provision enhanced the civil and criminal penalties for Medicare and Medicaid fraud. With all stakeholders working together to reduce fraud, we can help ensure the long-term sustainability of these critical programs.
 ￼ 
Additionally, each November we recognize Diabetes Awareness month.  In addition to negatively impacting the personal health of the more than 100 million Americans who suffer with Diabetes, it is a condition that significantly increases overall costs to the healthcare system.  Prevention, education and proper management are essential in reversing this troubling public health concern.  Visit  www.diabetes.org to learn more. 
￼ 
Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Gus Bilirakis

Subject: A Big Step in the Continued Fight Against Opioid Addiction
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A message from Congressman Scott Tipton
￼

Contact Me
#CUTtheCODE
￼
￼
￼

About Me
Media Center
Serving You
Legislation
Contact Me


Hi, 
In 2016 and 2017, the Department of Health and Human Services estimated that more than 130 Americans died each day from an opioid-related drug overdose. Today, opioid overdoses are the leading cause of accidental death in the United States. 
The fight against the opioid epidemic has received strong bipartisan support in Washington. In 2016, Congress passed and President Obama signed into law the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act (CARA) and 21st Century Cures Act, both of which helped provide states with resources to expand opioid abuse and treatment efforts. In fact, since the 21st Century Cures Act became law, Colorado has received over $15 million in grant money to help meet the needs of our impacted communities. 
After CARA and the 21st Century Cures Act were signed into law, I continued to travel across Colorado’s Third District to meet with the healthcare officials, law enforcement officers and first responders who are on the front lines of this fight and listen to their feedback. During these meetings it became apparent that while both bills were certainly a step in the right direction, there was more work to be done.
The opioid crisis is a multifaceted issue, and no one approach will bring it to an end. We must advance policies that facilitate prevention education and effective treatment, ensure law enforcement has the tools it needs to respond to bad actors trying to bring dangerous opioids across U.S. borders, and support health care professionals in their work to decrease prescribed addiction. During the 115th Congress, we worked together to introduce a series of proposals to address opioid abuse from every angle.  
This past month, Congress passed, and President Trump signed into law a sweeping bipartisan package that includes more than 70 of the proposals that we introduced this Congress. The proposals included in the law, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, range from arming first responders with the overdose-reversing drug naloxone and providing law enforcement with more tools to help intercept deadly synthetic opioids at the border, to expanding Medicare coverage of substance abuse disorder treatments and services. 
Included in this groundbreaking package was a proposal that I helped introduce called the Alternatives to Opioids (ALTO) in the Emergency Department Act, which specifically addresses the complex issue of prescribed addiction. While there are many different reasons why an individual may become addicted to opioids, all too often, addiction begins with an injury and a prescription to treat the pain. The ALTO Act will help remedy this issue by providing hospitals across the country with the resources to promote non-opioid pain treatments in emergency rooms. 
The ALTO Act is based on a successful pilot program that was started by the Colorado Hospital Association and took place in 10 hospital emergency departments across our state. The program was so effective that the 10 participating sites were able to reduce the distribution of prescribed opioids by 36 percent over a six-month period. Now that this program will be replicated in hospital emergency departments across the nation, the impact will be profound.
I am proud of the work that has been accomplished thus far to confront opioid addiction. The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act is a big step and I have no doubt that this package of bills will help save countless lives. However, the opioid crisis cannot be solved overnight, and the work is still far from done. In the 116th Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike must continue to listen to the impacted families, healthcare providers and law enforcement officials back home and work together to address this national crisis.  
I plan to continue these conversations back in Colorado’s Third District and I encourage you to share any ideas, background or knowledge that you may have on this issue with us by calling my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-4761 or writing to me at www.tipton.house.gov. 
Sincerely, 
￼

Subject: Bucshon Bulletin
Message:
￼ ￼ 
News from Representative Bucshon 
￼ 
MEET LARRY     CONTACT     SERVING YOU     MEDIA     LEGISLATION     INDIANA'S 8TH 
Fellow Hoosier,
Thanks for tuning into this month’s edition of the Bucshon Bulletin. Continue reading to learn about the work I’m doing in Congress to address the issues that matter to Hoosiers, such as legislation I’ve supported to combat the opioid crisis and improve our national water infrastructure. 
Supporting Our Troops Abroad
Last week I had the opportunity to travel to Afghanistan as part of a bipartisan Congressional delegation to meet Afghan government officials and American troops stationed there. 
One of the most important duties of Congress is to ensure our troops around the world have the necessary tools and resources they need to get the job done. It’s one thing to attend briefings and classified updates in Washington on our operations and efforts to ensure peace around the world, but it is quite another to see it first-hand and hear from commanders and troops on the ground.
During my trip to Afghanistan, I saw the direct result of our increased funding for troops and supplies. It has had a positive impact. From the commanders of the NATO-led Resolute Support mission, down the chain of command, our men and women in uniform are the best trained fighting force in the world and I am honored to have met with them and been reassured that they have the personnel, training and equipment necessary to accomplish their mission. While the threat of terrorism remains constant, so will our efforts to defend against it. 

￼
Fighting the Opioid Epidemic
President Trump signed the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6) on October 24. This important legislation included my bill, the Opioid Screening and Chronic Pain Management Alternatives for Seniors Act in Section 2002 of the bill.
The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act will help our struggling communities to combat the opioid crisis by focusing on improving care for those who have opioid use disorder, and preventing opioid misuse and addiction. This comprehensive legislation, negotiated and agreed upon by both chambers in a bipartisan manner, will help states like Indiana combat the growing opioid epidemic. It will give hope to families and it will save lives.
As a physician, I believe it is vital to support initiatives that will help to prevent seniors from misusing or becoming addicted to opioids while managing their chronic pain. One of the ways to address the opioid crisis is to prevent Americans from becoming addicted in the first place. By screening seniors as they enter the Medicare system, we can use this milestone as an opportunity to address their concerns and manage their chronic pain while reducing risks associated with opioid use. As opioid use disorder continues to increase among older Americans, our seniors need to understand the risks of opioid use and discuss with their physicians the best course of treatment. 

￼
Improving Hoosier Waterways
President Trump signed the America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018 (S.3021) on October 23, 2018. This important legislation included my bill, Promoting Hydropower Development at Existing Nonpowered Dams Act in Section 3003 of the bill. 
Our water infrastructure is vital to the economic success and prosperity of our nation. This is especially true for Southwest Indiana which is bordered by two major rivers, the Wabash and Ohio Rivers. The America’s Water Infrastructure Act makes important investments that will set in motion improvements to our ports, inland waterways, locks, dams, flood protection, and other critical water infrastructure.
The Promoting Hydropower Development at Existing Nonpowered Dams Act cuts through the red tape and instructs the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to create an expedited permitting process that will result in a final decision on an application in two years or less. Hydropower provides benefits in the form of jobs, economic investment, improved public health, and resource conservation. It’s also a great source of American-made energy. In the Eighth Congressional district alone, there are six non-powered dams that could be modernized to produce clean energy.
Video of my speech on the House Floor in support of this legislation can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GU6YfTVkA4Y  

￼
Improving Hoosier Infrastructure
On November 28, 2018, we took a step forward in breathing new life into the historic Harmony Way Bridge.  I was proud to support my bill, the Restore Harmony Way Bridge Act (H.R. 6793), when it passed through the House of Representatives by unanimous consent. This legislation would convey the Harmony Way Bridge to the New Harmony Bridge Bi-State Commission established by Indiana and Illinois - allowing the states to have management over the Harmony Way Bridge and write the next chapter for this historic bridge.
The Harmony Way Bridge was an engineering marvel that was built in 1930.  After decades of use, the bridge was closed in 2012 due to structural concerns.  Communities on both sides of the Wabash River in Indiana and Illinois want to see this historic community landmark preserved.  Unfortunately, the federal law that led to the bridge’s construction has also prevented it from being refurbished and reopened by the states of Indiana and Illinois.    More Photos from Afghanistan 
￼
￼
￼
￼
 
￼

￼
 

In service,
￼ 
Larry Bucshon, M.D. 
P.S. Make sure to visit my official Facebook Page and Twitter account to receive daily updates from my office. 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼

Subject: On Track
Message:
￼ 
  

ON TRACK

Great news! We have secured the federal funding necessary to keep the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project (SHEP) on track in 2019. 

Last week, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers released funding which includes $52.12 million in additional funds for SHEP. This funding, combined with President Trump's original budget request of $49 million, brings the total fiscal year 2019 federal funding for SHEP to more than $100 million. This will keep the critical economic development project on track. 

With this commitment, we are one step closer to realizing the full economic impact expanding our harbor will have on the nation and the world. 

I will continue fighting for this federal support to keep the project moving forward and on time until it becomes a reality. 

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CLXXXIX

Monday, November 26, 2018:  Today is academy day!  Each year a group of volunteers from the First District perform the task of interviewing candidates on my behalf for the service academies and make recommendations for placement.  This stellar group of volunteers is, by design, made up of individuals with and without military experience.  As we gather this morning at the National Museum of the Mighty Eighth Air Force in Pooler, I have the opportunity to welcome the students and family members and introduce them to our volunteer academy board before the interview process begins.  Next, I head to our Savannah office where I meet with a constituent regarding insurance coverage of medical formula. 
￼
Rep. Carter visiting the Savannah Center for Blind and Low Vision
Many parents of children with rare genetic diseases are faced with high medical costs and depend on insurance to help defray these costs.  Afterwards, I meet with a constituent who tragically lost her daughter a few years ago as a result of domestic violence and we discuss possible legislation that could strengthen our laws in this area.  Next, I head to the Savannah Center for Blind and Low Vision (SavannahCBLV) to learn more of the fine services this agency is providing to promote independence and dignity for people who are vision impaired or blind.  Serving counties in Southeast Georgia and Southern South Carolina, their services are offered in the home or in the center in Savannah.  After a great visit and tour of their facilities I head back to our Savannah office where I meet with my good friend, Dr. Jack Considine, to discuss an array of issues mainly focusing on health care.

Tuesday, November 27, 2018:  I’m up at 4:30 a.m. this morning and at the airport at 6:10 a.m. for a 7:10 a.m. direct flight to Washington.  Bleary eyed, I anxiously await to board my flight when I am informed that the flight has been delayed until 8:40 a.m.  After notifying my staff that I have been delayed and will not be able to deliver the keynote address to a national health care group having their annual meeting in Washington this morning, I am informed that the flight has now been delayed until 11:30 a.m.  Once again I contact my staff and they are able to book me on a different flight that gets me into Washington at 1:30 p.m.  Not only do I end up missing the keynote address but I also miss three other meetings that I had scheduled today.  Oh, the joys of relying on air carriers!  Once I’m finally at the Capitol, I meet with my Chief of Staff who, due to my absence, was earlier today tasked with picking our number for office assignment for the next session.  Fortunately (at least for him) he chose a good number and we will be relocating to an office closer to the House Chamber and near our committee meeting rooms. 
￼
Rep. Carter at the Fall Awards Banquet of the National Aeronautic Association
Next, I head to an Energy and Commerce (E&C) Committee member briefing on maternal mortality presented by the U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA).  The briefing is a synopsis of a 3-day summit that was held over the summer that brought together experts from around the U.S. and the world to discuss strategies in reducing maternal mortality.  Later, I attend a Whip Team meeting where we hear from Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen who updates us on the situation at the southwest border.  After our first vote series of the day, I head downtown where I attend the Fall Awards Banquet of the National Aeronautic Association and share in the excitement of witnessing my good friend, Mark Burns, President of Gulfstream Aerospace in Savannah, receiving the Wesley L. McDonald Distinguished Statesman of Aviation Award. 
￼
Rep. Carter and Mark Burns, President of Gulfstream Aerospace, at the Fall Awards Banquet of the National Aeronautic Association
This award honors Americans who have made significant contributions to aeronautics over an extended period of time as Mark has during his 35 year career with Gulfstream.

Wednesday, November 28, 2018:  This morning starts with our weekly GOP Conference and there is a lot to discuss this morning as we finish out the 115th Congress and continue to prepare for the 116th Congress.  Afterwards, I head back to my office where I film a video welcome to the Georgia Transit Association Meeting being held in Jekyll Island next weekend.  Afterwards, we have our weekly staff briefing where we have lots to discuss with the upcoming office move and trying to tie up loose ends legislatively during the lame duck session. 
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with the Georgia Farm Bureau Federation
Later, I meet with CIOX to discuss health information management services and Health and Human Services (HHS) electronic health record requirements.  Next, I meet with the American Consumers & Workers Justice Coalition (ACWJC) to discuss flooring products and the impact of tariffs on their business.  After meeting with members of the Georgia Farm Bureau Federation to learn more about the immense devastation the agriculture community experienced from Hurricane Michael and how we can help them with disaster relief, I meet with the Alliance for Patient Access, a non-profit that advocates for patient access to approved therapies and treatments. 
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with the Alliance for Patient Access
My last two meetings of the day are with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) and the Integrative Health Policy Consortium.

Thursday, November 29, 2018:  One of the joys of serving in Washington is making good friends and this morning I have the pleasure of meeting with one of my good friends, Tom Madson.  Tom has represented Gulfstream Aerospace in Washington for the past 20 years and before that served our country in the Air Force for 26 years. 
￼
Rep. Carter speaking at The Hill's New Member Reception
Tom will be retiring tomorrow from Gulfstream and I have the opportunity this morning to wish him well in this new chapter of his life.  Afterwards, I attend a Doctor’s Caucus meeting with the American Society of Clinical Oncologists before heading to a Steering Committee meeting where I am serving as a proxy for my Georgia colleague, Rep. Tom Graves (R-GA).  In the Republican Conference we have a steering committee that decides appointments and leadership positions on committees.  Tom is the Georgia/South Carolina representative on the Steering Committee but because he is applying for an appointment, he has asked me to be his proxy during his presentation.  This is my first experience on this committee and I find it to be fascinating.  Later, I head to my office where I meet with representatives from the West African country of Liberia and end my day at The Hill’s New Member reception downtown where I share with incoming members of the 116th Congress some of my experiences when I started four years ago.

Friday, November 30, 2018:  I’m at the White House this morning as I assist my Deputy Chief of Staff, Mary Carpenter, and her mother as well as Hunter Odom from Richmond Hill gain access for a tour.  Once back at the Capitol, I head to the 116th Organizing Conference of the GOP to ratify the recommendations of the Steering Committee.  Our first and only vote series of the day is afterwards and then I head to the airport for my return flight home.

Subject: Vt. Bernie Buzz: Update from Vermont
Message:
Click here to view this message in your browser. 

￼

Helping Vermonters Keep Warm

￼

As the weather gets colder and heating costs go up, some Vermonters will have a hard time keeping warm this winter. If you or someone you know is struggling to pay to heat their home, help may be available. Honestly, it is unconscionable that in the wealthiest country on earth, some Vermonters – including seniors and families with young children – have to choose between keeping their homes warm or putting food on the table. That’s why I am fighting in Washington to increase funding for the federal Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) rather than cut it like the president and his friends in Congress have proposed. 

Video



Our Dairy Farmers Deserve a Fair Price

￼

Vermont’s dairy farmers are struggling to survive. The price they get for their milk has been below the cost of production for four years in a row. Our state has lost one-third of its dairy farms in the last decade, and more than 65 this year alone. And, as farms disappear, so do the businesses and jobs they support. That’s why I have introduced legislation to provide emergency relief to our dairy farmers, and have urged the U.S. Department of Agriculture to increase its purchases of excess milk products. However, farmers need a long-term solution, and to my mind that has got to include managing the supply of milk. In recent weeks, my office has held listening sessions with dairy farmers in Addison and Franklin Counties to hear their ideas to ensure fair prices. 

Video
Read More



Fighting for Net Neutrality

I’m proud Vermont has taken steps to restore net neutrality after President Trump’s FCC chair, Ajit Pai, began dismantling important federal net neutrality rules on behalf of huge corporations like Verizon, Comcast and AT&T. Net neutrality simply means that Internet Service Providers cannot discriminate by halting, slowing, or otherwise tampering with the transfer of data and content. With the repeal of net neutrality, Internet Service Providers can divide the web into slow and fast lanes and restrict or charge more for certain content. Vermont has put in place measures to stop companies from auctioning off the internet to the highest corporate bidder. It is no wonder that these companies’ front groups are now suing the state. Now more than ever before, we need a free and open internet. 

Read More



State of the Union Essay Contest

￼

I am pleased to announce my ninth annual State of the Union essay contest, which gives Vermont’s high school students an opportunity to describe what they think are the major issues facing our country, and what they would do to solve those challenges. I always look forward to seeing what students chose to write about, and then joining the twenty finalists for a lively roundtable discussion at the Vermont Statehouse. I even submit the essays of the twenty finalists to the Congressional Record, the official archive of Congress. The deadline to submit an essay is January 9, 2019. I hope you consider writing one!

Read More



An Alarming Increase in Hate Crimes

We should all be very alarmed about the significant increase in hate crimes here in Vermont and throughout our country. It goes without saying that no one in America should fear for their safety because of their religious beliefs, race, immigration status, sexual orientation, gender identity or disability. Americans can disagree politically, but we should never resort to hate speech, much less violence. We must do everything possible to overcome the growing divisiveness and corrosion of political discourse in this country. It is destructive to our democracy. 

Read More



Fighting for Vermont’s Working Families 

￼ 

I recently visited Northern Counties Health Care’s Orleans Dental Center, the Head Start in Hardwick, the Lamoille Family Center in Morristown, and the Community Health Services of Lamoille Valley in Morrisville. Each of these facilities provide absolutely critical services in their community and without them, too many Vermonters – especially our young people – could fall through the cracks. These organizations were very clear about what their communities need: quality, affordable housing, child care and health care. To my mind, every Vermonter – and every person in this country – should be able to access these basic human needs. 

Read More

Subject: We Must Protect T-Band Spectrum Use for First Responders
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
December 02, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Eliot L. Engel - Proudly Serving the Bronx and Westchester
Website | Biography | Constituent Services | Press Releases | Photo Album

We Must Protect T-Band Spectrum Use 
for First Responders
Dear Friend:  
There is an issue of critical importance to the New York area that has flown under the radar for some time--the preservation of a life-saving first responder radio spectrum known as the T-Band.   For decades, the T-Band radio spectrum has supported vital public safety radio communications among our first responders. It allows police, firefighters and EMS to communicate even when cell towers, electricity, or the internet are down. It even functions deep underground in tunnels and inside concrete buildings. 
But now, thanks to an outdated provision in the law, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is required to reallocate and auction the T-Band spectrum for use by the private sector by 2021. This would endanger crucial public safety communications here in the Bronx and Westchester, as well as in major metropolitan areas across the United States.  It would also force police, firefighters, and EMS to spend millions to buy new radios and cause first responders to rely on untested systems.
I wrote a bill, the “Don’t Break Up the T-Band Act,” to allow law-enforcement, fire officials, and EMS to continue using the T-Band spectrum to operate their radios for day-to-day life saving operations.   My legislation has bipartisan support in the House, and is backed by law-enforcement and fire department officials from New York. It is my hope that with the start of the new Congress we will be able to move this critical bill forward and allow our first-responders to continue using the T-Band spectrum to communicate effectively when keeping us safe.
Sincerely, ￼ Eliot L. Engel MEMBER OF CONGRESS

Subject: Remembering a Commander in Chief
Message:

News from Representative Jeff Denham
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼



￼
 
DENHAM.HOUSE.GOV
ABOUT
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
ISSUES & LEGISLATION
NEWSROOM
CONTACT


December 1, 2018 
Dear friend,  Last night we learned that President George H.W. Bush passed away at the age of 94. As a member of the U.S. Air Force, I was proud to serve in the war of my generation under President George H.W. Bush. He was a thoughtful, kind and patriotic Commander in Chief. He put service before self and inspired many. He will be dearly missed.  Delivering on my promise to secure our water: Earlier this week I met with Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue, Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke and Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works Rickey "R.D." James, along with Reps. David Valadao (CA-21), Jim Costa (CA-16) and John Garamendi (CA-03), to announce a $449 million grant for the Sites Reservoir Project to bring more water storage to the Central Valley. This is a major victory for the Valley and will help to finally get this water storage project underway.  Over the past few months, I’ve brought Secretary Perdue, Secretary Zinke and Assistant Secretary James, in addition to Environmental Protection Agency Acting Administrator Andrew Wheeler, to the Central Valley and secured their support to fight for Central Valley water rights and improve our water storage. As a result, President Trump signed a presidential memorandum in October to address hydroelectric relicensing, like what is currently happening at Don Pedro, and require agencies to consider local plans, like the Tuolumne River Management Plan developed by Modesto and Turlock Irrigation Districts, to avoid catastrophic water grabs at the hands of Sacramento Bureaucrats.  Protecting our water and way of life has always been and continues to be my top priority. I will keep fighting for the Central Valley as the 115th Congress comes to a close.  Sincerely, 
￼  Jeff Denham Member of Congress
